name: Zhenghui, Upright Meeting (T 1010.01)
location: This point overlaps with Baihui (GV 20) , which is 5 cun directly above the midpoint of the anterior hairline or at the midpoint of the line connecting the apexes of the two ears. | Johnson: Upright Meeting is located on the center of the top of the head, in the same location as DU20 Bai Hui. Advice from Dr. Young: “Ask the patient to sit upright. Place a thread along the midline of the head from the tip of the nose to the nape of the neck. Place another thread from the tip of the ear apex across the head to the other ear apex. This point is located at the intersection of the two pieces of thread” (Dr. Young, 2008).
primary_indications: Post-stroke complications such as speech impairment
hemiplegia Interior or exterior wind-related syndrome: tremors
johnson_indications: Facial paralysis or tics (mouth and eye)*
Ball of the foot pain (use moxa)*
techniques: Needle forward, backward, or to the side 0.1 - 0.3 cun This point can also be bled | Johnson: Dao Ma: Upright Meeting (DU20) is often needled in combination with 1010.05 Anterior Meeting (DU21) and/or 1010.06 Posterior Meeting (DU19). Threading DU20.
comments: Not used with infants or children under the age of seven. (You must wait until the fontanels fuse.) Cautions: • In Tung’s acupuncture, this point is always bled and therefore is always safe as the puncture is shallow. Although acupuncture texts do allow 0.3-0.8mm needling of DU15, deeper needling may cause damage to the spinal cord. Please see needling notes below. • “Too deep insertion at this point can cause paralysis. In ancient China, if there was a crazy person running around naked menacing people with knives or clubs, three or four men might be necessary to catch such a person and hold them down. Then a thick iron needle like a shoemaker’s awl would be inserted at DU16 Feng Fu to intentionally paralyze the person. If the wound was not too deep, this paralysis was only temporary. But sometimes, because the mad person would be thrashing around, the needle would penetrate too deeply, and the person would be paralyzed for life” (Dr. Lee, 1992). • Though All Pivot may help with morning sickness, I never use it for this issue because it does not address the root of the problem, namely protein deficiency. See 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points for further information and dietary advice.
combinations: •  Anxiety or depression: Needling 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20) with 1010.08 Tranquility (Yin Tang) calms the spirit (shen) and sedates the mind. For anxiety or depression, Dr. Lee often added these two points to her Ten Great Needles Treatment. •  Tremors: 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), LV3/LI4 Four Gates. •  Calming the nervous system: 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), LV3/LI4 Four Gates. •  Calming the spirit: 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), 1010.08 Tranquility (Yin Tang). •  Unconsciousness or coma: Bleed the Jing-Well points or fingertips; needle 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), PC6 Nei Guan, DU26 Ren Zhong, KD1 Yong Quan, LV2 Xing Jian or LV3 Tai Chong needled toward KD1 Yong Quan. •  Wind and shaking diseases: 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows, 77.18 Shen Guan. An extensive write-up on the treatment of Parkinson’s disease can be found in 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows, Comments. •  Hemiplegia: 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31). See 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) for a complete write-up. •  Intellectual disability: 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), HT7 Shen Men, KD4 Da Zhong. •  Tailbone pain: Bilaterally needle 55.04-55.05 Flower Bone Three/Flower Bone Four; this is the best treatment, however, if it is not convenient, unilaterally or bilaterally needle 33.12 Heart Gate (males on the left, females on the right, or needle bilaterally if one side is not enough); needle 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), 1010.06 Posterior Meeting (DU19); bilaterally needle 66.01 Seal. •  Prolapse (anal, uterine, bladder): Moxa (either direct or with a stick or moxa pot) 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20) to warm and raise the yang. Depending upon the type of prolapse, other points are added.
reaction_areas: Brain, Spine Eyes, Lung Horse Gold Water: Kidney, Lung Horse Fast Water: Urinary Bladder, Kidney Kidney, Six Bowels

name: Zhouyuan, State Round (T 1010.02)
location: This point is near the BL channel, 1.3 cun lateral to Baihui (GV 20) on both left and right sides. Baihui (GV 20) is 5 cun directly above the midpoint of the anterior hairline or in the midpoint of the line connecting the apexes of the two ears.
primary_indications: shortness of breath leading to low back pain Fatigue
techniques: Needle obliquely forward, backward or to the side 0.1 - 0.3 cun . This point can also be bled.
comments: Cautions: • In Tung’s acupuncture, this point is always bled and therefore is always safe as the puncture is shallow. Please see needling notes below. • “Too deep insertion at this point can cause paralysis. combinations: Parkinson’s disease or arm tremors: “For early Parkinson’s disease, bilaterally thread a 60mm needle from 1010.02 State Round (UB7) toward UB5 Da Zhu. This will also treat arm tremors” (Dr. Lee, 1992). My extensive write-up on the treatment of Parkinson’s disease can be found in 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows, Comments.

name: Zhoukun, State Elder Brother (T 1010.03)
location: This point is near the BL channel, 1.3 cun lateral and 1.5 cun posterior to Baihui (GV 20) on both left and right sides, close to Luoque (BL 8) . Baihui (GV 20) is 5 cun directly above the midpoint of the anterior hairline or in the midpoint of the line connecting the apexes of the two ears. | Johnson: 1010.02 State Round is located 1.3 cun (a little less than two fingers) to the left and right sides of 1010.01 Upright Meeting, close to UB7 Tong Tian (which is located 1.5 cun lateral to 1010.01 Upright Meeting). 1010.03 State Elder Brother is located 1.0 cun (1.5 cun) posterior to 1010.02 State Round, on both sides of the midline. This point is UB8 Luo Que.
primary_indications: shortness of breath leading to low back pain Fatigue
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun obliquely forward, backward or to the side. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 1010.02 State Round and/or 1010.03 State Elder Brother are needled as Supplementary Points to 1010.04 State High Mountain (UB6 - Chief Point) to strengthen its treatment effect. Needle technique: Bilaterally needle either State Round or State Elder Brother with

name: Zhoulun, UB5 Da Zhu. (T 1010.04)
location: This point is near the BL channel, 1.3 cun lateral and 1.5 cun anterior to Baihui (GV 20) on both left and right sides, close to Chengguang (BL 6) and Tongtian (BL 7) . Baihui (GV 20) is 5 cun directly above the midpoint of the anterior hairline or in the midpoint of the line connecting the apexes of the two ears. | Johnson: State High Mountain is located 1.5 cun (two fingers) anterior to 1010.02 State Round, on both sides of the head (in the same location as UB6 Cheng Guan).
primary_indications: Brain tumor Hemiplegia Shortness of breath
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected area. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Dao Ma: Combine State High Mountain (Chief Point) with either 1010.02 State Round (UB7) or 1010.03 State Elder Brother (UB8) to strengthen the treatment effect. Bilaterally needle horizontally from State High Mountain toward UB5 Da Zhu. Remember to needle the right side for a left-brain tumor, and vice versa. Depth: 1.0-2.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: State Round and State Elder Brother have indications such as asthma and Urinary Bladder sciatica due to the Reaction Area of the Lung and because of the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yang (UB). The following functions are typical of UB7 and UB8: Expel wind Clear heat Open the lung and regulate the nose Improve vision Clear wind and transform phlegm Calm the spirit See 1010.04 State High Mountain for additional comments. Energetic pathways: The following functions are typical of State High Mountain (UB6): Expels wind and clears heat Clears the head Benefits eyes and nose Benign brain tumors: 1010.04 State High Mountain has similar indications as 1010.02 State Round and 1010.03 State Elder Brother; however, it also has the indication of benign brain tumors and bulging eyeballs. Commentary (Dr. Lee): “One can tell if the tumor is on the left or right side of the brain by looking at the eyeballs. If the right eyeball bulges, the tumor is on the right side. If the left eyeball bulges, the tumor is on the left side” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Cautions: • In Tung’s acupuncture, this point is always bled and therefore is always safe as the puncture is shallow. Although acupuncture texts do allow 0.3-0.8mm needling of DU15, deeper needling may cause damage to the spinal cord. Please see needling notes below. • “Too deep insertion at this point can cause paralysis. In ancient China, if there was a crazy person running around naked menacing people with knives or clubs, three or four men might be necessary to catch such a person and hold them down. Then a thick iron needle like a shoemaker’s awl would be inserted at DU16 Feng Fu to intentionally paralyze the person. If the wound was not too deep, this paralysis was only temporary. But sometimes, because the mad person would be thrashing around, the needle would penetrate too deeply, and the person would be paralyzed for life” (Dr. Lee, 1992). • Though All Pivot may help with morning sickness, I never use it for this issue because it does not address the root of the problem, namely protein deficiency. See 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points for further information and dietary advice.
combinations: Parkinson’s disease or arm tremors: “For early Parkinson’s disease, bilaterally thread a 60mm needle from 1010.02 State Round (UB7) toward UB5 Da Zhu. This will also treat arm tremors” (Dr. Lee, 1992). My extensive write-up on the treatment of Parkinson’s disease can be found in 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows, Comments. Bulging eyeball (due to brain tumor, Dr. Lee): For brain tumor with bulging eyeball, use direct moxa on opposite-side 1010.04 State High Mountain (UB6). The moxa must burn. (The first two moxa will hurt, after which there will be no pain, though there will be a scar.) The eyeball should recede 8 to 12 hours after direct moxa. Alternate treatment: Thread a 50-60mm needle from 1010.03 State Elder Brother (UB8) to 1010.04 State High Mountain (UB6).

name: Qianhui (T 1010.05)
location: This point overlaps with Qianding (GV 21) , which is 3.5 cun directly above the midpoint of the anterior hairline.
primary_indications: feeling of distension in the head Nervousness
johnson_indications: Seeing spots in front of the eyes
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun
comments: Treating all wind diseases: In this book, we chose to separate Anterior Meeting (DU21) and 1010.06 Posterior Meeting(DU19) because they have enough individual indications to warrant separation; however, at least 90% of the time we are using them together as a Dao Ma to treat all types of wind diseases. •  Energetic pathways: Anterior Meeting (DU21) subdues Liver yang, clears the head and eyes, and calms the spirit. Following are a few useful energetic combinations: •  To warm Shao Yin (HT/KD): Needle DU21 with KD1 Yong Quan and PC6 Nei Guan.•  To disperse phlegm: Needle DU21 with PC6 Nei Guan and 77.14 Four Flower Outer (ST40). •  To enhance Heart qi and rebuild Heart yang: Needle DU21 with 66.03-66.04 Fire Hardness/Fire Master and PC6 Nei Guan
combinations: Emergency point for coma or unconsciousness: 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20)can be used as an emergency point to restore consciousness. For coma, needle DU19,DU20, DU21, DU26, PC6, and LV3 through KD1, and bleed the Jing-Well points or fingertips. •  Tranquilize the spirit and free the channels, any wind diseases: Needle 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), 1010.02 State Round (UB7), 1010.03 State Elder Brother (UB8), 1010.04 State High Mountain (UB6), 1010.05 Anterior Meeting (DU21) and 1010.06 Posterior Meeting (DU19) (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Tailbone pain: 1010.05 Anterior Meeting (DU21) can be needled with 1010.06 Posterior Meeting (DU19) to treat tailbone pain, because together they warm and raise the yang. (Conversely, bleeding the sacrum can relieve pressure in the head and occiput.) •  Hemiplegia: Needle 1010.06 Posterior Meeting (DU19), 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), 1010.05 Anterior Meeting (DU21). See 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) for stroke protocol.

name: Houhui, Posterior Meeting (DU19) (T 1010.06)
location: This point overlaps with Houding (GV 19) , which is 5.5 cun directly above the midpoint of the posterior hairline. | Johnson: Posterior Meeting is located 1.6 cun (a little more than two fingers) posterior to 1010.01 Upright Meeting. This is the same location as DU19 Hou Ding.
primary_indications: dizziness Tuberculosis of the bone Thoracic vertebrae pain
loss of speech due to wind-stroke
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun

This is effective in the treatment of heel pain (top treating bottom). •  Spine pain: Needle 1010.06 Posterior Meeting (DU19); this treats the entire spine but is most effective for the lower thoracic/upper lumbar area.

name: Zongshu, All Pivot (T 1010.07)
location: This point is on the GV channel, 0.8 cun above the posterior hairline. Some books state it overlaps with Fengfu (GV 16) , which is 1 cun above the midpoint of the posterior hairline, while others say it overlaps with Yamen (GV 15) , which is 0.5 cun above the midpoint of the posterior hairline. | Johnson: All Pivot is found in the occipital notch, directly below the external occipital protuberance, in the depression between the bilateral origins of the trapezius muscle, 0.8 cun superior to the posterior hairline. Note: All Pivot is an area approximately 2 cm in length. We locate it 0.8 cun above the hairline. Others may call it the DU15 Ya Men - DU16 Feng Fu area.
primary_indications: summer time enteritis with vomiting and diarrhea
johnson_indications: Nausea and vomiting due to toxicity of any kind:
Loss of voice (due to internal weakness, cold or flu)
techniques: Needle 0.1-0.2 cun . This point should not be needled more than 0.2 cun deep unless treating aphasia, which the needling depth is 0.3 cun . This point works best when it is bled. Pinch the muscles first prior to bleeding. | Johnson: Bleeding technique: Bleed All Pivot with a large tipped bleeding needle, rather than a smaller diameter needle that would be used for deeper punctures. In this case, a lancet is entirely insufficient. A shallow bleed is always done with a large tip in order to make a bigger puncture site, allowing for a larger volume of blood. Patient positioning: Ask the patient to sit in a chair, with their elbows on the table and hands supporting their forehead (like a tripod). Make sure they do not drop their chin, as this would make the area in the back of the neck tighter, and therefore harder for you to grip. Pinching up the skin: The difficulty in bleeding All Pivot is that the skin must be pinched and firmly held. If you are within the hairline (as you will be on most patients), the hair will cause the skin to slip through your fingers when the pressure of the needle is applied. Because a superficial puncture will not do the job, it is necessary to pinch as much flesh as possible in order to secure the area and allow for a deeper puncture, as deep as 3-4mm. This point rarely bleeds on its own; it has to be “milked.” Squeeze and swipe: Once the point is punctured, squeeze hard and swipe, squeeze hard and swipe, and keep it bleeding for a few minutes. If the puncture closes and beads of blood dry up before you are done, gently scrub the puncture site with a wet cloth to open it again. Note: Use water rather than alcohol on the puncture site, because alcohol will sting unnecessarily. Blood vessels: On two occasions in more than thirty years, I have hit a blood vessel in this area, causing spontaneous bleeding. As long as the bleeding is not rhythmic, you will know that it is from a vein, not an artery. Should this happen, and the bleeding is not rhythmic, allow it to bleed for 60 seconds and then apply pressure to stop the bleeding. In this area, a point that bleeds on its own may be likely to open up again later, so be sure to advise the patient to wait until the following day to shower or wash their hair. Depth: 0.3.0 cun
comments: Cautions: In Tung’s acupuncture, this point is always bled and therefore is always safe as the puncture is shallow. Although acupuncture texts do allow 0.3-0.8mm needling of DU15, deeper needling may cause damage to the spinal cord. Please see needling notes below. “Too deep insertion at this point can cause paralysis. In ancient China, if there was a crazy person running around naked menacing people with knives or clubs, three or four men might be necessary to catch such a person and hold them down. Then a thick iron needle like a shoemaker’s awl would be inserted at DU16 Feng Fu to intentionally paralyze the person. If the wound was not too deep, this paralysis was only temporary. But sometimes, because the mad person would be thrashing around, the needle would penetrate too deeply, and the person would be paralyzed for life” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Though All Pivot may help with morning sickness, I never use it for this issue because it does not address the root of the problem, namely protein deficiency. See 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points for further information and dietary advice. Energetic pathways: When properly punctured, All Pivot is extraordinary in relieving extreme nausea and vomiting because it releases toxins that have accumulated in the area of the brain stem. In fact, nausea and/or vomiting is a sign of toxin buildup, often related to chemical exposure, drug addiction withdrawal, heat stroke or motion sickness. Additional energetic functions include: Clears Heart and calms spirit Clears heat and calms wind Clears the brain Expels wind Nourishes the Sea of Marrow Benefits the tongue and treats muteness Nausea: When a person is nauseous, their stomach spasms and draws upward. By bleeding this area of the brain stem where toxins collect, we cause the stomach to relax and descend. The patient usually experiences a sensation of the stomach dropping within the first minute after bleeding begins in this area. In the past 30 years, on two occasions I have punctured a vein here, but it is rare for this to happen. Aside from those two occasions, I have found it necessary to squeeze hard in order to draw one drop of blood. Sometimes it may be difficult to get the blood going, but once you do, you may keep it going by occasionally swiping the area with a damp cloth. Even in cases of paralytic colon with extreme dry heaving, the patient usually reports feeling the stomach drop within the first minute or approximately 10-20 drops of blood, and feeling relief from the nausea. Once the stomach drops, I continue to bleed the point for another minute or two in order to completely clean the toxins from the brainstem area. Gua Sha (Dr. Lee): “Bleeding this point can stop nausea and vomiting and tranquilizes the hollow bowels. One can also use Gua Sha to turn the skin in this area black and blue, instead of bleeding” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Note: Dr. Lee did this Gua Sha treatment on me. It is excellent for stiff neck and detoxifies the brain stem of accumulated pollutants, but for nausea and vomiting, Gua Sha is far slower and more painful than bleeding All Pivot. Paralytic colon: A patients whose colon does not “wake up” after anesthesia does not recover their bowel sounds, and therefore cannot be discharged from the hospital. Because toxins are being reabsorbed into the bloodstream through the colon, the patient quickly becomes very nauseous. Because the patient has not eaten since the night before their surgery, their vomiting is dry heaves. We bleed All Pivot to stop the nausea and vomiting, and to drop the stomach. Once the patient is comfortable (within five minutes of bleeding All Pivot), needle SP4 Gong Sun and PC6 Nei Guan to restore peristalsis. Within four to six hours, there should be bowel sounds. Note: I try to treat the patient early in the day so that I can return in the later afternoon, if necessary, to reapply the needle portion of the treatment. In thirty years, I have had to return to the hospital only two or three times. This treatment works like a charm, and in every instance, the patient has gone home the same day. Side effects from cancer treatment: Bleeding All Pivot is a real blessing in helping patients who are undergoing chemotherapy and radiation and suffering from nausea. I never hesitate to bleed All Pivot to drop the stomach, as this does not interfere with the cancer treatment. Since treating HIV in the mid-1980s in San Francisco, I have always recommended the use of THC to treat nausea and vomiting and also to encourage appetite. These days, I suggest using CBD instead, unless the patient needs the THC to make them hungry.1 When the patient takes a break in their chemotherapy program, thoroughly cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas, so as not to interfere with the best effect of their chemotherapy. Heat stroke: For marathon runners or people who are suffering from heat exhaustion or summer heat stroke, bleeding All Pivot beautifully descends the reflux of Stomach qi. Be sure the patient hydrates slowly with warm water, as excessive water or cold water may cause reflux. Loss of voice: All Pivot treats lost voice from internal weakness, cold or flu because it is a wind point, and because it is opposite REN24 Cheng Jiang. Stroke: All Pivot treats sudden aphasia and difficulty swallowing. Motion sickness: Although All Pivot drops the stomach in cases of extreme motion sickness, Dr. Young gave us a good alternative for treating children. He said to tape a slice of raw ginger to PC6 Nei Guan and have them eat dried mango, a much better solution for kids.
combinations: Post-chemotherapy detoxification: Bleed 1010.07 All Pivot; needle PC6 Nei Guan; cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas. For acute stomach pain, needle LU5 Chi Ze, LU10 Yu Ji and ST34 Liang Qiu. Lost voice (due to internal weakness): Bleed 1010.07 All Pivot. Paralytic colon: In patients with paralytic colon after anesthesia, bleed 1010.07 All Pivot and needle SP4 Gong Sun and PC6 Nei Guan. Acid reflux: Bleed 1010.07 All Pivot; needle 77.17 Heaven Emperor and 77.18 Shen Guan; 88.03 Passing Heaven, 88.10 Passing Back; SP4 Gong Sun. Aloe vera juice is very good for healing the mucous membrane of the stomach. Nausea (dry heaves or wet heaves): Bleed 1010.07 All Pivot for dry heaves (sound, no vomit), needle PC5 Jian Shi or PC7 Da Ling; for wet heaves (vomit, no sound), bleed

name: Zhenjing, Tranquility (T 1010.08)
location: This point is 0.3 cun above Yintang , which is midway between the medial ends of the eyebrows. | Johnson: Tranquility is Tung’s version of classic extra acupuncture point Yin Tang. While the classic location of Yin Tang is midway between the eyebrows, Master Tung needled this point 0.3 cun superior, threading the needle downward through Yin Tang.
primary_indications: night terror or night crying in children/babies
johnson_indications: Children crying at night or startling easily
Pain or paralysis of the four limbs
Stress related: shaky, weak or numb extremities*
techniques: Needle subcutaneously 0.3 - 0.5 cun towards the nose. This point can also be bled when treating acute conditions. | Johnson: Needle downward into the point: The needle is inserted 0.3 cun superior to Yin Tang and needled downward toward the nose. For easier needle insertion, pinch up the skin just above the eyebrows and insert the needle, threading it superficially downward beneath the thicker skin found between the eyebrows. Scar tissue: Internal thickening or scarring beneath the skin is common in this area, due to childhood acne or botox. Starting the needle above the affected area makes insertion much more comfortable for patients with scar tissue. Bruising or bleeding: Patients may bruise at the site of the insertion, or the point may bleed a drop or two when the needle is removed. Always have cotton balls on hand in case the point bleeds when the needle is removed. If Yin Tang bleeds, note it in the patient’s chart so that you can avoid the blood vessel in future insertions. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: 1010.08 Tranquility is located on the DU meridian, just above Yin Tang (Extra Point), and it has a very strong sedative effect. Dr. Young teaches that this area of the face corresponds to the Heart and Lung. Tranquility connects Lung and Heart to treat both, making this an excellent point to calm the Heart and spirit, and to open the mind. Other functions include: expelling wind, alleviating pain, activating the collaterals, and benefiting the nose and eyes. Calming the spirit: For my patients with anxiety, hyperactivity or Liver yang rising, this is the first needle they receive if they are lying face up. It helps them to stay on the table, relaxed or asleep, for the duration of their treatment. When they wake up, they feel rested and rejuvenated. Clear the brain: Combine Tranquility with 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20) for the treatment of epilepsy, insomnia and manic depression to calm the spirit and clear the brain. Precautions: Tranquility descends the qi and clears the brain, so if the treatment is designed to raise the pure qi to the head, be sure it is in the patient’s best interest to add this point. Some patients with depression benefit from Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment with the addition of Tranquility and DU20 to clear the brain, though the rest of the treatment is directed toward bringing the pure qi to the head. If a patient has a frontal headache, I only needle this point if the headache is sinus related.

name: Shangli, Supreme Mile (T 1010.09)
location: This point overlaps with Zanzhu (BL 2) , which is superior to the inner canthus, in a depression on the medial end of the eyebrow. Some books state this point is 0.2 cun above Zanzhu (BL 2) . | Johnson: Supreme Mile is located 0.2 cun above the medial end of the eyebrow.
primary_indications: All disorders of the eyes: blurry vision
techniques: Needle subcutaneously and inferiorly 0.1 - 0.2 cun . | Johnson: These points are usually bled: Look for a vein beneath the skin and insert a narrow- gauge bleeding needle or 18-gauge hypodermic needle tip approximately 0.3 cun deep, inserted in the same direction as the vein. Preparation: Whether needling or bleeding this point, always have cotton balls on hand so the blood does not run downward toward the patient’s eyes when the needle is removed! Depth: 0.1-0.3.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Supreme Mile is located 0.2 cun superior to UB2 Zan Zhu. It shares similar indications to UB2 and is an important point for the treatment of dizziness and headache. Additionally, Supreme Mile expels wind and clears heat, improves vision, clears the head and alleviates pain. Acute headache or face pain: I bleed this point for acute headache or face pain, but I do not needle it. It is not used for chronic headache.

name: Sifuer, Four Bowels Second (T 1010.10)
location: This point overlaps with Yuyao , which is 0.2 cun above the center of the eyebrow. | Johnson: 1010.10 Four Bowels Second is located 0.2 cun above the center of the eyebrows, 0.2 cun superior to Yu Yao (Extra Point).
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun subcutaneously and inferiorly. This point can also be bled. To treat acute headaches, epilepsy, and mania, it is best to bleed this point.
comments: Migraines (Tai Yang area): Bleeding the veins in the temple area deemed Tai Yang (Extra Point) is immediately helpful, and has a profound and lasting effect on migraine headaches. This technique is included here because in my opinion, bleeding any vein found in the sphenoid and frontal bone areas usually works like a charm on stubborn headaches. (Be sure you bleed a vein, not an artery. Arteries have a pulse; please check for the pulse with your fingers before you put on gloves to bleed the point.) I have successfully bled the vein found over the eyebrow many times to treat chronic migraines, especially those related to excess blood stagnation in the head. On a few occasions, one bleeding treatment was all it took to eliminate stubborn migraines forever. Do not be shy about performing this technique when the results can be life changing for your patient. Bleeding this area expels wind, alleviates pain, and benefits the eyes. Case history (herpes in the eye): These points are bled to clear the head and eyes. I have had several patients with herpes in their eye. One patient was taking Acyclovir around the clock and was still having regular outbreaks. He complained of seeing “cotton balls” in his visual field (indicative of white blood cells in the area), constant irritation in the affected eye, and diminished visual acuity. After I bled a vein that extended into the area of 1010.10 above his eyebrow, the sclera changed color from intense red to mostly white, the irritation subsided and the “cotton balls” disappeared from his visual field. With the third bleeding of this vessel, the output of blood significantly diminished, signaling the healing or shrinking of the vessel itself. The patient discontinued Acyclovir and had no further outbreaks in the following ten months until the death of his father, at which time he had a massive herpes outbreak in the same eye. When I bled the vessel again, it produced 50% of the original output, and so instead I bled the Head and Eye points found on the sides of the tip of the middle finger (Koryo Hand Therapy-KHT), thus saving the vein above his eyebrow in case it would need treatment for another traumatic event in the future. Intestinal correspondence (Dr. Young): “1010.11 Four Bowels First and 1010.10 Four Bowels Second have a holographic correspondence to the Large Intestine and the Small Intestine, and are therefore indicated for abdominal distension” (Dr. Young, 2008).
combinations: Acute headache: Bleed 1010.09 Supreme Mile, 1010.10 Four Bowels Second and 1010.11 Four Bowels First.

name: Sifuyi, Four Bowels First. (T 1010.11)
location: This point overlaps with Sizhukong (TH 23) , which is 0.2 cun above the lateral end of the eyebrow. | Johnson: 1010.11 Four Bowels First is located 0.2 cun superior to the lateral end of the eyebrows, 0.2 cun superior to SJ23 Si Zhu Kong.
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun subcutaneously and inferiorly. This point can also be bled. To treat acute headaches, epilepsy, and mania, it is best to bleed this point. | Johnson: These points are usually bled: Look for a vein beneath the skin and insert a narrow- gauge bleeding needle or 18-gauge hypodermic needle tip approximately 0.3 cun deep, inserted in the same direction as the vein. Preparation: Whether needling or bleeding this point, always have cotton balls on hand so the blood does not run downward toward the patient’s eyes when the needle is removed! Depth: 0.1-0.5 cun
comments: Migraines (Tai Yang area): Bleeding the veins in the temple area deemed Tai Yang (Extra Point) is immediately helpful, and has a profound and lasting effect on migraine headaches. On a few occasions, one bleeding treatment was all it took to eliminate stubborn migraines  forever. name: Zhengben, Upright Source (T 1010.12)
location: This point overlaps with Suliao (GV 25) , which is on the tip of the nose. | Johnson: Upright Source is located at the tip of the nose, in the opening between the lower lateral cartilages. Be very careful not to hit the cartilage. This is the same location as DU25 Su Liao.
primary_indications: feeling of being possessed by a ghost Rosacea Hangover
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun . Be careful not to injure the cartilage when needling this point. This point is most effective when bled. | Johnson: Needle or bleed: This point is commonly bled. Needle for declining mental function and Lung weakness; bleed with a three-edge needle for other indications. Caution: Puncturing this point is very painful. Depth: 0.1-0.2 cun
comments: Enhance memory: Upright Source awakens the brain, enhances memory for elderly patients who remember the past but forget the present, and opens the whole head. Awaken the brain: Upright Source is bled more than needled, in order to wake up the brain in cases of psychosis or inebriation. It can also clear the sinuses and treat bacterial skin infection on the face, but I would never consider using it for these reasons because puncturing this point is very painful.  Psychosis: Dr. Lee said that bleeding 1010.12 Upright Source “chases the devil away.” For psychosis from possession or grief, consider needling HT1 Ji Quan by firmly gripping the flesh of the armpit and quickly inserting the needle perpendicularly. To treat possession, you can tape the patient’s thumbs together and apply moxa on LU11 Shao Shang on both hands simultaneously. You must burn the flesh; only the first two grains of moxa will hurt.
combinations: Alcohol intoxication: 99.01 Ear Ring is bled for intoxication and can be combined with the bleeding of 1010.12 Upright Source (DU25). Other options are to bleed 55.01 Fire Bag, 99.08 Ear Apex or ST45 Li Dui.

name: Majinshui, Horse Gold Water (T 1010.13)
location: This point overlaps with Quanliao (SI 18) , which is located directly below the outer canthus, in the depression at the lower border of the zygomatic bone. | Johnson: 1010.13 Horse Gold Water is located directly beneath the edge of the outer canthus of the eye, just inferior to the zygomatic arch and level with LI20 and the nasal ala. This is the same location as SI18 Quan Liao.
primary_indications: Kidney stones Nephritis Rhinitis Acute back sprain
pain of the ribs when breathing
johnson_indications: Pain due to kidney stone (will not dissolve the stone)*
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun If the pain is immediately relieved after the needle is inserted, the point location is correct. If there is bleeding after the needle is pulled out, then the location is incorrect.
comments: Energetic pathways: Horse Gold Water and Horse Fast Water are always used together as a Dao Ma. They tonify and regulate the qi of the Lung and Kidneys to treat urinary system issues. In the point name, “Gold” indicates metal, and in this case the Lung, while “Water” refers to the connection to the Kidneys and Urinary Bladder. Both points share the Reaction Areas of the Lung and Kidney; 1010.13 has a stronger effect on the Kidney, and 1010.14 more strongly affects the Urinary Bladder. Additional functions: SI18 Quan Liao is the crossing point of the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and the Hand Tai Yang (SI). It expels wind and alleviates pain, clears heat and disperses swelling. For these reasons, 1010.13 is also used for lower back pain, although I would only implement it if there were also urinary indications. Kidney or bladder stones, urinary pain, uremia or urinary tract infection: My “go-to” points for just about any urinary condition – including all of the ones listed above as well as incontinence – are 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, which are Kidney points on the Spleen channel that strengthen the Kidneys and move the water. To these points, I add additional supplementary points depending upon the condition. (Also see Combinations below and 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors.) For urinary stones, infection or inflammation (including prostatitis)
combinations: Kidney or bladder stones, urinary pain, uremia or urinary tract infection: See Comments above. Urinary stones: 001 Hand Golden Gate with 22.07 Lower White (Xia Bai) relieves the pain of kidney stones or gallbladder stones. Add 1010.13 Horse Gold Water (kidney stone), 1010.14 Horse Fast Water (bladder stone), and 1010.16 Six Fast for stones in the urethra. Add 11.17 Wood (Anger) for burning urine due to anger. Acute back strain (Dr. Young): Needle opposite side 1010.13 Horse Gold Water with 1010.19 Water Through. If the pain is bilateral or centered in the back, needle both points bilaterally (Dr. Young, 2008)
reaction_areas: Horse Gold Water: Kidney, Lung Horse Fast Water: Urinary Bladder, Kidney Kidney, Six Bowels

name: Makuaishui, Horse Fast Water (T 1010.14)
location: This point is on the SI channel, 0.4 cun inferior to Quanliao (SI 18) , at the level of the lower border of the ala nasi. Quanliao (SI 18) is located directly below the outer canthus, in the depression at the lower border of the zygomatic bone. | Johnson: 1010.14 Horse Fast Water is located approximately 0.4 cun inferior to Horse Gold Water, level with DU26 Ren Zhong.
johnson_indications: Pain due to kidney stone (will not dissolve the stone)*
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun | Johnson: Dao Ma: 1010.13 Horse Gold Water is combined with 1010.14 Horse Fast Water for most indications. Palpation note: Patients do not like to have a practitioner’s hands on their face when their eyes are open, so whenever possible, palpate for this point by walking your finger gently in from the side of the face, stopping when you reach the inner edge of the outer canthus (this inner edge is found more medial than it appears), then dropping straight down to find Horse Gold Water just beneath the zygomatic arch. Needle perpendicularly and bilaterally, or on the opposite side for one-sided lower back pain. Depth: 0.5-0.8 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Horse Gold Water and Horse Fast Water are always used together as a Dao Ma. They tonify and regulate the qi of the Lung and Kidneys to treat urinary system issues. In the point name, “Gold” indicates metal, and in this case the Lung, while “Water” refers to the connection to the Kidneys and Urinary Bladder. Both points share the Reaction Areas of the Lung and Kidney; 1010.13 has a stronger effect on the Kidney, and 1010.14 more strongly affects the Urinary Bladder. Additional functions: SI18 Quan Liao is the crossing point of the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and the Hand Tai Yang (SI). It expels wind and alleviates pain, clears heat and disperses swelling. For these reasons, 1010.13 is also used for lower back pain, although I would only implement it if there were also urinary indications. Kidney or bladder stones, urinary pain, uremia or urinary tract infection: My “go-to” points for just about any urinary condition – including all of the ones listed above as well as incontinence – are 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, which are Kidney points on the Spleen channel that strengthen the Kidneys and move the water. To these points, I add 475 Head and Face Points additional supplementary points depending upon the condition. (Also see Combinations below and 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors.) For urinary stones, infection or inflammation (including prostatitis)
combinations: Kidney or bladder stones, urinary pain, uremia or urinary tract infection: See Comments above. Urinary stones: 001 Hand Golden Gate with 22.07 Lower White (Xia Bai) relieves the pain of kidney stones or gallbladder stones. Add 1010.13 Horse Gold Water (kidney stone), 1010.14 Horse Fast Water (bladder stone), and 1010.16 Six Fast for stones in the urethra. Add 11.17 Wood (Anger) for burning urine due to anger. Acute back strain (Dr. Young): Needle opposite side 1010.13 Horse Gold Water with 1010.19 Water Through. If the pain is bilateral or centered in the back, needle both points bilaterally (Dr. Young, 2008)
reaction_areas: Horse Gold Water: Kidney, Lung Horse Fast Water: Urinary Bladder, Kidney Kidney, Six Bowels

name: Fukuai, Welcome Fragrance (T 1010.15)
location: This point is 0.5 cun lateral to the inferior border of the ala nasi, close to Yingxiang (LI 20) . | Johnson: Welcome Fragrance is found at the level of the nasal ala, lateral to the nose, at the creases formed by the laugh lines of the face. Note: My location and direction of needling for LI20 was established while observing in the long needle treatment department of the research hospital in He Fei, China, in 1987. From that day forward, I have always needled this point as described in Needling Notes below.
techniques: Needle in any direction 0.1 - 0.3 cun . This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Welcome Fragrance (LI20): Classically, LI20 is located directly next to the nasal ala and is needled with a perpendicular insertion. I hope that you will never needle it that way again, as that location and insertion are extremely painful and virtually ineffective. 2 Fu Kuai translates as “Bowels Fast;” however, I always refer to this point as “1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20)” and only needle it as described in the needling notes. Curving needle technique: My preferred way of needling Welcome Fragrance is to utilize the laugh lines at the level of the nasal ala and direct the needle superficially toward Yin Tang. The difficulty of this manner of insertion is that a slight curve must be introduced to the tip of the needle in order to lift it over the edge of the nasal bone. I have developed an easy method that I call “the curving needle technique.” By holding the handle of the needle at a 45-degree angle away from the body, and thus flattening the shaft of the needle against the skin, introduce a curve in the shaft that extends to the tip and causes it to lift up and over the bone. Watch the tip of the needle as it is progressing, and after the tip of the needle passes the nasal bone, lower the handle to drop the curve. By doing this, you will avoid contact between the needle tip and the sensitive underside of the epidermis. Note: This curving needle technique is useful in the insertion of many different points (11.06 Return to the Nest, 22.04 Da Bai, 22.08 (SI3), 66.10 (SP3), 66.11 (SP4), UB65 Shu Gu), but in Welcome Fragrance it is essential, because a straight needle insertion will painfully hit the bone. With this curving needle technique, a 1.0 cun needle can be inserted virtually painlessly and nearly all the way in.
comments: Welcome Fragrance (LI20): I use Welcome Fragrance primarily to open the sinuses quickly, and for common cold, allergies, and acute or chronic sinus swelling. Needled as instructed above, LI20 can open a congested sinus cavity in ten minutes or less; patients are surprised when they can suddenly breathe through both nostrils easily. Digestive issues: Because LI20 Ying Xiang is the crossing point of the Stomach and Large Intestine meridians, in Tung’s acupuncture it also has the indications of abdominal distension and pain. Because there are so many other useful points for digestive conditions, I never use LI20 that way, though it may result in some positive side effects for digestion.
combinations: Allergies, colds and flu: 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with A.04 San Cha Three and 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20) is a perfect pattern. Acne: 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20) is a useful Guiding Point for treating acne on the face, when used in combination with 88.17-88.19 Four Horses and A.04 San Cha Three.

name: Liukuai, Six Fast (T 1010.16)
location: This point is 1.4 cun lateral to Renzhong (GV 26) , which is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the philtrum. | Johnson: Six Fast is located 1.4 cun (just under two fingers) lateral to DU26 Ren Zhong in the laugh line.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun or subcutaneously outwards 0.5 - 1.5 cun . This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Depth: 0.1-0.3 cun
comments: Urinary stone (pain): 1010.14 Horse Fast Water, 1010.16 Six Fast and 1010.17 Seven Fast correspond with the lower jiao area of the face and treat pain from a urinary stone, though they do not dissolve it. Note: In order to slowly dissolve urinary calculi, drink up to 40 pounds of Lysmachia (Jin Qian Cao). Dietary advice: Ask the patient to eat handfuls of raw walnuts for prevention and treatment (no salt or sugar). Caffeine, alcohol, spicy foods and oily foods (including dairy) need to be strictly avoided.
combinations: Pain from stones in the urethra: Needle 1010.16 Six Fast with 1010.14 Horse Fast Water. In order to slowly dissolve urinary calculi, drink up to 40 pounds of Lysmachia (Jin Qian Cao). Inflammation or urethra pain: Needle 1010.16 Six Fast with 1010.17 Seven Fast.
reaction_areas: Horse Gold Water: Kidney, Lung Horse Fast Water: Urinary Bladder, Kidney Kidney, Six Bowels

name: Qikuai, Seven Fast (T 1010.17)
location: This point overlaps with Dicang (ST 4) , which is lateral to the corner of the mouth, directly below the pupil of the eye. | Johnson: Seven Fast is located 0.5 cun lateral to the corner of the mouth. This is the same location as ST4 Di Cang.
primary_indications: abdominal pain Facial paralysis Generalized weakness from LU deficiency
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun or thread the needle laterally 0.5 - 1.5 cun . This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Needle laterally from the corner of the mouth toward the outside. Select this point on the left side to treat right-sided facial paralysis, and vice versa (Dr. Young, 2008). Depth: 0.5-1.5 cun
comments: Facial paralysis due to wind: “Use ST4 Di Cang in all cases where treacherous wind enters the ear, mouth and eye, and leads to deviation” (Secret Writings of Bian Que, 310 B.C.E.).

name: Muzhi, Wood Branch (T 1010.18)
location: This point overlaps with Xiaguan (ST 7) on the face, which is in the depression between the zygomatic arch and the mandibular notch when the mouth is closed. | Johnson: Wood Branch is located in the depression just anterior to the condyloid process of the mandible when the mouth is wide open. This is the same location as ST7 Xia Guan.
secondary_indications: Weakness of the lower limbs in the elderly
johnson_indications: In elderly people, weakness of the legs with a tendency to fall
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Needle technique: Ask the patient to open their mouth wide to locate the point more easily, then close gently. Needle with strong stimulation using a 15mm needle. Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: ST7 is the meeting point of the Gallbladder and Stomach meridians, so it treats conditions that affect both, such as gallstones. In the name of the point, “Wood” indicates a connection to the Liver, while “Branch” refers to the Gallbladder in relation to the Liver. Resolves pain; does not dissolve stones: Wood Branch resolves real gallbladder pain and early stage gallbladder inflammation, though it doesn’t dissolve the stones. I love using this point with 88.14-88.16 Gallbladder Points in the treatment of cholecystitis, sludge or stones in the gallbladder. My experience with Wood Branch is that it keeps the patient comfortable until the effects of 88.14-88.16 have time to work. Recently, I stopped using Wood Branch when the patient was no longer experiencing any gallbladder discomfort, and two days later the pain returned (though it was minimal). I recommend using Wood Branch for at least three treatments before continuing with 88.14-88.16 Gallbladder Points alone. See 88.15 Fire Branch/88.16 Fire All for a comprehensive discussion of gallbladder diseases. Gallstone commentary (Dr. Lee): “The presence of gallstones indicates that there is something is wrong in the patient’s life; they are unhappy, worried or full of regret” (Dr. Lee, 1992). “Empty gallbladder:” A patient with Liver weakness is easily tired. A patient with Gallbladder weakness is easily startled; this is called “empty gallbladder,” indicating that the bile is lacking.

name: Shuitong, Water Through. (T 1010.19)
location: This point is on the face, close to the ST channel, 0.4 cun inferior to the corner of the mouth. | Johnson: 1010.19 Water Through is located 0.4 cun directly below the corner of the mouth. Be sure to locate this point based upon the place where the lip pigment ends, as the crease of the lips extends with age and may be misleading. Needle this point horizontally beneath the skin, toward the angle of the jaw.
primary_indications: Rheumatism Kidney deficiency causing low back pain
johnson_indications: Chest or back pain due to gas
Joint pain due to Kidney deficiency
techniques: Needle obliquely and away from the midline, 0.1 - 0.5 cun . It is not necessary to be exact on the point location. Look for an area near this point that is dark or purplish in color to needle for best results. | Johnson: Dao Ma: Water Through and Water Gold are usually needled together in the combination called 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through.3 Patient positioning: Asthmatic patients may need a higher pillow or two pillows in order to breathe more comfortably; always ask them what they would prefer. Bilaterally needled: The points are usually needled bilaterally by threading the needles horizontally toward the corner of the jaw. In cases of one-sided pathology, they can be needled on the side opposite the indications. Superficially threaded: To keep the needle superficial, first tap the tip in just beneath the epidermis, on top of the muscle. Then, flatten the shaft of the needle against the skin by holding the handle up slightly while advancing the needle toward the corner of the jaw. When the needle is superficial enough and in the proper zone, you will be 3 Though the point numbers are reversed, I always refer to this combination as “Water Gold/Water Through.” able to see the tip of the needle progressing. I needle these four points in this manner (using only one hand) in order to keep my hands away from the patient’s face and eyes. Alternately, while you are learning to do this efficiently, once the needle tip is inserted you may press your thumb against the needle shaft while advancing the needle. This has the same function of flattening the needle shaft, using the surface of the chin as a guide, which keeps your needle trajectory as superficial as possible. Bruising: These points may bruise easily, especially if the needle is inserted too deeply. The two more lateral points are more likely to bruise. Keep the needle tip superficial enough to see it moving back toward the angle of the jaw. This prevents bleeding or bruising caused by contact with the blood vessels located in the large, strong masseter muscles. Sensitivity: While you insert the needles, watch for the patient “hard blinking” their eyes; this provides feedback on their sensitivity. Often the points are very sensitive toward the end of the needle insertion, due to the number of nerves and blood vessels in that area. In some patients, the tip of the needle may touch the masseter muscle once it is fully inserted. This is a large muscle with lots of nerves and an ample blood supply, so it can be sensitive. In this case, when the needle is removed, there may be a drop of blood, and the point may bruise a little bit. Parallel appearance: When needled together, the needle handles will be parallel to each other after insertion. Handles crossing: Depending upon the size of the ball of the patient’s chin, the needle handles may cross when 1010.20 Water Gold is needled. Alternative needle technique: Dr. Young suggested to bilaterally thread a single needle from 1010.20 Water Gold toward 1010.19 Water Through in the direction of the Lung area on the cheek. Note: I tried this technique for about six months but found four needles to be more effective. Areas of influence: This area of the face relates to water. Needling toward the left side of the face influences metal. Needling toward the right side of the face influences earth. Needle retention: On occasion I have sent patients home with these needles retained, and asked them to return for removal in a few hours. This way, in the treatment of chronic cough or chronic lower back pain, the points have more time to work. If I am needling the points “to go,” the needles must be angled slightly downward (to counteract gravity and the weight of the needle handle) and inserted 1.0 cun, so as not to walk their way out. I also show the patient how to ease them back in, as they frequently start to come out when the patient talks too much. If a needle falls out completely, the patient is instructed to bring it back to me for disposal and not to reinsert. I may teach the patient to use just acupressure without needles as a self- treatment. Depth: 0.5-1.2 cun
comments: Water Gold/Water Through with 88.17-88.19 Four Horses: I cannot speak highly enough about this combination of points and find myself using it all day, every day, in my clinic. Water Gold/Water Through points treat Kidney and Lung, while 88.17-88.19 Four Horses points treat Lung and Liver. Used together, these point patterns are extraordinary for all lung diseases, especially asthma or bronchitis due to allergies. This is always my “go-to” combination for severe common cold, bronchitis, cough, pleurisy, or emphysema. Because Four Horses strongly tonifies the qi, and Water Gold/Water Through tonifies the Kidneys, this combination is very helpful when treating chronic lung diseases of the weak or elderly, including: pneumonia, COPD, cystic fibrosis, bronchiectasis and lung tumors. Sometimes I also add LU5, and almost always add A.04 San Cha Three. •  Energetic pathways: Due to their location on the chin, Water Gold and Water Through are easy to locate and needle, making them very clinically useful. They are chosen to treat conditions such as cough or asthma, and they are often combined with other points to refine or hone the direction of the treatment or improve a treatment outcome (see Combinations below). These marvelous points increase the power of the Kidney qi, which comes from the Kidney and Lung, and this is reflected in the point names. “Water” indicates a connection to the Kidney, while “Gold” indicates a connection to metal and the Lungs. Water Gold/Water Through points have the Reaction Area of Kidney and were two of Master Tung’s favorite points for tonifying and strengthening the Kidneys. •  Regulating qi and blood: The Large Intestine meridian is internally connected to the Lung and goes around the mouth, ending at LI20 to connect to the Stomach meridian, and tonifying the earth to produce metal. Because the Yang Ming (ST/LI) channel has more qi and more blood, Water Gold/Water Through points are effective in regulating qi and blood, strengthening the Lung and Kidneys. •  Diagnostic clues: A green hue around the mouth and chin is a sign of Kidney weakness and could indicate chronic Kidney deficiency in cases such as asthma and lower back pain. Additionally, darkness around the eyes, especially under the eyes and/or extending through the area of the lacrimal bone, indicates extreme depletion and might also occur with dizziness, blurred vision and lower back pain. In patients who have received a kidney transplant, I have noticed extreme discoloration in this area. •  Diagnostic signs of Kidney deficiency (Dr. Lee, 1992): •  Darkness under the eyes: “These points treat Kidney weakness and fatigue, In this case, the skin under the eyes will be dark and there will be dizziness, blurred vision, low back pain, etc.” •  Greenish hue under the chin: “According to Master Tung, if the Kidney weakness is severe, one will find a greenish or darkish vein under the chin. If one needles through this, it will bleed upon withdrawal of the needle. It may also cause this area to be black and blue for a few days. If the disease is not so severe, needling this point will not result in bleeding or bruising. If the skin is darkened in this location, needling here can effectively treat a variety of diseases.” •  Facial hue in asthma: “Patients with long-term asthma due to Kidney weakness also tend to have a green or gray facial complexion. Using these two points to treat this condition lightens the face color.” •  Little finger length: The little finger usually extends beyond the crease between the second and third phalanx of the ring finger. A short little finger indicates Kidney deficiency.Breathing (KD and LU): In Chinese medicine, breathing is viewed as the Kidney qi grasping the descending Lung qi and anchoring it. If the Kidneys are not able to receive the Lung qi, breathing is long and labored. If the Lung qi is not descending, there is panting. Water Gold/Water Through points connect metal (Lung) and water (Kidney) to strongly tonify the Kidney and powerfully regulate Lung qi. They are useful for symptoms of qi reversal, such as cough, asthma, hiccups and vomiting. •  Cough, asthma or bronchitis: 22.11 Earth Water is a three-point pattern and is Tung’s version of LU10. In TCM, LU10 Yu Ji is the Ying-Spring point of the Lung meridian; it clears Lung heat and sedates fire. 1010.19 Water Through has a similar function when combined with 1010.20 Water Gold. They are my favorite points for treating acute or chronic cough, asthma or bronchitis. Though acupuncture is very effective for calming asthma, in serious cases you must combine acupuncture with herbs. Cupping the upper back, including Ding Chuan (Extra Point located next to DU14), is always useful in treating early wind chill and often asthma, as well. •  Cough (Dr. Young): “1010.20 Water Gold calms the qi. For cough in the morning needle 1010.20 Water Gold with 22.11 Earth Water (Tung’s LU10). For cough in the afternoon needle Water Gold and 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5). A very simple treatment using just these two points” (Dr. Young, 2008). •  Transporting Points: In several of Dr. Young’s lectures, he provided the following examples of Transporting Points used for cough, with seasonal and time references: Seasonal uses: •  For cough in winter or at nighttime: Use Jing-Well points. Needle one point on each side with a thin piece of ginger inside the patient’s mouth, between the cheek and gum. •  For cough in spring or in the morning: Use Ying-Spring points. •  For cough in summer or at noon: Use Shu-Stream points. •  For cough in fall or afternoon: Use He-Sea points. Horary times:•  3:00–9:00 a.m. = morning: Use Ying-Spring points. •  9:00–3:00 p.m. = noon: Use Shu-Stream points. •  3:00–9:00 p.m. = afternoon: Use He–Sea points. •  9:00–3:00 a.m. = night: Use Jing–Well points. •  Low back pain (Active Qi Moving): I love the effects of Water Gold/Water Through in strengthening the lower back and legs, and have used them successfully many times over the years in the treatment of chronic lower back pain. Due to their location on the chin, these points allow the patient to gently walk around while the needles are retained (Active Qi Moving). I typically ask the patient to walk around the clinic. If this is not possible they may walk outside, though if they are elderly, I am reluctant to send them out of my sight.•  Acute lumbar sprain (Dr. Young): Needling opposite-side 1010.19 Water Through and 1010.13 Horse Gold Water offers immediate relief for acute lumbar sprain. Needle bilaterally if the condition affects both sides. The sooner you can needle these points after the onset of the condition, the more effective the treatment will be (Dr. Young, 2008).Note: For acute lumbar sprain, I also recommend the following treatments: 1.  Bleed veins found in the popliteal crease (UB39-UB40 area). 2.  Cup the lumbar/sacral area. 3.  Needle 11.12 Er Jiao Ming. •  Male sexual disorders: Water Through tonifies deficient Kidney qi, increasing energy (including sexual energy), and it is used to treat impotence, paralysis, and weakness in the legs. Kidney qi, derived from Kidney and Lung, is also a factor in prostate enlargement.•  Impotence and premature ejaculation: Needling 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors and 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through strongly tonifies the Kidney qi. However, the best point for impotence is LV1 Da Dun, the wood point on a wood channel, which opens orifices and drains dampness, and is a good point to relieve stress from nervousness. The Liver channel passes through and around the genitals, and LV1 Da Dun is a Jing-Well point that clears heat, frees the channels and calms the spirit. Premature ejaculation happens when the Kidney is hard to control; needle 77.18-77.21 Two or Three Emperors to treat both impotence and premature ejaculation. •  Arthritis pain due to Kidney (Dr. Lee): “These points treat joint pain due to Kidney deficiency. In this case, the kidneys are not adequately removing uric acid, which then deposits in the joints as crystals. One can tell if arthritis is due to Kidney deficiency by blackness or darkness of the chin” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Case history (acute back strain, Dr. Lee): “A physician came to my office at 6:00 am one day. That morning, while putting on his shoes, his back went into spasm. I needled these four points and had him walk around, twisting his back, lifting his legs, and trying to mobilize his back as much as possible. After the treatment, he returned home and took a short nap. At 10:00 am that same morning he went to his office and saw patients all day as usual. This doctor reported to me that when this had happened to him before, if he took very strong medicine for such back spasms, he had to stay in bed for three days and then would have side effects of headache and stomachache. If he took a lower dose so as not to have these side effects, he would typically have to remain in bed for seven days. When using these points to treat twisted back or back spasm, it is best to treat on the day it happens” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Case history (chronic lumbar pain, Dr. Lee): “While visiting a clinic in China, a patient was presented to me who had lower back pain and had been treated repeatedly without much improvement. He was leaning against the wall as I inserted four needles into his chin. The other doctors watched skeptically. Only a few minutes later, the patient let out a deep cough. In that moment, everyone present simultaneously realized that the patient was radically improved. His pain was practically gone. Those of us who primarily use Master Tung’s points are not surprised by this type of instantaneous result” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Hiccups: Master Tung needled 1010.20 Water Gold to treat a patient with severe, relentless hiccups (Dr. Wang, 2013).
combinations: Asthma (allergic): In this sequence, needle: 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) or A.04 San Cha Three, 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20). •  Asthma (severe): Choose from the following points, bleed every 7-10 days with acupuncture 2-3 times per week: 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), 77.09 Four Flower Middle, 77.14 Four Flower Outer, DU14 Da Zhui, UB13 Fei Shu, UB42 Po Hu and UB43 Gao Huang Shu.•  Asthma (severe): Potentially, use all of the following: Cup Ding Chuan (Extra Point); bleed 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5); bilaterally needle 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars, 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through. •  Asthma (with cold thighs): Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment (bilaterally needle ST36, SP6, LI11, LI4, LU7 in this sequence, tonifying the bottom and sedating the top); moxa SP10 Xue Hai. •  Asthma (with green chin): 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through. •  Asthma (with red chin): Deeply needle or bleed 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36). •  Asthma or cough with yin deficiency: 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors. If severe, add 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars. •  Asthma or cough with yang deficiency: 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36), 77.21 Man Emperor (SP6), if severe add 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars. •  Emphysema: 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), 22.11 Earth Water (Tung’s LU10), bleed 77.08-77.14 Four Flower line. •  Pneumonia: 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, 22.01-22.02 Double Child/ Double Fairy, needle or bleed 22.11 Earth Water (Tung’s LU10). If there is a dark vein, bleed 22.04 Da Bai. •  Cough: 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, 88.17-88.19 Four Horses or 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) (especially in the afternoon). •  Pleurisy: 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, A.04 San Cha Three, 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/ Water Through.

name: Shuijin, Water Gold (T 1010.20)
location: This point is on the face, close to the ST channel, about 1 cun inferior and 0.5 cun medial to the corner of the mouth, or 0.5 cun obliquely medial to Shuitong (T 1010.19) . | Johnson: 1010.20 Water Gold is located at the lateral corner of the ball of the chin (at the end of the “rainbow”), 0.5 cun inferior and medial to Water Through. Needle this point parallel to Water Through, toward the angle of the jaw.
primary_indications: Rheumatism Kidney deficiency causing back pain
johnson_indications: Chest or back pain due to gas
Joint pain due to Kidney deficiency
techniques: Needle obliquely and away from the midline, 0.1 - 0.5 cun . It is not necessary to be exact on the point location. Look for an area near this point that is dark or purplish in color to needle for best results. | Johnson: Dao Ma: Water Through and Water Gold are usually needled together in the combination called 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through.3 Patient positioning: Asthmatic patients may need a higher pillow or two pillows in order to breathe more comfortably; always ask them what they would prefer. Bilaterally needled: The points are usually needled bilaterally by threading the needles horizontally toward the corner of the jaw. In cases of one-sided pathology, they can be needled on the side opposite the indications. Superficially threaded: To keep the needle superficial, first tap the tip in just beneath the epidermis, on top of the muscle. Then, flatten the shaft of the needle against the skin by holding the handle up slightly while advancing the needle toward the corner of the jaw. When the needle is superficial enough and in the proper zone, you will be 3 Though the point numbers are reversed, I always refer to this combination as “Water Gold/Water Through.” able to see the tip of the needle progressing. I needle these four points in this manner (using only one hand) in order to keep my hands away from the patient’s face and eyes. Alternately, while you are learning to do this efficiently, once the needle tip is inserted you may press your thumb against the needle shaft while advancing the needle. This has the same function of flattening the needle shaft, using the surface of the chin as a guide, which keeps your needle trajectory as superficial as possible. Bruising: These points may bruise easily, especially if the needle is inserted too deeply. The two more lateral points are more likely to bruise. Keep the needle tip superficial enough to see it moving back toward the angle of the jaw. This prevents bleeding or bruising caused by contact with the blood vessels located in the large, strong masseter muscles. Sensitivity: While you insert the needles, watch for the patient “hard blinking” their eyes; this provides feedback on their sensitivity. Often the points are very sensitive toward the end of the needle insertion, due to the number of nerves and blood vessels in that area. In some patients, the tip of the needle may touch the masseter muscle once it is fully inserted. This is a large muscle with lots of nerves and an ample blood supply, so it can be sensitive. In this case, when the needle is removed, there may be a drop of blood, and the point may bruise a little bit. Parallel appearance: When needled together, the needle handles will be parallel to each other after insertion. Handles crossing: Depending upon the size of the ball of the patient’s chin, the needle handles may cross when 1010.20 Water Gold is needled. Alternative needle technique: Dr. Young suggested to bilaterally thread a single needle from 1010.20 Water Gold toward 1010.19 Water Through in the direction of the Lung area on the cheek. Note: I tried this technique for about six months but found four needles to be more effective. Areas of influence: This area of the face relates to water. Needling toward the left side of the face influences metal. Needling toward the right side of the face influences earth. Needle retention: On occasion I have sent patients home with these needles retained, and asked them to return for removal in a few hours. This way, in the treatment of chronic cough or chronic lower back pain, the points have more time to work. If I am needling the points “to go,” the needles must be angled slightly downward (to counteract gravity and the weight of the needle handle) and inserted 1.0 cun, so as not to walk their way out. I also show the patient how to ease them back in, as they frequently start to come out when the patient talks too much. If a needle falls out completely, the patient is instructed to bring it back to me for disposal and not to reinsert. I may teach the patient to use just acupressure without needles as a self- treatment. Depth: 0.5-1.2 cun
comments: Water Gold/Water Through with 88.17-88.19 Four Horses: I cannot speak highly enough about this combination of points and find myself using it all day, every day, in my clinic. Water Gold/Water Through points treat Kidney and Lung, while 88.17-88.19 Four Horses points treat Lung and Liver. Used together, these point patterns are extraordinary for all lung diseases, especially asthma or bronchitis due to allergies. This is always my “go-to” combination for severe common cold, bronchitis, cough, pleurisy, or emphysema. Because Four Horses strongly tonifies the qi, and Water Gold/Water Through tonifies the Kidneys, this combination is very helpful when treating chronic lung diseases of the weak or elderly, including: pneumonia, COPD, cystic fibrosis, bronchiectasis and lung tumors. Sometimes I also add LU5, and almost always add A.04 San Cha Three. •  Energetic pathways: Due to their location on the chin, Water Gold and Water Through are easy to locate and needle, making them very clinically useful. They are chosen to treat conditions such as cough or asthma, and they are often combined with other points to refine or hone the direction of the treatment or improve a treatment outcome (see Combinations below). These marvelous points increase the power of the Kidney qi, which comes from the Kidney and Lung, and this is reflected in the point names. “Water” indicates a connection to the Kidney, while “Gold” indicates a connection to metal and the Lungs. Water Gold/Water Through points have the Reaction Area of Kidney and were two of Master Tung’s favorite points for tonifying and strengthening the Kidneys. •  Regulating qi and blood: The Large Intestine meridian is internally connected to the Lung and goes around the mouth, ending at LI20 to connect to the Stomach meridian, and tonifying the earth to produce metal. Because the Yang Ming (ST/LI) channel has more qi and more blood, Water Gold/Water Through points are effective in regulating qi and blood, strengthening the Lung and Kidneys. •  Diagnostic clues: A green hue around the mouth and chin is a sign of Kidney weakness and could indicate chronic Kidney deficiency in cases such as asthma and lower back pain. Additionally, darkness around the eyes, especially under the eyes and/or extending through the area of the lacrimal bone, indicates extreme depletion and might also occur with dizziness, blurred vision and lower back pain. In patients who have received a kidney transplant, I have noticed extreme discoloration in this area. •  Diagnostic signs of Kidney deficiency (Dr. Lee, 1992): •  Darkness under the eyes: “These points treat Kidney weakness and fatigue, In this case, the skin under the eyes will be dark and there will be dizziness, blurred vision, low back pain, etc.” •  Greenish hue under the chin: “According to Master Tung, if the Kidney weakness is severe, one will find a greenish or darkish vein under the chin. If one needles through this, it will bleed upon withdrawal of the needle. It may also cause this area to be black and blue for a few days. If the disease is not so severe, needling this point will not result in bleeding or bruising. If the skin is darkened in this location, needling here can effectively treat a variety of diseases.” •  Facial hue in asthma: “Patients with long-term asthma due to Kidney weakness also tend to have a green or gray facial complexion. Using these two points to treat this condition lightens the face color.” •  Little finger length: The little finger usually extends beyond the crease between the second and third phalanx of the ring finger. A short little finger indicates Kidney deficiency.Breathing (KD and LU): In Chinese medicine, breathing is viewed as the Kidney qi grasping the descending Lung qi and anchoring it. name: Yuhuo, Jade Fire (T 1010.21)
location: This point overlaps with Sibai (ST 2) , which is in the depression of the infraorbital foramen directly below the pupil of the eye. | Johnson: Jade Fire is located in the infraorbital foramen of the maxilla bone, directly inferior to the center of the eyeball. This is the same location as ST2 Su Bai.
johnson_indications: Pain due to stagnation or deficiency of blood
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun | Johnson: Depth: 0.1-0.3.0 cun
comments: Regulates blood: Because Jade Fire has the Reaction Areas of the Heart and Liver, it regulates the blood and is used for any kind of pain due to blood deficiency or stagnation. Knee pain relates to the Heart disorders: All Tung’s points with “Fire” in their name treat the Heart and knee.

name: Biyi, Nose Wing (T 1010.22)
location: This point is in the depression on the alae of the nose, midway between the lateral border of the alae and the tip of the nose. | Johnson: Nose Wing is located at the end of the curl of the nasal ala, where many cultures pierce the nose. The needle is inserted through the nose into the nasal cavity; be careful not to contact the septum.
primary_indications: Pain due to qi deficiency and/or stagnation
secondary_indications: tongue stiffness or tightness with difficulty speaking
sore throat Pain in the limbs
nerve pain due to Kidney deficiency
johnson_indications: Severe pain due to qi deficiency or qi stagnation*
Whole-body pain due to Kidney deficiency*
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun . | Johnson: Unilaterally needle: This point is usually needled on the left side because it has a strong influence on qi, though it may be needled on the right for left-sided pain. The left side relates to males (Lung – qi), while the right side relates to females (Liver – blood). Needling technique: Pushing gently against the tip of the nose will cause the nasal ala to flare out and give you more room to needle. To desensitize the point, place the tip of the needle against the point and press it in without inserting (similar to the technique for needling finger points). Then, insert quickly without bouncing, making sure not to hit the septum inside the nose. Stimulation: Provide strong stimulation for a few seconds, then leave the needle alone. Painful point: This point is very painful when needled. It is fine once you get through the nose, but be sure not to hit the septum, as this would be excruciating. Needling this point always makes the patient’s eyes water. Warn the patient ahead of time so they will not feel embarrassed about crying. Retention time: Retain the needle for at least one hour. If left longer, it will be more energizing, but do not leave the needle overnight. Many students ask to have this point needled at the end of an intense three-day seminar, when they have a long distance to drive before they sleep. It is both energizing and very good for leg pain from driving. Needle size: I needle this point with a thin 0.16 x 15mm needle (Chinese gauge 40, Japanese #1 gauge). Depth: 0.1-0.3 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Nose Wing is essential in cases of real exhaustion or qi deficiency because it has the Reaction Areas of the Lung, Spleen and Kidney. Nose Wing warms the yang, increases energy, clears the brain and wakes a tired spirit. It is excellent for treating soreness and pain of the whole body. Sciatica due to qi deficiency: In combination with opposite-side 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/ Da Bai and 22.06-22.07 Zhong Bai/Xia Bai, Nose Wing is very good for sciatica due to qi deficiency. Tonifies yang (Dr. Young): “Nose Wing is located on the most protruded area of the face, where all of the yang energy gathers from the yang meridians of the face. For this reason, it can be selected to raise the yang qi of the entire body” (Dr. Young, 2008). Resolves pain (Dr. Lee) : “Nose Wing and 1010.21 Jade Fire are major points for quieting pain. Jade Fire treats all pain due to blood stasis, blood vacuity, and blood desertion. Nose Wing treats pain due to qi deficiency, qi desertion and qi congestion. It also clears the brain, relieves fatigue and clears the mind” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Tongue stiffness (Dr. Lee): “Some patients suffer from a stiff or tight tongue. Due to overwork, a quick temper, and suppressed anger, qi may congest in the supraorbital bone. If the patient pushes him/herself and never rests, they may tighten their jaws. After some time, such physical and emotional stress may weaken the Heart. Because the tongue is the portal of the Heart, it may become tight or stiff” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Sciatica due to qi deficiency: 1010.22 Nose Wing, 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, and/or 22.06-22.07 Zhong Bai/Xia Bai. Note: Though Nose Wing is usually needled on the left side, it may be needled on the right side when treating left-sided sciatica.

name: Zhouhuo, State Fire (T 1010.23)
location: This point is 1.5 cun superior to the ear apex, close to Shuaigu (GB 8) . | Johnson: State Fire is located 1.5 cun superior to the apex of the ear.
johnson_indications: Kidney yin deficient tiredness, lack of strength in the four limbs and/or lower back pain.
UB channel sciatica due to Lung deficiency
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun obliquely in any direction. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Too sensitive: Due to the large number of blood vessels traversing the side of the head, this area is very sensitive. Because bleeding 99.08 Ear Apex is equally effective and less sensitive than this point, I usually choose Ear Apex instead. Depth: 0.1-0.3.0 cun Sensitivity: Due to the many blood vessels traversing the side of the head, this point can be very sensitive, so downsize your needle gauge. Angle of insertion: Insert superficially toward the ear. Depth: 0.2-0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Because it has the Reaction Area of Heart, and its name includes “Fire,” State Fire treats cardiovascular diseases. Energetic pathways: Because of the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yang (UB), this point is used to treat sciatica resulting from Lung deficiency. State Gold has the Reaction Area of the Lung, and “Gold” in the point name indicates the connection to metal and the Lung. State Gold is a crossing point of the San Jiao, Gallbladder and Urinary Bladder meridians, all of which are involved in sciatica.

name: Zhoujin, State Gold (T 1010.24)
location: This point is on the GB channel, 1.5 cun superior and 1 cun posterior to the ear apex. | Johnson: State Gold is located 1.5 cun superior and 1.0 cun posterior to the ear apex.
johnson_indications: UB channel sciatica due to Lung deficiency
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun obliquely in any direction. This point can also be bled.
comments: Energetic pathways: Because of the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yang (UB), this point is used to treat sciatica resulting from Lung deficiency. State Gold has the Reaction Area of the Lung, and “Gold” in the point name indicates the connection to metal and the Lung.
