State Gold is a crossing point of the San Jiao, Gallbladder and Urinary Bladder meridians, all of which are involved in sciatica.

name: Zhoushui, State Water (T 1010.25)
location: This is a two-point set on the Du (governing) channel with the first point on the tip of the external occipital protuberance and the second point 0.8 cun above the first. | Johnson: State Water is a two-point pattern. The first point is located on top of the occipital protuberance. The second point is located 0.8 cun superior to the first point.
primary_indications: weakness and numbness of the lower extremities
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun or obliquely, touching the bone. Needling to touch the skull will stimulate the Kidney to help treat spinal pain. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Patient positioning: When inserting State Water, be sure that the patient does not hold their chin down. If they hold their chin down, the neck is tight, and it should be relaxed when these points are needled. Needle technique: Start by sliding your finger up the center of the back of the neck into the posterior hairline, locating the occipital notch and parting the hair. Move up and over the notch until your finger is centered on the top of the occipital protuberance. Insert the needle horizontally downward, flattening the shaft of the needle against the patient’s head in order to thread it superficially. The second needle is located 0.8 cun superior to the first and is also threaded superficially downward until it contacts the first needle. Occasionally, a needle will tap the bone of the occipital protuberance. If this occurs, back the needle out slightly and use a curving needle technique to lift the tip of the needle up and over the bone. You may need to pull up a bit of hair/scalp just above the shaft of the needle to create a space for the needle to slide over the bone. Rotating the neck: After insertion, have the patient rotate their head to the left and right to verify that there is no muscular tension on the needles. Combining with other needles to treat low back pain: I often combine State Water with 55.04 Flower Bone Three and 55.05 Flower Bone Four. I needle State Water first, while the patient is standing. Because patients with lower back pain have an extremely difficult time lying on their stomach, once I have needled Flower Bone Three and Flower Bone Four with the patient lying face down on the table, I then help them sit up by swinging their legs over the side of the table. From this position it is easier for them to pivot their hips and lie back down, face up. Carefully cup the back of their head, with your hand covering the needles, while they reposition their head on the pillow. Because the State Water needles are inserted horizontally beneath the skin, they are flattened between the head and the pillow as long as the patient does not move around. Place a bolster under the legs, elevating the feet to avoid putting additional stress on the lumbar spine. This is a comfortable position for the patient to maintain during a treatment of at least one hour. Depth: 0.5-0.8 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: “Water” in the point name indicates that these points relate to the Kidney. State Water points are located on the DU channel and therefore can treat the entire spine, but are especially good for the lumbar spine and specifically the area of L5-S1. The DU Mai warms the yang and treats weakness of the lower limbs. Herniated disc (L5-S1): When I am treating a severely protruding disk at L5-S1, I often needle State Water in combination with 55.04-55.05 Flower Bone Three/Flower Bone Four. State Water sends the qi down the spine, whereas Flower Bone Three and Flower Bone Four send the qi up the spine; the qi meets at the hinge (L5-S1 area). Also consider bleeding veins found in the popliteal crease (UB39-UB40 area) to release pressure in the lower back. If there is severe sciatica, bleed DT.08 or DT.09 (palpate for tenderness). See needling instructions above for combining State Water with Flower Bone Three and Flower Bone Four. Treating low back pain (Dr. Lee): “I use State Water quite often to treat lower back pain. While the needles are in place, I have the patient mobilize their lower back. The treatment should continue until their pain or numbness is relieved.
combinations: Lower back pain: 1010.25 State Water, cup the back, then needle 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/ Da Bai, SI3 Hou Xi, UB65 Shu Gu. •  Coccyx or sacral pain, lower back pain (L5-S1), or sciatica: 1010.25 State Water, 55.04-55.05 Flower Bone Three/Flower Bone Four.

name: Dajian, Great Distance (T 11.01)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.01 Dajian , is located on the palmar aspect of the index finger, midway along the radial margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line B). | Johnson: 11.01-11.05 Hernia Points are a five-point unit. These five points are located on the palmar surface of the index finger, measured from the proximal crease of each phalange: 11.05 is located in the center of the first phalange (C-line). 11.01 is located on the B-line (radial/thumb side of the index finger) at the same level as 11.05. 11.02 is distal to 11.01, also on the B-line, halfway between 11.01 and the most proximal line of the first and second phalangeal joint. 11.03 and 11.04 are located on the second phalange, on the B-line, evenly spaced between the proximal creases of the first and second phalanx.
primary_indications: bearing down sensation of the testicles
abdominal distension or bloating Heart disease
shortness of breath Acute or chronic enteritis
johnson_indications: Pain at the corner of the eye
techniques: Needle perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, towards the dorsal aspect of the hand. Needle contralateral to the affected side. For HT conditions, needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun . For SI conditions, hernia, knee pain, and other conditions, needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun . Bleeding is also effective for hernia if there are nearby veins or dark spots. | Johnson: Needle unilaterally only: Points are usually needled on the left side for men, right side for women. However, always treat the side opposite the location of symptoms. If the patient has multiple hernias use the left side only. Needle size and gauge: I use a 15mm x 0.16 needle (Japanese 1 gauge or Chinese 40 gauge) and insert it at least halfway on most patients, depending upon the size of their finger. Holding the patient’s hand, place your fingers on the dorsum of the patient’s fingers and monitor the depth of insertion by feeling the pressure of the approaching needle tip, stopping before making contact with the underside of the epidermis. Depths: Heart disease: 0.3.0 cun Hernia: 0.2-0.3 cun Knee and lower leg: 0.3-0.4 cun
comments: 11.01-11.05 are collectively known as the Hernia Points: They are most frequently used for hernia. These points are not used for hiatal hernia. In the treatment of intestinal hernia, it is not necessary to needle all five points, but I always do to strengthen the effect. LV1 Da Dun can be used as a Guiding Point. 11.05 Middle Distance regulates the heart rate: In an emergency situation, if a needle is not available, bury your fingernail into the point to relieve chest pain due to angina. In the clinic, when treating a patient with an irregular heart rate, I usually needle Middle Distance on its own for ten minutes to stabilize the heart before proceeding. This is especially helpful in the treatment of elderly patients. Please remember this point; in an emergency it can make a difference between life and death. Moxibustion and bleeding to treat hernia: Place a moxa pot or moxa heat pack with padding on the bulging hernia to cause it to shrink. Bleed small veins in the vicinity of the medial malleolus to treat hernia and many other lower jiao conditions. Energetic pathways: The Hand Yang Ming (LI) meridian connects with the Foot Jue Yin (LV) meridian, so there are many Liver indications for these points, including vertigo, blurred vision and urethritis. Due to the internal/external connection between the Large Intestine and Lung, the points also treat bronchitis and yellow phlegm. Because fingers correspond to the lower jiao, there are also indications such as hernia, urinary bladder infection, urethra and uterine pain. Knee pain: In Tung’s points system, all points that treat the Heart also treat the knee, including these; however, there are many points that are better for knee pain.
combinations: Hernia: 11.01 Great Distance, 11.02 Small Distance, 11.04 External Distance, 11.05 Middle Distance and LV1 (Guiding Point). Urinary tract infection and urethra pain: 11.01 Great Distance and 11.04 External Distance.
reaction_areas: Heart, Small Intestine and Large Intestine

name: Xiaojian, Small Distance (T 11.02)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.02 Xiaojian , is located on the palmar aspect of the index finger, along the radial margin of the proximal phalangeal bone, ¾ distal from the MCP joint (line B). | Johnson: See 11.01 Great Distance for location.
primary_indications: Hernia Acute and chronic enteritis Dyspnea
secondary_indications: gan ji (infantile malnutrition) TMJ pain Tonsillitis
johnson_indications: Pain at the corner of the eye
See 11.01 Great Distance for needling notes, comments and combinations.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, towards the dorsal aspect of the hand. For HT and LU conditions, needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun . For hernia, SI conditions, and knee pain and all other conditions, needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun . Bleeding is also effective for hernia if there are nearby veins or dark spots. Needle contralateral to the affected side.
comments: See 11.01 Great Distance
combinations: See 11.01 Great Distance
reaction_areas: Heart, Small Intestine and Large Intestine

name: Fujian, Floating Distance (T 11.03)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.03 Fujian , is on the palmar aspect of the index finger, along the radial margin of the middle phalangeal bone (line B). Divide the middle phalanx into thirds, and locate this point at the junction of the distal 1/3 and middle 1/3 of this distance. | Johnson: See 11.01 Great Distance for location.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, 0.1 - 0.2 cun towards the dorsal aspect of the hand. Bleeding is also effective for hernia if there are nearby veins or dark spots. The therapeutic effect is most apparent when yellow fluids can be squeezed out when bleeding this point. | Johnson: See 11.01 Great Distance for needling notes.
comments: Energetic pathways: Due to the relationship between the Hand and Foot Yang Ming (LI/ST), this point treats toothache and stomachache. Needle this point with 11.04 External Distance for these indications.
combinations: See 11.01 Great Distance for combinations.

name: Waijian, External Distance (T 11.04)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.04 Waijian , is located on the palmar aspect of the index finger, along the radial margin of the middle phalangeal bone (line B). Divide the middle phalanx into thirds, and locate this point at the junction of the proximal 1/3 and middle 1/3 of this distance. | Johnson: See 11.01 Great Distance for location.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, 0.1 - 0.2 cun towards the dorsal aspect of the hand. Needle contralateral to the affected side. Bleeding is also effective for hernia if there are nearby veins or dark spots. The therapeutic effect is most apparent when yellow fluids can be squeezed out when bleeding this point. | Johnson: See 11.01 Great Distance for needling notes.
comments: Energetic pathways: Due to the relationship between the Hand and Foot Yang Ming (LI/ST), this point treats toothache and stomachache (needle this point with 11.03 Floating Distance for these indications).
combinations: See 11.01 Great Distance for combinations.

name: Zhongjian, Middle Distance (T 11.05)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.05 Zhongjian , is located on the palmar aspect of index finger, at the center of the proximal phalanx (line C). | Johnson: See 11.01 Great Distance for location.
secondary_indications: soreness and pain of the eyes Knee pain
johnson_indications: Pain at the corner of the eye
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.25 cun . For HT, LU, and head conditions, needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun deep. For hernia and knee pain, 0.25 cun deep. Bleeding is also effective for hernia if there are nearby veins or dark spots. Needle contralateral to the affected side. | Johnson: 11.05 needling: For points located in the center of a phalange, pinch up the skin prior to needling. Insert the needle slowly until you gently contact the periosteum. See 11.01 Great Distance for additional needling notes.
comments: Case history (heart disease, Dr. Lee): “One day I was in Tianjin in the People’s Republic of China. I was visiting a famous hospital there and talked to a young doctor in the emergency room where cardiac patients were brought. Nowadays in China heart attack patients are treated with a combination of modern Western medicines and traditional Chinese medicines administered intravenously. In China today, mostly what they know about acupuncture is the twelve or fourteen regular channel system. I thought to show the doctors in this hospital something about Master Tung’s extraordinary points. I showed this young doctor in the emergency room 11.05 Middle Distance and told him its indications and that it is especially good for heart conditions. Some time later, a man was brought into the emergency room suffering from a heart attack. His face was cyanotic and he could not breathe freely. Middle Distance is also indicated for trouble breathing. Therefore, this young doctor picked up a short needle and immediately inserted it in the area of Middle Distance. The man took a deep breath and said thank you to the young doctor since now he could breathe. This young doctor became famous in this hospital for using this point. When others would ask him about it, he would only smile and not tell them where he had learned it” (Dr. Lee, 1992). See 11.01 Great Distance for additional comments.
combinations: Anxiety (with palpitations): 11.05 Middle Distance with the proximal point of 11.17 Wood (Anger) is an effective combination to treat anxiety accompanied by palpitations or rapid heartbeat (Renaud). Irregular heart rate: Unilaterally needle 11.05 Middle Distance or 11.19 Heart Normal; bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master; needling PC6 Nei Guan is also effective. See 11.01 Great Distance for hernia and other combinations unrelated to heart disease.

name: Huanchao, Return to the Nest (T 11.06)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.06 Huanchao , is located on the palmar aspect of the ring finger, at the center along the ulnar aspect of the middle phalanx (line E). | Johnson: Return to the Nest is located on the ulnar side of the middle phalange of the ring finger, centered between the second and third finger creases, just palmar to the intersection of the red and white skin.
primary_indications: Any reproductive and gynecological disorders Menstrual disorders
johnson_indications: Menopausal hot flashes, night sweats, irritability and depression*
Gynecological issues (due to Liver qi stagnation)*
Blocked fallopian tube (often due to phlegm)*
Cyclic migraines (may have nausea, vomiting, photophobia)*
Liver qi stagnation in the uterus*
Uterine pain following abortion or miscarriage*
Tipped uterus leading to back pain and frequent urination*
Leucorrhea with red or white discharge (if leukorrhea persists for 10 years or more, consider the possibility of cancer)*
Vaginal swelling especially during prolonged labor (with excess Liver or high blood pressure)*
Abdominal pain due to reproductive issues
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun . The effect to treat the KI channel is enhanced when the needle tip touches the bone. Alternatively, it can also be needled from the dorsal aspect of the phalange, adjacent to the edge of the bone (cutting or shaving the bone technique). | Johnson: Needle unilaterally only: It is fine to needle either side (usually combined with 11.24 Gynecological Points on the opposite hand). Needle size and gauge: I use a 15mm x 0.16 needle (Japanese 1 gauge or Chinese 40 gauge), inserted just palmar to the intersection of red and white skin in order to avoid immediately striking the side of the phalange. In order to wrap the needle under the bone, I use a curving needle technique, inserting the tip and then introducing a curve in the shaft by holding the handle at a 90-degree angle to the tip. The goal is to insert the needle between the bone and the tendon, as this provides a Kidney function by contacting the palmar surface of the bone (bone treats bone) and a Liver function (tendon treats tendon). Point Location and Needling Technique, for curving needle technique on this point. Avoiding blood vessels: It is important to look carefully for blood vessels, as they are frequently found in the area of this point. Vessels may not be obvious, but I have learned an effective way to identify them. Blood vessels beneath the surface cast a shadow, which causes the skin to appear slightly darker than the surrounding area. If we look carefully and choose the more pink or white skin (relatively speaking, considering skin tone), we are far more likely to avoid blood vessels. If the patient feels a sharp burning sensation when Return to the Nest is needled, you have struck a blood vessel. Remove the needle and start again. If you should hit a blood vessel, note its location in your chart so you can avoid it in the future. Pegging a tendon: You have pegged a tendon if you see a small depression around the needle where it enters the skin. It will not be particularly sensitive, but the finger will not be able to move at all and the needle will not rotate easily to stimulate the point. If this happens, withdraw the needle until its tip is just under the epidermis and redirect it slightly. Needle stimulation: I often apply strong stimulation to the needle once it is in place, rotating quickly, clockwise and counterclockwise, carefully watching the patient’s eyes for any sign of discomfort (hard blinking). As this point is used to open blocked fallopian tubes and stop menstrual cramps immediately, strong stimulation is required. 5 Cited in Dr. Wang (2013) 39 Finger Points Needle retention: Retain the needle for 45 minutes to one hour or until you recognize that the treatment is complete. Combining points for gynecological issues: 11.17 Wood (Anger) is frequently used in combination with Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points. When combining these points, first needle 11.17 Wood (Anger) and 11.24 Gynecological Points on the patient’s left hand, followed by 11.06 Return to the Nest on the right hand. This arrangement allows you to best position the patient’s hands after needling, because the Gynecological Points combine better with Wood (Anger) than with Return to the Nest. If you are needling the points multiple times in one week (or even daily in the case of infertility) you can alternate the arrangement by needling Wood (Anger) with Return to the Nest on the patient’s left hand, and needling Gynecological Points on the right hand. We always needle Wood (Anger) on the left side (opposite the liver). Gynecological Points and Return to the Nest can be needled on either hand, and each can be needled unilaterally, but they should never both be needled on the same hand. Alternative needling methods: Other Tung’s points practitioners describe needling Return to the Nest by picking up the point at the junction of red and white skin (E-line or A-line), from a dorsal direction. In my opinion, once the finger is relaxed, the location appears the same as in the manner described above. I like using a curving needle technique on Return to the Nest because the Kidney governs hormones and bones, and bone treats bone, so by bringing the shaft of the needle into contact with the palmar surface of the bone, we create a strong Kidney tonification. Depth: 0.3.0 cun
comments: 11.06 combined with 11.24: Unilaterally needled, primarily for women, Return to the Nest is usually combined with 11.24 Gynecological Points to treat all gynecological diseases, as it regulates female hormones. Return to the Nest has a stronger effect on the ovaries, whereas 11.24 Gynecological Points adjusts the qi of the uterus. 11.06 regulates blood (cycles), while 11.24 regulates qi. Function: Return to the Nest releases Liver qi stagnation, quiets the womb, and calms the fetus. It has a strong tonification and regulatory effect on the Kidney, Liver and San Jiao. Cyclical symptoms: Any symptoms that are cyclic in nature have an ovarian component because the ovaries regulate the menstrual rhythm. Dysmenorrhea: 11.06 relieves dysmenorrhea better than SP6 San Yin Jiao because Return to the Nest prevents acute or chronic cramping from reoccurring. However, SP6 with electrical stimulation is more effective for intense cramping, especially on the first day of the period once full bleeding has commenced. Unfortunately, this powerful effect is only temporary and cannot be implemented prior to menstruation. Pregnancy: Return to the Nest quiets the womb and calms the fetus; therefore, it can be used in any kind of pregnancy-related illness. Points that are used to treat infertility are always safe to use during pregnancy. This knowledge is helpful, as the patient may not know when she has conceived. Labor and delivery: See Comments, KD1 Yong Quan for an ‘Easy Delivery Formula’ and induction protocol. Energetic pathways: In the name of this point, “nest” refers to the womb. Multiple channels affect female reproductive organs, but primarily we think of the Liver and Kidney channels. Return to the Nest is located on the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) channel and is used to regulate hormones (ovaries) because of the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and the Foot Shao Yin (KD). The Hand and Foot Shao Yang (SJ/GB) connect to the Liver through the internal/external relationship between the Gallbladder and Liver. This makes Return to the Nest effective in the treatment of PMS (irritability and depression), irregular menstrual cycles, dysmenorrhea, cyclic migraines, and any gynecological issue related to the Liver and hormonal functions. We can also derive a Liver connection through the Hand and Foot Jue Yin relationship, as the Hand Jue Yin (PC) channel splits at PC8 Lao Gong and proceeds to the tips of the middle and ring fingers, connecting with the San Jiao channel through Return to the Nest. 11.06 combined with 11.17 Wood (Anger) : Tung’s fantastic points, 11.17 Wood (Anger), are also related to Liver and PMS. This is because female reproductive issues such as breast pain, migraines, irritability, depression, dysmenorrhea, fibroid cysts and tumors, and emotional instability due to menopause are often associated with Liver imbalance. Diagnostic tools: When there is pain in the lower jiao, I often use opposite-side 66.05 Golden Gate and Return to the Nest as diagnostic tools. Golden Gate usually clears any kind of gastrointestinal discomfort. If it does not relieve the pain, I remove the needle and then needle Return to the Nest with strong stimulation. If there is still no change, the discomfort is likely urinary in origin. Tipped uterus: Return to the Nest treats lower back pain due to tipped uterus. The uterus does not tilt without a reason, and usually the cause is multiple fibroids or tumors putting pressure on the bladder and the nerves of the lower back, thus causing frequent urination and lower back pain. Also see 11.24 Gynecological Points, Comments. Yoga pose for retroverted uterus: Retroverted uterus can also be caused by holding the urine too long or not getting enough bed rest after childbirth. When this condition is treated with 11.06 and 11.24, the patient should be asked to do the following exercise (Child’s Pose in Hatha yoga) twice daily, in the morning before arising and at night before going to bed. With an empty bladder, the woman should kneel down, lay her chest on her thighs, and stretch her arms out over her head for a few minutes. This increases the angle of the hips to more than 90 degrees, allowing gravity to help pull the uterus forward (Dr. Lee, 1992). Uterine pain due to abortion: “For uterine pain due to abortion, use only 11.06. In my experience, bilateral needling of SP6 San Yin Jiao only relieves this pain for about 10 minutes. With one needle, Return to the Nest relieves such pain for four to five hours. For uterine pain with pus due to infection, use this point with REN3 Zhong Ji and Zi Gong (Extra Points 3.0 cun lateral to REN3). Four or five treatments will relieve the pain” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Bleeding technique: Look for blood vessels in the area of SP6 San Yin Jiao, often associated with lower jiao stagnation. Use pricking bleeding techniques to bleed these vessels, and needle 11.06 and 11.24. This bleeding technique is also effective for urinary and lower bowel disorders. Neck and shoulder pain: Because Return to the Nest is found on the San Jiao channel, it functions like SJ5 Wai Guan in the treatment of neck, shoulder and upper arm pain. I would never choose it specifically to treat musculoskeletal issues, but patients might tell you that their pain has improved after receiving this point. Infertility: If the patient’s little finger does not extend to the crease between the second and third phalange of the ring finger, it is diagnostic for Kidney deficiency and is always a sign of infertility (Dr. Young, 2008). Male reproductive: Dr. Wang cites Dr. Liu in saying that Return to the Nest can be used to treat prostatitis (due to cold evil) in older males because it promotes the yang qi of the San Jiao. My dear friend, Dr. Ta Viet Hoang, has used Return to the Nest successfully in treating scrotal inflammation.
combinations: Infertility: 11.06 Return to the Nest on one side, 11.24 Gynecological Points on the other side (alternate sides daily for two months; stop after conception). Points to strengthen and regulate Spleen, Liver and Kidney: 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters, Three Plum Blossom, 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points and 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. Menopause: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. If emotional, add 11.17 Wood (Anger), Four Gates, Prefrontal Scalp Points, DU20. Amenorrhea: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with ST25 Tian Shu (Yang Ming Mu point), 66.15 Water Fairy (Tung’s KD5), and REN24 Cheng Jiang (Ren Mai - Jing Well). Dysmenorrhea: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43) or ST44 Xian Gu; SP6 San Yin Jiao (needled with or without electric or pricking bleeding); REN24 Cheng Jiang; 66.02 Wood Wife, 66.03 Fire Hardness. Irregular menses: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters or Three Plum Blossom. Promoting conception: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, Three Plum Blossom (not after ovulation). Habitual miscarriage: 11.06 Return to the Nest on one side, 11.24 Gynecological Points on the other side, 88.10-88.11 Kidney Passing Points.

name: Zhisima, Finger Four Horses (T 11.07)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.07 Zhisima , is a three-point set on the dorsal aspect of the index finger, on the ulnar margin of the middle phalangeal bone (line F). Divide the middle phalanx into fourths, and locate these three points at ½, ¼, and ¾ of the distance between the PIP and DIP joints. | Johnson: This three-point unit is located on the dorsal surface of the index finger, with points evenly spaced on the ulnar line (0.2 cun lateral to the midline) of the middle phalange.
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, towards the palm. | Johnson: Depth: 0.2-0.3.0 cun
comments: Finger Four Horses and Leg Four Horses: These points share a similar function with 88.17-88.19 Four Horses on the leg, but the finger points are far less effective because the large thigh muscles have more qi and blood and therefore a more powerful effect. For skin diseases only on the hands, use 11.07 Finger Four Horses with the addition of bilateral 11.17 Wood (Anger). Hormonal splotches: I most frequently use these points for splotchy dark patches on the face from hormonal imbalances, often seen during menopause and sometimes in pregnancy. Energetic pathways: Finger Four Horses is located on the Large Intestine meridian. Due to the internal/external connection between the Lung and Large Intestine meridians, and the fact that Lung governs skin, this point is effective for skin diseases. These points can be used to treat joint pain and breast issues, due to the special relationship between the Hand Yang Ming (LI) and the Foot Jue Yin (LV).
combinations: Dermatitis (on the hands): 11.07 Finger Four Horses, 11.17 Wood (Anger).

name: Zhiwujin & Zhiqianjin, Finger Five Gold (T 11.08)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.08 Zhiwujin & Zhiqianjin , is a two-point set on the dorsal aspect of the index finger, along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line F). Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 of the distance between the PIP and MCP joints. | Johnson: This two-point unit is located on the dorsal surface of the index finger; the points are equally spaced on the ulnar line of the proximal phalange.
secondary_indications: Fish bone stuck in the throat
johnson_indications: Fish bone stuck in the throat*
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 - 0.3 cun , adjacent to the edge of the bone towards the palm. | Johnson: Depth: 0.3.0 cun, needled alongside the proximal phalange
comments: Finger, Arm and Leg Five Gold/One Thousand Gold: All points whose names include “Jin/Gold” are effective for diseases of the abdomen, intestine and throat, due to the internal/external connection of the Lung and Large Intestine (metal element). However, for the same conditions, 33.08-33.09 Arm Five/One Thousand Gold and 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold are far more powerful, though their names are similar. Fish bone: Finger Five Gold/Finger Thousand Gold is primarily needled for fish bone stuck in the throat. 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold or the TCM points PC5 Jian Shi and LI3 San Jian also may be needled for this condition. My teacher, Dr. Lee, would have the patient slowly drink a mixture of vinegar and honey, as vinegar dissolves fish bones. Abdominal pain: 11.08 is indicated for abdominal pain because of the connection between the Hand and Foot Yang Ming (LI/ST). Opposite side 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43) is much more powerful, and I always choose it first for gastrointestinal abdominal pain.

name: Xinxi, Heart Knee (T 11.09)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.09 Xinxi , is a two-point set on the dorsal side of the middle finger, ulnar and radial to the midpoint of the middle phalanx, along the margins of the phalangeal bone (lines F and H). | Johnson: Heart Knee is a two-point unit located on the dorsal surface of the middle finger; the points are centered on either side of the second phalange.
primary_indications: Knee pain around Ququan (LR 8) Neck pain
johnson_indications: Deformed knees (due to arthritis or bone spur)*
Knee pain (caused by Heart fatigue or overwork)*
Shoulder and scapular pain (due to overwork)
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, towards the palm. | Johnson: Contact the bone: Slide the needles along both sides of the medial phalange, touching the bone. Patients’ phalanx differ in width. Because we want to slide the needle alongside the phalange, we need to determine its proper width. Begin by placing the needles closer together than you might expect is necessary in order to find the edges of the phalange. If the needle taps the bone, lift it up and angle it slightly away from the bone until it slides alongside the medial phalange. This may cause the needle handles to cross in the middle, which is not a problem. 45 Finger Points Positioning: Place fingers from your non-needling hand under the palmar surface of the patient’s fingers so you feel the pressure of the needle tip approaching your fingers as it advances. Stop before making contact with the underside of the patient’s epidermis, as this surface is just as sensitive as the exterior one. Depth: 0.3.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: In Master Tung’s system, all points that treat the Heart also treat the knees. The Heart governs blood and blood vessels, and because we do not treat the Heart directly but treat it through the Pericardium and Stomach meridians, opposite side PC6 Nei Guan is often chosen in the treatment of knee pain. Located on the middle finger, which relates to the Pericardium channel, Heart Knee points utilize the special relationship between the Hand Jue Yin (PC) and the Foot Yang Ming (ST) channels, the latter traversing the knee joint. Degenerative knee pain: Heart Knee is best used for degenerative knee pain and not for injury. These points are outstandingly effective in the treatment of chronic or deficient knee pain, especially with the elderly. The points are needled bilaterally because the degenerative process is bilateral, although one knee may be more painful than the other. Active Qi Moving: One of the advantages of Heart Knee is that the patient can go for a gentle stroll while the needles are retained (Active Qi Moving technique). Scapular and back pain (due to overwork): The back of the middle finger corresponds to the spine; therefore, Heart Knee can be needled for scapular, shoulder and whole spine pain (similar to UB60 Kun Lun). However, when treating spine pain, my preference is always to bleed UB40 Wei Zhong.

name: Muhuo, Wood Fire (T 11.10)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.10 Muhuo , is located on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, at the center of the DIP joint (line G). | Johnson: Wood Fire is located on the dorsum of the middle finger, at the very center of the most distal joint crease, needled horizontally toward the little finger. Cautions: Raises blood pressure: Needle 11.10 Wood Fire as soon as possible following a stroke. Keep track of the number of times you use Wood Fire. The first five times Wood Fire is needled, retention must be for five minutes only (set a timer and pay close attention to it). The next five times, needle retention is for three minutes only. After the tenth treatment, needle retention must be for one minute only. These retention times must be strictly observed due to Wood Fire’s tendency to increase the blood pressure. It is better not to use this point than to needle it incorrectly. Wood Fire may be needled safely every other day, even once daily, but never more than one time each day.
secondary_indications: tightness or distension of the lower leg)
ankle pain after exposure to cold/icy water Headache
johnson_indications: Cold feet and legs in the elderly due to circulatory problems (worse in the wintertime)*
techniques: Needle superficially 0.1 - 0.2 cun and obliquely 15 degrees towards the ring finger. Never retain needles for more than 5 minutes. First treatment should be no more than 5 minutes, second treatment (5 days later) for 3 minutes, and last treatment (after 10 days) for 1 minute. This point can also be bled if the area appears dark or if it has surrounding dark veins. Needle or bleed contralateral to the affected side. | Johnson: Needle retention time: See Cautions above for needle retention times. It is essential that you follow these times exactly. Needling technique: Needle bilaterally, superficially, and horizontally beneath the skin, toward the little finger. Depth: 0.3 cun
comments: Cautions: • Raises blood pressure: Needle 11.10 Wood Fire as soon as possible following a stroke. Keep track of the number of times you use Wood Fire. The first five times Wood Fire is needled, retention must be for five minutes only (set a timer and pay close attention to it). The next five times, needle retention is for three minutes only. After the tenth treatment, needle retention must be for one minute only. These retention times must be strictly observed due to Wood Fire’s tendency to increase the blood pressure. It is better not to use this point than to needle it incorrectly. Wood Fire may be needled safely every other day, even once daily, but never more than one time each day. Stroke: Because Wood Fire strongly warms the Yang, opens the orifices and disperses cold, it is extremely useful in post-stroke treatment. Its name, Wood Fire, comes from its location between the wood and fire points of the Pericardium channel. Liver (wind) and Pericardium (fire) share a Jue Yin connection, and we use them both to treat the Heart and circulation. Dr. Lee sometimes referred to these points as Wood Phlegm, because stroke has to do with Liver wind rising and phlegm masking the orifices. Wood, wind, phlegm and fire are all implicated in the use of Mu Huo after a stroke. After needling Mu Huo in an acute post-stroke treatment, we may then choose opposite side 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai (also located between wood and fire points) with GB31 and GB32 (88.25 and A.01), also on the opposite side. Be sure to use Active Qi Moving technique after needling the above points. See 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB21) for my comprehensive hemiplegia/stroke protocol. Cold extremities: As useful as it is for stroke, I am far more likely to use Wood Fire to treat the freezing cold extremities of my elderly patients. Because many of them take high blood pressure medications, I am equally cautious in my observation of the needle retention time restrictions. I always needle Mu Huo alone, so as to not be distracted by needling other points. Then, I often add 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points and moxa heat packs (lower abdominal and lower back) for a dynamite warming effect. Energetic pathways: The Reaction Area of Mu Huo is the Heart and Liver. Because we can access both of these through the Pericardium, and because both the Heart and Liver meridians travel to the head (the Liver meridian passing through the throat), the Pericardium meridian is chosen particularly for stroke, aphasia due to stroke, blood circulation and heart disease. Medial knee pain: Mu Huo is used to treat medial knee pain (often due to bone spurs); however, for this I find 33.12 Heart Gate to be exceptional.
combinations: Hemiplegia: First use 11.10 Wood Fire (see 11.10 Wood Fire, Cautions), then use 22.05 Ling Gu (fire), 22.04 Da Bai (wood) for 45 minutes. For older or more chronic patients, leave needles in longer than 45 minutes. See 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB21) for my comprehensive hemiplegia/stroke protocol.

name: Feixin, Lung Heart (T 11.11)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.11 Feixin , is a two-point set on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, evenly distributed along the midline of the middle phalanx (line G). Divide the middle phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 of the distance between the PIP and DIP joints. | Johnson: This two-point unit is located on the dorsum of the middle finger; the points are equally spaced on the midline of the middle phalange, needled toward the little finger.
johnson_indications: Spinal pain due to Ankylosing Spondylitis, hormonal imbalance, degeneration or injury
techniques: Needle 0.5 cun horizontally towards the little finger. | Johnson: Needle bilaterally Retention: Needle retention of up to two hours may be required. Depth: 0.4 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Because of the Hand Shao Yin (HT)/Foot Shao Yin (KD) relationship, these points also treat sacral, knee and heel pain. Spine pain: Heart Lung is indicated for spine pain because the middle finger represents the spine. It is especially good for lumbar or sacral vertebral pain (Dr. Young, 2008). Varicose veins: “Varicose veins are due to heart and lung weakness. These points tonify Lung qi, which can be difficult to build up. Because the heart pumps blood out to the limbs, and the lungs draw blood back to the trunk, weakness of the heart and lungs may result in blood collecting in the limbs. In this case, every bone in the spine may feel painful to palpation. In addition, the legs may be bloated and distended with varicose veins. Women who use long-term synthetic hormonal replacement therapies and patients who take daily hormone replacements (sex change therapy) may experience this kind of pain and congestion” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Prolapse: As Heart Lung strengthens the heart and circulation, and supports the Lung qi in “holding up” (prevents prolapse), it treats distension and pain of the lower leg, varicosities and calf cramps.
combinations: Sacral pain: 11.11 Lung Heart, 33.12 Heart Gate. Spine pain: 11.11 Lung Heart, 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons (every vertebra in pain).

name: Erjiaoming, Two Corner Bright (T 11.12)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.12 Erjiaoming , is a two-point set on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, evenly distributed along the midline of the proximal phalanx (line G). Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 the distance between the PIP and MCP joints. | Johnson: Two Corner Bright is a two-point unit located on the dorsum of the middle finger; the points are evenly spaced on the centerline of the proximal phalange.
primary_indications: acute back sprain Pain of the nasal bone (sinus pain)
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.5 cun horizontally towards the little finger. | Johnson: Direction: Needle horizontally and superficially toward the little finger. Depth: 0.3-0.4 cun
comments: Lower back pain: These points have the Reaction Area of the Kidney. They tonify the Kidney to treat Kidney-deficient conditions. Because the dorsum of the middle finger corresponds to the spine and Du Mai, Er Jiao Ming is remarkably effective in the treatment of spinal and lumbar pain. The points are especially useful in treating acute lumbar sprain or twisted lower back, when one cannot breathe, cannot stand straight and cannot move. In this case, I might additionally advise either cupping the lumbar muscles or bleeding UB40 Wei Zhong for a quick and solid fix. Supraorbital pain: Er Jiao Ming is located on the Pericardium meridian on the middle finger. Because of the relationship between the Hand Jue Yin (PC) and Foot Yang Ming (ST) meridian (which travels to the face), these points are good for frontal headache, supraorbital pain, facial bone pain and nasal bone pain. It is very common for patients, especially women, to have the above symptoms from excessive anger and crying. Because the Liver and Pericardium share the Jue Yin channel, Er Jiao Ming can relieve face pain due to emotional states from Liver qi congestion.

name: Dan, Gallbladder (T 11.13)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.13 Dan , is a two-point set on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, ulnar and radial to the midpoint of the proximal phalanx along the margins of the phalangeal bone (lines F and H). | Johnson: This two-point unit is located on the dorsum of the middle finger; the points are centered on both sides of the proximal phalange.
primary_indications: Night crying in infants and children
secondary_indications: shaking and fear Jaundice Soreness and swelling of the calf from overexertion Lateral ankle pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun towards the palm. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Bleeding: These points can be needled, but are more commonly bled. Only bleed if you see a vessel near these points. May be bled twice weekly. Depth: 0.2-0.3 cun
comments: Energetic pathways (sleep): Since Hand Shao Yin (HT) connects to Foot Shao Yang (GB), and Hand Jue Yin (PC) connects to Foot Yang Ming (ST), disruption of sleep may be related to either Heart or Stomach and can be treated with 11.13 Gallbladder. Restless sleeping is related to the Pericardium/Heart connection. Sudden awakening or being easily startled, with an accompanying rapid heart rate, has to do with weakness in the Gallbladder, or in Traditional Chinese Medicine terms, “empty Gallbladder.” Energetic pathways (knee pain): These points’ effectiveness in the treatment of knee pain is partly due to the connection between Hand Shao Yin (HT) and Foot Shao Yang (GB); they are also effective because the Pericardium has a close relationship to the Heart, Stomach and Liver, all of which relate to the knee. As Master Tung’s system has many points from which to choose, I might choose these for knee pain if there are also Gallbladder indications. Nocturnal distress: “When a mother eats spicy food, it passes into her milk and is consumed by her baby. Spicy food attacks the Lung, and excess Lung energy over- controls the Liver, which causes the baby to cry all day and night. For babies who cry at night, needle both points once per week. For persistent cases, 3-4 treatments ought to be sufficient” (Dr. Lee, 1992).

name: Zhisanzhong, Finger Three Weights (T 11.14)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.14 Zhisanzhong , is a three-point set on the dorsal aspect of the ring finger, TH channel, evenly distributed along the ulnar margin of the middle phalangeal bone (line F). Divide the middle phalanx into fourths, and locate these three points at ¼, ½, and ¾ of the distance between the PIP and DIP joints. | Johnson: This three-point unit is located on the dorsum of the ring finger, 0.2 cun lateral to the midline (ulnar side) of the middle phalange, evenly spaced between the creases.
secondary_indications: swollen and painful breast or nipple
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun adjacent to the edge of the bone towards the palm. | Johnson: Needle bilaterally. Depth: 0.3 cun
comments: Finger and Leg Three Weights: Finger Three Weights points are similar in their therapeutic function to 77.05-77.07 Three Weights, though points on the finger are not nearly as powerful as those on the legs. Energetic pathways: As 77.05-77.07 Three Weights points are located between the Shao Yang (GB) and the Yang Ming (ST) channels, they deal with wind and phlegm conditions, such as facial paralysis, muscle atrophy and breast distension. Finger Three Weights points carry some of the same influences that are related to the Shao Yang and Yang Ming channels because they are located on the San Jiao channel, which has an internal/external connection to the Pericardium channel, and the Pericardium shares a special relationship with the Stomach channel (Hand Jue Yin/Foot Yang Ming). Acute conditions: Since Finger Three Weights points are located between the Jing- Well and Ying-Spring points, they are more suitable for treating acute conditions or as additional points to enhance the function of 77.05-77.07 Three Weights.

name: Zhishen, Finger Kidney (T 11.15)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.15 Zhishen , is a three-point set on the dorsal aspect of the ring finger, TH channel, evenly distributed along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line F). Divide the proximal phalanx into fourths, and locate these three points at ¼, ½, and ¾ of the distance between the MCP and PIP joints. | Johnson: This three-point unit is located on the dorsum of the ring finger, with points evenly spaced on the ulnar side of the proximal phalange.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 cun adjacent to edge of the bone towards the palm. | Johnson: Needle bilaterally. Depth: 0.2-0.3 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: These points treat Kidney deficiency due to the connection between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and the Foot Shao Yin (KD). Because the Kidney controls the five fluids, this point is especially good for dry mouth and thirst. 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors and 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points are similar in function,though far more powerful. •  Heart weakness: Finger Kidney is used to treat heart weakness, as Hand and Foot Shao Yin (HT/KD) are being connected through the San Jiao channel in this case (Hand Shao Yang/Foot Shao Yin). All of the indications for Finger Kidney are due to Kidney yin deficiency. The Heart and Kidneys should be evenly balanced, and deficiency in one affects the other. •  Upper back pain is usually due to Kidney deficiency. Master Tung used these points in the treatment of upper back pain in the area of UB43 Gao Huang Shu.

name: Huoxi, Fire Knee (T 11.16)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.16 Huoxi , overlaps with Shaoze (SI 1) , which is on the ulnar corner of the little fingernail (line F). | Johnson: Fire Knee is located on the dorsum of the little finger, 0.2 cun lateral to the nail root. This is the same location as SI1 Shao Ze.
primary_indications: Psychological disorders ( shen disturbance) with phlegm misting the Heart or anger
johnson_indications: Pain in the Hand Tai Yang channel*
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun . Needle bilaterally to treat emotional and psychological conditions. | Johnson: Bleeding: This point is bled. When bleeding Jing-Well points in general, puncture at a 45-degree angle in order to avoid contacting the bone and damaging the periosteum. Additionally, this angle provides a greater surface area than a perpendicular puncture and therefore a greater volume of blood (though still small).
comments: Energetic pathways: Fire Knee is located at SI1 Shao Ze, the Jing-Well and metal point on a fire channel, and has the Reaction Area of Heart. It has the functions of opening the orifices, clearing heat, and opening the Heart, and is used for resuscitation. Rheumatoid arthritis: Bleeding this point is very effective for rheumatoid arthritis (phlegm) with deformed joints, especially in the hands. Mental illness: Phlegm masking the orifices is a frequent cause of mental disturbance. This phlegm is foamy and frothy, not sticky like that which comes from the Lung. Anger may especially induce this type of phlegm obstruction. Due to the connection between the Small Intestine and Heart, and the Tai Yang (SI) relationship to the Du Mai, spine and brain, Fire Knee clears the mind. “If phlegm obstructs the orifices of the Heart, the person will seem rational one moment and nod their head in understanding. Then the next moment they will forget everything they were just told” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Tai Yang channel disorders: This point is indicated by difficulty in raising the arm and has a special effect for pain in the Hand Tai Yang (SI) meridian. Fire Knee is effective for treating frozen shoulder because of the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yang (SI) and the Leg Tai Yin (SP), through which the Spleen channel relates to the back of the shoulder, while the Hand and Foot Tai Yin (LU/SP) relate to the front of the shoulder.

name: Mu, Wood (Anger) (T 11.17)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.17 Mu , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the index finger, evenly distributed along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line D). Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 of the distance between the MCP and PIP joints. Some sources indicate this is a three-point group rather than a two-point group. | Johnson: Wood (Anger) is a two-point unit located on the palmar surface of the index finger, on the ulnar side (D-line) of the proximal phalange, dividing the space between the proximal joint creases into equal thirds.
primary_indications: tearing with exposure to wind Itchy skin
cracked skin on the fingers or rough palms or hands
general itching due to wind Right hypochondriac pain
secondary_indications: LR channel disorders: Liver qi stagnation
Wood overacting on Earth symptoms such as stomach pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 - 0.3 cun adjacent to the edge of the bone towards the back aspect of the hand. Needle the affected side when treating skin disorders. With all other conditions, needle the side opposite to the problem. For bloating due to Liver overacting on Spleen, needle both sides. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Needle unilaterally: Wood (Anger) points are usually needled on the left side only (opposite the liver organ) to treat emotional issues related to Liver qi. Needle bilaterally: Wood (Anger) points are needled on both sides to treat sinus problems, dry or tearing eyes, skin diseases on the hands, and extremely sweaty palms. Nerve sensation: If the patient feels a “zing” toward the tip of the finger, you have struck a nerve. Nerves are hard to avoid because you cannot see them. Remove the needle completely and do not reinsert it until the next treatment. Carefully note the location of the nerve in your chart. Hitting a nerve is not necessarily painful, and it may cause only a slight sensation; however, stimulating the point or leaving the needle in may cause repeated electrical “zings” in the weeks to come. The patient will not like this and will think of you frequently, for the wrong reasons. This is a two-point combination: The proximal point is the Chief Point; the distal point is the Supporting Point. In many cases, needling the proximal point is sufficient. If the patient is extremely angry or very depressed, needle both points. Helpful hints: There are a few tricks to facilitate the needling of these points. Use your non-needling hand to hold the back of the patient’s left hand securely in your palm. Arch back their wrist, using the side of your hand at their dorsal wrist crease. Secure their index, middle and ring fingers in an open position. You also may want to secure the patient’s thumb inside a ring made by the thumb and index finger of your needling hand. If the patient applies any pressure to your needling hand with their thumb, suggest that they hold their own little finger and thumb together, making it easier for you to needle without their interference. Avoiding blood vessels: For the comfortable needling of the palmar surface of the hand, perhaps the most crucial step is to very carefully scan the area for faint or obvious blood vessels. Look for the pink or white skin and avoid any area, however small, that has a blue or greenish hue. Tiny adjustments to avoid blood vessels make a huge difference in the patient’s comfort when these points are needled. Do not use a guide tube: Point location on the fingers needs to be precise; therefore, it is not advisable to use a guide tube. First, place the tip of the needle on the point with firm pressure to desensitize the skin. After pausing for a few seconds, and without bouncing, quickly insert the needle through the first millimeter of the skin (the most sensitive area). After a quick and shallow penetration of the surface, incrementally bounce the needle to a deeper level, testing along the way to be sure that you are not “pegging” a tendon or tapping the bone. The needle needs to be free in its correct position, so pay very close attention to the tissues through which the needle passes and to any body language expressing the patient’s sensitivity. Positioning: With the dorsal surface of the patient’s fingers lying gently against the palmar surface of your own fingers, you will be able to feel the pressure of the progressing needle tip. Stop before it penetrates the underside of the epidermis, as this is just as sensitive as the exterior surface. Combinations: See 11.06 Return to the Nest, Needling Notes for information about combining 11.17 Wood (Anger) with 11.24 Gynecological Points and 11.06 Return to the Nest for the treatment of gynecological diseases. Depth: 0.3-0.4 cun
comments: Cautions: 11.17 vs. 11.20: Wood (Anger) points are needled for Liver qi stagnation, whereas 11.20 Wood Inflammation points are for liver organ disease and pain. For patients with serious liver organ issues such as hepatitis, cirrhosis or liver cancer, Wood (Anger) points are NOT the points to choose. For those cases, 11.20 Wood Inflammation points are a better choice. Wood Inflammation is priceless in treating liver organ diseases but should never be used in combination with Wood (Anger), as they are too powerful to combine and would make the patient feel ill. Irritability and anger: Excellent for easing stress, these points can be added to any Liver calming treatment. They are exceptional for treating Liver qi stagnation and Liver fire rising, with a tight pulse, anger, irritability, and depression. These points expel heat to clear the head and eyes, open the orifices, resuscitate, and promote smooth circulation of Liver qi. Wood Anger Points: Dr. Lee fondly called this two-point combination the “Wood Anger Points,” because they have a profound effect upon the nervous system and liver. I call them the “Million Dollar Points,” because if I had ten cents for every time they have come in handy, I’d be a millionaire. These points soothe the savage beast. If the patient is in a manic state of rage, needle these points immediately. The Liver needs to stretch out, to be big and free to speak, and to say just how it feels. A patient who has Liver qi congestion, and who cannot speak their truth for any reason, gets tighter and tighter until they are boiling mad. This is the setup for a migraine. When this anger is still not allowed expression, it turns inward on itself and becomes severe depression. These days, people carry the weight of the world on their shoulders, and the resulting stress and frustration is the cause of most one-sided headaches, temporomandibular joint (TMJ) pain, insomnia, high blood pressure, depression and anxiety. In these cases, I often begin treatment with cupping and needling, and sometimes even bleeding. However, it is also necessary to help people learn to release frustration and tension in a way that is useful to them and does not harm others. Premenstrual: These points can be especially sensitive if the patient is premenstrual or having a hard time emotionally. I judge a female patient’s level of Liver qi stagnation based on the degree of her premenstrual breast pain. If she has no breast pain, I consider her Liver qi congestion to be mild. If she has breast pain for a day or two, she clearly needs a little help. If she has two weeks of breast pain before her period, this indicates a serious case of Liver qi and blood stagnation. Often, such a patient also has nausea and vomiting with severe menstrual cramping. Energetic pathways: Wood (Anger) lends a powerful wind influence due to the special relationship between the Hand Yang Ming (LI) and the Foot Jue Yin (LV). This is seen in its association with emotional states (such as irritability, anger and depression), as well as with sinus congestion and blurred vision, as the Liver channel passes deeply through the inside of the throat and sinuses on its way to the top of the head. These points are also very effective in the treatment of skin and sinus issues due to the internal/external connection between the Large Intestine and Lung, as well as the Large Intestine/Liver relationship. The large intestine and liver organs both clean toxins from the body; the Lung governs the skin and keeps it healthy, and opens to the nose. Wood (Anger) points are used to treat skin conditions on the hands, usually in combination with 88.17-88.19 Four Horses. Of note, the Wood (Anger) points are located on the Koryo Hand Therapy (KHT) Lung channel, reinforcing their relationship to the skin and sinuses. Urinary bladder infections: In my clinic, I have found that most women with bladder infections have been extremely angry in the 24 hours preceding onset. The rising Liver fire hits the Heart, transferring the heat to the Small Intestine and thereby the Urinary Bladder. Because I so frequently see this connection, my first question to a woman with a bladder infection is, “Did you recently get really angry?” Ten times out of ten, the answer is, “Yes!” 66.03 Fire Hardness (Tung’s LV2) is also an important point to treat this condition because it is the Ying-Spring and fire point on the Liver meridian which flows through the genitals, and thus it clears heat. Void after sex: I always advise patients to urinate after sex in order to flush bacteria from their urethra. This simple practice can stop many infections from taking hold. Liver qi stagnation: I use Wood (Anger) points multiple times daily in my clinic, with excellent results. They are particularly useful because of their extraordinary effect of releasing Liver qi stagnation, and because they can easily be combined with any other treatment protocol to open the flow of energy throughout the entire nervous system. Patients absolutely love these points and often ask for them to be needled. They know that no matter what their practitioner chooses to address during their visit, they will very likely go home feeling happy and relaxed.
combinations: Depression or addiction, with nervous system tension: 11.17 Wood (Anger), Four Gates, Prefrontal Scalp Points, DU20. Depression with exhaustion: 11.17 Wood (Anger), Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles. Depression due to Liver qi congestion: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows. Irritability and anger: See Comments, above. PMS or menopause: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.24 Gynecological Points on one side,Four Gates, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. •  Psoriasis: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 88.17-88.19 Four Horses.

name: Pizhong, Spleen Edema (T 11.18)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.18 Pizhong , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the middle finger, along the midline of the middle phalanx (line C). Divide the middle phalanx into thirds, and located these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 the distance between the PIP and DIP joints. | Johnson: Spleen Edema is a two-point unit located on the palmar surface of the right middle finger, on the center line of the middle phalange, with points evenly spaced between the finger creases.
primary_indications: abdominal bloating Chest and upper back pain
johnson_indications: Inflammation or hardening of the spleen*
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun . | Johnson: Needle unilaterally: Insert on the right side only, opposite the spleen. 11.18 needling: For points located in the center of a phalange, pinch up the skin prior to needling and insert the needle slowly until you gently contact the periosteum. Direction: Shallow insertion, straight in. Depth: 0.2-0.3 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: The middle finger pertains to the Pericardium and the fire element, and it has a close relationship to the Heart. Spleen Edema strengthens fire to promote earth, and treats diseases of the Spleen and Stomach due to the relationship between the Hand Jue Yin (PC) and the Foot Yang Ming (ST). Hiccups: Spleen Edema is effective for hiccups because of the relationship between the Pericardium and Stomach channels. Rubbing the Pericardium channel, or the whole middle finger, stops hiccups (especially in young children). Case history (cold food injuring the spleen, Dr. Lee): “A man on a strict vegetarian diet came to me because he was so thin and weak. I could palpate his spleen three inches below his ribs. He ate only raw vegetables and drank cold water. According to Chinese medicine, raw foods and cold drinks injure the spleen. I treated him with this point and three days later his spleen had shrunk back under his ribs” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Splenomegaly: 11.18 Spleen Edema is effective in the treatment of enlarged spleen and can be added to 77.05-77.07 Three Weights or 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/Wood Scoop.

name: Xinchang, Heart Normal (T 11.19)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.19 Xinchang , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the middle finger, evenly distributed along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line D). Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 of the distance between the MCP and PIP joints. | Johnson: Heart Normal is a two-point unit located on the palmar surface of the middle finger, on the ulnar side of the proximal phalange (D-line), with points evenly spaced between the finger creases. Note: It is located and needled similarly to 11.17 Wood (Anger), but is found on the middle finger.
johnson_indications: Phlegm obstructing the Heart orifices (cannot think clearly)*
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun along the edge of the bone towards the dorsal aspect of the hand. Needle bilaterally. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Depth: 0.3-0.4 cun
comments: Cautions: • 11.17 vs. 11.20: 11.17 Wood (Anger) points are needled for Liver qi stagnation, whereas Wood Inflammation points are for liver organ disease and pain. For patients with serious liver organ issues such as hepatitis, cirrhosis or liver cancer, 11.17 Wood (Anger) points are NOT the points to choose. For those cases, Wood Inflammation is a better choice. Wood Inflammation is priceless in treating liver organ diseases but should never be used in combination with Wood (Anger), as they are too powerful to combine and would make the patient feel ill. Cautions: • Forbidden to needle during pregnancy.Phlegm: Similar to 11.11 Lung Heart, Heart Normal resolves frothy phlegm due to anger, not sticky phlegm from the Lung. Energetic pathways: Dr. Lee used the metaphor of a balloon to represent the heart, and said that treating the heart directly by needling Heart channel points is like popping the balloon with a pin. In Tung’s point system, we choose one of two methods to affect the Heart. If the patient has a Heart excess condition, we sedate the Stomach (child) to let the air out of the balloon slowly, from the opening at the bottom. If the patient has a deficiency, we tonify the Liver (mother) in order to replenish. Because the Pericardium is the Heart Protector, points on the Pericardium channel are always chosen over points on the Heart channel. The Hand Jue Yin (PC) and Foot Yang Ming (ST) share a powerful energetic connection, so we often choose the Stomach channel to treat the Heart through the Pericardium. Additionally, the Hand and Foot Jue Yin connect the Pericardium to the Liver. Thus, the Pericardium serves as an intermediary that connects to both the Stomach (excess) and the Liver (deficiency) in balancing the Heart. Heart disease: For enlarged heart and heart disease, bleed DT.07 Three Gold (Shu Points close to HT, PC, SI and LU). Case history (phlegm obstructing the Heart, Dr. Lee): “Once in Singapore I was asked to treat an old woman who was quite sick. Several years before she had retired and given her business to her daughter-in-law. Her daughter-in-law then turned on this woman and would not give her any money, only fed her once per day, and treated her very badly. Of course the mother-in-law was filled with sorrow, hatred, and regret. Finally, her friends took her to their house and tried to care for her. When I came to try to treat this woman, I prescribed herbs that I then boiled myself. I tried to give these to this woman, but she just poured them out on the floor. This woman did not know what she was doing. This was a case of phlegm obstructing the portals of the Heart due to years of harboring ill will and other negative feelings” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Heart disease: 11.19 Heart Normal with 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points. Irregular heart rate: Unilaterally needle 11.05 Middle Distance or 11.19 Heart Normal; bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master; needling PC6 Nei Guan is also effective.

name: Muyan, Wood Inflammation (T 11.20)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.20 Muyan , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the ring finger, evenly distributed along the ulnar margin of the middle phalangeal bone (line D). Divide the middle phalanx into thirds, and located these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 the distance between the PIP and DIP joints. | Johnson: Wood Inflammation is a two-point unit located on the palmar surface of the ring finger, on the ulnar side (D-line) of the middle phalange, and it divides the space between the proximal joint creases into equal thirds.
primary_indications: liver cirrhosis Liver fire with irritability
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 - 0.3 cun adjacent to the bone towards the dorsal aspect of the hand.
comments: Cautions: • 11.17 vs. 11.20: Wood (Anger) points are needled for Liver qi stagnation, whereas 11.20 Wood Inflammation points are for liver organ disease and pain. For patients with serious liver organ issues such as hepatitis, cirrhosis or liver cancer, Wood (Anger) points are NOT the points to choose. For those cases, 11.20 Wood Inflammation points are a better choice. Wood Inflammation is priceless in treating liver organ diseases but should never be used in combination with Wood (Anger), as they are too powerful to combine and would make the patient feel ill. Serious liver disease: To treat serious liver disease, always combine 11.20 Wood Inflammation with 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows. In this case, Three Yellows are the primary treating points, while Wood Inflammation manages the pain. Wood Inflammation is extraordinarily effective for liver organ pain due to liver disease. Liver cancer can be one of the most painful types of cancer, so these points are invaluable not only for the patient but for their entire family too, as they will keep the patient comfortable until the end of life. •  Energetic pathways: The Liver is the Reaction Area of Wood Inflammation. Through the relationship of Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yang (GB), we connect to the Liver/Gallbladder (internal/external). We also reach the Liver because these points are located on the San Jiao channel and share an internal/external connection with the Pericardium (Hand and Foot Jue Yin). Adding to that, the special relationship between the San Jiao and Kidney meridians (Hand Shao Yang/Foot Shao Yin) brings in a Kidney influence to treat chronic diseases. The combination of these energetic  relationships makes Wood Inflammation points some of the most powerful in Tung’s system of acupuncture. •  Function: 11.17 Wood (Anger) is needled for Liver qi stagnation (emotional issues), whereas 11.20 Wood Inflammation is selected for liver organ disease and liver pain, because 11.20 clears heat and calms fire (serious organ disease). •  Channel sensitivity: Some patients with advanced liver disease may find 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows too painful to be needled or even palpated, especially if they are premenstrual. In this case, start with Wood Inflammation and add Three Yellows at a future time when the patient is better able to tolerate them. An herbal formula will most certainly hasten that time and is required in any kind of serious liver disease. •  Exhaustion due to liver: Patients with hepatitis are often exhausted. They are tired not due to qi deficiency but because their liver is not cleaning the blood properly, and their blood has become “dirty,” or toxic (Dr. Lee, 1992). If you tonify the qi in these patients, you will worsen their condition. First, clean the DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas by thoroughly cupping, following the color until clear margins are reached. If the skin color is black after cupping, the patient may feel more fatigued the following day, although most patients will feel lighter and more energetic due to their liver’s improved functioning. •  Case histories (hepatitis and HIV) : In the mid 1980s, I had an HIV clinic in San Francisco, where I saw many extreme cases of combined hepatitis and HIV. My patients’ elevated transaminase levels ranged between 600 and 1600 (far beyond the normal level of 0-40 units per liter of serum). These patients were hospitalized for caregiving and monitoring only, as Western medicine had no recourse with which to treat them. In extreme cases, symptoms often included headaches, insomnia, liver pain, nosebleeds, exhaustion, anger and depression, constipation or diarrhea, jaundice, back pain, nausea and vomiting. Only TCM is able to resolve this degree of severity, with 11.20 Wood Inflammation, 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows, cupping DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas, and a Chinese herbal formula to strongly clean and detoxify the liver. As this was during the early stages of the HIV epidemic, many allopathic physicians did not know how to help this community of patients. I was gratefully welcomed in the AIDS wards in all of San Francisco’s major hospitals. Doctors and nurses came into the rooms to watch me work; families cooked my herbal teas, which were then administered at the proper times by the nursing staff. Many patients were well enough to go home within days of their treatment, with liver enzyme levels below 200. •  Polycystic liver and kidneys: I have successfully treated several cases of polycystic kidney disease, often with multiple cysts in the liver. Because the liver and the kidneys both need to be treated, a point combination including 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan) is utilized. First, I needle 11.20 Wood Inflammation, and then in order to keep the number of needles to a minimum, I use either 88.12 and 88.14 Two Yellows with Shen Guan, or 88.12 Bright Yellow with 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors, perhaps alternating the two options. If the patient has an advanced or terminal disease, I treat them as often as possible; three treatments a week may be necessary to manage their condition.
combinations: For all liver disease: SI4 Wan Gu is an excellent choice for clearing damp heat. •  Wood attacking earth (diarrhea): If Liver and Spleen are both affected, needle 88.12- 88.14 Three Yellows, 11.20 Wood Inflammation, 33.10 Intestine Gate, 33.11 Liver Gate. •  Cirrhosis: •  Bleed Liver, Gallbladder and Spleen Shu points. •  Unilaterally needle left side 11.20 Wood Inflammation, bilaterally needle 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows. •  Unilaterally needle left side 11.20 Wood Inflammation, 33.11 Liver Gate, bilaterally needle 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows. •  Alternatively, use left side 33.11 Liver Gate with bilateral 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/ Wood Scoop. Note: In my experience, the Wood Keep/Wood Scoop points have mixed results when used for liver and blood diseases

name: Sanyan, Three Eyes (T 11.21)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.21 Sanyan , is located on the palmar aspect of the ring finger, along the radial margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line B). Divide the distance between the MCP and PIP joints into thirds, and locate this point at the distal third (closest to the PIP joint). | Johnson: Three Eyes is located on the palmar surface of the ring finger, 0.2 cun radial to the midline, 1/3 of the distance between the distal crease and the proximal crease of the first phalange.
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun along the edge of the bone. | Johnson: Depth: 0.3 cun
comments: Three Eyes is a tonifying point that has indications similar to ST36 Zu San Li, but it is far less powerful. I do not use this point.
meridian: Between Pericardium and San Jiao San Jiao

name: Fuyuan, Recovery (T 11.22)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.22 Fuyuan , is three-point set on the palmar aspect of the ring finger, along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line D). Divide the proximal phalanx into fourths, and locate these three points at 1/4, 1/2, and 3/4 the distance between the MCP and PIP joints. | Johnson: Recovery is a three-point unit located on the palmar surface of the ring finger, on the ulnar side of the proximal phalange (D-line), evenly spaced between the finger creases (always measuring from the most distal crease).
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun . This point also can be bled for clear/yellowish fluids. | Johnson: Needle bilaterally: For systemic conditions affecting multiple joints. Needle unilaterally: Needle the opposite side if one joint is affected. Contact the bone: Slide the needles down the ulnar side of the phalange. Depth: 0.3 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: 11.22 Recovery is located on the San Jiao channel and treats the bone due to the internal/external relationship between the Hand and Foot Shao Yang (SJ/GB). It is also highly effective for bone disorders because of the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yin (KD). The needling technique used with these points, that of sliding the needle shaft alongside the bone, provides an additional bone-treating-bone Kidney function. Supplementing points: Use the Recovery points in addition to other points, as they are not strong enough to use on their own. Case history (bone steaming disorder): This is a condition of deep internal heat arising from severe yin deficiency, described as heat that seems to come from the bones. I treated a patient who had a bone cyst the size of a golf ball on his tibial tuberosity. It was inactive for most of his life, but suddenly became very hot and swollen. I could feel intense heat radiating out when I placed my hand over the cyst. Bleeding the cyst twice, two weeks in a row, resolved the situation. I also could have added the Recovery points.
combinations: Bone steaming: 11.22 Recovery with HT6 Yin Xi, KD26 Yu Zhong, UB13 Fei Shu.

name: Yanhuang, Yellow Eye (T 11.23)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.23 Yanhuang , is located on the palmar aspect of the little finger, along the midline of the middle phalanx (line C). Locate this point halfway between the PIP and DIP joints. | Johnson: Yellow Eye is located on the palmar surface of the little finger, centered on the middle phalange.
johnson_indications: Yellowing of the sclera of the eyes (due to hepatitis)*
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun perpendicularly. | Johnson: 11.23 needling: For points located in the center of a phalange, pinch up the skin prior to needling and insert the needle slowly until you gently contact the periosteum. Depth: 0.2 cun Needled bilaterally
comments: Energetic pathways: Located between HT9 Shao Chong and SI1 Shao Ze (both Jing- Well points), Yellow Eye is used to drain damp heat (SI) and calm the spirit (HT). Additionally, it utilizes the special relationship between Hand Shao Yin (HT) and Foot Shao Yang (GB). Yellow eyes: This point is not particularly powerful, but it treats yellowing of the sclera due to hepatitis. For any other kind of jaundice, Yellow Eye is not effective. A.07 Night Blindness - Ye Mang Energetic pathways: A.07 Night Blindness is located between the Heart and Small Intestine meridians. Due to the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yin (HT) and the Foot Shao Yang (GB), this point promotes healthy eyesight. Through the Shao Yin (HT/KD) relationship, the little finger is closely related to the Kidney; therefore, Night Blindness tonifies the power of vision. Acting as a Jing-Well point for either Heart or Small Intestine, this point calms the spirit and benefits the eyes. Additionally, there is a Hand and Foot Tai Yang (SI/UB) relationship that leads to the Kidney via its internal/external connection with the Urinary Bladder. For these reasons, this point is useful in the treatment of night blindness.
combinations: Night blindness: A.07 Night Blindness with 55.02 Flower Bone One and 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan), 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7) or A.07 Night Blindness with 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan), 77.28 Bright Light, GB20 Feng Chi and GB37 Guang Ming.

name: Fuke, Gynecological Points (T 11.24)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.24 Fuke , is a two-point set on the on the dorsal aspect of the thumb, along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line F).
