Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 the distance between the MCP and IP joints. | Johnson: Gynecological Points are a two-point unit located on the dorsal surface of the thumb, on the ulnar line of the proximal phalange, 0.3 cun lateral to the midline and halfway between the dorsal midline and the junction of red and white skin6.
primary_indications: All acute or chronic gynecological disorders Any menstrual irregularities
or uterus tilted to the right or left Vaginal flatulence Post-partum arthritis
johnson_indications: Menopausal hot flashes, night sweats, irritability and depression*
Uterine pain following abortion or miscarriage*
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun perpendicularly along the edge of the bone, towards the palm. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Needle unilaterally: Needle perpendicularly from the dorsal surface toward the palmar surface, just inside the heads of the proximal phalange. This appears as a horizontal insertion, with the shaft of the needle passing just beneath the junction of red and white skin; watch for the tip of the needle advancing toward the underside of the epidermis. Combining points for gynecological issues: 11.17 Wood (Anger) is frequently used in combination with Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points. When combining these points, we first needle 11.17 Wood (Anger) and 11.24 Gynecological Points on the patient’s left hand, followed by 11.06 Return to the Nest on the right hand. This arrangement allows you to best position the patient’s hands for needling, because the Gynecological Points combine better with Wood (Anger) than with Return to the Nest. If you are needling the points multiple times in one week (or even daily in the case of infertility), you can alternate the arrangement by needling Wood (Anger) with Return to the Nest on the left hand, and needling Gynecological Points on the right hand. We always needle Wood (Anger) on the left side, opposite the liver. Gynecological Points and Return to the Nest can be needled on either hand, and each can be needled unilaterally, but they should never both be needled on the same hand. Depth: 0.3-0.4 cun
comments: Brain connection: These points regulate hormonal activity. Located on the thumb, they have a powerful and direct connection to the brain. Qi and blood: The Gynecological Points are for qi; they guide the qi to adjust the uterus. 11.06 Return to the Nest is for blood; it regulates ovarian activity (hormones) and is responsible for regulating cycles. When combined with 11.17 Wood (Anger), the Gynecological Points and Return to the Nest are useful for hormonal imbalances of any kind, including any cyclic ailments, premenstrual or menopausal disorders, migraine headaches, infertility, endometriosis, amenorrhea, irritability, anxiety and depression. Tipped uterus: 11.24 adjusts the qi of the uterus. It is used to treat tipped uterus, which is most often caused by uterine tumors, cysts or fibroids, and is usually accompanied by lower back pain and frequent urination. Also see 11.06 Return to the Nest, Comments. Infertility due to stagnation: Not included in Tung’s system are points called Three Plum Blossom. This three-point unit is located on the abdomen. The first point is 3.0 cun inferior to the navel; the other two points are found bilaterally, 2.0 cun inferior to the navel and 2.0 cun lateral to the midline. When treating infertility, Three Plum Blossom clears uterine stagnation and cleans the womb, treating damp heat conditions such as endometriosis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Three Plum Blossom points are not used after ovulation when patients are trying to conceive. When I am treating a woman for infertility with damp heat accumulation in the uterus, I ask her to use birth control for three months in order to clean and revitalize the womb without any possibility of conception. Bleeding small veins in the area of SP6 San Yin Jiao is also useful for uterine stagnation. The need for cleaning might be characterized by a tongue that is red or coated yellow. See 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters for additional information. Infertility due to hormonal imbalance: Many women experience an irregular menstrual cycle due to exhaustion, overwork and cold damp accumulation in the uterus. A white coating or pale tongue with teeth marks indicates damp cold, requiring qi tonification, warming, and clearing dampness. Chronic leucorrhea that persists for ten years or more may be indicative of cancer.
combinations: Infertility: 11.06 Return to the Nest on one side, 11.24 Gynecological Points on the other side (alternate sides daily for two months; stop after conception). Points to strengthen and regulate Spleen, Liver and Kidney: 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters, Three Plum Blossom, 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points and 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. Menopause: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. If the patient is emotional, add 11.17 Wood (Anger), LI4/LV3 Four Gates, Prefrontal Scalp Points, DU20. Amenorrhea: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with ST25 Tian Shu (Yang Ming Mu point), 66.15 Water Fairy (Tung’s KD5), and REN24 Cheng Jiang (Ren Mai – Jing-Well). Dysmenorrhea: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43) or ST44 Xian Gu; SP6 San Yin Jiao (needled – with or without electric or pricking bleeding); REN24 Cheng Jiang; 66.02 Wood Wife, 66.03 Fire Hardness. Irregular menses: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters or Three Plum Blossom. Promoting conception: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, Three Plum Blossom (not after ovulation). Habitual miscarriage: 11.06 Return to the Nest on one side, 11.24 Gynecological Points on the other side, 88.10-88.11 Kidney Passing Points.

name: Zhixian, Stop Spit (T 11.25)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.25 Zhixian , is a two-point set on the dorsal aspect of the thumb, evenly distributed along the radial margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line H). Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 the distance between the MCP and IP joints. According to Dr. Chuan-Min Wang, this is a five-point set located in the same area. | Johnson: Stop Spit is a two-point unit located on the dorsum of the thumb, on the radial side of the proximal phalange; the points are evenly spaced between the creases. Stop Spit is similar to 11.24 Gynecological Points but is located on the opposite side of the thumb.
secondary_indications: diarrhea from Spleen qi deficiency Atrophy of the optic nerve
tearing upon exposure to wind Toothache Intestinal hernia
johnson_indications: Drooling in adults due to brain injury*
techniques: Needle perpendicular 0.2 - 0.3 cun along the bone towards the palm. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Depth: 0.3.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Stop Spit is located on the Hand Tai Yin (LU) meridian, which shares an internal connection to the Foot Tai Yin (SP). These points tonify the qi and astringe, treating excessive salivation due to Lung and Spleen deficiency.
combinations: Drooling due to brain injury: Though not frequently chosen, 11.25 Stop Spit is very useful for patients with brain injuries who are constantly drooling. Needling Stop Spit and applying a moxa pot to KD2 Ran Gu will manage drooling, resulting in fewer clothing changes each day.

name: Zhiwu, Control Dirt (T 11.26)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.26 Zhiwu , is a three-point set on the dorsal aspect of the thumb, evenly distributed along the midline of the proximal phalanx (line G). Divide the proximal phalanx into fourths, and locate these three points at ¼, ½, and ¾ the distance between the MCP and IP joints. | Johnson: Control Dirt is a three-point unit located on the dorsum of the thumb, on the center line of the proximal phalange. If a very dark vessel is present, it should be bled; a lancet is adequate for bleeding in this case.
primary_indications: burns with continuous oozing of blood and/or pus (including post-tumor surgical wounds)
techniques: Needle obliquely 0.1 - 0.2 cun from bottom to top. For best results, bleed the points and squeeze out the dark blood. | Johnson: Bleed: Though Control Dirt is described as being a three-point pattern, it is never needled, only bled, and only when an extremely dark vessel is seen. A lancet is adequate for bleeding in this case. For easier bleeding, warm the patient’s hands. On cold or rainy days, patients do not bleed as well.
comments: Energetic pathways: Control Dirt is located on the Lung channel. Because the Lung governs the skin and the Liver cleans the blood, these points are used to treat infections and abscesses, utilizing the relationship of metal controlling wood. Also relevant is the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and the Foot Tai Yang (UB); the former governs the Wei qi, and the latter is frequently attacked by external wind. This point is located between the Jing-Well and Ying-Spring points; the Ying-Spring points treat exterior diseases. Dark vessels on the dorsal thumb: Students in my classes are often dismayed to find dark vessels on the back of their own thumbs, yet these vessels are rarely as dark as what we are looking for. The photo above does not show a blood vessel, as they are not common; it is for point location only. Every dark vessel on the dorsum of the thumb does not mean that there is a corresponding infection. However, when we find a very dark vessel in this area, we need to ascertain whether there is an infection somewhere in the body, perhaps unknown to the patient. If your patient has shingles (herpes zoster) or a known infection or abscess, check this area. If I see a black vessel in this area, I am inclined to bleed it just for good measure. Persistent infection: Bleed Control Dirt when there is a wound that will not heal, such as a postsurgical incision with continuous drainage, difficult bedsores, any kind of severe toxin in the body, persistent infection or necrotic tissue. Black blood vs. yellow fluid: “If black blood comes out when this point is bled, the condition will heal quickly, even overnight. If yellow fluid comes out, the condition will not heal” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Bleeding the area surrounding the external malleolus: In the treatment of shingles, herpes, or otitis media, we may also bleed the small vessels found in the area of the external malleolus. Also consider bleeding 99.08 Ear Apex for these conditions. Case history (non-healing wound, Master Tung): “An 11-year-old boy had surgery on his leg. After the operation the wound would not close and was constantly weeping. The boy was in the hospital for one week and his father was very worried. He went to see Master Tung and asked for his help. Master Tung had to sneak into the hospital. He bled these points on the dorsal side of the boy’s thumb at about 11:00 am in the morning. By 3:00 pm that afternoon the weeping had stopped and the boy was discharged, whereas before bleeding Control Dirt, the nurses had to change the dressings hourly” (Dr. Lee, 1992).

name: Wuhu, Five Tigers (T 11.27)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.27 Wuhu , is a five-point set evenly distributed along the radial aspect of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, at the border between the palmar and dorsal aspects of the thumb between the red and the white skin (line A). The points are numbered so that the most distal is the 1st point and the most proximal is the 5th point. Each point is 2 fen from the next point. | Johnson: Five Tigers are a five-point unit located on the radial side of the proximal phalange of the thumb, just palmar to the junction of red and white skin on the radial side of either thumb, between the condyles of the proximal phalange (this space is only about a finger’s width). The points are numbered 1-5, distal to proximal: Five Tigers One is located just proximal to the distal condyle of the first phalange. Five Tigers Two is located between Five Tigers Three and Five Tigers One. Five Tigers Three is located in the middle of the proximal phalange. Five Tigers Four is located between Five Tigers Three and Five Tigers Five. Five Tigers Five is located just distal to the proximal condyle of the first phalange.
primary_indications: pain as a side effect of medication use
johnson_indications: Enlargement or swelling of multiple joints*
Ankle pain (A.05 Small Joint is more effective)
Sore throat, cough, pneumonia, or swollen glands
Five Tigers One (distal): Finger and palm pain, rheumatoid arthritis, tenosynovitis, headache
Five Tigers Two: Deformed fingers, rheumatoid arthritis, tendinitis
Five Tigers Three (middle): Toe pain, gout, frontal headache
Five Tigers Four: Instep pain, dorsum and ankle pain
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun for upper body disorders, 0.2 - 0.4 cun for lower body disorders. The needle needs to touch the tendon or the bone. Needle contralateral to the affected side. This point also can be bled to release blood or clear/yellowish fluids. | Johnson: Needle just palmar to the junction of red and white skin on the radial side of either thumb, between the condyles of the proximal phalange (this space is only about a finger’s width). Unilateral or bilateral: Generally, these points are needled on the side opposite the affected area, though bilateral needling is done when treating bilateral finger pain. Guide Point: Five Tigers One may be selected as a Guide Point to treat pain of the thumb, and it is needled on the affected side. Bone-treating-bone function: Slide the needles along the palmar surface of the bone to activate the bone-treating-bone function. Depth: 0.2-0.3 cun
comments: Five Tigers are primarily used to treat musculoskeletal joint pain. “Tigers” implies a quick and powerful effect. Dao Ma combinations: Though each point has individual indications, I always use Five Tigers One and Two together when treating fingers or hands, and Five Tigers Three, Four and Five together when treating issues on the feet or toes. Never needle all five points together in one session; choose points to treat either the hands or the feet. Neural connections: The thumb is our grasping and laboring tool, important to our evolution. Many of Master Tung’s most powerful points are located on the thumb and fingers. The motor and sensory lines found in scalp acupuncture connect with a very large area of projection related to the thumb (especially) and also the fingers. Five Tigers are amazingly effective because of this strong connection to the brain and nervous system. Sore throat: Five Tigers are located on the Lung channel and tonify the Lung and Spleen. Due to this location, they can be selected to treat sore throat, pneumonia, and swollen glands. Frontal headache: Five Tigers Three may treat frontal headaches; however, this would only be a side effect of its use, as there are far more powerful points to choose.
combinations: Any finger, palm or thumb pain: 11.27 Five Tigers One and Two on the opposite side with 11.27 Five Tigers One on the same side as a Guiding Point (needled last). Toe, ankle, foot or heel pain: 11.27 Five Tigers Three, Four and Five (I always use all three). Gout: Needle opposite side 11.27 Five Tigers Three, Four and Five, deep needle 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36) on the same side (up to 60mm, lifting the needle 50% every 10 minutes to disperse heat). See detailed commentary, 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36). Heel pain: 11.27 Five Tigers Five, PC7 Da Ling or 22.05 Ling Gu. Rheumatoid arthritis: 11.27 Five Tigers, 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points, 33.12 Heart Gate – all bilaterally. SJ5 Wai Guan (opposite side) opens to all five fingers for rheumatoid arthritis of the wrist. Use SI4 Wan Gu on the opposite side with SI3 Hou Xi on the same side as a Guiding Point. Trigger finger: Needle opposite side 11.27 Five Tigers One and Two, SJ5 Wai Guan; bleed same side 33.16 Curve Mound (Tung’s LU5).

name: Shuangling * (T 11.28)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.28* Shuangling , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the middle finger, along the radial and ulnar margins of the PIP joint. Each point is 0.25 cun ulnar and radial to the center of the PIP joint (lines B and D).
secondary_indications: gan ji (infantile malnutrition) Liver cirrhosis Vitiligo
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. If the condition is in the center, needle the side that is more painful upon palpation. This point can also be bled, especially in cases of pediatric disease. It is most effective when dark blood or yellowish liquid is squeezed out.

name: Muling * (T 11.29)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.29* Muling , is located on the palmar aspect of the ring finger, along the radial margin of the PIP joint (line B).
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 - 0.3 cun . This point can also be bled. It is most effective when dark blood or yellowish liquid is squeezed out.

name: Baguansanxue (T 11.30)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.30* Baguansanxue , is on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, along the radial margin of the proximal phalangeal bone, 0.25 cun proximal to the midpoint of the proximal phalanx (line H).
techniques: Needle obliquely towards the fingertips 0.2 - 0.5 cun for arm and leg pain. For hemiplegia, needle obliquely towards the fingertips 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Baguansixue (T 11.31)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.31* Baguansixue , is located on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone, 0.25 cun proximal to the midpoint of the proximal phalanx (line F).
techniques: Needle obliquely towards the fingertips 0.2 - 0.5 cun for arm and leg pain. For hemiplegia, needle obliquely towards the fingertips 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Zhuyuan (T 11.32)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.32* Zhuyuan , is a two-point set located on both the radial margin of the IP joint (Line A) and ulnar margin of the IP joint (Line E) of the thumb.

name: Chongzi, Double Child (T 22.01)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.01 Chongzi , is on the thenar eminence, about 1 cun below the first and second metacarpal skin fold. | Johnson: Double Child and Double Fairy are easy to locate because they are often sensitive to palpation: 22.02 Double Fairy is located on the thenar eminence at the base of the palm. Holding the patient’s thumb closed against their hand, with their fingers straight, follow a line down the center of the index finger to locate the point, just distal to the proximal head of the first metacarpal bone. Roll your finger up and over the proximal end of the bone to palpate the point. 22.01 Double Child is located approximately 1.0 cun distal to Double Fairy, just proximal to the distal head of the first metacarpal bone. It is located straight across from the large knuckle of the thumb, one large cun (a big thumb’s breadth) medial to the edge of the hand. A line drawn between Double Child and Double Fairy is parallel to the side of the hand.
primary_indications: Upper back pain (especially between scapula and neck)
neck pain Respiratory disorders: asthma (especially in children)
johnson_indications: Upper back pain (between spine and scapula, UB43 area)*
Chest pain radiating from the upper back*
Difficulty opening and closing the hands or extending the fingers*
Knee pain (I never choose Double Child/Double Fairy for this indication, but knee pain may respond to these points)
Uterine or ovarian cysts or tumors*
Bronchitis (with phlegm that is difficult to expectorate)
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 1 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side when treating pain. When treating everything else, needle the side of Chongzi (T 22.01) where there is more pain upon palpation. This point can also be bled, especially in pediatric cases. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 22.01 Double Child is combined with 22.02 Double Fairy. I always needle Double Fairy first, and then follow the first metacarpal bone to find Double Child just proximal to the distal head of the bone. Positioning: Hold the patient’s thumb against the side of their hand and ask them to relax their thumb, so that the muscles are as soft as possible when needled. Blood vessels: The thenar eminence has a large concentration of nerves and blood vessels, making these points more sensitive to palpate as well as needle, and contributing to their powerful effects. Avoid obvious blood vessels when needling. Guide tube: When inserting these needles, I use a guide tube, asking the patient to cough while I tap in the needle. I ask the patient to cough again while I quickly insert the needle to depth. Stimulation: On the palmar surface of the hands, I use very thin needles (0.16 x 30mm) and stimulate them gently and carefully due to palmar sensitivity. Because of the prevalent nerve and blood supply and the strength of this muscle, strong stimulation is unnecessary. Be sure to watch the patient’s eyes and stop stimulation of the needles if you observe hard blinking, which indicates pain. Positioning after insertion: With these needles, the most comfortable resting position is with the patient’s hand on its side, palm facing the body. I may place a rolled-up hand towel under the wrist if the patient prefers it. The patient may be less comfortable if the needles are vertical or hanging downward. Unilateral vs. bilateral needling: These points are usually needled on the opposite side to treat neck and scapular pain. However, they can be needled bilaterally for bilateral Tai Yang (UB) neck pain, especially when it is not possible to needle 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons.
comments: Energetic pathways: Due to the Tai Yin/Tai Yang connection between the Lung and Urinary Bladder meridians, Double Child/Double Fairy points are instantly effective in the treatment of upper back, scapular, and Tai Yang neck pain. If the patient also has upper respiratory issues and/or gastroenteritis, these points will address those conditions as well as upper back and neck pain (22.11/LU10 area). However, I typically choose them only for scapular and neck pain. •  Imaging: Though they are always used together, Double Fairy treats the neck while Double Child treats the scapula and upper back. •  Diagnostics: Dark blood vessels found at the proximal end of the thenar eminence are diagnostic of uterine fibroids or tumors, endometriosis or lower jiao stagnation. •  Fallen pillow neck: When treating neck pain, I often cup the neck before needling. However, Double Child/Double Fairy points are particularly good in the treatment of sudden onset neck pain that is worsened by cupping or Tui Na. This situation usually occurs when someone has slept near an open window and contracted a wind chill. (The name, “fallen pillow neck,” refers to the cervical subluxation that suggests a loss of one’s pillow during the night.) •  Neck and back pain: Whereas UB65 Shu Gu with SI3 Hou Xi treats the back, and GB39/77.05-77.07 Three Weights treats the neck, Double Child/Double Fairy covers both. •  Hemiplegia: 22.01 and 22.02 are effective in the treatment of hemiplegia because they are located on the opposite side of the hand from 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai (Spirit Bone/Great White). I use these points for hemiplegia only if there are also respiratory or intestinal indications. See 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) for my comprehensive hemiplegia/stroke protocol. •  Pneumonia, fever, and bronchitis: Double Child/Double Fairy points are effective for pneumonia, fever, and bronchitis because they clear heat and sedate fire due to their proximity to 22.11 Earth Water (LU10), the Ying-Spring point of the Lung. •  Reaction Area of Heart and Lung: 22.02 Double Fairy has the additional Reaction Area of the Heart, which explains its indications of knee pain and palpitations. I do not use Double Fairy specifically for these indications; however, if the upper back and neck are treated with these points, these conditions may also improve. •  Case history (lung cancer, Dr. Lee): “I once treated a woman with late stage lung cancer. Although there was really no hope of keeping her alive, the family wanted me to treat her to reduce the pain. At 6:00 am I went to her house and needled Double Child/Double Fairy. At 5:00 pm after work I returned to see her and she had no pain at all. Two weeks later she died, but her family was grateful that her pain was relieved” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Acute neck sprain: Needle 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy on the opposite side with REN24 Cheng Jiang; usually, one treatment is enough. If the onset is sudden, REN24 Cheng Jiang may be enough. For immediate relief, rotate the neck every 10 minutes while the needles are retained (Active Qi Moving). •  Chronic neck pain: As a substitute for 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons, we can bilaterally needle 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy, adding REN24 as an immediate fix for neck pain. This is typically done only when the Achilles tendon has been compromised. 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy with PC6 Nei Guan is another option. (In classical Chinese medical literature, neck pain is considered a Jue Yin problem.) •  Hand pain: If the patient has difficulty opening and closing the hands, sedate or bleed 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) on the same side, and then needle 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy on the opposite side. For joint pain in the fingers, carpal tunnel syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis, we can also needle SJ5 Wai Guan as part of the Yang Wei Mai. •  Thenar eminence pain: Needle opposite side: 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy, 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, SJ5 Wai Guan and 33.04 Fire Threaded (SJ6), or 22.11 Earth Water. These points are all effective for hand pain. •  Pneumonia, cough, asthma, or lung problems in children: For children five years old or younger, quickly insert and remove the needles at 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy, without retention, or bleed the Si Feng (Extra Points). These kids may also need upper back cupping, Shoni-shin Japanese pediatric techniques, and/or spinal roll (starting at the bottom, roll the skin up the spine). Children older than five years can retain needles (with a good storybook); with them, I may use 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with A.04 San Cha Three or Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles. Kids of all ages can be cupped, slowly and carefully; the practitioner must adjust the pressure to olerance.

name: Chongxian, Double Fairy (T 22.02)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.02 Chongxian , is on the thenar eminence, between the first and second metacarpal bones, 1 cun below Chongzi (T 22.01) , 2 cun from the skin fold. It is exactly on the opposite side of Linggu (T 22.05) , which is on the dorsal aspect of the hand. | Johnson: Double Child and Double Fairy are easy to locate because they are often sensitive to palpation: 22.02 Double Fairy is located on the thenar eminence at the base of the palm. Holding the patient’s thumb closed against their hand, with their fingers straight, follow a line down the center of the index finger to locate the point, just distal to the proximal head of the first metacarpal bone. Roll your finger up and over the proximal end of the bone to palpate the point. 22.01 Double Child is located approximately 1.0 cun distal to Double Fairy, just proximal to the distal head of the first metacarpal bone. It is located straight across from the large knuckle of the thumb, one large cun (a big thumb’s breadth) medial to the edge of the hand. A line drawn between Double Child and Double Fairy is parallel to the side of the hand. Meridian: Lung Reaction Areas: Lung (22.01-22.02); Heart (22.02 only)
secondary_indications: Knee pain (especially the medial side on the SP channel) Common cold
johnson_indications: Upper back pain (between spine and scapula, UB43 area)*
Chest pain radiating from the upper back*
Difficulty opening and closing the hands or extending the fingers*
Knee pain (I never choose Double Child/Double Fairy for this indication, but knee pain may respond to these points)
Uterine or ovarian cysts or tumors*
Bronchitis (with phlegm that is difficult to expectorate)
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 cun . Deep needling tends to produce better results. Needle contralateral to the affected side when treating pain. When treating everything else, needle the side of Chongxian (T 22.02) where there is more pain upon palpation. This point can also be bled. Blue veins in this area indicate poor digestion or pain of the neck/shoulder/scapular area as this general area is reflective of the Stomach and the neck/shoulder/scapular areas. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 22.01 Double Child is combined with 22.02 Double Fairy.
