name: Shangbai, Upper White (T 22.03)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.03 Shangbai , is located on the dorsal aspect of the hand between the index and middle fingers, 0.5 cun proximal to the MCP joints of these fingers. | Johnson: Upper White is located on the dorsum of the hand, between the second and third metacarpal bones, 0.5 cun proximal to the metacarpal-phalangeal joint of the middle finger. Hand Golden Gate is located 1.0 cun proximal to 22.03 Shang Bai, between the second and third metacarpal bones, similar to the location of 66.05 Foot Golden Gate, which is between the second and third metatarsal bones. Fen Bai is located just proximal to the distal head of the first metacarpal bone, on the ulnar side. Find 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/ Da Bai and add Fen Bai to make a triangle of these three points.
primary_indications: weakness or tired eyes from overuse
johnson_indications: Weakness of the legs and feet
techniques: Needle 1 cun . This point is most often needled bilaterally for optimal effect. Needle bilaterally for neck pain. Needle bilaterally and retain needles for 1 hour for itchy eyes. Needle the diseased side for wrist sprain. Needle the healthy side for weakness of the feet. | Johnson: Bilateral needling: Needle Shang Bai bilaterally for neck, lower back and stomach pain Unilateral needling: Needle opposite the affected side for rib pain and sciatica. Needle on the affected side to treat wrist sprain at the radial side of the wrist (Dr. Young) and toothache. Depth: 0.5-0.7 cun Perpendicular insertion. Bilateral needling: Needle bilaterally for lower back pain. Unilateral needling: Needle the opposite side for gallbladder or kidney stone pain. Dao Ma: Most frequently used with 22.07 Lower White (Xia Bai) or as a Supporting Point for 22.03 Shang Bai (Upper White). Depth: 0.5-0.7 cun Needling instruction: Fen Bai is needled perpendicularly. When the shaft of the needle contacts the bone, a bone-treating-bone Kidney tonification function is obtained. Depth: .05-1.0 cun
comments: Reaction Areas: Shang Bai relates to the wood element via its Reaction Area (Liver) and its location between the Large Intestine and Pericardium channels, both of which share connections to the Liver: Hand Yang Ming (LI) shares a special relationship with Foot Jue Yin (LV), and Hand Jue Yin (PC) is connected with Foot Jue Yin (LV). Thus, Shang Bai acts as a wood Shu-Stream point that treats heaviness of the joints. The Reaction Area (Heart) and the special relationship between Hand Jue Yin (PC) and Foot Yang Ming (ST) explain the indications for stomach pain and also chest pain due 89 Hand Points to angina. The Reaction Area (Lung) and the word “white” in the name of this point indicate a relationship to the metal element, Lung and qi. Treating upper back and scapular pain: 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy points are better for upper back and scapular pain. Dr. Wei-Chieh Young discovered  Hand Men Jin. When combined with 22.07 Xia Bai to treat acute lumbar strain, this point increases effectiveness by 90%. Cholecystitis: Needle this point to treat cramping gallbladder pain caused by gallstones. It can be added to either 88.14-88.16 Gallbladder Points with 1010.18 Wood Branch or 66.03-66.04 Fire Hardness/Fire Master with 1010.18 Wood Branch. Urinary stones: Hand Golden Gate can be used in combination with 22.07 Xia Bai for gallbladder or bladder stones. Please see combinations below. To flush out bladder stones, use Chuan Niu Xi in addition to a damp-heat formula or stone formula, and drink a lot of corn silk tea. Energetic pathways: Fen Bai is located opposite 22.01 Double Child, while Ling Gu is located opposite 22.02 Double Fairy. For each set of opposites, the power of the points is enhanced when they are connected through deep needling of either point. Double Child relates to Lung and treats UB channel upper back and scapular pain, as it utilizes the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yang (UB).
combinations: Eye diseases: Combine 22.03 Upper White with bleeding 99.08 Ear Apex for redness of the canthus; combine with A.04 Three Jam Three for soreness and distension of the eyes; combine with 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows and 11.17 Wood (Anger) for itching of the eyes (Dr. Young). Twisted back (sudden): Needle 22.03 Upper White with  Hand Golden Gate. This is especially good for middle back and waist pain. Hand Golden Gate - Men Jin7 Acute lumbar strain: 22.07 Lower White (Xia Bai),  Hand Golden Gate; 22.03 Shang Bai,  Hand Golden Gate. Cramping gallbladder pain:  Hand Golden Gate, needled with 22.07 Lower White (Xia Bai) and Dan Nang Xue (Extra Point located 1-2.0 cun inferior to GB34 Yang Ling Quan), treats cramping gallbladder pain (due to gallstones). 7 I assigned reference numbers – 001 to Hand Golden Gate and 002 to Fen Bai – because these points were not previously included in any other numbering system, though mentioned by Dr. Young and McCann/Ross. Urinary stones: 001 Hand Golden Gate with 22.07 Lower White (Xia Bai) relieves the pain of kidney stones or gallbladder stones. Add 1010.13 Horse Gold Water (kidney stone), 1010.14 Horse Fast Water (bladder stone), and 1010.16 Six Fast for stones in the urethra. Add 11.17 Wood (Anger) for burning urine due to anger.  002 Divided White - Fen Bai8 Cutting Opposite and Behind - Fan Hou Jue9 Frozen shoulder: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 002 Fen Bai. See 77.08 Four Flower Upper, extensive commentary.

name: Dabai, Great White (T 22.04)
location: There are discrepancies among different sources as to the exact location of The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.04 Dabai . Some references state this point overlaps with Sanjian (LI 3) and some say Hegu (LI 4) . Therefore, palpate for the most tender point and needle the ah shi point on or between these two points. | Johnson: Da Bai is located on the back of the hand, just proximal and radial to the distal head of the second metacarpal bone. To find Da Bai (Great White) from the classic location of LI3 San Jian, move superior to the tendon and into the depression immediately inferior to the bone.
johnson_indications: Headache (due to common cold or flu)*
Poor absorption and digestion, difficult to gain weight
techniques: Bleed the point or nearby veins for respiratory disorders (asthma, fever, pneumonia). Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun along the bone. Needle contralateral to the affected side. | Johnson: Needling instruction: Da Bai is usually needled opposite the affected side, toward PC8 Lao Gong. The needle is wrapped around the second metacarpal bone in order to obtain an extra bone-treating-bone Kidney function. For sciatica, use a 1.0 to 1.5 cun needle; for other conditions, 1.0 cun is adequate. The point can also be needled perpendicularly. Bleeding: Da Bai can be bled; however, I have had unfavorable experiences (hematoma) when bleeding this point, so I prefer to needle it. Upper back points are easily bled for high fever, pneumonia, and childhood asthma. Depth: 0.5-1.5 cun
comments: Cautions: • Raises blood pressure. Dao Ma combination: Da Bai (Great White) is occasionally needled on its own, but is more commonly used in combination, with 22.05 Ling Gu (Spirit Bone) as the Chief Point and Da Bai as the Supporting Point. Often in Master Tung’s Dao Ma patterns, one point is supporting the other, but what makes this combination unique is that both Ling Gu and Da Bai, when used individually, are Chief Points. They are needled together primarily to treat a wide variety of diseases by tonifying the qi and warming the yang.10 Energetic pathways: Metal: White is the color of metal, indicating a connection to the metal element (Lung/Large Intestine). All “Bai/White” points (e.g., Da Bai, Shang Bai, Ci Bai, Zhong Bai, Xia Bai) treat the ears, eyes, nose and throat, as well as facial disorders. Da Bai (Great White) is also used in the treatment of high fever, bronchitis, pneumonia, emphysema, asthma, and headache due to common cold, for several reasons: it is located on the Large Intestine channel, which shares an internal/ external connection to the Lung; it has the Reaction Area of the Lung; and it is found in the upper jiao portion of the hand. Water: Acting as LI3 San Jian, Da Bai shares similar indications. Because Da Bai is needled closer to the bone – adding a bone-treating-bone, Kidney-tonifying function – it is superior to LI3 San Jian in the treatment of many Kidney-related diseases, such as lower back pain, sciatica, and weakness of the legs. Wood: Da Bai shares the energetic effects of LI3 San Jian, the Shu-Stream and wood point of the Hand Yang Ming, so both points treat wind in the Lung channel; however, Da Bai is much more powerful than LI3. Because the Hand Yang Ming (LI) meridian shares a special relationship with Foot Jue Yin (LV), Da Bai is effective for both internal and external wind conditions. Purplish vein near Da Bai in children: If there is a purplish vein in the area of Da Bai extending into the first phalange, always bleed it. This may appear with high fever, asthma or pneumonia; however, a dark vein here indicates a constitutional pathology of some kind. Bleeding LU11 Shao Shang and LI1 Shang Yang may be substituted when treating wind-heat conditions, though needling these points is more painful. See 22.05 Ling Gu (Spirit Bone) for additional commentary.
combinations: Common cold with headache: 22.04 Da Bai, A.04 San Cha Three. Sciatica (UB, GB, SP and ST): 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai. Groin pain: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 33.12 Heart Gate. Tennis elbow: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai. Dizziness: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai. Facial twitch: This is common after Bell’s palsy or excessive stress. Use 22.04 Da Bai, 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles. Trigeminal neuralgia: The middle branch of the trigeminal nerve is the most commonly affected area and can be difficult to resolve. Use 22.04 Da Bai and SI3 Hou Xi, because SI3 links to SI18 Quan Liao and the middle branch of the trigeminal nerve, while 22.04 Da Bai goes to the Yang Ming area (LI/ST) – the middle and lower branches of the nerve. Stimulate one needle on each side, or use all four for a stronger treatment, while the patient simultaneously moves their face (Active Qi Moving). Also consider 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/ Four Flower Middle. 10 When 22.04 Da Bai is combined with 22.05 Ling Gu, I always refer to this combination as “22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai.” Ling Gu as the Chief Point is listed first, even though the point numbering is reversed. Shao Yang branch: Use A.04 San Cha Three or 22.06 Zhong Bai to treat the upper branch of the trigeminal nerve, as Shao Yang relates to the side of the face. Additionally, for Shao Yang-type trigeminal neuralgia, use 77.05-77.07 Three Weights, 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles (or 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/Wood Scoop though less effective), adding 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan) for chronic cases. You may also bleed the Tai Yang area, being careful to avoid the artery. Herbs: Trigeminal neuralgia can be excruciatingly painful and may require narcotics. Wu Gong (centipede), Quan Xie (scorpion) and Jiang Can (silk worm) are all very useful in relieving severe pain due to wind, restoring normal flow of qi in all channels and collaterals, neutralizing toxins and dispersing nodules. Extremely small doses of each are used. 1.5 qian Quan Xie (scorpion) can be added to San Pien Tang in cases of unbearable pain.11 Insomnia: 22.04 Da Bai, 66.03 Fire Hardness (Tung’s LV2); this treatment is also known as Anxiety Four Gates or Fire Four Gates. Frequent urination: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. Painful urination: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 11.17 Wood (Anger), 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Fast Water/Horse Gold Water. Consider LI4/LV3 Four Gates. Spinal pain: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai. Consider bleeding UB40 Wei Zhong. Ischial nerve pain: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai. 11 Amounts indicated are for loose herbs measured in qian (1 qian = 3 grams)

name: Linggu, Spirit Bone (T 22.05)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.05 Linggu , is located on the LI channel, on the dorsal aspect of the hand, at the junction between the 1st and 2nd metacarpal bones, proximal to Hegu (LI 4) . This point is directly opposite to Chongxian (T 22.02) . | Johnson: Ling Gu is located on the dorsum of the hand, immediately distal to the proximal junction of the first and second metacarpal bones. Slide down the bone.
primary_indications: elbow pain Any gynecological and menstrual disorder Amenorrhea
insufficient lactation Any digestive disorder Poor appetite
xiao ke (wasting and thirsting) syndrome Any disorder of the face and head Eyes
any eye disorder Any strange or chronic disorder that is unresponsive to regular treatments
secondary_indications: chronic laryngitis with tickling and urge to cough
post-meningitis symptoms Various types of sweating
johnson_indications: Swelling of bone and surrounding tissue
techniques: Cautions: Forbidden to needle during pregnancy. Needle perpendicularly 1 - 1.5 cun . Patient should move his/her back while needles are being manipulated. Needle contralateral to the affected area. Avoid the radial artery when needling. When treating problems involving the bone, needles should be inserted along the edge of the bone or touching the bone for optimal effectiveness. | Johnson: Needling instruction: Ling Gu is needled perpendicularly, as close as possible to the junction of the first and second metacarpal bones. A bone-treating-bone Kidney tonification function is obtained when the needle shaft contacts the bone. Dao Ma: 22.05 Ling Gu (Spirit Bone) is almost always paired with 22.04 Da Bai (Great White). In this combination, Ling Gu is the Chief Point, and Da Bai is the Supporting Point. Depth: 0.5-1.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Ling Gu (Spirit Bone) is located on the Large Intestine meridian, anatomically between LU9 Tai Yuan (LU Yuan-Source/Shu-Stream point) and LI4 He Gu (LI Yuan-Source point). Ling Gu and Da Bai excel at tonifying qi deficiency anywhere in the body, primarily due to their location on either side of He Gu, a major Yuan-Source point. Da Bai links to the upper jiao, He Gu relates to the middle jiao, and Ling Gu relates to the lower jiao; therefore, indications are connected to all three jiao. The combination of Ling Gu/Da Bai nourishes and warms the yang, powerfully tonifies qi, and can be used to treat indications such as exhaustion, chronic cough or frequent urination due to yang deficiency. As explained below, Ling Gu and Da Bai regulate metal and water as well as wood and fire, and are internally/externally connected to the earth element (LI/ST), tonifying Stomach qi to treat insufficient digestion. The combination of these energetics makes Ling Gu and Da Bai among the most powerful acupuncture points on the entire body. Harmonizing metal and water: Ling Gu (Spirit Bone) and Da Bai (Great White) represent the relationship between descending Lung qi and receiving Kidney qi. Da Bai is in the upper jiao area of the hand, representing the Lung, while Ling Gu is in the lower jiao area of the hand, representing the Kidneys. Lung and Kidney nourish the yin, regulate fluids and tonify qi. By harmonizing metal and water, they regulate breathing. When the Lung qi is not descending, people pant; if the Kidney qi is not properly receiving, breathing is long and labored. Large Intestine and Lung are externally/internally related, and Ling Gu and Da Bai both share the Reaction Area of the Lungs. Additionally, Ling Gu is located opposite 22.02 Double Fairy; deep needling of either point connects them to each other and enhances their potency. Double Fairy relates to Lung and treats pain of the upper back and scapula along the UB channel because it utilizes the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yang (UB). It is because both Lung and Urinary Bladder disperse fluids, and Large Intestine and Lung are connected, that Ling Gu and Da Bai are useful in the treatment of frequent or painful urination. This same relationship (LI/LU/UB) accounts for the points’ extraordinary usefulness in the treatment of Urinary Bladder sciatica. Sciatica: Whether the sciatica is along the Urinary Bladder, Gallbladder, Spleen or Stomach channel, or a combination of these, Ling Gu and Da Bai can treat it. The special relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yang (UB), explained above, is one reason for these points’ unparalleled ability to strengthen the leg. Seventy percent of sciatica cases seen in the clinic are found along the Urinary Bladder channel and are related to the disc between the fifth lumbar vertebrae and the sacrum; twenty percent are connected to the L4-L5 disc and reflect on the Gallbladder channel. The remaining ten percent are L3-L4 disc related, affecting the Spleen or Stomach channel. If more than one disc is compromised, sciatica affects multiple channels. Ling Gu and Da Bai are the only Dao Ma combination found in Tung’s acupuncture that is capable of addressing all channels simultaneously. Energetic connections related to sciatica include: In TCM, the Kidney is said to govern the lower back and legs. Through the five-element relationship of metal (LU) as the mother of water (KD), the Lung and Kidney are connected. The points also strengthen the lower back due to the LU/UB special relationship (described above), as well as the internal/external relationship between the Kidney and Urinary Bladder, and the points’ Kidney tonification function that is activated when the needles contact the bone. Among these Kidney connections, an extremely important one is the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yin (KD). Many patients experience sciatica that is primarily along the Gallbladder channel or is a combination of Urinary and Gallbladder types. Because Hand Shao Yang and Foot Shao Yang (SJ/GB) share a pathway, this powerful relationship between Shao Yang and Shao Yin (SJ/KD) enables Ling Gu and Da Bai to treat both channels. Additionally, imaging systems reveal a correspondence between the fingers and the hips. There are further connections to lower back and Kidney: Ling Gu is located on the lower jiao segment of the hand, and the Kidney and Large Intestine channels are opposites on the Chinese clock (horary). Because Yang Ming (LI/ST) and Tai Yin (LU/SP) both connect to the earth element, Ling Gu and Da Bai are also effective in the treatment of sciatica along the Spleen or Stomach channel. Case histories (sciatica): Sciatica due to lung cancer (Dr. Lee): I remember a particular case in Dr. Lee’s clinic in which UB channel sciatica resolved quickly but returned the following day. This made Dr. Lee suspect a lung condition, so she ordered a chest X-ray that identified the patient’s lung cancer. Lung weakness may show up on the Urinary Bladder channel as either sciatica or scapular pain. Sciatica patient testing his “fix”: A patient in my practice was a heavy smoker with sciatica. After I needled Ling Gu and Da Bai, his sciatic pain completely disappeared. He went home and bench pressed to test the strength of his lower back after the treatment, as patients sometimes do. The pain immediately returned and was more severe than before, and I was not able to affect it with a second treatment the following day. It is best not to suggest to patients the possibility of cancer; however, I asked him to get a chest X-ray as soon as possible. Unfortunately, he never came back. It is always a good idea to remind patients to rest after their treatments. Regulating wood and fire: Points such as Ling Gu and Da Bai, which treat earth, metal and water simultaneously, are the best points for tonifying qi. When there is blood deficiency, the yin and fluids are also weak. When there is yang deficiency, qi and fire are lacking. Da Bai (Tung’s LI3), which is activated by LI4 He Gu (Source Point) and is a wood Shu point, strongly relates to wood. Ling Gu, also activated by He Gu and LI5 Yang Xi (fire point), relates to fire. Together, they tonify qi, generating wood to build fire and thus warming the yang. By tonifying qi and warming the yang, these points are able to build the blood. Because the Yang Ming channel has more qi and more blood, Ling Gu and Da Bai are not only tonifying but also regulating for the qi and blood, and they can be very useful in the treatment of muscle atrophy and hemiplegia as well as digestive weakness, poor appetite, abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, constipation, and stomach or anal prolapse. Wood/wind/tendon diseases: Because the Hand Yang Ming (LI) meridian shares a special relationship with the Foot Jue Yin (LV), Ling Gu and Da Bai are effective in the treatment of wood, wind and tendon diseases, such as: migraines; tinnitus; dizziness; hemiplegia; facial paralysis; shoulder pain; tennis elbow; pain in the hip, groin, knee or heel; and urinary or menstrual disorders. Brain connections: Through the special relationship of Large Intestine and Liver, Ling Gu and Da Bai connect with the brain. When combined with LV2 or LV3 and/or 11.17 Wood (Anger), they can be used for confused mental states, anxiety, depression or internalized rage. We find that classic, earth-type Four Gates LI4 He Gu with LV3 Tai Chong (22.05 Ling Gu/66.04 Fire Master, which is Tung’s LV3) and alternatively, fire- type Anxiety Four Gates (22.04 Da Bai with 66.03 Fire Hardness, which is Tung’s LV2), all derive their strength from the main Source points and strongest qi points of the Liver and Large Intestine channels.
combinations: Confused mental state: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, LI11 Qu Chi, 77.18- 77.21 Three Emperors. Dizziness: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, add LI11 Qu Chi (if due to Large Intestine/ Liver connection) or PC6 Nei Guan if there is nausea. Elbow pain: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai. Frozen Shoulder: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 002 Fen Bai. See 77.08 Four Flower Upper, comprehensive commentary. Groin pain: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 33.12 Heart Gate. Heel pain: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 11.27.5 Five Tiger (opposite side), UB65 Guiding Point. Hemiplegia: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), 77.18 Shen Guan. When blood pressure is still high, bleed DT.04 Five Mountain Range. See 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB21) for hemiplegia/stroke protocol. Stroke: Opposite side: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), A.01 Qi Li (GB32), DU19 Hou Ding and DU21 Qian Ding (threaded through DU20 Bai Hui). See 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB21) for hemiplegia/stroke protocol. Inguinal crease pain: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai. Ischial nerve pain: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai. Meniere’s disease: 22.05 Ling Gu, PC6 Nei Guan (one side), LI11 Qu Chi (other side), 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows. Frequent urination: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. Painful urination: 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 11.17 Wood (Anger), 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Fast Water/Horse Gold Water. Consider 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, LI4/LV3 Four Gates.

name: Zhongbai, Middle White (T 22.06)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.06 Zhongbai , is located on the TH channel and overlaps with Zhongzhu (TH 3) , which is on the dorsal aspect of the hand between the ring and little fingers, 0.5 cun proximal to the MCP joints of these fingers. | Johnson: 22.06 Middle White (Zhong Bai) is located on the dorsum of the hand, immediately proximal to the junction of the fourth and fifth metacarpal-phalangeal joints. (Zhong Bai is Tung’s version of SJ3 Zhong Zhu.) 22.07 Lower White (Xia Bai) is located 1.0 cun proximal to 22.06 Middle White.
primary_indications: ankle pain and heel pain due to Kidney deficiency Kidney disease or Kidney deficiency causing back pain and soreness
secondary_indications: dizziness High blood pressure with or without frontal headache Acute or chronic nephritis
edema of the extremities Disorders of the ears
johnson_indications: Waist, flank and rib pain (Dai Mai)
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 22.06 Zhong Bai (Chief Point) and 22.07 Xia Bai (Supporting Point) are most effective if used together in treating illness due to Kidney deficiency. Needling instruction: Use perpendicular insertion, avoiding the blood vessel if possible. Depth: 0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: The primary function of the Middle White/Lower White (Zhong Bai/Xia Bai) combination is a result of the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yin (KD), which makes for strong Kidney tonification. For this reason, the points are exceptionally effective in the treatment of Gallbladder channel sciatica and lower leg pain. Due to this connection, these points are also effective for nephritis, edema, exhaustion, spine pain, bone spurs, astigmatism, tinnitus and irritation at the roots of the teeth. Because there are so many San Jiao and Gallbladder points located on the sides of the head, 22.06-22.07 Zhong Bai/Xia Bai are especially good for clearing stagnation and bringing clear qi to the head. Similar to GB31, they treat Shao Yang wind issues, such as headache, migraine, mania, hypertension, Meniere’s disease, dizziness and vertigo. This is because of the Hand and Foot Shao Yang (SJ/GB) relationship, as well as the San Jiao/Pericardium/Liver/Gallbladder connections. Zhong Bai as a Guiding Point: Because of its easy access to the Shao Yang points on the head, Zhong Bai is a terrific Guiding Point for any indications related to the ears, shooting pain in the head, trigeminal neuralgia, TMJ or facial paralysis. Sciatica (Gallbladder): Zhong Bai is Tung’s version of SJ3 Zhong Zhu, the Shu-Stream point, so it treats heaviness and pain along the Shao Yang (SJ/GB) meridian, tonifying the qi of the San Jiao. It shares the same connection to the Kidney, and passes through the same area, as A.04 San Cha Three. Both of these points have a very powerful effect on sciatica as well as exhaustion from Kidney deficiency. Treatment: When treating Gallbladder channel sciatica, I usually combine Zhong Bai and Xia Bai with 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai. Of diagnostic interest, Gallbladder channel sciatica is especially characterized by pain when getting up from sitting. See 22.05 Ling Gu for comprehensive commentary on sciatica. Pain around the navel: SI3 Hou Xi (22.08 Wrist Prosperous One) with LI10 Shou San Li or LI11 Qu Chi treats pain around the navel. However, 22.06-22.07 Zhong Bai/Xia Bai are better than SI3 because they function like GB41 Lin Qi in tonifying the Kidney, and they open the Dai Mai to treat pain stuck in the waist and lower back. Pain behind the heart: Middle White/Lower White can be used like 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) and also UB60 Kun Lun (or all of them together) to treat palpitations, anxiety and pain behind the heart, due to the internal/external connection between the San Jiao and Pericardium (Heart Protector) and also the following energetic pathways and special relationships: SJ-PC-LV-GB-HT-KD-SJ.
combinations: Tinnitus: 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan), 22.06 Middle White. Teeth irritation: 22.06-22.07 Middle White/Lower White. Otitis media: Opposite-side 22.06-22.07 Middle White/Lower White and 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles, with 22.06 Zhong Bai on the same side as a Guiding Point. Trigeminal neuralgia: Opposite-side 22.06-22.07 Middle White/Lower White and 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles, with 22.06 Zhong Bai on the same side as a Guiding Point. Sciatica (Gallbladder): 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 22.06-22.07 Zhong Bai/Xia Bai or SJ5 Wai Guan (opposite side), 66.09 Water Curve (GB41) as a Guiding Point (same side). Of diagnostic interest, Gallbladder channel sciatica is especially characterized by pain when getting up from sitting.

name: Xiabai, -22.07 Zhong Bai/Xia Bai. (T 22.07)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.07 Xiabai , is located on the TH channel and overlaps with the extra point Yao Tong Xue , which is between the 4th and 5th metacarpal bones, 1.5 cun proximal to the MCP joints of these two fingers. It is 1 cun posterior to Zhongbai (T 22.06).
johnson_indications: Waist, flank and rib pain (Dai Mai)
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.5 cun deep. Needle contralateral to the affected side.
comments: Stones and roundworms: 22.07 Xia Bai (Lower White) is very good when used alone for tight, cramping pain of the kidney and gallbladder due to stones. It is also used alone for pain caused by roundworms. •  See 22.06 Zhong Bai (Middle White) for additional comments and combinations.

name: Wanshunyi, Wrist Prosperous One (T 22.08)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.08 Wanshunyi , is on the ulnar margin of the hand at the junction of the red and white skin, 2.5 cun distal to the wrist joint crease, or 0.5 cun proximal to Houxi (SI 3) , which is proximal to the 5th MCP joint. | Johnson: 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One is located 0.5 cun proximal to SI3 Hou Xi. 22.09 Wrist Prosperous Two is located 1.0 cun proximal to Wrist Prosperous One. Note: I always substitute SI3 Hou Xi for Wrist Prosperous One and Two. SI3 is easy to locate at the end of the solid crease under the distal head of the fifth metacarpal.
johnson_indications: Sciatica (Urinary Bladder channel due to Kidney deficiency)*
Spine and whole back pain along the Urinary Bladder channel*
Pain behind the knee (Urinary Bladder channel)*
Knee or ankle pain with flexion
Small Intestine channel wrist pain (Guiding Point)
Neck stiffness (cannot turn head side to side)
Lower abdominal pain due to water retention
Pain on both sides of the waist
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. | Johnson: Needling instruction: SI3 Hou Xi is needled much like 22.04 Da Bai, but is located on the opposite side of the hand. Wrap the needle around the fifth metacarpal bone just beneath the distal head, using a curving needle technique. You may needle at the crease found just proximal to the fifth metacarpal-phalangeal joint, since the skin of the crease is desensitized. I insert the needle as close as possible to the junction of red and white skin and the shaft of the metacarpal bone. Hand positioning: Bend the patient’s elbow and rest their loosely closed fist against their chest. This is the most comfortable needling position for the practitioner and the patient, and it allows for easier needling alongside the bone. Dao Ma: For weak patients, needle either Wrist Prosperous One or Wrist Prosperous Two but not both. Needle both points if the patient is strong. Depth: Shallow insertion (0.5 cun; heaven level) treats the shoulder, while deeper insertion (1.0 cun) goes to the lower back. Insertion to a depth of 1.5 cun treats the lower leg, sciatica, or the back of the knee.
comments: Similar in function to SI3 Hou Xi: 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One and 22.09 Wrist Prosperous Two are acting as Master Tung’s version of SI3 Back Ravine. The name “Back Ravine” refers to the vertebral column. Wrist Prosperous One and Two can be used together, but in most circumstances I use SI3 Hou Xi instead, and call it Wrist Prosperous One. The classical point Hou Xi is one of my very favorite points because it powerfully opens the spine, is the Master point of the Du Mai, and is the Shu-Stream point of the Hand Tai Yang channel. Some of the classical attributes of SI3 include: alleviating pain by activating the channel; clearing wind and heat; calming the spirit; regulating the Du Mai; benefiting the entire back and neck; reviving consciousness and opening the orifices; treating disorders of the head and senses, including tinnitus and deafness, mania and psychosis, epilepsy, and stroke; febrile diseases; jaundice; and malaria. Energetic pathways: The power of SI3 Hou Xi has to do with the connection between the Hand Tai Yang and Foot Tai Yang (SI/UB) and the internal/external relationship between the Urinary Bladder and Kidney. When the needle is curved under the bone, it activates an additional bone-treating-bone, Kidney tonification function. Deep needling of this point connects to 22.06 Zhong Bai (Tung’s SJ3), activating the special relationship between the San Jiao and Kidney (Hand Tai Yang/Foot Tai Yin). Because the Small Intestine has an internal/external connection with the Heart, and the Hand Shao Yin and Foot Shao Yin (HT/KD) share a pathway, all of the above-listed connections explain this point’s abundant Kidney-deficiency indications. SI3 is a good Guiding Point for frozen shoulder because of the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yang (SI) and the Foot Tai Yin (SP), as well as the connection of Hand and Foot Tai Yin (LU/SP). By utilizing the relationship between the Small Intestine and Spleen (treating the back of the shoulder, SI9-SI10), we can access the front of the shoulder, which relates to Lung and Spleen. Remember that SI3 is a very powerful wood Shu-Stream point, used for heaviness and pain because it drains wind (wood) and damp (earth). In Tung’s system, Urinary Bladder channel sciatica is often referred to as “Lung-deficient sciatica” due to the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yang (UB) channels, as well as the relationship between Hand Tai Yang and Foot Tai Yang (SI/UB). Because of these connections, SI3 Hou Xi is one of the best points for opening the spine, and it serves as a good starting place in the treatment of Urinary Bladder channel sciatica. Sciatica (Urinary Bladder channel): SI3 Back Ravine opens the spine. In combination with 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, it has an amazing effect in the treatment of opposite- side UB channel sciatica or any pain of the opposite thigh. UB65 Shu Gu, Bone Association Point, is added as an excellent Guiding Point to pull the qi into the affected leg. In severe cases, I may also needle 1010.22 Nose Wing or bleed DT.08 Essence Branch. SI3 is uniquely effective for pain in the back of the knee, swelling, or sciatica. Bone spur protocol (Dr. Young): Dr. Young taught me a powerful protocol for treating all bone spurs, and I use it regularly in my clinic: bilaterally needle SI3 Hou Xi, UB65 Shu Gu, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), and DU26 Ren Zhong, all of which treat tendon and bone. If the spurs are cervical, substitute REN24 Cheng Jiang for DU26 Ren Zhong in every other treatment when using this protocol, as REN24 Cheng Jiang is specific for cervical vertebrae. Both points are extremely painful, so needle to gently tap the bone and do not stimulate the point. Before needling either point, inform the patient that their eyes will water. Due to the sensitivity of these two points, it may be necessary to alternate the bone spur treatment protocol with other point patterns, such as 77.05-77.07 Three Weights (Tung’s GB39), to be sensitive to the patient and avoid their anticipation of pain. 119 Hand Points UB40: The most powerful treatment for bone spurs, especially along the spine, is the bleeding of UB40 Wei Zhong every two weeks. This clears stagnation and increases circulation by removing “dirty” blood and stimulating the production of new, freshly oxygenated blood cells in the bone marrow. Energetic pathways: We use SI3 Hou Xi because it is the Master point of the Du Mai and has the tremendous effect of opening the spine. UB65 Shu Gu, Bone Association Point, activates the Urinary Bladder channel, relaxes sinews, alleviates pain, clears heat, expels wind, and is good for inflammation. It is the wood Shu- Stream point on the Urinary Bladder channel and, as its name implies, is useful in treating bone. 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) expels wind and damp, activates the channel and alleviates pain. Because the Shao Yang channel controls bone, and GB31 Wind Market disperses wind, this point has much to do with the circulation of channels and collaterals and is specific to bone spurs. Likewise, DU26 Ren Zhong is specifically used for bone spurs; it clears the senses, cools heat, calms the spirit and benefits the spine, especially the lumbar spine. It is also the point at which the Yang Ming channel (LI/ST) intersects with the Du Mai. Inflammation: Bone spur pain comes from the surrounding soft tissue inflammation pressing on the nerve, and not from the spur itself, unless the spur is biting into the spinal cord. To make sure the inflammation does not return, it is essential to continue treatment with a formula for soft tissue inflammation after the pain is gone. If the bone spurs are severe, treat the patient three times per week. The spurs may not go away, but the pain should dissipate. Treatment for bone spurs takes at least 6-8 weeks if the spurs are located on the lumbar or cervical spine. If treatment does not resolve the pain, which can be severe, an MRI is required. It is essential that the patient rest! Diet is also crucial; the patient must avoid any kind of inflammatory food. Emulsified turmeric, Omega-3 fish oils, and boswellia supplements may also be helpful. Three Yellows: 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows or just 88.12 Bright Yellow (exactly opposite GB31) can also be used for bone spurs; add 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Middle/Lower if the spurs are found on the knee or heel. See 77.08 Four Flower Middle for other points that can be used for knee and heel spurs. Kidney deficiency/diagnostics: Wrist Prosperous tonifies the Kidneys and is used for many types of Kidney-deficient diseases, such as nephritis, exhaustion, dizziness, blurred vision, fatigue, swollen joints, headaches, and pain of the whole back and spine. If the side of the hand, including and below SI3, is thin, the patient may have had trouble with nephritis as a child. If it is soft and there are veins in this area, the patient may have a history of asthma. Medial elbow pain: For golfer’s elbow, needle opposite-side 33.12 Heart Gate with same-side SI3 Hou Xi, because SI3 is a great Guiding Point for any Small Intestine channel issues affecting the wrist, forearm, elbow, scapula or neck. Tinnitus or deafness: Combine SI3 with 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, because the Small Intestine channel ends at SI19 Ting Gong, Listening Palace, just in front of the ear opening.
combinations: Back pain: Needle opposite-side or bilateral SI3 Hou Xi, UB65 Shu Gu on the same side as a Guiding Point. For spine pain or muscle spasm on both sides of the spine, use both points bilaterally with strong stimulation. Bone spurs: SI3 Hou Xi, UB65 Shu Gu, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), and either DU26 Ren Zhong or REN24 Cheng Jiang. Bleed UB40 Wei Zhong every two weeks.

name: Wanshuner, Wrist Prosperous Two (T 22.09)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.09 Wanshuner , is on the ulnar margin of the hand at the junction of the red and white skin, 1.5 cun distal to the wrist joint, 1 cun proximal to Wanshunyi (T 22.08) . | Johnson: 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One is located 0.5 cun proximal to SI3 Hou Xi. 22.09 Wrist Prosperous Two is located 1.0 cun proximal to Wrist Prosperous One. Note: I always substitute SI3 Hou Xi for Wrist Prosperous One and Two. SI3 is easy to locate at the end of the solid crease under the distal head of the fifth metacarpal.
primary_indications: swelling of the bones in the extremities
popliteal fossa pain Acute neck sprain
upper back pain in between the scapulae
johnson_indications: Sciatica (Urinary Bladder channel due to Kidney deficiency)*
Spine and whole back pain along the Urinary Bladder channel*
Pain behind the knee (Urinary Bladder channel)*
Knee or ankle pain with flexion
Small Intestine channel wrist pain (Guiding Point)
Neck stiffness (cannot turn head side to side)
Lower abdominal pain due to water retention
Pain on both sides of the waist
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 - 1.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side or bilaterally. | Johnson: Needling instruction: SI3 Hou Xi is needled much like 22.04 Da Bai, but is located on the opposite side of the hand. Wrap the needle around the fifth metacarpal bone just beneath the distal head, using a curving needle technique. You may needle at the crease found just proximal to the fifth metacarpal-phalangeal joint, since the skin of the crease is desensitized. I insert the needle as close as possible to the junction of red and white skin and the shaft of the metacarpal bone. Hand positioning: Bend the patient’s elbow and rest their loosely closed fist against their chest. This is the most comfortable needling position for the practitioner and the patient, and it allows for easier needling alongside the bone. Dao Ma: For weak patients, needle either Wrist Prosperous One or Wrist Prosperous Two but not both. Needle both points if the patient is strong. Depth: Shallow insertion (0.5 cun; heaven level) treats the shoulder, while deeper insertion (1.0 cun) goes to the lower back. Insertion to a depth of 1.5 cun treats the lower leg, sciatica, or the back of the knee.
comments: Similar in function to SI3 Hou Xi: 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One and 22.09 Wrist Prosperous Two are acting as Master Tung’s version of SI3 Back Ravine. The name “Back Ravine” refers to the vertebral column. Wrist Prosperous One and Two can be used together, but in most circumstances I use SI3 Hou Xi instead, and call it Wrist Prosperous One. The classical point Hou Xi is one of my very favorite points because it powerfully opens the spine, is the Master point of the Du Mai, and is the Shu-Stream point of the Hand Tai Yang channel. Some of the classical attributes of SI3 include: alleviating pain by activating the channel; clearing wind and heat; calming the spirit; regulating the Du Mai; benefiting the entire back and neck; reviving consciousness and opening the orifices; treating disorders of the head and senses, including tinnitus and deafness, mania and psychosis, epilepsy, and stroke; febrile diseases; jaundice; and malaria. Energetic pathways: The power of SI3 Hou Xi has to do with the connection between the Hand Tai Yang and Foot Tai Yang (SI/UB) and the internal/external relationship between the Urinary Bladder and Kidney. When the needle is curved under the bone, it activates an additional bone-treating-bone, Kidney tonification function. Deep needling of this point connects to 22.06 Zhong Bai (Tung’s SJ3), activating the special relationship between the San Jiao and Kidney (Hand Tai Yang/Foot Tai Yin). Because the Small Intestine has an internal/external connection with the Heart, and the Hand Shao Yin and Foot Shao Yin (HT/KD) share a pathway, all of the above-listed connections explain this point’s abundant Kidney-deficiency indications. SI3 is a good Guiding Point for frozen shoulder because of the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yang (SI) and the Foot Tai Yin (SP), as well as the connection of Hand and Foot Tai Yin (LU/SP). By utilizing the relationship between the Small Intestine and Spleen (treating the back of the shoulder, SI9-SI10), we can access the front of the shoulder, which relates to Lung and Spleen. Remember that SI3 is a very powerful wood Shu-Stream point, used for heaviness and pain because it drains wind (wood) and damp (earth). In Tung’s system, Urinary Bladder channel sciatica is often referred to as “Lung-deficient sciatica” due to the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yang (UB) channels, as well as the relationship between Hand Tai Yang and Foot Tai Yang (SI/UB). Because of these connections, SI3 Hou Xi is one of the best points for opening the spine, and it serves as a good starting place in the treatment of Urinary Bladder channel sciatica. Sciatica (Urinary Bladder channel): SI3 Back Ravine opens the spine. In combination with 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, it has an amazing effect in the treatment of opposite- side UB channel sciatica or any pain of the opposite thigh. UB65 Shu Gu, Bone Association Point, is added as an excellent Guiding Point to pull the qi into the affected leg. In severe cases, I may also needle 1010.22 Nose Wing or bleed DT.08 Essence Branch. SI3 is uniquely effective for pain in the back of the knee, swelling, or sciatica. Bone spur protocol (Dr. Young): Dr. Young taught me a powerful protocol for treating all bone spurs, and I use it regularly in my clinic: bilaterally needle SI3 Hou Xi, UB65 Shu Gu, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), and DU26 Ren Zhong, all of which treat tendon and bone. If the spurs are cervical, substitute REN24 Cheng Jiang for DU26 Ren Zhong in every other treatment when using this protocol, as REN24 Cheng Jiang is specific for cervical vertebrae. Both points are extremely painful, so needle to gently tap the bone and do not stimulate the point. Before needling either point, inform the patient that their eyes will water. Due to the sensitivity of these two points, it may be necessary to alternate the bone spur treatment protocol with other point patterns, such as 77.05-77.07 Three Weights (Tung’s GB39), to be sensitive to the patient and avoid their anticipation of pain. 119 Hand Points UB40: The most powerful treatment for bone spurs, especially along the spine, is the bleeding of UB40 Wei Zhong every two weeks. This clears stagnation and increases circulation by removing “dirty” blood and stimulating the production of new, freshly oxygenated blood cells in the bone marrow. Energetic pathways: We use SI3 Hou Xi because it is the Master point of the Du Mai and has the tremendous effect of opening the spine. UB65 Shu Gu, Bone Association Point, activates the Urinary Bladder channel, relaxes sinews, alleviates pain, clears heat, expels wind, and is good for inflammation. It is the wood Shu- Stream point on the Urinary Bladder channel and, as its name implies, is useful in treating bone. 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) expels wind and damp, activates the channel and alleviates pain. Because the Shao Yang channel controls bone, and GB31 Wind Market disperses wind, this point has much to do with the circulation of channels and collaterals and is specific to bone spurs. Likewise, DU26 Ren Zhong is specifically used for bone spurs; it clears the senses, cools heat, calms the spirit and benefits the spine, especially the lumbar spine. It is also the point at which the Yang Ming channel (LI/ST) intersects with the Du Mai. Inflammation: Bone spur pain comes from the surrounding soft tissue inflammation pressing on the nerve, and not from the spur itself, unless the spur is biting into the spinal cord. To make sure the inflammation does not return, it is essential to continue treatment with a formula for soft tissue inflammation after the pain is gone. If the bone spurs are severe, treat the patient three times per week. The spurs may not go away, but the pain should dissipate. Treatment for bone spurs takes at least 6-8 weeks if the spurs are located on the lumbar or cervical spine. If treatment does not resolve the pain, which can be severe, an MRI is required. It is essential that the patient rest! Diet is also crucial; the patient must avoid any kind of inflammatory food. Emulsified turmeric, Omega-3 fish oils, and boswellia supplements may also be helpful. Three Yellows: 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows or just 88.12 Bright Yellow (exactly opposite GB31) can also be used for bone spurs; add 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Middle/Lower if the spurs are found on the knee or heel. See 77.08 Four Flower Middle for other points that can be used for knee and heel spurs. Kidney deficiency/diagnostics: Wrist Prosperous tonifies the Kidneys and is used for many types of Kidney-deficient diseases, such as nephritis, exhaustion, dizziness, blurred vision, fatigue, swollen joints, headaches, and pain of the whole back and spine. If the side of the hand, including and below SI3, is thin, the patient may have had trouble with nephritis as a child. If it is soft and there are veins in this area, the patient may have a history of asthma. Medial elbow pain: For golfer’s elbow, needle opposite-side 33.12 Heart Gate with same-side SI3 Hou Xi, because SI3 is a great Guiding Point for any Small Intestine channel issues affecting the wrist, forearm, elbow, scapula or neck. Tinnitus or deafness: Combine SI3 with 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, because the Small Intestine channel ends at SI19 Ting Gong, Listening Palace, just in front of the ear opening.
combinations: Back pain: Needle opposite-side or bilateral SI3 Hou Xi, UB65 Shu Gu on the same side as a Guiding Point. For spine pain or muscle spasm on both sides of the spine, use both points bilaterally with strong stimulation. Bone spurs: SI3 Hou Xi, UB65 Shu Gu, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), and either DU26 Ren Zhong or REN24 Cheng Jiang. Bleed UB40 Wei Zhong every two weeks.

name: Shoujie, Hand Release (T 22.10)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.10 Shoujie , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the hand, along the HT channel between the 4th and 5th metacarpal bones. The first point overlaps with Shaofu (HT 8) , which is where the tip of the little finger touches the palm when a fist is made. In general, this will be on the distal transverse palmar crease. The second point is 0.5 cun proximal to the first point. There are some sources that state this is an individual point (overlapping Shaofu (HT 8) ), while others state that it is a three-point set, with the third point being 0.5 cun proximal to the second one. | Johnson: Hand Release is located on the palmar surface of the hand, between the fourth and fifth metacarpal bones, at the spot where the little finger touches when the hand is locked in a grip. This is the same location as HT8 Shao Fu.
primary_indications: adverse reaction to acupuncture such as numbness
disorientation of qi flow Back pain
secondary_indications: cancer-related pain (especially Lung cancer and nasopharyngeal cancer)
used as an anesthesia point for dental work and surgeries
johnson_indications: Fainting or numbness caused by acupuncture needle insertion or when qi and blood are out of order
Itching, and irritability due to itching
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 - 0.8 cun. This point can also be bled for a more immediate effect. Needle contralateral to the affected side. | Johnson: Needling instruction: Bleed or needle this point. Retention: Retain needles for 5-10 minutes or until a stuck needle can be removed. Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Hand Release is the Ying-Spring fire point on a fire channel; it warms the yang and strengthens the Heart. Ying-Spring points are related to a change in face color (such as sudden red, white or green face coloration) from trauma or needling. The Heart controls the shen and zhi (will/intent), and most Heart channel points treat states of consciousness. The classics say, “All pain comes from the Heart.” Hand Release is useful for recovery from painful needling (hyperdermic or acupuncture) and swelling or pain from injuries. Dr. Lee found it useful for women who bled easily or who had excessive pain due to the use of hormone replacement therapy. Itching: Itching relates to the Heart. It causes the skin to change color and creates irritability, causing more itching. Hand Release calms itching as soon as it is needled because it is a Ying-Spring point that reduces fire, redness and heat. Itching is due to both wind and fire fighting, and qi and blood fighting. The treatment principle is to disperse wind, reduce fire and vitalize the blood. Some skin diseases, such as psoriasis, are more common in wealthy cultures due to rich foods, environmental toxins, pet allergens, etc. To treat itchy skin and rashes, I bleed 99.08 Ear Apex, cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas, and needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with A.04 San Cha Three. 88.28 Release (Tung’s ST34): Similar to Hand Release, 88.28 is also used for disturbance in the flow of qi and blood, swelling and pain from needling or traumatic injury, and extreme fatigue. 88.28 is found on the Stomach channel, just below classic ST34 Liang Qiu. See 88.28 Release for further information.
combinations: Itching: To treat itchy skin and rashes, bleed 99.08 Ear Apex, cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas, and needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with A.04 San Cha Three. See Comments, above. Swelling and pain from needling or traumatic injury, extreme fatigue, disturbance in the flow of qi and blood: Bleed or needle 22.10 Hand Release or needle 88.25 Release.

name: Tushui, Earth Water (T 22.11)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.11 Tushui , is a three-point set on the LU channel, on the palmar aspect of the thumb, evenly distributed along the radial margin of the metacarpal bone (line A). The center point overlaps with Yuji (LU 10) . The second and third points are 0.5 cun distal and 0.5 cun proximal to the center point. | Johnson: Earth Water is a three-point unit located on the palmar surface of the hand. The central point is LU10 Yu Ji, located at the midpoint of the first metacarpal bone. The other two points are located 0.5 cun from either side of the central point. These points are found on the radial side of the first metacarpal bone, palmar to the border of the red and white skin, in the depression between the first metacarpal bone and the thenar muscles.
johnson_indications: Hand pain: hand or finger bone pain or inflammation
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun . For knee pain, needle along the edge of the bone. | Johnson: Often bled: In cases of acute asthma, bleeding 22.11 Earth Water may improve breathing immediately. Use a spring-loaded lancet or shallow puncture to bleed the veins in this area. Avoid blood vessels: When needling these points, avoid the blood vessels found in the area. Depth: 0.5 cun
comments: Lung channel: The Lung channel originates in the middle jiao, in the region of the Stomach, and then travels downward to the Large Intestine. From there it ascends close to the cardiac sphincter, crosses the diaphragm, enters the lungs and connects to the Stomach and Kidney channels via the Chong Mai. The primary channel then emerges at LU1 Zhong Fu and descends along the arm, lateral to the Heart and Pericardium channels. Energetic pathways: Tung’s LU10 are the three points included in Tu Shui/Earth Water; they have the Reaction Areas of the Spleen and Kidney, indicating the connection to earth (Spleen/Stomach) and water (Kidney/Urinary Bladder). As Lung and Large Intestine are both metal, Earth Water therefore relates to metal, earth and water, treating diseases of the Lung, Spleen, Stomach, Large Intestine and Kidney. Textbook LU10 Yu Ji descends Lung qi, relieves sore throat, clears Lung heat, descends rebellious qi, and harmonizes the Stomach and Heart. Likewise, Earth Water tonifies and regulates qi and is very effective in the treatment of gastrointestinal and lung conditions (especially asthma). Its efficacy is due to the internal/external relationship between Lung and Large Intestine, which is strengthened by the Hand and Foot Tai Yin relationship (LU/SP) and the Hand and Foot Yang Ming relationship (LI/ST). Hand Tai Yin (LU) shares a special relationship with Foot Tai Yang (UB), and both of them diffuse water; this further explains the use of Earth Water in draining dampness. Gastroenteritis: The middle point (metal) of the three-point Earth Water is textbook LU10 Yu Ji, the Chief Point in this pattern, and it can be used to treat acute stomachache. The distal point (earth) represents the Spleen and Stomach, and it is a Supporting Point that treats qi deficiency. The proximal point (water) represents cold and Kidney, and it is a Supporting Point that treats diarrhea. Earth Water therefore effectively drains cold or hot dampness, including damp heat from the Stomach, via the intestines and urinary bladder. Sore throat: Because the Chief Point of Earth Water overlaps LU10 Yu Ji, the fire Ying- Spring point, it is effective in the treatment of sore throat due to external pathogenic wind heat. Asthma: LU10 can stop wheezing immediately, especially when it is bled. Because the thenar eminence has a large supply of nerves and blood, bleeding veins in this area is excellent for asthma, emphysema or pneumonia. However, this is painful, and puncturing the area too deeply can create lingering pain and bruising. For that reason, I use a spring-loaded lancet and bleed only when absolutely necessary. Good alternatives are to bleed or needle 33.16 Curve Mound (Tung’s LU5), or to cup (and/or bleed) points on the upper back. If a patient comes to you in an emergency asthmatic condition, on their way to the hospital to get on a respirator, you can buy time by cupping Ding Chuan (Extra Point) and bleeding LU5, then follow with additional treatment for asthma. This may allow the patient to avoid the emergency room. Diagnostic veins: According to the Huangdi Neijing, the area of the thenar eminence can help diagnose gastric and intestinal disorders (Dr. Carson, 1988). If the thenar eminence is a blue or green color, it indicates Stomach cold (excess water in the earth), while red color indicates Stomach heat. This area is often red when there is constipation, or green when there is acute diarrhea or loose stool from cold; it may have blue swollen veins if there is enteritis or severe diarrhea (Dr. Young). A plethora of veins located in the lower third of the thenar eminence is often diagnostic of uterine fibroids, cysts or tumors. Thirty percent of women over 30 years of age have fibroids. If a patient has many veins in this area, ask her if she has frequent urination or lower back pain during menses, indicative of a tipped uterus due to fibroids. Metacarpal thumb pain: Though less effective than 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy, Earth Water is used to treat hand pain, especially due to injury, when needled on the opposite side. 22.11 is a good option specifically for metacarpal thumb pain, as 11.27.1-2 Five Tigers and 66.01 Seal are only effective when treating the phalangeal joints of the thumb.
combinations: Acute or chronic diarrhea: 22.11 Earth Water, 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), LI11 Qu Chi. Asthma (cold type): Needle 22.11 Earth Water with 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through and LU5 Chi Ze. Asthma (hot type): 22.11 Earth Water (needle with strong sedation, or bleed LU10), deeply needle 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36). Pneumonia: Bleed 22.11 Earth Water to clear heat and sedate fire. Sore throat: Needle LU10 Yu Ji and A.04 San Cha Three, one point on each hand, for any type of sore throat but especially due to common cold (Dr. Young). Bleed VT.01 Nine Moths. For sore throat due to dryness, eat egg fried in sesame oil to moisten the lungs. Stomach diseases and infantile malnutrition: 22.11 Earth Water (LU10), 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4) (Dr. Young).

name: Fanhoujue * (T 22.12)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.12 Fanhoujue , is on the dorsal aspect of the hand, 1 cun distal to Linggu (T 22.05) at the ulnar margin of the first metacarpal bone.
techniques: Needle 0.5 cun along the edge of the bone.

name: Xiaojie * (T 22.13)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.13 Xiaojie , is on the LU channel, at the junction of the shaft and head of the first metacarpal bone, at the border between the palmar and dorsal aspects of the thumb (line A).
secondary_indications: and pain of the wrist and elbow Stomach pain
techniques: Thread the needle 1 - 1.5 cun along the bone towards the wrist, Daling (PC 7) .

name: Sanchayi * (T 22.15)
location: When making a fist, the Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.15 Sanchayi , is on the dorsal aspect of the hand, in the junction between the 2nd and 3rd phalanges.
secondary_indications: stomach pain Irregular menstruation Weak lung qi
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun towards the wrist while the patient makes a fist. Needle should go in parallel to the skin of the dorsum of the hand.

name: Sanchaer * (T 22.16)
location: When making a fist, the Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.16 Sanchaer , is on the dorsal aspect of the hand, in the junction between the 3rd and 4th phalanges.
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun towards the wrist while the patient makes a fist. The needle should go in parallel to the skin of the dorsum of the hand.

name: Sanchasan * (T 22.17)
location: When making a fist, the Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.17 Sanchasan , is on the dorsal aspect of the hand, in the junction between the 4th and 5th phalanges.
primary_indications: edema from nephritis or other kidney diseases Severe common cold
secondary_indications: redness and swelling or pain of the eyes
techniques: Needle 1 - 1.5 cun towards the wrist while the patient makes a fist. The needle should go in parallel to the skin of the dorsum of the hand.

name: Zhihan * (T 22.18)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.18 Zhihan , is on the TH channel, on the dorsal aspect of the hand, between the 3rd and 4th metacarpal bones, 1.5 cun proximal to these MCP joints.
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Shoujingdian * (T 22.19)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.19 Shoujingdian , is on the TH channel, on the dorsal aspect of the hand in between the 3rd and 4th metacarpal bones, 0.5 cun proximal to the MCP joint.
primary_indications: taiyang and Du (governing) channel neck pains.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Shanggao * (T 22.21)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.21 Shanggao , is on the palmar aspect of the hand, along the HT channel between the 4th and 5th metacarpal bones, 0.5 cun proximal to the second point of Shoujie (T 22.10) , along the edge of the 5th metacarpal. Some sources state it is 1 - 1.5 cun proximal to Shaofu (HT 8) , which is where the tip of the little finger touches when a fist is made. To determine where to needle, palpate for the strongest ah shi sensation in this area of the palm.
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.8 cun .

name: Xiagao * (T 22.22)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.22 Xiagao , is on the palmar aspect of the hand, along the HT channel between the 4th and 5th metacarpal bones, 0.5 cun proximal to Shanggao (T 22.21)* , along the edge of the 5th metacarpal. To determine where to needle, palpate for the strongest ah shi sensation in this area of the palm.
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.8 cun .

name: Guguan * (T 22.24)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.24* Guguan , is on the palmar aspect of the hand, 0.5 cun distal and 0.5 cun radial to Daling (PC 7) .
primary_indications: and heat sensation in the uterus Hemiplegia
bone spur causing pinched nerve and neuralgia Duodenal ulcer Excess uric acid in the body
techniques: Needle perpendicularly or obliquely 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Zhongguan * (T 22.25)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.25* Zhongguan , is located on the PC channel, on the palmar aspect of the hand, 0.5 cun distal to Daling (PC 7) , which is in the middle of the transverse crease of the wrist.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle obliquely and distally up to 1.5 cun for disorders of the bone, including bone spurs.

name: Muguan * (T 22.26)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.26* Muguan , is on the palmar aspect of the hand, 0.5 cun distal and 0.5 cun ulnar to Daling (PC 7) .
primary_indications: drug poisoning Any gynecological disorders involving inflammation and heat
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle obliquely and distally up to 1.5 cun for disorders of the bone, including bone spurs.

name: Tianweixue * (T 22.27)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.27* Tianweixue , in an ashi point is located between Lieque (LU 7) and Yangxi (LI 5) .
primary_indications: Smoking and substance abuse urges to overcome addiction
techniques: Needle, moxa, or massage

name: Qimen, This Door (T 33.01)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.01 Qimen , is on the LI channel, 2 cun proximal to the wrist crease. | Johnson: This Door, This Corner and This Uprightness are located on the back side of the radial bone, along the Large Intestine meridian. Use LI4 and LI11 as reference points. 33.01 This Door is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) proximal to the wrist crease. 33.02 This Corner is located 2.0 cun proximal to the first point. 33.03 This Uprightness is located 2.0 cun proximal to the second point.
techniques: Needle 15 degrees obliquely towards Yangxi (LI 5) , 0.2 - 0.5 cun . It is said that perpendicular needling yields no therapeutic effect. | Johnson: Dao Ma: This Door, This Corner, and This Uprightness are needled together, unilaterally. I usually needle them on the left side, though needling them on the right side is allowed. Positioning and needling: Locate the points on the Large Intestine channel, with the patient’s forearm across their chest. Pinch up the skin and horizontally thread 30mm needles in one of two directions (see below). Insert the needle 1 mm under the epidermis and on top of the muscle. Then, flattening the shaft of the needle against the skin to use it as a guide, keep the needle superficial as you insert it. After initial insertion, when you flatten the shaft against the skin, if you see a slight “pucker” of skin in front of the tip of the needle, back the needle out slightly so that the skin flattens out and the pucker disappears, then proceed with inserting superficially between the epidermis and the muscle beneath. Due to the many veins in this area that may cause the needles to skew, you will likely need to slightly reposition the needles to correct their trajectory once they are inserted, aligning them as if on a line drawn between LI4 and LI11. If the needles are inserted correctly, the patient should be able to comfortably and fully rotate their forearm. Pain with rotation of the arm usually implies that the insertion is too deep. Tonification vs. sedation: In cases of deficiency (more common than excess conditions), tonify the points by needling toward the elbow with the flow of the Large Intestine channel. If there is an excess condition, sedate the points by needling toward the wrist. Depth: Thread the needles horizontally beneath the skin, 1.0 cun.
comments: Imaging: This area of the forearm corresponds with the anus and genitals. The point closest to the wrist treats the navel, while the more proximal point treats the anus. I primarily use these points in the treatment of hemorrhoids, anal fissures, and prolapse. They derive their power in part from LI7 Wen Liu, the Xi-Cleft point of the Large Intestine, which is located between This Door and This Corner; Xi-Cleft points regulate qi and blood. I have needled these points in both directions, depending on whether the patient had an excess or deficient condition. If I am treating a hard and dry (excess) constipation, I needle against the meridian, toward the wrist. If I am treating anal 129 Hand Points prolapse, hemorrhoids or bleeding, I thread the needles along the back side of the radius, toward the elbow. Hemorrhoids and constipation: This area of the forearm is useful in the treatment of hemorrhoids. It includes the area of extra point Er Bai (located four cun proximal to PC7 Da Ling on both sides of the tendon) and 33.04 Fire Threaded (SJ6), and it mirrors 77.04 Catching Ball (UB57). All three of these are used to treat constipation and hemorrhoids. Bleeding UB40: Even more effective for hemorrhoids is the bleeding of UB40 Wei Zhong. Hemorrhoids are a form of varicosity, indicating blood stagnation. The bleeding of veins in the popliteal crease clears the stagnant, black (deoxygenated) blood and stimulates the bone marrow to produce fresh, oxygenated blood. In severe cases of constipation and/or hemorrhoids, I bleed two or three veins on the back of each knee. In most cases, very dark blood appears and the hemorrhoids are significantly improved within 24 hours. If there are no obvious veins, do not bleed. Prolapse: Prolapse is thought of as a dropping down or slipping of the qi, and in TCM it relates to the Lung and Kidney. These points, found on the Large Intestine meridian, have an internal/external relationship with the Lung and the Reaction Area of Lung. Because Lung is the mother of Kidney, we can use the analogy of a straw in a glass of water to describe the ability of the Lung to draw qi upwards, strengthening the Kidney. If we cap the top of a straw with our finger and lift it out of the water, the straw remains full. This illustrates the action of strong Lung qi. When we uncap the straw, the water drops out; this can be likened to Lung deficiency causing Kidney weakness (incontinence). If the Lung energy is weak, there may be anal prolapse, menstrual spotting or urinary incontinence. We can use this analogy to understand any kind of prolapse, including hemorrhoids; it is also relevant for uterine bleeding. Additionally, if a laboring mother has a cough due to Lung excess, labor is delayed because the excess is delaying or holding up the descent of the baby. In this case, the treatment principle is to disperse Lung qi to induce labor. Gynecological indications: The special relationship between the Hand Yang Ming (LI) and Foot Jue Yin (LV) explains the gynecological indications for these points. Because so many other points treat female reproductive diseases, I only choose 33.01-33.03 This Door/This Corner/This Uprightness if the patient also has hemorrhoids, fissures or constipation.

name: Qijiao, This Corner (T 33.02)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.02 Qijiao , is on the LI channel, 4 cun proximal to the wrist crease. | Johnson: This Door, This Corner and This Uprightness are located on the back side of the radial bone, along the Large Intestine meridian. Use LI4 and LI11 as reference points. 33.01 This Door is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) proximal to the wrist crease. 33.02 This Corner is located 2.0 cun proximal to the first point. 33.03 This Uprightness is located 2.0 cun proximal to the second point.
techniques: Needle 15 degrees obliquely towards Yangxi (LI 5) , 0.2 - 0.5 cun . It is said that perpendicular needling yields no therapeutic effect. | Johnson: Dao Ma: This Door, This Corner, and This Uprightness are needled together, unilaterally. I usually needle them on the left side, though needling them on the right side is allowed. Positioning and needling: Locate the points on the Large Intestine channel, with the patient’s forearm across their chest. Pinch up the skin and horizontally thread 30mm needles in one of two directions (see below). Insert the needle 1 mm under the epidermis and on top of the muscle. Then, flattening the shaft of the needle against the skin to use it as a guide, keep the needle superficial as you insert it. After initial insertion, when you flatten the shaft against the skin, if you see a slight “pucker” of skin in front of the tip of the needle, back the needle out slightly so that the skin flattens out and the pucker disappears, then proceed with inserting superficially between the epidermis and the muscle beneath. Due to the many veins in this area that may cause the needles to skew, you will likely need to slightly reposition the needles to correct their trajectory once they are inserted, aligning them as if on a line drawn between LI4 and LI11. If the needles are inserted correctly, the patient should be able to comfortably and fully rotate their forearm. Pain with rotation of the arm usually implies that the insertion is too deep. Tonification vs. sedation: In cases of deficiency (more common than excess conditions), tonify the points by needling toward the elbow with the flow of the Large Intestine channel. If there is an excess condition, sedate the points by needling toward the wrist. Depth: Thread the needles horizontally beneath the skin, 1.0 cun.
comments: Imaging: This area of the forearm corresponds with the anus and genitals. The point closest to the wrist treats the navel, while the more proximal point treats the anus. I primarily use these points in the treatment of hemorrhoids, anal fissures, and prolapse. They derive their power in part from LI7 Wen Liu, the Xi-Cleft point of the Large Intestine, which is located between This Door and This Corner; Xi-Cleft points regulate qi and blood. I have needled these points in both directions, depending on whether the patient had an excess or deficient condition. If I am treating a hard and dry (excess) constipation, I needle against the meridian, toward the wrist. If I am treating anal prolapse, hemorrhoids or bleeding, I thread the needles along the back side of the radius, toward the elbow. Hemorrhoids and constipation: This area of the forearm is useful in the treatment of hemorrhoids. It includes the area of extra point Er Bai (located four cun proximal to PC7 Da Ling on both sides of the tendon) and 33.04 Fire Threaded (SJ6), and it mirrors 77.04 Catching Ball (UB57). All three of these are used to treat constipation and hemorrhoids. Bleeding UB40: Even more effective for hemorrhoids is the bleeding of UB40 Wei Zhong. Hemorrhoids are a form of varicosity, indicating blood stagnation. The bleeding of veins in the popliteal crease clears the stagnant, black (deoxygenated) blood and stimulates the bone marrow to produce fresh, oxygenated blood. In severe cases of constipation and/or hemorrhoids, I bleed two or three veins on the back of each knee. In most cases, very dark blood appears and the hemorrhoids are significantly improved within 24 hours. If there are no obvious veins, do not bleed. Prolapse: Prolapse is thought of as a dropping down or slipping of the qi, and in TCM it relates to the Lung and Kidney. These points, found on the Large Intestine meridian, have an internal/external relationship with the Lung and the Reaction Area of Lung. Because Lung is the mother of Kidney, we can use the analogy of a straw in a glass of water to describe the ability of the Lung to draw qi upwards, strengthening the Kidney. If we cap the top of a straw with our finger and lift it out of the water, the straw remains full. This illustrates the action of strong Lung qi. When we uncap the straw, the water drops out; this can be likened to Lung deficiency causing Kidney weakness (incontinence). If the Lung energy is weak, there may be anal prolapse, menstrual spotting or urinary incontinence. We can use this analogy to understand any kind of prolapse, including hemorrhoids; it is also relevant for uterine bleeding. Additionally, if a laboring mother has a cough due to Lung excess, labor is delayed because the excess is delaying or holding up the descent of the baby. In this case, the treatment principle is to disperse Lung qi to induce labor. Gynecological indications: The special relationship between the Hand Yang Ming (LI) and Foot Jue Yin (LV) explains the gynecological indications for these points. Because so many other points treat female reproductive diseases, I only choose 33.01-33.03 This Door/This Corner/This Uprightness if the patient also has hemorrhoids, fissures or constipation.

name: Qizheng, This Uprightness (T 33.03)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.03 Qizheng , is on the LI channel, 6 cun proximal to the wrist crease. | Johnson: This Door, This Corner and This Uprightness are located on the back side of the radial bone, along the Large Intestine meridian. Use LI4 and LI11 as reference points. 33.01 This Door is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) proximal to the wrist crease. 33.02 This Corner is located 2.0 cun proximal to the first point. 33.03 This Uprightness is located 2.0 cun proximal to the second point.
techniques: Needle 15 degrees obliquely towards Yangxi (LI 5) , 0.2 - 0.5 cun . It is said that perpendicular needling yields no therapeutic effect. | Johnson: Dao Ma: This Door, This Corner, and This Uprightness are needled together, unilaterally. I usually needle them on the left side, though needling them on the right side is allowed. Positioning and needling: Locate the points on the Large Intestine channel, with the patient’s forearm across their chest. Pinch up the skin and horizontally thread 30mm needles in one of two directions (see below). Insert the needle 1 mm under the epidermis and on top of the muscle. Then, flattening the shaft of the needle against the skin to use it as a guide, keep the needle superficial as you insert it. After initial insertion, when you flatten the shaft against the skin, if you see a slight “pucker” of skin in front of the tip of the needle, back the needle out slightly so that the skin flattens out and the pucker disappears, then proceed with inserting superficially between the epidermis and the muscle beneath. Due to the many veins in this area that may cause the needles to skew, you will likely need to slightly reposition the needles to correct their trajectory once they are inserted, aligning them as if on a line drawn between LI4 and LI11. If the needles are inserted correctly, the patient should be able to comfortably and fully rotate their forearm. Pain with rotation of the arm usually implies that the insertion is too deep. Tonification vs. sedation: In cases of deficiency (more common than excess conditions), tonify the points by needling toward the elbow with the flow of the Large Intestine channel. If there is an excess condition, sedate the points by needling toward the wrist. Depth: Thread the needles horizontally beneath the skin, 1.0 cun.

Prolapse: Prolapse is thought of as a dropping down or slipping of the qi, and in TCM it relates to the Lung and Kidney.
