Because so many other points treat female reproductive diseases, I only choose 33.01-33.03 This Door/This Corner/This Uprightness if the patient also has hemorrhoids, fissures or constipation.

name: Huochuan, Fire Threaded (T 33.04)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.04 Huochuan , overlaps with Zhigou (TH 6) , which is located 3 cun proximal to the wrist crease in between the radius and the ulna. | Johnson: Fire Threaded is located 3.0 cun (four fingers) proximal to the wrist crease, on the posterior surface of the forearm, centered between the radius and the ulna. This is the same location as SJ6 Zhi Gou.
primary_indications: chest pain that may radiate to the back
radiating spasms or cramps of the forearm or hand
johnson_indications: Ankle sprain (A.05 Small Joint is better for treating ankle sprain.)
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle deeper to penetrate the PC channel for cardiovascular disorders. | Johnson: Patient positioning: Needled singularly, this point does not require any specific position. However, if needled as a Dao Ma with 33.05 Fire Mound and 33.06 Fire Mountain, the point should be located with the patient’s forearm lying across their chest and elbow resting on the table. Needle unilaterally only, on the same side or opposite side as the indications. Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Fire Threaded has the Reaction Area of the Heart and Lung and is a fire point on a fire channel, connecting the San Jiao and Pericardium meridians. Indications for these points relate to both Liver and Kidney due to the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yin (KD), the San Jiao and Pericardium (internal/external), and the Liver through the Hand and Foot Jue Yin (PC/LV). Fire element: This point is located at SJ6 Zhi Gou (the fire point on a fire meridian). “Huo” in the point name translates as “fire,” indicating the internal/external connection between the San Jiao and Pericardium. “Chuan” in the name may be translated as “stringing together” (Dr. Carson) or “threaded” (Dr. Young), referring to the fact that we needle from SJ6 through to the Pericardium meridian, thereby affecting the chest and heart. Constipation: Fire Threaded is primarily used for constipation because it regulates qi and controls fire. 66.13 Water Crystal (Tung’s KD6) can be added; together they regulate qi and tonify fluids. Dao Ma: Fire Threaded is often combined with 33.05 Fire Mound and 33.06 Fire Mountain to treat chest pain or spasm of the hand or forearm. These are very powerful points, so needle them on one side only – either on the same side as the chest pain, or on the right side for women and the left side for men. Lower back and waist: Fire Threaded treats acute muscular strain of the waist or low back, due to the special connection between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yin (KD). Shao Yang pain: Due to the internal/external connection between the Hand and Foot Shao Yang (SJ/GB), this point treats sprained ankle and stiff neck, though I would more likely choose A.05 Small Joint for ankle sprain and 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles for Shao Yang neck pain. If Fire Threaded is used for other reasons and the ankle or neck responds, it is because of the Shao Yang connection. Rib pain: This point is effective in the treatment of rib pain, especially toward the front of the body; for lateral rib pain, add GB34 Yang Ling Quan.
combinations: Chest pain and fullness: 33.04 Fire Threaded, 33.05 Fire Mound, 33.06 Fire Mountain. Constipation: Bilaterally needle: 33.04 Fire Threaded, 66.13 Water Crystal (Tung’s KD6). Rib pain: Needle opposite side: 33.04 Fire Threaded, GB34 Yang Ling Quan.

name: Huoling, Fire Mound (T 33.05)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.05 Huoling , is on the TH channel, 5 cun proximal to the wrist, and 2 cun proximal to Huochuan (T 33.04) . | Johnson: Fire Mound is located 5 cun proximal to the wrist crease (1.5 cun/two fingers proximal to 33.04 Fire Threaded) on the San Jiao channel.
primary_indications: chest distension with radiating spasms or cramps of the forearm or hand
radiating finger numbness GB channel sciatica
johnson_indications: Cramping, fullness or tightness of the chest with sadness or depression*
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun . Needle deeper to penetrate the PC channel for cardiovascular disorders. Needle contralateral to the affected side. | Johnson: Patient positioning: Locate the point with the patient’s forearm across their chest, elbow resting on the table. Needle unilaterally only, on the same side or opposite side as the indications. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Dao Ma: Please review Comments for the previous point, 33.04 Fire Threaded, as they also apply to this point. Generally, I needle 33.04 Fire Threaded, 33.05 Fire Mound and 33.06 Fire Mountain together, especially for cramping chest spasm or severe chest pain and tightness with shortness of breath. This chest pain is not true angina; instead, it is more muscular in nature. Hand or forearm cramping: Fire Threaded, Fire Mound and Fire Mountain are found between the large tendons of the forearm. Because tendon treats tendon, these points are good for cramping of the forearm or hand. Chest spasm: The above Dao Ma combination is very useful when treating the muscles of the chest cavity. This is true for any kind of contusion, such as from a car accident involving contact with an airbag or a steering wheel, or a situation of overuse or overexertion that results in muscular spasm of the chest or thorax. Gallbladder channel sciatica: Though there are many options for treating Gallbladder channel sciatica, 33.04 Fire Threaded, 33.05 Fire Mound and 33.06 Fire Mountain can be considered due to the connection between the Hand and Foot Shao Yang and the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yin (KD). I would likely choose 22.06 Zhong Bai and 22.07 Xia Bai unless the patient also had severe cramping or spasm, in which case 33.04-33.06 would be superior.
combinations: Muscular cramping in the chest or forearm: Needle 33.04 Fire Threaded, 33.05 Fire Mound and 33.06 Fire Mountain. Severe chest oppression with difficulty breathing: Needle 33.04 Fire Threaded, 33.05 Fire Mound and 33.06 Fire Mountain.

name: Huoshan, Fire Mountain (T 33.06)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.06 Huoshan , is on the TH channel, 6.5 cun proximal to the wrist, or 1.5 cun proximal to Huoling (T 33.05) . | Johnson: Fire Mountain is located 1.5 cun (two fingers) proximal to 33.05 Fire Mound.
primary_indications: chest distension Radiating spasms or cramps of the forearm or hand
johnson_indications: Cramping, fullness or tightness of the chest with sadness or depression
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1.5 cun . Needle deeper to penetrate the PC channel for cardiovascular disorders.

name: Huofuhai, Fire Bowels Sea (T 33.07)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.07 Huofuhai , is on the TH channel close to Shousanli (LI 10) , 8.5 cun proximal to the wrist, and 2 cun proximal to Huoshan (T 33.06) on the muscular prominence of the dorsal forearm. | Johnson: Fire Bowels Sea is located 8.5 cun proximal to the wrist crease, just on top of the radius. This is the same location as LI10 Shou San Li.
primary_indications: soreness of the back and legs
johnson_indications: Waist, lower back or leg pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1.5 cun . When needling for exhaustion and anti-aging, do not needle the point for more than 10 minutes. After removing the needle, use acupressure afterward to continue stimulating the point. It is also appropriate to apply moxibustion to this point. | Johnson: Needle perpendicularly. Weakness: For the treatment of anemia, dizziness, leg pain, blurred vision, low back pain and exhaustion, retain the needle for ten minutes, then moxa using 3-5 balls. Longevity: See Comments below. Tennis elbow, lower back pain and sciatica: Contact the bone with the needle shaft. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Muscle treats muscle: Needling in muscle tonifies earth and Spleen, restoring qi. In the name of this point, “huo” – meaning “fire” – indicates tonification of earth via the mother (fire). With the Reaction Area of the Heart and Lung, and needled toward the Pericardium, this point tonifies fire. Energetic pathways: Master Tung needled Fire Bowels Sea (LI10) and LI11 Qu Chi together but even closer to the bone, with the LI11 needle just distal to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus, and the LI10 needle sliding down the edge of the radius. This approach creates a combined function for San Jiao and Large Intestine. The Yang Ming (LI) aspect, mirroring ST36, tonifies qi and blood (Yang Ming having more qi and more blood), and the San Jiao aspect strengthens the Kidney due to the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yin (KD). The latter, along with the bone-treating-bone Kidney function, contributes to the point’s effectiveness in the treatment of sciatica, back pain, weakness of the legs, anemia and exhaustion. Because of the special relationship between the Hand Yang Ming (LI) and Foot Jue Yin (LV), Fire Bowels Sea has the effect of dispersing wind (LV) and moving qi and blood (LI) to treat dizziness, blurred vision and fatigue. Because Large Intestine and Lung share an internal/external connection, this point also treats respiratory disorders. Longevity protocol: All of the above energetic relationships make Fire Bowels Sea useful in increasing longevity. To bring qi to the point, we start by needling Fire Bowels Sea superficially in four directions from the same point: needle toward one direction, pull the needle toward the surface but not completely out, then insert the needle toward the next direction, etc. Finally, leave the needle in a perpendicular position for the application of moxa. In Dr. Lee’s clinic, we often added a warm needling technique using moxa balls approximately the size of large marbles. We made these by firmly pressing moxa together with our fingers and qi, then splitting the ball, surrounding the handle of the needle with the two halves, and firmly pressing them together again, with qi. We bilaterally applied a moxa ball and burned it on the needle handle; we did this three times for a weak patient, and five times for a strong patient, every other day for three months. Every fifth, tenth and fifteenth treatment, we bilaterally burned 7-9 moxa balls. In modern clinics, moxa balls have been replaced by stick-on moxa, which cannot easily be applied to a needle. You can substitute two stick-on moxa per moxa ball and apply them directly to the point, using a small cardboard shield. Even better, heavily puncture a slice of ginger with a fork and place it over the point, then apply either moxa balls or stick-on moxa. Massage: For calf muscle injury or spasm or for loss of firm hand grip, massage this area from elbow to wrist (brachioradialis). Case history (muscle atrophy, Dr. Lee): “I once had a case of a man whose muscles in his entire body had atrophied. When he was a young man, he had made a foolish bet. He and a friend made a bet to see who could stay in the Pacific Ocean for the longest time. Before jumping in, this man drank a bottle of wheat germ oil. Wheat germ is a very nourishing substance and the oil of wheat germ is even more so. This wheat germ oil made his body warm and he was able to remain in the cold water the longest and won the bet. However, 20 years later, this man was reduced to a skeleton. He could not even feed himself or sit up for any length of time. Previously he had been very tall and athletic in build. Now he was just skin and bones. I needled 11.14 Finger Three Weights but was skeptical about its ability to treat such an advanced case. Therefore, I also applied moxa to LI10 Shou San Li, a point for longevity. This allowed him to at least regain the use of his arm so that he could feed himself. This man’s condition was due to cold injuring the Spleen” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Tennis Elbow (Large Intestine channel): Needle opposite-side 33.07 Fire Bowels Sea (LI10), LI11 Qu Chi (needle both LI10 and LI11 just above the radius, sliding the shaft of the needle along the bone); needle same-side 22.04 Great White (Da Bai) or 22.05 Spirit Bone (Ling Gu) as a Guiding Point.

name: Shouwujin, Arm Five Gold (T 33.08)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.08 Shouwujin , is between the TH and SI channels, 6.5 cun proximal to the wrist, 0.5 cun ulnar to the TH channel.| Johnson: Arm Five Gold and Arm Thousand Gold are located on the dorsum of the forearm, between the San Jiao and Small Intestine channels. To locate these points, from the Small Intestine channel, roll over the edge of the ulna and allow your fingers to fall into the groove just above the edge of the bone (0.5 cun lateral to San Jiao): 33.08 Arm Five Gold is located 6.5 cun (four fingers twice plus one small finger) proximal to the wrist crease. 33.09 Arm Thousand Gold is located 1.5 cun (two fingers) proximal to Arm Five Gold.
secondary_indications: abdominal pain Drug or food poisoning Early stage of carbuncles
johnson_indications: Lower leg or foot numbness, distension or pain
Skin problems on the arm that are difficult to heal (33.09)
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 1.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. | Johnson: Unilateral: Needle opposite side only. Patient positioning: Locate the point with the patient’s forearm across their abdomen, palm down, elbow resting on the table. Insertion: Insert the needles in the groove found on the radial side of the ulna. Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun Note: Needling deeper than 0.5 cun is less effective (Dr. Lee, 1992).
comments: Energetic pathways: Needled as a Dao Ma, 33.08-33.09 Arm Five/Arm Thousand Gold, in very close proximity to bones and tendons, treat both Kidney (bone) and Liver (tendon). The San Jiao is connected to the Gallbladder, and the Small Intestine is connected to the Urinary Bladder; thus, Arm Five Gold and Arm Thousand Gold are especially useful for sciatica found on the Urinary Bladder and Gallbladder channels. UB65 Shu Gu or GB41 Ling Qi (or both) can be added as Guiding Points. 33.08 Arm Five Gold has the Reaction Area of the Liver, while 33.09 Arm Thousand Gold has the Reaction Area of the Lung. As metal controls wood, these points treat issues related to tendons and ligaments. Sciatica due to cold: Patients who eat irregularly or consume cold food or beverages extinguish their Small Intestine fire and may experience abdominal distension or pain. Because the Hand and Foot Tai Yang (SI/UB) are connected, this can also cause Urinary Bladder channel sciatica due to cold, because the Small Intestine fire is not sufficient to nourish the Urinary Bladder. Tenacious sciatica: When customary treatments for sciatica are insufficient, I often palpate the most sensitive point in the area of DT.08 Essence Branch or DT.09 Gold Forest (SI9-SI10), and bleed and cup the point for an immediate fix. This is especially good for stubborn sciatica found on the lower Gallbladder channel. Abdominal disorders: Because there are so many good options to treat gastrointestinal disorders, these points are only chosen to treat such disorders when sciatica is also present.
combinations: Arm pain: 33.08-33.09 Arm Five/Arm Thousand Gold. Sciatica: On the opposite side, needle 33.08-33.09 Arm Five/Arm Thousand Gold, with optional UB65 Shu Gu or 66.09 Water Curve (GB41) as Guiding Points on the same side. For stubborn sciatica, bleed and cup DT.08 Essence Branch or DT.09 Gold Forest (SI9-SI10). Skin problems on the arms: 33.09 Arm Thousand Gold may be selected on its own to treat early stage skin infections on the arms (Dr. Young, 2008).
meridian: Between San Jiao and Small Intestine

name: Shouqianjin, Arm Thousand Gold (T 33.09)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.09 Shouqianjin , is between the TH and SI channels, 8 cun proximal to the wrist, 0.5 cun ulnar to the TH channel. | Johnson: Arm Five Gold and Arm Thousand Gold are located on the dorsum of the forearm, between the San Jiao and Small Intestine channels. To locate these points, from the Small Intestine channel, roll over the edge of the ulna and allow your fingers to fall into the groove just above the edge of the bone (0.5 cun lateral to San Jiao): 33.08 Arm Five Gold is located 6.5 cun (four fingers twice plus one small finger) proximal to the wrist crease. 33.09 Arm Thousand Gold is located 1.5 cun (two fingers) proximal to Arm Five Gold.

johnson_indications: Lower leg or foot numbness, distension or pain
Skin problems on the arm that are difficult to heal (33.09)

Patient positioning: Locate the point with the patient’s forearm across their abdomen, palm down, elbow resting on the table. The San Jiao is connected to the Gallbladder, and the Small Intestine is connected to the Urinary Bladder; thus, Arm Five Gold and Arm Thousand Gold are especially useful for sciatica found on the Urinary Bladder and Gallbladder channels. UB65 Shu Gu or GB41 Ling Qi (or both) can be added as Guiding Points. 33.08 Arm Five Gold has the Reaction Area of the Liver, while 33.09 Arm Thousand Gold has the Reaction Area of the Lung. As metal controls wood, these points treat issues related to tendons and ligaments. Sciatica due to cold: Patients who eat irregularly or consume cold food or beverages extinguish their Small Intestine fire and may experience abdominal distension or pain. Because the Hand and Foot Tai Yang (SI/UB) are connected, this can also cause Urinary Bladder channel sciatica due to cold, because the Small Intestine fire is not sufficient to nourish the Urinary Bladder. Tenacious sciatica: When customary treatments for sciatica are insufficient, I often palpate the most sensitive point in the area of DT.08 Essence Branch or DT.09 Gold Forest (SI9-SI10), and bleed and cup the point for an immediate fix. This is especially good for stubborn sciatica found on the lower Gallbladder channel. Abdominal disorders: Because there are so many good options to treat gastrointestinal disorders, these points are only chosen to treat such disorders when sciatica is also present.

Sciatica: On the opposite side, needle 33.08-33.09 Arm Five/Arm Thousand Gold, with optional UB65 Shu Gu or 66.09 Water Curve (GB41) as Guiding Points on the same side. For stubborn sciatica, bleed and cup DT.08 Essence Branch or DT.09 Gold Forest (SI9-SI10). Skin problems on the arms: 33.09 Arm Thousand Gold may be selected on its own to treat early stage skin infections on the arms (Dr. Young, 2008).
meridian: Between San Jiao and Small Intestine

name: Changmen, Intestine Gate (T 33.10)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.10 Changmen , is on the SI channel, 3 cun proximal to the dorsal crease of the wrist. | Johnson: Intestine Gate is located 3.0 cun (four fingers) above the wrist crease, just inferior to the ulna (on the Small Intestine meridian).
primary_indications: All digestive and intestinal disorders Stomach ulcer
disorders of the anus and/or rectum
johnson_indications: Inflammation of the rectum due to hepatitis
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 1 cun . | Johnson: Needle unilaterally: This point can be needled or acupressure can be applied. (See Comments.) Dao Ma: Needle on the left side when combining with 33.11 Liver Gate. Depth: 0.5-0.8 cun.
comments: Imaging: Each part of the body can be divided into three areas that correspond to the three burners of the San Jiao (upper, middle and lower). On the forearm, the area closest to the wrist reflects the upper jiao. Intestine Gate and 33.11 Liver Gate are located on the middle of the forearm, reflecting the middle jiao, as are Er Bei (Extra Point) and 33.04 Fire Threaded (SJ6), which are also used for gastroenteritis. Energetic pathways: Intestine Gate is located on the Small Intestine meridian, which is in charge of water metabolism and drains damp heat; therefore, this point is very effective for the treatment of diarrhea, hepatitis, and acute intestinal diseases. Due to the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yang (SI) and Foot Tai Yin (SP) channels, the Small Intestine is linked to the earth element, immune function, and dampness in the body. Acute colitis and acupressure: I teach my patients who have IBS and Crohn’s disease how to find Intestine Gate, as it can be life changing for people who are anxious about leaving their house and losing bowel control in public. Many of these patients will not board an airplane or even go shopping; they are obsessed and fearful to the point of having panic attacks. They are thrilled to discover that by holding this point firmly, they are able to control their bowels until they can locate a toilet. Dao Ma: Intestine Gate is frequently needled with 33.11 Liver Gate for treating issues such as hepatitis, because patients who have hepatitis often have intestinal issues as well; this is related to wood overly controlling earth. The two points do not have to be needled together unless the patient presents with both liver and intestinal issues. When combining them, I needle both points on the left side, opposite the liver.
combinations: Diarrhea: 33.10 Intestine Gate, 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43). Hepatitis with intestinal issues: 33.10 Intestine Gate, 33.11 Liver Gate.

name: Ganmen, Liver Gate (T 33.11)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.11 Ganmen , is on the SI channel, 6 cun proximal to the wrist crease. | Johnson: Liver Gate is located 6 cun (four fingers twice) proximal to the wrist crease, just inferior to the ulna (on the Small Intestine meridian).
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needling this point will immediately relieve the bitter taste in the mouth and pain in the hepatic/hypochondriac area. Turning the needle to the right will relieve chest pain associated with hepatitis, while turning needle to the left will relieve intestinal/abdominal pain. Needle the left side when treating acute hepatitis. | Johnson: Needle unilaterally on the left side (opposite the liver) to treat liver diseases. Needle stimulation: When the needle is rotated clockwise, chest stuffiness is relieved; when the needle is rotated counterclockwise, intestinal pain is relieved (Dr. Young, 2008). Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Liver Gate is found on the Small Intestine channel, which shares a special relationship with the Spleen meridian (Hand Tai Yang with Foot Tai Yin), making this point especially good for draining damp heat. The Small Intestine channel is classically used for clearing damp heat conditions, and the Spleen channel removes dampness, making Liver Gate effective in the treatment of hepatitis and all other liver diseases. When wood attacks earth, diarrhea is often the result. When it is combined with 33.10 Intestine Gate, Liver Gate can be used for any kind of gastroenteritis with a Liver origin. Calf cramping: Liver Gate treats lower leg cramping because the Liver relates to tendons, and all Liver points are useful for treating tendons and spasms. The point is found in the area of the forearm that mirrors the gastrocnemius and also relates to the bowels.
combinations: Acute or chronic hepatitis: Unilaterally needle on the left side: 11.20 Wood Inflammation, 33.11 Liver Gate; bilaterally needle 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows. With intestinal inflammation, add 33.10 Intestine Gate. If chronic, add 77.17 Heaven Emperor or 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan). Additional points to consider: ST36, SP9, UB18 and LV3 are classically used to treat hepatitis. Cirrhosis: See 11.20 Wood Inflammation, Combinations. Constipation: 33.11 Liver Gate, SJ6 Zhi Gou. Jaundice: 33.11 Liver Gate, SI4 Wan Gu.

name: Xinmen, Heart Gate (T 33.12)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.12 Xinmen , is on the SI channel, 1.5 cun distal to the olecranon. | Johnson: I locate Heart Gate on the Small Intestine meridian, 2.0 cun (three fingers) distal to the tip of the ulna (just beyond the flaring of the ulna). Note: Most resources find this point closer to the tip of the ulna (1.5 cun distal to the tip); however, a needle immediately hits bone upon insertion in this location.
johnson_indications: Acute gastroenteritis with vomiting and diarrhea
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun towards the wrist. Needle contralateral to the affected side. | Johnson: Location: I have found Heart Gate to be more effective when it is needled 2.0 cun distal to the tip of the elbow, just beyond the flaring of the ulna. This location allows for deeper needling. Unilateral vs. bilateral: This point is needled unilaterally for conditions on the opposite side. It can be needled bilaterally to treat rheumatoid arthritis or coccyx pain. Needling technique: Start by inserting the needle perpendicularly until the bone is gently touched. Then, slightly withdraw the needle to a superficial level and reinsert, angling away from the bone. Repeat this process until you are able to identify the edge of the ulna. Insert the needle to a depth of 0.5-1.0 cun, sliding the shaft of the needle against the ulna for a bone-treating-bone, Kidney tonification effect. When tapping the bone, be sure to do it gently so as not to damage the periosteum. Using this approach, you can easily find the most powerful and effective location. Use strong stimulation on this point until the patient reports a change in their symptoms, especially when treating groin, elbow or coccyx pain. Rheumatoid arthritis may require further treatment before the patient notices improvement. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Heart Gate has the Reaction Area of the Heart and is located near SI8 Xiao Hai, the earth and He-Sea point of the Small Intestine meridian. The Heart and Small Intestine share an internal/external relationship. For all of these reasons, Heart Gate treats any disease related to the heart. In Tung’s system, any point with ”Heart” or “Fire” in its name treats both heart and knees. Additionally, imaging systems reveal a correspondence between the elbow and knee. Because of the connection between the Hand and Foot Tai Yang (SI/UB), Heart Gate also is used to treat symptoms related to sciatica and the low back, sacrum, and coccyx. Coronary heart disease: While Heart Gate is useful in the treatment of chronic heart disease, I rarely choose to use it without 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points or 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle, as these points are more powerful. Myocarditis: This problem is typically seen in younger people whose heart muscle was injured by a cold or flu. They may not realize that this has happened, but as a practitioner you may recognize this condition by its extreme shortness of breath and fatigue, uncommon in youth. The treatment of choice is to needle 33.12 Heart Gate or PC6 Nei Guan with 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36); further treatment information can be found in Combinations below. Groin pain: Heart Gate falls into the category of my favorite points due to its extraordinary effectiveness in the treatment of groin pain. We do not have many points to treat the vicinity of ST31; however, Heart Gate on the opposite side is all that is needed. Inflammation of the hip joint, or deterioration of the ball of the femur, is experienced in the groin. Groin pain may necessitate an X-ray to determine the extent of arthritic degeneration. Many patients and even practitioners use the phrase “hip pain” in reference to pain of the greater trochanter of the femur; however, they are referring to the Gallbladder channel. True hip joint pain, on the other hand, has a medial presentation in the groin. Groin pain with sciatica: If a patient is experiencing groin pain and sciatica, position them on their side, bending their top leg in order to thoroughly cup the affected side. Be sure to cup both GB29 and GB30 specifically. I also recommend cupping UB36 while the patient is lying on their side, as the skin color after cupping here is often extremely dark (indicating toxin buildup) whether or not the patient has UB channel sciatica. I often refer to UB36 as “sciatica looking for a place to happen.” When groin pain occurs simultaneously with sciatica, Heart Gate can be used in conjunction with SI3 Hou Xi, 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, and/or 22.06- 22.07 Zhong Bai/Xia Bai. Guiding Points are optional. Knee pain: Common or acute knee pain usually improves quickly, especially for athletes who have been overusing their knees. Medial knee pain is caused by injury to the meniscus, degenerative joint disease, and/or bone spurring. Degenerative knee pain is present when the patient climbs and descends stairs; for this type of pain, I bilaterally needle 11.09 Heart Knee. If the knee pain is due to bone spurring, the pain is worse when the patient walks downhill or descends stairs; in this case, I use 33.12 Heart Gate on the opposite side, with 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master as Guiding Points to pull the qi directly into the knee. This combination is especially useful because the Liver controls tendons, and the knee joint is completely wrapped in tendons. 66.03 has a fire nature, whereas 66.04 has an earth nature; needling close to the bone will tonify the Kidney (water) on a wood channel, therefore treating wind, cold and damp by building fire and nourishing earth. It is my experience that bone spurs do not easily dissolve. However, soft tissue inflammation around the spur is usually responsible for most of the pain. Often bone spur pain is worse in heavier patients; treatments that release toxins can help to promote weight loss and resolve knee pain. 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle can be needled on the opposite side or bled on the same side (if a good vein is found). For pain underneath the kneecap (inside the joint), my favorite treatment is to bleed DT.07 Three Gold (same side or both sides). Often I suggest emulsified turmeric or boswellia compound as good anti-inflammatory agents to deal with knee pain from bone spurring. If both knees are equally painful, bilaterally needle 33.12 Heart Gate and LV2 or LV3 with strong stimulation. Case histories (inner knee pain, Dr. Lee): •  “Heart Gate can also treat inner leg pain and sacral area nerve pain. I use this point a lot with older patients. Most older patients have some heart problems. For some time I had failed to treat inner knee pain successfully. I searched and searched for an effective treatment protocol. One day a woman came to me suffering from dry heaves. I needled this point and not only did her dry heaves stop, but so did her inner knee pain. Since then I use this point to treat inner knee pain by needling the opposite side” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  “Another time, I went to Canada to treat an 88-year-old lady with sore legs and knees. She was quite obese and could not walk without a cane or a walker. I palpated her entire knee and found the most tender spot to be the inner knee. I needled Heart Gate, one time. The patient fell asleep and slept soundly for two hours. After that, all her leg pain and soreness disappeared, not only her inner knee pain. Since then I have never forgotten that inner knee pain is caused by the Heart” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Tailbone pain: I have frequently seen that two scenarios cause broken tailbones: elderly patients falling backwards onto cement, and women’s coccyx breaking during labor and delivery. Heart Gate is very effective when combined with 55.04-55.05 Flower Bone Three/Flower Bone Four to treat severe pain or fracture of the coccyx. For coccyx pain from a typical slip and fall, bilateral Heart Gate should be adequate. If the sacral pain has to do with prolapse (urinary bladder, uterine, hemorrhoid, etc.), needle DU19 and DU21 combined, through DU20, or directly moxa DU20. Over  time, I have discovered a few additional toxin areas (similar to DT.01-DT.02), one of which is located at the very base of the coccyx. Though this area is difficult to access, I am certain to apply a small cup to it when the patient is experiencing coccyx pain, especially from an old impact or fracture. (Never cup it within six months of a break.) Surprisingly, on most patients the skin in this area turns black when cupped. •  Rheumatoid arthritis: In treating rheumatoid arthritis, I have had extraordinary results using bilateral 33.12 Heart Gate, 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points, and 11.27 Five Tigers. I have also used direct moxa on joint nodules with good results; however, I caution practitioners to experiment on one joint first, to determine whether a particular patient responds positively to this kind of direct heat. Some patients may have inflammatory or heat-type rheumatoid arthritis that might be exacerbated by direct moxa. I have found cupping of DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas to be helpful, as well.
combinations: Elbow pain (medial, “golfer’s elbow”): Needle opposite-side 33.12 Heart Gate with same side SI3 Hou Xi as a Guiding Point (optional). •  Knee pain (bone spur): Needle opposite-side 33.12 Heart Gate, 77.09 Four Flower Middle, 77.11 Four Flower Lower. As a Guiding Point, needle 66.03 Fire Hardness and/or 66.04 Fire Master. See 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One for additional information, including nutritional advice, related to the treatment of bone spurs.•  Myocarditis (heart muscle infection after flu or cold): 33.12 Heart Gate or PC6 Nei Guan with 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36); 66.03 Fire Hardness, 66.04 Fire Master; bleed 99.08 Ear Apex and/or the 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line.•  Rheumatoid arthritis: Bilaterally needle: 11.27 Five Tigers, 33.12 Heart Gate, 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points. Use direct moxa as needed (see Comments above). •  Swelling below the heart: 33.12 Heart Gate; 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points; PC6 Nei Guan with ST36 Zu San Li (Old Doctors’ Two Old Needles – a historically famous point combination). •  Palpitations (fast pulse): 11.19 Heart Normal; A.04 San Cha Three; 33.12 Heart Gate; 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points; bleed 99.08 Ear Apex.

name: Renshi, Man Scholar (T 33.13)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.13 Renshi , is 4 cun proximal to the wrist crease on the LU or PC channel. | Johnson: Man Scholar, Earth Scholar and Heavenly Scholar are typically needled together as a Dao Ma known as Three Scholars. Master Tung intentionally places Man, Earth, and Heaven in this order: 33.13 Man Scholar is located 4 cun (three fingers twice) proximal to the wrist crease along the Lung channel (just lateral to the flexor carpi radialis tendon). 33.15 Heavenly Scholar is located 3.0 cun (four fingers) distal to 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), along the Lung channel. 33.14 Earth Scholar is located midway between the other two points, near LU6 Kong Zui.
secondary_indications: Pain in the palm or fingers
johnson_indications: Pain of the palm reaching toward the fingers
techniques: Needle 0.5 cun for LU disorders, 1 cun for HT and KI disorders. Needle the side opposite to the affected area. Since this point is on or in between the PC or LU channel, select the PC channel when treating cardiovascular problems and use the LU channel when treating respiratory disorders. | Johnson: Patient positioning and needling instruction: It took me more than twenty years to figure out the best way to position the patient for these needles. The patient is uncomfortable when the points are needled with the arms open alongside the body (palms up) for a prolonged period of time. For the comfort of the patient, needle this three-point unit with the patient lying on their back, arms alongside the body, palms down, with each wrist supported by a small, rolled-up hand towel. Position the arms with the elbows bent and relaxed. Rotate their wrist so the thumb points to the ceiling, being careful that the patient does not tuck in their elbow, as is the common tendency. With the wrist in this position, needle 33.13 Man Scholar lateral to the tendon (on the Lung channel), then rotate the wrist back to the palm-down position. The second point, 33.15 Heavenly Scholar, is most easily located by tracking the tendon from 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), 2.0 cun (three fingers) distal to LU5; once you have found the point, insert your needle next to the tendon, in the large muscle. 33.14 Earth Scholar is found midway on the diagonal line between 33.13 and 33.15. Though the patient’s position requires the practitioner to be flexible, it enables the patient to comfortably retain the needles for up to an hour. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun: Asthma, palm, finger, shoulder, arm and back: 0.5 cun Heart disease and palpitation: 1.0 cun
comments: Asthma: I rarely needle Three Scholars, as there are other treatments that work as well or better for chronic asthma and that are easier to access. However, I have patients who request these points because they are extremely effective and require only a few treatments. Three Scholars may be combined with 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, as these points also tonify Lung and Kidney. Combine with 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, especially when the asthma is allergic or severe. Man Scholar: 33.13 may be needled on its own to treat pain in the fingers, arms, shoulders and upper back. Calf spasm: Because the forearm and calf mirror each other, these points can treat calf spasm on the opposite side.
combinations: Asthma: 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars, 22.05 Ling Gu (Dr. Young, 2008). Asthma (acute): 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars. Asthma (severe): Cup Ding Chuan (Extra Point); bleed 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5); bilaterally needle 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars, 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 1010.19- 1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through. Asthma (yang deficient): 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars, ST36 Zu San Li, SP6 San Yin Jiao. Asthma (yang excess): 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars; deep needle or bleed 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) and/or 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36). Cough (chronic): 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars, 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through. Cough (with upper back and/or chest pain): 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars, 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy.

name: Dishi, Earth Scholar (T 33.14)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.14 Dishi , is 7 cun proximal to the wrist crease on the LU or PC channel, 3 cun proximal to Renshi (T 33.13) . On the LU channel, it overlaps Kongzui (LU 6) . | Johnson: See 33.13 Man Scholar for point location.
secondary_indications: lack of flexibility of the hand Heart disease
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 - 1.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected area. Use shallow insertion for respiratory issues and deep insertion for cardiac disorders. Since this point is on or in between the PC and LU channel, select the PC channel to treat cardiovascular problems and use the LU channel to treat respiratory disorders. | Johnson: See 33.13 Man Scholar for additional needling notes. Depth: 1.0-1.5 cun: Asthma, common cold, headache and Kidney deficiency: 1.0 cun Heart disease or palpitation: 1.5 cun
comments: Tung’s LU6: Earth Scholar overlaps the classical point LU6 Kong Zui, which is primarily used to clear heat and remove obstruction. As the Lung Xi-Cleft point, it disperses and descends Lung qi, clears heat and removes toxins, moistens the lungs, stops bleeding, and relieves sore throat. Combined in Three Scholars, it is primarily used to treat asthma, especially when also combined with 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) or LU10 Yu Ji. In her clinic, Dr. Lee used this Dao Ma frequently; however, I tend to reserve it for severe cases or use it upon request, as there are many other options for treating asthma. See 33.13 Man Scholar for comments and combinations.

name: Tianshi, Heavenly Scholar (T 33.15)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.15 Tianshi , is 10 cun proximal to the wrist crease on the LU or PC channel, 3 cun proximal to Dishi (T 33.14) . | Johnson: See 33.13 Man Scholar for point location.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 - 1.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected area. If the condition is in the center, needle bilaterally. Use shallow insertion for respiratory issues or conditions that are recent in onset. Use deep insertion for cardiac disorders or chronic, long-term conditions. Since this point is on or in between the PC or LU channel, select the PC channel when treating cardiovascular problems and use the LU channel when treating respiratory disorders. | Johnson: See 33.13 Man Scholar for additional needling notes. Depth: 1.5 cun
comments: See 33.13 Man Scholar for comments and combinations.

name: Quling, Curve Mound (T 33.16)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.16 Quling , overlaps with Chize (LU 5) , which is 0.5 cun radial to the biceps brachii tendon in the cubital fossa. | Johnson: Curve Mound is located on the anterior elbow crease, lateral to the biceps tendon. This is the same location as LU5 Chi Ze. Inner Courtyard is found on the anterior surface of the forearm, 3.0 cun (four fingers) proximal to the wrist crease, between the tendons. Note: This is the ancient location of this point. The TCM textbook location is usually 2.0 cun (three fingers) above the wrist crease.
primary_indications: cough and any excess condition of the Lung Elbow joint pain
including vomiting and diarrhea Muscle spasm
secondary_indications: laryngitis Acute mastitis Thyroid nodule or swelling Intestinal cholera
johnson_indications: Arthritis or inflammation of the elbow
Summer heat stroke with sudden vomiting or dry heaves and diarrhea
Urination: excessive, scanty or difficult Cracked and bleeding palms and feet
Dizziness or vertigo (with nausea and vomiting)
Spasm and pain of the upper extremities
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Use a three-edged needle to bleed the dark veins close to this point. Bleeding dark veins in the cubital fossa can treat the following conditions: asthma, digestive disorders, heart disease, shoulder and upper extremity pain, common cold and sore throat. | Johnson: This point is commonly bled for many indications, using any good vein that is small to medium sized on the anterior elbow crease. Avoid the artery. If you cannot locate a good vessel, needle the point, contacting the biceps tendon with the shaft of the needle. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun Positioning and needling: Support the wrist with a rolled-up hand towel so the patient can rest their arm with the palm downward, creating an arch where the needle will be. For easiest insertion, pull the elbow slightly outward, then rotate the wrist 90 degrees toward the ceiling. Have the patient keep their elbow in this position while you insert the needle between the two large tendons (palmaris longus and flexor carpi radialis). Then rotate their wrist back to the palm-down position. Needle sensation: If the patient feels an electrical nerve sensation travelling to the hand, you do not need to further stimulate the needle. Gently turn the hand over to rest the arm with the needle in place. Note: It is common for patients to feel an electrical sensation during insertion and removal of the needle for certain points, such as PC6, SP6 and KD7. While the needle is retained, the sensation typically goes away, but if it does not, you can adjust or relocate the needle to stop the sensation. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Lung and Kidney: Because He-Sea points treat the reversal of qi, Curve Mound smooths the qi, helping to hold it up or raise it in cases of diarrhea, prolapse and incontinence, and helping to descend the qi for chest and lung conditions such as cough and asthma. This effect is due to the fact that it is a water point on a metal channel, and therefore has a powerful effect on both Lung and Kidney. If Lung energy is not descending, there is fast panting. If the Kidneys are not able to receive, breathing is long and labored. A forceful cough indicates an exterior wind attack, whereas the deep cough of chronic bronchitis indicates Kidney deficiency. When treating cough or asthma, bleed or sedate LU5. Lung and Liver: Curve Mound is an excellent point to sedate when metal is over- controlling wood, as with stroke and/or paralysis. Because it is located directly adjacent to the biceps tendon, and because tendon treats tendon, Curve Mound is frequently needled for cramping or spasms anywhere in the body, frozen shoulder, carpal tunnel or post-stroke syndromes. For any of these indications, we can needle the opposite side or bleed the same side. Alternatively, tonify Curve Mound to indirectly treat the Liver in deficiency cases when wood is excess, with indications such as irritability, depression, PMS, headaches, insomnia, etc. Another good option might be to moxa the areas of DT.07 Three Gold or UB13 Fei Shu to strengthen metal in order to control wood. Bleeding treatments: In 1987, Dr. Lee and I travelled to the Anhui Province in central China to study bleeding techniques with Dr. Xiu-Zhen Wang, a third generation doctor of bloodletting. Though Dr. Wang chose to bleed points that were specific to each case, her comprehensive bleeding treatment for clearing stagnation and increasing circulation included the bleeding of Tai Yang (Extra Point) to clear the head, LU5 to clear the upper body and UB40 Wei Zhong to clear the lower body. Because UB40 has more blood, it may also be used to clear the spine and the entire body. There is much more to say about this ancient healing art, as it is only with bleeding techniques that I have seen the truly miraculous occur. We must protect and advance this technique and work with our licensing boards to preserve it. Bleeding LU5: Curve Mound is the He-Sea and water point of the Lung meridian. It is a primary point to bleed in difficult cases and to clear stagnation in the upper body. In my clinic, I commonly bleed LU5 for: heart blockage, chest congestion (heart or lung), asthma, frozen shoulder, carpal tunnel, common cold with sore throat, red eyes, heat stroke, and problems of the head and/or face. LU5 is an excellent point to bleed for any kind of excess condition of the lungs, partly because as the water point, it puts out fire to resolve sore throat, tonsillitis, pneumonia and laryngitis. Horary: Dr. Young teaches that the most effective time to bleed LU5 is between 3:00–5:00 p.m. This is because of the Tai Yin/Tai Yang (LU/UB) relationship, and because this is the height of the Urinary Bladder time of day (horary). 155 Forearm Points Case history (red sclera): I once had an unexpected result in a LU5 bleeding demonstration. The student who volunteered to be treated had arrived that morning with completely bloodshot eyes. I did not ask the reason for this condition; however, we were all amazed to see the color of his sclera return to bright white in a matter of moments, while the blood was still gently flowing. Case history (feverish and irritable, Dr. Lee): Dr. Lee described bleeding LU5 for an angry woman who had a common cold and fever; not only did the fever break immediately, but the anger did too (Dr. Lee, 1992). Case history (cracked and bleeding palms and soles, Dr. Young): Dr. Young described a case in which he bled Curve Mound (LU5) and UB40 Wei Zhong for a patient with cracked and bleeding palms and soles; the patient’s skin began healing the next week. Why I include this point: Although it is not found in Master Tung’s acupuncture system, PC6 Inner Courtyard is included in this body of work because it is very powerful and I often combine it with Tung’s points. My location of this point, 3.0 cun (four fingers) above the wrist crease, is an ancient one, not a textbook TCM location. I have always found this location of Nei Guan to be incredibly effective. Part of the power of this point is due to its connection with the vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve), which has parasympathetic control of the heart, lungs and digestive tract. Because of this connection, Inner Courtyard opens the chest, regulates Heart qi, calms the spirit, harmonizes the stomach, relieves nausea and vomiting and regulates qi. All of the above illustrate the connection between the Pericardium and Stomach pathways. Energetic pathways: PC6 utilizes the special relationship between the Hand Jue Yin (PC) and Foot Yang Ming (ST) as well as the Hand and Foot Jue Yin (PC/ LV) connection. When combined with SP4 Gong Sun, PC6 Nei Guan becomes the Coupling Point of the Chong Mai, which is utilizing the deeper Kidney points located on the chest and abdomen. Knee pain and heart disease: The Stomach and Liver channels are the main pathways through the knee. The Jue Yin connection to the Liver, in addition to the location of PC6 between two tendons (because tendon treats tendon) makes Nei Guan terrific for knee pain, especially when combined with LV3 as a Guiding Point on the same side. Many blood vessels, tendons and ligaments transit the knee, so Nei Guan also treats knee pain because blood vessels treat blood vessels. The Heart is responsible for blood vessels and circulation, while the Pericardium (heart protector) imprints emotions on the blood, making PC6 very useful in the treatment of chest congestion, palpitations, anxiety and heart disease. In Tung’s system, any point used to treat the heart is also effective for knee pain. Chest and abdominal congestion: Accessing the deeper Kidney points of the Chong Mai through stimulation of 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) with Inner Courtyard is my all-time favorite treatment for cock’s crow diarrhea, Crohn’s disease, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), and abdominal or chest pain. On occasion, I add 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43) to the treatment, immediately relieving gas and bloating on the opposite side. For gastroenteritis, including IBS and Crohn’s disease, needle SP4 first and then PC6. If you are using the combination for palpitations, anxiety and chest pain, needle PC6 first. Case history (Crohn’s disease using 66.05, SP4, PC6): I have used the above combination in several instances to treat severe abdominal pain due to Crohn’s disease, but one case was especially memorable. The patient had post-surgical adhesions and scar tissue from the removal of a segment of intestines, had been taking steroids for six years, and was experiencing intense abdominal pain and diarrhea. After six months of treatment using the combination of ST43, SP4 and PC6, she tapered off steroids completely. Her dietary restrictions – avoiding inflammatory foods such as wheat, dairy, sugar, raw food, alcohol, spicy foods, caffeine, etc. – were initially severe and are now more relaxed. She was treated for approximately two years, and now, five years after her first visit, she still avoids inflammatory foods and drinks but enjoys them on special occasions with few, if any, intestinal repercussions. Old Doctors’ Two Old Needles: This is a classic combination of PC6 and ST36, used for coronary heart disease and heart failure, due to the special relationship between Hand Jue Yin (PC) and Foot Yang Ming (ST) and the impact it has on the vagus nerve. For tight chest due to anxiety, PC6 with ST36 immediately relieves tension and opens the chest. In Tung’s system, we use 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle (Tung’s ST36) with very deep needle insertion (50-60mm) to relieve acute or chronic angina or severe excess frontal headache. Case history (Crohn’s disease using ST36): These points were also very effective for a case of Crohn’s disease in a patient who had postsurgical abdominal pain and diarrhea, and also presented with glaucoma. Because 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle are used for pressure behind the eyes as well as gastroenteritis, this combination of points effectively resolved both issues. 55.02 Flower Bone One, my favorite point combination for treating any eye disease, was also used regularly.
combinations: I commonly bleed LU5 for the following disorders: heart blockage, chest congestion (heart or lung), asthma, frozen shoulder, carpal tunnel, common cold with sore throat, tonsillitis, pneumonia and laryngitis, red eyes, and heat stroke. Asthma (allergic): 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20). Asthma (severe): Bleed the following: 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), 77.09 Four Flower Middle, 77.14 Four Flower Outer, DU14 Da Zhui, UB13 Fei Shu, UB42 Po Hu and UB43 Gao Huang Shu. Asthma (severe): Cup Ding Chuan (Extra Point); bleed 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5); bilaterally needle 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars, 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 1010.19- 1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through. Asthma (with cold thighs): Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment (bilaterally needle ST36, SP6, LI11, LI4, LU7 in this order, tonifying the bottom and sedating the top); moxa SP10 Xue Hai. Asthma (with green chin): 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through. Asthma (with red chin): Deeply needle or bleed 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36). Coughing: 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through. Emphysema or pneumonia: 22.11 Earth Water, 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, bleed 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) and 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line. Frequent urination: 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan). PC6 Inner Courtyard - Nei Guan TCM Point (ancient location) Abdominal pain with stomachache, indigestion, IBS or Crohn’s disease: First, sedate opposite side 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), one side at a time if both sides of the abdomen are painful. Then add 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4), PC6 Nei Guan. Chest heaviness, oppression and anxiety: Needle PC6 Nei Guan first, then add 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4). Coronary heart disease, heart failure, angina (acute or chronic), or tight chest due to anxiety: Needle Old Doctors’ Two Old Needles: PC6 Nei Guan first, then deep needle (50-60mm) 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36). Coma: Needle DU26 Ren Zhong (alternatively, use DU19, DU20, DU21 needled toward DU20 Bai Hu), PC6 Nei Guan and 66.04 Fire Master (Tung’s LV3) needled toward KD1 Yong Quan. Knee pain: Needle PC6 Nei Guan with 44.06 Shoulder Triangle; needle opposite-side PC6 Nei Guan with same-side LV3 Tai Chong as a Guiding Point. 159 Forearm Points Meniere’s disease: Internal wind may be stirred up when too many needles are used, so it is important to use fewer needles when treating a wind disease. Needle unilaterally: PC6 Nei Guan with LI11 Qu Chi or PC6 Nei Guan with 22.05 Ling Gu; bilaterally needle 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows, combined with unilateral PC6 Nei Guan for nausea and unilateral LI11 Qu Chi for vertigo and dizziness. Motion sickness: Tape a large slice of fresh ginger to PC6 Nei Guan, and eat dried mango (Dr. Young, 2008). Myocarditis: Bilaterally needle: 33.12 Heart Gate, PC6 Nei Guan, 77.08 Four Flower Middle (Tung’s ST36), 66.03-66.04 Fire Hardness/Fire Master. Bleed 99.08 Ear Apex and 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line. Paralytic colon (post-anesthesia): Bleed 1010.07 All Pivot (DU15-DU16), needle 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) first, then PC6 Nei Guan. Stomach ulcer (excess or deficient): 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4), PC6 Nei Guan, deeply needle REN12 Zhong Wan.

name: Xinling * (T 33.17)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.17* Xinling , is a three-point set on the PC channel, 1.5 cun , 2.5 cun , and 3.5 cun proximal to the wrist crease.
secondary_indications: numbness of the hands and feet Acupuncture anesthesia point for neck surgeries
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun . In severe cases, the needle can be inserted deeply to penetrate through the skin of the TH channel. Needle obliquely at 45 degrees towards the heart, 0.5 - 1 cun , when treating cardiovascular disorders. Needle obliquely at 30 degrees towards the heart, 0.5 - 1 cun , when treating the chest and head. Needle towards the palm to treat hand and foot disorders.

name: Ganlingsanxue (T 33.18)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.18* Ganlingsanxue , is a three-point set on the HT channel, 3 cun , 6 cun , and 9 cun proximal to the wrist crease.
secondary_indications: inflammation of the spinal cord membrane Sciatic pain
pain of the tendons and bones
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1.5 cun or obliquely up to 2 cun .

name: Houjian * (T 33.19)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.19* Houjian , is in between the LI and TH channels, 2 cun distal and 1 cun ulnar to Quchi (LI 11) , which is on the lateral end of the transverse cubital crease.
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Fugesan * (T 33.20)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.20* Fugesan , is a three-point set on the LI channel. The first point is 0.8 cun distal to Quchi (LI 11) , which is on the lateral end of the transverse cubital crease. The other two points are 0.8 cun medial and 0.8 cun lateral to the first point.
primary_indications: Pain and soreness in the bones and tendons of the entire back
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Fenjin, Dividing Gold (T 44.01)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.01 Fenjin , is on the LU channel, 1.5 cun proximal to Chize (LU 5) on the anterior aspect of the upper arm. | Johnson: Dividing Gold is located on the biceps muscle of the upper arm, 1.5 cun (two fingers) proximal to 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), in the hollow between the two heads of the biceps tendon.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 0.5-0.8 cun
comments: Common cold: Because it is located on the Lung meridian, Dividing Gold is effective in the treatment of severe colds with nasal congestion, sinus inflammation and laryngitis; however, there are many other points I would choose over this one, such as33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) or A.04 San Cha Three. Dao Ma: Dividing Gold may be combined with 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), though I am far more likely to use the latter in other combinations.

name: Houzhui, Back Vertebrae (T 44.02)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.02 Houzhui , is on the TH channel, 2.5 cun proximal to the olecranon along the posterior edge of the humerus. | Johnson: 44.02 Back Vertebrae is located on the back of the arm, 2.5 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, on the San Jiao channel, 0.5 cun superior to SJ11 Qing Leng Yuan. 44.03 Head Wisdom is located on the San Jiao channel on the back of the arm, 4.5 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, 0.5 cun inferior to SJ12 Xiao Luo.
primary_indications: Subluxation or dislocation of the spine
johnson_indications: Dislocated or herniated disc of the thoracic vertebrae*
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun along the side of the bone or touching the bone. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 44.02 Back Vertebrae may be combined with 44.03 Head Wisdom in the treatment of spine diseases, especially lumbar. Positioning and needling: For needling these points, it is best if the patient lies face down, with their head in a face cradle and their arms over the sides of the table. However, the patient’s head should not be in a face-down position if there are spinal issues. Alternatively, if the patient is lying on their back, a small hand towel may be placed under each elbow, so the practitioner can access the San Jiao channel on the dorsum of the upper arm. This positioning enables one to treat the thoracic vertebrae with 44.02 and 44.03 while needling additional leg points, such as 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors to tonify the Kidneys, if desired. Retention: Retain the needles for one hour or more. Depth: 0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: The San Jiao meridian connects to all three burners and to the Kidneys through the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yin (KD); this explains the indication of nephritis. Needling Back Vertebrae close to the bone activates the bone-treating-bone system, enhancing its Kidney tonification effect. Back Vertebrae is especially effective in the treatment of the spine and bones, not only because the Kidney governs bones, but also because of the Hand and Foot Shao Yang (SJ/GB) connection (Gallbladder controlling bone). Through the relationship of San Jiao to Gallbladder, we also stimulate the internal/external Gallbladder/Liver relationship. Spine pain: Depending upon which area of the spine is being treated, there are multiple alternatives to using Back Vertebrae, including: 22.04-22.05 Great White/ Spirit Bone (Ling Gu/Da Bai) for lumbar spine, 88.17-88.19 Four Horses for thoracic spine, 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons for cervical spine, or bleeding UB40 Wei Zhong to treat the entire spine. Cupping is an excellent treatment for back spasms surrounding troubled discs; however, never cup directly over a herniated or protruding disc. One can determine whether a disc is damaged by gently palpating between the posterior vertebral spinous processes. If there is no pain, press slightly harder; if there is still no pain, it is unlikely that the disc is herniated. Case history (spinal degeneration): A 92-year-old woman with extreme spinal degeneration from osteoarthritis and osteoporosis fell and fractured her ninth thoracic vertebra. She underwent a vertebroplasty procedure in which cement mixture was injected into the fractured bone, using imaging guidance. This is a newer treatment for painful compression fractures in the spinal column, which are a common result of osteoporosis. She regained fifty percent mobility; however, she still had constant shooting pain ten weeks after the procedure. I bilaterally needled 44.02-44.03 and 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. After the first treatment, the patient reported being more than fifty percent better. The following week I repeated the same treatment, after which her pain became intermittent and only occurred when she moved in a particular way or lifted any object weighing more than five pounds. Additionally, I gave her a bone-building formula. I am truly impressed by the efficacy of this combination of points, especially given her age and the extent of her osteoporosis.
combinations: Spinal degeneration: Bilaterally needle 44.02 Back Vertebrae, 44.03 Head Wisdom and 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. See case history, above.

name: Shouying, Head Wisdom (T 44.03)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.03 Shouying , is on the TH channel, 4.5 cun proximal to the olecranon along the posterior edge of the humerus. It is 2 cun proximal to Houzhui (T 44.02) . | Johnson: 44.02 Back Vertebrae is located on the back of the arm, 2.5 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, on the San Jiao channel, 0.5 cun superior to SJ11 Qing Leng Yuan. 44.03 Head Wisdom is located on the San Jiao channel on the back of the arm, 4.5 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, 0.5 cun inferior to SJ12 Xiao Luo.
primary_indications: Subluxation or dislocation of the spine
secondary_indications: nighttime cough in the elderly Shoulder pain
johnson_indications: Dislocated or herniated disc of the thoracic vertebrae*
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun along the side of the bone or touching the bone. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 44.02 Back Vertebrae may be combined with 44.03 Head Wisdom in the treatment of spine diseases, especially lumbar.
