combinations: Spinal degeneration: Bilaterally needle 44.02 Back Vertebrae, 44.03 Head Wisdom and 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. See case history, above.

name: Fuding, Wealth Top (T 44.04)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.04 Fuding , is on the TH channel, on the posterior aspect of the upper arm, 1 cun proximal to Xiaoluo (TH 12) and 2.5 cun proximal to Shouying (T 44.03). | Johnson: These points are located on the San Jiao channel on the back of the arm: 44.04 Wealth Top is located 7 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, between SJ12 Xiao Luo and SJ13 Nao Hui. 44.05 Back Branch is located 8 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, 1.0 cun proximal to 44.04
techniques: Needle 0.3 cun for fatigue and exhaustion, and 0.5 cun for everything else.
comments: Dao Ma: 44.04 Wealth Top is usually needled with 44.05 Back Branch. Because Wealth Top has the Reaction Area of the Heart and Liver, it circulates the blood and is used to treat arteriosclerosis, hypertension, dizziness, headache and fatigue. Unique indication: 44.05 Back Branch kills microbes and increases resistance to infection.
combinations: Head and neck wind: 44.04 Wealth Top and 44.05 Back Branch are combined to treat pain in the nape of the neck, stiff neck and facial paralysis (Dr. Carson, 1973). •  Hypertension: 44.04 Wealth Top and 44.05 Back Branch are effective for hypertension. Also consider bleeding 99.08 Ear Apex (acute or chronic), DT.05 Five Mountain Range and/or fingertips (severe and acute).

name: Houzhi, Back Branch (T 44.05)
location: On the posterior of the upper arm, this Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.05 Houzhi , is on the TH channel, 1 cun proximal to Fuding (T 44.04) , 8 cun proximal to the olecranon. | Johnson: These points are located on the San Jiao channel on the back of the arm: 44.04 Wealth Top is located 7 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, between SJ12 Xiao Luo and SJ13 Nao Hui. 44.05 Back Branch is located 8 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, 1.0 cun proximal to 44.04
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 1 cun , or obliquely 1 - 1.5 cun .
comments: Dao Ma: 44.04 Wealth Top is usually needled with 44.05 Back Branch. Because Wealth Top has the Reaction Area of the Heart and Liver, it circulates the blood and is used to treat arteriosclerosis, hypertension, dizziness, headache and fatigue. Unique indication: 44.05 Back Branch kills microbes and increases resistance to infection.
combinations: Head and neck wind: 44.04 Wealth Top and 44.05 Back Branch are combined to treat pain in the nape of the neck, stiff neck and facial paralysis (Dr. Carson, 1973). •  Hypertension: 44.04 Wealth Top and 44.05 Back Branch are effective for hypertension. Also consider bleeding 99.08 Ear Apex (acute or chronic), DT.05 Five Mountain Range and/or fingertips (severe and acute).

name: Jianzhong, Shoulder Center (T 44.06)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.06 Jianzhong , is on the LI channel, 2.5 cun distal to the acromion joint, on the midpoint of the deltoid muscle. | Johnson: Shoulder Center is located 2.5-3.0 cun (depending upon the size of the deltoid) below the acromion process. Note: To easily locate Shoulder Center, adduct the arm and identify the depression at LI15 Jian Yu. The center of the deltoid muscle and Shoulder Center are four fingers distal to this depression. Palpate for the most tender point.
primary_indications: palpitations Skin diseases (especially in the neck and arm area)
secondary_indications: xing bi (mobile painful obstruction) and arthritis and pain in multiple joints
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun . In general, needle contralateral to the affected side. Needle on the same side as the affected area when treating skin conditions, hemiplegia, polio, and shoulder pain. | Johnson: Shoulder Triangle: Shoulder Center is the apex of the classic three-point combination known as Shoulder Triangle. Locate Shoulder Center, and then form an equilateral triangle with each side being 1.5 cun in length (see drawing above). Shoulder Center relates to the Hand Yang Ming (LI) channel, the anterior point relates to the Lung channel, and the posterior point relates to the San Jiao channel. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Functions: Because Shoulder Center is located in the deltoid muscle, needling this point activates both the muscle-treating-muscle and the muscle-treating-skin functions. This point is needled for muscle spasms, weakness and atrophy, especially in the legs; polio; knee pain; hemiplegia; shoulder pain; and frozen shoulder. It is remarkably effective for treating rashes on the neck; this relates to its Reaction Area, the Heart, which governs itching. Shoulder Triangle: There is a classic textbook Dao Ma combination called Shoulder Triangle, which is described in the needling notes. I use Shoulder Triangle only for deltoid-related shoulder pain. Weakness in the legs (Dr. Young): Dr. Young suggests combining Shoulder Center with 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points, bilaterally, to address elderly patients’ weakness in the legs.
combinations: Nosebleed: Needle 44.06 Shoulder Center with 66.04 Fire Master or 66.08 Sixth Finish. Sinus congestion: Needle 44.06 Shoulder Center, 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, with 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20) as a Guiding Point. Neck rash: Needle 44.06 Shoulder Center; 88.17-88.19 Four Horses; bleed 99.08 Ear Apex. Acromium pain (select from the following opposite-side points): 44.06 Shoulder Center, 77.18 Kidney Gate, 22.01 Double Child, 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points, 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles. Needle same-side 44.06 Shoulder Center as a Guiding Point. Shoulder pain (select from the following opposite-side points): 44.06 Shoulder Center, 77.18 Kidney Gate, 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles or 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy, 77.27 Outer Three Gates. •  Frozen shoulder: See 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36). •  Upper arm pain: Needle opposite-side 44.06 Shoulder Center, 77.18 Kidney Gate, 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles or 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31). Guiding Points are optional. •  Arthritis in the legs: Needle opposite-side 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) with A.01 Seven Miles (GB32), 44.06 Shoulder Center, A.04 San Cha Three and 22.05 Ling Gu. •  Legs numb: Tonify qi for numbness, using 44.06 Shoulder Center with 88.17-88.19 Four Horses; 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors; 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points; or 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points. •  Legs cold and painful: Needle 44.06 Shoulder Center, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), 88.03 Passing Heaven, 88.10 Passing Stomach, 11.10 Wood Fire (see 11.10 Wood Fire for needling cautions). Apply a moxa pot to: DU4, UB23, REN4, REN6. •  Polio, muscle atrophy or weakness of legs: Chief Point: 44.06 Shoulder Center; Supporting Points: 44.11 Cloud White, 44.12 Plum White, 44.15 Lower Curve, 44.16  Upper Curve. •  Weakness in the legs (elderly patient): Bilaterally needle 44.06 Shoulder Center, 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points (Dr. Young, 2008). •  Knee pain: Needle opposite-side 44.06 Shoulder Center; bleed same-side DT.07 Three Gold; needle opposite-side PC6 Nei Guan with LV3 Tai Chong as a Guiding Point. •  Sole pain (instep): Needle opposite-side 11.27.3-4 Five Tigers, 44.06 Shoulder Center, bleed same-side DT.08 Essence Branch. •  Drop foot: First, needle opposite-side 11.10 Wood Fire (see 11.10 Wood Fire for needling cautions), and then add 44.06 Shoulder Center and 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31). Have the patient walk backwards down a narrow hallway, supporting themselves with the wall, and/or stand in a warm, shallow therapy pool while holding on to the edge and rising up onto their toes and then lowering the heels back down, repeatedly. These two exercises will retrain the brain and eliminate most drop foot tendencies.•  Aphasia due to wind stroke: Needle 44.06 Shoulder Center, SP5 Shang Qiu, 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through.

name: Beimian, Back Face (T 44.07)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.07 Beimian , is overlaps with Jianyu (LI 15) , which is in the center of the depression anterior and inferior to the acromion when the arm is raised. Some sources state Beimian (T 44.07) is 1 cun posterior to Jianyu (LI 15) . | Johnson: Back Face is located between the shoulder and the arm, in the depression found when the arm is raised. This is the same location as LI15 Jian Yu.
secondary_indications: sore throat Scrofula Weakness of the legs Frozen shoulder
johnson_indications: Hand and foot pain due to hypertension
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun perpendicularly. Fatigue, weakness of the legs, vomiting, acute enteritis, and cholera, bleed this point and 4 points (above, below, left, and right) around the point (5 points total). Supraspinatus tendinitis, needle 2 - 3 cun towards Jiquan (HT 1) . Frozen shoulder, needle 2 - 3 cun towards the deltoid muscle. | Johnson: Usually bled: This point can be needled, but is commonly bled. Bleed and cup any vein in the area or any tender point within one cun of LI15. Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Large Intestine/Lung, Spleen and Stomach: Back Face treats many conditions because of its internal/external connection to the Lung and its shared pathway with the Stomach (Hand and Foot Yang Ming). It raises the pure qi, regulates the Lung qi, strengthens and tonifies the Spleen qi and disperses wind. Therefore, it can be used for abdominal distension, voice without strength, exhaustion and fatigue. “If there is abdominal distension and the voice lacks strength, this indicates that the clear qi is not ascending” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Large Intestine/Liver: Due to the special relationship between the Hand Yang Ming (LI) and the Foot Jue Yin (LV), this point affects both Liver and Gallbladder and can be bled to treat sudden deafness or tinnitus, Meniere’s disease, dry cholera, vomiting, acute enteritis or hand and foot pain due to high blood pressure.

name: Renzong, Man Ancestor (T 44.08)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.08 Renzong , overlaps with Shouwuli (LI 13) , which is 3 cun proximal to the cubital crease, in the depression between the lateral border of the humerus and the m. biceps brachii. Some sources indicate this point is 3 cun above the cubital crease on the LU channel. | Johnson: Man Ancestor is located 3.0 cun proximal to the elbow crease. This is the same location as LI13 Shou Wu Li. Note: This point is located via the Lung channel and needled toward the Large Intestine channel. To avoid injury, please carefully read the needling notes below.
techniques: Needle 0.5 cun for common cold and asthma. Needle 0.8 cun for swollen limbs. Needle 1.2 cun for LR, GB, SP disorders. Needle location must be precise so as not to injure the biceps muscle or the humerus. | Johnson: Position for locating and needling: In Dr. Lee’s clinic, we rarely needled 44.08-44.10 Three Ancestors due to their proximity to a major artery and their propensity to bruise. These points are almost always sensitive. They must be needled very carefully, if at all. For the easiest point location and best insertion, first locate all three points with the arm extended and the palm up. The points are along the Lung channel between the two heads of the biceps muscle. Once you have located them, hold your fingers on the points as you bend the elbow and rotate the arm across the chest. While holding the 171 Upper Arm Points biceps muscle in this position, needle the points toward the Large Intestine channel in order to avoid injuring the muscle or puncturing the artery. Depth: 0.5-1.5 cun Colds and asthma: 0.5 cun Edema and swollen arm: 0.8 cun Liver, gallbladder and spleen disease: 1.2 cun
comments: Blood vessel treats blood vessel: In Tung’s points system, there are many different points to choose in treating asthma and common cold, coronary heart disease, and spleen, liver and gallbladder diseases. For that reason, I do not often needle Three Ancestors, though I might use them for resuscitation in an emergency. Though other emergency points are equally effective, Three Ancestors are easily accessed, and they are effective because blood vessel treats blood vessel. Because Lung, Heart and Liver all relate to circulation and blood vessels, and because the Liver additionally relates to tendons, these points treat edema and pain of the arm and leg. Three Ancestors: Master Tung placed Man, Earth, and Heavenly Ancestor intentionally in this order because man receives from both earth and heaven and is the least of these.
combinations: Heart and kidney edema: 44.08-44.10 Three Ancestors, 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points. Any kind of Bi disease: 44.08-44.10 Three Ancestors, 77.08 Four Flower Middle (Tung’s ST36), 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5).

name: Dizong, Earth Ancestor (T 44.09)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.09 Dizong , is 1 cun distal to Binao (LI 14) and 6 cun proximal to the cubital crease, in the depression between the lateral border of the humerus and the m. biceps brachii. Some books indicate this point is on the LU channel. | Johnson: Earth Ancestor is located 6 cun proximal to the elbow crease. Note: This point is located via the Lung channel and needled toward the Large Intestine channel. To avoid injury, please carefully read the needling notes below.
primary_indications: congestive heart failure Cerebral vascular occlusion
cerebral thrombosis Stiffness of the tongue
techniques: Needle 1 cun for mild conditions. Needle up to 2 cun bilaterally for severe conditions. | Johnson: Position for locating and needling: This point is almost always sensitive. First, locate the point along the Lung channel between the two heads of the biceps muscle, with the arm extended and palm up. Once you have located it, hold your finger on the point as you bend the elbow and rotate the arm across the chest. While holding the biceps muscle in this position, needle the point toward the Large Intestine channel in order to avoid injuring the muscle or puncturing the artery. Depth: 1.0-2.0 cun
comments: Resuscitation: Earth Ancestor has the Reaction Area of the Heart and is primarily needled as a resuscitation point. It can be combined with 22.10 Hand Release (HT8) (Dr. Maher, 2005).

name: Tianzong, Heavenly Ancestor (T 44.10)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.10 Tianzong , is on the LI channel, 9 cun proximal to the cubital crease, in the depression between the lateral border of the humerus and the m. biceps brachii, or 3 cun proximal to Dizong (T 44.09) . Some sources indicate this point is on the LU channel. | Johnson: Heavenly Ancestor is located 9 cun proximal to the elbow crease. Note: This point is located via the Lung channel and needled toward the Large Intestine channel. To avoid injury, please carefully read the needling notes below.
secondary_indications: infantile paralysis Diabetes mellitus Headache from cardiac insufficiency
techniques: Needle 1 - 1.5 cun . | Johnson: Position for locating and needling: This point is almost always sensitive. First, locate the point along the Lung channel between the two heads of the biceps muscle, with the arm extended and palm up. Once you have located it, hold your finger on the point as you bend the elbow and rotate the arm across the chest. While holding the biceps muscle in this position, needle the point toward the Large Intestine channel in order to avoid injuring the muscle or puncturing the artery. Depth: 1.0-1.5 cun
comments: Gynecological indications: Because this area of the shoulder corresponds to the genitals, Heavenly Ancestor has gynecological indications. In a case of severe vulvadynia, I might use this point and/or 44.11 Cloud White. For most gynecological conditions, I use other points. Due to the muscle-treating-muscle system, needling the muscle strengthens the Spleen to resolve dampness; this explains its use in the treatment of leucorrhea. Lower body correspondence: Due to its location on the muscle, and because the shoulder and upper arm correspond holographically with the hip and thigh, this point treats polio as well as general weakness of legs and muscles. Body odor: In Tung’s system, few points are useful for excessive body odor, specifically armpit odor. As this is a common problem with teenage males, remember this unusual indication for both Heavenly Ancestor and 44.12 Plum White.

name: Yunbai, Cloud White (T 44.11)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.11 Yunbai , is in between the LU and LI channels, 1 cun anterior and 1 cun superior to the center of the deltoid muscle. It is in a natural depression on the anterior edge of the deltoid muscle. | Johnson: Cloud White is located 1.5 cun anterior and 0.5 cun superior to 44.06 Shoulder Center (2.5-3.0 cun below the acromion process, at the center of the deltoid muscle).
johnson_indications: Leucorrhea (qi deficient red or white discharge)
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun (For leucorrhea: 0.5 cun)
comments: Energetic pathways: In the name of this point, “White” indicates a relationship to Lung and metal; Cloud White tonifies Lung qi. It is located in a large muscle between the Lung channel and Large Intestine channel. Needling into the muscle activates the muscle-treating-muscle system, thereby strengthening the Spleen; it also tonifies qi and disperses dampness. I tend to choose these points only in warm weather, when they are easily accessible because women are wearing short sleeves. In general, I choose other points for treating vaginal discharges; Tung’s system has some of the best, including 66.02 Wood Wife, 11.06 Return to the Nest, and 11.24 Gynecological Points as well as 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters and Three Plum Blossom, to name a few. Constitutional treatments may also be effective. Holographic images: In one system of correspondences, this area of the shoulder corresponds to the genitals, making it effective for treating diseases of the lower jiao, such as leucorrhea and vaginitis. In another system, the shoulder corresponds to the hips, so Cloud White may be combined with 44.06 Shoulder Center to treat weakness and distending pain of the hip, leg or calf muscles. This makes it additionally useful in the treatment of polio, muscle atrophy or hemiplegia, also due to the muscle-treating muscle function. We may consider adding these points to treatments for multiple sclerosis, fibromyalgia or any kind of palsy, though I have not tried them for these indications.
combinations: Gynecological disease: 44.11 Cloud White with 44.06 Shoulder Center or 44.11 Cloud White with 44.10 Heavenly Ancestor, 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, SP6 San Yin Jiao and 66.02 Wood Wife. Weakness with distending leg pain: 44.11 Cloud White, 44.06 Shoulder Center. Polio, muscle atrophy or weakness of legs: Chief Point: 44.06 Shoulder Center; Supporting Points: 44.11 Cloud White, 44.12 Plum White, 44.15 Lower Curve, 44.16 Upper Curve.

name: Libai, Plum White (T 44.12)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.12 Libai , is in between the LU and LI channels, 1 cun inferior and 1 cun anterior to the center of the deltoid muscle. It is in the natural depression on the anterior edge of the deltoid muscle. | Johnson: Plum White is located 2.0 cun distal to 44.11 Cloud White.
secondary_indications: Excessive perspiration Lateral leg or calf pain
foot pain or sprain Post-polio syndrome
johnson_indications: Lower leg, calf and foot pain
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 0.3-0.8 cun, depending upon deltoid muscle mass
comments: Body odor: I primarily use this point to treat body odor and excessive sweating of the armpits. See 44.11 Cloud White for further comments.
combinations: Body odor: 44.10 Heavenly Ancestor and 44.12 Plum White. Polio, muscle atrophy or weakness of legs: Chief Point: 44.06 Shoulder Center; Supporting Points: 44.11 Cloud White, 44.12 Plum White, 44.15 Lower Curve, 44.16 Upper Curve.

name: Zhitong, Branch Through (T 44.13)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.13 Zhitong , is on the SI channel, 4.5 cun proximal to the elbow. | Johnson: 44.13 Branch Through is located 1.0 cun medial to 44.03 Head Wisdom (44.03 is located on the back of the arm, 4.5 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow). 44.14 Falling Through is located 1.0 cun medial to 44.04 Wealth Top (44.04 is located on the back of the arm, 7 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow).
johnson_indications: Lack of strength in the four limbs
techniques: Needle perpendiculary 0.3 - 1 cun , or obliquely 1 - 1.5 cun .
comments: Energetic pathways: Located on the Small Intestine channel, Branch Through and Falling Through treat Kidney diseases due to the Hand and Foot Tai Yang (SI/UB) connection, and also due to the internal/external relationship between the Urinary Bladder and Kidney. A bone-treating-bone Kidney tonification function is activated when these points are needled close to the bone. Liver and Kidney Reaction Areas: Branch Through and Falling Through may be combined with 44.15 Lower Curve and 44.16 Upper Curve for hypertension, hemiplegia, dizziness, etc., because they share the Reaction Areas of Kidney and Liver, and also due to the KD/LV (mother/child) relationship. Considering the ease of location and efficacy, I am likely to choose 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors before I needle these points. The two Dao Ma patterns cannot be combined, as one is on the anterior and one is on the posterior side of the arm. If the patient were positioned in a straight chair, this could be accomplished. Caution (high blood pressure): If the patient’s blood pressure is exceedingly high, I recommend bleeding DT.04 Five Mountain Range or the fingertips (more effective than bleeding the Jing Well points). A patient whose blood pressure is nearing 220/120 should not be allowed to leave the clinic until blood pressure treatments bring it down to around 150/90, after which time they should be directed to the nearest emergency room for medication. It is always wiser to wean patients with high blood pressure off their medications slowly than to risk any kind of cerebrovascular event. Be smart!

name: Luotong, Falling Through (T 44.14)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.14 Luotong , is on the SI channel, 7 cun proximal to the elbow. | Johnson: 44.13 Branch Through is located 1.0 cun medial to 44.03 Head Wisdom (44.03 is located on the back of the arm, 4.5 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow). 44.14 Falling Through is located 1.0 cun medial to 44.04 Wealth Top (44.04 is located on the back of the arm, 7 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow).
johnson_indications: Lack of strength in the four limbs
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun along the bone. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 44.13 Branch Through is usually combined with 44.14 Falling Through, as they share indications and Reaction Areas. Depth: 0.6-1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Located on the Small Intestine channel, Branch Through and Falling Through treat Kidney diseases due to the Hand and Foot Tai Yang (SI/UB) connection, and also due to the internal/external relationship between the Urinary Bladder and Kidney. A bone-treating-bone Kidney tonification function is activated when these points are needled close to the bone. Liver and Kidney Reaction Areas: Branch Through and Falling Through may be combined with 44.15 Lower Curve and 44.16 Upper Curve for hypertension, hemiplegia, dizziness, etc., because they share the Reaction Areas of Kidney and Liver, and also due to the KD/LV (mother/child) relationship. Considering the ease of location and efficacy, I am likely to choose 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors before I needle these points. The two Dao Ma patterns cannot be combined, as one is on the anterior and one is on the posterior side of the arm. If the patient were positioned in a straight chair, this could be accomplished. Caution (high blood pressure): If the patient’s blood pressure is exceedingly high, I recommend bleeding DT.04 Five Mountain Range or the fingertips (more effective than bleeding the Jing Well points). A patient whose blood pressure is nearing 220/120 should not be allowed to leave the clinic until blood pressure treatments bring it down to around 150/90, after which time they should be directed to the nearest emergency room for medication. It is always wiser to wean patients with high blood pressure off their medications slowly than to risk any kind of cerebrovascular event. Be smart!

name: Xiaqu, Lower Curve (T 44.15)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.15 Xiaqu , is on the SI channel, 8 cun proximal to the elbow, on the same level as Naohui (TH 13) . | Johnson: Lower Curve is located on the back of the arm, 8 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow and 1.0 cun medial to the midline.
johnson_indications: Joint instability due to nerve damage
techniques: Needle 0.6 - 1.5 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 0.6-1.0 cun
comments: Reaction Areas: 44.15 Lower Curve has the Reaction Areas of Liver and Lung. 44.16 Upper Curve has the Reaction Areas of Liver and Kidney. Dao Ma: 44.15 Lower Curve is usually combined with 44.16 Upper Curve. Because these points are located in a muscular area, and because muscle treats muscle, the points tonify the Spleen. Needled together as a Dao Ma, they treat diseases related to Liver, Kidney and Spleen deficiency, such as sciatica, hypertension and polio. Nerve damage due to injury, stenosis: 44.15 Lower Curve is unique in that it treats nerve damage due to injury. This point is effective in treating cervical injury or stenosis; 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons could also be chosen or added.
combinations: Nerve damage due to injury, stenosis: 44.15 Lower Curve is unique in that it treats nerve damage due to injury. This point is effective in treating cervical injury or stenosis; 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons could also be chosen or added. Polio, muscle atrophy or weakness of legs: Chief Point: 44.06 Shoulder Center; Supporting Points: 44.11 Cloud White, 44.12 Plum White, 44.15 Lower Curve, 44.16 Upper Curve.

name: Shangqu, Upper Curve (T 44.16)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.16 Shangqu , is on the lateral aspect of the upper arm, in between the LI and TH channels, 1 cun posterior to the center of the deltoid muscle. | Johnson: Upper Curve is located 1.0 cun posterior to 44.06 Shoulder Center (2.5-3.0 cun below the acromion process, at the center of the deltoid muscle).
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1.5 cun . | Johnson: Bleed for cirrhosis or hepatitis (Dr. Carson, 1973). Needle opposite side for structural issues. Depth: 0.6-1.5 cun
comments: See 44.15 Lower Curve for additional comments and combinations.

name: Shuiyu (T 44.17)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.17 Shuiyu , overlaps with Naoshu (SI 10) . With the arm adducted, follow the posterior axillary crease superiorly to a depression just below the scapular spine. Some sources state this point is 0.5 cun above Jianzhen (SI 9) , which lies posterior and inferior to the shoulder joint, and 1 cun above the posterior end of the axillary fossa. | Johnson: Water Healing is located 1.5 cun posterior and 0.5 cun superior to 44.06 Shoulder Center (2.5-3.0 cun below the acromion process, at the center of the deltoid muscle). It may also be found in the same location as SI10 Nao Shu, in the depression inferior to the scapular spine, directly above the posterior end of the axillary fold. Note: Carefully palpate the Small Intestine channel on the back of the shoulder for the most sensitive point.
secondary_indications: leg muscle pain General weakness Urticaria
johnson_indications: Pain of the arm, wrist and dorsum of the hand
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Use a lancet to prick yellow fluids from this point to treat kidney diseases. When treating arm, wrist or hand pain, bleed the same side for dark blood. | Johnson: Bleeding: To treat kidney diseases, bleed Water Healing until yellow fluid appears. To treat pain of the upper arm, wrist and dorsum of the hand, bleed Water Healing until dark blood appears (Dr. Young, 2008). I find that bleeding 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) has a much stronger effect. Remember that for structural problems, bleeding is done on the same side as the indication.•  Needled: Opposite side or bilaterally. •  Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: In Master Tung’s system, all points on the back of the upper arm can be used to treat Kidney disorders; this is exemplified by Water Healing’s Reaction Area of the Kidney. Additionally, we reach the Kidney through several energetic pathways: first, the internal/external connection between the Hand and Foot Tai Yang (SI/UB), which allows us to access the Kidney via the Urinary Bladder; second, the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yin (KD), which are both significant in terms of water metabolism as well as nephritis (22.06-22.07); and third, the connection between Hand Tai Yang (SI) and Foot Tai Yin (SP), both of which are capable of draining dampness because earth controls water, making Small Intestine points useful in the treatment of water diseases. In Tung’s acupuncture system, we have two powerful examples of Kidney points found on the Spleen channel: Three Emperors, including 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan), and 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points. In the name of 44.17, Shui Yu, “Shui” translates as “water” (implying water diseases), and Yu translates as “healing” or “cure.” •  Case history (foot numbness and weakness, Master Tung): To treat a patient with foot numbness, trembling and weakness, Master Tung bilaterally needled: 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan), 44.06 Shoulder Center, 44.11 Cloud White, and needled right side 44.07 Back Face; left side 44.17 Water Healing (Dr. Wang, 2013).

name: Sanling * (T 44.18)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.18* Sanling , is a three-point set consisting of a central point 0.5 cun proximal to Quze (PC 3) , which is on the ulnar side of the tendon m. biceps brachii on the transverse crease of the elbow. The two others points are 0.5 cun radial and 0.5 cun ulnar to the first.
primary_indications: chest pain radiating to the upper back Gaohuangshu (BL 43) area
difficulty breathing from insufficient oxygen to the heart
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun perpendicularly or obliquely. This point should be bled for optimal effect. Look for a dark vein or shadow to bleed. Squeezing out black blood will yield better effects than squeezing out red blood.

name: Shenjian * (T 44.19)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.19* Shenjian , is on the shoulder, close to the LI channel, between Jianfeng (T 44.31)* and Yunbai (T 44.11) .[ Jianfeng (T 44.31)* is located 0.5 cun inferior to Jianyu (LI 15) . Yunbai (T 44.11) is located 1 cun anterior and 1 cun superior to the center of the deltoid muscle.]
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun or obliquely downward 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Pianjian * (T 44.20)
location: According to Henry McCann, this Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.20* Pianjian , is 1 cun horizontally posterior to Jianyu (LI 15) , which is anterior and inferior to the acromion in a depression found when the arm abducted. This point is closer to the TH channel. However, according to James Maher, this point is located at the midpoint of Jianfeng (T 44.31)* and Shangqu (T 44.16) . [ Jianfeng (T 44.31)* is located 0.5 cun inferior to Jianyu (LI 15) . Shangqu (T 44.16) is located on the lateral aspect of the upper arm, 1 cun posterior to the center of the deltoid muscle.]
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Guciyi * (T 44.21)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.21* Guciyi , is on the LI channel, 2 cun proximal to Quchi (LI 11) , which is on the lateral end of the transverse cubital crease.
techniques: Needle to touch the bone.

name: Gucier * (T 44.22)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.22* Gucier , is on the LI channel, 4 cun proximal to Quchi (LI 11) , 2 cun above Guciyi (T 44.21)* .
techniques: Needle to touch the bone.

name: Gucisan * (T 44.23)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.23* Gucisan , is on the LI channel, 6 cun proximal to Quchi (LI 11) , 2 cun above Gucier (T 44.22)* .
techniques: Needle to touch the bone.

name: Zhengji * (T 44.24)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.24* Zhengji , is a three-point set on the LI channel, 2 cun , 4 cun , and 6 cun proximal to the lateral end of the transverse cubital crease. There are some sources that state this set of 3 points is on the LU channel instead.
primary_indications: Disorders of the bone: bone spurs
stiffness and inability to bend the spine
techniques: Needle perpendicularly or obliquely towards the shoulder 1 - 1.5 cun . This point specifically targets any spinal disorders. It is most effective when the needle touches the bone.

name: Feiqiyi * (T 44.25)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.25* Feiqiyi, is 3 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, between the LI and the TH channels.
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Feiqier * (T 44.26)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.26* Feiqier , is 3 cun above Feiqiyi (T 44.25)* , or 6 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, between the LI and TH channels.
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Sanshen * (T 44.27)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.27* Sanshen , is a three-point set on the TH channel, on the lateral aspect of the upper arm. These points are 1.5 cun , 2.5 cun , and 3.5 cun proximal to the olecranon when the elbow is flexed.
secondary_indications: cough in the elderly Throat cancer
techniques: Needle 1 cun perpendicularly to tonify the Kidney. Needle obliquely and superiorly 0.5 cun when treating the throat and bronchitis.

name: Dingke * (T 44.28)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.28* Dingke , is 1.6 cun proximal and 0.5 cun anterior to Quchi (LI 11) , which is on the lateral end of the transverse cubital crease.
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Houjian * (T 44.29)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point Houjian has been renumbered to T 33.19. It was initially numbered incorrectly in the 44.xx zone. The location of this point is on the forearm, and therefore, is in the 33.xx zone. Please see Houjian (T 33.19)* for point information.

name: Fugesan * (T 44.30)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point Fugesan has been renumbered to T 33.20. It was initially numbered incorrectly in the 44.xx zone. The location of this point is on the forearm, and therefore, is in the 33.xx zone. Please see Fugesan (T 33.20)* for point information.

name: Jianfeng * (T 44.31)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.31* Jianfeng , is 0.5 cun inferior to Jianyu (LI 15) , which is in the depression of the anterior superior portion of the shoulder on the m. deltoideus.
primary_indications: numbness and bi zheng (painful obstruction syndrome) of the arms or half of the body
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 0.8 cun or obliquely downward 0.8 cun .

name: Huobao, Fire Bag (T 55.01)
location: This point overlaps with the extra point Duyin , which is on the plantar aspect of the 2nd toe, at the midpoint of the transverse crease of the DIP joint. There are discrepancies on the exact location of this point among different sources, therefore palpate for the ah shi point near the location described above for best results. | Johnson: Fire Bag is located on the plantar surface of the second toe. Look for a vessel in the center of the distal crease. Note: This point is found at the same location as Du Yin (Extra Point), and it is always bled. Cautions: Forbidden during pregnancy except when the placenta is retained.
secondary_indications: Hepatic disorders Red or white vaginal discharge
johnson_indications: Heart attack with icy cold hands and feet*
Nonstop bleeding after delivery or traumatic injury
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun to touch the bone. This point can be bled, especially for angina. | Johnson: Fire Bag is usually bled: Bilaterally bleed a visible vein on the underside of the second toe. Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Fire Bag, located on the Stomach meridian, may be the most important point in all of Tung’s system because it can be used to save a life. Due to the special relationship between the Foot Yang Ming (ST) and Hand Jue Yin (PC), Fire Bag is a good emergency point to use when someone is having or has recently had a heart attack. “Huo” translates as “fire,” in this case meaning “heart.” “Bao” translates as “envelope” or “bag” (referring to the Pericardium). Because the Pericardium is the Heart Protector, points on the Pericardium channel are always chosen over points on the Heart channel. Emergency point for chest and Heart disorders: Dr. Lee used the metaphor of a balloon to represent the heart, and said that treating the heart directly by needling Heart channel points is like popping the balloon with a pin. Bleeding Fire Bag allows a slow release of pressure to stabilize the Heart and immediately resolve chest pain. When the heart is in spasm, circulation is compromised, and the hands and feet may be icy cold. Bleeding Fire Bag calms the spasm, reducing pressure in the chest. After the treatment, the patient will be able to breathe more easily and you will see proper color quickly return to their face. Heart attack or severe angina: In an emergency, when there is no time to acquire a bleeding needle, it may be necessary to use a sharp knife to bleed this point. This kind of situation is one in which a person may have a heart attack in the morning and die by evening. An acupuncturist who is prepared to bleed Fire Bag may be able to significantly reduce permanent damage to the heart before an ambulance arrives. Be sure to have someone call 911 immediately while you are bleeding Fire Bag. Angina: In cases of acute, mild or moderate angina, rather than bleeding Fire Bag, I deeply needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle to release pressure from the chest. I carry 60mm needles in the glove box of my car and have used them on multiple occasions for this reason. The Four Flower Line (Stomach meridian) utilizes the special relationship between the Foot Yang Ming (ST) and Hand Jue Yin (PC). When PC6 Nei Guan is added to 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36), the combination becomes an ancient point pattern called Old Doctors’ Two Old Needles. Gas pains mimic chest pain: It is far more common for chest pain to be caused by gas trapped in the chest than by a heart attack. People panic when they have chest pain; they may think they are dying and call you in the middle of the night. If they are able to easily talk to you on the phone, they are probably not having a heart attack. I suggest that in this situation, you ask the patient to firmly strike their sternum three times with a flat fist and then attempt to belch. In most cases this releases the gas and instantly relieves the chest pain. Anxiety chest pain: Anxiety is probably the most frequent cause of chest pain. Patients with chest pain from anxiety are likely to think they may be dying. You may or may not be able to calm them down; such patients typically need a trip to the emergency room and an EKG to be convinced that they are not having a heart attack. Labor and delivery concerns: Retained placenta: Delivering a retained placenta is the primary use of textbook Du Yin (Extra Point), also known as 55.01 Fire Bag. We may also use PC6 Nei Guan and GB21 Jian Jing for this purpose; however, a quick prick of Fire Bag with a lancet usually does the job. Never pull on the umbilical cord to encourage the release of the placenta, as this would cause a piece of the placenta to remain in the uterus, resulting in bleeding that will not stop. Should this happen, the patient will need to be transported to the emergency room for a D&C. Always check a delivered placenta to insure that it is completely intact. Difficult delivery: There are so many effective ways to induce labor or speed delivery that I would only choose to bleed Fire Bag on a laboring mother if nothing else seemed to work. Nonstop bleeding: Fire Bag is said to be useful to treat nonstop bleeding after delivery or traumatic injury when blood loss is not dramatic, but I have not tried it for this purpose. Hernia: In a case of twisted intestine or acute intestinal hernia when swelling prevents the hernia from receding, it may help to bleed Fire Bag. Both of these conditions are excruciatingly painful and the patient may require surgical attention. When surgically “violated,” the intestines are likely to develop adhesions and scar tissue. If you are able to treat the patient first, surgical scar tissue may be avoided. Liver cancer: Fire Bag is said to prolong the life of liver cancer patients, although I have never used it in this way. The Stomach meridian treats liver diseases due to the special relationship between the Stomach and Pericardium meridians and the internal/ external relationship between the Hand and Foot Jue Yin (PC/LV). Epilepsy: Some TCM textbooks say that Fire Bag, also known as Du Yin, is bled for patients experiencing a grand mal seizure. Though this approach seems theoretically sound, it is hard to imagine accessing this area when a patient is having an excess- type seizure. For treatment of a deficient or flaccid-type seizure, I would not bleed this point. Flower Bone Points Flower Bone Points—“Hua” translates as “flower;” “Gu” translates as “bone.” We can generally state the following (Dr. Young, 2008): Flower Bone One treats the eyes and head (upper jiao). Flower Bone Two treats the arms (middle jiao). Flower Bone Three treats the waist (lower jiao). Flower Bone Four treats the sit bones (lower jiao).

name: Huaguyi, Flower Bone One (T 55.02)
location: This is a four-point set on the sole of the foot between the 1st and 2nd metatarsals. The first point is 0.5 cun from the web margin, opposite to Xingjian (LR 2) . The rest are 1 cun , 1.5 cun , and 2 cun from the web margin on the same line. The third point is opposite to Taichong (LR 3) . | Johnson: In this combination, all four needles are found on the ball of the foot, opposite LV2 and LV3. The first point in the pattern is just proximal to the intersection of the distal heads of the first and second metatarsal bones. The second point is just distal to the intersection of the first and second metatarsal-phalangeal joints. Divide the area between the second point and the web of the large toe and second toe into equal thirds and insert two additional needles in line with the others.
primary_indications: tearing of eyes or sensitivity to wind
johnson_indications: Tearing eyes sensitive to the wind
Aching pain of the nasal bone
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . | Johnson: Needle bilaterally. Introduction to Flower Bone points: For success in using Flower Bone point patterns, palpation is essential. Once the practitioner has developed extremely sensitive fingers and has accurately located these points on four or five pairs of feet, needling will be more or less routine. In my supervision classes, we spend up to an hour per student perfecting palpation of these points. In my opinion, this time is very well spent, as the Flower Bone One points are unsurpassed when it comes to treating difficult eye diseases. The following description of precise palpation and needling of Flower Bone One also applies to the other Flower Bone Points (Flower Bone Two, Three and Four), Point Location and Needling Technique. Although the description below is lengthy, the clues provided make all the difference in successfully locating and needling the Flower Bone points: Patient positioning: For almost thirty years, I have needled these points on patients lying face down. When a patient is in this position, I place a pillow under their lower legs, suspending their toes slightly above the table so their feet are completely relaxed. I do not have them place their head in a face cradle for the short time that they will be lying face down, because it is important that their feet are close to the end of the table during palpation and needling. After needling, because this needle pattern requires lengthy retention (up to one hour or more), I help the patient turn over onto their back. This is most easily done if they swing their legs over the side of the table and sit up, then rotate their hips and lie down on their back. I place a bolster beneath their knees. Most patients are more comfortable lying on their back for the duration of the treatment, and additional points may be needled more easily in this position, as well. It was only recently, with a patient who was unable to lie on their stomach, that I taught myself how to needle these points with the overhang produced when the patient is lying face up. I highly recommend that first, you master palpating and needling these points with the patient face down, when the plantar surface of the feet is more easily accessible and you have the advantage of gravity. Palpation: Palpating the points is by far the most difficult aspect of properly applying the Flower Bone point patterns. It is absolutely necessary that you sit at the foot of the table, nearly eye level with the patient’s feet; it is impossible to accurately palpate the location of the points while standing, as your wrists will not be able to manage the angle required. Marking the feet: In supervision classes, my students mark the balls of each other’s feet, and then a supervisor checks the marks before students begin needling. The student practitioner sits at the foot of the table, facing the plantar surface of their partner’s feet, and carefully palpates the proximal side of the metatarsal-phalangeal joints, marking what they feel on the feet. When students are using their eyes and not their palpation skills, they tend to inaccurately draw the metatarsal heads in a straight line across the ball of the foot. Accurate palpation reveals that the proximal edge of the distal heads of the first and fifth metatarsal bones are significantly larger and superior to the three metatarsal heads in between. (See drawing above.) Tip versus top: When identifying the proximal edge of the distal metatarsal heads, it is important to find the high point of the metatarsal-phalangeal joint and roll a finger over the proximal edge. Most students palpate the tip of the bone (see the dot on the metatarsal-phalangeal head in the drawing of the right foot, shown above) and call it the top. However, the top is the most proximal edge, and it is located more deeply than the tip. The tip of the bone is what makes contact with the ground when we walk. Misinterpretation of tip for top (rolling over the proximal edge of the metatarsal) is one of the most frequent mistakes made by students learning these points, and it inevitably results in their needle hitting bone. Push on the toes: If you have a hard time locating the metatarsal heads, push down on the corresponding toe and the metatarsal head will pop right up. Find all five metatarsals: It is essential to locate the correct number of metatarsals. When people are standing, the bones of their feet spread; however, when the feet are not weighted, the bones may somewhat overlap, giving the appearance that one metatarsal is missing. Focusing on just one at a time, you will be able to differentiate all five. If the lateral edges of the metatarsal heads overlap, draw them that way. It is at the intersections of these bones, overlapping or not, that the needles are inserted. Needling: Due to the wide variation of bone structure in feet, this is one of the most difficult point patterns to needle correctly. Because the foot bones are very close 191 Plantar Foot Points together, there is absolutely no room for error. As people age, their feet become increasingly misshapen, so it is essential that you practice foot palpation until your perception of the bones beneath your fingers is perfected. Needle gauge: It is a good idea to teach yourself to wield a thin needle. I usually use 0.15 x 30 mm needles (#1, 40-gauge needle) for all of the Flower Bone points. Thinner gauge needles will bend without your knowing it, while larger gauge needles are unnecessarily painful. Remember that every time you touch a bone with a needle, the patient feels it. Nerves and blood vessels: These needles are not painful unless they plow into the bone or hit a blood vessel. The feet are extraordinarily expressive, and a mild curling of the toes may simply indicate sensation on the plantar surface, where nerve endings are very close together. It is fine to proceed if you see this kind of reaction. However, if you hit a blood vessel, the toes may radically curl or the foot may twitch significantly. Should this happen, you must decide whether to needle quickly through the vessel or remove and/or redirect the needle. It is not always necessary to remove the needle when the sensation occurs after initial insertion, causing the foot to jump. I highly recommend using needle guide tubes with a strong tap in order to move quickly and efficiently through this highly innervated area. Perceiving needle depth: Always use both hands and keep the fingers of your non-needling hand on the dorsum of the foot (in the patient’s Liver valley), as this enables you to feel the subtle pressure of the approaching needle tip. The inside of the epidermis on the dorsum is just as sensitive as the surface of the skin, so placing one hand on the dorsum of the foot gives you information necessary to know when to stop, thereby reducing needle sensitivity for the patient. This technique also provides counter-pressure and assures that the practitioner is aware of the precise location of the needle. Retention: One-hour retention is required. Removing the needles: This is considered deep needling, so when removing a needle, place a finger on each side of it and pull up firmly. If the patient’s foot twitches as you needle a point, it is likely that you have hit a small blood vessel, so when pulling the needle, be prepared for a tiny drop of blood. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Extraordinary points for the eyes: Dr. Lee taught me to use Flower Bone One, and it has become one of my specialties. In one of Dr. Young’s classes I asked him why he was not recommending Flower Bone One, and he said he doesn’t use these points due to their inconvenience. He was correct in stating their degree of difficulty. However, I use these points all the time and find them to be absolutely miraculous in the treatment of extraordinarily difficult eye diseases, such as optic nerve atrophy, glaucoma, and macular degeneration, all of which I have successfully treated multiple times. Without these points, I would have no confidence in positive outcomes for these disorders. In addition to these rather severe conditions, Flower Bone One can also be used for: nearsightedness, farsightedness, astigmatism, night blindness, eye inflammation, tearing eyes, photophobia, itching or irritated eyes, trachoma and eyelid infection. Liver and Kidney energetic pathways: The eyes are the opening to the Liver; the Kidney is the mother of the Liver. Flower Bone One, found in the Liver valley, treats the anatomy of the eye, but in order to treat the vision we must add points that relate to the Kidneys, such as: 77.18-77.21 Two or Three Emperors, substituting 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7) for 77.21 Man Emperor (Tung’s SP6), along with GB20 Feng Chi and GB37 Guang Ming. Case histories (optic nerve atrophy): A 35-year-old woman presented with vertigo and dizziness. Her condition had been diagnosed as Mal de Debarquement Syndrome, an inner ear problem that produces a pronounced and persistent rocking sensation after leaving a boat. She could not walk without falling down. I treated her vertigo and dizziness with 88.17-88.19 Four Horses and A.04 San Cha Three, but her condition did not improve. I also cupped her neck and jaw in order to restore proper blood flow to her brain. This resolved her migraine headaches and TMJ, but the rocking did not change. Both of us were discouraged, and she discontinued treatment. A few weeks later, she was diagnosed with optic nerve atrophy. When she was 15 years old, she had a brain tumor removed; now, twenty years later, scar tissue was impacting her optic nerve. I had been on the wrong track in treating her inner ear. I asked her to return for Flower Bone One, and after two treatments the vertigo completely stopped. I recommended at least ten visits and suggested one treatment per quarter, indefinitely, to continually strengthen the optic nerve in response to the continuous accumulation of scar tissue. A student asked if I would recommend needling these points for a one-year-old baby with optic nerve issues. Unless you have needled these points quite often, I recommend training the child’s parents to use acupressure to massage these points for five minutes, three times daily. Alternatively, you could also teach them to apply Koryo Hand Therapy pellets17 to Flower Bone One. Case histories (glaucoma): Often in my practice, random patients show up concurrently with the same disease process, even a rare one. This happened more than twenty years ago when I found myself treating three different patients with glaucoma simultaneously: The first patient was a 65-year-old man with glaucoma and Crohn’s disease. He had multiple laser surgeries on both eyes, and a large portion of his intestine had been removed. Once each week, I treated him with Flower Bone One and then had him turn onto his back and needled 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle, points used for pressure behind the eyes as well as gastroenteritis. His intraocular pressure started to descend nicely, from 22 mmHg to 12 mmHg. His visual field exams also radically improved, and he was able to entirely discontinue his glaucoma medication. With additional support from an herbal formula, his Crohn’s disease was completely healed within three months. The second glaucoma patient was born with congenitally closed tear ducts. Within 24 hours of his birth, the optic nerves were destroyed, leaving him legally blind and with glaucoma. Because the first patient’s treatment had worked so well, I used the same treatment with the second patient. This patient’s intraocular pressure reduced from 19 mmHg to 11 mmHg and stayed there. I treated him once weekly for the first year and occasionally over the following three years. Now, 17 Tae-Woo Yoo, Koryo Hand Therapy (2001) 193 Plantar Foot Points nineteen years later, and without further treatment for his eyes, he is still free of glaucoma medication, though his visual field exams will never improve. The third patient was 73 years old when he entered my practice. He loved nothing more than to spend all of his days tending his orchards on his tractor, in the sun and wind. Because of this, his eyes were like those of a 90-year-old. I tried to use the treatment that had worked so well with the other two patients, but when I saw no obvious improvement within a few weeks, I had to check my thinking. Once I began to use Flower Bone One with modified Two Emperors (77.18 Shen Guan and 77.28 Bright Light), the patient’s eyes began to improve. This patient was never able to discontinue using eye drops, but his visual field exams got better and better. He is now 93 years old and can still be found in the orchards, surrounded by walnuts and oranges. Cautions: Treatment may reduce the intraocular pressure and improve the visual field. Once the pressure is lowered, the patient may need additional treatments at least quarterly, to prevent the pressure from rising again. Monitor carefully. The first patient described above, with glaucoma and Crohn’s disease, never had bowel problems again; however, his intraocular pressure increased after ten years without treatment. This was a learning experience for me. Macular degeneration: This condition can be difficult to treat. Initially, these patients need to be treated at least weekly, though it is better to treat them three times a week for the first few weeks. Chronic conditions such as macular degeneration require a minimum of ten treatments before the practitioner can assess whether the condition will improve. If there are no signs of change and the patient is younger than 80 years old, continue with another ten treatments before making your determination. Patients older than 80 are less likely to respond, due to lack of circulation and significantly diminished eyesight. Case histories (macular degeneration): I simultaneously treated a father and daughter who were both suffering from macular degeneration. The father was 78 years old and had the dry type of macular degeneration. With the application of 55.02 Flower Bone One, 77.18-77.19 Three Emperors, GB20 Feng Chi and GB37 Guang Ming, the progression of the disease stopped completely. Recently, the patient reported that his vision had improved and he noticed wavy lines only when he was very tired. We continue treatment bi-monthly so that he will continue to be able to read and drive. Older eyes usually respond more slowly to treatment, and their condition may not reverse or improve. This man’s daughter was in her early 50s and suffered from the wet type of macular degeneration. She had received injections into her eyeballs every ten days to treat this condition. It was expected that over time, the injections would be less and less frequent. Unfortunately, her response to the injections was not good, and after six months, she still required them regularly. After four acupuncture treatments in four weeks, she was able to wait two weeks between injections. After four months of weekly acupuncture, she was able to receive her injections six weeks apart. At that point, I referred her to another practitioner and have not heard about her progress since. I treated an 80-year-old patient who also had the wet type of macular degeneration. She came to me after receiving injections in her eyeballs for a number of months. She vowed never to have these injections again because she had an allergic reaction to the medication that had caused her severe pain in both eyes after the last two injections. She lived alone and was extremely distraught about the possibility of losing her driver’s license and therefore her freedom. With this motivation, she came for treatment three times weekly. I also treated her for upper back, neck and arm pain. The cupping of her neck and shoulders, where the skin was black after cupping, helped to open the blockage to her eyes. After eight weeks of treatment and no further injections, she saw a new ophthalmologist who reviewed the records sent by her previous doctor, claimed that her eyes had improved, and said she no longer required the injections. Due to her age, she will always require at least quarterly treatment to maintain this improved condition. A number of years ago, I treated a 90-year-old who had no central vision at all, and the treatments were unsuccessful in making any noticeable change. We discontinued treatment after twelve visits in three months, as her degeneration was too far advanced. Additional information about these three case histories: Although I thoroughly cupped the neck and shoulders of the three successfully treated patients mentioned above, I did not bleed their Tai Yang area or Ear Apex. If I had had less encouraging results with any of them, I would have bled these areas. All three patients took Chinese patent herbal medicines for their eyes and also the supplement called Complete Eye Factor, a combination of zinc and lutein. Cataracts: Since the advent of corrective lenses used in cataract surgeries and the fact that the vision is immediately restored after these surgeries, I always recommend that patients take advantage of this surgical correction offered via allopathic medicine. Eye diseases (commentary, Dr. Lee): “Flower Bone One is very good for eye diseases. There is not much trachoma in the United States but there are many cases of red eyes or conjunctivitis due to overeating fried foods and drinking alcohol. Inflammation of the eyelids may also be due to overdrinking alcohol, especially if the alcohol is poor quality. Eyes sensitive to the wind and fearing light are symptoms of Liver Yin deficiency. Patients with this type of condition should go to bed early, usually before 9:00 pm. Such people have used up their Liver Blood. Going to bed early allows the Liver to refill with Blood. Going to bed late prevents the Liver from storing the Blood adequately. Therefore, besides doing acupuncture, such patients also must change their lifestyle” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Herbal formulas: For weakness of the eyes or degenerative eye diseases, I frequently combine a few herbal formulas: Lycii & Chrysanthemum (Qi Ju Di Huang Wan), Bright Eye Rehmannia (Ming Mu Di Huang Wan), Dendrobium Night Sight Pills (Shi Hu Ye Guang Wan) and a supplement called Complete Eye Factor by Vital Health, a combination that includes zinc and lutein. Zinc is reported to halt the progression of macular degeneration.
combinations: Dry or tearing eyes: Bilaterally: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 55.02 Flower Bone One, 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan) with 77.21 Man Emperor (Tung’s SP6) or 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7).•  Glaucoma: •  Patients younger than 60 years old: 55.02 Flower Bone One combined with 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/ Four Flower Middle. •  Elderly patients: I am more likely to use 55.02 Flower Bone One with 77.18-77.28 Three Emperors, GB20 Feng Chi and GB37 Guang Ming. However, if the patient presses on their eyeballs with their warm fingers and finds this uncomfortable, use 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/ Four Flower Middle instead.•  Macular degeneration: 55.02 Flower Bone One, 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan) with 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7), GB20 Feng Chi, GB37 Guang Ming.•  Optic nerve atrophy: 55.02 Flower Bone One, 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan) with 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7), GB20 Feng Chi, GB37 Guang Ming.•  Miscellaneous eye diseases (nearsightedness, farsightedness, astigmatism, night blindness, eye inflammation, photophobia, trachoma and eyelid infection): 55.02 Flower Bone One, 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan) with 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7), GB20 Feng Chi, GB37 Guang Ming.

name: Huaguer, Flower Bone Two (T 55.03)
location: This is a two-point set on the sole of the foot between the 2 nd and the 3 rd metatarsals. The two points are 1 cun and 1.5 cun posterior from the web margin, approximately opposite to Xiangu (ST 43) . | Johnson: Flower Bone Two is a two-point pattern located on the ball of the foot, opposite the Stomach meridian. The first point is just distal to the junction of the second and third metatarsal-phalangeal joints. The second point is 0.5 cun distal to the first point.
johnson_indications: Motor impairment of arms (cannot lift arms upwards)
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Flower Bone Two is composed of two points located on the ball of the foot, opposite the Stomach valley and the point ST43 Xian Gu. Due to the internal/external connection between the Spleen and Stomach, these points treat the Spleen and related conditions, especially those of a muscular nature. Dietary excess: Excessive consumption of sweets sedates the Spleen; Spleen deficiency leads to muscular weakness. Excessive sugar causes redness in the center of the tongue (the Stomach area), a hallmark of overeating sugar. In some cases, loose skin and weak muscles may be the result of a patient eating too many almonds or sunflower seeds, which contain cyanide (Dr. Lee, 1992).

name: Huagusan, Flower Bone Three (T 55.04)
location: This point is on the sole of the foot between the 3 rd and the 4 th metatarsals, 2 cun posterior from the web margin, opposite to Muliu (T 66.06).  | Johnson: Cheng Jiang is centered in the depression of the mentolabial groove (at the crease of the chin). Meridian: REN Mai Ren Zhong is found directly inferior to the nose, at the juncture of the upper third and middle third of the philtrum. Meridian: DU Mai DT.01 Separate Branch Upper and DT.02 Separate Branch Lower are located on the lateral edge of the scapula, though we would refer to the Toxin Area as half on and half off the scapula. Though I never needle these points, I cup them all the time. See the picture , showing cup marks over areas that have been seven-star hammered on the outside edge of the right scapula; also see Needling Notes and Comments below. Note: On a large person, it is permissible to use three cups to cover the area.
techniques: Needle 0.5 – 1 cun . | Johnson: Needle bilaterally.•  Patient positioning: Because this needle pattern requires lengthy retention (45 minutesor longer), after needling, I help the patient to turn over onto their back. This is most easily done if they swing their legs over the side of the table and sit up, then rotate their hips and lie down on their back. I place a bolster beneath their knees. •  Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Tailbone pain: Bilateral 55.04 Flower Bone Three and 55.05 Flower Bone Four have no equal for treating tailbone pain. In one case, a single treatment was able to resolve coccyx pain that had persisted for more than twenty years. •  Palpation: Before needling these points, carefully palpate the tailbone. To avoid surprising the patient, start palpating at the top of the sacrum and slowly move toward the coccyx. If they fell on their tailbone or broke it during labor and delivery, it may be extraordinarily sensitive, so palpate very gently. Though Flower Bone Three and Flower Bone Four are indicated to treat spinal pain, if the sacrum or coccyx is not tender, I generally choose other points.•  Elderly patients: These points are excellent for elderly patients who have fallen on their backside and broken their tailbone. If the pain is only in the coccyx area, these points work quickly. •  Coccyx broken during labor/delivery: Many women break their coccyx during difficult labor and delivery, and the pain may persist for years after the bone heals. These points can resolve this pain, even many years later. •  Cupping: A small cup placed at the junction of the sacrum and the coccyx yields surprisingly dark skin color on many patients, even those without pain. I always check this area for color when cupping the sacrum and lower back. •  Bulging discs: Flower Bone Three and Flower Bone Four send the qi up the legs and to the spine, and they may be combined with 1010.25 State Water, which sends the qi down the spine; the ascending and descending qi connect at the lumbosacral hinge. I frequently use this combination when there is a bulging or protruding disc at L5-S1. With both the patient and practitioner standing, first insert 1010.25 State Water horizontally downward beneath the skin. Then, help them to lie down on their back by cupping your hand over these needles as they gently lay their head on the pillow. Carefully withdraw your hand and advise them not to lift their head or turn it radically. Place a bolster under their legs. Needle Flower Bone Three and Flower Bone Four. If the overhang of the feet created by this position makes it difficult for you to needle the Flower Bone points, they may be needled with the patient lying face down. However, people with bulging discs are not able to turn over easily, so I suggest that you teach yourself to needle these points with the patient lying comfortably on their back. •  Leg and foot numbness (Dr. Lee): “Flower Bone Three and Flower Bone Four treat the entire leg as well as numbness of the legs and feet. During treatment, typically the numbness gives way to tingling and then the tingling goes away. If the patient complains about these sensations, explain that they are normal in the process of recovery. While the patient is lying down with the needles in place, have the patient raise their legs one at a time so the stimulation moves down from their hips to their lower legs. The effect is not as good if one does not move the legs in this way. Otherwise, this is a very effective point combination with good results from only a few needles” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Abdominal pain: 55.05 Flower Bone Four treats stomach and lower abdominal pain; however, nothing works better for these conditions than 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43). •  Stops bleeding: 55.05 Flower Bone Four stops bleeding; however, 66.08 Sixth Finish might be a better choice.
combinations: Bulging discs, L5-S1 hinge: Bilaterally needle 55.04 Flower Bone Three, 55.05 Flower Bone Four; needle 1010.25 State Water.•  Tailbone pain: Bilaterally needle 55.04-55.05 Flower Bone Three/Flower Bone Four. This is the best treatment; however, if it is not convenient: Unilaterally or bilaterally needle 33.12 Heart Gate (males on the left, females on the right, or needle bilaterally if one side is not enough); needle 1010.01 Uprightness Meeting (DU20), 1010.06 Posterior Meeting (DU19); bilaterally needle 66.01 Seal. •  Numbness of the legs and feet: 55.04-55.05 Flower Bone Three/Flower Bone Four treat the entire leg as well as numbness of the legs and feet. During treatment, typically the numbness gives way to tingling and then the tingling goes away (Dr. Lee, 1992).

name: Huagusi, Flower Bone Three/Flower Bone Four. (T 55.05)
location: This point is on the sole of the foot, between the 4th and 5th metatarsals, 1.5 cun posterior to the web margin, opposite to Diwuhui (GB 42) . | Johnson: Cheng Jiang is centered in the depression of the mentolabial groove (at the crease of the chin). Meridian: REN Mai Ren Zhong is found directly inferior to the nose, at the juncture of the upper third and middle third of the philtrum. DT.01 Separate Branch Upper and DT.02 Separate Branch Lower are located on the lateral edge of the scapula, though we would refer to the Toxin Area as half on and half off the scapula. Though I never needle these points, I cup them all the time. See the picture , showing cup marks over areas that have been seven-star hammered on the outside edge of the right scapula; also see Needling Notes and Comments below. Note: On a large person, it is permissible to use three cups to cover the area.
secondary_indications: Pain of the spine Abdominal pain

This is the best treatment; however, if it is not convenient: Unilaterally or bilaterally needle 33.12 Heart Gate (males on the left, females on the right, or needle bilaterally if one side is not enough); needle 1010.01 Uprightness Meeting (DU20), 1010.06 Posterior Meeting (DU19); bilaterally needle 66.01 Seal. •  Numbness of the legs and feet: 55.04-55.05 Flower Bone Three/Flower Bone Four treat the entire leg as well as numbness of the legs and feet.
