name: Shangliu, Upper Tumor (T 55.06)
location: This point is on the KI channel, on the sole of the foot, at the center of the anterior edge of the heel on the plantar surface proximal to Yongquan (KI 1) . | Johnson: Upper Tumor is located on the plantar surface of the foot, centered on the distal edge of the heel. Note: Upper Tumor is needled in a Dao Ma combination called Three Stove Bottom. These two variations of Three Stove Bottom are not usually used together. When aggressively treating brain tumors, alternate between the two Three Stove Bottom variations: Three Stove Bottom combines Upper Tumor with two additional points, 0.3 cun on either side of Upper Tumor; the treatment uses a total of three needles. (See right foot in drawing to the left.) Another variation combines Upper Tumor with one additional point, which is 1.0 cun distal to Upper Tumor; the treatment uses a total of two needles. (See left foot in drawing to the left.)
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.5 cun . | Johnson: Cautions: In my experience, these points cause immediate nausea if the needle insertion is deeper than 0.5 cun. This area can be sensitive, so insert the needle quickly. Upper Tumor can be used for those who have had an operation for a brain tumor and are still in pain or recuperating. The patient should feel their head clear after the needle is inserted. If the patient feels that their head becomes more distended after this point is needled, remove the needle(s). Calluses: Patients who frequently walk barefoot may have a hard callus on the distal edge of their heel. Place your needle in front of or behind the callus and target the point from an angle. Adding Upper Tumor: Needling this area does not interfere with other treatments on the regular meridians, but it carries those treatments’ effects to the head. Depth: 0.5 cun maximum
comments: Energetic pathways: The sole of the foot relates to the Kidney, and the Kidney governs the brain. In imaging systems, we use the bottom to treat the top, and because Upper Tumor has the Reaction Area of the cerebellum, it is particularly effective in any kind of brain excess, including edema, inflammation, infection or nerve damage. Brain tumor: Any kind of growth in the brain, including scar tissue, should be considered urgent, because the neurological impact of even tiny amounts of accumulating abnormal tissue can result in the loss of sensory or motor function, memory, or cognitive abilities. When a patient has an aggressive brain tumor, whether it is malignant or benign, I treat them as often as possible, alternating between the two variations of Upper Tumor combined with either 77.05-77.07 Three Weights or 77.27 Outer Three Gates, depending upon whether the tumor is cancer related or not. If there is malignancy somewhere in the body, I needle 77.27 Outer Three Gates and add a point or point pattern to carry its influence to the affected area. In this case, Upper Tumor directs the treatment toward the brain. Diagnostics: Several indications are common to brain tumors, including: dizziness, nausea, vomiting, severe headache, and the inability to walk in a straight line and/or to speak coherently. The presentation depends on the type of tumor and its location. Caring for the terminally ill: The prognosis may be dismal in such cases. However, when a practitioner is able to provide any amount of symptomatic relief (while being careful not to give a guarantee of false hope), it is enormously helpful to the patient and their families or caregivers. These situations also give us the opportunity to provide a strong shoulder for those who are faithfully taking care of their beloved around the clock. After thirty years of practice, I have come to see the similarities between birth and death and to know without a doubt that showing up and helping in whatever way I can is deeply impactful. When people are afraid, it is truly important for them to feel seen and heard. Open your heart to such painful situations and know that you will grow from them in inconceivable ways. Case history (brain tumor, Dr. Lee): “A little girl was brought to me with a brain tumor. An MRI showed that the tumor was very big. When she first came, her condition was already quite bad. She only seemed semiconscious. She could not answer questions or even open her mouth to show her tongue. I needled this point 203 Plantar Foot Points and after 45 minutes she became more responsive. She could answer questions, show her tongue, and even began playing with the curtain around the treatment table. Her eyeballs no longer turned up and were clear. However, the next day, she was even more unconscious. She seemed to be able to listen and to answer ‘yes,’ but I do not believe she actually understood what she was saying. When asked if she wanted to go to the hospital, she said ‘yes.’ She went to the hospital and never came out” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Case history (glioblastoma): I treated a 42-year-old female patient with an aggressive brain tumor that had been diagnosed recently. She presented with irrational and irate behavior, extreme headache, nausea and vomiting. I knew I had very little time to respond, so I treated her every day that I could. After the first treatment, in which I used 11.17 Wood (Anger), Three Stove Bottom and 77.05-77.07 Three Weights, she stopped vomiting and was able to eat small amounts regularly; her headache became moderate and intermittent. Subsequently, I alternated variations of Upper Tumor with Three Weights or 77.27 Outer Three Gates. She still had occasional bursts of anger, and these were very difficult for her family members, who knew they were losing her. Two weeks later, on the day she died, all of the symptoms returned for a few hours, and then she was gone. Her identical twin sister is still a patient in my practice today. Case history (glioblastoma): This kind of cancer is extremely aggressive, and often the best we can do is offer palliative treatment. This patient, a 38-year-old female, had been put on an extreme ketogenic (high fat/low carb) diet by her oncologist to try to control the growth of the cancer. She was eating pounds of bacon and blueberries. Though she passed away four months later, I treated her in her home three times a week and taught the treatment to her family members. She was able to put her affairs in order and say her goodbyes, but this was a case we could not win. Case history (5.5mm benign brain tumor): In 2008, a 70-year-old man who lived two hours from my office presented with severe facial pain following the surgical removal of a tumor on the right side of his brain. Prior to his surgery, he was dizzy and falling down, and had an earache and difficulty swallowing. He was informed that the surgery would certainly cause loss of hearing on the right side and would likely result in extreme facial pain. After the surgery, he could not handle the excruciating facial pain and he spoke of suicide. Surgical intervention that causes damage to nerves is a common cause of untreatable pain. I began treatment using Three Weights and Upper Tumor on the side opposite the tumor. The treatment did not resolve the facial pain but did improve it; the patient reduced his pain medications and safely drove the long distance to my office by himself. Not long after we began treatment, he was diagnosed with another tumor of the same kind on the left side of his brain. His surgeon wanted to quickly use cyberknife technique before the tumor grew too large to be treated without opening the cranium. Because the patient had been told that another surgery would cause him to lose his hearing completely, and due to his long commute, I referred him to one of my students closer to his home. I would have liked to have worked with him longer; we may have been able to regenerate the damaged nerves involved in his facial pain and surgical deafness. Blood stagnation headaches: Upper Tumor is particularly useful in treating headache or brain tumor with nausea and vomiting, especially when these occur at night. Stagnation-type headaches may increase when the patient lies still, and they are often worse between 3 a.m. and 5 a.m. Bleeding: For severe headache and brain tumor, also consider bleeding Tai Yang, UB40 Wei Zhong, 77.05-77.07 Three Weights or 77.14 Four Flower Outer (Tung’s ST40). When preparing to bleed, always look for a vein in the general area rather than looking for the point. In imaging systems, we use the bottom to treat the top, so both legs may be utilized; however, if the tumor is on one side only, be sure to bleed the same side. Occipital pain: Upper Tumor combines beautifully with 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons to treat the area of the cerebellum. Case history (severe headaches, Dr. Lee): “A 50-year-old woodcutter was knocked down by a tree and his head was shaken backwards violently. After being hospitalized, he still had severe headaches all the time. Each time his physician refilled his pain medication it would be for 100 pills, and his wife had to inject him with morphine every three hours. Over a period of two years, he had five heart attacks due to such heavy pain medication, since it is well known that pain medications affect the heart. Finally, a doctor referred him to me with severe insomnia and severe headache. I needled 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons. He then slept, hard. After 45 minutes he awoke and I asked him to gently shake his head. He shook it a little and there was no pain. Then I asked him to shake it more forcefully and still there was no pain. The man stood up. He said he could not believe it. I asked him what he could not believe. He just kept saying he could not believe it. I called his wife into the office and she asked him what he could not believe. He said he could not believe he no longer had a headache. Then she said she could not believe it. I explained to the patient that he should not do any heavy lifting or any heavy work. He left my office and returned home. After sitting around the house for one week, the man grew bored and did some digging in order to plant some flowers. This caused him to get a headache again. He came back to my office and we did several more treatments. Finally we got rid of all his headaches” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Brain tumor: Alternate between the two variations of 55.06 Upper Tumor, combined with either 77.05-77.07 Three Weights or 77.27 Outer Three Gates.•  Brain tumor with severe weakness or deficiency: 66.10 Fire Connection, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4), 66.12 Fire Scatter (KD2), needled opposite or one side only. 55.06 Upper Tumor may be added on the same side as the needles above. •  Acute concussion or severe occipital headache: 55.06 Upper Tumor, 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons.•  Epilepsy (excess type): People who have seizures in the early morning hours have excess-type epilepsy. Needle 55.06 Upper Tumor, needle or bleed 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle or 77.05-77.07 Three Weights. •  Epilepsy (deficient type): People who have seizures in the late afternoon have deficient-type epilepsy. Needle 55.06 Upper Tumor with Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment (bilateral ST36, SP6, LI11, LI4, LU7, in that order; tonify the bottom and sedate the top).Meningitis: 55.06 Upper Tumor, 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons, bleed DT.17 Up-Shooting Heaven or UB40 Wei Zhong. If you suspect the patient has meningitis (high fever, stiff neck, extreme headache), immediately refer them to the emergency room for a spinal tap to confirm the diagnosis.•  Insomnia (severe): For severe insomnia or insomnia with a headache, use a needle with 7 to 9 moxa balls (use 7 for men; use 9 for women) on a point located in the center of the heel (approximately 1.0 cun proximal to 55.06 Upper Tumor). •  Blood stagnation headaches: 55.06 Upper Tumor is particularly useful in treating headache or brain tumor with nausea and vomiting, especially when these occur at night. Stagnation-type headaches may increase when the patient lies still, and they are often worse between 3–5 a.m. •  Bleeding: For severe headache and brain tumor, also consider bleeding Tai Yang, UB40 Wei Zhong, 77.05-77.07 Three Weights or 77.14 Four Flower Outer (Tung’s ST40).

name: Sansheng * (T 55.07)
location: This is a three-point set on the KI channel, on the midline of the sole, 1 cun , 2 cun , and 3 cun posterior to Yongquan (KI 1) .
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Haibao, Seal (T 66.01)
location: This point is on the SP channel in between Yinbai (SP 1) and Dadu (SP 2) on the border of the red and white skin. | Johnson: 66.01 Seal is located on the medial side of the big toe, at the junction of the red and white skin. Note: Other acupuncture books locate Seal at the center of the phalangeal joint. I locate it at the medial midpoint of the distal phalanx, halfway between the distal and proximal attachments of the toenail and halfway between the dorsal and plantar surfaces.
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun . Needle the side contralateral to the area of pain. For example, needle the right toe for left thumb pain. | Johnson: Seal is extremely painful to needle, so do it quickly with strong stimulation, using the following techniques: Ask the patient to cough twice with insertion: first when you penetrate the surface, where nerve endings are located, and again as you take the needle down to the desired depth and very gently tap the bone. Have the patient move their thumb as you are stimulating the needle for approximately 10 seconds; this not only serves as a good distraction but also guides the qi (Active Qi Moving) to the thumb from the farthest distance possible. Unilaterally needle the opposite side for thumb and index finger pain. Seal may be needled bilaterally for internal disorders, but due to its sensitivity I never use this point for any issues other than thumb pain, for which it is unsurpassed. Needle type: 0.16 x 15mm needle (Japanese gauge 1, Chinese gauge 40). Depth: 0.3-0.4 cun or until you tap the distal phalanx.
comments: Thumb pain: Seal is extraordinary in the treatment of acute or chronic thumb pain. Elderly patients who fall on their hands, massage practitioners, arthritic patients and even acupuncturists love the effects of Seal in spite of its sensitivity. Most patients who arrive in my office do not have a primary complaint of thumb pain; however, in a thorough history taken on the first visit, I may discover that the thumb joint needs attention. Because Seal represents the most distal trajectory (big toe to opposite thumb), it needs to be needled by itself in order to maintain a clear energetic line, so Seal should be inserted as soon as possible if other treatments are planned for the same day. I often place a note on the outside of the patient’s file folder reminding me to needle Seal immediately, especially if the patient needs to wait for my full attention because the clinic is busy. By the time I rejoin them in the treatment room, Seal has already been working to address their thumb pain, and by the time we discuss their progress since the last treatment, we can usually move on to treating an issue other than thumb pain. Most patients need multiple issues addressed in every treatment. If the patient only wants treatment for their thumb pain, I needle opposite-side 11.27 Five Tigers One and Two with opposite-side Seal, while the patient rotates the affected thumb until the pain is gone (approximately two minutes); then I add Five Tigers One on the same side as a Guiding Point. Since discovering Seal’s effectiveness, I love to treat patients who have thumb pain. Thenar eminence pain: Seal is most effective for the two most distal joints and does not seem to affect the metacarpal bone itself. To treat the thenar eminence, consider using these points on the side opposite the indications: 22.01-22.02 Double Child/ Double Fairy, 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, SJ5 Wai Guan and 33.04 Fire Threaded (SJ6), or 22.11 Earth Water. These points are all effective for hand pain. Vaginitis: Seal treats gynecological problems because it strengthens the Spleen and clears dampness. However, instead of using these points, I always use 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 11.17 Wood (Anger) and 66.02 Wood Wife, because they are less painful to needle and much more powerful.
combinations: Thumb pain: Needle opposite-side 66.01 Seal with opposite-side 11.27 Five Tigers One and Two. If desired, add same-side 11.27 Five Tigers One as a Guiding Point.

name: Mufu, Wood Wife (T 66.02)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 0.3 cun lateral to the center of the dorsal middle phalange of the 2nd toe. | Johnson: Wood Wife is located on the dorsum of the foot, 0.3 cun lateral to the center of the middle phalanx of the second toe.
primary_indications: especially red or white vaginal discharge Amenorrhea
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.4 cun along the bone. | Johnson: Needle on the right side: This point may be needled bilaterally or unilaterally on either side. I often use the right side only, because the point is painful and the right side of the body relates to females and blood. Point is sensitive to needle: Wood Wife is second only to 66.01 Seal in sensitivity. Hold the patient’s second toe, placing your finger behind the plantar surface so that you may perceive the advancing needle tip before it contacts the plantar epidermis. Quickly insert a thin-gauge needle from the dorsal surface, and slide the needle shaft down the lateral side of the middle phalanx. Apply strong stimulation for eight to ten seconds before retaining the needle for the duration of the treatment. Needle type: 0.16 x 15mm needle (Japanese gauge 1, Chinese gauge 40). Depth: 0.2-0.4 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Wood Wife is located on the Stomach meridian and acts as ST44 Nei Ting (also known as “Inner Courtyard,” implying the uterus); both of them clear damp heat, adjust the qi and blood, calm the spirit and quiet the womb. In the point name, the word ‘wood’ indicates a relationship to Liver. Wood Wife treats wood attacking earth (Liver and Spleen disharmony) as well as damp heat in the Liver and Gallbladder. Gynecological indications: Wood Wife is usually combined with 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points. Because Wood Wife is sensitive, I only use it when the situation includes vaginal discharge or irritation. Patients with interstitial cystitis or vulvadynia will remember this point and adamantly request it, especially premenstrually, because it provides immediate relief. Interstitial cystitis (IC): This problem is becoming far more prevalent in modern society as women find themselves overcommitted, overwhelmed, angry and resentful. I frequently use Wood Wife to treat burning urine and interstitial cystitis due to anger; however, there are also many other components in the treatment of interstitial cystitis: KHT bleeding: The most effective treatment I have found for interstitial cystitis is slightly painful, but patients find it well worth the temporary discomfort. This Koryo Hand Therapy (KHT) treatment is the bilateral bleeding of the lower A-line (midline) on the palm. In KHT, the central line from the middle finger to PC7 Da Ling is considered the Conception Vessel. Using a spring-loaded lancet, begin puncturing about 1.3 cm distal to PC7 Da Ling, and make approximately five punctures close together (within 1 cm) on the midline. Then, lateral to the midline on each side, make an additional line of four punctures that are spaced in between the points of the midline. Puncture all of the points on both hands quickly, then squeeze each hand and swipe off the beads of blood. This way, the patient does not anticipate the puncturing of the second hand while you swipe the first hand. Needle treatment: Needle left side 11.17 Wood (Anger), unilaterally needle 66.02 Wood Wife; bilaterally needle 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water, 77.18-77.21 Two or Three Emperors, LV3/LI4 Four Gates; deep needle REN3 Zhong Ji or REN4 Guan Yuan (50mm needle). I may add the Prefrontal Scalp Points if the patient has trouble sleeping, is depressed or has a lot of anxiety. This represents more acupuncture needles than are usually used in a single treatment, but IC is a complicated condition and I have found it responds well to the treatment described here. Dietary triggers: Diet is an important component in the treatment of interstitial cystitis. Chemicals of any kind must be strictly avoided, as must any inflammatory foods and beverages, such as caffeine, alcohol, spicy food, and processed sugar. If the patient is aware of triggers produced by grains or dairy, those too must be removed from the diet. I have had many good results in the treatment of IC, but not without strict dietary compliance. Blocked fallopian tube: Sticky phlegm is a common cause of infertility due to blocked fallopian tubes. If a tube is blocked, the qi is blocked. Choose this point to free the blockage, harmonizing Liver and Spleen. Controlling Liver fire: “For premenstrual or menopausal women, the practitioner should primarily treat the Liver. Women with hormonal imbalances may have a tendency toward anger, worry and frustration. These emotions can generate Liver fire, inflaming the Heart. 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors with Wood Wife is a good combination to soften the Liver and nourish water in order to control fire” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Cervical dysplasia: 66.02 Wood Wife, 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 77.27 Outer Three Gates. Infertility due to blocked fallopian tube: 66.02 Wood Wife, 11.06 Return to the Nest,

name: Huoying, Fire Hardness (T 66.03)
location: This point overlaps with Xingjian (LR 2) , which is between the 1st and 2nd toes, proximal to the margin of the web at the junction of the red and white skin. | Johnson: Fire Hardness is located on the dorsum of the foot, immediately proximal to the distal heads of the first and second metatarsal bones. This point is needled in the valley of the Liver meridian, approximately 0.5-1.0 cun proximal to the web between the toes.  Cautions: Forbidden to needle during pregnancy.
primary_indications: Myocardial infarction (emergency point for syncope) Chin pain
secondary_indications: inflammation of the uterus Knee swelling Eye pain Dysuria
johnson_indications: Dizziness due to high or low blood pressure*
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. Visible veins near this point can be bled. Bleeding this point can be helpful for knee swelling, eye pain, and dysuria. | Johnson: Downsize needle gauge: Try to avoid the visible blood vessels in this area when needling this point. Because an artery is located beneath the point, I use a very thin needle (#1 Japanese gauge, Chinese 40 gauge). It is nearly impossible to avoid the blood vessel, so a finer gauge needle is preferable. I have treated patients who have forbidden me to needle this point because they experienced trauma when other practitioners needled it. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Fire Hardness is the fire point on a wood meridian; it tonifies fire and strengthens the Heart. As the Ying-Spring point, it clears heat to address conditions such as urethra infection and uterine inflammation. Fire Hardness is used as an emergency point for the heart due to its proximity to the Tai Chong artery (first dorsal metatarsal artery), the Jue Yin connection (LV/PC), and the fact that blood vessel treats blood vessel. It opens the jaw to treat conditions such as TMJ because wood governs the tendons. Fire Hardness treats dizziness because Liver controls wind. For all of the above reasons, it is especially effective when used to treat fainting or coma. 19 Textbook LV2: In the list of indications, please note those designated with an asterisk (*). These indications are included because they are associated with Textbook LV2 and are also relevant to 66.03 Fire Hardness (Tung’s LV2). Treating a slow heart rate (Dr. Lee): “One usually drains the Liver, but when the pulse is too slow one must supplement the Liver instead. Liver is the mother of the Heart, supplementing the Liver nourishes its child, the Heart. Fire Hardness is quite useful. Fire in its name indicates the Heart. Heart palpitations can either be fast or slow. Fire Hardness treats slow palpitations. A slow pulse indicates the heart does not have enough strength to pump. Therefore, supplement this point to nourish the Heart. One can also supplement this point to treat unconsciousness with a slow pulse. Elderly people who move slow, have slow responses, look old beyond their years, and have a pulse that beats less than three times per respiratory cycle may die within two years if left untreated. Even if a person’s pulse is slow because of athletic training, this is not so good. Although people say this is good, it is well known that athletes do not tend to be long-lived. This is because when the heart beats too slowly it is easy for other problems to develop. Such a slow heartbeat signifies that the heart is weak” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Urogenital indications: Fire Hardness treats urinary pain as well as gynecological problems including fibroids and tumors, because the Liver channel travels through the groin and reproductive area. Urinary bladder infections: In my clinic, I have found that most women with bladder infections have been extremely angry in the 24 hours preceding onset. The rising Liver fire hits the Heart, transferring the heat to the Small Intestine and thereby the Urinary Bladder. Because I so frequently see this connection, my first question to a woman with a bladder infection is, “Did you recently get really angry?” Ten times out of ten, the answer is, “Yes!” 66.03 Fire Hardness (Tung’s LV2) is an important point to treat this condition because it is the Ying-Spring and fire point on the Liver meridian which flows through the genitals, and thus it clears heat. Void after sex: I always advise patients to urinate after sex in order to flush bacteria from their urethra. This simple practice can stop many infections from taking hold. Opposite-side foot pain: If a patient has pain on the dorsum of the foot, Fire Hardness and/or 66.04 Fire Master can be needled on the opposite foot to treat the pain. I have found it helpful to oil and rub (Gua Sha) the painful area using a porcelain soup spoon or using my finger if the area is bony. If both sides are equally painful, treat them consecutively, not simultaneously. Anxiety and insomnia: Long ago, Dr. Young taught me to use a “fire” type of Four Gates, with 22.04 Da Bai and 66.03 Fire Hardness (also known as Anxiety Four Gates). To these points I may add the Prefrontal Scalp Points for anxiety and insomnia.
combinations: Most of the following combinations utilize the Dao Ma of 66.03 Fire Hardness and 66.04 Fire Master. Because Fire Hardness is a powerful point either alone or in combination, this section includes all of the combinations that utilize both 66.03 and 66.04. Fire Master includes additional combinations. However, the first three combinations shown below are more specific to Fire Hardness due to its Ying-Spring ability to clear heat. •  Anxiety and insomnia: Bilaterally needle 22.04 Da Bai and 66.03 Fire Hardness (Anxiety Four Gates); optionally, add Prefrontal Scalp Points. •  Urinary pain, uremia or urinary tract infection: Bilaterally needle, choosing one or more of the following points: 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master, 22.05 Ling Gu, 11.03 Floating Distance, 11.04 External Distance, 44.11 Cloud White, 44.12 Plum White. •  Vaginitis: Unilaterally needle: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 44.11 Cloud White, 66.02 Wood Wife, bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master.•  Jaw pain: To open the jaw for a patient with TMJ or jaw pain, bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master; if there is also clenching, consider KD1 Yong Quan, 55.06 Upper Tumor and the extra point 1.0 cun distal. •  If the pain is arthritic, ST41 Jie Xi is especially useful (ST41 is also used to clear Stomach heat in cases of bruxism). •  Other point options include: SJ5 Wai Guan or SJ6 Zhi Gou, GB34 Yang Ling Quan, PC5 Jian Shi. •  Bleeding options include 99.08 Ear Apex, veins in the vicinity of Tai Yang, and 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5). Dizziness (due to high blood pressure): Bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, LI11 Qu Chi and/or 22.05 Ling Gu; bleed DT.04 Five Mountain Range and/or the fingertips to radically drop the blood pressure (if needed).•  Hypertension (systolic relates to Heart, diastolic relates to Kidney): Bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, LI11 Qu Chi and/or LI4 He Gu. •  Other point options include: bilaterally needle UB65 Shu Gu, GB34 Yang Ling Quan, Jian Gu (a wood point between LI3 and LI4), PC6 Nei Guan, 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36), SP9 Yin Ling Quan, 22.06 Middle White (Tung’s SJ3), SJ5 Wai Guan. •  To radically drop the blood pressure, good bleeding options include: DT.04 Five Mountain Range, 99.07 Ear Back, and the fingertips (if needed); veins found in the vicinity of 77.09 Four Flower Middle and 77.14 Four Flower Outer (Tung’s ST40) are also effective and easily bled. Irregular heart rate: Unilaterally needle 11.05 Middle Distance or 11.19 Heart Normal; bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master; needling PC6 Nei Guan is also effective.•  Myocarditis: Bilaterally needle 33.12 Heart Gate, PC6 Nei Guan, 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36), 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master, bleed 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line and/or 99.08 Ear Apex.•  Top of the foot pain: Needle opposite-side 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master, apply Gua Sha to the affected side. See 66.04 Fire Master for additional commentary.

name: Huozhu, Fire Master (T 66.04)
location: This point overlaps with Taichong (LR 3) , which is on the dorsum of the foot in the depression distal to the junction of the 1st and 2nd metatarsal bones. | Johnson: Fire Master is located on the dorsum of the foot, just distal to the proximal junction of the first and second metatarsal bones, directly over the first dorsal metatarsal artery. Cautions: Forbidden to needle during pregnancy.
primary_indications: heart disease leading to headache Liver or gastrointestinal diseases Neurasthenia Pain and numbness of the hands and feet Gynecological disorders: Inflammation or tumors of the uterus
secondary_indications: facial paralysis Swollen bones Extreme fatigue Non-infectious urinary pain
johnson_indications: Heart numbness and paralysis (slow or irregular heart rate)
Dizziness due to high or low blood pressure*
Finger or hand pain or numbness
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.8 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. Visible veins near this point can be bled. | Johnson: Downsize needle gauge: Try to avoid visible blood vessels when needling this point. Due to the artery located beneath the point, I use a very thin needle (#1 Japanese gauge, Chinese 40 gauge). It is nearly impossible to avoid the blood vessel, so a finer gauge needle is preferable. I’ve treated patients who have forbidden me to needle this point because they experienced trauma when other practitioners needled it. Needle close to the junctions of the metatarsal bones to enhance the bone-treating- bone, Kidney tonification function. Depth: 0.5-1.5 cun
comments: Overview: Tung’s LV3, 66.04 Fire Master is located in the depression just proximal to textbook LV3 Tai Chong. As an earth point on a wood channel needled close to the bone (Kidney), Fire Master tonifies Liver (wood), Spleen (earth) and Kidney (water), thus treating wind, damp and cold, and making it a very good point for tendons, muscles and joints. These influences also make this point useful for digestive 219 Foot and Ankle Points disorders, including nausea, vomiting or nervous stomach. It is an excellent choice in any situation when wood and earth are not harmonious. Because of Fire Master’s distal location over a primary artery and its relationship to the blood vessels and tendons, it is the best Guiding Point for knee and groin issues. It is often needled as the Chief Point with 66.03 Fire Hardness for emergencies. Fire Master strengthens the heart via the Liver/Pericardium/Heart connection. It shares the textbook TCM functions of LV3; thus, it also clears Liver fire and subdues yang; disperses wind; calms Liver qi and moves stagnation; nourishes Liver yin and blood; clears the head and eyes; drains damp heat of the Liver and Gallbladder; and regulates menstruation. Energetic pathways (Wood tonifies fire): Fire Master tonifies the mother to build the child. Whether we are tonifying the Heart using the Liver, or sedating a Heart excess using the Stomach meridian, we never use points found on the Heart meridian. My teacher, Dr. Lee, described the Heart as a balloon that could be burst with a needle if Heart meridian points were used. (See 55.01 Fire Bag for additional commentary.) Instead, using Tung’s acupuncture, we choose points on either the Jue Yin (PC/LV) channel or the Yang Ming (ST) channel. Worthy of note, Master Tung assigned the Reaction Area of the Heart to both 66.03 Fire Hardness and 66.04 Fire Master. Dr. Lee’s commentary: “One usually drains the Liver, but when the pulse is too slow one must supplement the Liver instead. Liver is the mother of the Heart, supplementing the Liver nourishes its child, the Heart” (Dr. Lee, 1992). See 66.03 Fire Hardness for additional commentary. Blood vessel treating blood vessel: Because both Fire Hardness and Fire Master are over the LV3 Tai Chong artery, they can be used for resuscitation, coma, and other emergency heart situations, such as heart muscle spasm or spasm of the coronary vessels. They are also chosen for heart numbness (uneasiness in the chest), which often occurs during the menstrual period of a patient who has deficiency cold with a slow, unsteady, irregular or skipping heartbeat. The Liver and Pericardium, both Jue Yin, have a very powerful influence on the blood. In classical TCM it is said that the Liver governs and stores the blood, while the Pericardium imprints the emotions on the blood22. For these reasons, the Pericardium efficiently treats both deficient and excess heart-related conditions that are either physical or psychological. Energetic pathways (fire and earth): In Tung’s acupuncture, the Foot Yang Ming (ST) and Hand Jue Yin (PC) share a special relationship that is useful in the treatment of excess heart-related issues. One of the most significant Tung’s point patterns utilizing this relationship is 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle for angina or heart attack. Two other examples of this relationship are 55.01 Fire Bag for heart attack and PC6 with ST36 (Old Doctors’ Two Old Needles) to treat coronary heart disease. Energetic pathways (wood/wind): Fire Master treats headaches, hypertension, dizziness, epilepsy, or nosebleeds related to excess Liver disease. It is the earth point on a wood channel, capable of subduing endogenous wind and hyperactivity of the liver, extinguishing draft and calming spasm.
combinations: Jaw pain: To open the jaw for a patient with TMJ or jaw pain, bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master; if there is also clenching, consider KD1 Yong Quan, 55.06 Upper Tumor and the extra point 1.0 cun distal. See Comments above for extensive commentary related to anger, TMJ and migraines.•  If the pain is arthritic, ST41 Jie Xi is especially useful. (ST41 is also used to clear Stomach heat in cases of bruxism.) •  Other point options include: SJ5 Wai Guan or SJ6 Zhi Gou, GB34 Yang Ling Quan, PC5 Jian Shi. •  Bleeding options include 99.08 Ear Apex, veins in the vicinity of Tai Yang, and 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5).•  Dry mouth with sore throat (chronic): Needle 88.09 Passing Kidney; 66.04 Fire Master (or Four Gates), 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors or 66.14 Water Phase.•  Irregular heart rate: Unilaterally needle 11.05 Middle Distance or 11.19 Heart Normal; bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master; needling PC6 Nei Guan is also effective.•  Myocarditis: Bilaterally needle 33.12 Heart Gate, PC6 Nei Guan, 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36), 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master, bleed 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line and/or 99.08 Ear Apex.•  Slow heart rate: Bilaterally needle, choosing from the following points: 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master, 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points, PC6 Nei Guan, A.03 Three Jam Two.Groin pain: Needle opposite-side 22.05 Ling Gu or 33.12 Heart Gate, needle same-side 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master as a Guiding Point. •  Knee pain (especially kneecap): Needle opposite-side PC6 Nei Guan, needle same-side 66.04 Fire Master as a Guiding Point.•  Anxiety and insomnia: Bilaterally needle 22.05 Ling Gu and 66.04 Fire Master (Tung’s Four Gates), optionally add 11.17 Wood (Anger) and/or Prefrontal Scalp Points. •  Dizziness (due to high blood pressure): Bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04Fire Master, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, LI11 Qu Chi and/or 22.05 Ling Gu; bleed DT.04 Five Mountain Range and/or the fingertips to radically drop the blood pressure(if needed).•  Hypertension (systolic relates to Heart, diastolic relates to Kidney): Bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, LI11 Qu Chi and/or LI4 He Gu. •  Other point options include: bilaterally needle UB65 Shu Gu, GB34 Yang Ling Quan, Jian Gu (a wood point between LI3 and LI4), PC6 Nei Guan, 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36), SP9 Yin Ling Quan, 22.06 Middle White (Tung’s SJ3), SJ5 Wai Guan. •  To radically drop the blood pressure, good bleeding options include: DT.04 Five Mountain Range, 99.07 Ear Back, and the fingertips (if needed); veins found in the vicinity of 77.09 Four Flower Middle and 77.14 Four Flower Outer (Tung’s ST40) are also effective and easily bled. •  Menopausal symptoms: Unilaterally needle 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors, LI4/LV3 Four Gates or Anxiety Four Gates (22.04 Da Bai with 66.03 Fire Hardness). •  Vaginitis: Unilaterally needle 66.02 Wood Wife, 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 44.11 Cloud White; bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master.•  Uterine tumors or inflammation: Bilaterally needle 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master.•  Urinary pain, uremia or urinary tract infection: Unilaterally needle left side 11.17 Wood (Anger), bilaterally needle from the following points: 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master, 22.05 Ling Gu, 11.03 Floating Distance, 11.04 External Distance, 44.11 Cloud White, 44.12 Plum White. •  Interstitial cystitis: See 66.02 Wood Wife, Comments.•  Hand and foot pain: 66.04 Fire Master, 22.05 Ling Gu. •  Top of the foot pain: Needle opposite-side 66.03 Fire Hardness or 66.04 Fire Master; apply Gua Sha to same side. (See Comments above.)

name: Menjin, Golden Gate (T 66.05)
location: This point overlaps with Xiangu (ST 43) , which is in the depression distal to the junction of the 2nd and 3rd metatarsal bones. | Johnson: Golden Gate, Master Tung’s version of ST43 Xian Gu, is located proximal to the TCM location. This point on the dorsum of the foot is just distal to the proximal junction of the second and third metatarsals. It is located similarly to 66.04 Fire Master, moving laterally one metatarsal Do not needle bilaterally.
primary_indications: peritonitis Lower abdominal pain before or after menstruation
secondary_indications: headaches Inflammation of the uterus and ovaries
johnson_indications: Pain at side of the head near Tai Yang (Extra Point)
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Needle towards or penetrate through to Yongquan (KI 1) to treat vertex headaches. This point can also be bled. Bleeding this point is more effective than needling when treating migraines.
comments: Energetic pathways: As the wood point of the Stomach meridian, 66.05 Golden Gate harmonizes wood within the earth, soothes the Liver, releases the Spleen, and regulates Liver, Spleen and Stomach. Needled close to the bone, Golden Gate also activates the Kidney. When the word “Gold” appears in the name of a point, it refers to metal and therefore Lung and Large Intestine. In this case, it refers to both; there is an internal/external relationship between the Lung and Large Intestine here, as well as a connection between the Hand and Foot Yang Ming channels (LI/ST), which lend the function of profoundly tonifying earth to build metal. •  Diagnostics: When needled correctly, this point can serve a diagnostic purpose: if opposite-side abdominal pain does not lessen immediately upon insertion, the origin of the pain is likely reproductive or urinary.•  Abdominal pain: Food stagnation creates a lot of accumulated gas and therefore discomfort. Via palpation, we can assess the severity and location of the condition. Holding one hand on top of the other, palpate the patient’s entire abdomen with the flat surface of your fingers to gently ascertain painful pockets of gas, inflammation, adhesions or scar tissue. Do not palpate by touching your skin to theirs, as this causes unnecessary stimulation. Everything you need to learn can be felt through clothing or a thin blanket. Palpation is impossible over a belt or buckle. Patients with abdominal distension, gas or bloating usually experience pain bilaterally, though one side may be worse. If this is the case, I start by treating the least painful side first, needling ST43 on the opposite side using a thumb-back sedation technique (see below). I can relieve discomfort within thirty seconds – more quickly than I can return to check the belly again. •  Thumb-back sedation technique: In order to sedate on the Stomach channel, use your right hand to needle the patient’s left foot, or your left hand to needle the patient’s right foot. Gripping the needle firmly with qi, rotate it by pulling your thumb backward, then gently roll the needle forward and firmly pull back again with qi, six times in total. •  Note: You must learn to use both hands to successfully apply tonification or sedation needle techniques, because the energy of the body is flowing out, around, and back up. It is easy to imagine this flow of energy when using the analogy of an apple cut on a vertical plane. Once you have mastered the technique, it will become second nature to you. Sedating on the Stomach channel is the same as on the Gallbladder and Urinary Bladder channels; moving thumb forward on these three channels will tonify. Most acupuncture points in Tung’s system are needled with strong stimulation and a neutral needle rotation.•  Recheck the abdomen: After applying the thumb-back sedation technique, I re-check the abdomen on the side opposite the needle. Upon palpation, if the sensitivity is less than eighty percent better, I sedate again in the same manner. •  Switch to the other side: When the abdominal sensitivity has improved more than eighty percent, I remove the needle, then needle Golden Gate on the opposite foot. Switching hands, I repeat the thumb-back sedation technique on the side opposite the worst abdominal pain. •  Note: It is very important to keep your eyes on the patient’s eyes during the process of needle rotation, because the tip of the needle is likely to catch a small muscle fiber and twist it, causing severe pain. Watching the patient’s eyes, you will spot their involuntary blink as a response to the pain; at this point, stop and minutely traction up or down (raising or inserting the needle tip the tiniest amount), and then begin rotating the needle again before the patient can say, “Ouch.” Though this method of sedation sounds complicated, it is actually quite simple and has a profound effect. If you were to tonify (thumb forward), the patient’s abdominal pain would increase. •  Adding additional needles: After clearing both sides of the abdomen using unilateral needling of Golden Gate, retain the last needle for the duration of the treatment and add 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) and antique PC6 Nei Guan (3.0 cun above the wrist crease). This simple treatment is by far my favorite way to address even the most stubborn cases of IBS or Crohn’s disease, not to mention indigestion, diarrhea, gas or bloating.•  Paralytic colon: The treatment outlined above can be used when bowel sounds are not forthcoming after surgery. When the intestine does not “wake up” after anesthesia,residual toxins in the intestine begin to be reabsorbed into the bloodstream, causing severe nausea and dry heaves. Because the patient has not eaten since the night before surgery, there is nothing to vomit. To relieve nausea immediately, bleed 1010.07 All Pivot (Tung’s DU16). It is usually adequate to release a small amount of blood, but the blood must be squeezed out from the puncture site. After thirty to sixty seconds, the patient usually reports their stomach dropping or relaxing. (See 1010.07 All Pivot for further information.) Continue squeezing and swiping for at least ten drops beyond the relaxing of the stomach. Then needle Golden Gate, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) and antique PC6 Nei Guan (3.0 cun above the wrist crease). Usually within a few hours of this treatment, bowel sounds are heard and the patient can go home.•  Bowel diseases: To treat indigestion, diarrhea, gas or bloating, I most commonly use Golden Gate in the combination shown above. However, Golden Gate is capable of much more. It has been my primary treatment in cases with adhesions and chronic post-surgical pain from resected bowels due to Crohn’s disease. Chronic diseases always imply Kidney weakness, and Golden Gate needled close to the bone (proximal to Textbook ST43, higher up on the dorsum of the foot) is very useful in treating cock’s crow diarrhea, which is always due to Kidney yang deficiency. In combination with SP4 and PC6, it is highly effective for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and chronic food allergies, although the allergen must also be removed from the diet. These cases often involve a toxic headache, which also responds to the needling of Golden Gate.•  Pineapple heals intestines: I remember Dr. Lee giving nearly every patient with intestinal disorders instructions to eat two small cans of pineapple every day for at least three months. She said pineapple could even heal colon cancer, and that it would clean out (even scrub) pockets of debris within the intestines. After five to ten days of eating pineapple, patients may see black material mixed in with their stool, indicating old fecal matter is being expelled. •  Caution: If you palpate any kind of abdominal mass that you cannot identify, do not hesitate to refer the patient to their Western doctor.•  Migraine headache: Golden Gate is a wood Shu-Stream point on an earth channel (wind and damp), making it perfect for harmonizing Liver and Spleen (wood attacking earth). For this reason, it is frequently used for migraine headache in the Tai Yang (Extra Point) area, menstrual cramping, irritability or TMJ when these are related to Liver qi stagnation. If the headache is cyclic, implying hormonal imbalance, I am likely to add 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.06 Return to the Nest, and 11.24 Gynecological Points. As a Shu-Point, Golden Gate is good for TMJ and joint pain, but if the headache is related to tight tendons in the neck, I am likely to use 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles, adding Golden Gate if there is nausea and vomiting. For a patient with chronic migraines, I usually cup the neck and shoulders to open blood flow through the neck and head. These cup marks are always black or extremely dark. Be sure to include the area directly behind the ear (SJ17). •  Tai Yang area bleeding for migraine: In a bleeding class I taught, a student with constant, chronic migraines volunteered for a demonstration of Tai Yang (Extra Point) area bleeding. Because more than one person in the class wanted the experience of having Tai Yang bled, I bled only the right side on this particular volunteer. Six weeks later, he emailed that he hadn’t had a headache since the treatment. Bleeding any available vein in the vicinity of Tai Yang (Extra Point) often resolves chronic migraines with one treatment. Be sure the vessel you are bleeding does not have a pulse; find the artery easily located in the temple area and avoid it.•  Case history (migraine, Dr. Lee): “An eleven-year-old girl was brought by her mother to my office. She left school with an intense migraine headache. The child was crying very badly due to the pain. I put her on the treatment bed and needled this point. She dried her eyes and said that her pain was gone. Then she looked down at her foot and saw the needle. While the pain was bad, she did not even feel or know anything about the needle. But when the pain was gone, seeing the needle she became frightened and began to cry again. I asked her if she would rather have her headache. The little girl smiled and asked her mother if she could return to the party they were having at school. This little girl was pubescent and the headache was associated with the changes initiated by puberty. This point can provide great relief for such cases. It can stop the nausea, vomiting, and headaches. Only one needle, easy to use. I use this point a great deal” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Dao Ma: Dr. Young recommends combining Golden Gate with ST44 Nei Ting as a Dao Ma to make Golden Gate even more effective (Dr. Young, 2008). •  Nasal congestion: Though I never use Golden Gate specifically for sinusitis, it is useful when food allergies cause nasal obstruction. If I am treating a patient for some kind of intestinal distress and their sinuses clear, it may be related to this point. Tung’s system has many options for treating congested sinuses; my favorite is LI20 Welcome Fragrance, superficially needled toward Yin Tang (for needling instruction, see 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance). However, because Golden Gate relates to metal, and metal relates to Lung and Large Intestine, this point can open the nose and resolve blocked sinuses.
combinations: IBS, Crohn’s disease, colitis, abdominal pain, indigestion, burping, gas and bloating: 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4), PC6 Nei Guan.•  Cock’s crow diarrhea: 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), 66.12 Fire Scatter (Tung’s KD2), UB60 Kun Lun, LI11 Qu Chi, 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan). •  Severe diarrhea: 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), 33.10 Intestine Gate, LI11 Qu Chi, 77.11-77.12 Four Flower Lower/Bowel Intestine. Intestinal bleeding: 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), LU6 Kong Zui, 88.04-88.05 Three Sisters (One and Two), bleed 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line (Stomach channel).•  Eyelids heavy or unable to open: Bilaterally needle A.04 San Cha Three, unilaterally needle 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43).•  Menstrual cramping: 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), ST44 Nei Ting. •  Rectal prolapse: 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), ST44 Nei Ting. •  Menstrual-related headaches: For headaches that are cyclical, implying hormonal imbalance, needle 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points and 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43). See Comments above.•  Chronic migraines or Tai Yang (Extra Point) area headaches: Cup the neck and shoulders to open blood flow through the neck and head. These cup marks are always black or extremely dark. Be sure to include the area directly behind the ear (SJ17) and bleed the Tai Yang area. See Comments above.

name: Muliu, Wood Keep (T 66.06)
location: This point is on the dorsum of the foot, 2 cun proximal to the web margin between the 3rd and 4th toes. | Johnson: 66.06 Wood Keep is located on the dorsum of the foot, just distal to the proximal heads of the third and fourth metatarsals. 66.07 Wood Scoop is located on the dorsum of the foot, just proximal to the distal heads of the third and fourth metatarsals, 1.0 cun distal to Wood Keep.
secondary_indications: infantile paralysis Middle finger or ring finger pain or stiffness Pain
tumor in the clavicle and shoulder area TMJ
johnson_indications: Middle or ring finger pain or locking*
Neuroma (between the third and fourth metatarsal bones)*
Blood diseases: leucopenia, anemia, leukemia, platelet problems
Stiff neck and upper back pain
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 1 cun . | Johnson: Palpation: Palpate carefully to determine the location of the bones, trying to avoid any obvious blood vessels when you needle these points. Unilateral vs. bilateral needling: To treat pain and structural issues, needle the side opposite the indications. For all other indications, needle bilaterally. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Some sources claim the Liver meridian has a branch to the middle toe; for that pathway, Wood Keep would be the Ying-Spring point and Wood Scoop would be the Shu-Stream point. These points treat diseases related to qi, blood, muscles and tendons because the Stomach channel is full of qi and blood, the Liver stores the blood and governs tendons, and the Spleen controls blood and governs qi and muscles (Dr. Young, 2008). I relate these points to a Gallbladder channel collateral pathway and always needle Wood Keep and Wood Scoop together, as a Dao Ma, to regulate qi and blood. They are located between the Stomach and Gallbladder meridians (earth and wood); therefore, they treat Spleen and Liver disharmony and associated diseases. Because of the connection to the Foot Shao Yang (GB) channel, indications like trigeminal neuralgia, earache, and stiff neck can be treated. Trigger finger: My favorite use of these points is in the treatment of opposite-side pain or trigger finger affecting the middle or ring finger (Pericardium). Jue Yin (PC/LV) treats tendons and ligaments, and it can be reached through the special relationship between the Hand Jue Yin (PC) and Foot Yang Ming (ST), the Gallbladder/Liver internal/external connection, and the shared meridian pathway of the Liver/ Pericardium. The neck and shoulders can also be treated through all of the above connections. Neuroma: These are also my favorite points for treating opposite-side neuromas. I have found that neuromas do not like to be disturbed with needles, Tui Na massage, moxa or bleeding. Local treatment always has negative results, but opposite-side needling is safe and effective. When neuromas form, they are always in this space between the third and fourth metatarsals and rarely on both sides of the body. Blood diseases: Wood Keep and Wood Scoop build blood and may be used to treat any kind of leukemia (Heart/Spleen/Liver), anemia, and clotting disorders (both excess and deficient). However, they may be most effective in the treatment of leucopenia. For blood diseases, always treat the Liver and Spleen; it is also important to consider 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows and 77.05-77.07 Three Weights. In my experience, both of these combinations are more powerful than Wood Keep/Wood Scoop. Numbness: Wood Keep and Wood Scoop are needled bilaterally for blood diseases or numbness of the whole body because they adjust both qi and blood.
combinations: Breast cancer: 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/Wood Scoop, 88.17-88.19 Four Horses (bleed). Ear pain: 66.06 Wood Keep, 77.07 Third Weight. Stiff tongue and difficulty speaking: 66.06 Wood Keep, 77.07 Third Weight. Trigeminal neuralgia: 66.06 Wood Keep, 77.07 Third Weight. Trigger finger: Needle opposite-side 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/Wood Scoop for opposite-side pain or trigger finger affecting the middle or ring finger (Pericardium meridian). Neuroma: Needle opposite-side 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/Wood Scoop. I have found that neuromas do not like to be disturbed with needles, Tui Na massage, moxa or bleeding. Local treatment always has negative results, but opposite-side needling is safe and effective. When neuromas form, they are always in this space between the third and fourth metatarsals and rarely on both sides of the body. Numbness: Bilaterally needle 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/Wood Scoop for blood diseases or numbness of the whole body.

name: Mudou, Wood Scoop (T 66.07)
location: This point is on the dorsum of the foot, 0.5 cun proximal to the web margin between the 3rd and 4th toes. | Johnson: 66.06 Wood Keep is located on the dorsum of the foot, just distal to the proximal heads of the third and fourth metatarsals. 66.07 Wood Scoop is located on the dorsum of the foot, just proximal to the distal heads of the third and fourth metatarsals, 1.0 cun distal to Wood Keep.
primary_indications: Splenomegaly with palpable mass Hepatic disorders
johnson_indications: Middle or ring finger pain or lockin*
Neuroma (between the third andfourth metatarsal bones*
Blood diseases: leucopenia, anemia, leukemia, platelet problems
Stiff neck and upper back pain
