name: Liuwan, Sixth Finish (T 66.08)
location: This point overlaps with Xiaxi (GB 43) , which is between the 4th and 5th metatarsal bones, 0.5 cun proximal to the web margin. Some books state this point is 0.5 cun proximal to Xiaxi (GB 43) . | Johnson: Sixth Finish is located on the dorsum of the foot, between the fourth and fifth metatarsal bones, 0.5 cun proximal to the metatarsal and phalangeal joints.
primary_indications: Migraines Bleeding due to trauma: injuries
johnson_indications: Excessive bleeding due to external trauma (including tooth extraction)
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 0.3 – 0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Though this point is not located on the web of the foot, it is still acting as GB43 Xia Xi, a water point on a wood channel. It tonifies water, moistens wood, strengthens the Liver and Kidney, and clears damp heat from the Gallbladder channel. Uterine bleeding: In the treatment of avalanche bleeding (functional uterine bleeding), I have found that moxa on LV1 Da Dun and SP1 Yin Bai is far more effective. (See 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters for further information.)
reaction_areas: Kidney, Lung Cautions: • This point is astringing and will stop bleeding. However, because of its astringent nature, it is contraindicated for patients with asthma, cough, lung disease, excessive phlegm, and weakness, as it may worsen their condition (Dr. Young, 2008).

name: Shuiqu, Water Curve (T 66.09)
location: This point overlaps with Zulinqi (GB 41) , which is between the 4th and 5th metatarsal bones, 1.5 cun proximal to the web margin, in the depression lateral to the tendon of the m. extensor digiti minimi of the foot. | Johnson: Water Curve is located on the dorsum of the foot, between the fourth and fifth metatarsal bones, just distal to the proximal junction of the bones (lateral to the tendon). This is the same location as GB41 Ling Qi.
primary_indications: swelling of the limbs from poor kidney function Tinnitus
secondary_indications: dai (girdle) channel waist pain Weight loss Abdominal distension
johnson_indications: Hand and wrist weakness or pain
Whole-body joint and bone pain or numbness
Tendon and muscle tension in the lower legs
Pain in the back of the knee
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Water Curve is located at Textbook GB41 Ling Qi, and it is the Master Point of the Dai Mai (belt vessel). In TCM, it is said to move Liver qi and benefit the eyes and breasts, and it is frequently used for foot pain. As a Shu-Stream point, it treats heavy and aching joints, even nerve pain; for this reason, I use it most as a Guiding Point on the affected side when treating Gallbladder channel sciatica. As a wood point on a wood channel, needled alongside the bone and lateral to the tendon, it tonifies Liver and Kidney, eliminates wind and relaxes tight tendons and muscles. Because Shao Yang controls bones, when this point is needled alongside the bone it can be used to treat wind- and damp-related bone diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and pain in the joints and bones of the whole body (bone-treating-bone function). With the Reaction Areas of both Lung and Kidney, this point has the word “Water” in its name, indicating a relationship to dispersing fluids as well as a further connection to the Kidney, more specifically to poor kidney function resulting in damp conditions such as edema, obesity, abdominal distension, lower back pain, and gynecological issues. Dai Mai: Because Water Curve is the Master Point of the Dai Mai, when we use it in conjunction with SJ5 Wai Guan and/or A.04 San Cha Three, it can treat lower back, waist and leg pain. Obesity: Moxa can be used on Water Curve to treat life-threatening or extreme obesity; however, do not abuse it for ordinary weight loss.

name: Huolian, Fire Connection (T 66.10)
location: This point overlaps with Taibai (SP 3) . Some sources state this point is 0.5 cun proximal to Taibai (SP 3) . | Johnson: Fire Connection is located on the medial side of the foot, just proximal to the distal head of the first metatarsal bone, tucked into the curve. This is the same location as SP3 Tai Bai.
johnson_indications: Dizziness, blurred vision and vertigo due to hypertension
Mania with dizziness, nausea and vomiting
techniques: Perpendicular insertion 0.5 - 0.8 cun along the bone. | Johnson: Unilateral vs. bilateral needling: Master Tung taught that Fire Connection, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum and 66.12 Fire Scatter – individually or in combination – were to be needled only unilaterally. Dr. Young states that though it is preferable to use fewer needles, no side effects have been noted when these three points have been combined bilaterally (Dr. Young, 2008). In textbook TCM, each of these individual points can be needled bilaterally. Curving needle: Fire Connection should be located and needled very close to the bone, at the junction of the red and white skin on the medial side of the foot, with a curving needle technique for a deeper insertion. Use a guide tube to quickly penetrate the surface of this sensitive area. With the tip inserted, introduce a curve into the shaft of the needle by holding its handle up (toward the leg), and then guide the needle shaft to wrap closely beneath the metatarsal bones. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun.
comments: Energetic pathways: Fire Connection is located close to SP3 Tai Bai, but it is needled even closer to the bone so that it treats the Kidney as well as the Spleen and Heart. The point’s name indicates its ability to clear fire and strengthen the Heart. It is used in the treatment of palpitations and hypertension because it balances water and fire, restoring and stabilizing good communication between the Hand and Foot Shao Yin (HT/KD). Fire Connection is the best point for resolving dizziness caused by hypertension. Spleen weakness: Fire Connection is used to treat Spleen-deficient conditions such as tiredness and weakness in the extremities. It is also good for frontal headache and supraorbital pain from deficiency. (For supraorbital pain from excess, see 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle.) Brain tumor: Fire Connection, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum and 66.12 Fire Scatter all clear excess Fire. They can be needled together to treat conditions such as headache, brain tumor and meningitis. However, it is contraindicated to needle the three points on both feet at the same time. Pregnancy: Master Tung suggested that 66.10 Fire Connection, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum and 66.12 Fire Scatter were forbidden to needle during pregnancy; however, Dr. Young tells us to avoid only 66.12 Fire Scatter (Tung’s KD2). According to textbook TCM, SP3 Tai Bai, SP4 Gong Sun and KD2 Ran Gu are not contraindicated during pregnancy.

name: Huoju, Fire Chrysanthemum (T 66.11)
location: This point overlaps with Gongsun (SP 4) , which is located on the medial side of the foot, in the depression distal and inferior to the base of the first metatarsal bone. | Johnson: Fire Chrysanthemum is located on the medial side of the foot, just distal and inferior to the proximal head of the first metatarsal bone. This is Master Tung’s version of SP4 Gong Sun.
primary_indications: limited range of motion of the neck Numbness of the hand and fingers
secondary_indications: eye pain due to increased pressure in the eyes Post-stroke delirium
johnson_indications: Distended feeling in the head and brain
Numbness of the hands (due to cervical bone spur or hypertension)*
techniques: Perpendicular insertion 0.5 - 0.8 cun along the bone. This point can also be bled. Bleed dark veins nearby to invigorate qi and blood circulation, resuscitate the brain, and open the orifices. | Johnson: Curving needle: Gently walk your finger down the shaft of the first metatarsal bone toward the proximal head until you feel the bone begin to flare, then back off a little bit to place your needle in the identified curve. Needle this point very close to the bone, at the junction of the red and white skin on the medial side of the foot. Use a guide tube to penetrate the surface quickly, as this is a sensitive area. Insert the needle using a curving needle technique (holding the handle of the needle up in order to introduce a curve into the shaft), sliding the shaft closely beneath the first and second metatarsal bones. Once the needle has been inserted correctly, strong stimulation is not painful. Unilateral vs. bilateral needling: Master Tung taught that Fire Connection, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum and 66.12 Fire Scatter – individually or in combination – were to be needled only unilaterally. Dr. Young states that though it is preferable to use fewer needles, no side effects have been noted when these three points have been combined bilaterally (Dr. Young, 2008). In textbook TCM, each of these individual points can be needled bilaterally. Depth: 1.0-1.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Fire Chrysanthemum was one of Master Tung’s favorites to clear the head and eyes. Like its namesake herb, Ju Hua (Chrysanthemum), Fire Chrysanthemum clears heat in the head, improving vision. It is similar to SP4 Gong Sun but is needled even closer to the bone, lending a stronger Kidney tonification function. “Fire” in the point name indicates a relationship to the Heart. Fire Chrysanthemum regulates the Heart and Kidney (fire and water) to resolve excess fire. It is the Luo-Connecting point of the Spleen channel and the Master Point of the Chong Mai (Sea of Blood). Abdomen and chest: 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43) with Fire Chrysanthemum and PC6 Nei Guan25 is my favorite treatment for abdominal distension, gas and bloating, diarrhea, irritable bowel, and Crohn’s disease; this treatment utilizes the deeper Kidney points of the Chong Mai. To treat digestive or abdominal issues, first needle  I always needle the antique location of PC6 Nei Guan, found 3.0 cun proximal to the wrist crease. Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4) and then PC6 Nei Guan. When Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4) is treated first, the treatment is directed to the lower abdomen. PC6 Nei Guan sedates the Liver, treating Liver qi attacking the Stomach due to anger and anxiety. If I am treating anxiety-related chest pain, heaviness or palpitations, I first needle PC6 Nei Guan (Master Point of the Yin Wei Mai) and then Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4) in order to direct the treatment to the chest. Additionally, I usually add the Prefrontal Scalp Points. Paralytic colon: The treatment outlined above can be used when bowel sounds are not forthcoming after surgery. When the intestine does not “wake up” after anesthesia, residual toxins in the intestine begin to be reabsorbed into the bloodstream, causing severe nausea and dry heaves. Because the patient has not eaten since the night before surgery, there is nothing to vomit. To relieve nausea immediately, bleed 1010.07 All Pivot (Tung’s DU16). It is usually adequate to release a small amount of blood, but the blood must be squeezed out from the puncture site. After thirty to sixty seconds, the patient usually reports their stomach dropping or relaxing. Continue squeezing and swiping for at least ten drops beyond the relaxing of the stomach. Then needle Golden Gate, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) and antique PC6 Nei Guan (3.0 cun above the wrist crease). Usually within a few hours of this treatment, bowel sounds are heard and the patient can go home. See 1010.07 All Pivot for further information related to paralytic colon. Diagnostics: Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4) is very good for abdominal pain. If the pain goes away, it is a functional problem such as indigestion, gas, bloating, constipation, etc. If the pain comes back, it may be a serious gastrointestinal organ problem (cancer, perforated ulcer, bowel obstruction); in this case, the patient needs to see their Western medical physician, especially if you palpate any unidentifiable mass. Do not scare the patient unnecessarily; refer them to a physician without voicing your suspicions. Deficient frontal headache: When frontal headaches occur due to an excess condition, treat the Stomach channel; but for a deficient-type headache, choose from Spleen channel points such as 66.11 (SP4), 77.17 Heaven Emperor (SP9), and/or 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan). See 77.18 Shen Guan and 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36) for additional information related to the diagnosis and treatment of both deficient and excess type frontal headaches. Blood-deficient headaches: Because SP4 is the Master Point of the Chong Mai, it is used to treat blood-deficient headaches. Floaters and heavy eyelids: With A.04 San Cha Three and 66.05 Golden Gate, Fire Chrysanthemum is useful in the treatment of heavy eyelids (inability to keep the eyes open) and floaters. When the visual field includes one or two floaters, it is not of great concern; however, a plethora of floaters can be a precursor or an indication of a detaching retina. If the patient also sees flashing lights in the darkness, begin treatment using 55.02 Flower Bone One immediately, for detaching retina (see 55.02 Flower Bone One). A detached retina is extremely serious and can lead to blindness. Western medical intervention is extreme, as a laser is used to create multiple small scars (often two hundred or more) that attach the retina to the back of the eyeball. I have treated this condition very successfully numerous times using Flower Bone One. I am reluctant to refer such a patient to an ophthalmologist for diagnosis, because the patient will be frightened into the more radical surgical procedure. In my opinion, it is far more beneficial to strengthen the anatomy of the eye so that the retina naturally reattaches than to introduce scarring in an eye that is already weak and compromised. 241 Foot and Ankle Points Hypertension and hypercholesterolemia: Hypertension is a wind and phlegm condition that can be caused by high cholesterol or arteriosclerosis. 77.14 Four Flower Outer (ST40) and Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) are used together to disperse phlegm and open the blood vessels. Four Flower Outer lowers cholesterol because it is the Stomach Luo point for phlegm; TCM considers cholesterol as a type of phlegm. Stiff neck and high cholesterol are often related. Dr. Young’s treatment for promoting weight loss: For issues of weight loss, phlegm and fat, needle the following combination: REN4 Guan Yuan, SI4 Wan Gu, Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4), 77.14 Four Flower Outer (ST40) and ST34 Liang Qiu. REN4 is the Mu point of the Small Intestine channel and is good for absorption. SI4 drains dampness. SP4 and ST40 eliminate phlegm and fat, and ST34 suppresses the appetite. Dr. Young also recommends eating lots of apples. Finger numbness: Finger numbness can be caused by cholesterol, hypertension, pharmaceutical side effects or cervical bone spurring. It is important to determine the cause of the problem. Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4) is useful in treating numbness related to high cholesterol and hypertension. Pregnancy: Master Tung suggested that 66.10 Fire Connection, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum and 66.12 Fire Scatter were forbidden to needle during pregnancy; however, Dr. Young tells us to avoid only 66.12 Fire Scatter (Tung’s KD2). According to textbook TCM, SP3 Tai Bai, SP4 Gong Sun and KD2 Ran Gu are not contraindicated during pregnancy.
combinations: Abdominal pain, stomachache and indigestion: Sedate opposite-side 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), needle 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) and PC6 Nei Guan. Chest heaviness, oppression and anxiety: First, needle PC6 Nei Guan, then add 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4). Paralytic colon: Bleed 1010.07 All Pivot, needle 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) and antique PC6 Nei Guan. Stomach ulcer (excess or deficient): 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4), PC6 Nei Guan, deeply needle REN12 Zhong Wan. Hypertension and hypercholesterolemia: 77.14 Four Flower Outer (Tung’s ST40),

name: Huosan, Fire Scatter (T 66.12)
location: This point is on the KI channel and overlaps with Rangu (KI 2) . Some sources state this point is 0.5 cun proximal to Rangu (KI 2) . | Johnson: Fire Scatter is located on the medial side of the foot at the junction of the red and white skin, 1.0 cun proximal to 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4), in the depression just below the tuberosity of the navicular bone. The point is Master Tung’s version of KD2 Ran Gu. Caution: Do not needle during pregnancy.
secondary_indications: declining vision Neurasthenia Low back pain
johnson_indications: Drooling (due to brain injury or tumor)*
Lower back pain and kidney deficiency from sex addiction*
techniques: Perpendicular insertion 0.5 - 0.8 cun . | Johnson: Unilateral vs. bilateral needling: Master Tung taught that Fire Connection, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum and 66.12 Fire Scatter – individually or in combination – were to be needled only unilaterally. Dr. Young states that though it is preferable to use fewer needles, no side effects have been noted when these three points have been combined bilaterally (Dr. Young, 2008). In textbook TCM, each of these individual points can be needled bilaterally. Depth: 0.5-0.8 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Fire Scatter is located near KD2 Ran Gu but is needled closer to the bone, lending it an even stronger Kidney tonification effect. It is a fire point on the Kidney channel, tonifying water in the treatment of Kidney-deficient diseases. Because it has the Reaction Areas of both Kidney and Heart, and “Fire” in its name, it not only tonifies water but also disperses fire, balancing the Heart and Kidneys. Fire Scatter regulates the lower jiao and benefits the bladder, so it is useful in the treatment of lower back pain. Hot and cold feet: Fire Scatter is used for elderly people who suffer from having one foot that is hot while the other foot is cold. In this case, tonify the cold side first, then withdraw the needle and sedate the hot side. Do not needle both sides simultaneously (Dr. Lee, 1992). If both feet are cold, I usually needle 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points to increase circulation. Moxa pots on Ming Men and REN4 Guan Yuan also warm the feet beautifully. Migraines: Fire Scatter is effective in the treatment of headaches accompanied by dizziness because it disperses fire due to its connection with the Kidney (water) and Heart (fire). Moxa for drooling: Use a moxa pot on this point to control drooling that occurs due to brain injury or tumor.
combinations: Brain tumor: 66.10 Fire Connection, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum, 66.12 Fire Scatter. Drooling: Moxa: 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum, 66.12 Fire Scatter, male patients on the left side, female patients on the right side. Drooling due to brain injury: Though not frequently chosen, 11.25 Stop Spit is very useful for patients with brain injuries who are constantly drooling. Needling 11.25 Stop Spit and applying a moxa pot to KD2 Ran Gu will manage drooling, resulting in fewer clothing changes each day. Elderly patient with one cold foot and one hot foot: Tonify 66.12 Fire Scatter on the cold side first, then drain the hot side; do not needle both sides simultaneously. If both feet are cold, bilaterally needle 88.02 Passing Mountain or 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points, with moxa on REN4-REN6, UB23 Shen Shu and DU4 Ming Men. High blood pressure: 66.10 Fire Connection, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum, 66.12 Fire Scatter. Meningitis: 66.10 Fire Connection, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum, 66.12 Fire Scatter.
reaction_areas: Heart, Kidney, Six Bowels Caution: • Do not needle during pregnancy.

name: Shuijing, Water Crystal (T 66.13)
location: This point is on the KI channel, 2 cun below the tip of the medial malleolus. Some sources state that this point overlaps with Zhaohai (KI 6) , which is in the depression below the tip of the medial malleolus. | Johnson: On the arch of the foot beneath the bone, Water Crystal is located on the medial side, 2.0 cun (three fingers) inferior to the apex of the medial malleolus. Note: This location of KD6 is on the Kidney channel; although it is significantly distal to the TCM textbook location, it is Master Tung’s version of KD6 Zhao Hai.
johnson_indications: Uterine enlargement, fibroids, tumors or inflammation
techniques: Perpendicular insertion 0.5 - 1 cun along the bone. Visible veins near this point can be bled, especially for chronic gynecological disorders. | Johnson: Bone-treating-bone effect: Slide the needle alongside the bone to enhance the Kidney tonification effect. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: “Water Crystal” refers to the uterus (Dr. Young, 2008). Master Tung used this point to treat gynecological disease as well as uterine and lower abdominal fullness. Though it is acting as Textbook KD6, this point does not tonify fluids in the same way; therefore, if treating sore throat (with LU7) or constipation (with SJ6), I add 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors to increase Kidney fluids. In the early 1980s, I used this point with HIV patients who had a chronic sore throat, but 77.18 Shen Guan was likely the point that made the biggest difference. Textbook KD6: In the list of indications above, please note the one designated with an asterisk (*). This indication is included because it is associated with Textbook KD6 and also relevant to 66.13 Water Crystal (Tung’s KD6).
combinations: Sore throat: Sedate LU7 Lie Que, tonify 66.13 Water Crystal or 66.14 Water Phase (Tung’s KD3). Constipation: Sedate 33.04 Fire Threaded (SJ6), 77.04 Catching Ball (UB57) for acute constipation. For chronic constipation, needle 66.13 Water Crystal to moisten the yin (however, I am more likely to choose 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors to tonify fluids). Tell your patient to eat figs, dates and prunes. Fibroids: Needle 66.13 Water Crystal; unilaterally needle 11.24 Gynecological Points,

name: Shuixiang, Water Phase (T 66.14)
location: This point overlaps with Taixi (KI 3) , which is posterior to the medial malleolus, in the depression between the tip of the medial malleolus and the tendo calcaneus. | Johnson: Water Phase (also known as Water Minister) is located level with the tip of the medial malleolus on the anterior border of the tendo calcaneus. This is Tung’s KD3 Tai Xi.
primary_indications: back pain due to Kidney deficiency
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle on or closer to the anterior border of the Achilles tendon for better effect. Penetrate the needle through to Kunlun (BL 60) for best effect. | Johnson: Liver tonification: Because the Liver governs tendons and ligaments, needling this point on the anterior border of the tendon will enhance the Liver function (tendon treats tendon). Dao Ma: Water Phase (Chief Point) can be needled with Supporting Point 66.15 Water Fairy. Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Water Phase is Master Tung’s version of KD3 Tai Xi, the Shu- Stream, Source and earth point on the Kidney channel. It tonifies Kidney yang and nourishes Kidney yin, strengthening the lower back and clearing deficient fire. It also tonifies the Spleen and benefits the Lungs. As an earth point on a water channel, needled close to the tendon (wood), the point has Spleen, Kidney and Liver influences, making it very useful in treating symptoms related to hypertension, head and eye diseases (Liver); brain, spine and vertebrae (Kidney); and digestive and metabolic disorders such as diabetes, proteinuria, floating edema, nausea and vomiting (Spleen and Kidney). For the same reasons, this point can be used to treat postpartum fever (fever after delivery, with pain all over the body, also known as “afterbirth wind” in TCM) and hypertension in pregnancy. Dao Ma: 66.15 Water Fairy is located near KD5 Shui Quan, the Xi-Cleft point of the Kidney channel, and it tonifies qi and blood of the Kidney. Combined with Water Phase, it strengthens the Kidney and Spleen as well as the power of the earth to control water. If earth is unable to control water, there is excessive urination. If water cannot control fire, dryness of the mouth may result. These points may also be combined with 77.17 Heaven Emperor (SP9), a water point on an earth channel, to treat conditions involving both earth and water (such as proteinuria). 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors or 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points may be chosen instead, because they are at least as powerful.•  Eye diseases: Because Liver governs the anatomy of the eye, and Kidney governs the power of vision, Water Phase or 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7) can be substituted for 77.21 Man Emperor whenever 77.18-77.21 Two or Three Emperors are being used to treat the eyes.•  Lower back pain: When 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons needles are retained for longer than thirty minutes while the patient’s head is resting in a face cradle, their lower back may begin to ache. After removing the needles, have the patient turn over and place a bolster under their legs, then needle Water Phase bilaterally and retain the needles for ten minutes. The patient’s back will feel fine when they stand up. •  Moxa: To tonify the Kidneys, burn 3-5 moxa cones on this point bilaterally.
combinations: Diabetes: Needle 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points or 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors; 66.14 Water Phase; SJ4 Yang Chi to regulate the qi. •  Chronic dry mouth with sore throat: Needle 88.09 Passing Kidney; 66.04 Fire Master (or Four Gates), 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors or 66.14 Water Phase.•  Toothache (root): Needle 66.14 Water Phase, 22.06-22.07 Middle White/Lower White.•  Lumbar pain: Needle SI3 Hou Xi, 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 22.03 Upper White, 22.06-22.07 Middle White/Lower White, UB65 Shu Gu, 66.09 Water Curve (GB41) or 66.14 Water Phase as a Guiding Point (treats midline lower back pain).•  Achilles pain: Needle opposite-side 66.14 Water Phase, contacting the anterior border of the Achilles tendon, through to UB60 Kun Lun. •  Hypertension in pregnancy: Preeclampsia is a very serious condition that can be effectively treated with a strong herbal formula. The following Dao Ma can be utilized along with other points: 66.14 Water Phase, 66.15 Water Fairy (Tung’s KD5). •  Postpartum fever: This condition usually involves pain all over the body. The following Dao Ma can be utilized along with other points: 66.14 Water Phase, 66.15 Water Fairy (Tung’s KD5). •  Kidney failure: Needle 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points or 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors; 66.14 Water Phase; 77.17 Heaven Emperor (SP9) (water point on an earth channel). Alternate points, never more than eight needles. Burn moxa on the navel (line with paper, add salt, cover with a slice of ginger that is pierced with a fork and then use large moxa balls, approximately ¾” diameter).

name: Shuixian, Water Fairy (T 66.15)
location: This point is on the KI channel, 2 cun directly inferior or distal to Taixi (KI 3) , which is posterior to the medial malleolus, in the depression between the tip of the medial malleolus and the tendo calcaneus. | Johnson: Water Fairy is located directly inferior to Water Phase, just proximal to the superior border of the calcaneal tuberosity. This is Tung’s KD5 Shui Quan.
primary_indications: back pain due to Kidney deficiency
johnson_indications: See Chief Point 66.14 Water Phase, Indications.
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle on or closer to the anterior border of the Achilles tendon for better effect. Penetrate the needle through to Kunlun (BL 60) for best effect. | Johnson: Dao Ma: Used as a Supporting Point along with 66.14 Water Phase for treating diseases related to Kidney deficiency. Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun Deep
comments: Energetic pathways: Water Fairy is located near KD5 Shui Quan, the Xi-Cleft point of the Kidney channel. KD5 tonifies the source qi of the Kidney. This point is indicated for amenorrhea because Xi-Cleft points store qi and blood. In TCM, Shui Quan regulates the Chong Mai and Ren vessels, and also regulates menstruation. Amenorrhea: Water Fairy is located near KD5 Shui Quan, the Xi-Cleft point on the Kidney meridian, and it tonifies Kidney Source qi. ST25 is the Mu Point for the Large Intestine, and it regulates qi and blood. REN24 is the best point for amenorrhea because the Stomach and Large Intestine meridians (Yang Ming) have more qi and more blood, and both travel around the mouth. As the Jing-Well point for the REN channel (which travels through the genitals and regulates qi and blood), REN24 opens the orifices. See 66.14 Water Phase for additional comments.
combinations: Amenorrhea: Needle ST25 Tian Shu with KD5 Shui Quan; needle REN24 Cheng Jiang. See Comments above. See 66.14 Water Phase for Dao Ma combinations.

name: Tung's Wantong * (T 66.16)
location: This is a 2 point set. The first point is inferior to the tip of the lateral malleolus on the lower border of the calcaneus. The second point is 2 cun distal to the first one.
techniques: Needle 1 cun .

name: Zhengjin, Upright Tendon (T 77.01)
location: This point is on the BL channel, 3.5 cun proximal to the bottom of the heel on the Achilles tendon. It is midway between Kunlun (BL 60) and Taixi (KI 3) on the midline of the posterior aspect of the lower leg. | Johnson: 77.01 Upright Tendon is located in the center of the flat surface of the Achilles tendon, 3.5 cun proximal to the heel. Draw a line from the tip of each malleolus – the external and the internal – up to the top of the tendon. There will be a space of approximately 1.0 cun between the two lines. Locate Upright Tendon in the center of this space or choose any large crease, being careful to avoid blood vessels that are on top of the tendon (See extensive needling notes below). 77.02 Upright Ancestry is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) superior to Upright Tendon, centered on the Achilles tendon. Carefully palpate the flaring sides of the tendon, as it follows the tibia and is often found veering toward one side or the other.
johnson_indications: Shaking or tremors of the head
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 0.8 cun . Use a thicker gauge needle and pierce through the tendon to touch the bone for optimal effect. For stronger patients, needle in a sitting position. For weak patients, needle in a prone or sideway position. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Point Location and Needling Technique, and on the Eastern Currents webinar platform that houses my series of beginning and advanced classes. The Correct Tendons video includes three demonstrations of the location and needling of these points. Learning these points may be challenging, but I include them among my favorites of Master Tung’s points, and their usefulness in treating neck and head injuries is unsurpassed. Dao Ma: 77.01 Upright Tendon and 77.02 Upright Ancestry are always needled together (Point Coupling) in the combination known as Correct Tendons. Two additional points – 77.03 Upright Scholar and 77.04 Catching Ball (Tung’s UB57) – are rarely used, because 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons are remarkably powerful and need no further Dao Ma. Needle gauge/length: The Correct Tendons points are the second-most difficult set of points to execute in Tung’s system (second only to 55.02 Flower Bone One) because needling them requires inserting a long, thin needle through the Achilles tendon, the thickest tendon in the body. With practice, it is easily accomplished. Using a larger gauge needle would be easier but far more painful for the patient, so I highly recommend practicing until perfecting the use of a 0.20 x 50mm (Japanese gauge 3, Chinese gauge 36) needle for these points. During the incremental insertion of the needle shaft, one millimeter at a time, the practitioner may at first experience their fingers slipping on the shaft until they have learned to grasp the needle with qi. It is impossible to insert these needles into the Achilles tendon without touching the shaft, and it also would be impossible while holding the needle with a sterile cotton ball; therefore, practitioners may choose to wear sterile gloves when needling these points. Because bone treats bone, and these needles are used specifically for anomalies along the spine, gently tap the bone to enhance the Kidney tonification effect. Unless the patient is under five feet tall, 40mm length needles are not long enough to gently tap the back of the tibia. For most patients, a 50mm needle will suffice; however, patients taller than six feet may require a 60mm needle. If the needle does not tap the bone, you must determine whether the needle is too short or whether it missed the back of the tibia and slid to one side or the other. See the paragraph that begins, “Gently tapping the back of the tibia,” below. Patient positioning: Because I primarily use Correct Tendons to treat a variety of neck injuries, I have found it necessary to position my patients in various ways so that they can be comfortable, including: face down on the table, face up on the table, lying on their side, or sitting in a chair. Because these points are some of the most difficult to needle, I would advise a practitioner who is practicing their insertion for the first few times to begin with the patient lying face down, with their head resting in a face cradle. When the patient is in this position, their legs are stabilized and the direction of your needling is supported by gravity. Primary position, face down: Always use a face cradle when needling these points on a patient who is lying face down, because anyone with a neck injury should neither turn nor lift their head. Active Qi Moving technique is not recommended, as the weight of the head would further injure the neck. Place a pillow under their ankles and dorsal feet so that their toes are slightly elevated off the table and completely relaxed. The pillow under the ankles allows the legs and lumbar vertebrae to relax, as well. Next, see the paragraph that begins, “Massage the tendon,” below (this step cannot be overemphasized). Side position: If a patient cannot lie on their stomach with their head in a face cradle, these points can be needled with the patient lying on their side. This position might be preferable for many patients; however, it is extremely difficult for an inexperienced needler of Correct Tendons. When the patient is lying on their side, the practitioner is required to insert fine needles through a heavy tendon using only one hand, because the other hand needs to stabilize the anterior tibia in order to prevent it from sliding on the table. Practice is essential, as learning to grip the needle with qi is necessary for inserting in this position. With the patient lying on their side, place one or two pillows under their head and neck (not under the shoulder), so the head is perfectly perpendicular to the shoulders and not tipped toward the table or ceiling. Adjust the pillows to be sure that the shoulder contacting the table is comfortable. In order to remove the twist from the lumbar vertebrae, have the patient straighten their bottom leg and bend their top leg, and place a large pillow under their bent knee. Now use rolled hand towels to prop both Achilles tendons in a perfectly relaxed position. To best accomplish this, fold two hand towels in half lengthwise and roll them together; place the large roll under the medial ankle and arch of the top foot, rolling the towel back and forth and thereby rotating the foot toward the table and the ceiling, until the Achilles tendon is in a neutral position. Fold a third hand towel in half lengthwise, making a small roll, and place it under the bottom ankle, again rolling it forward and back until the tendon and the bottom foot are perfectly suspended and relaxed. Be careful not to allow the bottom foot to extend off the table, as that would cause it to become icy cold during the treatment. Using the hand towel to suspend the foot on the table is necessary because otherwise, with the Urinary Bladder channel contacting the table, the foot would be pushed toward the ceiling, putting pressure on the Achilles tendon. For comfortable insertion, it is essential that the tendon is utterly relaxed. Next, see the paragraph that begins, “Massage the tendon,” below. Face-up position: On one occasion, I treated a rugby coach who had broken his neck in a scrum. He was sporting a plastic neck brace that screwed into his skull, and he was unable to lie face down or on his side. Sitting in a chair was also uncomfortable for him, so I had to be creative. With pillows at the right height under his head, he lay down on the table, face up, with his ankles hanging off the end and a bolster under his knees. I then had to lie on the floor and needle upwards through the Achilles tendons, which worked well. However, I would never recommend this type of insertion for a practitioner new to Correct Tendons. Sitting position: As a child, I frequently saw my aunt in a traction device due to severe arthritis in her neck. Correct Tendons altogether eliminated her need for this device. Because she was unable to comfortably lie face down, face up, or on either side, I taught myself to needle Correct Tendons while she sat in a straight chair (with arm rests), with a small pillow behind her lumbar spine and her feet flat on the floor (wearing open-back shoes or flip-flops). Because every Correct Tendons needling position necessitates that the legs be completely relaxed, a sitting position requires the legs to remain parallel so that the Achilles tendons are perfectly neutral. To help the patient comfortably retain this position for the duration of the treatment, it is necessary to tie a belt or strap around the thighs (approximately 4-6 inches above the knees, to avoid knee strain) so that they can relax their legs. Sit on the floor in front of the patient and firmly but briefly massage the calves and Achilles tendons. Using your mind’s eye to guide your fingers, palpate the flat surface of the Achilles tendon in relation to the malleoli and insert the needles through the tendon toward the back of tibia until you feel a gentle bone tap. This position is by far the most difficult for needling Correct Tendons, but with patience and practice you will be successful. Massage the tendon: The Correct Tendons points are infinitely easier to needle if you first quickly but deeply massage the gastrocnemius muscle and Achilles tendon. Forgetting to do this one thing will basically cause torture for your patient and extreme frustration for you. With the patient lying face down, bend the knee of one leg at a time. When the right knee is bent, use your left forearm to flex the patient’s foot forward and back, holding their heel in your left palm and pushing down on their foot with your forearm across their plantar surface. While stretching the foot and Achilles in this manner, use the web between your right thumb and index fingers to deeply press the Achilles tendon against the back of their tibia for 15-30 seconds; do this in several different areas of the tendon, especially just above the Achilles insertion on the calcaneus bone. Then place the leg back on the table, and firmly, quickly massage both heads of the gastrocnemius muscle and the Achilles tendon again. This process should take only a couple of minutes. Then switch to the other leg. The Achilles is ready to be needled only after this massage. Women who wear high heels will want to stretch their legs thoroughly before the treatment described above. Flat surface of the Achilles tendon: It is very interesting (and essential) to note that in most patients, the Achilles tendon is not straight; instead it angles either laterally or medially. This is because the tendon, which is attached to the gastrocnemius muscle, veers according to the structure of the bones beneath it (primarily the tibia, as the fibula is a floating bone). In order to insert a needle so that its tip gently taps the back of the tibia, one must precisely locate the flat surface of the Achilles tendon. On some people’s calves, the Achilles tendon is obvious, whereas on others, the surrounding muscle may obscure it unless you press down on either side of it with both of your index fingers. Palpating the tendon in this manner shows you not only the tendon’s overall direction but also its width. As you move proximally toward the location of the second point, you will notice that the tendon flares as you approach the gastrocnemius. When needling Correct Tendons, we want our point location to be in the exact center of the width of the tendon, and our needle trajectory to be perfectly perpendicular to its flat surface. In most cases, because the tendon veers to one side or the other, the flat top of the tendon is not horizontal. I suggest using a guide tube, which allows you to firmly tap the needle into the tendon and also shows the perpendicular placement of the needle in the middle of the angled tendon. This determines and sets the trajectory of the needle, which is held by the tendon itself. Once the needle has been tapped, the only way to change this trajectory is to lift the tip of the needle out of the tendon to a position just beneath the skin. When the needle is “loose,” it can be repegged into the tendon again. Repegging the tendon is an important step that ensures a trajectory, which results in the gentle tapping of the back of the tibia. To confirm that the trajectory is correct, once you have tapped the needle in and removed the tube, use the tube to hold the needle erect. If it appears that the shaft of the needle is perfectly straight, and there are no tiny folds of skin around the needle (indicating an imperfect trajectory), you may proceed with your needle insertion (see directions below). If the shaft of your needle is not perfectly perpendicular to the flat top of the tendon (keeping in mind that the flat surface of the tendon may be at an angle), it is necessary to repeg the tendon in order to correct not only your insertion but also your trajectory, because the projection of an improperly placed needle will become greater and greater as the needle reaches its full depth. If you are using a 0.20 x 50mm needle and you do not feel the bone tap on the back of the tibia, you may have missed the back of the tibia altogether; in this case, it is necessary to determine which side of the tibia the needle has slid down. Contacting the periosteum on either the medial or lateral side of the tibia has a particular sensation and can be bad for the bone (see the paragraph that begins, “Needle sensation,” below). Use the crease: When locating 77.01 Upright Tendon, the more distal of the two points, place your index fingers on both the medial and lateral malleoli. Now, bring both fingers to the top of the tendon and notice that your lateral finger is approximately one cun distal to your medial one. If there is a significant crease in the skin on top of the tendon between your two fingers, you may choose to needle through that crease as it is already desensitized. However, it is not at all necessary to choose a crease; any point between your two fingers will work, because the location of the Correct Tendons points does not need to be exact. Just be sure to avoid any blood vessels that you can feel on top of the Achilles tendon; you may be able to see them, but they will slip around on top of the tendon when palpated. Needling through these blood vessels is painful, and it may damage the vessel. I experienced this when these points were repeatedly needled on me; many years later, this vessel is still enlarged with scar tissue and sensitive. Inserting the needle: With the patient lying face down in a face cradle, and a pillow elevating their toes slightly off the table, massage their calves as directed above. Standing on the side of the table, place the palm of your hand that is closest to the patient’s feet very gently over the heel of their foot. This hand position is to simply balance your body without putting any weight whatsoever on the patient’s foot. This same hand will incrementally insert the needle into the tendon, one millimeter at a time, once the needle has been tapped, checked, and confirmed as properly placed (see above). With your opposite hand, grasp the shaft of the needle, and while balancing this hand weightlessly against the patient’s gastrocnemius with your little finger, begin to apply downward pressure to the needle while it is incrementally inserted into the tendon. Once the Achilles tendon has been fully penetrated, there will be a discernable density change. Continue needle insertion until you very gently tap the back of the tibia. Gently tapping the back of the tibia: Patients feel even the most subtle bone tap, so anticipate it carefully to avoid plowing into the bone and damaging the periosteum (the bone’s protective layer). If you use a needle of the appropriate length (see above) but no bone tap is felt (a “donk,” as if against stone), then the needle has slid down on one side of the tibia or the other, and you need to determine which side it is. Sliding the needle shaft alongside the tibia may produce a slight electrical sensation that wraps around the tibia; this is not particularly uncomfortable for the patient, but it indicates incorrect needle placement and is unhealthy for the periosteum. If this occurs, or if you miss the bone tap, you need to remove the needle from the tendon (to just beneath the skin) and repeg it to correct the trajectory. Missing the bone tap indicates incorrect placement and does not provide a good therapeutic result. Needle sensation: When these points are needled correctly, most patients describe the needling sensation with words such as “thick,” rather than “painful.” If your needle insertion is painful, the needle gauge is probably too large, and you need to practice wielding a finer needle. Because these points are so powerful, being needled through the strongest tendon in the entire body, insertion alone is enough and no stimulation is required. Some patients experience a subtle sensation of qi moving through the legs and lower body quickly, somewhat slowing down through the lumbar spine, picking up speed through the thoracic vertebrae and then “slugging out” in the cervical spine before ascending up and over the head into the eyes. For this reason, I ask the patient (if they are awake) to mentally picture keeping their spine open, in order for the energy to pass through as easily as possible. Most people do not experience the subtleties of this sensation and shortly fall sound asleep. Retention: Because the qi has a long way to travel from one end of the body to the other, it is best to retain these needles for sixty minutes. The preferred position for needling Correct Tendons is face down, with the head resting in a face cradle. Patients need to be forewarned that their sinuses will always congest in this position; otherwise, they will become concerned about having contracted a common cold or flu from the face cradle. Beneath the face cradle, I always place a chair where the patient can rest their arms and, when necessary, reach for a box of Kleenex or ring a bell to get my attention. If a patient has lower back pain, the lengthy time in a facedown position may exacerbate the pain, even though their lower back will also benefit as the qi passes through on the way to the head, strengthening the entire spine. After removing the needles, I always have the patient turn over and rest with a bolster under their knees for at least five minutes. Make sure they do not cross their ankles and they let their sacrum gently settle into the table, straightening all their vertebrae up to the neck. If their lower back is uncomfortable, quickly needle KD3 Tai Xi bilaterally and retain for ten minutes. When they get up, their back will feel fine. I ask my patients to thoroughly stretch their calves and Achilles tendons before they go to bed that night and again the next morning, to alleviate any lingering tightness or tenderness in the tendon. Needling frequency: For best clinical results in severe cases, I have found that it is better to needle Correct Tendons three times in two weeks rather than once per week for three weeks. The decreased interval between treatments can make a big difference. Usually within two to three treatments, there is a significant improvement, though continued treatment may be required to complete recovery. Depth: 1.5-2.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Correct Tendons points are located on the back of the Achilles tendon between the Urinary Bladder and Kidney meridians, and they have the Reaction Areas of Brain and Spine. Upright Tendon is located between UB60 Kun Lun and KD3 Tai Xi. Before humans evolved to walk on two legs, the spine was the highest part of the body, and Mount Kun Lun represents this “highest mountain.” Both UB60 and Correct Tendons treat the spine and are especially effective for occipital headaches, whiplash, concussion, and brain diseases. Because Correct Tendons are needled deeply through the Achilles tendon to gently tap the back of the tibia, they activate both the tendon-treating-tendon and bone-treating-bone systems. Needling through this large tendon makes them also useful for treating spasms anywhere in the body, including spasms from menstrual cramping and plantar fasciitis. Tapping the bone enhances the function of Kidney tonification because it relates to the brain, spine and bone marrow. Correct Tendons regulates the qi either by raising the yang to warm the entire body or by descending excess yang qi and dispersing wind from the head and spine. Neck and head: The Correct Tendons point pattern is among my top five favorites in Tung’s acupuncture because it is clinically outstanding for any disease involving the cervical spine, occipital area or cerebellum. Interestingly, is it said that if the Achilles tendon is cut, the head cannot be held erect. These points are my first choice for head and neck injuries such as whiplash, concussion, neck pain or stiffness (including protruding or herniated discs and stenosis), occipital headaches, and intracranial injury or disease. Correct Tendons points are so powerful that it is rarely necessary to add any other points; however, I often cup the entire upper back and neck before needling these points. Lumbar spine: Correct Tendons adjusts misalignment all the way up the spine, so when there are lumbar or thoracic anomalies, they respond to the use of Correct Tendons in the treatment of the head or neck. Although these points can be used for lower back pain, I am likely to choose other points if the patient does not have any head or neck indications, because Master Tung’s system has so many points to choose from. Ankylosing spondylitis: Ankylosing spondylitis is a condition that causes the fusion of the entire spinal column. The slow calcification of the spine gradually causes a bending forward which results in the patient looking only at the ground when walking. It is more commonly found among twenty- to forty-year-old men of Jewish decent; however, I treated two Chinese brothers who had this condition. 271 Lower Leg Points Ankylosing spondylitis can also be the result of interactions of both pharmaceutical and recreational drugs. My mother had this condition from a lifetime of taking aspirin on a daily basis. Treatment: My primary treatment for this condition is bamboo cupping of the entire spine, every two weeks. Bamboo cupping is a bleeding technique that utilizes small sections of bamboo that are boiled and placed over a small puncture made between the posterior spinous processes of the vertebra. The boiled bamboo cups create a suction which draws a small clot of blood from between all the vertebrae, thus vitalizing the blood and preventing further calcification. What is already fused will not unfuse, but you can stop the progression. I have successfully treated three cases using bamboo cupping along with Correct Tendons. Bamboo cupping takes 20-30 minutes, so insert Correct Tendons first, as this will make for a much more efficient treatment. Ankylosing spondylitis is a condition that allopathic medicine has not been able to treat successfully. Herbal formulas: I have treated three patients using the formula Kang Gu Zeng Sheng Pien. This formula strengthens qi and yang; tonifies Kidney and Liver; fortifies marrow, tendon and bone; clears damp; relieves pain; and is used specifically for calcification following injury, or in spontaneous multiplicative spondylitis. It is good for tendon pain and numbness, as well as chronic vertebral subluxations and spinal inflammation. Another popular formula is Shen Jin Tong Bi Wan, which dispels wind, cold and damp that invades as the result of an overall deficiency. Other individual ankylosing spondylitis treatment options (given in no specific order): Bleed UB40 Wei Zhong; bilaterally needle 88.12 Bright Yellow. Bilaterally needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Middle, 22.06 Zhong Bai (Middle White), 1010.13 Horse Gold Water, 11.12 Er Jiao Ming (Two Corner Bright). Bilaterally needle 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles, SI3 Hou Xi. Needled bilaterally 77.09 Four Flower Middle, 77.10 Four Flower Quasi. Bilaterally needle 77.18 Kidney Gate, 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7), SI3 Hou Xi and UB65 Shu Gu (if there is Kidney deficiency). Needle DU26 Ren Zhong; bilaterally needle LI11 Qu Chi; moxa UB18-UB20. Bilaterally needle 11.11 Lung Heart. Case history (ankylosing spondylitis): A 34-year-old male reported having the constant sensation of a cement block between his shoulder blades, indicative of his thoracic spine beginning to fuse. His lumbar vertebrae had already fused and were no longer painful. Once a week for eighteen months, I needled Correct Tendons, and every other week I bamboo-cupped his entire thoracic and lumbar spine. Within three months, he reported that the heaviness between his shoulder blades was largely gone. By the time we discontinued treatment, he was comfortable and the calcification had stopped. I have treated four other cases with similar results; however his was the most profound, I think because he was the youngest. It is my belief that in all of these cases, without bamboo cupping and Correct Tendons, these patients would have lived their life facing the ground. Case history (severe occipital headache): I was called to the hospital to treat a young man who had been admitted ten days earlier due to a severe occipital headache. His doctor had placed him on an intravenous morphine drip, but this provided him with no relief. First, I did a simple but thorough Gua Sha treatment on the back of his neck, and then I needled Correct Tendons. As soon as the needles were inserted the headache began to recede. The following day, the young man was able to leave the hospital. The doctor and nursing staff were thoroughly impressed. This is the power of Correct Tendons. Case history (chronic neck restriction): One of my patients was an arborist who had been unable to turn her head to either side or move it up and down for more than ten years. Her job was at stake. I began treatment by thoroughly cupping her entire neck and shoulders in a sitting position, in order to cup the musculature without gaps. The cup marks were black. Immediately after cupping she had a fifty percent improvement in the mobility of her neck. I then needled Correct Tendons, retaining the needles for one hour, after which her mobility increased to eighty percent. Despite her marked improvement, when she arrived home, her family convinced her that the cup marks were evidence that she had been abused. This inspired me to create a tri-fold color brochure with photographs of dark cup marks taken on days one, three, five and seven following a thorough cupping session. This brochure explains what to expect during and after cupping therapy. I have shown it to patients before cupping sessions ever since I treated the arborist. Case history (paralysis and coldness, Dr. Lee): “A 22-year-old man had been in a car accident four years before and had broken his neck. He was paralyzed from the neck down and his arms were getting weaker and weaker. All other treatments had failed so he came to see me. Although it was the hot part of summer, he wore a heavy winter jacket. He would also always ask for a glass of warm water to wrap his hands around in an effort to warm them. In addition, he would always ask me to order him a hot meal. When I palpated his neck at DU16 Feng Fu, just below the base of the skull, there was severe pain. This meant that there was still blood stasis that was obstructing the flow of yang qi. I told him he would have to receive three treatments per week. After needling him the first two times at Correct Tendons the sub-occipital pain was lessened. After three treatments he said he could breathe deeper. After the fourth and fifth treatments, he said his whole body felt warmer. A few weeks later, he no longer needed to warm his hands by wrapping them around a hot glass of water” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Case history (severe headache, Dr. Lee): “A 50-year-old woodcutter was knocked down by a tree and his head was shaken backwards violently. After being hospitalized, he still had severe headaches all the time. Each time his physician refilled his pain medication it would be for 100 pills, and his wife had to inject him with morphine every three hours. Over a period of two years, he had five heart attacks due to such heavy pain medication, since it is well known that pain medications affect the heart. Finally a doctor referred him to me with severe insomnia and severe headache. I needled 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons. He then slept, hard. After 45 minutes he awoke and I asked him to gently shake his head. He shook it a little and there was no pain. Then I asked him to shake it more forcefully and still there was no pain. The man stood up. He said he could not believe it. I asked him what he could not believe. He just kept saying he could not believe it. I called his wife into the office and she asked him what he could not believe. He said he could not believe he no longer had a headache. Then she said she could not believe it. I explained to the patient that he should not do any heavy lifting or any heavy work. He left my office and returned home. After sitting around the house for one week, the man grew bored and did some digging in order to plant some flowers. This caused him to get a headache again. He came back to my office and we did several more treatments. Finally, we got rid of all his headaches” (Dr. Lee, 1992).30 Case history (pain in the spine, Dr. Lee): “A patient had pain in every joint of her spine. Correct Tendons points were needled in three subsequent treatments. The first treatment cleared her neck, the second cleared the spine to five inches below her neck, and the third cleared her whole back, and the pain was gone” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Case history (occipital headache, Dr. Lee): “This point is also very effective for the treatment of occipital headache due to past trauma to the back of the head or neck. For instance, this area can be injured if a child has been shaken violently back and forth. Often this will not cause problems when the child is young but may result in occipital headaches when the person is in their late twenties or thirties” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Plantar fasciitis or Achilles tendon pain: Needle opposite-side 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons. Brain tumor, meningitis or severe occipital headache: 55.06 Upper Tumor, 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons (needle twice daily if possible). Twisted back: 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, bleed UB40 Wei Zhong, then use 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons. 30 I was with Miriam when she treated this patient. In addition to needling 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons, she cupped the patient’s neck and upper back; the skin was black after cupping. She also needled 55.06 Upper Tumor.

name: Zhengzong, Upright Ancestry (T 77.02)
location: This point is on the Achilles tendon, 5.5 cun proximal to the bottom of the heel or 2 cun proximal to Zhengjin (T 77.01) , which is midway between Kunlun (BL 60) and Taixi (KI 3) on the midline of the posterior aspect of the lower leg. | Johnson: 77.01 Upright Tendon is located in the center of the flat surface of the Achilles tendon, 3.5 cun proximal to the heel. Draw a line from the tip of each malleolus – the external and the internal – up to the top of the tendon. There will be a space of approximately 1.0 cun between the two lines. Locate Upright Tendon in the center of this space or choose any large crease, being careful to avoid blood vessels that are on top of the tendon (See extensive needling notes below). 77.02 Upright Ancestry is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) superior to Upright Tendon, centered on the Achilles tendon. Carefully palpate the flaring sides of the tendon, as it follows the tibia and is often found veering toward one side or the other.
johnson_indications: Shaking or tremors of the head
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Use a thicker gauge needle and pierce through the tendon to touch the bone for optimal effect. For stronger patients, needle in a sitting position. For weak patients, needle in a prone or sideway position. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Point Location and Needling Technique, and on the Eastern Currents webinar platform that houses my series of beginning and advanced classes. The Correct Tendons video includes three demonstrations of the location and needling of these points. Learning these points may be challenging, but I include them among my favorites of Master Tung’s points, and their usefulness in treating neck and head injuries is unsurpassed. Dao Ma: 77.01 Upright Tendon and 77.02 Upright Ancestry are always needled together (Point Coupling) in the combination known as Correct Tendons. Two additional points – 77.03 Upright Scholar and 77.04 Catching Ball (Tung’s UB57) – are rarely used, because 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons are remarkably powerful and need no further Dao Ma. Needle gauge/length: The Correct Tendons points are the second-most difficult set of points to execute in Tung’s system (second only to 55.02 Flower Bone One) because needling them requires inserting a long, thin needle through the Achilles tendon, the thickest tendon in the body. With practice, it is easily accomplished. Using a larger gauge needle would be easier but far more painful for the patient, so I highly recommend practicing until perfecting the use of a 0.20 x 50mm (Japanese gauge 3, Chinese gauge 36) needle for these points. During the incremental insertion of the needle shaft, one millimeter at a time, the practitioner may at first experience their fingers slipping on the shaft until they have learned to grasp the needle with qi. It is impossible to insert these needles into the Achilles tendon without touching the shaft, and it also would be impossible while holding the needle with a sterile cotton ball; therefore, practitioners may choose to wear sterile gloves when needling these points. Because bone treats bone, and these needles are used specifically for anomalies along the spine, gently tap the bone to enhance the Kidney tonification effect. Unless the patient is under five feet tall, 40mm length needles are not long enough to gently tap the back of the tibia. For most patients, a 50mm needle will suffice; however, patients taller than six feet may require a 60mm needle. If the needle does not tap the bone, you must determine whether the needle is too short or whether it missed the back of the tibia and slid to one side or the other. See the paragraph that begins, “Gently tapping the back of the tibia,” below. Patient positioning: Because I primarily use Correct Tendons to treat a variety of neck injuries, I have found it necessary to position my patients in various ways so that they can be comfortable, including: face down on the table, face up on the table, lying on their side, or sitting in a chair. Because these points are some of the most difficult to needle, I would advise a practitioner who is practicing their insertion for the first few times to begin with the patient lying face down, with their head resting in a face cradle. When the patient is in this position, their legs are stabilized and the direction of your needling is supported by gravity. Primary position, face down: Always use a face cradle when needling these points on a patient who is lying face down, because anyone with a neck injury should neither turn nor lift their head. Active Qi Moving technique is not recommended, as the weight of the head would further injure the neck. Place a pillow under their ankles and dorsal feet so that their toes are slightly elevated off the table and completely relaxed. The pillow under the ankles allows the legs and lumbar vertebrae to relax, as well. Next, see the paragraph that begins, “Massage the tendon,” below (this step cannot be overemphasized). Side position: If a patient cannot lie on their stomach with their head in a face cradle, these points can be needled with the patient lying on their side. This position might be preferable for many patients; however, it is extremely difficult for an inexperienced needler of Correct Tendons. When the patient is lying on their side, the practitioner is required to insert fine needles through a heavy tendon using only one hand, because the other hand needs to stabilize the anterior tibia in order to prevent it from sliding on the table. Practice is essential, as learning to grip the needle with qi is necessary for inserting in this position. With the patient lying on their side, place one or two pillows under their head and neck (not under the shoulder), so the head is perfectly perpendicular to the shoulders and not tipped toward the table or ceiling. Adjust the pillows to be sure that the shoulder contacting the table is comfortable. In order to remove the twist from the lumbar vertebrae, have the patient straighten their bottom leg and bend their top leg, and place a large pillow under their bent knee. Now use rolled hand towels to prop both Achilles tendons in a perfectly relaxed position. To best accomplish this, fold two hand towels in half lengthwise and roll them together; place the large roll under the medial ankle and arch of the top foot, rolling the towel back and forth and thereby rotating the foot toward the table and the ceiling, until the Achilles tendon is in a neutral position. Fold a third hand towel in half lengthwise, making a small roll, and place it under the bottom ankle, again rolling it forward and back until the tendon and the bottom foot are perfectly suspended and relaxed. Be careful not to allow the bottom foot to extend off the table, as that would cause it to become icy cold during the treatment. Using the hand towel to suspend the foot on the table is necessary because otherwise, with the Urinary Bladder channel contacting the table, the foot would be pushed toward the ceiling, putting pressure on the Achilles tendon. For comfortable insertion, it is essential that the tendon is utterly relaxed. Next, see the paragraph that begins, “Massage the tendon,” below. Face-up position: On one occasion, I treated a rugby coach who had broken his neck in a scrum. He was sporting a plastic neck brace that screwed into his skull, and he was unable to lie face down or on his side. Sitting in a chair was also uncomfortable for him, so I had to be creative. With pillows at the right height under his head, he lay down on the table, face up, with his ankles hanging off the end and a bolster under his knees. I then had to lie on the floor and needle upwards through the Achilles tendons, which worked well. However, I would never recommend this type of insertion for a practitioner new to Correct Tendons. Sitting position: As a child, I frequently saw my aunt in a traction device due to severe arthritis in her neck. Correct Tendons altogether eliminated her need for this device. Because she was unable to comfortably lie face down, face up, or on either side, I taught myself to needle Correct Tendons while she sat in a straight chair (with arm rests), with a small pillow behind her lumbar spine and her feet flat on the floor (wearing open-back shoes or flip-flops). Because every Correct Tendons needling position necessitates that the legs be completely relaxed, a sitting position requires the legs to remain parallel so that the Achilles tendons are perfectly neutral. To help the patient comfortably retain this position for the duration of the treatment, it is necessary to tie a belt or strap around the thighs (approximately 4-6 inches above the knees, to avoid knee strain) so that they can relax their legs. Sit on the floor in front of the patient and firmly but briefly massage the calves and Achilles tendons. Using your mind’s eye to guide your fingers, palpate the flat surface of the Achilles tendon in relation to the malleoli and insert the needles through the tendon toward the back of tibia until you feel a gentle bone tap. This position is by far the most difficult for needling Correct Tendons, but with patience and practice you will be successful. Forgetting to do this one thing will basically cause torture for your patient and extreme frustration for you. With the patient lying face down, bend the knee of one leg at a time. When the right knee is bent, use your left forearm to flex the patient’s foot forward and back, holding their heel in your left palm and pushing down on their foot with your forearm across their plantar surface. While stretching the foot and Achilles in this manner, use the web between your right thumb and index fingers to deeply press the Achilles tendon against the back of their tibia for 15-30 seconds; do this in several different areas of the tendon, especially just above the Achilles insertion on the calcaneus bone. Then place the leg back on the table, and firmly, quickly massage both heads of the gastrocnemius muscle and the Achilles tendon again. This process should take only a couple of minutes. Then switch to the other leg. The Achilles is ready to be needled only after this massage. Women who wear high heels will want to stretch their legs thoroughly before the treatment described above. Flat surface of the Achilles tendon: It is very interesting (and essential) to note that in most patients, the Achilles tendon is not straight; instead it angles either laterally or medially. This is because the tendon, which is attached to the gastrocnemius muscle, veers according to the structure of the bones beneath it (primarily the tibia, as the fibula is a floating bone).
