When needling Correct Tendons, we want our point location to be in the exact center of the width of the tendon, and our needle trajectory to be perfectly perpendicular to its flat surface. In most cases, because the tendon veers to one side or the other, the flat top of the tendon is not horizontal. I suggest using a guide tube, which allows you to firmly tap the needle into the tendon and also shows the perpendicular placement of the needle in the middle of the angled tendon. This determines and sets the trajectory of the needle, which is held by the tendon itself. Once the needle has been tapped, the only way to change this trajectory is to lift the tip of the needle out of the tendon to a position just beneath the skin. When the needle is “loose,” it can be repegged into the tendon again. Repegging the tendon is an important step that ensures a trajectory, which results in the gentle tapping of the back of the tibia. To confirm that the trajectory is correct, once you have tapped the needle in and removed the tube, use the tube to hold the needle erect. If it appears that the shaft of the needle is perfectly straight, and there are no tiny folds of skin around the needle (indicating an imperfect trajectory), you may proceed with your needle insertion (see directions below). If the shaft of your needle is not perfectly perpendicular to the flat top of the tendon (keeping in mind that the flat surface of the tendon may be at an angle), it is necessary to repeg the tendon in order to correct not only your insertion but also your trajectory, because the projection of an improperly placed needle will become greater and greater as the needle reaches its full depth. If you are using a 0.20 x 50mm needle and you do not feel the bone tap on the back of the tibia, you may have missed the back of the tibia altogether; in this case, it is necessary to determine which side of the tibia the needle has slid down. Contacting the periosteum on either the medial or lateral side of the tibia has a particular sensation and can be bad for the bone (see the paragraph that begins, “Needle sensation,” below). Use the crease: When locating 77.01 Upright Tendon, the more distal of the two points, place your index fingers on both the medial and lateral malleoli. Now, bring both fingers to the top of the tendon and notice that your lateral finger is approximately one cun distal to your medial one. If there is a significant crease in the skin on top of the tendon between your two fingers, you may choose to needle through that crease as it is already desensitized. However, it is not at all necessary to choose a crease; any point between your two fingers will work, because the location of the Correct Tendons points does not need to be exact. Just be sure to avoid any blood vessels that you can feel on top of the Achilles tendon; you may be able to see them, but they will slip around on top of the tendon when palpated. Needling through these blood vessels is painful, and it may damage the vessel. I experienced this when these points were repeatedly needled on me; many years later, this vessel is still enlarged with scar tissue and sensitive. Inserting the needle: With the patient lying face down in a face cradle, and a pillow elevating their toes slightly off the table, massage their calves as directed above. Standing on the side of the table, place the palm of your hand that is closest to the patient’s feet very gently over the heel of their foot. This hand position is to simply balance your body without putting any weight whatsoever on the patient’s foot. This same hand will incrementally insert the needle into the tendon, one millimeter at a time, once the needle has been tapped, checked, and confirmed as properly placed (see above). With your opposite hand, grasp the shaft of the needle, and while balancing this hand weightlessly against the patient’s gastrocnemius with your little finger, begin to apply downward pressure to the needle while it is incrementally inserted into the tendon. Once the Achilles tendon has been fully penetrated, there will be a discernable density change. Continue needle insertion until you very gently tap the back of the tibia. Gently tapping the back of the tibia: Patients feel even the most subtle bone tap, so anticipate it carefully to avoid plowing into the bone and damaging the periosteum (the bone’s protective layer). If you use a needle of the appropriate length (see above) but no bone tap is felt (a “donk,” as if against stone), then the needle has slid down on one side of the tibia or the other, and you need to determine which side it is. Sliding the needle shaft alongside the tibia may produce a slight electrical sensation that wraps around the tibia; this is not particularly uncomfortable for the patient, but it indicates incorrect needle placement and is unhealthy for the periosteum. If this occurs, or if you miss the bone tap, you need to remove the needle from the tendon (to just beneath the skin) and repeg it to correct the trajectory. Missing the bone tap indicates incorrect placement and does not provide a good therapeutic result. Needle sensation: When these points are needled correctly, most patients describe the needling sensation with words such as “thick,” rather than “painful.” If your needle insertion is painful, the needle gauge is probably too large, and you need to practice wielding a finer needle. Because these points are so powerful, being needled through the strongest tendon in the entire body, insertion alone is enough and no stimulation is required. Some patients experience a subtle sensation of qi moving through the legs and lower body quickly, somewhat slowing down through the lumbar spine, picking up speed through the thoracic vertebrae and then “slugging out” in the cervical spine before ascending up and over the head into the eyes. For this reason, I ask the patient (if they are awake) to mentally picture keeping their spine open, in order for the energy to pass through as easily as possible. Most people do not experience the subtleties of this sensation and shortly fall sound asleep. Retention: Because the qi has a long way to travel from one end of the body to the other, it is best to retain these needles for sixty minutes. The preferred position for needling Correct Tendons is face down, with the head resting in a face cradle. Patients need to be forewarned that their sinuses will always congest in this position; otherwise, they will become concerned about having contracted a common cold or flu from the face cradle. Beneath the face cradle, I always place a chair where the patient can rest their arms and, when necessary, reach for a box of Kleenex or ring a bell to get my attention. If a patient has lower back pain, the lengthy time in a facedown position may exacerbate the pain, even though their lower back will also benefit as the qi passes through on the way to the head, strengthening the entire spine. After removing the needles, I always have the patient turn over and rest with a bolster under their knees for at least five minutes. Make sure they do not cross their ankles and they let their sacrum gently settle into the table, straightening all their vertebrae up to the neck. If their lower back is uncomfortable, quickly needle KD3 Tai Xi bilaterally and retain for ten minutes. When they get up, their back will feel fine. I ask my patients to thoroughly stretch their calves and Achilles tendons before they go to bed that night and again the next morning, to alleviate any lingering tightness or tenderness in the tendon. Needling frequency: For best clinical results in severe cases, I have found that it is better to needle Correct Tendons three times in two weeks rather than once per week for three weeks. The decreased interval between treatments can make a big difference. Usually within two to three treatments, there is a significant improvement, though continued treatment may be required to complete recovery. Depth: 1.5-2.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Correct Tendons points are located on the back of the Achilles tendon between the Urinary Bladder and Kidney meridians, and they have the Reaction Areas of Brain and Spine. Upright Tendon is located between UB60 Kun Lun and KD3 Tai Xi. Before humans evolved to walk on two legs, the spine was the highest part of the body, and Mount Kun Lun represents this “highest mountain.” Both UB60 and Correct Tendons treat the spine and are especially effective for occipital headaches, whiplash, concussion, and brain diseases. Because Correct Tendons are needled deeply through the Achilles tendon to gently tap the back of the tibia, they activate both the tendon-treating-tendon and bone-treating-bone systems. Needling through this large tendon makes them also useful for treating spasms anywhere in the body, including spasms from menstrual cramping and plantar fasciitis. Tapping the bone enhances the function of Kidney tonification because it relates to the brain, spine and bone marrow. Correct Tendons regulates the qi either by raising the yang to warm the entire body or by descending excess yang qi and dispersing wind from the head and spine. Neck and head: The Correct Tendons point pattern is among my top five favorites in Tung’s acupuncture because it is clinically outstanding for any disease involving the cervical spine, occipital area or cerebellum. Interestingly, is it said that if the Achilles tendon is cut, the head cannot be held erect. These points are my first choice for head and neck injuries such as whiplash, concussion, neck pain or stiffness (including protruding or herniated discs and stenosis), occipital headaches, and intracranial injury or disease. Correct Tendons points are so powerful that it is rarely necessary to add any other points; however, I often cup the entire upper back and neck before needling these points. Lumbar spine: Correct Tendons adjusts misalignment all the way up the spine, so when there are lumbar or thoracic anomalies, they respond to the use of Correct Tendons in the treatment of the head or neck. Although these points can be used for lower back pain, I am likely to choose other points if the patient does not have any head or neck indications, because Master Tung’s system has so many points to choose from. Ankylosing spondylitis: Ankylosing spondylitis is a condition that causes the fusion of the entire spinal column. The slow calcification of the spine gradually causes a bending forward which results in the patient looking only at the ground when walking. It is more commonly found among twenty- to forty-year-old men of Jewish decent; however, I treated two Chinese brothers who had this condition. Ankylosing spondylitis can also be the result of interactions of both pharmaceutical and recreational drugs. My mother had this condition from a lifetime of taking aspirin on a daily basis. Treatment: My primary treatment for this condition is bamboo cupping of the entire spine, every two weeks. Bamboo cupping is a bleeding technique that utilizes small sections of bamboo that are boiled and placed over a small puncture made between the posterior spinous processes of the vertebra. The boiled bamboo cups create a suction which draws a small clot of blood from between all the vertebrae, thus vitalizing the blood and preventing further calcification. What is already fused will not unfuse, but you can stop the progression. I have successfully treated three cases using bamboo cupping along with Correct Tendons. Bamboo cupping takes 20-30 minutes, so insert Correct Tendons first, as this will make for a much more efficient treatment. Ankylosing spondylitis is a condition that allopathic medicine has not been able to treat successfully. Herbal formulas: I have treated three patients using the formula Kang Gu Zeng Sheng Pien. This formula strengthens qi and yang; tonifies Kidney and Liver; fortifies marrow, tendon and bone; clears damp; relieves pain; and is used specifically for calcification following injury, or in spontaneous multiplicative spondylitis. It is good for tendon pain and numbness, as well as chronic vertebral subluxations and spinal inflammation. Another popular formula is Shen Jin Tong Bi Wan, which dispels wind, cold and damp that invades as the result of an overall deficiency. Other individual ankylosing spondylitis treatment options (given in no specific order): Bleed UB40 Wei Zhong; bilaterally needle 88.12 Bright Yellow. Bilaterally needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Middle, 22.06 Zhong Bai (Middle White), 1010.13 Horse Gold Water, 11.12 Er Jiao Ming (Two Corner Bright). Bilaterally needle 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles, SI3 Hou Xi. Needled bilaterally 77.09 Four Flower Middle, 77.10 Four Flower Quasi. Bilaterally needle 77.18 Kidney Gate, 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7), SI3 Hou Xi and UB65 Shu Gu (if there is Kidney deficiency). Needle DU26 Ren Zhong; bilaterally needle LI11 Qu Chi; moxa UB18-UB20. Bilaterally needle 11.11 Lung Heart. Case history (ankylosing spondylitis): A 34-year-old male reported having the constant sensation of a cement block between his shoulder blades, indicative of his thoracic spine beginning to fuse. His lumbar vertebrae had already fused and were no longer painful. Once a week for eighteen months, I needled Correct Tendons, and every other week I bamboo-cupped his entire thoracic and lumbar spine. Within three months, he reported that the heaviness between his shoulder blades was largely gone. By the time we discontinued treatment, he was comfortable and the calcification had stopped. I have treated four other cases with similar results; however his was the most profound, I think because he was the youngest. It is my belief that in all of these cases, without bamboo cupping and Correct Tendons, these patients would have lived their life facing the ground. Case history (severe occipital headache): I was called to the hospital to treat a young man who had been admitted ten days earlier due to a severe occipital headache. His doctor had placed him on an intravenous morphine drip, but this provided him with no relief. First, I did a simple but thorough Gua Sha treatment on the back of his neck, and then I needled Correct Tendons. As soon as the needles were inserted the headache began to recede. The following day, the young man was able to leave the hospital. The doctor and nursing staff were thoroughly impressed. This is the power of Correct Tendons. Case history (chronic neck restriction): One of my patients was an arborist who had been unable to turn her head to either side or move it up and down for more than ten years. Her job was at stake. I began treatment by thoroughly cupping her entire neck and shoulders in a sitting position, in order to cup the musculature without gaps. The cup marks were black. Immediately after cupping she had a fifty percent improvement in the mobility of her neck. I then needled Correct Tendons, retaining the needles for one hour, after which her mobility increased to eighty percent. Despite her marked improvement, when she arrived home, her family convinced her that the cup marks were evidence that she had been abused. This inspired me to create a tri-fold color brochure with photographs of dark cup marks taken on days one, three, five and seven following a thorough cupping session. This brochure explains what to expect during and after cupping therapy. I have shown it to patients before cupping sessions ever since I treated the arborist. Case history (paralysis and coldness, Dr. Lee): “A 22-year-old man had been in a car accident four years before and had broken his neck. He was paralyzed from the neck down and his arms were getting weaker and weaker. All other treatments had failed so he came to see me. Although it was the hot part of summer, he wore a heavy winter jacket. He would also always ask for a glass of warm water to wrap his hands around in an effort to warm them. In addition, he would always ask me to order him a hot meal. When I palpated his neck at DU16 Feng Fu, just below the base of the skull, there was severe pain. This meant that there was still blood stasis that was obstructing the flow of yang qi. I told him he would have to receive three treatments per week. After needling him the first two times at Correct Tendons the sub-occipital pain was lessened. After three treatments he said he could breathe deeper. After the fourth and fifth treatments, he said his whole body felt warmer. A few weeks later, he no longer needed to warm his hands by wrapping them around a hot glass of water” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Case history (severe headache, Dr. Lee): “A 50-year-old woodcutter was knocked down by a tree and his head was shaken backwards violently. After being hospitalized, he still had severe headaches all the time. Each time his physician refilled his pain medication it would be for 100 pills, and his wife had to inject him with morphine every three hours. Over a period of two years, he had five heart attacks due to such heavy pain medication, since it is well known that pain medications affect the heart. Finally a doctor referred him to me with severe insomnia and severe headache. I needled 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons. He then slept, hard. After 45 minutes he awoke and I asked him to gently shake his head. He shook it a little and there was no pain. Then I asked him to shake it more forcefully and still there was no pain. The man stood up. He said he could not believe it. I asked him what he could not believe. He just kept saying he could not believe it. I called his wife into the office and she asked him what he could not believe. He said he could not believe he no longer had a headache. Then she said she could not believe it. I explained to the patient that he should not do any heavy lifting or any heavy work. He left my office and returned home. After sitting around the house for one week, the man grew bored and did some digging in order to plant some flowers. This caused him to get a headache again. He came back to my office and we did several more treatments. Finally, we got rid of all his headaches” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Case history (pain in the spine, Dr. Lee): “A patient had pain in every joint of her spine. Correct Tendons points were needled in three subsequent treatments. The first treatment cleared her neck, the second cleared the spine to five inches below her neck, and the third cleared her whole back, and the pain was gone” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Case history (occipital headache, Dr. Lee): “This point is also very effective for the treatment of occipital headache due to past trauma to the back of the head or neck. For instance, this area can be injured if a child has been shaken violently back and forth. Often this will not cause problems when the child is young but may result in occipital headaches when the person is in their late twenties or thirties” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Plantar fasciitis or Achilles tendon pain: Needle opposite-side 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons. Brain tumor, meningitis or severe occipital headache: 55.06 Upper Tumor, 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons (needle twice daily if possible). Twisted back: 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through, bleed UB40 Wei Zhong, then use 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons. I was with Miriam when she treated this patient. In addition to needling 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons, she cupped the patient’s neck and upper back; the skin was black after cupping. She also needled 55.06 Upper Tumor.

name: Zhengshi, Upright Scholar (T 77.03)
location: This point is on the Achilles tendon, 5.5 cun proximal to the bottom of the heel or 4 cun proximal to Zhengjin (T 77.01) , which is midway between Kunlun (BL 60) and Taixi (KI 3) on the midline of the posterior aspect of the lower leg. | Johnson: Upright Scholar is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) superior to 77.02 Upright Ancestry (six fingers above 77.01 Upright Tendon).
johnson_indications: Upper back, shoulder and hand pain
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1.5 cun . Use a thicker gauge needle and pierce through the tendon to touch the bone for optimal effect. For stronger patients, needle in a sitting position. For weak patients, needle in a prone or sideway position. | Johnson: Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Upright Scholar, located on the Urinary Bladder meridian, can be needled with 77.04 Catching Ball to treat back pain in the area of UB43 Gao Huang Shu, the low back, or sciatic pain. Upright Scholar can also be added to 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons to enhance the treatment effect of those points; however, it is not typically done and is unnecessary. I rarely use these points because there are so many better options. Back pain and UB sciatica: Upright Scholar with 77.04 Catching Ball can be used in the treatment of sciatica due to the relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yang (UB), but because there are so many great points for sciatica, for better results I would choose among: SI3 Hou Xi, UB65 Shu Gu, 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 33.08-33.09 Arm Five Gold/One Thousand Gold and 1010.22 Nose Wing. For the UB43 area, I use 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy instead.

name: Boqiu, Catching Ball (T 77.04)
location: This point is 1.5 cun distal to Chengshan (BL 57) on the midline of the posterior aspect of the lower leg where the Achilles tendon leaves the gastrocnemius muscle. | Johnson: Catching Ball is located 2.5 cun superior to 77.03 Upright Scholar, 1.5 cun distal to UB57 Cheng Shan. The classic book location of UB40 is in the center of the knee crease, between the tendons; however, because I never needle this point and only use it as a bleeding point, I choose any visible vein in the back of the knee.
primary_indications: Cramps and spasms of the lower leg
secondary_indications: Nosebleed Occipital headache Lower back pain Huo luan (sudden turmoil disorder) Hemorrhoids Athlete's foot
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . It is best if the tip of the needle touches the bone. For severe cramping of the calf, needle may need to be retained for 2-3 hours. This point can also be bled. Bleeding visible dark veins near this point can immediately relieve back pain and spasms. | Johnson: Bleed the same side as the indication if a vessel is present, but only if no good vessel is found at UB40 Wei Zhong. Needle the opposite side for musculoskeletal conditions, or bilaterally for internal diseases. Depth: 1.0-2.0 cun
comments: Hemorrhoids: I have found that bleeding in the popliteal crease is the most effective way of treating hemorrhoids, and it usually produces immediate results. If multiple veins are available, bleed all of them. Be wary of vessels on the far lateral side of the popliteal crease. If you puncture the nerve in that area, the patient may experience a light, tingling nerve pain for a few weeks until the nerve heals. Catching Ball can be bled instead of UB40 Wei Zhong if there is no visible vessel at UB40; however, I am reluctant to do so because the gastrocnemius is a very strong muscle and any injury to it would be felt with every step. Spasm: Because tendon treats tendon, Catching Ball can be used for spasms or any kind of injury to the tendon. The name of this point refers to its location on the lower leg; the “ball” is the gastrocnemius muscle. This point can be used in the treatment of cholera because of the intense leg cramps that can be associated with that disease. However, because the needling itself may cause contracture of the gastrocnemius, I avoid Catching Ball and/or its use as a Dao Ma with 77.03 Upright Scholar because this local needling would possibly aggravate the condition.
combinations: Back or lower back (especially in UB43 area): 77.03 Upright Scholar, 77.04 Catching Ball. •  Cramping in cholera/gastroenteritis: 77.04 Catching Ball, 77.09 Four Flower Middle. •  Hemorrhoids: Bleed UB40 Wei Zhong or 77.04 Catching Ball. •  Gastrocnemius muscle pain: 77.04 Catching Ball, 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles, 33.03 This Uprightness, 33.04 Fire Threaded. Or needle 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons. •  Kidney deficiency: 77.04 Catching Ball, 77.09 Four Flower Middle. •  Spasm of leg muscles: 77.03 Upright Scholar, 77.04 Catching Ball (see Comments above). •  Dysmenorrhea (Dr. Young): Bilaterally needle 77.04 Catching Ball (UB57), 66.03 Fire Hardness; unilaterally needle 66.05 Golden Gate (ST43), REN24 Cheng Jiang (Jing-Well point of the Ren Channel); needle right-side 66.02 Wood Wife.

name: Yizhong, First Weight (T 77.05)
location: This point is between the GB and ST channels, 3 cun proximal to the lateral malleolus, and 1 cun anterior to the fibula. This point is at the same level of Xuanzhong (GB 39) . | Johnson: 77.05 First Weight is located on the lateral lower leg, 3.0 cun (four fingers) above the tip of the external malleolus, midway between the anterior edge of the fibula and the anterior tibial crest (approximately 1.0 cun lateral to the anterior tibial crest). Though Textbook GB39 is found on the back of the fibula, an antique version of the point is located on the anterior border. Because the anterior border can be difficult to palpate, start from Textbook GB39. 77.06 Second Weight is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) directly superior to First Weight. Palpate for the point, starting 0.5 cun above its landmark location. (See Needling Notes.) 77.07 Third Weight is located 2.0 cun directly superior to Second Weight. This point may be found slightly more lateral than the lower two points because the calf flares at this level. Again, palpate precisely for best results.
primary_indications: deviation of the eyes and mouth
abdominal mass Tumors and cancer: brain
secondary_indications: Cold bi zheng (painful obstruction syndrome) caused by excessive sexual activities
johnson_indications: Psychological issues due to wind and phlegm (such as mania, schizophrenia, phlegm masking the orifices)*
Bulging eyeballs due to brain tumor or hyperthyroidism
Splenomegaly (needle on the right side only) (Carson, 1973)*
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . Needle the healthy side when treating TMJ or deviation of the eyes and mouth. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 77.05 First Weight (Chief Point) is needled with Supporting Points 77.06 Second Weight and 77.07 Third Weight in the combination known as 77.05-77.07 Three Weights. These three points are most frequently needled together; however, it should 281 Lower Leg Points be noted that 77.07 Third Weight is similar in location to 77.14 Four Flower Outer/ Textbook ST40 and thus has a stronger influence than First Weight or Second Weight on phlegm. Palpation: When palpating 77.05-77.07 Three Weights, one can feel a pool of energy about the diameter of a pencil eraser. Because these points are easy to feel, I specifically recommend them to students for practicing precise point palpation. With most points in Tung’s system (and these in particular), while I emphasize knowing the exact anatomical location, I always start 0.5 cun above the expected location and then walk my finger downward, palpating for the precise point. In general, it is important to learn how to “feel” acupuncture points. Learn to place your consciousness in the tip of your palpating finger. Do not be discouraged if this takes time, practice and focus. Often the patient will feel when you are on the point, but don’t ask them to tell you where it is, because they might mislead you. Learn to rely on your own palpation by training yourself to feel for the points. Bleeding: Dark veins found in the vicinity of Three Weights are commonly bled to disperse phlegm and blood stagnation. Unilateral vs. bilateral: For one-sided conditions, such as Bell’s palsy, trigeminal neuralgia, TMJ, or pain in a breast, rib, hip, neck or shoulder, needle opposite the affected side. Needle bilaterally to treat systemic diseases and most brain disorders. Direction of stimulation: Almost without exception, when needling these points, we are directing the qi toward the head or the hip, breast, rib or shoulder girdle (including scapula and arm) on the side opposite the pain. For this reason, insert the three needles and then stimulate them distal to proximal (bottom to top). Spleen and liver: For splenomegaly or spleen organ issues, including blood diseases, needle Three Weights on the right side, opposite the spleen. For liver blood diseases, needle either bilaterally or on the left side, opposite the liver organ. Needle sensation: When these needles are inserted, the patient might feel a zing of energy descend down the leg. If the sensation stops at GB40, massage the area extending down the Gallbladder channel and gently tug on the fourth toe or stimulate the needle until the sensation reaches either LV3 or GB41. Do not leave the energy stuck at GB40 or the patient may have difficulty walking when they stand up after the treatment. When Three Weights are needled or even palpated, patients sometimes feel energy movement in their head, as well. Retention: If you are treating the brain, needles should be retained a full hour. Depth: 1.0 cun
comments: Other names for Three Weights: In the past, the Three Weights points were also called Three Measures or Three Layers. These names are correct and may appear in other written materials. Energetic pathways: The Three Weights points have a profound influence on any disease having to do with wind and phlegm because they are located between the Foot Shao Yang (GB), which dispels wind, and the Foot Yang Ming (ST), which drains dampness. 77.05 First Weight is anterior to GB39, the Meeting Point of Marrow; thus, Three Weights stimulates the production of healthy marrow and blood within the bone. These points are extremely important in influencing the blood, due to the fact that the Liver governs the blood and the Spleen controls the blood, and also due to the internal/external relationships between Liver and Gallbladder, Spleen and Stomach, and the Reaction Areas of Heart, Lung and Spleen. Furthermore, the relationship between the Hand and Foot Shao Yang (SJ/GB) relates to tendons, ligaments, neck, shoulder, arm, wrist and fingers; this also ties into the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yin (KD), influencing bones and brain. Brain: Three Weights treats brain injuries and stroke, in part because the Gallbladder meridian wraps around the head. Widely used with bleeding techniques, these points vitalize the blood by dispersing blood stagnation. They clear the brain and open the orifices by dispersing phlegm and dampness, and they extinguish draft and spasm to restore the brain’s proper motor and sensory functions. Some practitioners report that Three Weights points are more effective for the treatment of functional brain issues than for brain tumors. I have seen good results in the treatment of both functional issues and tumors. Liver organ disease: In cases of serious liver disease, I use 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows with 11.20 Wood Inflammation. However, liver function also improves if I use Three Weights to treat any of the indications listed above. Psychological issues and brain injury: Many psychiatric ailments are actually the result of what Chinese medicine would call “wind and phlegm obstructing the orifices.” This category could include schizophrenia, epilepsy, manic depression, certain types of insomnia and even Alzheimer’s and dementia. Because the Three Weights points have a very powerful ability to circulate blood in the brain, in addition to treating all of the above, they are an excellent choice for the treatment of cerebrovascular events that result in brain damage or deficiencies. Three Weights could be useful in any situation of oxygen depletion to the brain, such as drowning, or brain injury. They should be considered when treating everything from a mild concussion to a severe brain injury, such as frontal lobe impact from a car collision, or for diseases such as encephalitis or hydrocephalus. In these instances, I would consider adding 55.06 Upper Tumor variations. •  Case history (neck arterial occlusion): Because Tung’s system has so many options for treating neck and shoulder pain, and many of them are Gallbladder channel related, I choose to use Three Weights for neck and shoulder issues when there are blood diseases or any symptoms related to the indications for Three Weights. For example, I treated an elderly gentleman with an intravertebral artery that was 100% occluded in his neck. This condition originally caused him to have extreme dizziness and falling incidents. A neurosurgeon said the artery was inoperable because it had become blocked over a period of perhaps 40 years, and if it were surgically cleared, his brain – which had adapted over time to the reduction in blood flow – would be flooded, causing him to die instantly. With treatments including Three Weights, three times weekly for two months, his dizzy spells stopped completely. It is my assumption that this result had to do with the rerouting of the blood supply to his brain. After eighteen months with no episodes, we discontinued treatment with Three Weights to work on his new diagnosis of macular degeneration. Several years later, the macular degeneration is now completely resolved; however, he has begun to experience some dizziness again, as well as signs of dementia. I have begun treatment using 55.02 Flower Bone One to maintain the eyes and Three Weights to clear the brain. Both of these target the head, and so they can be effectively combined, bilaterally. Breast disease: Because ST17 is found on the nipple, and the Gallbladder meridian traverses the side of the breast, opposite-side Three Weights can relieve breast congestion, inflammation and/or tumor. Women who have had surgical procedures often have complications with the lymphatic system, making Three Weights the best choice for treating lymphedema of the arm, due to the wind, phlegm and circulatory influences of these points. Dr. Lee cautioned that for chronic problems such as spleen enlargement and breast cancer, one must be persistent because these conditions cannot be cured easily or quickly. Bleeding dark veins found between the Stomach and Gallbladder channels can be very helpful in reducing swollen and painful breasts.•  Heart and thyroid: Hypothyroidism occurs when the thyroid produces too little hormone. Hyperthyroidism occurs when the thyroid produces too much hormone. Both can be implicated in heart disease. Hypothyroidism may result in a slow heart rate, a rise in cholesterol, narrowing of the arteries and an increase in fluid surrounding the heart, potentially causing heart failure. Hyperthyroidism causes the heart to beat faster, which can lead to palpitations or an irregular heartbeat, known as atrial fibrillation. A rapid heartbeat can lead to heart failure, and atrial fibrillation also increases the risk of blood clots forming and passing to the brain, resulting in stroke. Hyperthyroid-related heart disease may include bulging eyeballs. combinations: Bell’s palsy, facial paralysis, trigeminal neuralgia: See 22.04 Da Bai, Combinations, 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/ Four Flower Middle and 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles for additional treatment information.•  Hip pain: With the patient lying on their side, and a large pillow supporting the upper leg and knee, thoroughly cup the sacrum and the hip joint, being sure to target GB29, GB30, UB36 and UB34 (cup no lower than GB31). name: Erzhong, Second Weight (T 77.06)
location: This point is between the GB and ST channels, 5 cun proximal to the lateral malleolus and 1 cun anterior to the fibula. It is 2 cun above Yizhong (T 77.05) . | Johnson: 77.05 First Weight is located on the lateral lower leg, 3.0 cun (four fingers) above the tip of the external malleolus, midway between the anterior edge of the fibula and the anterior tibial crest (approximately 1.0 cun lateral to the anterior tibial crest). Though Textbook GB39 is found on the back of the fibula, an antique version of the point is located on the anterior border. Because the anterior border can be difficult to palpate, start from Textbook GB39. 77.06 Second Weight is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) directly superior to First Weight. Palpate for the point, starting 0.5 cun above its landmark location. (See Needling Notes.) 77.07 Third Weight is located 2.0 cun directly superior to Second Weight. This point may be found slightly more lateral than the lower two points because the calf flares at this level. Again, palpate precisely for best results.
primary_indications: breast pain Tumors and cancer: brain
johnson_indications: Psychological issues due to wind and phlegm (such as mania, schizophrenia, phlegm masking the orifices)*
Bulging eyeballs due to brain tumor or hyperthyroidism
Splenomegaly (needle on the right side only) (Carson, 1973)*
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . Needle the healthy side when treating TMJ or deviation of the eyes and mouth. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 77.05 First Weight (Chief Point) is needled with Supporting Points 77.06 Second Weight and 77.07 Third Weight in the combination known as 77.05-77.07 Three Weights. These three points are most frequently needled together; however, it should 281 Lower Leg Points be noted that 77.07 Third Weight is similar in location to 77.14 Four Flower Outer/ Textbook ST40 and thus has a stronger influence than First Weight or Second Weight on phlegm. Palpation: When palpating 77.05-77.07 Three Weights, one can feel a pool of energy about the diameter of a pencil eraser. Because these points are easy to feel, I specifically recommend them to students for practicing precise point palpation. With most points in Tung’s system (and these in particular), while I emphasize knowing the exact anatomical location, I always start 0.5 cun above the expected location and then walk my finger downward, palpating for the precise point. In general, it is important to learn how to “feel” acupuncture points. Learn to place your consciousness in the tip of your palpating finger. Do not be discouraged if this takes time, practice and focus. Often the patient will feel when you are on the point, but don’t ask them to tell you where it is, because they might mislead you. Learn to rely on your own palpation by training yourself to feel for the points. Bleeding: Dark veins found in the vicinity of Three Weights are commonly bled to disperse phlegm and blood stagnation. Unilateral vs. bilateral: For one-sided conditions, such as Bell’s palsy, trigeminal neuralgia, TMJ, or pain in a breast, rib, hip, neck or shoulder, needle opposite the affected side. Needle bilaterally to treat systemic diseases and most brain disorders. Direction of stimulation: Almost without exception, when needling these points, we are directing the qi toward the head or the hip, breast, rib or shoulder girdle (including scapula and arm) on the side opposite the pain. For this reason, insert the three needles and then stimulate them distal to proximal (bottom to top). Spleen and liver: For splenomegaly or spleen organ issues, including blood diseases, needle Three Weights on the right side, opposite the spleen. For liver blood diseases, needle either bilaterally or on the left side, opposite the liver organ. Needle sensation: When these needles are inserted, the patient might feel a zing of energy descend down the leg. If the sensation stops at GB40, massage the area extending down the Gallbladder channel and gently tug on the fourth toe or stimulate the needle until the sensation reaches either LV3 or GB41. Do not leave the energy stuck at GB40 or the patient may have difficulty walking when they stand up after the treatment. When Three Weights are needled or even palpated, patients sometimes feel energy movement in their head, as well. Retention: If you are treating the brain, needles should be retained a full hour. Depth: 1.0 cun
comments: Other names for Three Weights: In the past, the Three Weights points were also called Three Measures or Three Layers. These names are correct and may appear in other written materials. Energetic pathways: The Three Weights points have a profound influence on any disease having to do with wind and phlegm because they are located between the Foot Shao Yang (GB), which dispels wind, and the Foot Yang Ming (ST), which drains dampness. 77.05 First Weight is anterior to GB39, the Meeting Point of Marrow; thus, Three Weights stimulates the production of healthy marrow and blood within the bone. These points are extremely important in influencing the blood, due to the fact that the Liver governs the blood and the Spleen controls the blood, and also due to the internal/external relationships between Liver and Gallbladder, Spleen and Stomach, and the Reaction Areas of Heart, Lung and Spleen. Furthermore, the relationship between the Hand and Foot Shao Yang (SJ/GB) relates to tendons, ligaments, neck, shoulder, arm, wrist and fingers; this also ties into the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yang (SJ) and Foot Shao Yin (KD), influencing bones and brain. Brain: Three Weights treats brain injuries and stroke, in part because the Gallbladder meridian wraps around the head. Widely used with bleeding techniques, these points vitalize the blood by dispersing blood stagnation. They clear the brain and open the orifices by dispersing phlegm and dampness, and they extinguish draft and spasm to restore the brain’s proper motor and sensory functions. Some practitioners report that Three Weights points are more effective for the treatment of functional brain issues than for brain tumors. I have seen good results in the treatment of both functional issues and tumors. Liver organ disease: In cases of serious liver disease, I use 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows with 11.20 Wood Inflammation. However, liver function also improves if I use Three Weights to treat any of the indications listed above. Psychological issues and brain injury: Many psychiatric ailments are actually the result of what Chinese medicine would call “wind and phlegm obstructing the orifices.” This category could include schizophrenia, epilepsy, manic depression, certain types of insomnia and even Alzheimer’s and dementia. Because the Three Weights points have a very powerful ability to circulate blood in the brain, in addition to treating all of the above, they are an excellent choice for the treatment of cerebrovascular events that result in brain damage or deficiencies. Three Weights could be useful in any situation of oxygen depletion to the brain, such as drowning, or brain injury. They should be considered when treating everything from a mild concussion to a severe brain injury, such as frontal lobe impact from a car collision, or for diseases such as encephalitis or hydrocephalus. In these instances, I would consider adding 55.06 Upper Tumor variations. •  Case history (neck arterial occlusion): Because Tung’s system has so many options for treating neck and shoulder pain, and many of them are Gallbladder channel related, I choose to use Three Weights for neck and shoulder issues when there are blood diseases or any symptoms related to the indications for Three Weights. For example, I treated an elderly gentleman with an intravertebral artery that was 100% occluded in his neck. This condition originally caused him to have extreme dizziness and falling incidents. A neurosurgeon said the artery was inoperable because it had become blocked over a period of perhaps 40 years, and if it were surgically cleared, his brain – which had adapted over time to the reduction in blood flow – would be flooded, causing him to die instantly. With treatments including Three Weights, three times weekly for two months, his dizzy spells stopped completely. It is my assumption that this result had to do with the rerouting of the blood supply to his brain. After eighteen months with no episodes, we discontinued treatment with Three Weights to work on his new diagnosis of macular degeneration. Several years later, the macular degeneration is now completely resolved; however, he has begun to experience some dizziness again, as well as signs of dementia. I have begun treatment using 55.02 Flower Bone One to maintain the eyes and Three Weights to clear the brain. Both of these target the head, and so they can be effectively combined, bilaterally. Breast disease: Because ST17 is found on the nipple, and the Gallbladder meridian traverses the side of the breast, opposite-side Three Weights can relieve breast congestion, inflammation and/or tumor. Women who have had surgical procedures often have complications with the lymphatic system, making Three Weights the best choice for treating lymphedema of the arm, due to the wind, phlegm and circulatory influences of these points. Dr. Lee cautioned that for chronic problems such as spleen enlargement and breast cancer, one must be persistent because these conditions cannot be cured easily or quickly. Bleeding dark veins found between the Stomach and Gallbladder channels can be very helpful in reducing swollen and painful breasts.•  Heart and thyroid: Hypothyroidism occurs when the thyroid produces too little hormone. Hyperthyroidism occurs when the thyroid produces too much hormone. Both can be implicated in heart disease. Hypothyroidism may result in a slow heart rate, a rise in cholesterol, narrowing of the arteries and an increase in fluid surrounding the heart, potentially causing heart failure. Hyperthyroidism causes the heart to beat faster, which can lead to palpitations or an irregular heartbeat, known as atrial fibrillation. A rapid heartbeat can lead to heart failure, and atrial fibrillation also increases the risk of blood clots forming and passing to the brain, resulting in stroke. Hyperthyroid-related heart disease may include bulging eyeballs. TCM teaches that chronic, difficult, strange or complicated diseases always have to do with phlegm or blood stagnation, so bleeding points such as Three Weights or 77.14 Four Flower Outer (ST40) is especially helpful for hyperthyroidism due to wind, phlegm or blood stagnation.
