name: Sihuashang, Earth Water (Tung’s LU10)
location: This point overlaps with Zusanli (ST 36) , which is 3 cun below the depression lateral to the patella ligament. | Johnson: Four Flower Upper is MasterTung’s version of ST36 Zu San Li. I do not use the textbook TCM method to locate this point. Needling Four Flower Upper in the manner described here will almost always elicit a strong qi sensation down the leg, resulting in immediate and outstanding results; therefore, I highly recommend the practitioner carefully and precisely execute the following directions: With one finger on the proximal head of the fibula and another on the base of the tibial tuberosity, draw a horizontal line from the base of the tibial tuberosity that intersects a vertical line drawn directly downward from the head of the fibula. Divide your horizontal line into equal thirds. Four Flower Upper is located one third of the distance lateral from the base of the tibial tuberosity. (77.22 Beside Three Miles is located two thirds of the distance.) •  Accurately verifying the base of the tibial tuberosity will confirm your point location. If you are less than 1.0 cun inferior (on a very tall patient it can be as much as 4 cun) to the head of the fibula, check the base of the tibial tuberosity again, as there is often a further extension that is easily missed. Starting 0.5 cun above and walking your finger downward into this point will help you to identify the exact location and hone your palpation skills, as the power of this point makes it very easy to feel. Note: Please see the drawing above for a good visual depiction of the point location. Four Flower Upper increases stomach acid; do not needle in cases of acid reflux or hot-type stomach ulcer.
primary_indications: stomach ulcers Cardiovascular disorders: coronary heart disease
johnson_indications: Deformity or swelling of the bones of the hands
techniques: Needle 2 cun for respiratory conditions, 3 cun for cardiovascular conditions. Needle along the edge of the tibia for maximum effect. This point can also be bled. Bleeding the dark veins in this area can also be effective for chronic history of any of the conditions listed above. | Johnson: Qi sensation: Four Flower Upper (ST36) is easily felt. The patient will know when you are on the point, and you will know, too, because you can palpate a large pool of energy there. Some practitioners describe this energy as a hole. When the point is needled, patients frequently feel a strong qi sensation traveling down their leg, perhaps to the second toe. They describe this sensation in different ways, including electrical, crampy or heavy. Some of my patients feel this sensation as soon as I palpate the point. Sometimes the electrical sensation occurs in both legs, but often it is only on one side, clearing the opposite side, automatically. Ask the patient not to wiggle their legs as you are inserting the needles. If the sensation is intense, I encourage them to wiggle their hands instead. Although the feeling is strong for two or three seconds, within 10 minutes the qi finds its equilibrium and the sensation fades completely. Always provide the patient with a bell or another way to alert you if they need a needle adjusted.•  Varicosities: Often, patients who have varicosities at or beneath ST36, do not want Four Flower Upper (ST36) to be needled, because they remember it as painful. Even when varicosities are not visible, frequently they can be felt beneath the surface as lumpy, squishy, collapsing tissue rather than the smooth feeling of healthy muscle. In such cases, avoiding the varicosities (which is usually recommended) may require treating an entirely different point that is far from ST36. The practitioner has to decide whether to choose a different point altogether or quickly penetrate through the vessel into the deeper tissue underneath, a technique that is only temporarily uncomfortable for the patient. Shallow needling is not recommended in these cases. For one patient I treated, choosing a different point was out of the question. After approximately three months of regular needling of ST36 through this patient’s varicosities, a 3.5” diameter area surrounding the point became firm and smooth in texture, free of varicosities, although they could still be palpated just outside that area. It was remarkable. •  Bleeding: When bleeding, always choose dark vessels in the area rather than the points themselves. I use a three-edged needle, though a 14-gauge hypodermic needle tip can be substituted. In all instances, avoid touching the tibia with the tip of any bleeding needle. If you substitute a hollow hypodermic needle tip for a three-edged needle, you may want to cover the open end with medical tape, both to prevent blood from passing quickly through the needle and to improve your grip. If I am bleeding multiple small veins (between eight and thirty sites) on the lower legs, I may choose a spring-loaded lancet, pushing hard and puncturing three times in quick succession at each site. Where there is a plethora of varicosities, this procedure results in a large volume of black blood, so I always do it with the patient sitting on a shower chair in a bathtub, where cleanup is quick and easy. Allow the body to expel as much blood as it desires. When the bleeding is completely finished, dry the legs thoroughly until all the punctures have clotted. Then, treat the patient with acupuncture, keeping them in your vicinity for at least thirty minutes. Though some people may be concerned about the quantity of blood lost, this black blood was already out of circulation before the bleeding treatment. Relieving the body of its “dirty” blood in this way stimulates the bone marrow to produce fresh, healthy, oxygenated new blood. Make sure you tell your patients to rest, eat well, and go to bed early following a bleeding procedure. Never bleed a patient who has low blood sugar.•  Relax the legs: Before needling Four Flower Upper and Four Flower Middle, rock your patient’s legs gently from side to side to ensure the muscles are completely relaxed, because the deep needling done on these points will prevent them from relaxing the muscles once the needles are inserted. Notice the position of their feet; patients who hold their big toes together are subconsciously engaging their thigh muscles. Do not try to separate their feet, but bring their attention to this simply by asking them to allow their knees to fall outward. •  Same side or opposite side: Four Flower points may be needled on the same side or opposite side to treat pain of the shoulders, arms, elbows and index finger. Stomach meridian points are the only points that are equally effective when needled on the same or opposite side of the pathology. •  Needle depth and retention: Deep insertion is common with this point; it often requires a 60mm needle. If the patient is less than 5’ tall, a 40mm needle insertion is adequate. Patients taller than 6’ require a 60mm needle for issues affecting their head. While deep insertion is initially sedating, when the needle is retained for a long time, it tonifies the point. When needling the bottom to treat the top (legs to head), use a deeper needle and retain it for a longer period of time, up to one hour, even when the effects are immediately noticed. •  Depths: Four Flower Upper is a good point to contrast deep and shallow needling techniques, as a deep needle is required in order for the qi to reach the head. Insertion of 0.5-1.0 cun gently tonifies or addresses adjacent conditions, such as knee or toe pain. Insertion of 1.0-2.0 cun can reach the abdomen. Insertion of 2.0-2.5 cun will effectively treat heart disease and angina. Inserting a 60mm needle is the most effective for glaucoma and frontal headache. Face and head disorders: 2.5-3.0 cun •  Heart disease and asthma: 2.0-2.5 cun •  Gastrointestinal disease: 1.0-2.0 cun•  Leg disease: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: T36 was one of Dr. Lee’s favorite points. She would say, “When you don’t know what to do, needle ST36.” (Note: Dr. Young feels the same way about GB31.)•  Energetic pathways: As the most powerful tonification and He-Sea point of the entire body, Four Flower Upper (ST36) regulates and adjusts the qi and blood of all the channels, strengthening the Spleen and Stomach to treat a wide variety of chronic illnesses. Because Four Flower Upper is needled alongside the tibia (one finger’s breadth lateral to the anterior tibial crest), the point has a bone-treating-bone Kidney tonification function, whether treating Spleen and Kidney yang deficiency or Liver and Kidney yin deficiency. Four Flower Upper goes to the Kidney level, treating chronic problems as well as those involving the Luo channels. It is very good for any problem on the front of the body, head, chest and/or abdomen. Four Flower Upper has the Reaction Areas of Heart and Lung. As the earth point on an earth meridian, following the mother/child producing cycle, Four Flower Upper tonifies earth to generate metal and is thus very effective for treating many conditions such as asthma and Crohn’s disease. Due to the special relationship between the Foot Yang Ming (Stomach) and Hand Jue Yin (Pericardium), Four Flower Upper is extraordinarily effective for coronary heart disease. In this case, earth can be used to sedate fire. Because the Yang Ming channel has more qi and more blood, we use this point to safely sedate excess, in conditions such as frontal headache, chest pain, frozen shoulder or toothache. For these treatments, deep needling (50-60mm) is required. Occasionally, bleeding may be the treatment of choice. •  Bleeding: Bleeding is very useful in the treatment of any hot or excess condition, such as: coronary heart disease, asthma, problems of the head, chest or abdomen, acute or chronic gastroenteritis, gout, skin issues, or any problems on the frontal body (Stomach channel). Because the Yang Ming (ST) channel has more qi and more blood, ST36 and points found along the Four Flower line (Stomach channel) can be safely and frequently bled without depleting the patient.•  Knee pain (Guiding Point): 66.04 Fire Master (Tung’s LV3) or 66.03 Fire Hardness (Tung’s LV2) can be used as a Guiding Point for knee pain. There are three primary reasons for this: first, the knee is tightly bound by tendons and ligaments (governed by wood); second, it is nourished by a plethora of blood vessels (relating to Heart, Pericardium and Liver; the Liver stores the blood); third, through the Hand and Foot Jue Yin relationship (PC/LV), we then connect the Pericardium to the Stomach meridian transiting the knee via the special relationship between the Hand Jue Yin (PC) and Foot Yang Ming (ST). Additionally, Master Tung taught that knee pain comes from the Heart, so all Tung’s points whose names include “Heart” or “Fire” can also be used to treat the knee.•  Asthma: In Tung’s acupuncture we have many options for treating asthma related to various origins, such as the Heart, Lung, Liver, Spleen or Kidney. The Kidney is the root of the whole body’s energy and houses the ancestral/pre-natal qi, so when asthma is the Kidney-deficient type, we want to determine whether it is yin deficiency or yang deficiency. When phlegm accumulates in the lungs, often Spleen qi is also deficient. Because the Spleen and Stomach are responsible for post-natal qi, digestion, metabolism and immune function, I often combine earth and water (Spleen and Kidney) treatment in deficient-type asthma. Usually I make this assessment using pulse and tongue diagnosis. If the pulse is weak and the tongue is pale with teeth marks, the asthma is likely to be the type caused by Kidney yang deficiency and Spleen qi deficiency. In this case, I use Four Flower Upper (ST36) with SP6 San Yin Jiao and 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through. Moxa heat packs on UB23 Shen Shu, DU4 Ming Men and REN4 Guan Yuan are also useful. If the asthma is the Kidney-yin-deficient type, the pulse is deep and rapid and the tongue is light red and dry. In this case, I use 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors (Shen Guan – Tung’s Master Kidney point, and Man Emperor – Tung’s SP6, both found on the Spleen channel) with 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through.•  Heart disease: Four Flower Upper is extraordinarily effective for coronary heart disease in two ways. In one case, earth (child) can be used to sedate fire (mother), draining heart excess. Signs of heart excess can include a red face, tachycardia (rapid heart rate), chest pain and high blood pressure. However, tachycardia is due to oxygen deficiency, so another way to think about the treatment of heart disease with ST36 is to recognize that the Four Flower Line (earth) has a regulating effect on earth, tonifying the mother (fire) to generate the son (metal). For these reasons, the Four Flower line is used for heart and lung, stomach and intestines. Most heart conditions are chronic in nature, and chronic diseases always involve phlegm and blood stagnation, so we might also bleed 77.14 Four Flower Outer (ST40) to disperse phlegm. An alternative to treating Four Flower Upper (ST36) in the treatment of heart conditions is to use 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points, located on the midline of the thigh. The Heart Passing Points are not only good for coronary heart disease but also are my points of choice when heart disease causes circulatory obstruction in the legs and feet (black feet). Don’t forget 11.05 Zhong Jian (index finger Hernia Point), which is easy to needle quickly to treat chest pain or arrhythmia. In cases of heart deficiency – signs of which include cold hands and feet, pale face, and a thready irregular pulse – we instead utilize 66.03-66.04 Fire Hardness/Fire Master (LV2/LV3), because in this circumstance wood (mother) is used to tonify fire (child), thus strengthening the heart. •  ST36 with PC6: There is an ancient point prescription that combines ST36 with PC6 Nei Guan. It is called Old Doctors’ Two Old Needles. Based on my assessment of the patient’s condition I will choose the proper needle length to insert into ST36 (for heart disease, use a deeper needle, for general use 30-40mm length needles are adequate). Because PC6 is also used to open the chest, Old Doctors’ Two Old Needles works like a charm in cases of real chest pain. Interestingly, Master Tung’s acupuncture recognizes the special relationship between the Foot Yang Ming (ST) and Hand Jue Yin (PC); perhaps Tung’s ancestors were the “Old Doctors.” •  Case history (angina): A deep (50-60mm) needle applied bilaterally on Four Flower Upper (ST36) will eliminate severe chest pain in less than one minute. I have seen this happen countless times and have learned to keep long needles in the glove box of my car for just such situations. In most cases, I also apply 77.09 Four Flower Middle bilaterally. Before I can even insert all four needles, the chest pain is gone. The needles must be retained for forty-five minutes to one hour so that circulation to the heart is adequately restored. One time I took my elderly neighbor to visit his slightly younger brother in a convalescent facility. As we were leaving the facility, my friend began to experience chest pain. It was not crushing and he could still speak, so I did not hesitate and ran to my glove box to retrieve my 60mm needles. This was one of many situations in which the chest pain was entirely gone before I could needle all four points. This same patient had been prescribed Procardia for the problem, but he refused to take it. Using Hua Tou Zai Zao Wan and Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle on a regular basis, he never experienced chest pain again. These points are phenomenal for increasing circulation to the heart and lungs. •  Heart numbness: Four Flower Middle treats heart numbness characterized by inability to sit still or lie down comfortably, and frequent changing of position. •  “How can one know if the arteries of the heart have hardened? In Chinese medicine we think that if the patient has pain on both sides of their heart, their coronary arteries have become sclerotic. How can one know if their heart has become paralyzed or numb? If one has a slow pulse and they toss and turn and cannot rest peacefully in bed, this is called heart organ paralysis or heart numbness. In this case, the patient will feel miserable, have a heavy heart, and have difficulty breathing” (Dr. Lee, 1992).•  “If one goes to bleed for heart paralysis or numbness but cannot find any visible blood vessels on the Four Flower Line then tonify 66.03-66.04 Fire Hardness/Fire Master instead” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Frontal headaches: I can immediately get rid of virtually any headache (except in cases of brain tumor). When needling for any type of headache, it is best to avoid using local acupuncture points as they may exacerbate the problem. Often I start by cupping the neck; however, this is not necessary if the patient is not complaining about neck tension. For chronic migraines, bleeding the vein just above the outside edge of the eyebrow is always the best and most effective treatment. A frontal headache is usually digestive or sinus related. It also can be caused by excessive Liver fire fueling Heart fire, in which case the headache is more severe and may have associated nausea. Blood stagnation may result in early morning excess headaches, as the pressure builds when the body is still. •  Diagnosis: First, we need to decide whether the frontal headache is an excess or deficient type. This is easily determined by asking the patient to place their fingers on their eyeballs and apply light pressure. This should be done with warm hands, because if the hands are cold, the cool pressure may feel good to a patient with an excess headache. If the headache is excess, they will not like warm pressure against their eyeballs. If the headache is deficient, they won’t mind the pressure, and it may even provide some relief.•  For excess-type headache: Bilaterally bleed or deeply needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle (50-60mm needles).•  For deficient-type headache: Bilaterally needle 77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate) and 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4). Because deficient frontal headaches may be caused by blood deficiency or fatigue, we might also consider implementing Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment (bilaterally needle ST36, SP6, LI11, LI4, and LU7 in this order, tonifying the bottom and sedating the top). See 77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate) for additional information related to deficient-type frontal headaches.•  For brain tumor: Bilaterally needle 55.06 Upper Tumor; unilaterally needle: 66.10 Fire Connection (SP3), 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4) and 66.12 Fire Scatter (KD2). (Some practitioners needle these bilaterally, though Master Tung advised not to.) See also 77.05- 77.07 Three Weights (Tung’s GB39).•  Case history (excess frontal headache): I arrived at the house of a friend who had invited a group over for Thanksgiving dinner. One of the guests had retired to a back bedroom some hours before, with a severe and disabling frontal headache. When I entered the room she was lying in the dark, unable to communicate well. All of the other guests were very concerned. I went to my car and retrieved he 60mm needles that I keep in the glove box for emergencies. I needled Four Flower Upper and Four Flower Middle bilaterally, and before I inserted the fourth needle her headache was virtually gone. She stayed in the dark for another hour, with the needles in place. After the needles were removed, she rejoined the party with a good appetite and no headache. This outcome is my common expectation for Four Flower Upper and Four Flower Middle. Though the symptoms may be relieved immediately upon the insertion of needles, the headache will return if the needles are not retained long enough.•  Case history (Crohn’s disease with glaucoma): I treated a 65-year-old man who had glaucoma and Crohn’s disease. He had had multiple laser surgeries on both eyes, and a large portion of his intestine had been removed. Once each week, I treated him with 55.02 Flower Bone One and then had him turn onto his back to needle Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle bilaterally, because these points are used for pressure behind the eyes as well as gastroenteritis. With additional support from an herbal formula, his Crohn’s disease was completely healed within six months. His intraocular pressure started to descend nicely, from 22 mmHg to 12 mmHg. His visual field exams also improved radically, and he was able to entirely discontinue his glaucoma medication within two years of treatment. •  Frozen shoulder (with same-side ST36): Frozen shoulder – also known as “fifty-year shoulder” – refers to a rigid condition of the shoulder joint that frequently occurs following an injury, but it also may have a slow onset. When a patient reports chronic or recurring shoulder pain, there is the potential for it to evolve into a completely immobilized state. In all of Tung’s acupuncture, structural problems are treated using points on the opposite side of the pathology, with the exception of the Stomach channel points. Because Stomach channel points are equally effective when needled on the same side as on the opposite side, when treating frozen shoulder I needle Four Flower Upper/Middle on the affected side to treat the Yang Ming aspect. If there are dark veins in the vicinity of the Stomach and Gallbladder channels, they may also be bled (on the same side as the frozen shoulder). Cup first, then bleed, then needle.•  Cupping: Cup outward from the spine, all the way around the entire shoulder girdle, to the front. Cup from the top of the neck, down to UB17, and all the way over to DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas, located over the outside edge of the scapula. Cup the deltoid and in front of the shoulder (LU1-LU2 area) with lighter pressure. The skin will be black after cupping! Sometimes shoulders may feel worse after cupping (the only joint where this seems to happen). If the patient can raise the affected arm, shave and cup the armpit. Frozen shoulder involves stagnation and poor circulation. If you don’t pull out the toxins, the qi cannot move into the area to heal it. Cup over several treatments, until the skin stops coloring (usually at least three cupping sessions). Each time the patient is cupped, their range of motion is likely to increase, so make sure they maintain the improvement by exercising the area.Exercise: Though the patient will complain and resist, it is essential that they routinely do the exercise of walking their fingers up a wall, with the goal of bringing the armpit to the wall or as close as possible. The more frozen the shoulder joint is, the more painful and difficult this exercise will be. For every other type of joint pain, I suggest that the patient rest and pamper the affected area. However, with frozen shoulder, resting only results in further and prolonged paralysis. As much as a patient may complain, wall walking can free the joint and hasten the healing. They may require herbs, NSAIDs or narcotics in order to manage this exercise, yet it is crucial.•  Bleeding LU5 is probably the single most important element of treating a frozen shoulder. LU5 is the water point on a metal channel; sedate LU5 so metal will not overcome wood. Because tendons and ligaments are governed by the wood element, once the wood relaxes, the arm can be raised. When we needle directly adjacent to the tendon, we bring in the tendon-treating-tendon influence, which is especially good for muscle and tendon spasms. In this case, it treats the shoulder, but it affects any spasm, including spasm from menstrual cramping. Bleeding is done on the affected side, but if you are not accustomed to bleeding, sedate LU5 on the opposite side.•  Opposite-side points: Recognizing that a frozen shoulder usually involves all of the channels, I often use far more needles to treat this condition than any other. Needle opposite-side 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan), 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), 44.06 Shoulder Center (add extra needles to form Shoulder Triangle); needle same-side 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle (or Zhong Ping, found 1.0 cun inferior to ST36 [Dr. Young]). Same-side Guiding Points could be chosen from: SI3 Hou Xi, A.04 San Cha Three, or 22.06 Middle White (Zhong Bai). For serious pain, I may also needle opposite-side 11.16 Fire Knee or left-side 1010.22 Nose Wing. All of the above point combinations can be used simultaneously when treating frozen shoulder; however, if the restriction is primarily on one or two channels, then choose from the following Chief and Guiding Points:•  77.18 Shen Guan and shoulder pain: When the patient cannot raise their arm, we use the Hand and Foot Tai Yin relationship (LU/SP) to reach the front of the shoulder, which relates to the Lung and Large Intestine. For anterior shoulder pain, needle opposite-side Kidney Gate (Shen Guan – Master Tung’s “Master Kidney Point,” located on the Spleen channel) with 22.04 Da Bai on the same side as a Guiding Point. Shen Guan is used in many shoulder point prescriptions because it has a unique relationship to both the front and the back of the shoulder. Through the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yang and Foot Tai Yin (SI/SP), we reach the back of the shoulder (SI9-SI10 area), and we use SI3 Hou Xi as a Guiding Point. Additionally, Shen Guan has the Reaction Area of the Kidney, and thus it utilizes the special relationship between the Leg Shao Yin (KD) and the Hand Shao Yang (SJ); both of these relate to bone and the San Jiao channel on the back of the shoulder. For this reason, we might consider using 22.06 Middle White (Tung’s SJ3) as a Guiding Point, as well. Three Guiding Points is too many; choose one or two at most.•  77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold: When the shoulder cannot move forward or back, and the arm cannot be brought behind the back, needle opposite-side Leg Five/One Thousand Gold with same-side A.04 San Cha Three or 22.06 Middle White (Tung’s SJ3) as a Guiding Point.44.06 Shoulder Triangle: Needling Shoulder Triangle is my favorite way to address pain in the opposite deltoid. When the shoulder pain is primarily muscular, I am always sure to cup the deltoid. Deltoid pain is a common symptom of overuse; however, it can also indicate severe cervical stenosis and may be the first obvious sign. For this reason, when patients complain of deltoid pain, I always make a thorough assessment of the cervical spine.•  Surgical intervention: Some patients opt for surgery because a frozen shoulder joint can be broken free under anesthesia, restoring range of motion. Patients choose this option to have better use of their arm, even when they are warned that their pain level will be the same after surgery. When a patient seeks acupuncture after this surgery, my treatment is identical to the treatment for a patient whose shoulder is still frozen. I always start with cupping and bleeding.•  Frequency of treatment: Frozen shoulders require patience and diligence from both patient and practitioner. Keep the cost low so that the patient can be treated as often as possible. Use anti-inflammatory agents such as emulsified turmeric and omega-3 fatty acids. Strong treatment is required.•  Gout (Dr. Young): Excess heat in the Yang Ming (ST) channel can cause gout. The treatment principle is to strengthen the Spleen to eliminate damp. Gout usually occurs in older men due to high stress and excess consumption of meat and alcohol. The following foods need to be avoided: mushrooms, shrimp, peanuts, internal organs, asparagus, beets, oranges, strawberries, sour fruits, and fructose (especially high fructose corn syrup). Foods that treat gout include: cherry juice, watermelon juice and celery seeds.•  Treatment: For gout in the big toe or middle toe, needle opposite-side 11.27.3 Five Tiger Three; sedate same-side 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36). Every ten minutes, raise the Four Flower Upper needle by half of its insertion depth, until you pull it out.•  Alternate treatment: Needle opposite-side 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31); tonify opposite-side 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36) or sedate same-side 77.08 (deep needling with strong stimulation; after ten minutes, raise the needle by half of its insertion depth and stimulate again; after ten more minutes, stimulate once more and pull the needle out quickly, to remove heat from the blood (“Cold Heaven Method”).•  77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate) reduces acid and is especially good for patients who are taking diuretics and have severe gout.•  Dr. Lee formula: When I was twenty-five years old, I experienced the most excruciating gout. Gout usually occurs in men who are eating too much meat and drinking too much alcohol. I had been vegetarian for seven years and never drank alcohol; however, at that time I had a practice treating HIV patients and was extremely stressed out. Even hopping on my healthy foot caused a sensation in my affected ankle that could only be described as “broken glass.” Though I don’t know its name or where she found it, Miriam gave me the following formula, which worked like a charm. This formula is cold in nature, and you will need to tonify the patient after they take it. For weak, older patients, use it only in the spring and summer, as it may be too depleting otherwise. It will decrease uric acid. If the patient uses this formula for ten days, they probably will never have gout again. The only patients in my practice who have ever had a recurrence were two men who could not give up drinking red wine. •  Gout formula: 3 Zhi Mu, 4 Ban Lang Gen, 4 Tu Fu Ling, 2 Zhi Zi, 3 Cang Zhu, 3 Bai Zhu, 3 Chi Shao Yao, 3 Bai Shao, 3.5 Niu Xi, .8 Cao Guo Ren, 3 Jin Yin Hua, 3 Ju Hua, 5 Lian Qiao, 2 Gan Cao, 3.5 Jing Jie, 4 Bai Xing Ren, 3 Yi Yi Ren, 3.5 San Leng.32 •  Note: Grind to a powder; take one tablespoon twice daily with warm water. Or, if the formula is encapsulated; take ten “00” capsules three times a day. •  Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment (ML10): When I studied with Dr. Lee, I watched her use her Ten Great Needles Treatment between ten and twenty times every day for a very wide variety of ailments. It was her primary “go-to” treatment for all colds, flus and allergies (with LI20 Welcome Fragrance), and for qi- and blood-deficient conditions such as: exhaustion and fatigue, postpartum anemia, post-surgical weakness, recovery from chemotherapy and radiation, severe blood loss, deficiency-type epilepsy, hypotension, hypothyroid, weakness causing mental instability, depression, confusion or anxiety. This treatment is excellent to address grief after the loss of a loved one, as it releases metal and bolsters the earth beneath the patient’s feet. Miriam often needled ML10 to address blood-deficient-type insomnia, adding Yin Tang (Extra Point) and DU20 Bai Hui, a combination also used with auricular points to increase metabolism in treatments for weight loss. Note: ML10 is not used for treating excess-type high blood pressure or other Liver-excess-type conditions.•  History: Dr. Lee’s O.M.D. thesis was published as Insights of a Senior Acupuncturist (1992). In this work, she explained the origin of her Ten Great Needles Treatment, which she created to address the widespread depression and mental health disorders she began to see in America. These types of disorders were less common in China, where the struggle for life itself took so much energy that few people were able to suffer anguish over the quality of their life. Consulting the Nei Jing, Dr. Lee found the following passage: “When the Stomach and Spleen, the central jiao, are attacked by emotion, pure qi cannot ascend to the brain, and the evil qi, the waste, cannot descend. It will remain stuck in the Stomach.” She rationalized that in Western terms, pure qi equates to oxygen, and evil qi equates to carbon dioxide, and when the pure qi, or oxygen, is not ascending to the head and the evil qi is not dispelled, mental disorders ensue, and the patient is not able to find their way forward in life. She needled these points and asked the patient to doze for half an hour, if possible. When returning to the patient, we knew when the pure qi had arrived because the color of the patient’s face had changed; their cheeks were pink and their face had shen.•  Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment: ST36, SP6 San Yin Jiao, LI11 Qu Chi, LI4 He Gu and LU7 Lie Que. In cases of deficiency or weakness, the points on the legs are tonified first, to raise the pure qi; then, the points on the arms are sedated to remove the evil qi and to make room for the pure qi to arrive. If the patient has excessive stagnation in the upper body, we may want to disperse the upper points before tonifying the lower points, to avoid causing a blockage in the center and pushing against the excess. ST36 frees up stuck qi in the middle jiao, causes the pure qi to ascend, adjusts the qi and blood of all the channels, strengthens the Spleen and Stomach, calms the spirit, and strengthens the Kidney, vision and hearing. ST36 has a regulatory function that can address blood pressure, help to increase or decrease white blood cells, and increase stomach acid, making it an effective remedy for food stagnation. I usually use a 30mm needle on this point for a constitutional type of treatment; however, if a patient has Heart excess, use a deep needle on ST36 (50mm). •  SP6 San Yin Jiao (77.21 Man Emperor) is chosen because stagnant Liver qi can cause depression, and SP6 links the Liver with the Kidney and Spleen. SP6 controls yin blood, regulates the reproductive system, and strengthens the Kidney qi to restore memory and vitality while bringing equilibrium to the Three Leg Yin.•  LI11 Qu Chi and LI4 He Gu help to move the bowels, eliminating waste and helping the evil qi to descend and drain. Additionally, LI11 dispels wind and relieves the surface, regulates qi and increases white blood cells. LI4 opens the Lung and Large Intestine and treats many diseases from the neck up. This point has a close relationship to the San Jiao, which regulates qi through all the jiao, regulates the pores, and expels wind. This point causes energy to rise and scatter.•  LU7 Lie Que clears the Kidney (which rules the brain), treats the head and neck, clears the chest, and treats the intestines. Because Lung is the mother of Kidney, we can use the analogy of a straw in a glass of water to describe the ability of the Lung to draw qi upwards, strengthening the Kidney. If we cap the top of a straw with our finger and lift it out of the water, the straw remains full. This illustrates the action of strong Lung qi. When we uncap the straw, the water drops out; this can be likened to Lung deficiency causing Kidney weakness (incontinence). If the Lung energy is weak, there may be anal prolapse, menstrual spotting or urinary incontinence. If Lung qi is excess, fluids are retained, causing difficult urination in conditions such as prostate enlargement. This is why an excess-type cough can delay labor and delivery. In order to induce labor, we must sedate the Lungs.ML10 variations:•  Shen Guan: For patients who are elderly or extremely qi deficient, 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan) can be added to the ML10 protocol. Please note that I sometimes define “elderly” as 40 years or older, as this is the age when the qi begins to wane. Shen Guan is frequently added when conditions are chronic, or for elderly patients.•  ML10 during pregnancy: During pregnancy, it is important to treat less frequently, using fewer needles and lighter stimulation. Miriam created the following variation on her Ten Great Needles Treatment specifically for pregnancy. Bilaterally needle: Four Flower Upper (ST36), 77.18 Shen Guan, LI11 Qu Chi, LU7 Lie Que (30 mm needles with only light stimulation). •  Caution: While treating pregnant patients, do not forget that both LI4 He Gu and SP6 San Yin Jiao are forbidden to needle during pregnancy!•  ST36 increases stomach acid: Needling Four Flower Upper tonifies Kidney yang, increasing stomach acid. (Note: SP9 Yin Lin Quan and 77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate) decrease stomach acid.) It is best not to needle Four Flower Upper if stomach acid is a problem; however, the point may be bled with good effects, treating chronic gastroenteritis, gastric pain and ulcers. •  ST36 promotes urination: Because Four Flower Upper promotes urination, I always ask the patient to empty their bladder before I needle this point. •  Toothache: Four Flower Upper treats toothache by sedating Stomach heat and Heart fire, pulling the qi downward.•  Case history (colitis): A twenty-year-old female patient had four years of chronic colitis (diarrhea five times a day). LI11 Qu Chi and Four Flower Upper were needled, and Li Zhong Wan and Shen Ling Bai Zhu San were prescribed. She returned ten days later and reported only one bout of diarrhea. •  Epilepsy and ST36:•  Case history (excess-type epilepsy): I treated a 38-year-old landscaper who was in peak physical condition. He was experiencing grand mal seizures that occurred most frequently in the early morning hours, and occasionally during the day (these would be considered Liver excess type). The seizures that woke him up between the hours of 1:00–4:00 a.m. caused him to severely chew his tongue and sometimes even break his teeth (a good reminder not to put your fingers into the mouth of a person having a seizure). Often after one of these severe seizures, he would experience double vision for several days. I found that a 60mm needle, inserted into 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle, would correct his vision. It is important to differentiate between an excess-type seizure and a deficient-type seizure. An easy indication can be the time of day when the seizure typically occurs. When a physically strong epileptic patient is lying still through the night, excess energy is not released through activity, resulting in more frequent nighttime or early morning seizures. Patients with epilepsy hate having seizures in public, primarily because frightened bystanders usually call 911, and the poor epileptic then wakes up in the emergency room, still having difficulty communicating. This patient knew that he had one to two seconds to throw himself into the nearest bushes to avoid this predictable outcome. He would wake up several hours later and attempt to go either to my clinic or to his home. I am not making any particular recommendation to those who witness someone having a seizure, but simply reporting their experience as it has been related to me. This type of case is a perfect candidate for a ketogenic diet or CBD oil (18:1) as both are anti-inflammatory. I recently gave this high potency CBD oil to my nephew who was having regular epileptic seizures, it has now been six weeks since his last seizure. My first patient using this CBD oil is an injured racing dog. He was having two seizures per week, severe tendon pain in one leg and an untreatable toe infection on the opposite foot, causing him to whimper a lot, especially at night. He has had no seizures since he began the CBD oil three months ago, and no longer whimpers. He is scheduled for an amputation of the toe, we will see if that is still required. I cannot believe how effective CBD is, and am now prescribing it for many of my more difficult cases, with tremendous results. One seventy-year old woman’s C-reactive protein has dropped from 19.6 to 12.2 in four weeks.•  Case history (deficient-type epilepsy): People who typically have seizures in the late afternoon, and not as often between midnight and 7:00 a.m, are more likely to be having deficient-type seizures. Four Flower Upper can be used to treat both excess and deficient types of epilepsy, but the way in which the point is used and the point combinations are very different, as are the herbs that treat the conditions. Remember that a deep needle on ST36 sedates excesses in the head. However, using a 30mm needle on ST36, as a part of Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment, will tonify and strengthen qi and blood while also expelling wind from the upper part of the body. The efficacy of this was beautifully illustrated when I treated a 35-year-old woman who was afraid to leave her house for fear of having a seizure and winding up in the emergency room again. Because her presentation was deficient – fatigue, cold hands and feet, pale tongue, soft stools, and brain fog – I chose to use Dr. Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment and give the formula Wu Chi Bai Feng Wan to strengthen and build the patient’s constitution. Her first few treatments required me to provide house calls, but by her fourth treatment she was confident enough to take the bus to my clinic. I treated her for approximately six months, after which she was happily released. •  Case history (asthma, Dr. Lee): “A five-year-old girl had spent the night in the hospital with an acute asthma attack. The entire night she had struggled for breath, crying, and vomiting. Her parents knew I start work at 5:30 am and so checked their daughter out of the hospital and brought her to me. They immediately put her on a treatment table and then went out into the waiting room to sleep. The little girl was crying. She was well-built physically. I used a 2.5 cun needle and inserted this deeply at Four Flower Upper. All at once, the child vomited a large lump of heavy, sticky phlegm, like a stone, that had been stuck in her stomach. Two years later, I met the child and her mother again. The mother told me that since that day, the child had not suffered any further asthma attacks. The child had grown considerably since then and had a very good complexion” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Case history (mental confusion, Dr. Lee): “Another time, I was asked to treat a young man who was a freshman in college. His family was very concerned since he did not seem able to remember things. Mental cases in which concentration and memory are impaired are often due to phlegm obstructing the portals of the Heart. In such cases, one must needle Four Flower Upper or Four Flower Middle very deeply, at least 2.5 cun. I also needle in such cases SP6 San Yin Jiao, LI11 Qu Chi, LI4 He Gu and LU7 Lie Que (ML10). The lower points are supplemented and the upper points drained. By draining the Large Intestine phlegm is discharged with the feces. In any case, I treated this young man three times, and after that his grades improved dramatically. The next year he took a heavier course load. I asked him if this worried him and he answered, ‘piece of cake’” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Case history (dry mouth, Dr. Lee): “Once a woman more than 80 years old came to me with dryness of the mouth. She could not eat bread or toast. She had to chew and chew these, and still they would only form a ball in her mouth, which she could not swallow. She said that it felt like chewing a sweater, as it was so dry and tasteless. I bled Four Flower Upper and immediately one could see more moisture in her mouth. That night she was able to eat and she returned the next day asking to be bled again. I explained that since the mouth was still moist we should wait one week before repeating the treatment. By the next week, her mouth had become dry again. But after three treatments her mouth remained moist. I believe this treatment works by clearing Stomach fire so that Stomach fluids and Spleen yin could regenerate automatically” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Qi and blood deficiency, exhaustion and fatigue: Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment. •  Frontal headache (excess type, pain behind the eyes that gets worse with pressure): Bilaterally, deeply needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle. •  Glaucoma (with pressure behind the eyes): Bilaterally needle 55.02 Flower Bone One, 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle.•  Epilepsy (excess type): Needle 55.06 Upper Tumor; deeply needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle; bilaterally needle 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31); bilaterally bleed 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle or 77.05-77.07 Three Weights. •  Epilepsy (deficient type): Bilaterally needle Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment (ST36, SP6, LU7, LI4, LI11); bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors, 55.06 Upper Tumor, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) or 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles; bilaterally needle 77.05-77.07 Three Weights.•  Heart excess/real chest pain: Bilaterally, deeply needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle. •  Coronary heart disease, heart failure, angina (acute or chronic), or tight chest due to anxiety: Needle Old Doctors’ Two Old Needles: PC6 Nei Guan first, then deep needle (50-60mm) 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36).•  Heart disease: Bilaterally, deeply needle 77.08 Four Flower Upper, bilaterally needle PC6 Nei Guan (Old Doctors’ Two Old Needles); retain the needles for at least one hour. •  Fast heart rate (tachycardia): Bilaterally, deeply needle 77.08 Four Flower Upper.•  Heart numbness (patient agitated, cannot lie down or sit still): Bilaterally, deeply needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle. •  Pleuritis: Bleed 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line; needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses or 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles; GB34 Yang Ling Quan with SJ3 Zhong Zhu (Dr. Young).•  Gout: See 77.08 Four Flower Upper, Comments.•  Frozen shoulder: See 77.08 Four Flower Upper, Comments. •  Bell’s palsy, facial paralysis, trigeminal neuralgia: •  Cup the entire affected area, extremely gently in cases of trigeminal neuralgia (it takes three pumps to keep the cup on; do not use additional pressure). The patient must completely avoid wind for 48 hours after cupping. See 66.04 Fire Master, Comments for additional information related to cupping the face and jaw. •  Bleed or bilaterally deeply needle (2.0-3.0 cun) 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle, angling the needles toward the head. Alternatively, substitute 77.05-77.07 Three Weights or 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles; needle 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) and/or 88.17-88.19 Four Horses. •  Additional points: If the patient cannot smile, needle 11.14 Finger Three Weights; if their eye does not close, needle opposite-side LI4 He Gu; if there are no wrinkles on the forehead, bleed same-side 99.08 Ear Apex; if the mouth is deviated, needle REN24 Cheng Jiang as a Guiding Point. Every five days, bleed the white line on the inside of the cheek where the teeth come together, to stimulate circulation in the face (especially good for paralysis). •  Notes: Treat the patient twice daily if possible. When the patient can whistle, they are recovering. If paralysis is not treated within three months of onset, it may be difficult to restore function, so start treatment immediately. After five years of paralysis, treatment is unlikely to restore function.•  Mouth ulcer: Bleed 77.08 Four Flower Upper (do not needle, because needling ST36 increases stomach acid). Topically apply Edgar Cayce’s Ipsab Herbal Gum Treatment (miraculous for canker sores).•  Gastrointestinal disease: Bilaterally needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle.•  Abdominal distension: Bilaterally needle 77.08 Four Flower Upper, ST44 Nei Ting, SP6 San Yin Jiao. Alternatively: 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4), PC6 Nei Guan.•  Irritable bowel/Crohn’s disease: Bilaterally needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle. Alternatively, 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4), PC6 Nei Guan.•  Asthma: Bilaterally, deeply needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle or 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors. Add 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) or 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through.•  Calf spasm: Deeply needle opposite-side 77.08 Four Flower Upper.

name: Sihuazhong, Four Flower Middle (T 77.09)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 7.5 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament on the knee. | Johnson: My teacher, Dr. Miriam Lee, found Four Flower Middle 3.0 cun (four fingers) inferior to 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36) and one large finger’s breadth lateral to the anterior tibial crest (at the level of ST37 Shang Ju Xu). The classic location of Four Flower Middle is 4.5 cun below Four Flower Upper. This location places the point 0.5 cun proximal to ST38 Tiao Kou. Note: I have found both locations to be equally effective, and I use them interchangeably. Often, Four Flower Middle does not appear to be directly inferior to Four Flower Upper (ST36); measure carefully and palpate for the precise location. This point is easily felt in both locations.
primary_indications: lung cancer Cardiovascular disorders: coronary heart disease
secondary_indications: Disorders of the eyes: soreness and pain of the eyeball
johnson_indications: Deformity or swelling of the bones of the hands
techniques: Needle 1.5 - 2 cun for asthma and eye problems, 3 cun for heart disease. Needling close to or along the tibia can yield the best therapeutic effect. Bilateral needling is recommended for treating lung disorders, pain of the elbow, scapula, and fingers. This point can also be bled, especially when treating gastrointestinal disorders, cardiovascular disorders, chest stuffiness and pleurisy. Veins around this point can be bled with a three-edged needle to treat arteriosclerosis, acute stomach pain, enteritis, and chest congestion. | Johnson: See 77.08 Four Flower Upper, Needling Notes, as this point shares similar techniques. Dao Ma: Four Flower Middle is mostly needled as a Dao Ma with 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36). In many Tung’s acupuncture books, Four Flower Middle has indications in addition to those listed for Four Flower Upper; most of them are bone related. Though Four Flower Upper (ST36) may be needled alone, Four Flower Middle is usually used alongside it. Both points are considered Chief Points – they are equal in strength and power. Depths: 0.5-1.0 cun insertion gently tonifies or addresses adjacent conditions, such as knee or toe pain. 1.0-2.0 cun insertion reaches the abdomen. 2.0-2.5 cun insertion effectively treats heart disease and angina. Inserting a 60mm needle is the most effective for glaucoma and frontal headache. Face and head disorders: 2.5-3.0 cun Heart disease and asthma: 2.0-2.5 cun Gastrointestinal disease: 1.0-2.0 cun Leg disease: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Four Flower Middle shares the energetic pathways of 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36). See 77.08 Four Flower Upper for additional comments/combinations common to these two powerful points. Bone inflammation and bone spurs: Four Flower Middle, when needled or bled with 77.10 Four Flower Quasi, treats bone inflammation, deformity or swelling of the bones (also known as “steaming bones”), especially of the hands, and bone spurs of the knee and heel. Together, these points address inflammation of the bone using earth (Stomach) to control water (Kidney). Alternatively, 77.11 Four Flower Lower combined with 77.12 Bowel Intestine are also used for bone spurs of the knee and heel (also known as “cutting bone,” according to Dr. Young). All of the points described above must be needled close to the bone to activate the bone-treating-bone system. However, when bleeding, never touch the bone with the tip of a bleeding needle; instead bleed the veins nearby. Patients usually notice a reduction in their symptoms after approximately two weeks of treatment. See 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One for additional information, including nutritional advice, related to the treatment of bone spurs. Weight loss (Dr. Young): Needling or bleeding the Four Flower points releases toxins. I realized these points also promoted weight loss when many patients lost weight after bone spur treatments. Bone spur pain is usually worse in heavier patients, especially when they walk down stairs. Excess frontal headache (Dr. Lee): “I use Four Flower Middle quite frequently for the treatment of headaches, including migraines in both men and women, no matter how long they have suffered. However, for this one must use a long needle, at least 2.5 cun. If one presses the patient’s eyeballs and they feel hard like marbles, this means that they are prone to headaches. It also means that the blood vessels behind the eyes have become hard. The eyeballs are related to the Liver and the Liver is very susceptible to overwork and emotional stress. These headaches are due to Liver fire inflaming Heart fire. This point is on the Stomach channel. The Stomach is the child of the Heart. If one drains the child, it will automatically drain the mother. After the first 2-3 treatments, the patient may not notice much difference. However, after 4-5 treatments, their headaches will be greatly reduced and will become infrequent. Sometimes I use this point with LV3 Tai Chong. When this point is used for asthma, it drains the Stomach so that the Stomach will no longer over-control the Kidneys. Then the Kidneys may grasp the qi sent down by the Lungs” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Migraine: Deeply needle 77.09 Four Flower Middle, LV3 Tai Chong. Asthma and heart disease: In addition to other treatments, alternate bleeding 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) once monthly with 77.09 Four Flower Middle every two weeks and with the Shu Points on the back. Bone spurs (knee or heel): Needle opposite-side 77.09 Four Flower Middle, 77.10 Four Flower Quasi next to the bone, and same-side LV3 Tai Chong as a Guiding Point. Alternatively, needle opposite-side 33.12 Heart Gate or PC6 Nei Guan and 77.09 Four Flower Middle on the same side as a Guiding Point. 77.11 Four Flower Lower combined with 77.12 Bowel Intestine is also used for bone spurs of the knee and heel (Dr. Young, 2008). See 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One for additional information, including nutritional advice, related to the treatment of bone spurs. Lung tumor/cancer: Bleed 77.09 Four Flower Middle; needle 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai. 305 Lower Leg Points

name: Sihuafu, Four Flower Quasi (T 77.10)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 10 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament on the knee. | Johnson: Four Flower Quasi is located on the lateral side of the leg, 2.5 cun directly inferior to 77.09 Four Flower Middle (or 1.0 cun distal to ST39 Xia Ju Xu).
primary_indications: lung cancer Cardiovascular disorders: coronary heart disease
johnson_indications: Eyebrow pain (due to excessive crying or anger)
Deformity or swelling of the bones of the hands
Fluid in the chest or lungs
techniques: Needle 2 - 3 cun for asthma and eye pain. Bilateral needling is recommended for treating lung disorders, pain of the elbow, scapula and fingers. This point can also be bled. Bleed veins around this point with a three-edged needle for best therapeutic effect to treat arteriosclerosis, acute stomach pain, enteritis, chest congestion, and pleuritis. | Johnson: Bleed for most indications. •  Asthma: Deep insertion. •  Shoulder, elbow and index finger pain: Same-side needle or bleed.•  Depth: 2.0-3.0 cun
comments: Four Flower Quasi is primarily bled, and it is more an area than a distinct point. Look for dark vessels along the Stomach channel and bleed any vessel that is not directly on top of the tibia. If the bled point produces a significant amount of dark blood, there should be immediate results, especially in the treatment of frontal headache or chest tightness.•  Dao Ma close to the bone: When this point is needled, it must be added to 77.09 Four Flower Middle because it is not strong enough to be used on its own. To treat bone spurs or swelling of the bone, combine with 77.09 Four Flower Middle; needle close to the tibia and slide down the bone.•  Heart numbness (Dr. Lee): “If one goes to bleed Four Flower Quasi for heart paralysis or numbness but cannot find any visible blood vessels in this area or around 77.09 Four Flower Middle then tonify 66.03-66.04 Fire Hardness/Fire Master instead” (Dr. Lee, 1992)

name: Sihuaxia, Four Flower Lower (T 77.11)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 12.5 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament on the knee. This point is 2.5 cun below Sihuafu (T 77.10). | Johnson: Four Flower Lower and Bowel Intestine are always used together, but the point location varies somewhat to accommodate the patient’s physical structure. This area of the lower calf is heavily wrapped in ligaments that stabilize the fibula, a floating bone without any joint of its own. Because of these ligaments, insertion can be very difficult at both of these points. Four Flower Lower is needled between the tibia and the fibula, at the lowest part of the calf, where it is possible to insert the needle between the bones. Bowel Intestine is then needled 1.5 cun (two finger widths) superior to Four Flower Lower. These points are usually very sensitive, so I downsize my needle. (See Needling Notes.) 77.11 Four Flower Lower is officially located directly adjacent to the tibia, 3.5 cun (five fingers) proximal to ST41 Jie Xi. 77.12 Bowel Intestine is located 1.5 cun (two fingers) proximal to Four Flower Lower.
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Needling along the tibia is especially helpful when treating knee and heel bone spurs. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: See Location for additional information about the location and needling of these points. Dao Ma: Four Flower Lower and 77.12 Bowel Intestine are always needled together as a Dao Ma. Needle gauge: Use a 0.16 x 30mm needle (Chinese gauge 40, Japanese gauge 1). Depth: 1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathway: Four Flower Lower and 77.12 Bowel Intestine regulate the stomach and intestines, dispersing Stomach heat. Acute diarrhea: I only needle Four Flower Lower and 77.12 Bowel Intestine as a Dao Ma for gastrointestinal inflammation and acute diarrhea. I once had a diabetic patient who ate an entire serving bowl of fruit and had had diarrhea for over a week when she came for treatment. I inserted these needles bilaterally and retained them for one hour, and then she had no bowel movements for three days. When treating diarrhea, it is important to know whether it is bacterial. Never use these points in a situation of bacterial dysentery, when it is important to clean the toxins out of the intestines to stop the diarrhea, rather than stopping it through astringing. These points are also useful in situations of chronic diarrhea due to extreme qi deficiency. Bruxism: Teeth grinding during sleep (bruxism) may be due to parasites, as they are usually more active at night. Bruxism is usually due to Stomach heat. It is also common in alcoholics. Bone spurs of the knee and heel (Dr. Young): 77.11 Four Flower Lower combined with 77.12 Bowel Intestine can be used together to treat bone spurs of the knee and heel. Dr. Young refers to this treatment as “cutting bone.” See 77.09 Four Flower Middle and also 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One for additional information, including nutritional advice, related to the treatment of bone spurs.
combinations: Diarrhea (non-pathogenic cold-type): Needle 77.11-77.12 Four Flower Lower/Bowel Intestine, moxa between REN4–REN12. Knee and heel spurs: Needle 77.11-77.12 Four Flower Lower/Bowel Intestine closely along the bone (“cutting bone,” Dr. Young).
reaction_areas: Kidney, Lung, Six Bowels (77.11-77.12); Heart (77.12 only)

name: Sihuali, Four Flower Inner (T 77.13)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 1.2 cun medial to Sihuazhong (T 77.09) or 7.5 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) and 1.2 cun medial, on the inner border of the tibia. | Johnson: Four Flower Inner is located on the medial side of the lower leg, on the Spleen channel. Measure 4.5 cun distal to ST36 (77.08), then move medial to the anterior tibial crest, sliding down the inside border of the tibia.
techniques: Needle 1.5 - 2 cun . This point can also be bled. Bleeding the veins near the Dao Ma points can treat all cardiovascular, digestive, hepatic, and respiratory disorders. Also, it is beneficial for headaches, sciatica, and pleuritis. | Johnson: Needling: Slide the needle alongside the bone to enhance the bone-treating-bone, Kidney tonification function. Bleeding: For any of the indications listed above, bleeding visible veins found in the area of this point may be the best choice. Carefully avoid contact with the tibia. Depth: 1.0-1.5 cun
comments: Medial knee pain: Most knee pain found on the medial aspect of the knee is due to bone spurs. A soft tissue inflammation formula may be very helpful. Bleeding Four Flower Inner treats medial knee pain caused by degenerative arthritis and/or bone spurs in the knee.

name: Sihuawai, Four Flower Outer (T 77.14)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 7.5 cun distal and 1.5 cun lateral to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament on the knee, close to Tiaokou (ST 38) and Fenglong (ST 40) . | Johnson: Four Flower Outer is located on the lateral side of the lower leg. Measure 4.5 cun distal to 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36) and then move 1.5 cun lateral, or bleed any dark vein in the vicinity.

Lateral sciatica or nerve pain in the lower leg or foot
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . Shoulder pain and migraines, needle the side opposite to the affected area. Asthma and cold feet, needle bilaterally. This point can also be bled. Enteritis and the other conditions listed above (excluding the conditions under the needling techniques list directly above), bleed dark veins near this point. | Johnson: Four Flower Outer is most commonly bled: When bleeding, look for a vein in the area, not a specific point. Usually I bleed multiple sites on the lower leg, sometimes as many as twenty. Often the blood is very dark, even black; it may take several sessions before fresh red blood appears. Four Flower line points can be safely bled every 7-10 days. Bleed for: Gastroenteritis, pleurisy, distending feeling in the chest, asthma, sciatica (GB meridian), shoulder and arm pain, ear pain, chronic rhinitis, headache, hypertension, instep or sole pain. Needling depth: 1.0-1.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Four Flower Outer regulates qi and blood due to its proximity to ST40 Feng Long, the Gathering Point of phlegm and the Luo Point of the Stomach channel. Because the Yang Ming channel has more qi and more blood, it is the most commonly used channel for bloodletting. Bleeding Four Flower Outer clears blood heat, disperses blood stagnation, and dissolves phlegm. TCM teaches that difficult, chronic, strange or complicated diseases have to do with phlegm or blood stagnation. For example, phlegm obstructing the brain leads to stroke, but phlegm can also obstruct elsewhere. 77.07 Third Weight and Four Flower Outer can be used interchangeably as they are located very close to each other and share the similar energetics of dispersing wind and phlegm. Cholesterol in the blood: In TCM, high cholesterol is considered a type of phlegm and can be seen as oil in the blood. Oil and water do not mix, so when the cholesterol is high, there are jagged edges in the appearance of the blood. Rather than flowing in a smooth stream, it looks “choppy.” Hypertension and hypercholesterolemia: Hypertension is a wind and phlegm condition that can be caused by high cholesterol or arteriosclerosis. 77.14 Four Flower Outer (ST40) and Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) are used together to disperse phlegm and open the blood vessels. Four Flower Outer lowers cholesterol because it is the Stomach Luo point for phlegm; TCM considers cholesterol as a type of phlegm. Stiff neck and high cholesterol are often related. Frontal headache: Bleeding points along the Four Flower Line (77.08-77.14) is an excellent choice to treat excess frontal headache.
combinations: Bleed 77.14 Four Flower Outer to treat: Gastroenteritis, pleurisy, distending feeling in the chest, asthma, shoulder and arm pain, ear pain, chronic rhinitis, headache, hypertension, pain in the instep or sole of the foot, and Gallbladder channel sciatica. Ear pain: Bleed 77.14 Four Flower Outer. (I find needling 77.22 Beside Three Miles to be equally effective.) Shingles: Bleed 77.14 Four Flower Outer, 99.08 Ear Apex, 11.26 Control Dirt. After bleeding, needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses. Also consider bleeding the small vessels found in the area of the external malleolus. (See 11.26 Control Dirt, Comments.) 313 Lower Leg Points Alzheimer’s disease: Bilaterally needle 77.07 Third Weight, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors or bleed 77.14 Four Flower Outer, then needle DU20 Bai Hui, HT7 Shen Men, KD4 Da Zhong (Dr. Young, 2008). Parkinson’s disease: Bleed 77.14 Four Flower Outer, then needle either 88.12 Bright Yellow, 88.14 This Yellow, 77.18 Shen Guan or needle 88.12 Bright Yellow with 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors, DU19 Hou Ding, DU20 Bai Hui.•  Frontal headache (excess): Bleed 77.14 Four Flower Outer then needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle.•  Hypertension and hypercholesterolemia: 77.14 Four Flower Outer (Tung’s ST40), 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4).

name: Shangchun, Upper Lip (T 77.15)
location: This point overlaps with Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament when the knee is flexed. Some books state this point is at the lower mid or lateral ridge of the patella. | Johnson: Master Tung located Two Lips beneath the lateral corner of the patella, though I only saw them bled on the midline. Either location may be used. These points are most easily found with the knees bent, opening the space between the patella and the tibia: Lateral location: 77.15 Upper Lip is located 1.0 cun lateral to the distal apex of the patella. 77.16 Lower Lip is just distal to 77.15 Upper Lip, on the upper margin of the tibia. Midline location: 77.15 Upper Lip is located just beneath the distal apex of the patella. 77.16 Lower Lip is just distal to 77.15 Upper Lip, on the midline upper margin of the tibia.
primary_indications: difficulty speaking Thrush or oral candidiasis in children
vitiligo around the mouth or genitals
techniques: Bleed to expel dark blood and to purge heat for immediate results. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 77.15 Upper Lip and 77.16 Lower Lip are always bled together in a combination called Two Lips. If veins are visible, bleed them instead of the points. Midline bleeding: If you are bleeding on the midline, it is necessary to puncture firmly, as most patients’ skin is tough in this area. The patient should lie on their back with their legs bent, knees together and feet spread apart (like a tripod). When the legs are positioned this way, a space will open between the patella and the top of the tibia. Have the patient cough each time you pierce the skin (twice on each knee). Bleed all four points quickly in sequence so that the patient is not left anticipating the treatment 315 Lower Leg Points on the opposite side. You may need to pinch the skin firmly at each point to get blood from these points, swiping one drop at a time. Ten to twenty drops per point should be effective; however, I continue bleeding up to 50 drops per point if it is bleeding easily. If you find a vein crossing this space beneath the patella, always use the vessel, Point Location and Needling Technique. Lateral bleeding: Since my early days observing in Dr. Lee’s clinic and studying with Dr. Young, and until recently in my own practice, I always bled these points on the midline just below the tip of the patella and approximately 0.5 cun distal, never realizing that the official location was on a lateral line. One time, I bled Two Lips in this midline location on a 50-year-old woman, and though there was never any infection, a small red dot remained at each point of insertion for months following the treatment, and she developed minor knee pain. Since that time I have occasionally chosen to bleed Two Lips at the lateral location, avoiding the patellar ligament, though I have found this to be less effective. If the patient is younger and the herpes is aggressive, I still use the midline location, as I did for more than 25 years without incident.
comments: Dr. Lee pioneered the selection of these points for treating herpes: “Because the names of these last two points translate as Upper and Lower Lips, and because in Chinese the labia of the vagina are called the large and small lips, I got the idea that maybe these two points might be able to treat herpes genitalia. When a doctor’s wife came in to see me with very inflamed labia due to severe herpes, I decided to try this idea. I bled the four points on both legs and black blood ran copiously out. That night, four hours later, the woman called me to say that the pain, itching, and inflammation had ceased. I told this woman to ask her husband to come in so I could treat him so that he would not simply re-infect her. He came in the next day. Of course, men do not have lips or labia, but I decided to try these points anyway. In his case, I could only squeeze out a few drops of blood with difficulty. Nevertheless, after that he never had herpes again” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Herpes and HIV: From 1983-1988, I had an HIV clinic in San Francisco, and each day I treated multiple cases of herpes. When a case is severe, the blood is dark, nearly black. This treatment was highly effective when performed bi-monthly, and though the punctures were painful, patients regularly requested it. Chronic anal herpes makes bowel movements excruciating; the bleeding of Two Lips is invaluable for cooling the heat and alleviating the pain. Preventing herpes outbreaks during pregnancy: Bleeding Two Lips during the last trimester can help your patient avoid an active herpes outbreak around her due date, an outbreak that could require her to undergo a caesarean section. Dietary restriction: Overconsumption of caffeine, sugar and/or alcohol can cause high blood sugar, which may lead to outbreaks, especially among diabetics. I had one patient with extreme Liver excess who would develop a herpes outbreak after drinking only one cup of coffee. Case history (mouth sores, Dr. Lee): “A mother brought a little child to my office. The child had not been able to eat or drink for two days because of sores in her mouth. She just cried and cried. I quickly bled Two Lips. Of course, the child cried from the bleeding procedure. However, when I returned to the room, the child was standing up and asked me for a glass of water. After she drank the glass of water, she said she was hungry. I got her some crackers. In all she ate eight of these” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Thrush: Although thrush was originally listed as an indication for Two Lips, I would never consider bleeding these points for this type of candida unless it were life threatening. Strengthen the microbiome and avoid eating sugar, altogether.

name: Xiachun, Lower Lip (T 77.16)
location: This point is 1 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament when the knee is flexed. Some books state this point is 1 cun distal from the mid or lower lateral ridge of the patella. | Johnson: Master Tung located Two Lips beneath the lateral corner of the patella, though I only saw them bled on the midline. Either location may be used. These points are most easily found with the knees bent, opening the space between the patella and the tibia: Lateral location: 77.15 Upper Lip is located 1.0 cun lateral to the distal apex of the patella. 77.16 Lower Lip is just distal to 77.15 Upper Lip, on the upper margin of the tibia. Midline location: 77.15 Upper Lip is located just beneath the distal apex of the patella. 77.16 Lower Lip is just distal to 77.15 Upper Lip, on the midline upper margin of the tibia.
