name: Tianhuang, Heaven Emperor (T 77.17)
location: This point overlaps with Yinlingquan (SP 9) , which is located on the medial aspect of the lower leg, in the depression posterior and inferior to the medial condyle of the tibia. | Johnson: Heaven Emperor is located in the depression formed by the medial condyle of the tibia and the posterior border of the tibia. This is the same location as SP9 Yin Ling Quan. Cautions: Do not moxa Heaven Emperor, as it is a water point on an earth meridian. Earth needs water; applying moxa will dry out the earth. Use acupuncture only; do not use moxibustion on pregnant women. (Dr. Carson, 1973) Most sources state that needling this point is contraindicated in pregnancy.
secondary_indications: mei he qi (plum-pit qi) Heart disease with or without high blood pressure
pain associated with the bones (especially shoulder pain
neck and upper back pain in the T1 T2 area)
Urinary and kidney disorders including lin zheng (dysuria syndrome)
edema Radiating arm pain and neck tightness/pain
tightness along the BL channel in the neck and upper back
johnson_indications: Tightness of the neck and thoracic spine
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 2.5 cun along the edge of the bone. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Heaven Emperor vs. 77.18 Shen Guan: I rarely needle Heaven Emperor (SP9) except in combination with Shen Guan for acid reflux or deficient frontal headache. In every other instance, I substitute 77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate), Master Tung’s Master Kidney Point, as a much more powerful choice. Energetic pathways: Heaven Emperor is the He-Sea point of the Spleen and the water point on an earth channel, tonifying Spleen qi and Kidney yin. Needling close to the bone increases Kidney tonification (bone treats bone). Powerfully related to both Spleen and Kidney, all “Emperor” points (77.17-77.21) tonify both prenatal (Kidney) and postnatal (Spleen) qi. Acid reflux: Both Heaven Emperor and 77.18 Shen Guan decrease stomach acid. Because He-Sea points correct reflux in the flow of qi, and Heaven Emperor is the water point on an earth channel (cooling Stomach fire), this combination of two points is used for acid reflux and bad breath. Note: 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36) has the opposite effect, increasing stomach acid. Heart disease: SP9 treats all three Jiao. Though Master Tung needled Heaven Emperor to treat heart diseases – including hypertension, dizziness, headache, insomnia and arm pain – it is used for many kinds of Kidney-related conditions, as well. Case history (heart disease, Master Tung): “Once I saw Master Tung treat a man with 95% blockage of his coronary arteries. The man’s face was purple-black. He could not do anything. He kept fidgeting, standing up and sitting down, trying to pump blood to his heart. Master Tung needled Heaven Emperor. After a while, the patient was able to breathe deeply and I saw his facial color turn bright pink. That day, that was the only needle Master Tung used on this man with such a severe condition” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Heaven Emperor with KD3: Dr. Young combines Heaven Emperor with 66.14 Water Phase (KD3), as the two points share similar energetics – one point is water in earth, and the other point is earth within water. Together, they act like the herbal formula Zhen Wu Tang (True Warrior Formula) to treat edema, diabetes, proteinuria and other diseases of the Kidney and Spleen (Dr. Young, 2008). Combination: Acid reflux: Bilaterally needle 77.17 Heaven Emperor, 77.18 Shen Guan.
combinations: Acid reflux: Bilaterally needle 77.17 Heaven Emperor, 77.18 Shen Guan.

name: Tianhuangfu [shenguan], Kidney Gate (T 77.18)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 1.5 cun inferior to Yinlingquan (SP 9) , which is in the depression of the lower border of the medial condyle of the tibia on the medial aspect of the lower leg. | Johnson: Shen Guan is located on the medial side of the lower leg, 1.5 cun (two fingers) inferior to Textbook SP9.Cautions: Do not needle in cases of low blood pressure.
primary_indications: Back pain due to Kidney deficiency
frequent urination at night Acid reflux
secondary_indications: finger numbness High uric acid levels Heartburn
chest pain Disorders of the eyes: floaters
johnson_indications: Deficient hypertension (pressure that rises in the afternoon)*
Eye diseases due to Kidney deficiency*
Eyelid bags and dark rings around the eyes*
Numbness and pain in the hands and/or feet*
Leg and foot edema, weakness or varicosities*
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 2 cun . | Johnson: Bone-treating-bone function: Slide the needle down the back of the tibia, touching the bone. Needling close to bone enhances the Kidney tonification. Avoid the vein: A vein runs along the length of the tibia, and it is usually visible. This vessel makes 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors sensitive to needle, particularly for women (perhaps because they are more yin), so palpate gently and avoid the vein whenever possible when inserting needles. Surprisingly, these points don’t tend to bruise, and I have never seen Shen Guan or 77.19 Earth Emperor bleed. While I occasionally get a drop of blood from 77.21 Man Emperor (SP6), it is also unlikely to bruise. Perpendicular or horizontal insertion: Usually the Three Emperor points are needled perpendicularly, though occasionally they are inserted at a 45-degree angle toward the Kidney and Liver channels. This angle reduces the Kidney tonification influence by dispersing the overall effect among three channels (KD, SP, LV). Perpendicular insertion is by far the preferred choice, and it has the effect of strengthening the Heart. Dr. Young discusses angling Three Emperors needles toward the head when treating supraorbital bone pain or frontal headache; however, I prefer perpendicular insertion in these cases, too. Depth: 0.5-1.5 cun
comments: The name “Shen Guan”: “Shen Guan” translates as “Kidney Gate,” and in Tung’s acupuncture it is also referred to as Master Tung’s Master Kidney Point. All points that are “Gates” are very important points in the body, such as PC6 Nei Guan, SJ5 Wai Guan and 77.27 Wai San Guan, though Shen Guan is far more powerful than any of the others. Heaven, Earth and Man: Shen Guan is acting as Heaven Emperor in most of my treatments, so I will take the opportunity here to point out that Master Tung chose to name and order multiple point patterns in his family’s system differently, as compared to their usual sequence of Heaven, Man and Earth. This is because Master Tung was a Taoist, and he recognized that of the three, Man is the least and is supported by both Heaven and Earth, and therefore Man should be on the bottom. We see this in two other point patterns: 33.13-33.15 Heaven, Earth and Man Scholars and 44.08-44.10 Heaven, Earth and Man Ancestors. Energetic pathways: Shen Guan (Kidney Gate) and Three Emperors, Kidney points found on the Spleen channel, are unique in that they are the only points in Tung’s acupuncture that address four major systems – digestive, neurological, reproductive and urinary – in a remarkably powerful way. Shen Guan also has a cardiac influence due to its Reaction Areas of Heart and Kidney (Hand and Foot Shao Yin), and it can be used to treat arteriosclerosis. Shen Guan regulates earth and water to treat all diseases caused by Kidney deficiency. It tonifies Spleen and Kidney and has the unusual ability to benefit qi while tonifying yin, accomplishing this by strengthening the Spleen (earth) to restrain the Kidney (water), much like a dam holds back a lake. The Spleen governs postnatal qi, and the Kidney governs prenatal qi. When treating chronic conditions, always consider adding Shen Guan, since chronic diseases usually have a deficient Kidney component. However, when there is Kidney deficiency, we reduce the number of needles used, so you may want to omit other points when adding Shen Guan. In some instances, the special relationship between the Foot Tai Yin (Spleen) and Hand Tai Yang (Small Intestine) comes into play, such as when treating upper back or shoulder pain, neuropathy in the hands, deafness, tinnitus, or trigeminal neuralgia. For all of the reasons described here, Shen Guan is among the most commonly needled points in Tung’s acupuncture. Three Emperors: In my clinic, “classic” Three Emperors is comprised of 77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate), 77.19 Earth Emperor and 77.21 Man Emperor (Tung’s SP6). These points are one of Master Tung’s primary Dao Ma combinations used to strengthen both Kidney and Spleen function, and they are indicated to treat pathological changes due to Kidney deficiency. All Three Emperors points are needled bilaterally when an additional boost is needed for the treatment or when the treatment is specifically directed toward the lower legs and feet. Two Emperors: When combining Emperor points with other powerful point patterns, we often omit the middle point (Earth Emperor) in order to consolidate the treatment and reduce the number of needles. When the middle point is not needled, the combination of Shen Guan and Man Emperor is referred to as Two Emperors. Shen Guan or Heaven Emperor (proximal point): Although Tung’s textbook includes 77.17 Heaven Emperor, it is rarely chosen as a part of the classic Three Emperors treatment. Instead, 77.18 Shen Guan is nearly always substituted, as it is a much more powerful Kidney tonification point. Earth Emperor (middle point): The location of the middle point, 77.19 Earth Emperor, varies based upon the location chosen for the distal point, Man Emperor. For this reason it is considered to be a floating point found halfway between Shen Guan and Man Emperor (or the point substituted for Man Emperor; see below). Man Emperor (distal point): In all written sources, 77.21 Man Emperor is said to be the same as Textbook SP6 San Yin Jiao. However, I was taught that Master Tung officially found Man Emperor one cun proximal to Textbook SP6, and so it is referred to as Upper San Yin Jiao. This is the location that I most frequently utilize. Three additional points can be substitutes for Man Emperor (based upon varying uses); these would change its location and therefore also the location of Earth Emperor. Man Emperor substitutions include: 323 Lower Leg Points Textbook SP6: Textbook SP6 San Yin Jiao is a very powerful crossing point of the Liver, Kidney and Spleen channels (hence the name, Three Yin Crossing), and so it cannot be underestimated. According to many sources, this point is in the textbook location of Man Emperor. 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7): If we are utilizing the Three Emperors points in treatments for the eyes, we always substitute 77.28 Bright Light for Man Emperor. Bright Light is found at the same level as KD7 Fu Liu, but is directly behind the tibia on the Spleen channel. Textbook KD7: Textbook KD7 is found just anterior to the medial Achilles tendon, and it too may be used as a substitute for Man Emperor, especially in cases of extremely dry throat and mouth. 77.20 Four Limbs: All sources on Tung’s acupuncture cite 77.20 Four Limbs in the same location as Upper San Yin Jiao, Tung’s Man Emperor. Three Emperors vs. 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points: Kidney Passing Points, also Kidney points found on the Spleen channel, are mainly considered in cases of whole- body edema, nephritis or threatened miscarriage. Three Emperors have more of a gynecological, sexual and neurological function and are better for impotence and premature ejaculation. Both Three Emperors and the Kidney Passing Points are good for dry mouth, as they help the Kidney to control fluids and strengthen the kidneys in general. Three Emperors are a better choice for proteinuria, especially in cases of diabetes, preeclampsia, urinary infections or rheumatoid arthritis. They are essential in the treatment of menopausal hot flashes and night sweats, hypertension, diabetes and Kidney-deficient eye diseases. Sexual and urinary function: To treat premature ejaculation, we needle Shen Guan (Kidney Gate), because in this instance the Ming Men is not consolidated, and Shen Guan astringes and fortifies the Kidney Gate. It connects UB23 Shen Shu and REN4 Guan Yuan and is therefore useful in the treatment of premature ejaculation, impotence, incontinence, and frequent urination. See Combinations below for extensive urinary treatments. Urinary incontinence (Dr. Lee): “The Kidneys and Lungs work together as a pair in terms of water metabolism. If the Lungs are functioning correctly, one can hold their urine without any trouble. If the Lungs are weak in the elderly, this may lead to incontinence when they laugh, sneeze, or cough. Such incontinence is not a Kidney/ Bladder problem but a Lung problem. One should supplement the Lungs (child) by supplementing the Spleen and Stomach (mother)” (Dr. Lee, 1992). In terms of incontinence, most elderly patients also have Kidney deficiency in addition to Lung weakness. Note: I recently read an article in a journal of Chinese Medicine about why patients urinate often at night, and why it becomes more frequent as they get older. The article offered the theory that the prone body helps the kidneys to process toxins from the blood, whereas during the day the blood tends to pool in the lower body as the patient remains upright. We can moxa or apply moxa oil on the lower back (Ming Men) and from the pubic bone to the navel (to tonify the Dan Tian). Usually we do not moxa above the navel (except for severe kidney edema), as we do not want to dry out the digestion. Formulas: Liu Wei Di Huang (Six Ingredients) is especially good for yin deficient patients who are thirsty or constipated. If the tongue is pale with teeth marks, we cannot use Liu Wei Di Huang alone, but need to add Fu Zi and Rou Gui, resulting in the formula known as Jin Gui Shen Qi Wan (Golden Book Tea), to tonify Kidney yin and yang. Elderly patients should eat Semen Nelumbinis Nuciferae (Lian Zi) to supplement the Lungs, in order to help them hold in their water. Urinary tract infection (UTI): This textbook provides a great deal of information regarding UTI. See both 11.17 Wood (Anger) and the discussion of interstitial cystitis with 66.02 Wood Wife. •  Treatments: My most frequent treatments include 11.17 Wood (Anger) and 66.02 Wood Wife, along with 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors, 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water and REN4 Guan Yuan. •  Irritability: I may add LI4/LV3 Four Gates to open the nervous system and calm the spirit, though 66.03 Fire Hardness (LV2) may be substituted because it is the Ying-Spring and fire point on the Liver meridian which flows through the genitals, and thus it clears heat. (Note: When substituting LV2, I always pair it with LI3 San Jian, also known as Anxiety Four Gates.)•  Lower jiao heat: If the patient has good veins to bleed between the medialmalleolus and SP6 San Yin Jiao, these may also be useful. •  For bladder pain and/or spasms: Bleeding the Koryo Hand Therapy A-line (referenced in 66.02 Wood Wife) will be mmediately effective. •  Urethralgia: Choose from the following points: 66.03 Fire Hardness, 66.04 Fire Master; 22.05 Ling Gu; 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water; 11.01 Great Distance with 11.04 External Distance; 44.11 Yun Bai, 44.12 Li Bai.•  Formulas: For chronic bladder infections, patients should be advised to drink corn silk tea all of the time, instead of water, to flush the bladder and soothe irritation. The usual formulas for acute UTI are Ba Zheng San and Long Dan Xie Gan Tang, or Ba Zheng San with Zhu Ling Tang, but all of these are a little too cold for chronic issues. For both acute and chronic bladder infections, use Si Ni San (Chai Wu, Chi Shi, Shao Yao, Gan Cao) with Jie Geng and Fu Ling to descend the water. Dr. Young doesn’t usually use Ban Lan Gun or Pu Gong Ying, but he uses Jie Geng and Shi Gao to clear heat and kill microbes. Kidney infections need heavier herbs like Mu Li, Gui Ban, Long Gu and/or HuangQin and Huang Lian, which are bitter and cold to clear heat and dampness. These herbs are not to be used long term or with nephritis due to kidney failure (glomerulonephritis).•  Hematuria formulas: Xiao Ji Yin Zi or Zhu Ling Tang. •  Prostate enlargement is a Kidney-deficient condition where the enlarged prostate presses on the urethra, making it difficult to urinate. This usually causes dribbling or the inability to make a smooth stream of urine and is a problem for most men over age seventy. Classic texts advise to needle SP9 followed by ST36 to cause a strong flow of urine (see Combinations below for treatment options). If the patient is urinating between six and twelve times per night, I usually recommend a surgical procedure to remedy the situation quickly and efficiently. •  Anti-histamines: I once gave an elderly gentleman an antihistamine herbal formula for his cold. Shortly thereafter he was unable to urinate and required an emergency room visit. Since that time, I am extremely wary of using antihistamines for patients who might have an enlarged prostate. •  Case history (enlarged prostate and macular degeneration): I am working with a 71-year-old who lost one kidney due to cancer and who is also losing his eyesight due to cystic macular degeneration. We discussed the prospect of prostate surgery because his nocturia had become problematic at six times per night. As his eyes are improving with treatment, he is also urinating only twice a night now. I attribute the prostate improvement to Kidney tonification from the treatment that I am using for his eyes (55.02 Flower Bone One with 77.18-77.28 Three Emperors). This change occurred within three weeks of beginning treatment. •  Prostate combinations:•  Bilaterally needle 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water, 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors, and deeply needle one of the following: REN3 Zhong Ji, REN4 Guan Yuan or REN6 Qi Hai (sea of qi, tonifies Kidneys, releases stagnation in lower jiao). When needling is deep on the lower REN channel, the patient may feel “something going down,” or a “zing” into the genital area. Though they may not feel it, always prepare your patients for this, because they will be startled if it happens and they are not prepared. •  Moxa UB23 Shen Shu, DU4 Ming Men, REN6 Qi Hai and/or REN4 Guan Yuan.•  Bilaterally needle 66.04 Fire Master, 77.17 Heaven Emperor (SP9), sedate 77.08 Four Flower pper (ST36) to promote immediate urination. SP9 and ST36 are both He-Sea points tonifying earth to build water.•  Bilaterally needle 22.05 Ling Gu with 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors.•  Bilaterally needle 88.13 Heavenly Yellow, 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36) (Dr. Young, lectures, 1998).•  Bilaterally needle 44.06 Shoulder Center, 44.11 Cloud White, 44.15 Lower Curve (Dr. Young, lectures, 1998).•  Bilaterally needle 66.03-66.04 Fire Hardness/Fire Master. •  UB65 Shu Gu (the wood point on the Urinary Bladder channel).•  LV1 Da Dun can be used as a Guiding Point with any of the above treatments. •  Dietary recommendations and herbs for enlarged prostate: For those whose nocturia is fewer than six times nightly, the following dietary recommendations may be helpful: eat raw pumpkin seeds (up to one pound daily; they can be ground into a meal/powder); it is also good to eat chestnuts, apples and bee pollen. I usually prescribe Pau d’Arco, Kai Kit Wan or Jin Gui Shen Qi Wan. •  Formulas: For the elderly with deficient Kidney fire, use Jin Gui Shen Qi Wan. With qi and yin deficiencies, use Gui Zhi Fu Ling with Jin Gui Shen Qi and herbs to soften masses, like Xia Ku Cao, Kun Bu, Hai Zao, Mu Li.•  Prostatitis: This condition is usually caused by damp heat in the Liver and Gallbladder and occurs in younger or middle-aged men. It is characterized by radiating medial thigh pain, blood in the semen and sometimes tailbone pain. If it is chronic or Kidney qi deficient, there may be a white discharge. •  Prostatitis combinations:•  Bilaterally needle 66.03-66.04 Fire Hardness/Fire Master, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors.•  Bilaterally bleed small veins from the medial malleolus up to SP6 San Yin Jiao (insert the bleeding needle or lancet at an angle to avoid striking the tibia). Unilaterally needle left-side 11.01 Great Distance, 11.02 Small Distance; bilaterally needle LV1 Da Dun as a Guiding Point (Dr. Young, 2008).•  Dietary advice for prostatitis: Patients should eat apples, tomatoes, seaweed, oyster shell and zinc. •  Formulas: For damp heat, use Si Ni San with Zhi Bai Di Huang or Long Dan Xie Gan Tang with Bei Xie. For radiating pain, use Chuan Lian Zi, Li Zhi He, Yan Hu Suo and Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang. For Kidney qi deficiency with chronic white discharge, use Shen Qi Wan with Yi Mu Cao. With blood in the semen and radiating pain, use Huo Luo Xiao Ling Dan with Pu Huang and Wu Ling Zi or Gui Zhi Fu Ling and Ru Xiang, Mu Yao, Chuan Shan Jia, Di Long.•  Edema:•  Heart: When edema is heart related, it may show up on only one leg, or on both legs. Fluid may leak from acupuncture needle sites when the situation is severe. Chronic leg edema may be due to Kidney weakness in addition to the Heart; for that reason, we use Spleen and Kidney herbs and choose from both Heart and Kidney points listed below:•  For heart-related edema in the legs and feet: Use Spleen and Kidney herbs and the following points: 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points; 77.18-77.21 Two or Three Emperors with 88.03 Passing Heaven; 77.18 Shen Guan with 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36); Formulas for heart failure: Shen Fu Long Gu Mu Li Tang with Sheng Mai San or Zhen Wu Tang with Sheng Mai San.•  Kidney: Edema in the lower legs due to kidney failure or disease can be difficult to treat, and serious. We usually do not moxa above the navel, as this can be too drying, but in the case of edema due to kidney failure, moxa REN9 Shui Fen (the primary TCM point for edema). Facial edema relates to Kidney, though severe kidney disease may or may not involve facial swelling. •  Treatments may include: Bilateral 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points; 77.17 Heaven Emperor (SP9) (He-Sea/water point on an earth channel) or 77.18-77.28 Two or Three Emperors (using either 77.21 Man Emperor or 77.28 Bright Light); 77.18-77.21 Two or Three Emperors with 88.03 Passing Heaven and 22.06-22.07 Zhong Bai/Xia Bai to treat swollen, edematous limbs. Bleed 44.17 Water Healing to strengthen the kidneys, for edema, nephritis and proteinuria; 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36) can be used to induce urination as it is the He-Sea/earth point on an earth channel, and earth controls water.•  Formulas: For chronic edema, use Zhen Wu Tang. Other possibilities: Gui Zhi Shao Yao Zhi Mu Tang with Zhen Wu Tang or Shen Fu Tang with Ling Gui Zhu Gan Tang. These formulas can be used for either heart-related or kidney-related edema.•  Whole body: When the whole body is holding water, it may be due to both Heart and Kidney. 44.08-44.10 Three Ancestors treats whole-body edema (due to both Heart and Kidney). However, Three Ancestors are rarely used due to complications in locating and needling. See point choices above for both Heart and Kidney edema.•  Liver: Ascities or abdominal edema relates to the Liver. See 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows. Dietary advice for edema: Ask your patient to eat adzuki beans cooked with barley to help move the water. A bone broth can be used to cook them. If the patient cannot eat multiple bowls per day, they can blend the mixture into a warm drink that can be chugged. This will help reduce water retention without weakening the patient. •  Diuretics such as Lasix should be used as a last resort, as they squeeze the kidneys to remove excess water. If the person is in a weakened state, this could actually hasten their demise. Once patients are having needle aspiration to remove fluids, they are considered end stage. Fluids aspirated in this way will be quickly replaced. I had an end-stage cirrhosis patient who received needle aspiration twice for her ascites, before I was able to get on top of her liver disease with 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows and 11.20 Wood Inflammation. That was three years ago, and she is still alive today. •  Kidney failure (formulas): See Edema: Kidney Comments, above, for point combinations. Dong Chong Xia Cao (cordyceps) in a dosage of 6-9 grams daily for one to three weeks, then two times per week, is very helpful for any kind of kidney failure. With qi and yin deficiency, use Shen Qi Mai Wei Di Huang. For Spleen and Kidney yang deficiency, use Zhen Wu Tang. •  Edema due to kidney failure: Moxa on REN9 Shui Fen is the best treatment for this kind of edema. •  Failure to urinate: This condition indicates either a severely enlarged prostate (can be emergent when antihistamines are used) or kidney failure. •  Salt pouch: Using a salt pouch to warm the navel can promote urination, though with complete kidney failure, a salt pouch is not strong enough. Use moxa, as described below. •  Moxa on the navel: For difficulty urinating due to kidney failure, use moxa on the navel. Line the belly button with a thin paper and fill it with salt. Then, cover the salt with a thin slice of ginger that has been pierced many times with a fork. Burn five large moxa balls (or ten stick-on moxa cones) until the salt melts. •  Note: I learned this treatment in Dr. Lee’s clinic long before stick-on moxa was available. We hand-pressed moxa into balls for the above procedure. I witnessed multiple patients who were already on dialysis and unable to urinate begin to void again after the moxa treatment. In my own clinic, a patient with kidney failure also returned to urinating after moxibustion. Success with this protocol depends upon the severity of the kidney failure. For my patient, it was acute, not chronic. I had one patient with severe chronic kidney failure, for whom this treatment did not work.•  Bed-wetting: When the tip of the little finger does not reach the palmar line of the last joint on the ring finger, this indicates a genetic Kidney deficiency. Many children who were born prematurely have a problem with bed-wetting, a sign of Kidney deficiency. It is common for them to be fearful. The best treatment is to moxa from REN4 Guan Yuan to REN8 Shen Que (the navel). Salt pouch (for home treatment): This treatment is also used for failure to thrive and has been enormously helpful to me, personally, in my practice. Have the child’s parents sew a small non-flammable pouch and fill it with rock salt. This pouch can be heated in the microwave to tolerance. Also have them stitch a small felt pocket that has a Velcro enclosure on the top edge and attach it to a belt (also made of felt), and add a Velcro clasp. Place the heated salt pouch in the pocket, then strap it around the baby or toddler (or elder child who is bed wetting), over the navel, with the Velcro clasp in the back where the child cannot reach it. Be absolutely sure that the salt is hot, but not so hot that it burns. The pouch may be worn until it cools, or approximately forty-five minutes to one hour per session. Because this treatment is so comforting to the child, it may be done multiple times per day and continued until there is a reduction in enuresis. This treatment has been a godsend when used for infants who projectile vomit or do not roll over within a reasonable time, or for those who show any other signs of delayed development. The parents can decide how long to provide this treatment for their child, a good rule of thumb might be four to six weeks beyond the resumption of normal development or healthy digestion. Additionally, the salt pouch may be turned to the child’s back to heat the DU4 Ming Men – UB23 Shen Shu area. •  For older children: Bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Two or Three Emperors, 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water, 22.05 Ling Gu or 77.17 Heaven Emperor (SP9) with 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36).•  Shoulder pain: Shen Guan is frequently chosen to treat frozen shoulder or typical shoulder pain due to its wonderful ability to reach both the front and back of the shoulder in two very potent ways. Firstly, due to the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yin (SP) connection, it treats the front of the shoulder (LU1-LU2 area). Secondly, due to the special relationship between the Foot Tai Yin (Spleen) and Hand Tai Yang (Small Intestine), Kidney Gate can be used to treat the back of the shoulder. Please see 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36) for a detailed description of frozen shoulder treatment.•  Eye diseases: Although I always start any treatment for the eyes with 55.02 Flower Bone One, the Two or Three Emperors points are also exceptional when strengthening the power of vision is required. In these cases, I always substitute 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7) for 77.21 Man Emperor, adding GB20 and GB37 for a dynamite eye treatment. •  Case history (herpes in the eye): When treating herpes in the eye, once all of the above-listed needles are placed, I bleed the Koryo Hand Therapy (KHT) Eye and Head Points on the ends of the middle fingers – a truly miraculous treatment for restoring clear vision. My patient with this problem experienced what he called “cotton balls,” puffy white clouds in his visual field; these were white blood cells in the area that were attempting to fight the virus. His affected eye was red and he had difficulty focusing his vision. After only three treatments, including KHT bleeding techniques, his “bad” eye was seeing as well as his “good” eye. When treating a viral condition, it is necessary to continue treatment long after the improvement of symptoms, at least quarterly and perhaps indefinitely. For this patient, I also prescribed Ultra Vir-X by Biotics Research, and Dendrobium Night Sight Pills (Shihu Yeguang Wan) to bring the anti-viral formula to the eyes. •  Menopausal hot flashes and night sweats: One of my all-time favorite uses for Shen Guan and Two or Three Emperors is in the treatment of miserable menopausal women. If a woman is exiting fertility gracefully (asymptomatically), I do not encourage hormonal activity by providing unnecessary treatment. If it isn’t broken, don’t fix it; it’s far better to leave well enough alone. However, in extreme cases, if a woman is sweating all night and “suffocating” all day, she will really appreciate the following treatment: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.24 Gynecological Points, 11.06 Return to the Nest, 77.18-77.21 Two or Three Emperors, and LI4/LV3 Four Gates, in that order. If insomnia, depression or anxiety are also part of the picture, I frequently add the Prefrontal Scalp Points. •  Spleen points during pregnancy: Most Spleen channel points are contraindicated during pregnancy; however, Shen Guan may be an exception to that rule. Although some sources discourage its use, it is not officially forbidden. Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment, when modified for pregnancy, substitutes Shen Guan for SP6 San Yin Jiao (definitely contraindicated) and excludes LI4 He Gu. I have been using this combination for my pregnant patients for more than thirty years with fantastic results. Because the Kidneys are so utterly taxed during gestation, this treatment is enormously restorative. Once the baby has been delivered, Two or Three Emperors points will strengthen and consolidate the poor tired Kidneys and are a very important part of postpartum care. For this, Shen Guan is unsurpassed. Moxa is also extremely useful in postpartum care; please see Mother Roasting: The Use of Traditional Chinese Medicine in Post Partum Care by Raven Lang, OMD. Do not over-treat in pregnancy; only do what is required.•  Preeclampsia (toxemia) is marked by an increase in blood pressure and protein in the urine after the 20th week of pregnancy. Check your pregnant patient’s blood pressure every time you treat her, so you can establish a baseline and will know if her pressure starts to increase. Should the blood pressure rise during pregnancy, acupuncture treatment will be less important than prescribing the correct herbal formula to tonify Kidney yin and xtinguish Liver wind. I have had great success treating this condition using a powerful herbal formula and Shen Guan. •  Hypertension: Two or Three Emperors points are very helpful in treating Kidney-deficient-type hypertension. In my experience, when the blood pressure rises toward the late afternoon, it is associated with deficiency of the Kidneys. It could be Liver excess, as well, especially if the blood pressure is also exceptionally high upon awakening in the morning. Needling Two or Three Emperors to consolidate and strengthen Kidney qi gently lowers blood pressure. I often bleed 99.08 Ear Apex, too, when blood pressure hovers around 150/100. If a patient’s blood pressure is higher than that, I am more aggressive and may bleed the fingertips, 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line and/or DT.04 Five Mountain Range. When a patient’s diastolic pressure exceeds 100, I seriously consider sending them immediately to the emergency room for blood pressure medication, as soon as I have dropped their blood pressure with these kinds of bleeding treatments. I would rather they take blood pressure medications and then discontinue them safely, over time, than risk any kind of cerebrovascular accident. Be sure to follow up with these patients. •  Hypotension: “Sometimes after needling Two Emperors, the patient will experience orthostatic hypotension when they stand up. If this happens, immediately supplement ST36 Zu San Li and it will be relieved” (Dr. Lee, 1992). For this reason, I am very careful in needling the Emperors points when blood pressure is already low or when there has been excessive blood loss.•  Frontal headache (deficient type): To diagnose a deficient frontal headache, ask the patient to press gently on their eyeballs with warm fingers. If it is a deficient-type headache, they will like the pressure. For this type of headache, needle the Spleen channel, combining Shen Guan and 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) and/or 66.10 Fire Connection (SP3). Shen Guan is acting as the He-Sea point of the Spleen channel, though SP9 may be substituted. 66.10 Fire Connection (SP3) is the Yuan-Source and Shu-Stream point of the Spleen meridian, so it is good for pain and heaviness of the head. 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) is the Luo Connecting point and opens the Chong Mai. 66.10 and 66.11 are needled using a 30mm needle and the curving needle technique to wrap around the bone. Because a deficient frontal headache could be considered a tired or blood-deficient headache, also consider implementing Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment. See 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36) for additional information related to diagnosis and for treatment of excess-type frontal headaches.•  Combining points with Shen Guan: Shen Guan regulates the Spleen when combined with 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36), and tonifies the Kidneys when combined with KD7 Fu Liu. When treating Kidney and Spleen deficiency, choose either Three Emperors or 77.17 Heaven Emperor with 66.14 Water Phase (KD3) (Dr. Young, 2008). •  Acid reflux or stomach ulcer: Both Shen Guan and 77.17 Heaven Emperor decrease stomach acid. Because He-Sea points correct reflux in the flow of qi, and Heaven Emperor is the water point on an earth channel (cooling Stomach fire), this combination of two points is used for acid reflux and bad breath. Note: 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36) has the opposite effect, increasing stomach acid.•  Case history (gas and shoulder pain, Renaud): “A patient arrived complaining of one-sided shoulder pain that would be alleviated when she burped. She was a singer who had been diagnosed with acid reflux, which affected her voice. She had told her doctors that she felt her shoulder pain and her acid reflux symptoms seemed interrelated, but they told her there was no connection. Since I knew Shen Guan would treat both conditions, I needled it on the opposite-side leg that day and she felt better immediately.” •  Case history (diabetic neuropathy): Three Emperors are primary in the treatment of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy because they tonify Spleen qi and Kidney yin. I once had a patient whose feet were so sensitive he could not have the weight of a sheet placed over them. First, I treated the feet with gentle Gua Sha (oil and rubbing with a finger), and then added bilateral Three Emperors. After one treatment, his feet were eighty percent better. After the second treatment, his oncologist called me to find out what I was doing. •  Neuropathy: When treating neuropathy, it is always important to know its origin. Numbness in the extremities can be caused by multiple factors, such as: stenosis or bone spurring, high cholesterol, hypertension, pharmaceuticals, or diabetes, each requiring a different approach. When the numbness comes from the Heart, choose 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing points. If the numbness is related to medications that the patient is continuing to take, there is no point in treating it. If it is due to chemotherapy agents, simply wait to address it until chemotherapy finishes; also be sure to thoroughly cup the DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas at that time. •  Note: If there are bone spurs in the cervical vertebrae that are causing neuropathy, see 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One for the bone spur protocol.
combinations: Acid reflux I: Bilaterally needle 77.17 Heaven Emperor, 77.18 Shen Guan.•  Acid reflux II: Bleed 1010.07 All Pivot; bilaterally needle 77.17 Heaven Emperor, 77.18 Shen Guan, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4), PC6 Nei Guan; deeply needle REN12 Zhong Wan (60mm needle). •  Frontal headache (from deficiency): Bilaterally needle 77.18 Shen Guan or 77.17 Heaven Emperor with 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4) and/or 66.10 Fire Connection (SP3); also consider: A.04 San Cha Three or 22.06 Middle White (Tung’s SJ3); Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment. (See Comments above.)•  Numbness of the hands and feet: Bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors or 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (Tung’s SP4). •  Menopause: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.24 Gynecological Points, 11.06 Return to the Nest, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. If there is also irritability, anger, depression or insomnia, add LI4/LV3 Four Gates and the Prefrontal Scalp Points.•  Eye problems (deficiency type): Bilaterally needle 77.18 Shen Guan, 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7) (modified Two Emperors) with GB20 Feng Chi and GB37 Guang Ming, also bleed Tai Yang (Extra Point), or Koryo Hand Therapy (KHT) middle finger Eye Points. For cataracts or deviated eye, consider 55.02 Flower Bone One. •  Glaucoma: 55.02 Flower Bone One with either 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle or 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors with GB20 Feng Chi and GB37 Guang Ming.•  Floaters: Bilaterally needle 77.18 Shen Guan, 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7) (modified Two Emperors) with A.04 San Cha Three and 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43). •  Frozen shoulder: See 77.08 Four Flower Upper, Comments. •  Diabetes: Bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors with LI5 Yang Xi, 66.14 Water Phase (Tung’s KD3), SJ4 Yang Chi and LV3 Tai Chong. If there are diabetic lesions, bleed 11.26 Control Dirt.•  Proteinuria: Bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Two or Three Emperors. Difficulty urinating: Bilaterally needle 1010.14 Horse Fast Water, 77.17 Heaven Emperor (SP9) with 77.21 Man Emperor (SP6) or 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. Additional treatments: •  Bilaterally needle 77.17 Heaven Emperor (SP9), 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36).•  Bilaterally needle 44.06 Shoulder Center, 44.11 Cloud White, 44.12 lum White or 44.17 Water Healing.•  Formula: Shen Qi Tang with Niu Xi, Che Qian Zi.•  Frequent urination: Bilaterally needle 77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate) or 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water or 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through.Additional treatments: •  Bilaterally needle 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5), 77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate); 66.01 Seal, 66.02 Wood Wife, LU7 Lie Que (Dr. Young, 2008). Note: Both LU5 and LU7regulate fluid passageways. Herbs: should include Sang Piao Xiao, Long Gu, Mu Li.•  Turbid urine: There are five kinds of turbid urine: qi, sand, blood, with fever, or thick/turbid. Though different herbs are prescribed for each type, all formulas should include Chuan Nui Xi. We can use the same point combinations for all five types of turbidity, though a deep needle (50-60mm) on REN6 Qi Hai is the most important point and will be added to the following:•  Bilaterally needle 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points, 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water. •  Bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water, 66.03-66.04 Fire Hardness/Fire Master.•  Urethralgia: Unilaterally needle 11.03-11.04 Floating Distance/External Distance, bilaterally needle 22.05 Ling Gu, 66.03 Fire Hardness, 66.04 Fire Master; bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors; bilaterally needle 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water; bilaterally needle 44.11-44.12 Cloud White/Plum White; bilaterally needle 1010.16 Six Fast, 1010.17 Seven Fast.•  Swelling in legs and weakness: 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors.•  Varicosities: 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. Use pricking bleeding of small- to medium-sized veins; NEVER bleed large, ropy veins. It is all right to use a seven-star hammer.•  Late stage of paralysis, after stroke: 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, thread DU19-DU21. See 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB21) for hemiplegia/stroke protocol.
reaction_areas: Kidney, Heart Do not needle in cases of low blood pressure.

name: Dihuang, Earth Emperor (T 77.19)
location: This point is located on the SP channel, 7 cun proximal to the tip of the medial malleolus. | Johnson: Earth Emperor is located on the medial side of the lower leg. It is considered a floating point because it is found midway between 77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate) and 77.21 Man Emperor, and its location may vary as much as 1.0 cun, depending upon which version of Man Emperor is used. Note: See 77.18 Shen Guan: Three Emperors, Comments, for further details.
primary_indications: proteinuria Any urinary disorders: lin zheng (dysuria syndrome)
johnson_indications: Frequent painful urination due to urinary spasms (strangury)
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . | Johnson: Technique: Slide the needle down the back of the tibia, touching the bone and avoiding the blood vessel whenever possible. 33 In this list of indications, those found in bold are the situations in which I am most likely to needle Three Emperors instead of Two Emperors. The indications that are not bolded may require additional points that would preclude my use of Earth Emperor, in order to reduce the overall number of needles in a given treatment. Needling directions: This point is primarily needled perpendicularly. The point is occasionally needled at a 45-degree angle toward the head, especially when treating edema in the legs. The point is needled obliquely toward the Liver and Kidney channels when it is desirable to combine the effects of all three channels. Depth: 1.0-1.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Earth Emperor functions as SP7 Lou Gu (the Xi-Cleft point of the Spleen channel) and is indicated for treating urinary, reproductive, digestive and gynecological diseases resulting from Kidney and Spleen deficiency. Three Emperors Dao Ma: Earth Emperor and 77.21 Man Emperor are often needled as Supporting Points to 77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate), thus forming the Dao Ma combination known as Three Emperors. I add Earth Emperor to enhance the strength of the treatment and any time I am treating the lower extremities. However, for patients who are deficient, such as the elderly, or patients for whom the number of needles should be limited, Earth Emperor is a point I might omit. See 77.18 Shen Guan, Three Emperors, Comments, for further details. Postpartum: Postnatal deficiency relates to Spleen; prenatal deficiency relates to Kidney. This point treats both. (However, use this point after birth because it is contraindicated to needle during pregnancy.)

name: Sizhi, Four Limbs (T 77.20)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 4 cun proximal to the tip of the medial malleolus. | Johnson: Four Limbs is located on the medial side of the lower leg, four cun (six fingers) proximal to the tip of the medial malleolus. Note: This places Four Limbs at the same location as Tung’s “Upper San Yin Jiao” (also known as 77.21 Man Emperor). Cautions: Do not needle during pregnancy.
johnson_indications: Pain or tingling in the arms or fingers
Pain in the four limbs (hands and feet)
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1.2 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 0.5-1.2 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Four Limbs is located on the Spleen meridian and treats both the Spleen and the Kidney. Because it has the Reaction Areas of Heart, Kidney and Four Limbs, it is used to treat the extremities as related to the Hand and Foot Shao Yin, blood and circulation. Peripheral neuropathy: In order to know how to treat the condition, it is important to understand the cause of the tingling, numbness or pain in the arms or hands. If there are bone spurs in the cervical vertebrae, see 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One for the bone spur protocol. The treatment will be different than one that is designed to treat peripheral neuropathy from diabetes, drug side effects, high blood pressure and/or high cholesterol (see 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors). When the numbness comes from the Heart, choose 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing points. For neck pain, see 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons.
combinations: Sores on the legs: 77.20 Four Limbs, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. Tingling arms and fingers, hand and finger pain: 77.20 Four Limbs, 77.18 Shen Guan. See 77.21 Man Emperor, also known as Upper San Yin Jiao.
reaction_areas: Heart, Kidney, Four Limbs Cautions: • Do not needle during pregnancy.

name: Renhuang, -77.21 Two Emperors. If severe, add 33.13-33.15 Three Scholars. (T 77.21)
location: This point overlaps with Sanyinjiao (SP 6) , which is 3 cun directly above the tip of the medial malleolus along the posterior border of the tibia. | Johnson: Man Emperor, in all other written sources, is said to be located at Textbook SP6 San Yin Jiao. However, I was taught that Master Tung officially found Man Emperor 1.0 cun proximal to Textbook SP6, or three cun (four fingers) above the top (not the “tip”) of the medial malleolus, and thus it is referred to as Upper San Yin Jiao. This is the location that I most frequently utilize. Note: There are three other locations that can be substitutes for Man Emperor. See 77.18 Shen Guan, Three Emperors, Comments for possible 77.21 point substitutions. Do not needle during pregnancy except to induce labor. Because this point lowers blood pressure, avoid needling in cases of extremely low blood pressure.
primary_indications: proteinuria Any urinary disorders: lin zheng (dysuria syndrome)
johnson_indications: Weakness of the lower back and legs*
techniques: Needle 1 - 2.5 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 0.5-1.2 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Textbook Man Emperor, in the location of traditional SP6 San Yin Jiao, has the Reaction Area of Kidney. I usually needle Man Emperor (Tung’s SP6) as Upper San Yin Jiao, one cun proximal to textbook SP6 (placing it in the same location as 77.20 Four Limbs). The use of this location brings with it the additional Reaction Areas of Heart and Four Limbs, strengthening the Hand and Foot Shao Yin (HT/KD) connection and lending to it an even stronger influence on blood, blood vessels and circulation. For these reasons, 77.18 Shen Guan and Man Emperor (also known as Two Emperors) are frequently used to treat arteriosclerosis and coronary heart disease. These points are needled as close to the back of the tibia as possible. There is usually a dark blood vessel here, and it is hard to avoid; needling this vessel also contributes to the points’ efficacy in treating heart disease via the vessel-treating-vessel system. Similarly, needling the Emperors points close to the bone also activates the bone-treating-bone system, enhancing their overall Kidney tonification effects. This is particularly useful with any kind of chronic condition, including bone and bone marrow disorders, weakness in the lower limbs, deficient infertility, postpartum weakness, recovery after surgical procedures or chemotherapy, etc. The power of Man Emperor (Tung’s SP6) is also derived from its proximity to classic SP6, the crossing point of the Spleen, Liver and Kidney. •  Two or Three Emperors: Man Emperor is often needled as a Supporting Point to 77.18 Shen Guan in the combination known as Two Emperors, or with both Shen Guan and 77.19 Earth Emperor in the combination known as Three Emperors. (See 77.18 Shen Guan, Comments: Three Emperors.)•  Bleeding to treat stagnation of the lower jiao: There is a very convenient treatment for lower jiao stagnation, taught to me by Dr. Young. Look for the small veins (even spider veins) found in the area between SP6 and the medial malleolus. Bleeding these smaller vessels, usually with a lancet or hypodermic needle tip, is very effective for infertility, bladder infections, genital herpes outbreaks, and lower jiao conditions caused by wet heat. When treating a bladder infection, though the above treatment may be helpful, bleeding Koryo Hand Therapy A-line in the area of the hand/heel point is extraordinarily effective (see 66.02 Wood Wife, Comments on interstitial cystitis for further information). I am less inclined to use this treatment for bacterial dysentery. •  Caution: It is difficult to avoid tapping the tibia with the tip of your bleeding needle. Be very conscious of this, and if you must contact the bone, be sure to do it extremely gently. For this reason, I usually avoid using a spring-loaded lancet in this area, and instead use a hand-held instrument and puncture at a 45-degree angle.

name: Cesanli, Beside Three Miles (T 77.22)
location: This point is 1.5 cun lateral to Zusanli (ST 36) , between the ST and the GB channels. | Johnson: 77.22 Beside Three Miles is located on the lateral side of the lower leg, 1.0-1.5 cun lateral to 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36). In the proper location of this point, we utilize the exact method of locating Four Flower Upper: 77.22 Beside Three Miles: With one finger on the proximal head of the fibula and another on the base of the tibial tuberosity, draw a horizontal line from the base of the tibial tuberosity that intersects a vertical line drawn directly downward from the head of the fibula. Divide your horizontal line into equal thirds. 77.08 Four Flower Upper is located one third of the distance lateral from the base of the tibial tuberosity. 77.22 Beside Three Miles is located laterally, two thirds of the distance on this same horizontal line. Alternatively, measure one third of the distance medially on the same line, diagonally downward from the head of the fibula. (Please see the above drawing.) 77.23 Beside Three Miles Lower: This point is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) distal to 77.22 Beside Three Miles, two large finger breadths lateral to the anterior tibial crest. Beside Three Miles Lower is only occasionally found directly inferior to Beside Three Miles. Measure carefully and palpate for the precise location, as this point is easily felt and is a good point for palpation practice.
primary_indications: sinusitis Intercostal neuralgia Abdominal pain due to appendicitis
johnson_indications: Neck and shoulder strain or sprain (Shao Yang)*
One-sided pain of the body: neck, shoulder, elbow, wrist and heel
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. This point can also be bled, especially for disorders of the upper jiao . | Johnson: Needle sensation: When these needles are properly inserted, the patient may feel a zing of energy descend down the leg. I fish for this qi sensation if it does not happen spontaneously, because I have found the treatment to be immediately effective when the sensation happens. Often the sensation stops at GB40, in which case it is necessary to massage the area, beginning approximately two cun below the points, focusing on the ankle and the dorsum of the foot. Gently tug on the fourth toe or stimulate the needle until the sensation reaches either LV3 or GB41. Do not leave the energy stuck at GB40, or the patient may have difficulty walking after they get off the table. Opposite-side needling vs. bilateral needling: Beside Three Miles are nearly always needled on the side opposite the indications, as they are the most useful for one-sided issues. However, it is not forbidden to needle them bilaterally. If you obtain a strong “da qi” sensation in one leg, the patient may or may not feel the same sensation in the other leg, but if they do feel it, work to move the qi beyond the ankle, as described above. Tonification vs. sedation: If the patient is strong, or if the needle is tight when inserted, sedate the point. If the patient is weak, or if the needle is soft when inserted, tonify. Dao Ma: 77.22 Beside Three Miles (Chief Point) is always needled with 77.23 Beside Three Miles Lower (Supporting Point). Depth: 1.0-1.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: It is interesting to note that Beside Three Miles points have the Reaction Areas of Lung and Teeth. Because metal (Lung) controls wood (Liver/ Gallbladder), these points are exceptionally useful in the treatment of tendons and ligaments, obtaining their strength from their proximity to GB34 Yang Ling Quan, the Sea of Tendons. Located between the Shao Yang and Yang Ming channels, they also draw from ST36 Zu San Li (Leg Three Miles), hence their name. In Tung’s body of work, many points found between the Stomach and Gallbladder channels are loosely classified as “Gallbladder channel points.” All of them have a powerful effect on the head and neck, face, jaw and five senses; therefore, it is important to determine the root cause of the pathology before choosing from the following points: Beside Three Miles, 77.05-77.07 Three Weights, 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold, 77.27 Outer Three Gates, 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, and 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31). All Gallbladder points deal with joints, tendons and wind, especially Beside Three Miles, but we also want to think of bone and bone marrow, as related to Shao Yang (blood and Sea of Marrow). Migraines: Beside Three Miles are primary points for treating one-sided (Shao Yang) migraine headaches, spasm or pain, which often includes TMJ, the sternocleidomastoid muscle, GB20 Feng Chi and GB21 Jian Jing. Eventually, I always cup patients who have migraines, carefully choosing the timing if I am going to include the face area, because cupping marks will remain on the face for as much as a week after the treatment. I often bleed the vein above the eye or in the temple area, as well, as this usually provides immediate and lasting relief; on occasion, bleeding this area one time has been the only treatment needed. Be careful to avoid the artery by palpating for a pulse prior to donning your surgical gloves. (See 1010.10 Four Bowels Second for additional bleeding instructions). Ear disorders: Otitis media and ear pain: Because the Gallbladder channel wraps around the ear, Beside Three Miles points are excellent for otitis media and ear pain. Needle the side opposite the pain or bleed the same side. You can also needle opposite-side
combinations: Migraine headache: Needle opposite-side 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles. If migraines are cyclic, add 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points. With anger and/or depression, add 11.17 Wood (Anger). Bleed above the eye or in the temple area (see 1010.10 Four Bowels Second for further information).•  Headaches related to tight tendons in the neck: Needle 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles, adding 66.05 Golden Gate if there is nausea and vomiting. •  Bell’s palsy, facial paralysis, trigeminal neuralgia: See 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36), Combinations, for additional treatment information.•  Heel pain (severe): Needle opposite-side 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles or 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) (Dr. Young, 2008).•  One-sided shoulder, elbow, wrist, hand and/or finger pain (related to ligaments or tendons): Needle opposite-side 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles

name: Cexiasanli, Beside Three Miles Lower (T 77.23)

name: Zuqianjin, Leg Thousand Gold (T 77.24)
location: This point is between the ST and GB channels, 2 cun lateral and 7 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament below the knee when it is flexed. | Johnson: These points are located on the anterior border of the fibula and the gastrocnemius. The easiest way to locate them is to first locate 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles: 77.24 Leg Thousand Gold is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) distal and 0.5 cun lateral to 77.23 Beside Three Miles Lower. Palpate to fine-tune your point location. •  77.25 Leg Five Gold is located 2.0 cun directly distal to Leg Thousand Gold.
primary_indications: tonsillitis Pain in the shoulder area
secondary_indications: fish bone stuck in the throat
johnson_indications: Plum pit qi sensation in the throat*
Shoulder pain with difficulty moving the shoulder forward and back*
Inability to lift the arm over the head
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Needle sensation: Similar to 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles, when needling these points the patient may feel a zing of energy down the leg to the dorsum of the foot. If it does not happen spontaneously, I will fish for if it. Typically, the sensation stops at GB40 making it necessary to massage the area beginning approximately 2.0 cun below the points and specifically focusing on the ankle and the dorsum of the foot. Gently tug on the fourth toe or stimulate the needle until it reaches either LV3 or GB41. Do not leave the stuck energy at GB40, or the patient may have difficulty walking when they get off the table. •  Dao Ma: 77.24 Leg Thousand Gold and 77.25 Leg Five Gold are combined in the Dao Ma that I call “Leg Five/One Thousand Gold.”35 I use this name because otherwise when shortened, it would sound like the numbers 1,005 or 5,000. Instead I use a shortened version of Leg Five Gold/Leg Thousand Gold. I have used this same nomenclature with 33.08-33.09 Arm Five/One Thousand Gold.•  Usually opposite side: Needle on the opposite side to treat all indications listed, with the exception of hyperthyroid or goiter (needle bilaterally).•  Depth: 1.0-1.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: There are many points in Master Tung’s system located between the Gallbladder and Stomach meridians, all of which treat shoulder and upper back pain. Leg Thousand Gold and Leg Five Gold (also referred to as Leg Five/One Thousand Gold) additionally treat wind and phlegm, and have the Reaction Areas of Kidney, Lung and Thyroid. “Gold” in the name of these points implies metal, referring to Lung and Large Intestine. The following discussions illustrate the many different energetic pathways utilized by these points, which powerfully tonify metal to control wood.•  Hyperthyroid: I love to use these points for hyperthyroid, especially gestational hyperthyroid, which can be difficult to treat. When the Heart and Liver fire are rising in pregnancy, we must sedate very carefully in order to protect the fetus. Because these Gallbladder points utilize the special relationship between the Foot Shao Yang (GB)and the Hand Shao Yin (HT), they also connect the Hand and Foot Shao Yin (HT/KD), and so we see the Reaction Area of Kidney. These wonderful points are capable of gently draining fire from the Heart and Liver, while nourishing the Kidneys to stop sweating and hold the fetus. •  Goiter: Thyroid enlargement can relate to either hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism. With the Reaction Areas of Thyroid and Lung, these points connect to the Hand and Foot Yang Ming (LI/ST) passing through the throat and neck, which relate to the accumulation of qi and phlegm in the neck. Because of the internal/external relationship of Lung and Large Intestine, as well as the special relationship between the Hand Yang Ming (LI) and Foot Jue Yin (LV), we additionally address both internal and external wind as it relates to the throat (laryngitis/sore throat), as well as phlegm (goiter). •  Frozen shoulder: Leg Five/One Thousand Gold points are frequently part of my protocol for treating a frozen shoulder, as they implement all of the relationships discussed above. Affecting both the Lung and Large Intestine channels locally (difficulty moving the shoulder forward or backward), they also address tendons and ligaments through their relationship to the Liver and Gallbladder, and via the Shao Yang, the San Jiao (Hand Shao Yang) which powerfully affects the shoulder, elbow, arm, wrist and hand.•  Gastroenteritis: Due to the internal connection between the Stomach and Large Intestine meridians and the internal/external connection between the Lung and Large Intestine, these points treat acute intestinal inflammation. Clinically, I use these points primarily for frozen shoulder, thyroid, and throat diseases, and would likely choose other points (such as 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line/Stomach channel; or 66.05 Golden Gate, 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum, PC6 Nei Guan) to treat intestinal inflammation.•  Sore throat: These points can be used for sore throat, swollen throat, fish bone stuck in the throat, goiter or any other throat issue. However, for sore throat, I usually bleed either LU11 or LI1 bilaterally, or palpate the throat for areas of thickness (implying congestion) and bleed locally. I pinch up the loose skin on the throat before puncturing, then squeeze/swipe the blood until the throat pain is gone. On the throat, sensory nerve endings for pain are very far apart, so local bleeding is far less painful than bleeding the finger ing-Well points. See VT.01 Throat Nine Moths
combinations: Tonsillitis: Bleed locally (see Comments above) and bilaterally needle 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold.•  Frozen shoulder: See 77.08 Four Flower Middle (ST36).•  Growth in the throat: Bilaterally bleed 77.09 Four Flower Middle and needle 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold. •  Gestational hyperthyroid: Unilaterally needle 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points; bilaterally needle 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold. •  Hyperthyroid: Bilaterally needle 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold, add Auricular Points: Hunger, Heart/Thyroid, Internal Secretion, Kidney, Sympathetic, Shen Men. Also consider 77.05-77.07 Three Weights; 88.17-88.19 Four Horses or 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows (e.g., 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with 88.12 Bright Yellow, or Two Yellows with 88.17 Middle Horse or 88.25 Center Nine Miles).•  Goiter: Bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses; bilaterally needle or bleed 77.05-77.07 Three Weights or 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold.
