name: Qihu, Seven Tigers (T 77.26)
location: This point is a three-point set between the BL and the GB channels, behind the posterior border of the fibula and along the anterior border of the Achilles tendon. The points are 1.5 cun posterior to the lateral malleolus. The first point is 2 cun proximal to the lateral malleolus. The second point is 4 cun proximal to the lateral malleolus, or 2 cun proximal to the first point. The third point is 6 cun proximal to the lateral malleolus, or 2 cun proximal to the second point. | Johnson: Seven Tigers is a three- point unit located on the lateral side of the lower leg. The first point is 1.5 cun (two fingers) posterior and 2.0 cun (three fingers) proximal to the lateral malleolus. The second point is located 2.0 cun proximal to the first point. The third point is located 2.0 cun proximal to the second point.
johnson_indications: Clavicular pain, inflammation or injury (including broken clavicle)*
Breast bone pain with swelling and distension (sternum area)*
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Bleed any veins near these points prior to needling for best results. | Johnson: Depth: 0.5-0.8 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Seven Tigers are located between the Tai Yang (UB) and Shao Yang (GB) channels. Because of the special relationship between the Foot Tai Yang (UB) and Hand Tai Yin (LU), and the Foot and Hand Tai Yang (UB/SI) connection, these points treat pain of the clavicle, sternum and scapula, including broken clavicle. For an old injury, gentle cupping or bleeding locally may be helpful, but do not cup over a break that is less than twelve months old. Be aware that if the broken bones are separated and not touching, they will never fuse. Scapular pain: For scapular pain, I love 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy. If the situation is severe, opposite-side Seven Tigers may be added. 349 Lower Leg Points Clavicular pain (Dr. Lee): “I use Seven Tigers often for clavicular pain. There seems to be a lot of this type of pain in America. I do not know why. In some cases the pain is so severe that the patient cannot stand the slightest touch from even the clothes or bed sheets. If the case is longstanding, it may take perseverance, and recovery may be slow. But one should not give up” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Acromium pain: Choose from: 77.26 Seven Tigers; 77.18 Shen Guan; 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy; 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points; 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles. Chest contusion: Choose from: 77.26 Seven Tigers; 88.17-88.19 Four Horses; PC6 Nei Guan; 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy; bleed 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line. If acute: 88.28 Release (Tung’s ST34 Xi-Cleft). Clavicular pain: Needle opposite-side 77.26 Seven Tigers, or needle bilaterally for pain on both sides (Dr. Lee, 1992). Costal pain: Choose from: 77.26 Seven Tigers; 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31); 88.17-88.19 Four Horses; 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles. •  Scapular pain: Needle opposite-side 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy. If the situation is severe, opposite-side 77.26 Seven Tigers may be added.

name: Waisanguan, Outer Three Gates (T 77.27)
location: This is a three-point set on the GB channel. Divide the distance between the lateral malleolus and the head of the fibula into fourths, and locate these points at ¼, ½, and ¾ along this line. | Johnson: Outer Three Gates is a three-point unit located on the anterior border of the fibula. The middle point (Chief Point) is located midway on a line drawn between the proximal head of the fibula and the lateral malleolus, creating two sections. The other two points are located in the center of these two sections on the same line.
primary_indications: benign or malignant cancer in the abdomen or uterus Pain or weakness in the shoulder and arm
johnson_indications: Shoulder pain, inability to lift the arm over the head (Chief Point)
techniques: Needle 1 - 1.5 cun . For tumors, cancer, tonsillitis and mumps, needle bilaterally. These points can also be bled. It is best if dark blood is removed. | Johnson: Dao Ma: In this three-point pattern, needle the middle point first (Chief Point), then the upper and lower Supporting Points. Stimulate the Chief Point first, and then the outer Supporting Points, returning to the Chief Point to stimulate it again for a strong surge of qi in both directions. Needle bilaterally for cancer. Depth: 0.8-1.2 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Outer Three Gates can treat dermatological diseases because “Outer” implies an exterior function, and also because of the Lung Reaction Area. For the same reason, they can treat acne, tonsillitis, and neck and shoulder pain, especially when there is an inability to move the shoulder forward and backward (similar to 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold). Because I use Outer Three Gates primarily to treat cancer found anywhere in the body, I would not choose them in the treatment of other conditions unless the patient also has cancer, as there are so many other great points for all other indications. Cancer: It is important to know the legal restrictions of your license if you are treating a patient who has been diagnosed with a malignancy. In California, it is illegal for acupuncturists to treat cancer; however, we frequently treat patients who are receiving allopathic care and also request support from TCM. We have many ways of treating the side effects of chemotherapy and radiation, including detoxifying the body before beginning and after the conclusion of those treatments. I do not use Outer Three Gates unless there is malignancy, as benign tumors are better treated with points specific to their location. Directing the treatment: When I use Outer Three Gates to treat tumors, I always start by needling points that direct the treatment to the affected area. For example, in the treatment of a malignant brain tumor, I would first needle 55.06 Upper Tumor, followed by Outer Three Gates (alternating with 77.05-77.07 Three Weights). When malignancy is in the bladder, I first needle 1010.13-1010.14 Horse Gold Water/Horse Fast Water and then Outer Three Gates. If I were treating stomach cancer, I might needle 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43) along with Outer Three Gates (avoiding ST36). For female reproductive cancers, begin with 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points. In cases of Liver cancer, begin with 11.20 Wood Inflammation. Frequency: Outer Three Gates points may be needled daily, as they do not interfere with chemotherapy or radiation treatment. If there is an appropriate family member (licensed practitioner), I teach them to needle these points so they can easily be treated on a daily basis. Mitigating side effects: Whenever I am treating a patient who is undergoing chemotherapy, I carefully study in advance the particular agents that will be used, with the intention of strengthening and protecting any tissues that are typically inflamed or damaged by that agent. For example, if a chemotherapy drug causes mouth ulcers, I may bleed either LU5 or the Stomach channel to clear heat and/ or recommend the regular use of Edgar Cayce’s Ipsab. If the chemotherapy agent causes peripheral neuropathy, I will usually implement the bilateral needling of 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, etc. Side effects can be so severe that I highly recommend getting a jump on them. Sometimes it is hard to know whether it is the cancer or the cancer treatment that kills the patient. Take heart, be brave and compassionate, and do not give up too soon. However, if the patient has an open window to fly away, I always inform them of this option, as mourning family members tend to cling to them. Never push.

name: Guangming, Bright Light (T 77.28)
location: This point is on the KI channel and 1 cun posterior and 2 cun proximal to the tip of the medial malleolus. It is 2 cun proximal to Taixi (KI 3) , which is in the depression midway between the tip of the medial malleolus and the attachment of the Achilles tendon. Some references state that this point overlaps with Fuliu (KI 7) or Jiaoxin (KI 8) . | Johnson: Bright Light is located 1.0 cun lateral and 2.0 cun (three fingers) proximal to the tip of the medial malleolus, anterior to textbook KD7 Fu Liu, and just behind the tibia. This is Tung’s KD7.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Depth: 0.5–1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Bright Light (Tung’s KD7) is the metal and Jing-River point on a water channel. It tonifies the Kidney and the water element in general, to build wood. While the anatomy of the eye is governed by the Liver (wood), the power of vision comes from the Kidneys. Eye diseases: Bright Light is substituted for 77.21 Man Emperor whenever I am using the Dao Ma pattern 77.18-77.21 Two or Three Emperors in the treatment of eye diseases. (For more information, please see 55.02 Flower Bone One and 77.18 Shen Guan, Three Emperors, Comments). Glaucoma: If I am treating glaucoma in a patient younger than 60 years old, I usually treat 55.02 Flower Bone One combined with 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle. For elderly patients, I am more likely to use 55.02 Flower Bone One with 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, GB20 Feng Chi and GB37 Guang Ming. If the patient presses on their eyeballs with their warm fingers and finds this uncomfortable, use 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/ Four Flower Middle instead. Floaters: For treating floaters in the field of vision, use 77.18 Shen Guan, 77.28 Bright Light (Tung’s KD7) (modified Two Emperors) with A.04 San Cha Three and 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43). Commentary (Dr. Lee): “Bright Light treats similar eye problems as 77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate) with which it is often used. Such eye problems, including floaters, have to do with both the Liver and the Kidneys. Eye diseases can be difficult to treat, especially if due to diabetes. Sometimes I prefer to use GB20 Feng Chi that helps to nourish the optic nerves” (Dr. Lee, 1992).

name: Shuanglongyi * (T 77.29)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 1.5 cun below Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament when the knee is flexed.
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 0.8 cun .

name: Shuanglonger * (T 77.30)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 2.1 cun below Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament when the knee is flexed.
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 0.8 cun .

name: Tongguan, Passing Gate (T 88.01)
location: This point is on the anterior midline of the thigh, 5 cun above the upper margin of the patella, close to Futu (ST 32) . | Johnson: The Heart Passing Points are located on the anterior midline of the thigh, in the groove found between the rectus femoris and the vastus medialis. 88.01 Passing Gate is located 5 cun (seven fingers) proximal to the center of the top edge of the patella. 88.02 Passing Mountain is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) proximal to Passing Gate. 88.03 Passing Heaven is located 2.0 cun proximal to Passing Mountain. Caution: These are very powerful points. For this reason, Master Tung suggested needling all six points only when the patient is strong. In my practice, I use these points most frequently for elderly patients with heart disease, and I needle all six points except when the patient is extremely weak, such as after surgery.
primary_indications: All heart diseases: Coronary heart disorder
chest pain Nausea and vomiting Headache
johnson_indications: Poor circulation or paresthesia (prickling or tingling sensation)*
Whole body ache and multiple joint pain (especially fingers and toes)*
Weakness, swelling or pain of the legs due to Heart and Lung*
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 2 cun . | Johnson: Dao Ma: When combined together as a Dao Ma, these points are known as 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points, though sometimes only one or two points are selected on each side during a treatment. Alternate with Inner Passing Points: 88.29-88.31 Inner Passing Points (found 0.5 cun medial) can be substituted for the Heart Passing Points if you are using these points multiple times per week. Depth considerations: 88.01 Passing Gate (the point closest to the knee) is needled more shallowly than the other two points on most people’s thighs, as the flesh is less full. On thin, elderly legs, you will often contact the femur upon needling; go slowly and gently so as not to damage the periosteum, remembering that bone is very sensitive. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: ST32 and blood vessels: ST32 Fu Tu is located between 88.01 and 88.02, and is lateral to these two points. In The Great Compendium of Acupuncture and Moxibustion, ST32 is called the meeting point of blood vessels and luo meridians, indicating that this point strongly regulates blood vessels, which makes it very useful for cardiac patients (Dr. Carson, 1973; Dr. Young, 2008). Heart Reaction Area: All three points have the Reaction Area of the Heart and are used to tonify the Spleen and Stomach. The two upper points, 88.02 Passing Mountain and 88.03 Passing Heaven, are especially good for heart disease and circulation; the two lower points, 88.01 Passing Gate and 88.02 Passing Mountain, have a very powerful regulatory effect on the Stomach. These points tonify fire to generate earth, and thereby regulate qi, blood and circulation. Stomach and Pericardium: Due to the special relationship between the Foot Yang Ming (ST) and Hand Jue Yin (PC), these points are used to strengthen the heart, blood, blood vessels and circulation, and they also have indications related to the stomach. “Passing Gate” indicates a relationship to PC6 Nei Guan (Dr. Young, 2008). These points pass through the Inner Gate to the Heart. Heart (fire), Liver (wood), Spleen (earth) and Kidney (water) all relate to blood; this explains the indications of heart disease, palpitations, dizziness, blurred vision, gastritis and weakness. Leg pain and weakness: I find these points to be extraordinary in the treatment of elderly patients with coronary heart disease and seriously compromised circulation resulting in extreme weakness, cold, pain or numbness in the lower body. I treated an 88-year-old woman who was unable to walk across her kitchen without extreme pain in both legs. Her feet were nearly black with small veins (larger than spider veins). Within two treatments her pain was reduced by eighty percent. She now walks to the mailbox to get her mail and rides her stationary bike 20 minutes every day. Her treatments not only benefited her, but also enabled her to care for her husband with late stage Parkinson’s, allowing them both to remain in their home. Note: Dr. Lee once said, “Lack of strength in the arms and legs is due to heart weakness. This may be, in turn, due to excessive cold or overdosing with heart disease medication”. Rheumatoid arthritis: These are the primary constitutional points used to treat rheumatoid arthritis. If the patient has one or two painful joints in the extremities, we can choose from many points to treat each joint directly. However, if all the joints hurt or the whole body aches, it is a circulation issue, with qi and blood stagnation due to deficiency or phlegm. Found between the Stomach and Spleen channels, the Heart Passing Points have a strong effect on phlegm in the body (phlegm in the joints, phlegm obstructing the brain). The Heart Passing Points are more beneficial than points related to bone, though frequently we touch the femur when needling these 359 Lower Leg Points points, bringing in a bone-treating-bone Kidney function. We may choose to combine Heart Passing Points with 33.12 Heart Gate and 11.27 Five Tigers for a comprehensive rheumatoid arthritis treatment. When circulation is compromised, it is always helpful to clean DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas by cupping. Morning sickness and stabilizing pregnancy: 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points are the primary points used to treat morning sickness and threatened miscarriage; however, Heart Passing Points have similar indications. Due to the special relationship between the Stomach and Pericardium, these points stop vomiting and stabilize pregnancy. Note: PC6 Nei Guan stops vomiting because of this Yang Ming/Jue Yin connection, and also because it is directly related to the vagus nerve. Mental confusion: The Heart Passing Points treat phlegm masking the orifices, a common cause of mental confusion. In a class, Dr. Young once discussed a case in which Heart Passing Points were used to treat a five-year-old girl who did not talk. Impotence: For men with cold feet and impotence (frequently seen together), these points are excellent, as they warm the yang. Moxa pots, moxa boxes or moxa heat packs applied to the Ming Men area and to REN4-REN8 are a very good addition. Edema: Lower leg edema, which can be bilateral or unilateral, relates to the Heart and is a good indicator for these points. If lower leg edema is chronic and/or occurs due to Kidney weakness in addition to Heart, add 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan). Facial swelling relates to Kidney, and abdominal swelling relates to Liver. See 77.18 Shen Guan for further information related to heart failure and edema. Other indications: The Heart Passing Points can be used for other issues, such as those related to Heart and Lung, including upper back and shoulder pain, skin rashes, and rhinitis. Clinically, for all of these conditions I always choose 88.17-88.19 Four Horses over the Heart Passing Points. However, if a patient is treated with 88.01-88.03 and their sinus condition improves, it is due to the relationship between Stomach, Spleen and Lung, which the Heart Passing Points also utilize. Similarly, 88.17-88.19 Four Horses are my first choice for skin rashes; however, if a patient is treated for a heart condition and their skin improves, it is because all itching comes from the Heart. Knee pain: Master Tung taught that points with “Fire” or “Heart” in their name always treat the knee. Heart Passing Points may treat Heart-related knee pain when they are used for circulatory or coronary conditions. However, Tung’s system has so many fabulous points for Heart-related knee pain, and 11.09 Heart Knee would be my preferred choice, especially when treating degenerative knee pain. 88.03 Passing Heaven: This point can be used without 88.01 and 88.02 for knee pain or upper back and shoulder pain.
combinations: Knee pain: Bilaterally needle 11.09 Heart Knee; 88.02 Passing Mountain and 88.03 Passing Heaven or 88.03 Passing Heaven, alone. Swelling below the heart (distension of the stomach affecting chest): Alternate 33.12 Heart Gate, 88.01 Passing Gate, 88.02 Passing Mountain with Old Doctors’ Two Old Needles (ST36 and PC6 Nei Guan). Tachycardia: A.04 San Cha Three, 11.19 Heart Normal, A.04 San Cha Three, 33.12 Heart Gate, 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points; bleed 99.08 Ear Apex. Herbally, use Zhi Gan Cao Tang plus Ku Shen (especially good for tachycardia, according to Dr. Young). Stomach issues: Bleed 77.09 Four Flower Middle; bilaterally needle 88.01 Passing Gate and 88.02 Passing Mountain. Varicose veins: Locally bleed small veins or spider veins, always avoiding large ropey vessels; bilaterally needle 88.01-88.02 Heart Passing Points. Rheumatoid arthritis: Bilaterally needle 11.27 Five Tigers, 33.12 Heart Gate, 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points. See Comments above.
meridian: Between Spleen and Stomach, closer to the Stomach meridian

Moxa pots, moxa boxes or moxa heat packs applied to the Ming Men area and to REN4-REN8 are a very good addition. Edema: Lower leg edema, which can be bilateral or unilateral, relates to the Heart and is a good indicator for these points. If lower leg edema is chronic and/or occurs due to Kidney weakness in addition to Heart, add 77.18 Kidney Gate (Shen Guan). Facial swelling relates to Kidney, and abdominal swelling relates to Liver. See 77.18 Shen Guan for further information related to heart failure and edema. Other indications: The Heart Passing Points can be used for other issues, such as those related to Heart and Lung, including upper back and shoulder pain, skin rashes, and rhinitis. Clinically, for all of these conditions I always choose 88.17-88.19 Four Horses over the Heart Passing Points. However, if a patient is treated with 88.01-88.03 and their sinus condition improves, it is due to the relationship between Stomach, Spleen and Lung, which the Heart Passing Points also utilize. Similarly, 88.17-88.19 Four Horses are my first choice for skin rashes; however, if a patient is treated for a heart condition and their skin improves, it is because all itching comes from the Heart. Knee pain: Master Tung taught that points with “Fire” or “Heart” in their name always treat the knee. Heart Passing Points may treat Heart-related knee pain when they are used for circulatory or coronary conditions. However, Tung’s system has so many fabulous points for Heart-related knee pain, and 11.09 Heart Knee would be my preferred choice, especially when treating degenerative knee pain. 88.03 Passing Heaven: This point can be used without 88.01 and 88.02 for knee pain or upper back and shoulder pain.
combinations: Knee pain: Bilaterally needle 11.09 Heart Knee; 88.02 Passing Mountain and 88.03 Passing Heaven or 88.03 Passing Heaven, alone. Swelling below the heart (distension of the stomach affecting chest): Alternate 33.12 Heart Gate, 88.01 Passing Gate, 88.02 Passing Mountain with Old Doctors’ Two Old Needles (ST36 and PC6 Nei Guan). Tachycardia: A.04 San Cha Three, 11.19 Heart Normal, A.04 San Cha Three, 33.12 Heart Gate, 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points; bleed 99.08 Ear Apex. Herbally, use Zhi Gan Cao Tang plus Ku Shen (especially good for tachycardia, according to Dr. Young). Stomach issues: Bleed 77.09 Four Flower Middle; bilaterally needle 88.01 Passing Gate and 88.02 Passing Mountain. Varicose veins: Locally bleed small veins or spider veins, always avoiding large ropey vessels; bilaterally needle 88.01-88.02 Heart Passing Points. Rheumatoid arthritis: Bilaterally needle 11.27 Five Tigers, 33.12 Heart Gate, 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points. See Comments above.
meridian: Between Spleen and Stomach, closer to the Stomach meridian

name: Jiemeiyi, First Sister (T 88.04)
location: This point overlaps with Jimen (SP 11) , which is on the SP channel, 8 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella and 1 cun medial to the anterior midline of the thigh. | Johnson: 88.04 First Sister is located 8 cun (four fingers twice, plus three fingers) proximal, and 1.0 cun medial, to the center of the top of the patella. 88.05 Second Sister is located 2.5-3.0 cun proximal to First Sister. 88.06 Third Sister is located 2.5-3.0 cun proximal to Second Sister.
primary_indications: red or white vaginal discharge (non-bacterial type)
johnson_indications: Irregular menstruation (early, late, excessive or scanty)*
techniques: Needle 1 - 2.5 cun bilaterally. | Johnson: Needle bilaterally. Dao Ma: The points 88.04-88.06 are needled together in a combination known as Three Sisters. Note for male practitioners: For the patient’s privacy and convenience, 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points may be used without Three Sisters for hormonal imbalances. Depth: 1.0-2.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Because 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters have the Reaction Area of the Kidney and Uterus, and because they are located on the Spleen meridian, these points strengthen the Kidney and control the blood, making them invaluable in the treatment of gynecological diseases. Three Plum Blossom: Not included in Tung’s system is a three-point pattern called Three Plum Blossom, located on the lower abdomen. (Note: A comprehensive write-up on Three Plum Blossom is found directly after Three Sisters) Three Plum Blossom points are nearly interchangeable with Three Sisters in their function, though Three Sisters points have a greater effect on the ovaries, while Three Plum Blossom points have a stronger effect on the uterus. I assigned the Reaction Areas of Kidney and Uterus to Three Plum Blossom as they incorporate 363 Lower Leg Points REN4 Guan Yuan (intersection of the Three Foot Yin channels and REN; benefits uterus and nourishes Kidney) and ST27 Da Ju (benefits Kidney and nourishes essence). Any female complaint that is cyclic in nature is considered hormonal and can be treated using 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points and either Three Sisters or Three Plum Blossom. Both of the latter can be needled for Liver qi congestion or gynecological issues that have an emotional component; both of them regulate the menstrual cycle and are used for irregular or delayed menses, infertility, endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, and to expel a dead fetus. Delayed menses: Along with 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points, Three Sisters are my points of choice for irregular menses or when a menstrual cycle is delayed. When a woman is premenstrual and overdue (but not pregnant), and has irritability and breast pain, Three Sisters usually brings on the menstrual period within 24 to 48 hours. Birth control pills and regulating gynecological hormones: I use Three Sisters frequently to regulate hormones, especially in cases of PMS, irregular cycles or when a woman has been using birth control for an extended period of time. Three Sisters with 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points are very helpful in these situations. If the patient is anovulatory, this treatment will encourage the return of hormonal cycling. This was perfectly illustrated in the case of a 27-year-old woman who had been using birth control pills for fifteen years. It took almost six months using acupuncture and herbs to regulate her menstrual cycles. This regulation is usually accomplished in less than three months when the use of birth control pills has been fewer than five years. In my opinion, it may be safe to use birth control pills for fewer than five years, but when they are taken longer, it can be difficult to return the body to normal hormonal activity. Menopause and regulating hormones: If a woman is premenopausal and wishes to extend her fertility, the above treatment will accomplish just that, in most cases. If a woman is exiting fertility and has hot flashes and night sweats, I balance hormones with 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points and tonify the Kidneys with 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, and avoid Three Sisters. If a woman is exiting fertility gracefully, without symptoms of hormone imbalance or Kidney deficiency, I leave well enough alone and do not encourage hormonal activity by needling any of these female reproductive points, though Three Emperors may still be applied. Amenorrhea: Along with 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points, Three Sisters can be used in cases of amenorrhea; with a good herbal formula directed toward tonifying qi and blood (Liver and Spleen) and moving stagnation, the patient’s period should arrive. Return to the Nest and Gynecological Points alone are capable of this, but the addition of Three Sisters is likely to handle the situation. Dr. Young offers the following treatment for more difficult cases: Bilaterally needle 66.15 Water Fairy, ST25 Tian Shu; needle REN24 Cheng Jiang. The explanation for these points is as follows: Water Fairy is located near KD5 Shui Quan, the Xi-Cleft point on the Kidney meridian, and it tonifies Kidney Source qi. ST25 is the Mu Point for the Large Intestine and regulates qi and blood. REN24 is the best point for amenorrhea because the Stomach and Large Intestine meridians both go around the mouth. REN24 is the Jing-Well point for the REN channel so it opens the orifices. The REN channel also goes through the genitals and regulates qi and blood.  Fibroids and tumors: Dark blood vessels in the lower area of the thenar eminence (close to the wrist) are diagnostic of uterine fibroids or tumors. Fibroids often cause frequent urination, heavy bleeding and lower back pain. Thirty to forty percent of women over age thirty have fibroids, and many of them do not even know it. If the fibroids are the size of an egg, even if there are multiple small ones, they can be treated. If the fibroid is the size of an orange or larger, treating it is a bit too much to promise, and the patient likely will require surgery. If you can see the fibroids because they are that large, the patient will need surgery. If you can manage the symptoms related to fibroids (especially the heavy bleeding) until the patient reaches menopause, the fibroids will shrink at that time and she can probably avoid a hysterectomy. When a woman is told she has a tilted uterus, it is usually due to fibroids; the uterus does not tilt without a reason. During pregnancy: It is not uncommon for a woman to grow a fibroid during a pregnancy. The fibroid will disappear when the hormones change after delivery. Complications may arise if the fibroid prevents the baby from turning, causing a breech presentation. Even still, vaginal delivery may be possible with a skilled midwife or OB/GYN. In my practice, I always take the woman’s blood pressure regularly and palpate the position of the fetus so that I can easily determine if the pregnancy is not progressing as expected. By her second trimester, any pregnant woman in my practice also has regular prenatal visits with her primary birth practitioner; however, these days with the advent of HMOs and 15-minute appointments, patients cannot count on regular blood work or even blood pressure monitoring. I always order blood glucose, hematocrit and hemoglobin tests, as well, when these services are not rendered regularly. Three Sisters and Three Plum Blossom: I usually alternate these two point patterns when treating fibroids. Many women have multiple fibroids that swell right before their period, causing lower abdominal bloating and discomfort. We can use Three Sisters during the premenstrual week, as Three Plum Blossom (located on the lower abdomen) may be too sensitive. Please see Three Plum Blossom for point location and further information. Case history (myoma causing avalanche bleeding): A 35-year-old patient had an intrauterine myoma (in the wall of her uterus) very near the opening of the cervix, which prevented the cervix from closing completely. This caused her to spot or bleed continuously, and at times dangerously. She was capable of passing four clots, each the size of a fist, within fifteen minutes. Because of her age, this woman did not want to have a hysterectomy, though it had been recommended to her. In addition to Three Sisters, 11.06 Return to the Nest, and 11.24 Gynecological Points, she also required a loose herb formula and lots of moxa. Eventually, she was prescribed birth control pills. Almost twenty years later, she is now post- menopausal and still has her uterus. Case history (fibroids): I treated a 52-year-old woman with seven fibroids that varied in size; the largest was about the size of a duck egg. Every two weeks, she experienced avalanche bleeding. Her blood loss had led to extreme weakness and caused most of her hair to fall out. She was menopausal, with hot flashes and night sweats that were incapacitating. Because she was a prominent figure in our community, it was not convenient for her to have a hysterectomy, though her medical advisors were strongly recommending it. Using the above treatments along with a Chinese herbal formula and frequent application of moxa on LV1/ 365 Thigh Points SP1, we were able to get the bleeding completely under control. She kept her uterus and continued her rigorous speaking schedule. Her hair grew back, her health returned and she is now five years post-menopause. If a woman is close enough to menopause and has excessive or avalanche bleeding, usually the uterus can be saved. The fibroids will shrink after menopause. Case history (ten-pound fibroid): I walked into my treatment room and found a 40-year-old new patient lying face up on the table with what appeared to be a pregnancy but was a ten-pound fibroid. She had lost most of her hair and was dizzy and exhausted all of the time. With extremely heavy periods, she regularly bled onto her clothing and bed sheets. She was terrified to consult a surgeon for fear of requiring a hysterectomy. I knew that there was no possibility of resolving such a large fibroid. I promised to personally see her through her ordeal, and convinced her to allow me to take her to a renowned OB/GYN. Upon getting her blood test results, I asked her doctor whether he had ever seen hematocrit and hemoglobin levels that low, and his response was, “Not consistent with life.” He sent us immediately to the hospital for a blood transfusion of two pints. Shortly thereafter, the patient had a partial hysterectomy. Her dizziness stopped, her energy was restored, and within three months she had a full head of hair. Sometimes, the practitioner’s job is simply to help the patient do what needs to be done. LV1/SP1 moxa to stop bleeding: Because the Liver stores the blood and the Spleen controls the blood, moxa on LV1 and SP1 can be used for both avalanche bleeding (heat excess) and spotting (deficiency). A moxa stick or stick-on moxa may be chosen for the job. In my clinic, I use stick moxa. It is essential that the points are thoroughly heated without causing a burn or blister, as this would be painful and make it difficult to wear shoes. I never touch the tip of the moxa stick to the patient’s skin, because this certainly would cause a blister. Firmly holding the toe prevents the patient from flinching or jerking into the hot coal. I try to anticipate the patient’s indication that the point has become “hot.” After the heat from the tip of the moxa stick has effectively warmed the point to tolerance, I firmly grasp the large toe in a way that allows me to push the heat into the points with my thumb and index finger. I alternate between textbook LV1 and SP1, pushing the heat into one point while applying heat to the other. Count the seconds (“one, one thousand, two, one thousand,” etc.) while applying the heat to each point; it may initially take up to ten seconds for the patient to feel the heat, but after five applications, this may take only two seconds. Once both points have been heated completely (to the count of “one, one thousand”) on one foot, switch to the other foot. The patient is likely to require daily application, but it is extremely difficult if not impossible to apply moxa to these points on oneself, and LV1/SP1 moxa can be time consuming and smoky. For these reasons, I usually teach someone in the patient’s family how to use stick-on moxa. I advise them to be sure to use a shield between the large toe and second toe; a business card is perfect for this purpose. Fibroid formulas: To determine the correct herbal formula, you must first differentiate between excess and deficiency. If the Spleen qi is deficient, it will not be able to hold the blood, and blood will leak out. If there is blood heat (excess condition), the blood is being pushed out. Fibroids cause blockage, with heavy or excessive bleeding; vitalize the blood to stop bleeding. If the bleeding is severe, it must be stopped directly. Of course, every patient must be handled individually, but there are three primary ways to stop bleeding: 1. Block the source (flooding): Ten Ashes Formula (Shi Hui San) or Four Fresh Herbs (Si Sheng Wan) may be used to control heavy bleeding. 2. Disperse stagnation (uterine tumor): To the formula Gui Zhi Fu Ling (Cinnamon and Poria Formula), add Xiang Fu, Zhi Bei Mu, Mu Li (raw), and Xuan Shen. Gui Zhi guides the qi downward in this Urinary Bladder channel formula. 3. Tonify the Kidney and stop bleeding: Use Jiao Ai Tong. Note: Dang Gui Shao Yao Tang also can be used to move the blood, while powders or raw herbs can stop bleeding. I am aware of practitioners who have used Xue Yu Tan (carbonized hair) for these kinds of problems and seriously injured the patient. Please do not use this herb for functional uterine bleeding, as it clogs the system. Many other herbs are used in charred form to stop bleeding. Infertility due to hormonal imbalance: Taking Charge of Your Fertility by Toni Weschler is a great book about ovulation, fertility and female reproduction in general. If women are uninformed, I usually recommend that they read this book. Women who are receiving IVF treatments are usually very informed and have various devices for measuring their hormonal activity. Fertility Lens: I always suggest that a woman dealing with infertility acquire what is called a Fertility Lens. This device, also known as a female ovulation microscope, measures fertility through assessment of saliva. It is a small lipstick-shaped device with a built-in light source and a glass slide on which a small amount of saliva is placed. Once dried, saliva with a ferning pattern indicates ovulation, whereas outside of the 48- to 72-hour fertility window, there will be no visible striations. This device is extraordinarily helpful when a woman is attempting to conceive. Also, it is my opinion that every fifth-grade sex education class should include learning about the Fertility Lens, so that girls and women can know the wisdom of their bodies from an early age and avoid unwanted pregnancies. Treating infertility: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points and Three Sisters are the Tung’s points that are chosen most frequently to treat infertility. They assist with any kind of delayed period, except in the case of pregnancy. Points that are chosen to treat infertility are always safe to needle during pregnancy; this is good to remember, as you won’t always know when a patient has conceived. Most infertility is considered to have hormonal causes. Though treatments may vary depending upon the cause, the points listed above are always utilized, even in non-hormonal cases such as a blocked fallopian tube. Other causes might be: Kidney and Liver deficiency, qi and blood deficiency, Chong and REN deficiency, or a combination of these, any of which could result in a malformed uterus, an unstable pregnancy or a nonviable fetus. When treating a woman for infertility, I ask her to avoid conception for three months while I sort out the problem. Infertility due to deficiency or cold accumulation: Many women experience an irregular menstrual cycle due to exhaustion, overwork and cold damp accumulation in the uterus. A tongue with a white coating or a pale tongue with teeth marks indicates damp cold, requiring qi tonification, warming, and Thigh Points clearing dampness with an herbal formula. In addition to needling the points found above, moxa on the following points is very useful: ST36, SP6, UB23, DU4, REN4-REN8. Infertility due to damp heat accumulation or stagnation: When a woman has heat stagnation in her uterus, her tongue is red with a greasy coating; when the tongue is dark purple, it is quite severe. A thick yellow coating is also indicative of damp heat accumulation. Though the herbal treatment is different than it would be for a deficient cold picture, the Tung’s acupuncture treatment is the same. However, I may initially use Three Plum Blossom more than Three Sisters in order to clear uterine stagnation and clean the womb. Bleeding small veins found in the area of SP6 San Yin Jiao is also useful for clearing uterine stagnation. In my clinic, every woman I have treated for infertility due to damp heat has immediately conceived after three months of cleaning and revitalizing (while preventing conception). Once conception is attempted, I am very careful not to needle Three Plum Blossom post-ovulation, in the event that the woman has conceived. However, it is ideal to encourage a calm “Sea of Life” (womb) even as the woman is moving into ovulation, to facilitate implantation. Blocked fallopian tube: Phlegm can cause fallopian tubes to stick together; however, inflammation of the cervix and fallopian tubes is seen more frequently and is often due to Liver qi and blood stagnation. To treat this kind of inflammation, you will need to soothe the Liver, regulate the qi, activate the blood and release the stagnation. Open Tube Formula (Tong Guan Tong): 3 Tao Ren, 3 Hong Hua, 3 Chuan Xiong, 3 Dang Gui (this part is Si Wu Tang); add 2 Hui Xiang, 3 Lian Qiao, 3 Xiang Fu, 3 Chi Shao, 3 Dan Shen, 1.5 Zhi Gan Cao.36 Good for many types of infertility, this formula moves the blood and disperses phlegm, with Xiang Fu regulating the qi. If you are not sure if the fallopian tube is blocked, use this formula for three to four weeks and then proceed to the next formula for male or female infertility. I tend to mix the herbs in a granulated format for delivery, as it is easier for those who require long-term treatment. Male or female infertility formulas, tonifying Liver and Kidney: I have had outstanding results with the following formulas. Consider one or the other (but not both): 1. You Gui Wan with Yu Lin Zhu. 2. 6-2-5 (works for males or females): 6 = Nourish Essence Formula (Liu Wei Di Huang); 2 = Two Immortals Formula (Er Xian Tang); 5 = Five Seeds (Wu Zi Yen Zhong Tang: Tu Si Zi, Fu Pen Zi, Che Qian Zi, Wu Wei Zi, Gou Qi Zi). Cupping: I do not cup the patient’s lower back if she is trying to conceive or during her first trimester, in order to keep a very calm Sea of Life in the lower jiao for implantation. When the lower back is cupped, the patient can feel a pulling in the front. After the second trimester (for a complicated pregnancy) or the first trimester (for a normal pregnancy), gentle cupping may be very 36 Amounts indicated are for loose herbs measured in qian (1 qian = 3 grams).  Amounts indicated are for loose herbs measured in qian (1 qian = 3 grams).  helpful. In a normal pregnancy, I always cup the lower back and sacral area two weeks before delivery. This is a good treatment to prepare the mother for labor and may make delivery slightly easier, should it involve “back labor” (when the descending baby digs their heels into the lumbar vertebrae or sacrum). Threatened miscarriage: If a patient habitually miscarries just after her period was due, her body is rejecting the sperm and needs tonification. Usually, habitual miscarriage occurs at the same point in the woman’s cycle each time, such as two weeks after conception. Patients who are receiving fertility treatment or are at risk of miscarriage need to avoid climbing stairs, bouncing (e.g., aerobics), excessive exercise, and overwork. Before ovulation, they should avoid any activities that might “stir the pot” – such as intercourse – to allow the Sea of Life to settle into a calm, quiet pond. If a patient is trying to conceive, do not needle Three Plum Blossom after ovulation. Stabilizing the pregnancy: Unilaterally needle 11.06 Return to the Nest on one hand, 11.24 Gynecological Points on the other hand. Then bilaterally needle 88.10 Passing Stomach, 88.11 Passing Back without strong stimulation. If you are treating the patient multiple times each week, needle only one point on each leg. Post-miscarriage treatment: If a patient has miscarried, I may ask her to resist the inclination to try to get pregnant immediately. This provides us time over the next few months to clean the womb, tonify the qi and blood, strengthen and astringe, so that her body is prepared to hold her next pregnancy. Some women who have miscarried are so traumatized that they fear bonding with their baby when they conceive again; however, it is vitally important that the mother bond immediately with her fetus so that it feels wanted, safe and secure. The mother needs to eat right, stop jogging, talk to her baby and avoid pretending she is not pregnant. Her practitioner must be very compassionate and sensitive to the losses she has already endured, and at the same time help her to embrace her new baby.
combinations: Hormonal imbalance causing anger and depression: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters, Prefrontal Scalp Points. Uterine tumors or fibroids (without heavy bleeding): 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters, and bleed the small veins found in the area of SP6. Menopausal hot flashes/night sweats: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with either 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors or 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters, depending on whether the patient wishes to encourage or exit fertility. Er Xian Tang (Two Immortals formula). •  Leucorrhea: 66.02 Wood Wife, 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with either: 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters or 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points or 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors (all three options will regulate Spleen, Liver and Kidney).•  Menstrual induction: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters. •  Infertility: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters. See above for further information.

name: Jiemeier, Second Sister (T 88.05)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 10.5 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella and 1 cun medial to the anterior midline of the thigh. Three Sisters and Three Plum Blossom: I usually alternate these two point patterns when treating fibroids. Many women have multiple fibroids that swell right before their period, causing lower abdominal bloating and discomfort. We can use Three Sisters during the premenstrual week, as Three Plum Blossom (located on the lower abdomen) may be too sensitive. Please see Three Plum Blossom for point location and further information. Case history (myoma causing avalanche bleeding): A 35-year-old patient had an intrauterine myoma (in the wall of her uterus) very near the opening of the cervix, which prevented the cervix from closing completely. This caused her to spot or bleed continuously, and at times dangerously. She was capable of passing four clots, each the size of a fist, within fifteen minutes. Because of her age, this woman did not want to have a hysterectomy, though it had been recommended to her. In addition to Three Sisters, 11.06 Return to the Nest, and 11.24 Gynecological Points, she also required a loose herb formula and lots of moxa. Eventually, she was prescribed birth control pills. Almost twenty years later, she is now post- menopausal and still has her uterus. Case history (fibroids): I treated a 52-year-old woman with seven fibroids that varied in size; the largest was about the size of a duck egg. Every two weeks, she experienced avalanche bleeding. Her blood loss had led to extreme weakness and caused most of her hair to fall out. She was menopausal, with hot flashes and night sweats that were incapacitating. Because she was a prominent figure in our community, it was not convenient for her to have a hysterectomy, though her medical advisors were strongly recommending it. Using the above treatments along with a Chinese herbal formula and frequent application of moxa on LV1/ 365 Thigh Points SP1, we were able to get the bleeding completely under control. She kept her uterus and continued her rigorous speaking schedule. Her hair grew back, her health returned and she is now five years post-menopause. If a woman is close enough to menopause and has excessive or avalanche bleeding, usually the uterus can be saved. The fibroids will shrink after menopause. Case history (ten-pound fibroid): I walked into my treatment room and found a 40-year-old new patient lying face up on the table with what appeared to be a pregnancy but was a ten-pound fibroid. She had lost most of her hair and was dizzy and exhausted all of the time. With extremely heavy periods, she regularly bled onto her clothing and bed sheets. She was terrified to consult a surgeon for fear of requiring a hysterectomy. I knew that there was no possibility of resolving such a large fibroid. I promised to personally see her through her ordeal, and convinced her to allow me to take her to a renowned OB/GYN. Upon getting her blood test results, I asked her doctor whether he had ever seen hematocrit and hemoglobin levels that low, and his response was, “Not consistent with life.” He sent us immediately to the hospital for a blood transfusion of two pints. Shortly thereafter, the patient had a partial hysterectomy. Her dizziness stopped, her energy was restored, and within three months she had a full head of hair. Sometimes, the practitioner’s job is simply to help the patient do what needs to be done. LV1/SP1 moxa to stop bleeding: Because the Liver stores the blood and the Spleen controls the blood, moxa on LV1 and SP1 can be used for both avalanche bleeding (heat excess) and spotting (deficiency). A moxa stick or stick-on moxa may be chosen for the job. In my clinic, I use stick moxa. It is essential that the points are thoroughly heated without causing a burn or blister, as this would be painful and make it difficult to wear shoes. I never touch the tip of the moxa stick to the patient’s skin, because this certainly would cause a blister. Firmly holding the toe prevents the patient from flinching or jerking into the hot coal. I try to anticipate the patient’s indication that the point has become “hot.” After the heat from the tip of the moxa stick has effectively warmed the point to tolerance, I firmly grasp the large toe in a way that allows me to push the heat into the points with my thumb and index finger. I alternate between textbook LV1 and SP1, pushing the heat into one point while applying heat to the other. Count the seconds (“one, one thousand, two, one thousand,” etc.) while applying the heat to each point; it may initially take up to ten seconds for the patient to feel the heat, but after five applications, this may take only two seconds. Once both points have been heated completely (to the count of “one, one thousand”) on one foot, switch to the other foot. The patient is likely to require daily application, but it is extremely difficult if not impossible to apply moxa to these points on oneself, and LV1/SP1 moxa can be time consuming and smoky. For these reasons, I usually teach someone in the patient’s family how to use stick-on moxa. I advise them to be sure to use a shield between the large toe and second toe; a business card is perfect for this purpose. Fibroid formulas: To determine the correct herbal formula, you must first differentiate between excess and deficiency. If the Spleen qi is deficient, it will not be able to hold the blood, and blood will leak out. If there is blood heat (excess condition), the blood is being pushed out. Fibroids cause blockage, with heavy or excessive bleeding; vitalize the blood to stop bleeding. If the bleeding is severe, it must be stopped directly. Of course, every patient must be handled individually, but there are three primary ways to stop bleeding: 1. Block the source (flooding): Ten Ashes Formula (Shi Hui San) or Four Fresh Herbs (Si Sheng Wan) may be used to control heavy bleeding. 2. Disperse stagnation (uterine tumor): To the formula Gui Zhi Fu Ling (Cinnamon and Poria Formula), add Xiang Fu, Zhi Bei Mu, Mu Li (raw), and Xuan Shen. Gui Zhi guides the qi downward in this Urinary Bladder channel formula. 3. Tonify the Kidney and stop bleeding: Use Jiao Ai Tong. Note: Dang Gui Shao Yao Tang also can be used to move the blood, while powders or raw herbs can stop bleeding. I am aware of practitioners who have used Xue Yu Tan (carbonized hair) for these kinds of problems and seriously injured the patient. Please do not use this herb for functional uterine bleeding, as it clogs the system. Many other herbs are used in charred form to stop bleeding. Infertility due to hormonal imbalance: Taking Charge of Your Fertility by Toni Weschler is a great book about ovulation, fertility and female reproduction in general. If women are uninformed, I usually recommend that they read this book. Women who are receiving IVF treatments are usually very informed and have various devices for measuring their hormonal activity. Fertility Lens: I always suggest that a woman dealing with infertility acquire what is called a Fertility Lens. This device, also known as a female ovulation microscope, measures fertility through assessment of saliva. It is a small lipstick-shaped device with a built-in light source and a glass slide on which a small amount of saliva is placed. Once dried, saliva with a ferning pattern indicates ovulation, whereas outside of the 48- to 72-hour fertility window, there will be no visible striations. This device is extraordinarily helpful when a woman is attempting to conceive. Also, it is my opinion that every fifth-grade sex education class should include learning about the Fertility Lens, so that girls and women can know the wisdom of their bodies from an early age and avoid unwanted pregnancies. Treating infertility: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points and Three Sisters are the Tung’s points that are chosen most frequently to treat infertility. They assist with any kind of delayed period, except in the case of pregnancy. Points that are chosen to treat infertility are always safe to needle during pregnancy; this is good to remember, as you won’t always know when a patient has conceived. Most infertility is considered to have hormonal causes. Though treatments may vary depending upon the cause, the points listed above are always utilized, even in non-hormonal cases such as a blocked fallopian tube. Other causes might be: Kidney and Liver deficiency, qi and blood deficiency, Chong and REN deficiency, or a combination of these, any of which could result in a malformed uterus, an unstable pregnancy or a nonviable fetus. When treating a woman for infertility, I ask her to avoid conception for three months while I sort out the problem. Infertility due to deficiency or cold accumulation: Many women experience an irregular menstrual cycle due to exhaustion, overwork and cold damp accumulation in the uterus. A tongue with a white coating or a pale tongue with teeth marks indicates damp cold, requiring qi tonification, warming, and 367 Thigh Points clearing dampness with an herbal formula. In addition to needling the points found above, moxa on the following points is very useful: ST36, SP6, UB23, DU4, REN4-REN8. Infertility due to damp heat accumulation or stagnation: When a woman has heat stagnation in her uterus, her tongue is red with a greasy coating; when the tongue is dark purple, it is quite severe. A thick yellow coating is also indicative of damp heat accumulation. Though the herbal treatment is different than it would be for a deficient cold picture, the Tung’s acupuncture treatment is the same. However, I may initially use Three Plum Blossom more than Three Sisters in order to clear uterine stagnation and clean the womb. Bleeding small veins found in the area of SP6 San Yin Jiao is also useful for clearing uterine stagnation. In my clinic, every woman I have treated for infertility due to damp heat has immediately conceived after three months of cleaning and revitalizing (while preventing conception). Once conception is attempted, I am very careful not to needle Three Plum Blossom post-ovulation, in the event that the woman has conceived. However, it is ideal to encourage a calm “Sea of Life” (womb) even as the woman is moving into ovulation, to facilitate implantation. Blocked fallopian tube: Phlegm can cause fallopian tubes to stick together; however, inflammation of the cervix and fallopian tubes is seen more frequently and is often due to Liver qi and blood stagnation. To treat this kind of inflammation, you will need to soothe the Liver, regulate the qi, activate the blood and release the stagnation. Open Tube Formula (Tong Guan Tong): 3 Tao Ren, 3 Hong Hua, 3 Chuan Xiong, 3 Dang Gui (this part is Si Wu Tang); add 2 Hui Xiang, 3 Lian Qiao, 3 Xiang Fu, 3 Chi Shao, 3 Dan Shen, 1.5 Zhi Gan Cao.36 Good for many types of infertility, this formula moves the blood and disperses phlegm, with Xiang Fu regulating the qi. If you are not sure if the fallopian tube is blocked, use this formula for three to four weeks and then proceed to the next formula for male or female infertility. I tend to mix the herbs in a granulated format for delivery, as it is easier for those who require long-term treatment. Male or female infertility formulas, tonifying Liver and Kidney: I have had outstanding results with the following formulas. Consider one or the other (but not both): 1. You Gui Wan with Yu Lin Zhu. 2. 6-2-5 (works for males or females): 6 = Nourish Essence Formula (Liu Wei Di Huang); 2 = Two Immortals Formula (Er Xian Tang); 5 = Five Seeds (Wu Zi Yen Zhong Tang: Tu Si Zi, Fu Pen Zi, Che Qian Zi, Wu Wei Zi, Gou Qi Zi).37 Cupping: I do not cup the patient’s lower back if she is trying to conceive or during her first trimester, in order to keep a very calm Sea of Life in the lower jiao for implantation. When the lower back is cupped, the patient can feel a pulling in the front. After the second trimester (for a complicated pregnancy) or the first trimester (for a normal pregnancy), gentle cupping may be very 36 Amounts indicated are for loose herbs measured in qian (1 qian = 3 grams). 37 Amounts indicated are for loose herbs measured in qian (1 qian = 3 grams).  helpful. In a normal pregnancy, I always cup the lower back and sacral area two weeks before delivery. This is a good treatment to prepare the mother for labor and may make delivery slightly easier, should it involve “back labor” (when the descending baby digs their heels into the lumbar vertebrae or sacrum). Threatened miscarriage: If a patient habitually miscarries just after her period was due, her body is rejecting the sperm and needs tonification. Usually, habitual miscarriage occurs at the same point in the woman’s cycle each time, such as two weeks after conception. Patients who are receiving fertility treatment or are at risk of miscarriage need to avoid climbing stairs, bouncing (e.g., aerobics), excessive exercise, and overwork. Before ovulation, they should avoid any activities that might “stir the pot” – such as intercourse – to allow the Sea of Life to settle into a calm, quiet pond. If a patient is trying to conceive, do not needle Three Plum Blossom after ovulation. Stabilizing the pregnancy: Unilaterally needle 11.06 Return to the Nest on one hand, 11.24 Gynecological Points on the other hand. Then bilaterally needle 88.10 Passing Stomach, 88.11 Passing Back without strong stimulation. If you are treating the patient multiple times each week, needle only one point on each leg. Post-miscarriage treatment: If a patient has miscarried, I may ask her to resist the inclination to try to get pregnant immediately. This provides us time over the next few months to clean the womb, tonify the qi and blood, strengthen and astringe, so that her body is prepared to hold her next pregnancy. Some women who have miscarried are so traumatized that they fear bonding with their baby when they conceive again; however, it is vitally important that the mother bond immediately with her fetus so that it feels wanted, safe and secure. The mother needs to eat right, stop jogging, talk to her baby and avoid pretending she is not pregnant. Her practitioner must be very compassionate and sensitive to the losses she has already endured, and at the same time help her to embrace her new baby.
combinations: Hormonal imbalance causing anger and depression: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters, Prefrontal Scalp Points. Uterine tumors or fibroids (without heavy bleeding): 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters, and bleed the small veins found in the area of SP6. Menopausal hot flashes/night sweats: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with either 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors or 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters, depending on whether the patient wishes to encourage or exit fertility. Er Xian Tang (Two Immortals formula). •  Leucorrhea: 66.02 Wood Wife, 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with either: 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters or 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points or 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors (all three options will regulate Spleen, Liver and Kidney).•  Menstrual induction: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters. •  Infertility: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters. See above for further information.

name: Jiemeisan, Third Sister (T 88.06)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 13 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella and 1 cun medial to the anterior midline of the thigh. It is 2.5 cun proximal to Jiemeier (T 88.05) . | Johnson: 88.04 First Sister is located 8 cun (four fingers twice, plus three fingers) proximal, and 1.0 cun medial, to the center of the top of the patella. 88.05 Second Sister is located 2.5-3.0 cun proximal to First Sister. 88.06 Third Sister is located 2.5-3.0 cun proximal to Second Sister. Note: Needle on women only.
primary_indications: red or white vaginal discharge (non-bacterial type)
johnson_indications: Irregular menstruation (early, late, excessive or scanty)*
techniques: Needle 1 - 2.5 cun bilaterally. | Johnson: Needle bilaterally. Dao Ma: The points 88.04-88.06 are needled together in a combination known as Three Sisters. Note for male practitioners: For the patient’s privacy and convenience, 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points may be used without Three Sisters for hormonal imbalances. Depth: 1.0-2.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Because 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters have the Reaction Area of the Kidney and Uterus, and because they are located on the Spleen meridian, these points strengthen the Kidney and control the blood, making them invaluable in the treatment of gynecological diseases. Three Plum Blossom: Not included in Tung’s system is a three-point pattern called Three Plum Blossom, located on the lower abdomen. (Note: A comprehensive write-up on Three Plum Blossom is found directly after Three Sisters in this book.) Three Plum Blossom points are nearly interchangeable with Three Sisters in their function, though Three Sisters points have a greater effect on the ovaries, while Three Plum Blossom points have a stronger effect on the uterus. I assigned the Reaction Areas of Kidney and Uterus to Three Plum Blossom as they incorporate 363 Lower Leg Points REN4 Guan Yuan (intersection of the Three Foot Yin channels and REN; benefits uterus and nourishes Kidney) and ST27 Da Ju (benefits Kidney and nourishes essence). Any female complaint that is cyclic in nature is considered hormonal and can be treated using 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points and either Three Sisters or Three Plum Blossom. Both of the latter can be needled for Liver qi congestion or gynecological issues that have an emotional component; both of them regulate the menstrual cycle and are used for irregular or delayed menses, infertility, endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, and to expel a dead fetus. Delayed menses: Along with 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points, Three Sisters are my points of choice for irregular menses or when a menstrual cycle is delayed. When a woman is premenstrual and overdue (but not pregnant), and has irritability and breast pain, Three Sisters usually brings on the menstrual period within 24 to 48 hours. Birth control pills and regulating gynecological hormones: I use Three Sisters frequently to regulate hormones, especially in cases of PMS, irregular cycles or when a woman has been using birth control for an extended period of time. Three Sisters with 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points are very helpful in these situations. If the patient is anovulatory, this treatment will encourage the return of hormonal cycling. This was perfectly illustrated in the case of a 27-year-old woman who had been using birth control pills for fifteen years. It took almost six months using acupuncture and herbs to regulate her menstrual cycles. This regulation is usually accomplished in less than three months when the use of birth control pills has been fewer than five years. In my opinion, it may be safe to use birth control pills for fewer than five years, but when they are taken longer, it can be difficult to return the body to normal hormonal activity. Menopause and regulating hormones: If a woman is premenopausal and wishes to extend her fertility, the above treatment will accomplish just that, in most cases. If a woman is exiting fertility and has hot flashes and night sweats, I balance hormones with 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points and tonify the Kidneys with 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, and avoid Three Sisters. If a woman is exiting fertility gracefully, without symptoms of hormone imbalance or Kidney deficiency, I leave well enough alone and do not encourage hormonal activity by needling any of these female reproductive points, though Three Emperors may still be applied. Amenorrhea: Along with 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points, Three Sisters can be used in cases of amenorrhea; with a good herbal formula directed toward tonifying qi and blood (Liver and Spleen) and moving stagnation, the patient’s period should arrive. Return to the Nest and Gynecological Points alone are capable of this, but the addition of Three Sisters is likely to handle the situation. Dr. Young offers the following treatment for more difficult cases: Bilaterally needle 66.15 Water Fairy, ST25 Tian Shu; needle REN24 Cheng Jiang. The explanation for these points is as follows: Water Fairy is located near KD5 Shui Quan, the Xi-Cleft point on the Kidney meridian, and it tonifies Kidney Source qi. ST25 is the Mu Point for the Large Intestine and regulates qi and blood. REN24 is the best point for amenorrhea because the Stomach and Large Intestine meridians both go around the mouth. REN24 is the Jing-Well point for the REN channel so it opens the orifices. The REN channel also goes through the genitals and regulates qi and blood.  Fibroids and tumors: Dark blood vessels in the lower area of the thenar eminence (close to the wrist) are diagnostic of uterine fibroids or tumors. Fibroids often cause frequent urination, heavy bleeding and lower back pain. Thirty to forty percent of women over age thirty have fibroids, and many of them do not even know it. If the fibroids are the size of an egg, even if there are multiple small ones, they can be treated. If the fibroid is the size of an orange or larger, treating it is a bit too much to promise, and the patient likely will require surgery. If you can see the fibroids because they are that large, the patient will need surgery. If you can manage the symptoms related to fibroids (especially the heavy bleeding) until the patient reaches menopause, the fibroids will shrink at that time and she can probably avoid a hysterectomy. When a woman is told she has a tilted uterus, it is usually due to fibroids; the uterus does not tilt without a reason. During pregnancy: It is not uncommon for a woman to grow a fibroid during a pregnancy. The fibroid will disappear when the hormones change after delivery. Complications may arise if the fibroid prevents the baby from turning, causing a breech presentation. Even still, vaginal delivery may be possible with a skilled midwife or OB/GYN. In my practice, I always take the woman’s blood pressure regularly and palpate the position of the fetus so that I can easily determine if the pregnancy is not progressing as expected. By her second trimester, any pregnant woman in my practice also has regular prenatal visits with her primary birth practitioner; however, these days with the advent of HMOs and 15-minute appointments, patients cannot count on regular blood work or even blood pressure monitoring. Open Tube Formula (Tong Guan Tong): 3 Tao Ren, 3 Hong Hua, 3 Chuan Xiong, 3 Dang Gui (this part is Si Wu Tang); add 2 Hui Xiang, 3 Lian Qiao, 3 Xiang Fu, 3 Chi Shao, 3 Dan Shen, 1.5 Zhi Gan Cao.36 Good for many types of infertility, this formula moves the blood and disperses phlegm, with Xiang Fu regulating the qi. If you are not sure if the fallopian tube is blocked, use this formula for three to four weeks and then proceed to the next formula for male or female infertility. I tend to mix the herbs in a granulated format for delivery, as it is easier for those who require long-term treatment. Male or female infertility formulas, tonifying Liver and Kidney: I have had outstanding results with the following formulas. Consider one or the other (but not both): 1. You Gui Wan with Yu Lin Zhu. 2. 6-2-5 (works for males or females): 6 = Nourish Essence Formula (Liu Wei Di Huang); 2 = Two Immortals Formula (Er Xian Tang); 5 = Five Seeds (Wu Zi Yen Zhong Tang: Tu Si Zi, Fu Pen Zi, Che Qian Zi, Wu Wei Zi, Gou Qi Zi). Cupping: I do not cup the patient’s lower back if she is trying to conceive or during her first trimester, in order to keep a very calm Sea of Life in the lower jiao for implantation. When the lower back is cupped, the patient can feel a pulling in the front. After the second trimester (for a complicated pregnancy) or the first trimester (for a normal pregnancy), gentle cupping may be very 36 Amounts indicated are for loose herbs measured in qian (1 qian = 3 grams).  Amounts indicated are for loose herbs measured in qian (1 qian = 3 grams). helpful. In a normal pregnancy, I always cup the lower back and sacral area two weeks before delivery. This is a good treatment to prepare the mother for labor and may make delivery slightly easier, should it involve “back labor” (when the descending baby digs their heels into the lumbar vertebrae or sacrum). Threatened miscarriage: If a patient habitually miscarries just after her period was due, her body is rejecting the sperm and needs tonification. Usually, habitual miscarriage occurs at the same point in the woman’s cycle each time, such as two weeks after conception. Patients who are receiving fertility treatment or are at risk of miscarriage need to avoid climbing stairs, bouncing (e.g., aerobics), excessive exercise, and overwork. Before ovulation, they should avoid any activities that might “stir the pot” – such as intercourse – to allow the Sea of Life to settle into a calm, quiet pond. If a patient is trying to conceive, do not needle Three Plum Blossom after ovulation. Stabilizing the pregnancy: Unilaterally needle 11.06 Return to the Nest on one hand, 11.24 Gynecological Points on the other hand. Then bilaterally needle 88.10 Passing Stomach, 88.11 Passing Back without strong stimulation. If you are treating the patient multiple times each week, needle only one point on each leg. Post-miscarriage treatment: If a patient has miscarried, I may ask her to resist the inclination to try to get pregnant immediately. This provides us time over the next few months to clean the womb, tonify the qi and blood, strengthen and astringe, so that her body is prepared to hold her next pregnancy. Some women who have miscarried are so traumatized that they fear bonding with their baby when they conceive again; however, it is vitally important that the mother bond immediately with her fetus so that it feels wanted, safe and secure. The mother needs to eat right, stop jogging, talk to her baby and avoid pretending she is not pregnant. Her practitioner must be very compassionate and sensitive to the losses she has already endured, and at the same time help her to embrace her new baby.
combinations: Hormonal imbalance causing anger and depression: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters, Prefrontal Scalp Points. Uterine tumors or fibroids (without heavy bleeding): 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters, and bleed the small veins found in the area of SP6. Menopausal hot flashes/night sweats: 11.17 Wood (Anger), 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with either 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors or 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters, depending on whether the patient wishes to encourage or exit fertility. Er Xian Tang (Two Immortals formula). •  Leucorrhea: 66.02 Wood Wife, 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points with either: 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters or 88.09-88.11 Kidney Passing Points or 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors (all three options will regulate Spleen, Liver and Kidney).•  Menstrual induction: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters. •  Infertility: 11.06 Return to the Nest, 11.24 Gynecological Points, 88.04-88.06 Three Sisters. See above for further information.

name: Ganmaoyi, Catch Cold First (T 88.07)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 10.5 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella and 2 cun medial to the anterior midline of the thigh. It is 1 cun medial to Jiemeier (T 88.05) . | Johnson: 88.07 Catch Cold First is located on the thigh, 10.5 cun proximal to the superior border of the patella, and 2.0 cun medial to the midline (1.0 cun medial to 88.05 Second Sister). 88.08 Catch Cold Second is located 2.5 cun proximal to Catch Cold First, also 2.0 cun medial to the midline (1.0 cun medial to 88.06 Third Sister).
primary_indications: Severe common cold or flu with or without headache
johnson_indications: Headache (due to common cold or flu)
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 - 2 cun . Slow insertion is recommended. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 88.07 Catch Cold First is needled with 88.08 Catch Cold Second; the combination is called 88.07-88.08 Catch Cold. Needle direction: Needle obliquely toward the center of the thigh. Depth: 0.8-1.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Catch Cold points are located on the Spleen meridian, which shares a Tai Yin connection to the Lung. Because they have the Reaction Area of the Lung, Master Tung liked needling Catch Cold points to treat colds and flu. Cold/flu: because we have so many better options than these points for common cold and flu, I do not use these points. Please see 88.17-88.19 Four Horses for a comprehensive commentary on common cold/flu.
