Back pain due to accumulated toxins
techniques: Needle 1 - 3 cun perpendicularly towards the femur. Superficial depth addresses KI, middle depth addresses the LR, and deep level needling addresses the HT. | Johnson: Dao Ma: 88.12 Bright Yellow (Chief Point), 88.13 Heaven Yellow, and 88.14 This Yellow are collectively known as Three Yellows, and are usually needled bilaterally, for a total of six needles. •  Palpation: Careful palpation of the Liver channel is essential to obtain the outstanding effects of these points. On any patient with severe liver disease, these points are excruciatingly painful to palpation, and they may be too sensitive to be needled during the first few treatments and/or premenstrually (use 11.20 Wood Inflammation). •  Needle bilaterally: After starting with a deep needle at the middle point, Bright Yellow, palpate softly for the proximal and distal points. Deep palpation would stimulate the needle at Bright Yellow, which could be uncomfortable for the patient.•  Needle depths: When using these points, deep needle insertion is essential and relates to the points’ Reaction Areas. A needle insertion of 1.0 cun is used for treatment at the Kidney level, 2.0 cun is good for Liver, and 3.0 cun also affects the Heart. Because blood diseases involve all three, I often use a 50mm needle insertion to connect them. If the patient is very thin or small, downsize to a 40mm needle, whereas a patient of average or larger size requires a 50mm or even 60mm needle. •  Needle gauge and bruising: When needling Three Yellows, place your consciousness in the tip of the needle so you can experience the resistance caused by larger blood vessels when it happens. A larger blood vessel feels like a smaller tendon in that it pushes back, in the same way a rubber band would if needled. Withdraw and slightly redirect the needle to move off of a blood vessel. I usually use a .20 x 50mm needle, which is the thinnest gauge available in 50mm needles (Japanese gauge 3, Chinese gauge 36). Some diseases are characterized by bruising, so go slowly and carefully to avoid unnecessary purpura. In a case of advanced cirrhosis, bruising is expected with these points; however, as the condition improves, the bruising will stop. •  Depth: 1.0-3.0 cun •  Kidney disease: 1.0 cun•  Liver disease: 2.0 cun•  Heart disease: 3.0 cun
comments: Three Yellows: Among all of Master Tung’s points, and among classic textbook points as well, none treat the liver in a more profound and lasting way than Three Yellows. They address liver organ disease and are not used to treat emotional issues due to Liver qi congestion. Though emotional issues are also likely to be present, liver disease trumps emotional states caused by Liver qi congestion, so we add 11.20 Wood Inflammation rather than 11.17 Wood (Anger), but never both, as that could make the patient feel ill. •  Energetic pathways: In TCM, we understand that the Spleen controls blood and the Liver restores blood. Three Yellows points are located on the Liver meridian, but because they are in close proximity to the Spleen channel, they regulate the functions of both the liver and spleen. This is one of my favorite point patterns to use in the treatment of blood diseases. Exhaustion due to liver: In the 1980s in San Francisco, I had an HIV/AIDS clinic where I treated a multitude of patients with hepatitis and liver disease. The effects of Three Yellows were outstanding. From treating these patients, I realized that exhaustion due to liver was entirely based upon the liver’s inability to clean the blood, and that any direct tonification of qi and blood would worsen the condition. With proper treatment, patients who previously had been carried into my office were able to climb the two flights of stairs to reach my clinic. Today, I use Three Yellows for any kind of exhaustion, even a headache, when it is caused by toxicity or Liver weakness. •  Hepatitis: Hepatitis A, B and C can be treated using the same basic protocol: Three Yellows, 11.20 Wood Inflammation, and a thorough cupping of the DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas. With hepatitis A and B, the herbal emphasis is on cleaning the blood. However, in the treatment of hepatitis C, the herbal prescription is radically different, utilizing the principles of tonifying Spleen qi, moistening Kidney yin, moving blood stagnation, and detoxifying the liver. •  Case history (hepatitis C with end-stage cirrhosis): For two years, three times weekly, I treated a 60-year-old female patient who had hepatitis C and end-stage cirrhosis. She presented with abdominal ascites, severe edema in the legs and feet, extremely itchy rashes, exhaustion, irritability, depression, insomnia and suicidal ideation. She tried to be cooperative but was unwilling to take any herbs. At that time, the hepatitis C drug Harvoni was being tested in trials but was unavailable to the general public. I cupped the DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas and needled 11.20 Wood Inflammation, 33.10 Intestine Gate, 33.11 Liver Gate, and a combination of Three Yellows/Three Emperors. We modified her diet to clear damp heat, avoid toxins and tonify the Spleen. At first, she had radical bruising along the Liver channel, as bleeding is a typical sign of end-stage cirrhosis. However, within three months, the bruising diminished and then stopped. Within a few weeks of her initial treatment, her itching subsided and the rashes cleared completely, though the water retention continued to be an intermittent concern that occasionally required the use of Lasix. Once Harvoni became available, she was cleared of hepatitis C, and the ascites receded. She is currently waiting for a liver transplant but is unlikely to receive it due to her age and condition. Given enough time, it is possible that this patient could have recovered completely; however, she was not cooperative enough to see it through, and she chose to abandon her dietary restrictions and regular treatments. •  Case history (hepatitis B): This patient was told he needed a liver transplant due to heroin abuse. Though he had been clean and sober for five years, he initially presented as jaundiced (green/gray/yellow) with nosebleeds, serious liver pain, back pain, exhaustion, headaches and insomnia. Because his Three Yellows points were extremely sensitive to palpation, he would not allow me to needle them for the first six weeks. I needled 11.20 Wood Inflammation with other, less sensitive points and prescribed a hepatitis B formula. I cupped the rib cage over the liver, being careful not to touch the swollen liver itself, and cupped the DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas on both sides. When his liver had recovered enough to tolerate my needling of Three Yellows, he would only allow it while holding on to my elbow so he could feel that he was in control. After six months of biweekly treatments, he was removed from the transplant list, and within a year he was in good health, riding his mountain bike all over town. He continued taking herbs for three years and remained healthy until he took a trip to Thailand and unfortunately relapsed into drug use. Case history (hepatitis in pregnancy): A 46-year-old presented with hepatitis B during pregnancy. She was exhausted, slightly jaundiced and afraid she might lose her baby. Because Three Yellows are extraordinary in treating exhaustion due to liver, and safe to needle during pregnancy, I needled them along with 11.20 Wood Inflammation, 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points. I cupped her Toxin Areas and was able to give her a gentle liver cleansing formula, being very careful not to over-vitalize blood. After she gave birth to a healthy baby girl, we were able to use a stronger formula and permanently resolve her hepatitis B. She recently celebrated her 75th birthday and her daughter celebrated her 29th. •  Polycystic kidney disease (PKD): Polycystic kidney disease is a genetic predisposition for cysts in both the liver and kidneys. This kind of cyst formation ultimately leads to kidney failure, resulting in dialysis or a transplant. Early presentation may be as simple as slight lower back pain, slight hypertension, and nocturia. Patients with this disorder usually have a parent and/or sibling who are also dealing with it, and they should receive genetic counseling. Patients with PKD are usually monitored by their family physician or a nephrologist. It is essential that they eat a low-protein diet, as too much protein is extremely hard on the kidneys. •  Treatment: I have treated three cases of PKD using much the same approach. Because both the liver and kidneys are compromised, toxins may accumulate. Start with cleaning the toxins by: 1) cupping DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas, 2) cupping over the ribs on top of the liver, and 3) very gently cupping the lower back over the kidneys, following the color. Combine 11.20 Wood Inflammation and Three Yellows with 77.18 Shen Guan, occasionally using all Three Emperors (77.18-77.21). A carefully constructed herbal formula is absolutely essential. If you are unable to create a formula of individual loose herbs, you must refer these patients to someone who can. •  Case history (PKD, early intervention and remission): My first patient with a diagnosis of PKD was a 50-year-old woman with two adult children. She presented with minor low back pain and moderately high blood pressure. After twelve months of daily loose herbs and biweekly acupuncture treatments, she was officially in remission, which is extremely rare with this condition. Her liver and kidney cysts disappeared, she was able to discontinue all blood pressure medications, and her blood pressure stayed low once it had been brought down. She no longer feared kidney failure. I had begun treatment as soon as her symptoms were recognized, which leads me to believe that early intervention is far more likely to be successful. •  Case history (PKD, moderately advanced): The second patient had moderately advanced PKD and a brain aneurism that required surgical repair. He had a very high-stress job, had three children and was undergoing a divorce. I was unsuccessful in lowering his blood pressure, the first obvious sign of PKD. His brain surgery interrupted our treatment during a critical time, and a few years later he required a kidney transplant. •  Case history (PKD, late intervention): The third patient was a 35-year-old woman whose mother had died at age 52 due to PKD, and whose older sister was already on dialysis. I urgently recommended that she begin treatment, explaining the difficulties of PKD and my one successful cure. Because her only symptom was a slightly elevated blood pressure, she chose alternatives of a spiritual nature, believing she could heal it on her own. Eighteen years later, she wound up in my office asking for help. At that time, the cysts had enlarged her kidneys by half their normal size. Her blood pressure required medications, she was tired, and her sleep patterns were erratic. I told her I was not sure if I could manage her case, but I would try. I gave her a powerful herbal formula for tonifying Liver and Kidneys while breaking cysts and vitalizing qi and blood. I modified the formula many times, and within eighteen months she was feeling better than she had in years, riding her bike, doing African dance, sleeping well, and working hard. Her kidneys had begun to shrink, though multiple cysts were still identified in both kidneys and the liver. We continued treatment two or three times weekly. I began to use granules instead of loose herbs, as she was planning a three-month trip to Europe. We had agreed to communicate over Skype at least every other week while she was away, but she discontinued communication with me once she arrived in Holland. Ten days before she was due to return to the United States, she called to tell me that she had seriously relapsed. When she returned, she told me that she had discontinued her herbs when she arrived in the Netherlands because she was convinced that she was healed, but in fact the herbs had been entirely supporting her. Ten weeks after she stopped taking the herbs, their effects completely wore off and she crashed. Though she was full of regret, we were unable to regain the lost ground. She recently had a kidney transplant, and her body is now attempting to regain balance and recognize itself under the influence of immunosuppressive drugs. Though she has regained some of her lost muscle mass and is feeling far better than she did just before the transplant, she feels a kind of internal shaking, is easily overwhelmed, and has very dark skin around her eyes. She continues to struggle with seriously heeding my warnings that she focus only on her health and discontinue any superfluous activity. She is overconfident and still unable to fully recognize how frail she is. She frequently overcommits herself and later regrets it. As much as I have come to love this patient and fight for her life, I cannot save her from herself. Her case is a mixed blessing and a good lesson to never take a winning streak for granted. It is my belief that we would have prevailed if her acupuncture and herbs had been uninterrupted. I think she could have avoided dialysis and therefore a transplant. Her kidneys never would have returned to normal, but the disease process would likely not have progressed, and she might have maintained her good health. •  Wind diseases: Wind diseases are characterized by their shifting nature. Three Yellows points are very useful in the treatment of wind diseases, such as Parkinson’s and Meniere’s, because they very powerfully expel wind while tonifying the Liver. Shaking diseases such as Parkinson’s always relate to both the Liver and Kidneys, so Three Yellows alone is not enough. In this disease, water is not nourishing wood, so the root (Kidney/water) also needs to be treated. Meniere’s disease involves the inner ear (the window to the Kidney); when treating Meniere’s we also need to consider both dizziness and vomiting (wind and phlegm). •  Dizziness and vertigo: There are numerous reasons for dizziness and vertigo. Careful differentiation is required because in some cases, there may be more than one causative factor. The three primary factors are: excess Liver wind (including internal wind with external wind), Kidney yin or yang deficiency (or both), and blood deficiency. •  Meniere’s treatment: Meniere’s disease will return, usually in the springtime, if you do not completely resolve it. Three Yellows points are the best choice for treating Meniere’s disease, as it is an exacerbation of internal wind meeting external wind. To bilateral Three Yellows, add either LI11 Qu Chi or 22.05 Ling Gu, and PC6 Nei Guan, needled unilaterally. It is important to minimize the number of needles when treating wind diseases. Alternatively, consider 88.17-88.19 Four Horses when treating internal ear diseases, such as Meniere’s or Mal de Débarquement Syndrome. 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) is always a good option for wind diseases and internal ear pathologies, and it may be added to either Three Yellows or Four Horses, though its influence is already there. 44.07 Back Face (LI15) may be bled. •  LI11 Qu Chi is the He-Sea point on the Large Intestine channel and the primary TCM point for eliminating wind. It can be used for qi reversal and exterior conditions, and it cools heat, clears dampness, and regulates the blood, making it ideal in the treatment of all kinds of dizziness and vertigo. It utilizes a special internal relationship between the Yang Ming and Jue Yin channels (LI/LV), as well as the Yang Ming internal/external relationship with Stomach, giving it a strong qi and blood connection as well. 22.05 Ling Gu uses these same relationships and additionally tonifies the Kidney. Remember, choices need to be made to minimize the number of needles, so be selective rather than including all possible options (what I call “kitchen sinking”). •  PC6 Nei Guan is frequently used in this combination because it treats nausea and vomiting, which are common problems when vertigo is present. It additionally shares the Jue Yin connection to the Liver as well as a special internal connection to the Yang Ming (PC/ST). •  GB31 Wind Market mimics the effects of its counterpart, 88.12 Bright Yellow, and may also be added to Three Yellows, especially when it is used to treat blood diseases, particularly those involving the bone marrow and/or Liver wind. •  44.07 Back Face (LI15) is commonly bled for Meniere’s disease due to the special relationship between the Hand Yang Ming and Foot Jue Yin (LI/LV) and also the internal/external Liver and Gallbladder connection. Back Face is also useful for tinnitus and sudden deafness, for the same reasons. This point raises the pure qi and is also used for exhaustion and vomiting, similar to 1010.07 All Pivot for heat stroke. •  Epley Maneuver: Do a Google search for instructional videos to learn how to apply the Epley Maneuver, which is used to dislodge crystals found in the semicircular ducts of the inner ear. Make sure that patients with Meniere’s disease have someone to drive them home after undergoing this procedure, as they may immediately experience severe vertigo and even vomiting, which will then resolve. •  Meniere’s formula: Ban Xia Bai Zhu Tian Ma Tang and Er Chen Tang (Citrus and Pinellia Formula). Use Lychi and Chrysanthemum (Ji Gu Di Huang) to treat long term. •  Dizziness due to Kidney deficiency: Kidney deficiency is the most commonly seen cause of dizziness in the clinic; this can be either yin or yang deficiency, or both, and it most frequently affects the elderly. By far the best treatment in these cases is bilateral 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, because 77.18 Shen Guan (Kidney Gate) is Master Tung’s master Kidney point. 88.12 Bright Yellow may be added, or Shen Guan may be added to 88.12 and 88.14 Two Yellows to tonify water and eliminate wind while simultaneously building blood and minimizing the number of needles. 22.06-22.07 Zhong Bai/Xia Bai also can be used in these cases, as they are specific for dizziness and utilize the special internal relationship between the Shao Yang and Shao Yin (SJ/KD). •  Dizziness due to blood diseases: Three Yellows are my favorite points for treating blood diseases, although in Tung’s acupuncture we might also consider 77.05-77.07 Three Weights or 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/Wood Scoop. Choices are made relative to diagnosis and presentation. Of the three options, I have found Wood Keep/Wood Scoop to be the least effective, though I love these points for other uses. When treating Liver blood deficiency, I always choose Three Yellows because it tonifies and strengthens the Liver to clean the blood and expel wind. If the patient is also Spleen qi deficient, I might use Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment (bilateral ST36, SP6, LI11, LI4, LU7), with or without moxa on ST36 and SP6. Three Weights are chosen for blood diseases because they are located on the Gallbladder channel, adjacent to GB39 (the Sea of Marrow), and they affect both the Liver, which governs the blood, and the Spleen, which controls the blood. They disperse both wind and phlegm and are often used to increase circulation to the head and/or brain. Moxa on the Ming Men and REN4-REN8 is also very useful in building blood. •  Parkinson’s disease: There is still much to be learned to better understand Parkinson’s disease; however, the latest research implies that a buildup of endotoxins and environmental toxins (from heavy metals and other sources) in the brain causes a cascade of effects, including debilitating neurological deficits, dementia and depression. Functional medicine is on the brink of great discoveries with regard to detoxification protocols and immune system recovery through rebuilding the microbiome and restoring proper bile flow, thus reinstating detoxification pathways that have failed. Unfortunately, much irreversible damage has already been done, and it is predicted that in the relatively near future, 50% of all males will suffer from dementia and Alzheimer’s disease. Brain toxicity has now replaced amyloid plaque as the causative factor in Alzheimer’s. Major contributors are mercury (in fish and amalgams) and aluminum found in vaccines, which are often pushed upon unsuspecting populations around the world. Excessive amounts of lead, iron and copper are now frequently found in human bodies, as well as molds, parasites, viruses and retroviruses. Food and water sources are contaminated around the globe, and the desire to remain ignorant plagues any hope for a timely resolution. Also, overuse of antibiotics, NSAIDs and steroids have certainly played a part. That said, in the treatment of Parkinson’s, we can only do our best to protect any remaining neurons from further degeneration. •  Parkinson’s in TCM: In TCM, Parkinson’s is viewed as a shaking disease due to phlegm, fire, and wind. Because it is nearly always found in patients over the age of sixty, we want to avoid overtreatment and over-sedation by streamlining our protocols, using the fewest number of needles to achieve the best results. Cleaning toxins from the body (blood and brain) is paramount. I believe that in the near future, this will best be accomplished via intravenous delivery of agents that restore bile flow, stabilize mast cells and upregulate Nrf2. Substances such as phosphatidylcholine, glutathione, quercetin, r-lipoic acid, vitamin C, and many others, are also being delivered intravenously in new “cutting edge” therapies. Carefully constructed binders are required so toxins are not reabsorbed into the bloodstream but are instead carried out of the body through the bowels. As acupuncturists, we must simultaneously clean and support the patient’s body to our best ability, because absurdly, the IV treatments described above are currently beyond our scope of practice. Some acupuncturists may choose to hire nurse practitioners or other professionals to perform these IV therapies. I am currently implementing these types of detox protocols with patients in my practice. •  Treatment should include a thorough cupping of the DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas until the skin no longer colors. Bleeding of 99.08 Ear Apex, Tai Yang (temple area, avoiding the artery), LU5, UB40 and other appropriate points may be helpful. Because this typically is a treatment for the elderly, it is necessary to take a gentle approach over time, so as to avoid overwhelming the patient with too many needles. Be sure they have slept well and have eaten prior to your treatments. I have found a combination of Three Yellows and 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors to be the most effective, although I would never use all of these points together. 88.12 Bright Yellow may be added to 77.18 Shen Guan and 77.21 Man Emperor, or you might add 77.18 Shen Guan to 88.12 Bright Yellow and 88.14 This Yellow. Then add 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20) or 1010.06 Posterior Meeting (DU19) and 1010.05 Anterior Meeting (DU21) threaded through DU20 to clear the senses and calm the spirit, extinguish Liver wind and stabilize ascending yang. I often additionally needle 11.17 Wood (Anger) to address the underlying frustration and anger that living with Parkinson’s can create. LU5 can be needled or bled for tendon weakness and spasm. Dr. Young has said that PC3 Qu Ze, the He-Sea and water point on a fire meridian, is more effective than LU5 (33.16) because it is helpful for eliminating wind, due to the Jue Yin connection between the Pericardium and Liver meridians, and also because as a He-Sea water point, it tonifies Kidney qi for chronic diseases. Optional treatments: •  Calm tremors: Use 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), LV3 and LI4 (Four Gates) to resolve tremors and calm the nervous system. •  Weakness of the extremities (Parkinson’s disease): Thread a 3” needle from 1010.02 State Round (UB7) toward UB5 Da Zhu for Parkinson’s in the first year of treatment (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Drain damp heat: Unilaterally needle 33.10 Intestine Gate, 33.11 Liver Gate, 1010.06 Posterior Meeting (DU19), 1010.05 Anterior Meeting (DU21) (crossing needles at DU20). •  Formulas: The treatment principle is directed toward nourishing yin, dispelling wind and cleaning toxins; however, any herbal formula must be carefully customized to suit the individual. The following herbs and formulas may be helpful: Ling Yang Gou Teng Tang or herbs such as: Tian Ma, Gou Teng, Gui Ban, Mu Li, Bei Jia; Tian Ma Gou Teng Yin or Ding Zhen Wan (Pills for Calming Tremor). •  Bone spurs: Three Yellows can be selected for spine pain, but only if the pain is accompanied by some kind of liver-related condition, because we have so many choices when it comes to treating the spine. 88.12 Bright Yellow addresses bone spurs due to the internal/external relationship between the Liver and Gallbladder, and because Bright Yellow is located directly opposite 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), and Shao Yang (GB) controls bones. Tung’s palm diagnosis: “Master Tung treated an emaciated man who had tuberculosis who was cured after two months of treatment. However, he could not raise his arm due to residual severe shoulder pain. After inspecting his palm and finding a dark-greenish spot in the area of the Liver/Spleen channel, Master Tung needled Three Yellows to relieve the shoulder pain” (Dr. Wang, 2013 quoting Dr. Chen, 1964).
combinations: Liver cancer or disease: 11.20 Wood Inflammation, 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows. •  Hepatitis: 11.20 Wood Inflammation with 88.12- 88.14 Three Yellows, add 33.10 Intestine Gate and 33.11 Liver Gate for better effect. Consider ST36, SP9, UB18, LV3. •  Cirrhosis: Bleed UB18-UB20 (LV, GB and SP Shu Points). Unilaterally needle left-side 11.20 Wood Inflammation, 33.11 Liver Gate, SI4 Wan Gu; bilaterally needle 88.12- 88.14 Three Yellows. Also consider 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/Wood Scoop. •  Meniere’s disease: Bilaterally needle 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows; needle 22.05 Ling Gu or LI11 Qu Chi (classic TCM point for dizziness) on one side, PC6 Nei Guan (only if there is nausea and vomiting) on the other side. •  Chronic dizziness (due to Kidney deficiency): Bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, 22.06-22.07 Middle White/Lower White. •  Tiredness with dizziness: 88.12 Bright Yellow with 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors. •  Parkinson’s disease: 88.12-88.14 Two Yellows (choose two points only) with 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors, needle DU19 and DU21 directed toward DU20. •  Alternative treatment: Bilaterally needle 88.12- 88.14 Three Yellows, PC3 Qu Ze. •  To drain damp heat: Needle left-side 33.10 Intestine Gate and 33.11 Liver Gate. •  Shaky or weak legs: 88.12 Bright Yellow with 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors or 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows with 77.18 Shen Guan. •  Scoliosis: Glass cup the entire back; bamboo cup the spine; bilaterally needle 88.12- 88.14 Three Yellows, add DU26 Ren Zhong, LI11 Qu Chi, UB60 Kun Lun. Consider moxa on UB18 Gan Shu and UB20 Pi Shu (LV and SP Shu Points). Alternatively needle: SI3 Hou Xi, UB65 Shu Gu, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) and DU26 Ren Zhong (Dr. Young’s bone spur treatment). •  Canker sores: Edgar Cayce’s Ipsab tincture is miraculous for canker sores, reducing them by fifty percent overnight. Saturate a wisp of cotton with the tincture and place it between the cheek and gum. Needling 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows may also help with mouth sores, though I prefer Ipsab. •  Blood diseases: 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows, 77.18 Shen Guan (see Comments above). •  Digestive problems (due to wood attacking earth): 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows. •  Eye Pain (due to Liver excess): 55.02 Flower Bone One; 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows; 66.03 Fire Hardness (Tung’s LV2), 66.04 Fire Master (Tung’s LV3). •  Eye pain (due to deficiency): 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows, 77.28 Light Bright.
reaction_areas: Liver, Heart (88.12-88.14); Gallbladder (88.14 only) Cautions: •  These points may be extraordinarily tender premenstrually or with liver disease. For severe liver disease, you may choose to begin treatment with 11.20 Wood Inflammation and a strong herbal formula, adding Three Yellows when the patient can tolerate their palpation.

name: Huozhi, Fire Branch (T 88.15)
location: This point is on the LR channel, 1.5 cun distal to Minghuang (T 88.12) , which is at the center of the midline of the medial thigh. | Johnson: In order to locate the three 88.14-88.16 Gallbladder Points, it is first necessary to find 88.12 Bright Yellow, which is on the Liver channel, 8 cun above the top of the patella on the medial thigh: •  From 88.12 Bright Yellow, measure 3.0 cun below to locate 88.14 This Yellow, the Chief Point and middle point of the three Gallbladder Points. •  88.15 Fire Branch is located halfway between 88.12 Bright Yellow and 88.14 This Yellow, or 1.5 cun (two fingers) proximal to 88.14 This Yellow. •  88.16 Fire All is located 1.5 cun distal to 88.14 This Yellow.
primary_indications: dizziness and blurry vision due to Liver imbalance

Lower to mid-back pain (due to gallbladder)*
techniques: Needle 1.5 - 2.5 cun . | Johnson: Dao Ma: 88.15 Fire Branch and 88.16 Fire All are added to 88.14 This Yellow (Chief Point) in the combination known as 88.14-88.16 Gallbladder Points. •  Palpation: Palpate with light pressure, as these points will be very tender if the patient has an inflamed gallbladder. •  Note: I add 1010.18 Wood Branch (ST7) to the Gallbladder Points when treating acute cholecystitis; another option is 11.13 Gallbladder. •  Depth: 1.0-2.0 cun
comments: Detoxification, a big-picture view: Gallbladder inflammation, including sludge, stones and bile flow disruption, can cause a cascading effect of toxins in the bloodstream and therefore throughout all of the body’s tissues. Some people’s bodies are more capable of processing certain toxins than others, but everyone has residual toxins of some kind built up in their body. Whether one experiences the side effects of chemicals, molds, funguses, parasites, heavy metals, and/or pharmaceuticals depends upon the efficiency of the bile tree in the liver and the state of the gallbladder’s bile receptivity and flow. If the hepatocytes of the liver are overwhelmed by a myriad of toxins, or if the gallbladder is congested (or completely blocked), the result may be a shunting of unprocessed toxin buildup back into the bloodstream in order to dilute the toxins, save the hepatocytes, and temporarily postpone detoxification. This creates further pollution in the body, so it is absolutely essential that efficient bile flow is restored and maintained. There have always been environmental toxins and endotoxins requiring elimination by the body, but never in history have humans experienced the levels of toxicity currently found inside and outside of our bodies. •  Neurological disease epidemic: The worldwide rate of neurological disease in children has doubled since 2012. In the 1950s, one child in 5,000 was diagnosed as being somewhere on the autism spectrum. In 2012, it was one child in 88, and now one in 44 children has obvious neurological degeneration. Some people argue that we are now better at diagnosing autism, ADD, ADHD, and the like. However, one only needs to sit in the presence of a child who is unable to make eye contact or verbally communicate, and who self-soothes by hitting their head against a wall, to recognize that our species is in great jeopardy of biological and fiscal demise. Within the time span of two U.S. presidencies, our nation will be unable to care for a generation of disabled children as well as two generations of the elderly who are dealing with Alzheimer’s, dementia, Parkinson’s, multiple sclerosis and other neurologically degenerative diseases. •  Detoxification strategies: Though our global community faces a bleak picture and a daunting task, we are simultaneously at the cutting edge of discovering methods of recovering our physical and mental health. Scientists are researching ways to restore our body’s natural detox pathways (bile flow) and protective mechanisms such as the microbiome. •  The microbiome (part one): The microbiome is the body’s built-in immune system, sometimes referred to as the “gut microbiome.” Leading authorities no longer recommend probiotics; they say that each individual’s microbiome is so unique that the idea of supplementing it with a prescribed probiotic is now thought to be ludicrous. The latest research demonstrates that the microbiome is comprised of over 4,000 different types of flora (such as bacteria, molds, fungi, parasites, spirochetes, viruses and retroviruses), from which many details can be determined about an individual, including their sex and race, where they live, whether their birth was vaginal or by caesarian section, and if they were breast fed. One’s microbiome changes from one instant to the next, in response to new smells and environments, foods and chemical or environmental exposures. The health of the microbiome is essential for adequate immune response, and it will be a major part of future medical diagnostics as well as the restoration of bile flow and detox pathways. Researchers who study the microbiome are unknowingly reviving the concepts of the TCM “Earth School” in modern medicine. It is a very exciting time in the realm of study about autoimmune diseases, lymph drainage and the lymphatic system, including brain detoxification. See 88.17-88.19 Four Horses for “The microbiome (part two).” •  Ketogenesis and autophagy: Researchers are also recognizing our innate capacity to fuel the brain and body primarily through the metabolism of fat (ketogenesis – the old Atkins Diet model, recently revived), restoring the biological flexibility of our hunter/gatherer ancestors in using both glucose and fat as fuel. When we burn fat as fuel, it allows for a process known as autophagy, the body’s innate ability to rid itself of damaged, toxic, or unused cells. Though humans have always been able to metabolize sugar and fat, most modern brains operate on glucose alone. It has been proven that fat is a much cleaner fuel source without the devastating side effects that have grown out of the sole reliance upon glucose, which is insidious in contemporary cuisines and results in untold inflammation and metabolic syndromes. •  Parasympathetic pathways: All of the detoxification processes occurring within the human body are part of parasympathetic nervous system pathways. This means when the body is engaged in the “fight or flight” response of the sympathetic nervous system, detoxification will never take priority. The chronic, constant stress level of today’s society, a primary cause of our overactive sympathetic systems, must be addressed before – or at least simultaneously with – any other “downstream” interventions. In this regard, Oriental medicine, including Tai Chi, Qi Gong, meditation, acupuncture and herbal medicine, as well as a plethora of other mental, emotional, spiritual, and integrative medical interventions, will prove to be nothing less than lifesaving. •  Gallbladder inflammation: I love treating patients with gallbladder inflammation because I have the perfect tool: 88.14 This Yellow, 88.15 Fire Branch and 88.16 Fire All, also known as the Gallbladder Points, along with 1010.18 Wood Branch (ST7), are outstandingly effective in the treatment of gallbladder disease, inflammation, sludge or stones. Gallstones are easy to treat. In the more than thirty years that I have been in practice, only one of my patients with gallstones has required gallbladder surgery, though nearly all of them were on the surgical schedule when they began treatment with me. People can live with gallstones as long as the gallbladder is not trying to pass them. If I have two weeks to treat the patient, they will keep their gallbladder. In acute cases, I may treat them three times a week with strong needle stimulation and long retention. When the patient is no longer aware of their gallbladder, I usually discontinue needling 1010.18 Wood Branch (ST7). When they are sixty percent better, treatment frequency may be reduced to once or twice a week. Continue treating the patient until their gallbladder channel is no longer painful when palpated. Dietary advice: Ask the patient to eat handfuls of raw walnuts for prevention and treatment (no salt or sugar). Raw walnuts are good for kidney stones as well. Caffeine, alcohol, spicy foods and oily foods (including dairy) need to be strictly avoided when the gallbladder is inflamed. •  001 Hand Golden Gate: This point came to my attention after I had used the gallbladder protocol described above for more than twenty-five years with exceptional results. I add Hand Golden Gate to this body of work because it was given to us by Dr. Young and is therefore noteworthy, though I have not needled it to relieve cramping gallbladder pain. Please see 001 Hand Golden Gate for further information. •  Alternative treatments for gallbladder pain: •  001 Hand Golden Gate can be added to either 88.14-88.16 Gallbladder Points with 1010.18 Wood Branch (ST7) or 66.03-66.04 Fire Hardness/Fire Master with 1010.18 Wood Branch. •  Dr. Young gave us the following needle prescription, which can be considered an alternative: 001 Hand Golden Gate, needled with 22.07 Lower White (Xia Bai) and Dan Nang Xue (Extra Point located 1-2.0 cun inferior to GB34 Yang Ling Quan) treats cramping gallbladder pain. •  Bilaterally needle 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) or A.01 Seven Miles (GB32), 1010.18 Wood Branch (ST7). •  Gallstone pain (formulas): The Gallbladder Points will help with the inflammation and pain from gallstones or grit, but will not remove the stones. To dissolve the stones, long-term use of Li Dan (classic Gallbladder formula) with a tea made from the loose herb Jin Qian Cao (Lysmachia) usually does the trick. •  Other formulas (Dr. Young): Da Chai Hu Tong (Major Bupleurum Decoction) with Jin Qian Cao and Jin Nei Jin. Also, Si Ni San with 3 Mu Xiang, 3 Jin Qian Cao, 3 Zhi Shi, 3 Jin Nei Jin, Da Huang. If the patient has jaundice, use 10 Yun Chen Ho, 1.5 Da Huang, 1.0-1.5 Gan Cao. •  Case history (gallstones): In 1995, I treated a twenty-seven-year-old woman with multiple gallstones. She had extreme gallbladder pain, nausea and vomiting. She was on a surgical schedule to have her gallbladder removed ten days later. She was the only child of two elderly parents in ill health, and had a very stressful job. I had treated her five years previously for PMS and irritability, at her partner’s request. Aside from the severe gallbladder pain, she was in relatively good health. After two treatments using my standard protocol, her gallbladder pain was fifty percent better. After the first week of treatment, she was eighty percent better and cancelled her surgery. We fully restored the functioning of her gallbladder, though she would have needed to continue treatments for some time in order to completely dissolve the gallstones. As is common among patients, once she forgot about her gallbladder and the crisis she had averted, she discontinued treatment. Years later, she called me regarding her mother’s knee pain and expressed her gratitude once again that I had saved her gallbladder. I’m sure she will call me if she needs help again. •  Case history (teen with gallstones): Twenty-seven is young for gallstones, but I actually once had a fourteen-year-old gallbladder patient, and she was the only one who needed her gallbladder removed (and this was because she was too young and too disturbed to be compliant with her treatment). I will never forget Dr. Lee telling me, “Gallstones indicate that something is wrong in the patient’s life, too much worry or the patient is unhappy or has regrets of some kind.” My teenage patient was being raised by her grandparents because both of her parents were addicted to heroin and constantly in and out of rehab. •  Case history (cholecystitis): In 2018, I treated a woman who had cholecystitis and did not have gallstones. Because she was travelling, she gave me three weeks (nine treatments) to resolve her situation. She had constant gallbladder pain, what she called a “bubbling sensation” in her right upper quadrant, temple headaches and substantial nausea every time she ate. During her first treatment, I cupped her neck, shoulders, upper back and toxin areas, because gallbladder obstruction leads to toxin buildup. In all of these areas, the skin was black after cupping. In every treatment, I bilaterally needled 88.14-88.16 Gallbladder Points along with 1010.18 Wood Branch (ST7). In the fourth treatment (one week later), I cupped the remaining areas of her torso, sacrum and hips, and the skin in these areas was also dark after cupping. By the fifth treatment, she was no longer experiencing any nausea or bubbling sensations, and her gallbladder pain was completely gone. For the sixth treatment, I discontinued needling Wood Branch. When she returned two days later for her seventh treatment, she reported experiencing her gallbladder again, though lightly and intermittently. With her last two treatments, I returned to needling Wood Branch along with the Gallbladder Points. She left with a two-month supply of Li Dan and Jin Qian Cao. Six weeks later, she reported no further gallbladder trouble and has returned to her normal low-fat diet. •  Case history (SAMe40 induced cholecystitis): I had a fifty-year-old patient with extreme pain at REN14. I thought it was either an ulcer or gallstones. Her Liver channel and Gallbladder Points were extremely sensitive. I sent her for an ultrasound, which came back clear. Then she told me that she had been taking SAMe for depression and weight loss. SAMe makes people feel nauseous so they won’t eat as much. Please avoid SAMe and 5HTP because they can cause gallbladder inflammation. I would far rather give my patients Chinese herbs for depression and needle them for weight loss than upset their system in that way. It took six weeks for this patient’s Liver meridian to return to normal. •  TCM wisdom: If the Liver is weak, patients are tired. If the Gallbladder is weak, patients are easily startled. •  Heel or spine pain: “88.16 Fire All can be needled on the opposite side to treat heel or spine pain. This works but the effect does not last long” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Cholecystitis: Cup the Toxin Areas. Bilaterally needle 88.14-88.16 Gallbladder Points with 1010.18 Wood Branch (ST7). See Comments for additional treatment information. •  Gallstones: Cup the Toxin Areas. Bilaterally needle 88.14-88.16 Gallbladder Points with 1010.18 Wood Branch (ST7). See Comments for additional treatment options. •  Jaundice: Cup the Toxin Areas. Bilaterally needle 88.14-88.17 Three Yellows or 88.14 This Yellow, 88.15 Fire Branch, 88.16 Fire All or 88.12 Bright Yellow, 88.15 Fire Branch, 88.16 Fire All. •  Hepatitis: Cup the Toxin Areas. Bilaterally needle 88.14-88.17 Three Yellows or 88.14 This Yellow, 88.15 Fire Branch, 88.16 Fire All. •  Epilepsy: Bilaterally needle 88.14-88.16 Gallbladder Points, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) and 77.18 Kidney Gate (Dr. Young). I would also include 55.06 Upper Tumor in the above combination.
