techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.8 - 2.5 cun . Needle bilaterally, except when treating pain. For pain, needle contralateral to the affected side. | Johnson: Dao Ma: The combination of 88.17-88.19 is known as Four Horses. 88.17 Four Horses Middle is the Chief Point and the most powerful point for the Lungs. •  Palpation: Four Horses points are easy to locate because at each point, a depression, small hole or pool of energy can be felt. •  45-degree angle: A reliable approach to locating Four Horses is to identify where the muscles of the thigh change from a horizontal to a vertical plane, on a line originating at the lateral corner of the patella and extending up the thigh. Though the needles are inserted perpendicularly, after insertion they appear to be at a 45-degree angle to the body. Please see inset in point illustration above. •  Bilateral vs. unilateral insertion: Four Horses points are needled bilaterally to treat conditions such as asthma, colds and flus, allergies, thyroid and skin disorders. For conditions located on one side of the body, such as facial paralysis, hemiplegia, sciatica, flank pain, rib pain or breast pain, an opposite-side needling technique may be used. Upper back pain is an indication that may require either bilateral needling or the opposite-side technique. •  Insertion and stimulation: Typically, 88.17 Four Horses Middle, the Chief Point, is needled first. The other two points are Supplementary Points, located using 88.17 as a reference. After insertion, stimulate Four Horses Middle, and then the outer two points again. •  Needle with qi: For optimal results, please put some qi into your needling. Insert the needle deeply, hold the handle firmly, catch the qi and strongly stimulate these points. I am not suggesting that a patient should experience pain when receiving Four Horses; they should not. But very strong and forceful energy is available here, and you have an opportunity to direct and deliver it. Don’t waste the opportunity! Patients consistently report strong movement of qi in both directions when I needle these points. Downsize your needle gauge to the patient’s comfort level, and then decisively move the qi for immediate and excellent results. These points do not generally bruise, but be sure to avoid any visible blood vessels. •  Needling technique for skin diseases: It is said that skin treats skin and muscle also treats skin. When using Four Horses to treat skin issues, if time allows, insert the needles to the deepest muscle level and strongly stimulate to call the qi. After ten minutes, pull the needles halfway up (to medium depth) and stimulate again. After an additional ten minutes, pull the needles up to the superficial level again, stimulate, and let the patient retain them for the duration of the treatment (30-40 minutes). The technique of calling the qi and then bringing it to the surface is only used in the treatment of skin disorders, such as psoriasis, eczema, shingles, acne, or rashes. When needling for acne on the face, start with the most distal point and needle toward the proximal. •  When time is tight: In my clinic, I may bilaterally needle Four Horses with A.04 San Cha Three as soon as I enter the treatment room. Then I talk with the patient and hear their update, and after ten minutes I raise the needles halfway. Just before leaving the room, I pull the needles up to the superficial level. If the clinic is busy and I don’t have time to pull the needles up in stages, instead I insert them to the deep or medium level, stimulate strongly, then pull the energy to the surface level and cover the patient. However, the more gradual method may yield better results, depending on the skill of the practitioner. •  Retention: For constitutional complaints, Four Horses should be needled deeply and retained for a minimum of 45 minutes to be effective. For secondary complaints, a shorter treatment (20 minutes) with opposite-side needling may be utilized. •  Needling depths: The needling depth may range from 0.8 to 2.5 cun. At the most distal point, the needle typically contacts bone; when it does, tap it very gently to avoid injury to the periosteum. To insert to the necessary depth, I use needles of 40-50mm length. If a patient has large thighs, 60mm needles may be required. •  Depth: 0.8-2.5 cun
comments: My favorite points: The name Four Horses refers to the power of a four-horse carriage moving with extraordinary momentum. A one-horse carriage ride through the countryside on a lazy Sunday afternoon would not be a fitting metaphor for the strong and lasting effects of these amazing points. This three- or six-point pattern is easy to locate and very versatile. These points are prized by Tung’s acupuncture practitioners for their use in treating a wide and diverse array of disorders, especially lung diseases, including: impaired breathing and asthma, skin conditions, rhinitis, tuberculosis, rib pain, upper back pain, thyroid problems, and sciatica or lower back pain due to Lung deficiency. These points are extremely effective for pain related to Lung deficiency, especially when there is excess fatigue; for that reason, they are also primary points for fibromyalgia and multiple sclerosis. I love these points and use them more frequently in my practice than any other Dao Ma pattern. •  A.04 San Cha Three: Nearly every time I needle Four Horses, I add A.04 San Cha Three (needled toward HT8 Shao Fu), as they complement each other perfectly. This combination is my first choice for colds and flus, but it is also an excellent choice for skin conditions, allergies (seasonal or otherwise), and immune system weakness. (See A.04 San Cha Three.) •  The microbiome (part two): Our bodies are throwbacks to the era of hunters and gatherers, but since those times our diet and environment have radically changed. Because of our consumption of animals that are factory raised on GMO corn, steroids, and antibiotics, and also because many people ingest large quantities of sugar, caffeine, drugs or alcohol daily, we have created a world of suffering for ourselves and other beings. We are witnessing an unprecedented rise in autoimmune diseases, diabetes, autism, Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s and a host of other man-made calamities. Using the technology developed during the Human Genome Project (2003), scientists have newly discovered the human microbiome and the fact that we are composed of 50-100 trillion organisms that are non-human. These organisms that we host are sometimes working in harmony with us as a healthy microbiome, and thus constitute the majority of our immune system. However, in more recent history this relationship has become less harmonious due to the creation of a pathological biofilm, the overuse of antibiotics, poor diets, toxic chemical and environmental exposures, and a more or less sedentary, feasting lifestyle. The good news is that we are beginning to understand that we have been missing a very crucial piece of information, recently revealed by “The Microbiome Project.” Our microbiome is heavily influenced by our environment – what is around us. Chronic disease is the interaction between our environment and our genetic triggers; thus, the triggers alone are not a death sentence, and they may never genetically express, but for our choices and environments. Sadly, researchers have found that chronic disease processes begin in utero, as babies’ umbilical cords are loaded with more than two hundred and eighty known toxins, such as BPA (bisphenol A) and glyphosate, which poison our developing children before they even enter the world. This reality is sad and horrifying, and my only intention in sharing it is to awaken you to the real danger. We are not going to wake up in our world and discover all of the remarkable things that we did while we were sleeping; rather, we must awaken and take responsibility for the mess that we have created, and do everything in our power to clean it up immediately. The planet and future generations depend upon our conscious actions. It is absolutely crucial to understand that we control our fate. We must recover our leaky guts and immune systems by rebuilding our microbiome through cleansing and detoxing our bodies. Very simply, this means that if you choose to eat organic foods, that choice alone will lead you to feel better. Stop compromising! The unhealthy gut microbiome produces bioactive compounds that powerfully influence the central nervous system (CNS), creating unhealthy cravings that are difficult to ignore. Is it YOU who wants another candy bar, pastry and espresso, salted fries or bowl of pasta, or is it the bugs inside of you? For those of us who are health practitioners, awareness of these phenomena can help us educate and treat our patients. Patients need to fully understand what made them so sick before they will agree to do what they need to do to get well. They must understand that there will be a die-off of “bad” microbes before the healthy new ones can take over, and that detoxing can take time – sometimes more than a year or two. Dietary restrictions have to be spelled out clearly if patients are going to be successful in their healing. Children who were placed on round after round of antibiotics, seemingly from birth, have immune systems that are totally compromised. These children with hypersensitivities are unable to withstand the world as it is. We see this in their eating habits, health issues and emotional behaviors. I fear for their future, and ours as well. It would be interesting to study what such a child would be like if they were fed a healthy, chemical-free diet and protected from electromagnetic field smog and stray electricity. It is my belief that even autistic children would flourish in such an environment and likely become the prodigies of the future. Changing to an entirely clean diet may seem utterly overwhelming to families with poor eating habits (80% of Americans). If we propose permanent dietary changes as restrictive as the complete avoidance of all trans fats, sugars, flours, grains, and processed foods of any kind (in other words, inflammatory foods), parents freak out. Instead, it is better to suggest that they start with a short period of time – three months – to restrict their child’s diet. However, they will find that the changes in the child’s physical, mental and emotional health and their unmanageable behaviors will radically change within less than two weeks, after which the dietary restrictions will be viewed as a real godsend and will be easy to maintain. Parents of young children may have to use bribes (e.g., toys) to introduce healthier eating habits. In the beginning, tantrums and meltdowns are to be expected. It takes three days to break an addiction, so usually within four days, the child is hungry enough and willing to try new foods like leafy greens if they are prepared in a tasty manner. Get some nutritional counseling and get started. Honestly, the health of your child, your family, your community and our earth ALL begin here. We must take responsibility for what we put into our bodies and understand the dangers of factory farming, including chemicals introduced into the soil, water, air and food that we consume. In the 1960s, people were alarmed by the effects of DDT (Dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane), but now the primary chemical culprit is glyphosate. The chemical breakdown of glyphosate is AMPA (aminomethylphosphonic acid). When testing the environment or the blood for glyphosate poisoning, we must test for both glyphosate and AMPA to understand the seriousness of these and other toxic chemicals, which are now found worldwide, even in the rain. It is only through grassroots movements that the use of GMOs, harmful chemicals and factory farming will change. It is entirely up to us. Read labels, buy organic, and avoid plastics, and you will be on your way to a healthier future for your family and generations to come. Stop using antibacterial hand sanitizer and get some dirt under your fingernails. Touch the earth and let her touch you. In Chinese medicine, we think about the earth element when it comes to providing nutrients for the whole body and keeping the immune system vital and strong. Hippocrates said, “Let food be thy medicine and medicine be thy food.” I would contend that Chinese medicine said this first. Please see 88.15-88.16 Fire Branch/Fire All for “The microbiome (part one).” •  When I think of Four Horses, I think “immune system:” Four Horses are used to address all kinds of immune system reactions, from common cold and allergies to something as rare as the autoimmune disease known as pemphigoid/pemphigus. Allergic reactions usually involve some kind of trigger that pushes the liver beyond its capacity to detoxify the system when the Lung and Spleen are weak, and immunity is compromised. Four Horses have the Reaction Areas of the Lung and Liver. The Lung governs the surface (or Wei qi) and the Liver cleans the blood. When the Wei qi is weak, the body is vulnerable to external wind; when the Liver is weak, the blood is not clean and internal wind results. Found between the Shao Yang and Yang Ming channels, Four Horses relate to both wind and phlegm. Their extraordinary power comes from their ability to strengthen both the Lung and Liver through boosting the Spleen, cleaning the blood and expelling wind. •  Energetic pathways: Below is an explanation of the many different ways in which the energetics of Four Horses combine. We have done our best to tease out these relationships in a linear way in order that they might be more easily understood; however, they layer one upon another and are inextricably interwoven, interrelated, and not necessarily presented in order of importance. Their many overlapping energetic interactions make Four Horses extremely clinically useful: Spleen/Stomach: The Spleen governs the muscles, and together with the Stomach, it is responsible for postnatal qi. Four Horses points are located near the Stomach channel in the large quadriceps muscles of the thigh. Due to the abundant nerve and blood supply found there, needling these points provides ample tonification of qi and blood. Because of this earth element relationship, these points not only have a powerful influence over the immune system, but also are helpful in treating phlegm conditions such as hypothyroid and/or goiter. Muscle treats muscle, which enables us to use these points to treat muscle weakness or atrophy, multiple sclerosis and fibromyalgia. Because Four Horses points regulate the Spleen and Stomach, and the Stomach channel travels to the face, they are also used to treat diseases of the eyes, ears, nose and throat. •  Lung/Spleen: The Lung governs the Wei qi, which is responsible for the surface of the body and prevents the invasion of external pathogens. Because of the relationship of the Hand and Foot Tai Yin (LU/SP), Four Horses points tonify both Lung and Spleen qi. This makes them highly useful in the treatment of any kind of immune system deficiency, including autoimmune diseases, allergies, asthma, cough, colds or flus, phlegm, and skin diseases. The Spleen governs the muscles, and muscle treats muscle, but muscle also treats the skin. In most cases of Spleen deficiency, we see not only signs of internal dampness but also damp skin diseases, muscle weakness, loose stools and fatigue. •  Lung/Large Intenstine: In addition to the above relationships, Tai Yin and Yang Ming are connected through the internal/external relationship of the Lung and Large Intestine, and both have a strong influence over external wind. We frequently add LI20 Welcome Fragrance as a Guiding Point for issues on the face, such as acne, but it is especially good for sinus infections or inflammation, sinus headaches, as well as other nasal problems, such as polyps or atrophy. Nasal atrophy is the loss of the ability to smell and therefore also taste. It frequently occurs after surgery as a side effect to anesthesia but also may be related to other kinds of drug interactions. See 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20) for my unique and detailed needling instructions. •  Large Intestine/Liver: In Tung’s acupuncture, we recognize a special relationship between the Hand Yang Ming (LI) and Foot Jue Yin (LV), which work together to detoxify the body. While the Large Intestine and Lungs are closely related (the Large Intestine expels toxins through the bowels, the Lungs through the skin), the Liver detoxifies the entire body by filtering the blood. Both the Liver and the Large Intestine expel wind – the Liver internally, and the Large Intestine externally. Four Horses Middle, the Chief Point, is located anterior to GB31 Wind Market, so Four Horses is associated with all kinds of wind diseases due to the internal/ external relationship between the Liver and Gallbladder (wood and wind), making Four Horses very useful in the treatment of dizziness, vertigo, Meniere’s disease, Parkinson’s disease and hyperthyroidism. •  Lung/Liver: Four Horses points have the Reaction Areas of Lung and Liver; while the Lung governs the surface, the Liver cleans the blood. As previously discussed, one of the most common indications of a compromised immune system is an allergic skin reaction that happens when the surface is weak and the liver is overworked. Because Four Horses can be used to expel wind and move the blood, it is especially useful in treating allergic reactions that cause itching, rashes, psoriasis, eczema or fungal infections. Lung/Urinary Bladder: The Chinese have a saying: “The wind chill evil enters through the back of the neck.” Never is this more evident than in situations of wind chill lodging in the neck and upper back, causing not only muscle spasm but also the onset of most common colds and flu. There is a special relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yang (UB), characterized in part by the ability of both to disperse fluids. When the evil wind chill penetrates the Wei qi, governed by the Lungs, we use surface-dispersing herbs to open the exterior and induce sweating, thus relieving the Tai Yang upper back. The Tai Yin/Tai Yang relationship is also evident in the use of Four Horses for thorax pain (front or back), chest and rib pain, as well as Lung-deficient-type UB channel sciatica. However, I rarely use Four Horses for sciatica unless the patient also has another condition such as asthma, allergies or psoriasis, for which Four Horses points are indicated. •  Cough and asthma: Four Horses are my primary points and favorites for asthma and pneumonia, but they are also very good for any kind of cough, whether it is acute or chronic. If the wind chill has lodged in the upper back muscles, or if the lungs feel heavy or tight, cup the entire neck and upper back (with the patient sitting upright), then needle Four Horses, A.04 San Cha Three and 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/ Water Through. Bleeding 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) bilaterally is especially helpful in severe cases; it will open the lungs and immediately calm the breathing. If you are not comfortable bleeding LU5, it could be bilaterally needled. Water Gold/Water Through points tonify the Lungs and Kidneys and are great when a patient has been coughing or wheezing for an extended period of time. Because Water Gold/Water Through points are used for lower back pain and sexual dysfunction, they also can treat urinary incontinence that may arise toward the end of a severe upper respiratory infection. If the patient is experiencing allergic asthma, I am also likely to add 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20) to open the sinuses. •  Common cold: Illness may be avoided altogether if, within a few hours of being chilled, the patient takes an extremely hot shower with water beating upon the upper back and neck. This corresponds with the Chinese teaching, “The wind-chill evil enters through the back of the neck.” Often patients feel a shudder of cold coming out through the surface while they stand under the steaming hot water. They need to be careful not to get exposed to another chill after the hot shower (bring warm clothes into the bathroom). A good sweat, followed by a change of clothes, should relieve the chill. Treatments: •  Cupping: When a patient has a wind-chill invasion, I immediately cup their entire upper back to remove it. This must be done within a few hours of the exposure for best results, although it may still be appropriate days later if the chill is still lodged in the body. •  Cold/flu, sinusitis, allergies: Bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, A.04 San Cha Three and 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20) as Guiding Points; optional 11.17 Wood (Anger). •  Optional: Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment: Bilaterally needle ST36, SP6, LI11, LI4, LU7 in this order, tonifying the bottom and sedating the top), 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20). For headache from a common cold: Unilaterally needle 22.04 Da Bai and A.04 San Cha Three (one point on each side). •  For sore throat: Bleed VT.01 Throat Nine Moths or bleed LU11 and LI1. •  To clear the sinuses: Needle 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20) toward Yin Tang. •  Optional: To open the nose: Bilaterally needle proximal point 11.17 Wood (Anger). For nasal blockage with pain or headache: Unilaterally needle 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43). •  Allergy option: Needle 11.17 Wood (Anger), 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20), LI4/LV3 Four Gates or 22.04 Da Bai. •  For ear pain: Bleed 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles. •  Hyperthyroid: Four Horses points emphasize the relationship between wood and metal, as well as that of qi and blood. They treat conjunctivitis and hyperthyroid, both of which have a relationship to the Liver. According to TCM, simple goiter is phlegm accumulation in the neck, caused by qi and blood stagnation. Usually a strong emotional component is involved, and if irritability and frustration are also present, the condition may easily transform into Spleen qi (phlegm) obstruction with Liver qi stagnation. This causes Liver fire to rise, resulting in Heart yin deficiency and potentially hyperthyroidism. Because Four Horses points are located between the Shao Yang and Yang Ming channels, they are capable of addressing both wind and phlegm in a powerful way. Due to the relationships between San Jiao and Gallbladder, Gallbladder and Liver, and Spleen and Stomach, and their passage through the neck, where the thyroid gland is located, Four Horses becomes one of the best point patterns in the treatment of hyperthyroid disease, including enlarged thyroid, goiter, and/or related protrusion of the eyeballs. •  Skin diseases: Similar in function to LI11 Qu Chi and 44.06 Shoulder Center (also located in large muscles), Four Horses points treat the skin because needling muscle treats muscle and also treats the skin (Dr. Young, 2008). Skin diseases are more common in places where people eat rich foods, are exposed to environmental toxins, raise pets, etc. Four Horses are fabulous points for the skin – for itching, pruritis, acne, shingles, psoriasis, eczema, and skin fungus as well as thickening of the skin or scleroderma. I have found them to be extraordinary in the treatment of psoriasis (although dietary changes are also essential). If the skin disorder is severe, bleed 99.07 Ear Back or 99.08 Ear Apex once a week, because Shao Yang (SJ/GB) governs wind, and Tai Yang (SI/UB) governs the exterior and the skin; both Shao Yang and Tai Yang travel to the back of the ear. See Needling Notes above for further instructions related to the treatment of skin diseases. •  Acne: Four Horses is excellent for treating acne. Nine out of ten patients with acne have a red face. With Four Horses and A.04 San Cha Three, the patient’s face becomes less red, their skin improves, and the acne goes away. Over time, even the scars from acne may disappear. Add 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20) as a Guiding Point and treat 1-3 times weekly. Herbs and dietary restrictions are helpful. •  Itching and rashes: Itching and rashes are wind disorders that happen when qi, blood, wind and fire are fighting. With wind disorders, we must disperse wind, and vitalize and clean the blood. Though invaluable for itching and rashes, Four Horses can be rotated with the primary meridian points, SP6 San Yin Jiao, SP10 Xue Hai, LI11 Qu Chi, Bai Chong Wo (Extra Point) and HT8 Shao Fu (as A.04 San Cha Three). •  SP6 San Yin Jiao strengthens the Spleen and eliminates dampness. •  SP10 Xue Hai cools the blood and removes dampness to stop itching. •  LI11 Qu Chi clears heat, cools the blood, expels wind and alleviates itching. •  Bai Chong Wo (Extra Point), Hundred Insect Burrow, is located 1.0 cun proximal to SP10 and is used to relieve itching and soothe the skin. •  HT8 Shao Fu (which is reached via A.04 San Cha Three) is very good for itching because itching and pain belong to the Heart. As a Ying-Spring and fire point, HT8 disperses heat and treats changes in face color (not due to emotions). •  Psoriasis: I have successfully treated countless cases of psoriasis using Four Horses and A.04 San Cha Three. As long as the DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas (also known as Poison Points) are free of psoriasis, I thoroughly cup them weekly, until no color appears. For the quickest results, ask the patient to avoid caffeine, alcohol, spicy foods, dairy, wheat, sugar and albumin (egg whites). Eating egg yolks may reduce itching. Some patients are unable to follow these extreme dietary restrictions; however, in severe cases I will not treat them unless they are willing to comply. It is important that psoriasis patients wear only cotton next to their skin, and stay off of synthetic carpets, AstroTurf, and any other kind of chemical irritant. •  Case history: I first treated a patient with severe psoriasis in 1988. He was Filipino, so his natural skin color was brown; however, he had psoriatic lesions from head to toe, making his skin appear pink and white. His joints were also affected, swollen and inflamed from advanced psoriasis. I treated him using Four Horses, A.04 San Cha Three, dietary restrictions and a strong herbal formula. I advised him to take daily “sun baths” in the nude because sunshine is helpful in healing this kind of skin disease. Within three months, the pink and white lesions had turned to a light tan color and no longer looked crusted or inflamed. I then was able to cup the DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas. Within six months, his skin fully recovered, his joints were no longer painful, and he was able to discontinue treatment, maintaining his new healthy diet. •  Case history: A fifty-year-old real estate agent came to see me because of severe psoriasis on his hands. He also had large patches all over his body, but he was less concerned about those, as in his line of work it was necessary that he shake people’s hands. It was always awkward for him when clients saw his hands then withdrew their own. I discussed with him the parameters of treating severe psoriasis (outlined above) and told him that if he was unable to follow the dietary restrictions, I would be unable to help him. This man was addicted to caffeinated energy drinks and enjoyed one or two cocktails every evening. He agreed to the restrictions. After three months, with two or three treatments per week, he was 90% better. He was no longer afraid to offer a handshake. •  Case history: A sixty-year-old woman came to see me for a tangerine-sized patch of psoriasis on the back of her neck. It was dark red, solid and inflamed. It had appeared when she was fifteen years old. She also had psoriasis in and behind her ears and around her anterior hairline. I put her on the usual dietary restrictions and herbs for skin and hot flashes. She could only see me once a month because she lived four hours away. I thoroughly cupped her upper back and DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas and seven-star-hammered the healthy skin surrounding the lesion on the back of her neck. I then needled Four Horses, A.04 San Cha Three, 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points. Now, one year later, the lesion on her neck is entirely gone and she has mostly returned to her normal diet. Because she occasionally has one or two tiny spots of psoriasis within her hairline and in or behind her ears, she continues to take her herbal formula at a 25% dose and returns periodically for a maintenance treatment. I recently asked her to topically apply diluted tea tree oil on those areas and to do a better job of drying her ears after showering. •  Case history: A forty-year-old patient, whom I originally saw when she was in her thirties for asthma, returned four years ago with psoriasis on her hands and feet. The psoriasis on her feet was cracked and bleeding, and it prevented her from wearing shoes. She swam regularly in a chlorinated pool. Along with wearing sandals, swimming had caused her skin to suffer from exposure to chlorine, wind and sun, drying it even further. In order to treat this patient, I had to ask her to discontinue swimming until her skin had healed. This and the dietary restrictions were very challenging for her, but she complied. Within six weeks, her skin had improved by eighty percent and she was able to wear her regular shoes. She returned to swimming and maintained her dietary restrictions. After approximately eighteen months of intermittent treatment, I ran an allergy blood panel to determine which foods might cause her immune system to react. We were delighted to find that she had successfully turned off all of her triggers. When I called to give her the results of her blood test and to tell her that she might begin to include some of the foods she had been avoiding, she informed me that she had begun a Weight Watchers program and had already been including small amounts of the forbidden foods for over six months without any exacerbation of her psoriasis, but even more importantly, without triggering an immune reaction. It can be done! •  Case history (scleroderma): A forty-five-year-old man with scleroderma who lived three and a half hours away was referred to my office by an acupuncturist who was leaving his area. The patient had been suffering from scleroderma his entire adult life, with very large areas of scarring on the right side of his back, arm, leg, lateral ankle and foot. It had started in the ankle, so this area was the worst; it was entirely scarred, rigid and devoid of any pigment color. Areas of pigment loss and scarring created a pulling sensation though his right armpit down to his wrist. There was an area of scarring on his right scapula that pulled into his right neck and shoulder areas. Another painful area on his right flank caused a pulling sensation down the entire IT41 band of his right leg, exacerbating the severe disability in his ankle. I began his treatment by cupping all of the affected areas except the ankle, to which I applied warming oil and a heat lamp. The cupping gave him enormous relief; he even shaved his armpit before each treatment so I could apply cups there. The cupping in the armpit and down the medial arm was excruciatingly painful, but the subsequent relief from the pulling sensation of the scleroderma was worth it to him and lasted nearly the entire month between his treatments. He was unable to take herbs but followed the anti-inflammatory diet that I prescribed. His treatments included a full hour of cupping every visit, followed by Four Horses and San Cha Three. I treated him for two years, during which time his skin discontinued coloring after cupping, his scleroderma improved by 70%, and he began a full-time job that precluded him from continuing treatment. •  Tinnitus: Low-pitch tinnitus is most frequently thought of as a Kidney-deficient condition. It tends to get worse when the patient is tired, and it may even stop once in a while. Tinnitus can be difficult to treat, and Kidney tonification does not always help. For these patients, it may be more effective to tonify Spleen qi and yang using Four Horses with A.04 San Cha Three and 22.05 Ling Gu. SI3 Hou Xi and/or SI19 Ting Gong may also be helpful. •  Scalp acupuncture: For very stubborn tinnitus, you can thread three needles vertically toward the ear (beginning 1.0 cun above the ear, needle three points, one in the center and two 0.5 cun to either side). This area is known in scalp acupuncture as the “area of hearing and understanding language.” It is very painful to needle because there are multiple blood vessels in this area, so downsize your needle gauge (I use Seirin 00/0.12mm x 30mm needles with dark green handles). •  Guiding Points: SI19 Ting Gong with SJ21 Er Men or SJ22 Er He Liao can be needled on the same side as Guiding Points. •  Tinnitus in TCM: Interesting information is found in Applied Channel Theory in Chinese Medicine by Dr. Wang Ju-Yi and Jason Robertson (2008): “The relationship of the Kidney to the ears is often misunderstood and sometimes leads to ineffective clinical treatment. Classical references should be placed in the context of the Kidney’s relationship to growth, development and decline through the stages of life. In short, the Kidney is most often related to hearing problems in the elderly, when the Kidney essence is thought to wane … generally this is low-pitched tinnitus that is often worse in the afternoon or when the patient is tired. Note: Excess type tinnitus is high-pitched and often more acute ... it often involves problems with dampness or heat in the fluids of the ear. Use points on the Shao Yang meridian to dredge and drain.” •  Formulas (Dr. Young): The classic formula Yi Qi Cong Ming Tong is very useful in the treatment of tinnitus and consists of Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tong with Man Jing Zi, Ge Gen, Dang Shen and Sheng Ma. In China, doctors inject Ge Gen at SI19 to treat tinnitus. •  Other ear disorders: For ear pain, otitis media, hearing loss or sudden deafness, Four Horses with A.04 San Cha Three may be useful due to the Hand and Foot Shao Yang relationship. Other options might include bleeding the small veins surrounding the outside ankle between the lateral malleoli and GB39, bleeding 11.26 Control Dirt or bleeding LU5. For sudden hearing loss, we might include bilateral needling of 77.18 Shen Guan or 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. Bleeding 1010.07 All Pivot (Tung’s DU16) or needling the three points anterior to the ear (GB2, SI19, SJ21) might also be useful in these cases. For treating otitis media, usually I choose 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles and A.04 San Cha Three on the side opposite the indications, with same-side 22.06 Zhong Bai or SI3 Hou Xi as a Guiding Point. •  Red sclera: Because the Lungs govern the sclera, Four Horses can also treat eyes that are red due to Lung heat. Bleeding 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) or 99.08 Ear Apex is also an outstanding way to clear the eyes. Four Horses includes the specific indication of conjunctivitis. •  Fibromyalgia, multiple sclerosis, and muscle atrophy: We needle Four Horses with A.04 San Cha Three because of the muscle-treating-muscle principle, and because the Spleen governs muscles. Located very near the Stomach channel, in the large quadriceps muscles that have significant nerve and blood supplies, these points tonify Spleen qi, adjust the Spleen and Stomach, and can be very effective in the treatment of muscle weakness, fibromyalgia or multiple sclerosis. For the same reasons, you might also choose these points for hemiplegia, facial paralysis or spasm. •  Fibromyalgia: This condition is characterized by hypersensitivity of nerve endings. Because of this, if the patient is needle phobic, it is important to downsize needle gauge (I may use dark green handled Seirin needles 00/0.12mm). Cupping may be helpful for particularly inflamed muscles. However, three pumps are necessary to keep the suction on a cup, and that may be excruciating for the patient, so apply one small cup at a time. Liver stagnation causes fibromyalgia, which is especially exacerbated by stress. Treatment is directed toward soothing the Liver and opening stagnation, using LI4/LV3 Four Gates with GB41 Ling Qi and A.04 San Cha Three for whole-body pain. 66.07 Mu Liu can be added to regulate the Liver and tonify earth. 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with A.04 San Cha Three is another good treatment option. For fibromyalgia, my favorite formula by far is Xiao Yao Wan, with modifications. •  Multiple sclerosis: One way to diagnose multiple sclerosis (MS) is with IgG and IgA reactivity screening for myelin basic protein. If these counts are elevated, it is a likely indication of demyelination of the myelin sheath, which protects and insulates the nerve fibers surrounding the brain, spinal cord and optic nerves. MS can be temporary or permanent, depending upon the severity and location of the scars that interrupt nerve impulses to the brain. Early signs include heaviness, numbness, tingling and/or electrical sensations in the hands or legs. TCM recognizes a few typical patterns, made obvious through following the signs and symptoms. Spleen dampness is a common cause of circulatory obstruction, especially when combined with any kind of dampness in the external environment. Poor habits that weaken the power of the Liver and Kidneys are frequently seen, causing poor circulation and weakness in the legs, dizziness, vertigo, blurred vision or urinary incontinence, to name a few symptoms. By far the best prevention is a good diet that includes organic foods and excludes caffeine, alcohol, trans fats, cold foods, dairy products and genetically modified foods. Also, proper exercise, sleep and rest are essential in returning MS patients to full health. Following are suggestions for treating MS with Tung’s acupuncture: •  Treatment: The basic principle is to tonify the Spleen and Kidneys, detoxify the liver and brain, and strengthen nerves, tendons and muscles. Treatment should focus on 77.18 Shen Guan or 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors with GB34 Yang Ling Quan, or 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with A.04 San Cha Three. If it is difficult for the patient to extend their muscles, add 22.05 Ling Gu and 66.04 Fire Master (Tung’s LV3). If there is numbness, add 77.05-77.07 Three Weights with 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/Wood Scoop to wake up the brain and circulate the blood. Though individual herbs must be prescribed, Shao Yao Gan Cao plus Ge Gen is useful in softening tense or hard muscles; it will cause a soft stool, so it should be used to bowel tolerance. People with a damp Spleen may have a soft stool already; however, constipation can also be an issue when nerve conduction is sufficiently interrupted. •  Afterbirth wind (Dr. Lee): “In particular, I like to use Four Horses for the treatment of post-partum invasion of external cold, causing joint pain. Since these points are on the Stomach channel, they treat a wide range of diseases, especially those having to do with the Heart” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Thoracic pain: Four Horses is very effective for breast pain and chest pain, including chest pain due to injury, especially if the pain moves from the front to the sides. Because the points are found between the Shao Yang and Yang Ming channels, Four Horses treats breast and chest pain related to Yang Ming, but also treats pain that migrates to the side, relating to Shao Yang. Due to the Shao Yang connection, these points can be used bilaterally or unilaterally, for opposite-side pain of the upper back, chest, abdomen, rib, and intercostal or flank pain. Opposite-side needling is appropriate for hemiplegia, especially if there are also Lung or Liver conditions. •  Breast cancer: For breast cancer, needle 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/Wood Scoop and bleed Four Horses (Dr. Young).
combinations: Asthma: Bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses; 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai; 22.11 Earth Water (Tung’s LU10); 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through; needle or bleed 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5). If severe, bleed: 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5); 77.09 Four Flower Middle; 77.14 Four Flower Outer. Bleed UB42-UB43, UB13, DU14 every 7-10 days, needle 2-3 times a week. If the thighs are cold, moxa SP10 Xue Hai. If the chin is red, deeply needle (60mm needle) 77.08 Four Flower Upper (ST36); if the chin is green, bilaterally needle 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through. •  Cold/flu, sinusitis, allergies: Bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, A.04 San Cha Three and 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20) as Guiding Points; optional 11.17 Wood (Anger). See Commentary above for further options. •  Chronic cough: Bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, A.04 San Cha Three, 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through. •  Tuberculosis: Bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 22.11 Earth Water (Tung’s LU10); bleed 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line. •  Pleuritis: Bleed 77.08-77.14 Four Flower Line; bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with 1010.19-1010.20 Water Gold/Water Through. •  Chest contusion: Needle bilaterally or on the opposite side: 88.17-88.19 Four Horses to regulate lung and qi; PC6 Nei Guan, 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy to open the chest; if severe, bleed 77.09 Four Flower Middle; if acute, add 88.28 Release (Tung’s ST34), the Xi-Cleft Point that regulates qi and blood. •  Chest pain involving the back: Needle bilaterally or on the opposite side: 88.17-88.19 Four Horses; 77.18 Shen Guan; 22.03 Shang Bai; 22.01-22.02 Double Child/Double Fairy; 22.06 Zhong Bai (treats pain around the back of the heart). •  Sinus: Bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20) as Guiding Points; 44.06 Shoulder Center; 11.17 Wood (Anger) proximal point; 33.07 Fire Bowels Sea (Tung’s LI10); unilaterally needle 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43). Rhinitis: Bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with 88.01 Passing Gate and 88.03 Passing Heaven (relates to Heart and Lung). •  Itchy allergies (sinus): Needle left-side 11.17 Wood (Anger); bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, A.04 San Cha Three, 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20). •  Nasal dryness: Needle 11.17 Wood (Anger); bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses. •  Polyps: Bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, A.04 San Cha Three, 1010.15 Welcome Fragrance (LI20). •  Deafness or tinnitus: Bleed LU5 Qu Chi; bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 22.05 Ling Gu; A.04 San Cha Three, 22.05 Ling Gu; 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) and SI19 Ting Gong as a Guiding Point. For Kidney-deficient type: 22.06-22.07 Zhong Bai/ Xia Bai, 22.09 Wrist Prosperous Two, 22.05 Ling Gu, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), GB41 Ling Qi, GB42 Di Wu Hui, 88.12 Bright Yellow. •  Sudden hearing loss (in addition to the points listed above for deafness and tinnitus, consider the following points for Kidney deficiency): Bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, 88.32 Lost Voice, the three points in front of the ear (GB2, SI19, SJ21); bleed 1010.07 All Pivot (Tung’s DU16). •  Deaf-mutism: Bleed 77.07 Third Weight; needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses (Dr. Young). •  Ear nerve pain: Needle opposite-side 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31); bleed 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles; bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, A.04 San Cha Three. •  Skin allergies: Cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas; bleed 99.07 Ear Back; bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses (see Needling Notes), A.04 San Cha Three; patient should avoid consuming shrimp, egg whites, chicken, sugar and dairy. •  Psoriasis/eczema: Cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas; bleed 99.07 Ear Back; needle: 88.17-88.19 Four Horses (see Needling Notes), A.04 San Cha Three; LI11 Qu Chi, SP10 Xue Hai; Bai Chong Wo (Extra Point); 77.21 Man Emperor (Tung’s SP6), 11.17 Wood (Anger); boil eucalyptus leaves and wash the skin. For psoriasis on the hands, bilaterally needle 11.17 Wood (Anger). •  Acne: Cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas; bleed 99.07 Ear Back; needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses (see Needling Notes), A.04 San Cha Three; LI11 Qu Chi, SP10 Xue Hai; 77.21 Man Emperor (Tung’s SP6); 11.17 Wood (Anger), boil eucalyptus leaves and wash the skin. If severe, bleed DU14, UB13, UB15 to clear heat; the patient should eat less sugar, especially chocolate, and no oily or spicy foods. The patient should eat more fruit and vegetables, wash the face often, avoid staying out late, and avoid sunlight because the heat worsens acne. Daily bowel movements are important to remove toxins from the blood. •  Itching and rashes: Cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas; bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses (see Needling Notes); sedate LI11 Qu Chi and SP10 Xue Hai; Bai Chong Wo (Extra Point). •  Neck rashes: Needle bilaterally or on the side opposite the indications: 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 44.06 Shoulder Center; bleed 99.08 Ear Apex. •  Urticaria (hives): Cup the navel; bleed 99.07 Ear Back or 99.08 Ear Apex; bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, A.04 San Cha Three; optionally add 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31). The patient should avoid consuming egg whites. •  Shingles: Bleed 99.08 Ear Apex, bleed 11.26 Control Dirt, bleed 77.14 Four Flower Outer (ST40); bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses. For post-herpetic pain, to release the virus from the nerve endings, seven-star hammer (never before the scabs have fallen off). •  Rib pain that has moved from the chest to the sides: Needle bilaterally or on the opposite side: 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 33.04 Fire Threaded (SJ6), GB34 Yang Ling Quan. •  Intercostal pain: Needle opposite-side 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, with 66.09 Water Curve (GB41) on the same side as the pain. •  Back pain on both sides: Bleed UB40 Wei Zhong (any vein in the popliteal crease); bilaterally needle SI3 Hou Xi with UB65 Shu Gu; 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with 22.01 Double Child, 88.11 Passing Back, 77.04 Catching Ball (Tung’s UB57). •  Fibromyalgia: See 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, Comments. •  Multiple sclerosis: See 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, Comments. •  Leg numbness: To tonify qi, bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with bilateral or opposite-side 44.06 Shoulder Center. •  Hyperthyroid: For shaky, nervous, sweating, hungry wind disease, open the Four Gates (LI4/LV3) to soothe the Liver: bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses with 88.12 Bright Yellow; 88.12-88.14 Three Yellows with 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31); bilaterally needle or bleed 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold. •  Goiter: Bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses; bilaterally needle or bleed 77.05-77.07 Three Weights or 77.24-77.25 Leg Five/One Thousand Gold. •  Deviation of the mouth: Bleed 77.07 Third Weight; needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 88.09 Passing Kidney (Dr. Young). •  Facial twitch: Needle bilaterally or on the opposite side: 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles, 22.04 Da Bai, SI3 Hou Xi. Opposite-side treatments are usually applied, unless the problem is chronic. I have found the formula Tian Ma Gou Teng Yin to be enormously helpful, with symptoms abating within two or three doses; however, the patient should continue taking the herbs for at least 4-5 days. They should avoid caffeine and alcohol. •  Chest or abdominal pain: Needle opposite-side 88.17-88.19 Four Horses; unilaterally needle 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4), PC6 Nei Guan. For abdominal pain, needle SP4 first, followed by PC6. For chest pain, needle PC6 first to direct the treatment to the chest, followed by SP4. •  Lateral lower abdominal pain (between ST and GB channels): Needle 22.05 Ling Gu; SJ5 Wai Guan; PC6 Nei Guan; 88.17-88.19 Four Horses. Though any of the previous points might be used, I am unlikely to employ them. I would choose opposite-side 66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), with unilateral 66.11 Fire Chrysanthemum (SP4) and PC6 Nei Guan. •  Breast cancer: Needle 66.06-66.07 Wood Keep/Wood Scoop; bleed 88.17-88.19 Four Horses (Dr. Young), but only if you see good blood vessels in this area. •  Conjunctivitis: Bilaterally needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses; bleed same-side 99.07 Ear Back or 99.08 Ear Apex or Tai Yang (Extra Point). •  Heel pain: Needle bilateral or opposite-side 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, Hand Heel Points (PC7 and one additional point 1.0 cun distal)

name: Xiaquan, Lower Fountain (T 88.20)
location: This point is on the GB channel, 2.5 cun proximal to the center of the knee joint along the midline of the lateral thigh. | Johnson: Three Fountains are located on the lateral side of the thigh: 88.20 Lower Fountain is located 2.5 cun (three and a half fingers) above the knee crease. 88.21 Middle Fountain is located 2.0 cun (three fingers) proximal to Lower Fountain. 88.22 Upper Fountain is located 2.0 cun proximal to Middle Fountain.
primary_indications: deviation of the eyes and mouth
techniques: Needle 1 -2 cun on healthy side. | Johnson: Dao Ma: Lower Fountain with 88.21 Middle Fountain and 88.22 Upper Fountain are known as 88.20-88.22 Three Fountains. For one-sided issues, needle on the side opposite the indications. Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Three Fountains points are located on the Gallbladder channel and can be used to treat wind-related disorders such as Bell’s palsy and eye twitch, although I would usually choose 77.05-77.07 Three Weights over these points. Three Fountains points are better for treating hysterical paralysis or attack by wind than for true neurological conditions. Facial paralysis and numbness (Dr. Lee): “These points treat facial paralysis and numbness, not pain or neuralgia. Mostly women get this problem due to nervousness. A woman came for treatment of facial numbness and paralysis of one side of her face. She was married and had a son. Because of the educational opportunities here in America, she and her husband had decided to send their son to school in the United States. However, her husband had to stay in Hong Kong to take care of their family business. Therefore, this woman divided her time between Hong Kong and the United States. When she was in America with her son, she worried terribly about her husband in Hong Kong. When she was in Hong Kong with her husband, she worried terribly about her son. I treated this woman for two years off and on. Because she could never stop worrying, she could only get partial relief from her condition” (Dr. Lee, 1992)

name: Zhongquan, Middle Fountain (T 88.21)

name: Jinqianxia, Gold Front Lower (T 88.23)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 1 cun superior to the superior lateral corner of the patella. | Johnson: 88.23 Gold Front Lower and 88.24 Gold Front Upper are located on the same line as 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, on a line extending up from the lateral corner of the patella. •  88.23 Gold Front Lower is 1.0 cun proximal to the lateral edge of the patella. •  88.24 Gold Front Upper is 1.5 cun (2 fingers) proximal to Gold Front Lower.
primary_indications: Lung deficiency and Liver weakness patterns Protrusion of the sternum
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . | Johnson: Dao Ma: 88.23 Gold Front Lower is combined with 88.24 Gold Front Upper for all indications. •  Needle bilaterally. •  Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Gold Front Lower and Gold Front Upper have the Reaction Areas of the Liver and Lung, so they regulate qi and blood and disperse wind, treating epilepsy, skin allergies, headaches and other wind conditions. •  Rickets: These points uniquely treat protrusion of the manubrium due to rickets. Rickets arises due to a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium or phosphorus, leading to softening of the bones and abnormal bone growth during childhood.

name: Jinqianshang, Gold Front Upper (T 88.24)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 2.5 cun superior to the superior lateral corner of the patella or 1.5 cun superior to Jinqianxia (T 88.23) . | Johnson: 88.23 Gold Front Lower and 88.24 Gold Front Upper are located on the same line as 88.17-88.19 Four Horses, on a line extending up from the lateral corner of the patella. •  88.23 Gold Front Lower is 1.0 cun proximal to the lateral edge of the patella. •  88.24 Gold Front Upper is 1.5 cun (2 fingers) proximal to Gold Front Lower.
