name: Zhongjiuli, Center Nine Miles (T 88.25)
location: This point overlaps with Fengshi (GB 31) , which is at the center of the median line of the lateral thigh. | Johnson: Center Nine Miles is located 9 cun proximal to the popliteal crease on the lateral aspect of the thigh. This is the same location as textbook GB31 Wind Market.42 Name indicates location: Master Tung’s use of the name Center Nine Miles for GB31 reflects the fact that it is located halfway between the popliteal crease and the tip of the greater trochanter of the femur, a distance of 18 cun. Tip for easier point location: Because the popliteal crease is not visible when the patient is lying on their back, I always look for this point 8 cun (four fingers twice, plus three fingers) proximal to the top of the patella on the Gallbladder meridian. For the most powerful effect, palpate for the most sensitive point. 42 Many textbooks locate GB31 Wind Market by measuring 7.0 cun above the popliteal crease. This is where we find A.01 Qi Li (GB32), the next point in this book. 413 Thigh Points Note: Some TCM sources advise practitioners to locate GB31 by having the patient extend their arm to the side of their leg. I find this to be an unreliable way to find this point because of the wide variety in the lengths of people’s arms, as well as the fact that most patients are lying down with a bolster beneath their knees during treatment.
primary_indications: numbness and pain of the arms
secondary_indications: weakness of the nerves Severe itching
johnson_indications: Mental disorders including schizophrenia, bipolar, depression, etc.*
Pain in any of the following areas: upper, middle or lower back; spine; leg; thigh; sole of the foot; ear; eye; brow*
Numbness of the legs and back*
Peripheral neuropathy and/or numbness of the extremities*
Lymphedema as a result of breast cancer surgery*
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . | Johnson: Dao Ma: Center Nine Miles (GB31) is frequently added to many other point combinations due to its versatility and powerful ability to dispel internal and external wind. It may be needled as the Chief Point in two different Tung Dao Ma combinations. The most frequently used Dao Ma is GB31 needled with the Supplementary Point found 2.0 cun distal, A.01 Seven Miles (GB32). GB31 also may be needled with two Supplementary Points found 1.5 cun anterior and posterior, 88.26 Upper Nine Miles and 88.27 Lower Nine Miles; this Dao Ma pattern is named 88.25- 88.27 Three Nine Miles. Opposite-side vs. bilateral needling: Needle GB31 on the side opposite the indications to treat one-sided pathology, especially for the arm and head; otherwise, it may be needled bilaterally. •  Needle length: This point is best needled deeply enough that you can gently tap the femur, adding a stronger bone-treating-bone Kidney tonification effect. •  Depth: 0.8-2.0 cun
comments: GB31 is a favorite of Dr. Young: Dr. Young says that if you are not sure which point to choose, needle GB31, one of Master Tung’s favorite points. Interestingly, Dr. Lee said that if you don’t know what to do, needle ST36. Both GB31 and ST36 address a wide range of conditions. If you can find a point that directly targets a painful area, use it. If there is no direct avenue or if there is pain in multiple areas of the body, choose GB31. •  Energetic pathways: Center Nine Miles is found at the same location as GB31 Feng Shi, also known as Wind Market. It simultaneously adjusts the Spleen, Liver and Kidney because it is located on the Gallbladder channel in large muscle with ample blood and nerve supply (muscle treats muscle/SP), is needled through the IT band (tendon treats tendon/LV), and is deeply needled until the needle gently taps the femur (bone treats bone/KD). •  Shao Yang pathway: Because the Gallbladder channel wraps around the head, GB31 is an excellent choice for issues related to the upper body and head. It is very effective in the treatment of headaches, migraines, vertigo, tinnitus, mental disorders and insomnia due to Liver and Kidney deficiency. •  Pain and paralysis: Because wood governs wind and Shao Yang controls bone, Center Nine Miles disperses wind, tranquilizes the nervous system, relieves pain all over the body and calms the spirit. It can be used to treat any kind of pain, paralysis, nerve damage or weakness. Symptoms that move around or worsen with weather changes are characteristic of wind conditions and present the perfect situation in which to add GB31 Wind Market. •  One-sided pathology or movable pain: We can use opposite-side GB31 for trigeminal neuralgia, facial paralysis, hemiplegia, pain in the hip, leg, arm or ear, or any other kind of one-sided pathology. If a patient does not know the location of the pain, or if the pain moves around (indicating wind in the channels), use Center Nine Miles (GB31) with A.01 (GB32); 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles; or 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles. •  Bone spurs and bone disorders: Because Shao Yang (GB) controls bones, with GB39 Xuan Zhong as the Sea of Marrow point, GB31 is used in the treatment of bone diseases and spurs, including those of the spine, knee and heel. It is directly opposite 88.12 Bright Yellow, which is also indicated for bone spurring. See 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One (SI3) for bone spur protocols Hemiplegia from stroke: Stroke patients may come to you immediately following their stroke or some years later. Chronic hemiplegia is more difficult to treat and is often a combination of deficiency and severe stagnation. Acute hemiplegia from stroke is most frequently due to phlegm obstructing the brain. Treatment for hemiplegia is far more successful when it starts immediately. If it is the patient’s first stroke, and treatment begins within six months, full recovery is a real possibility. Massage and physical therapy are an essential part of recovery, yet it is difficult for patients to get enough physical therapy, both professionally and with help from family members, to regain full mobility. With daily acupuncture treatment and proper movement therapies, I usually can get acute stroke patients walking within three weeks of when they begin treatment. Work hard, reduce your fee, and treat the patient at least three times a week, as this will affect the rest of their life. For the heavy lifting involved in treating a stroke patient, be sure someone else is with you or the patient has a family member present. If the patient is older than 65 or if it is their second stroke, their condition will be more difficult to treat and will require herbs as well as acupuncture. If the stroke occurred more than five years prior to treatment, it is unlikely that you will be able to restore their functioning. •  Emotional and spiritual role of the practitioner: Depression is a common problem for stroke patients as well as family members who are their caregivers. Every attempt must be made to overcome lethargy and discouragement in order to get the patient out of their chair and back on their feet. Sobering and encouraging conversations must be faced, even if they are difficult. I recently had one of these challenging conversations with a stroke patient who was resisting her partner’s suggestions. It was necessary for me to point out that even though she had lost control over most of her activities, she was not going to secure her recovery or her future residence by saying, “Don’t tell me what to do” or “You’re not the boss of me,” because both the patient and her partner were elderly. This conversation reinforced the fact that all those concerned, including me, were working for her highest good. As a result, she let go of her stubbornness, reconnected with her partner from her heart, and achieved greater improvements in the following week than she had in the previous five months. Her partner was elated, as hope was restored for the patient and their future together. Remember that in these circumstances, caregivers are seriously challenged by the continual drain of patient care, loss of their own autonomy, and diminishing hope in terms of recovery. My standard stroke treatment: Although acupuncture treatment is generally given on the side opposite the symptoms, I usually start by carefully needling 11.10 Wood Fire bilaterally. Because Wood Fire raises blood pressure, and a stroke usually involves high blood pressure, it is vital that you precisely follow the needling protocol. Please see 11.10 Wood Fire, Cautions for detailed needling instructions. •  Scalp acupuncture: On the side of the head where the stroke occurred (opposite from the hemiplegia), thread needles down the Motor and Sensory Lines (these are more like zones than lines), being sure to cross over the central sulcus and needling toward a line that extends from GB1 and GB2. Now place three or four additional needles, side by side, from 1010.05 Anterior Meeting (DU21) to 1010.06 Posterior Meeting (DU19), or vice versa (DU19-DU21), straight through 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20). These needles will awaken the brain and stimulate the lower part of the body and urinary bladder. Next, I move laterally down the side of the head, optionally placing several needles parallel to those on top, crossing and connecting the Motor and Sensory Lines at the levels of the head, shoulder, arm, hand, thumb and fingers. Please note that the further you descend, the more sensitive the patient will be to your needles (see discussion about aphasia, below) , so you may choose to work with only particular areas on any given day. Though I thread needles nearly the entire length of both the Motor and Sensory Lines/areas, I do not add connecting/crossing needles all the way along these lines; instead, I focus on specific areas. (Connecting at all of the levels mentioned above would involve far too many needles and would be too painful.) The patient should retain these scalp needles for the duration of the treatment. Stimulate them regularly while moving the affected arm and leg. •  Opposite-side treatment for lower extremity: With the patient sitting in their wheelchair, on the side opposite the hemiplegia, needle 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/ Da Bai with strong qi. While stimulating the scalp points on the very top of the head, ask the patient to stomp their foot, instigating the movement with their mind if they are unable to move their leg. If they are able to stomp their own foot, ask an assistant to support the back of their knee while they move their leg, so they do not tire too easily. If they are unable to lift their leg and stomp their foot, a family member or assistant should do it for them while you aggressively stimulate the scalp needles. Rest and repeat several times or every 10 minutes. •  Transferring the patient to a table: If at all possible, I help the patient to move to a treatment table, allowing for the needling of GB31 and GB32 for the upper extremity treatment. Depending upon the patient’s coordination, I may need to remove the hand needles so that the muscles are not injured during the transfer. After the patient is on the table and I have performed the treatment for the upper extremity (described below), Ling Gu/Da Bai may be replaced. •  Opposite-side treatment for upper extremity: After doing the treatment described above for the lower extremity (including stomping), as the patient lies on a treatment table, needle opposite-side 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) with A.01 Seven Miles (GB32), again using strong stimulation. Have the patient move their arm, or if they cannot do so, ask a family member to move it for them while you stimulate the Motor and Sensory scalp needles along with those connecting at the level of the shoulder, arm or hand. Be sure to move the patient’s entire shoulder girdle in both directions as if they are throwing a ball, and then reverse the motion. Rest and repeat these arm movements several times. If needed, support the patient during this movement so that they will not overdo it and strain their muscles. Once the Gallbladder points have been needled and the arm movements have been made in several rounds, then add movements of the affected leg (including knee to chest, then internal and external rotation), followed by the arm movements; move both the arm and the leg, one after the other, approximately every ten minutes (set a timer) for the duration of the treatment. If your schedule allows you to spend more time with the patient, stimulate the associated needles as you move the limbs. If the patient cannot be moved to a table: 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles (Tung’s GB34) may be substituted for GB31 and GB32; however, these points are more specifically related to tendons and ligaments, whereas Center Nine Miles (GB31) has a much greater capacity to impact the brain, including in the treatment of stroke. •  Aphasia: If the patient is having trouble speaking, you may also cross the Motor and Sensory Lines at the level of the tongue; however, needling this area will be extraordinarily painful for the patient, so either downsize to Seirin “00”/0.12mm x 30mm needles or leave these points out. •  Bleeding 1010.07 All Pivot (Tung’s DU15-DU16) and/or the blood vessels underneath the tongue can also be useful for tongue paralysis. •  Duration of treatment: Treating a stroke patient can take a long time, not only because they move more slowly and laboriously, but also because there are so many components to the treatment. Be sure the patient is well hydrated and has excellent blood sugar before you begin. As is clear in the overall treatment protocol described above, it is important that you have assistance with physically moving the patient, especially because once the needles are placed and the patient is prone, someone else can take over moving the patient’s limbs for the next 30-40 minutes while you work with another patient. Additional bleeding treatment options: Most stroke patients are taking blood thinners; however, this does not mean their blood will not clot. If anything, it makes our bleeding techniques slightly more productive and therefore more effective. •  To clear the brain: Bleed 99.08 Ear Apex on the side opposite the hemiplegia (bleeding the same side where the stroke occurred within the brain). •  If the blood pressure is high: Bleed the Jing-Well points (I prefer bleeding the fingertips, being sure to hold them lower than the heart and “milking” the fingers); bleed 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) and UB40 Wei Zhong; or bleed DT.04 Five Mountain Range. Bleeding veins found on the Stomach or Gallbladder channels also reduces blood pressure. •  For phlegm accumulation: Bleed 77.14 Four Flower Outer (ST40/phlegm gathering point) to dissolve phlegm, move blood and clear stagnation. •  Bamboo cupping: Bamboo cupping is a bleeding technique that utilizes small three- to four-inch sections of bamboo, which are boiled and placed over small puncture sites. (Please see Bamboo Cupping on my DVD set, The Ancient Art of Cupping.) It is particularly effective for nerve damage or prolonged paralysis resulting in extreme blood stagnation. I used to watch Dr. Lee bamboo-cup stroke patients all the way down the Large Intestine channel on the arm and the Gallbladder channel on the leg. This treatment is especially helpful in a chronic case, when the patient has been immobile for more than six months. With any kind of bleeding treatment, be sure the patient has good blood sugar and is well rested before and after the procedure. In the right situation, bamboo cupping is invaluable. Of note, bamboo cupping is also my primary treatment for ankylosing spondylitis (see 77.01-77.02 Correct Tendons for further information). Additional needling options (in no particular order): Acute stroke that has just occurred: Needle 22.01-22.02 Double Child/ Double Fairy on the side opposite the brain bleed; needle or bleed 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5) on the same side, to sedate. •  Brain circulation: Needle 77.05-77.07 Three Weights to increase circulation to the brain. Needling on the same side as the brain bleed treats the affected arm. However, bleeding on the same side (dark veins found in the area of Three Weights) helps to clear blood stagnation in the brain. I may choose to needle Three Weights bilaterally to treat the whole brain and the arm, but you will need to decide for yourself what is best for your patient. •  Late-stage treatment: In addition to using the standard protocol, also bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors to tonify the Kidneys. With long-term paralysis, avoid the use of too many needles. Bleeding techniques are a great alternative in cases of long-term blood stagnation. Formulas: Dr. Young taught me to modify Bu Yang Huan Wu Tang for stroke. This formula is used for early-stage stroke, to move the qi and vitalize the blood. If constipation is an issue, add Rou Cong Rong (cistanche) and Suo Yang (cynomorium). If the blood pressure is not high, gradually increase the Huang Qi up to 50 grams. If there is hypertension, add Sang Ji Sheng and fried Du Zhong. Also, Di Huang Yin Zi is used to tonify Kidney yin and yang, astringe essence and open the orifices. Herbs such as Du Zhong and Huai Niu Xi can be added to subsequent formulas to tonify the Liver and Kidneys. I also like Hua Tou Zai Zao Wan for cerebral vascular issues or coronary heart disease. It is very effective in treating angina, but it does not prolong clotting time, so it is okay to take with blood thinners (which are typically prescribed). I also recommend high doses of emulsified turmeric, CoQ10 or PQQ, and Omega 3 in the form of krill oil, not fish oil (krill is lower on the food chain, so it carries less mercury). Liu Wei Di Huang (Six Ingredients) tonifies the Kidneys (as long as the patient can digest it; do not use if the patient has Spleen dampness/teeth marks). In acute stroke, if the patient has a feeding tube, you can use it to administer herbs directly into the stomach. •  Dietary recommendations: Because stroke patients are not moving, it is imperative that their nutrition is good. Calories must be spent on healthy fats and proteins, while sugars and simple carbohydrates must be avoided as much as possible. Do not pamper disabled patients with treats like alcohol, caffeine or sugar, because these would hamper their recovery. Fresh fruits and vegetables and non-processed foods are always best. Patients should not overeat, as extra weight would make it harder for them to move. •  Insomnia: Chronic insomnia (over five years) can lead to blood stagnation and the breakdown of communication between the Heart and Kidney. The treatment principle is to tonify Kidney yin, sedate Liver fire, dissolve phlegm, vitalize blood, and re-establish the Heart and Kidney connection. Trouble falling asleep is due to blood deficiency or Liver qi stagnation; trouble staying asleep is due to Liver and Kidney yin deficiency creating Liver yang rising. Patients who frequently awaken between 1:00–3:00 a.m. have Liver qi congestion; those who are awake for hours have Liver-related insomnia. If a patient is asleep and suddenly wakes up, it is due to empty Gallbladder. To address tossing and turning, restless or uncomfortable sleep, we can use the special relationship between the Hand Jue Yin and Foot Yang Ming (PC/ST) to tonify the Heart and calm the spirit. Dr. Young considers Center Nine Miles (GB31) the best point for Liver/Kidney-deficient insomnia, as well as insomnia due to Heart yang deficiency, for all of the above reasons and also due to the special relationship between the Hand Shao Yin (HT) and Foot Shao Yang (GB). Treatment options for insomnia: •  Needle 1010.08 Tranquility (Yin Tang); bilaterally needle Jian Gu (Extra Point), 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors (excellent for insomnia caused by Kidney yin deficiency) and 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31). •  Jian Gu (Extra Point): I learned Jian Gu from Dr. Young and have found it very useful. It is located by palpating the second metacarpal bone between 22.04 Da Bai (Great White) and 22.05 Ling Gu (Spirit Bone) to find the most sensitive point. I use a 0.15 x 16mm needle or a Koryo Hand Therapy needle pellet aligned with the metacarpal bone. As long as it does not get wet, a needle pellet can be retained overnight and removed by the patient the following day. •  Because of LV3 Tai Chong, the classic Four Gates combination (LI4/LV3) has a digestive function related to the earth element. When treating anxiety-type insomnia, we can use Anxiety Four Gates, a point combination of LI3 with LV2, for an effect more related to Ying-Spring fire. This combination was taught to me by Dr. Young to treat insomnia due to Liver and Kidney deficiency. To Anxiety Four Gates, 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors and 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) may be added. Additional insomnia options: •  Bleed 99.07 Ear Back or 99.08 Ear Apex for acute sleep issues due to Liver qi stagnation causing fire (Liver yang rising). These points can be bled safely once every four to five days. •  Needle the Prefrontal Scalp Points. •  Needle left-side 11.17 Wood (Anger). •  Needle 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20), especially with 1010.08 Tranquility. •  To treat insomnia with dreamful sleep, bilaterally needle HT7 Shen Men with GB44 Qiao Yin (Dr. Young). •  Insomnia formulas/dietary advice: Huang Lian, E Jiao, Egg Yolk Tang is a good formula for sleep. Drinking milk with egg yolk (no whites) is tranquilizing. Golden needles (dried day lily buds) are eaten for insomnia, and also to alleviate cough. Basic treatment principles for insomnia are to soothe the Liver fire, dissolve phlegm, vitalize blood and restore communication between Heart and Kidneys. Tian Wang Bu Xin Dan is used for deficiency of blood and vital essence of the Heart and Kidneys. For chronic insomnia, vitalize blood to dissolve stagnation with Xue Fu Zhu Yu Tang, or by combining Si Ni San with Tao Hong Si Wu Tang. People who have irritability from severe Liver qi stagnation, and who wake up between 1:00–3:00 a.m. (frequently extending to 3:30 a.m.), always respond best to a modified Xiao Yao Wan taken in high doses before bed. •  Response to trauma (Dr. Lee): “If a patient has had a traumatic injury such as falling from a ladder, treatment may alleviate the physical pain. But, in cases of PTSD the patient continues to suffer nightmares and other psychological disturbances, even though the physical trauma has healed. In these cases, use Center Nine Miles (GB31) or GB34 Yang Ling Quan to relieve the fear and trembling due to ‘empty’ Gallbladder” (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Itching and wind: In Chapter 74 of the Su Wen, it says, “All pain, itching and skin disorders arise from the Heart.” Because we understand that the perception of pain comes from the spirit, and in Chinese medicine the spirit is said to be stored in the Heart, we also recognize the special relationship between the Foot Shao Yang (GB) and Hand Shao Yin (HT) in relation to pain and itching. Does itching cause shen disturbance, or does shen disturbance, with the movement of wind, cause itching? This is like asking, “Which came first, the chicken or the egg?” Center Nine Miles, with its extraordinary capacity to expel wind and calm the spirit, is highly effective in treating all kinds of itching. I usually choose 88.17-88.19 Four Horses for itching because of the points’ proximity to GB31. If the itching is related to sinus conditions or an allergic response, Four Horses are utilizing not only the Gallbladder channel’s ability to dispel wind, but also their connection to the Lung (skin) and the Liver (blood). In extreme cases, we can combine GB31 with Four Horses and A.04 San Cha Three. See 88.17-88.19 Four Horses for further information. •  Migraines: Center Nine Miles (GB31) was one of Master Tung’s most commonly selected points. It treats whole-head headaches and migraines because it opens the Spleen, Liver, Kidney and all three Jiao, disperses wind, tranquilizes and relieves pain. Generally speaking, migraine headaches can be considered reoccurring severe headaches that are frequently accompanied by vomiting, light sensitivity, visual changes and extreme pain. Each person’s migraines involve different kinds of triggers: food allergies, hormones, chemical sensitivities, stress levels and sleep deprivation; but in my opinion, unexpressed anger is always a common denominator. Based on more than thirty years of experience, I offer the following advice for treating migraine headaches: •  Chronic migraines often include muscle spasms in the neck and shoulders that can result in the buildup of toxins. I may not cup a migraine patient during their initial visit, because I know the cups will be painful and I would prefer that the patient feel comfortable with me as a practitioner before I initiate such intense therapy. However, targeted and thorough cupping is definitely a part of my overall migraine treatment, and I prioritize it. Cupping the toxin areas, as well as the Shao Yang and Tai Yang areas of the neck, shoulders and upper back, is included. Sometimes cupping alone can resolve the worst type of headache, because when the muscles of the neck and shoulders are in spasm or full of toxin buildup, circulation to the head is blocked. Cupping pulls toxins out of the blood and draws freshly oxygenated blood into the head. If the patient also has severe TMJ, it is helpful to schedule a good time for face cupping. See 66.04 Fire Master for information about cupping the jaw for TMJ. Migraine treatment options: •  Center Nine Miles (GB31), needled on the opposite side or bilaterally, treats most points on the head and eliminates internal wind; it is particularly effective in treating temporal or parietal migraines. •  77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles (Tung’s GB34), are needled on the opposite side for Liver/Gallbladder headache related to tendons and ligaments, usually accompanied by neck and shoulder pain. •  22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai and Center Nine Miles (GB31) are effective for whole-head headache or headache on both sides. Tai Yang (Extra Point) bleeding is important in the treatment of chronic migraines, because it removes toxins and stagnation, clears the eyes, lowers blood pressure, calms the spirit and opens the mind. Be sure to find the artery in the temple area and avoid it. There are many uses for bleeding in this area. •  For nausea and vomiting due to migraine, bleed 1010.07 All Pivot to drop the stomach and stop vomiting. •  Bleeding 99.07 Ear Back or 99.08 Ear Apex clears wind heat from the head. •  66.05 Golden Gate (Tung’s ST43), needled unilaterally, is particularly helpful for Yang Ming channel migraines, especially frontal and temple types. If the headache is premenstrual, Golden Gate relieves the pain and quiets the womb (for cramping). •  66.12 Fire Scatter (KD2) may be needled (usually unilaterally) to treat migraines due to hypertension, because it harmonizes water and fire. This point is forbidden in pregnancy. •  Case history, leg and hip pain (Dr. Lee): “A 70-year-old woman arrived with leg and hip pain that was so severe she was in tears. She could not say exactly where the pain was since it seemed to move around. I treated 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles on the opposite side while she moved the affected leg. After the first treatment, the woman stopped crying and smiled. After three treatments her pain was eliminated entirely. This kind of moveable pain is caused by Gallbladder wind. If the patient suffers from this condition and you palpate opposite side 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) the patient will jump with pain” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Traumatic injury and being scared (nightmares and fear): Bilaterally needle 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), GB34 Yang Ling Quan. •  Moveable pain (caused by wind): Needle 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles. •  Hemiplegia: First, needle 11.10 Wood Fire (see needle cautions before needling this point), then needle Scalp Points, then needle opposite-side 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, transfer the patient to a table and needle 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), GB32 (A.01). See 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), Comments on hemiplegia. •  Bone disease: 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), GB34 Yang Ling Quan. •  Bone spurs: SI3 Hou Xi, UB65 Shu Gu, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), and either DU26 Ren Zhong or REN24 Cheng Jiang. Bleed UB40 Wei Zhong every two weeks. 88.12 Bright Yellow can also be used for bone spurs. See 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One (SI3), Comments. •  Heel spurs: 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles. •  Thigh pain: 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles, A.01 Qi Li; A.03 San Cha Two; A.04 San Cha Three; bleed DT.07; bleed DT.09. •  Sole of the foot pain or heat: 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, 11.27 Five Tiger Three. •  Spine pain: 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles. •  Arthritis in the legs: 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), GB32 (A.01); 44.06 Shoulder Center; A.04 San Cha Three; 22.05 Ling Gu. Drop foot: First, needle 11.10 Wood Fire (see needle cautions before needling this point), then 44.06 Shoulder Center, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) as a Guiding Point. •  Legs cold and painful: 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31); 44.06 Shoulder Center; 88.03 Passing Heaven, 88.10 Passing Stomach; 11.10 Wood Fire (see needle cautions before needling this point). •  Sudden leg weakness: 11.10 Wood Fire (see needle cautions before needling this point), 22.04-22.05 Ling Gu/Da Bai, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), A.01 Qi Li (GB32); 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors. •  Lymphedema: Needle on the opposite side: 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31), A.01 Seven Miles (GB32) and 33.16 Curve Mound (LU5). •  Epilepsy (excess type): Needle 55.06 Upper Tumor; deep needle 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle; bilaterally needle 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31); bilaterally bleed 77.08-77.09 Four Flower Upper/Four Flower Middle or 77.05-77.07 Three Weights. •  Epilepsy (deficient type): Bilaterally needle Dr. Miriam Lee’s Ten Great Needles Treatment (ST36, SP6, LU7, LI4, LI11); bilaterally needle 77.18-77.21 Two Emperors, 55.06 Upper Tumor, 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) or 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles; bilaterally needle 77.05-77.07 Three Weights. •  Eye tic: Needle opposite-side 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles with 77.18 Shen Guan, needle same-side SI3 Hou Xi as a Guiding Point; needle opposite-side 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) with KD7 Fu Liu, needle same-side SI3 Hou Xi as a Guiding Point. Eye tic is common after facial paralysis, especially if acupuncture has been done with electric stimulation. •  Tennis elbow (San Jiao channel): Needle opposite-side 77.22-77.23 Beside Three Miles or 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) with A.01 Qi Li (GB32), needle same-side A.04 San Cha Three or 22.06 Middle White (SJ3) as a Guiding Point. •  Tennis Elbow (Large Intestine channel): Needle opposite-side 33.07 Fire Bowels Sea (LI10), LI11 Qu Chi (needle both LI10 and LI11 just above the radius, sliding the shaft of the needle along the bone); needle same-side 22.04 Great White (Da Bai) or 22.05 Spirit Bone (Ling Gu) as a Guiding Point. •  Pain all over the body: Bilaterally needle 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) or 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles.

name: Shangjiuli, Upper Nine Miles (T 88.26)
location: This point is between the ST and GB channels, 1.5 cun anterior to Zhongjiuli (T 88.25) , which is on the GB channel at the midpoint of the midline of the lateral thigh. | Johnson: 88.26 Upper Nine Miles is located 1.5 cun (two fingers) anterior to 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31). 88.27 Lower Nine Miles is located 1.5 cun posterior to 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31).
primary_indications: Arm pain (HT channel) Abdominal distension (KI channel) from deficiency Eye pain
secondary_indications: vertebral pain Inability to raise arm due to shoulder pain
johnson_indications: Upper arm pain due to Heart
Thigh pain due to lack of blood flow (Lower Nine Miles)
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . | Johnson: Dao Ma (Three Nine Miles): Upper Nine Miles and Lower Nine Miles are needled with 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) as a three-point pattern. Alternatively, either 88.26 or 88.27 also could be needled with 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) as a two-point Dao Ma. Depth: 0.8-1.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: 88.26 Upper Nine Miles is located between the Stomach and Gallbladder meridians and has the Reaction Areas of Heart and Kidney. It is effective for treating arm pain, eye pain or abdominal distension due to Kidney deficiency. 88.27 Lower Nine Miles is located between the Urinary Bladder and Gallbladder meridians and has the Reaction Areas of Back and Legs. It is effective in the treatment of upper back and thigh pain, and of ischemia (poor blood flow) in the lower extremities. These points usually are needled bilaterally, but 88.25-88.27 Three Nine Miles also may be needled on the opposite side, along with opposite- side A.03 San Cha Two for one-sided leg pain. Needled on the opposite side, 88.27 Lower Nine Miles is very good for back pain found between T3 and T6 (Dr. Wang, 2013). See 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) for comments and combinations.

johnson_indications: Upper arm pain due to Heart
Thigh pain due to lack of blood flow (Lower Nine Miles)

Alternatively, either 88.26 or 88.27 also could be needled with 88.25 Center Nine Miles (GB31) as a two-point Dao Ma. Depth: 0.8-1.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: 88.26 Upper Nine Miles is located between the Stomach and Gallbladder meridians and has the Reaction Areas of Heart and Kidney. It is effective for treating arm pain, eye pain or abdominal distension due to Kidney deficiency. 88.27 Lower Nine Miles is located between the Urinary Bladder and Gallbladder meridians and has the Reaction Areas of Back and Legs. name: Jie, Release (T 88.28)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 1.5 cun superior and 0.3 cun medial to the superior lateral corner of the patella, near Liangqiu (ST 34) . | Johnson: This point is located in the depression 1.0 cun proximal and 0.3 cun lateral to the lateral/ proximal edge of the patella (1.0 cun distal to ST34 Liang Qiu).
primary_indications: swelling of needled area or lingering pain from acupuncture or injection
emotional trauma or exhaustion Black tinge on the face from toxin from overuse of medication or drugs Pain
soreness from excessive mental stimulation/stress or exhaustion
johnson_indications: Acute traumatic injury, strains and sprains*
Disturbance in the flow of qi and blood*
Dizziness, pain and/or swelling from acupuncture or injection*
Mental overstimulation leading to aching and pain
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun slowly and stimulate softly. Needle should be removed when pain is relieved. Do not retain the needles for more than 8 minutes. | Johnson: Retention time: Retain for approximately eight minutes if a traumatic injury occurred within the last forty-five minutes. Stuck needle: A needle will often appear to be stuck when its energetic work is not yet finished. If there is time to do so, leave the needle another ten minutes and then try removing it again. If there is not enough time, needle 88.28 Release to relax the muscle and easily remove the needle. Depth: 0.3-0.5 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: 88.28 Release shares the Xi-Cleft function of ST34 Liang Qiu. Xi- Cleft points are where qi and blood accumulate and are used to treat acute conditions and pain. 88.28 Release treats problems due to needling, including pain or swelling, difficulty removing a needle, a bent or broken needle, muscle not releasing the needle, or qi and blood going in the wrong direction from needling. Acute situations only: 88.28 Release treats acute injury, strains, sprains, joint pain or trauma. This point is not used for old or chronic injuries. Dizziness: 88.28 Release resolves dizziness after needling due to low blood sugar, fatigue, overeating, or excessive exercise. Have the patient lie down with their feet elevated, then needle this point. My patients are well trained to know that they should arrive for treatment with good blood sugar; however, I keep protein bars on hand for those requiring a boost in blood sugar. I always ask patients if they have eaten recently, especially before cupping, bleeding or strong needling. Emergency point (Dr. Lee): “This point can be used if one mistakenly pierces a blood vessel during acupuncture and there is pain and swelling. Also one may use this point for the treatment of traumatic injury where the patient is upset and cannot calm down. It will help stop the pain and calm the spirit. Another treatment for fear, shaking, pallor, cold sweats, and even apnea due to acupuncture is to needle 22.10 Hand Release (HT8 Shao Fu). One should also raise the patient’s legs, put a cold towel on their forehead, and stay calm, the practitioner should not become excited. One can also moxa ST36 Zu San Li which will move blood to the head. If the needle shock is very severe one can press the root of the tongue with a spoon in order to induce vomiting, because this causes the Stomach qi to raise upward and will also raise the qi back to the Heart. I do not use this point in emergency often, since points on the hands are more easily needled” (Dr. Lee, 1992). Emergency point (Dr. Young): “If the patient faints during acupuncture treatment force him to open the mouth and press the tongue root with a flat needle, spoon or finger a few times. When the patient is going to vomit wash his head with cold water or cover his head with a cold wet towel then give him a glass of cold water to bring him around. Shock due to torture can be alleviated with the same approach” (Dr. Young, 2008).

name: Neitongguan, Inner Passing Gate (T 88.29)
location: This point is 0.5 cun medial to Tongguan (T 88.01) , which is on the anterior midline of the thigh, 5 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella, close to the ST channel. | Johnson: 88.29-88.31 Inner Passing Points are located 0.5 cun medial to 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points: 88.29 Inner Passing Gate is located 0.5 medial to 88.01 Passing Gate. 88.30 Inner Passing Mountain is located 0.5 cun medial to 88.02 Passing Mountain. 88.31 Inner Passing Heaven is located 0.5 cun medial to 88.03 Passing Heaven.
primary_indications: transient ischemic attacks Cardiac disorders: palpitations
johnson_indications: Blood deficiency leading to whole-body pain
Weak arms and legs due to Heart deficiency, excessive cold or overmedication
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 0.5-1.0 cun
comments: Inner Passing Points are located close to the Heart Passing Points and share a similar function. They are not commonly chosen but may be occasionally needled as an alternative to 88.01-88.03 Heart Passing Points in order to alleviate point fatigue. Dao Ma: Inner Passing Gate is needled with 88.30 Inner Passing Mountain or 88.31 Inner Passing Heaven in the combination also known as 88.29-88.31 Inner Passing Points. Rheumatoid arthritis of the knee: Master Tung treated rheumatoid arthritis of the knee with the Inner Passing Points (Dr. Wang, 2013).
reaction_areas: Reaction Area: Heart Caution: • Do not needle all six points together.

name: Shiyin, Lost Voice (T 88.32)
location: This is a two-point set on the SP channel. The first point is at the center of the medial aspect of the knee joint, and the second point is 2 cun inferior to the first point. | Johnson: Lost Voice is a two-point pattern. The first point is located on the Spleen channel at the medial side of the knee joint, in line with the center of the patella. The second point is located two cun distal to the first point.
johnson_indications: Hoarseness, inflammation and swelling of the throat*
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun , or thread the needles towards the KI channel. | Johnson: Needles are inserted horizontally toward the posterior of the leg. Depth: 0.5-0.8 cun
comments: Energetic pathways: Lost Voice points are useful but not particularly powerful. I most frequently use these points for schoolteachers when laryngitis or bronchitis causes them to lose their voice. These points have a function similar to SP5 Shang Qiu. The Spleen, Liver and Kidney meridians all pass through the throat; the Spleen and Kidney connect to the root of the tongue. I have found that for the throat, a more powerful treatment is to bleed 1010.07 All Pivot (DU15-DU16 area) or VT.01 Nine Moths. Of course, bleeding LU11 and LI1 is always effective for sore throat. Commentary (Dr. Lee): “Some of Master Tung’s students say that there are three points here, not two. I have not found these points effective for loss of voice” (Dr. Lee, 1992).

name: Qili * (T 88.51)
location: This point is 2 cun distal to Zhongjiuli (T 88.25) , which overlaps with Fengshi (GB 31) , in the center of the median line of the lateral thigh. This point overlaps Zhongdu (GB 32) .
primary_indications: nerve pain Respiratory disorders Abdominal distension
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 2 - 3 cun .

name: Erhuan, Ear Ring (T 99.01)
location: This point is in the center of the ear lobe. It is at the same location as the auricular Eye Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine. | Johnson: Ear Ring is located in the center of the anterior surface of the earlobe.
techniques: Needle 0.1 cun towards the face. | Johnson: Depth: 1-1.5 fen
comments: Energetic pathways: This point is used primarily for hangover. Since the Liver governs the eye, and this point is located at the ear’s “Eye” point, it is being used to tonify the Liver. Diagnostic tip: Cardiac disease can be diagnosed by vertical lines in the earlobe area. Horizontal lines are diagnostic for tinnitus.
combinations: Alcohol intoxication: 99.01 Ear Ring is bled for alcohol intoxication, and this can be combined with the bleeding of 1010.12 Upright Source (DU25). Other options are to bleed 55.01 Fire Bag, 99.08 Ear Apex or ST45 Li Dui.

name: Muer, Wood Ear (T 99.02)
location: This point is on the upper half of the posterior ear, 0.3 cun below the horizontal vein (middle transverse line). | Johnson: This area is located approximately 0.3 cun inferior to the horizontal midline of the back of the ear. For most effective treatment, bleed any obvious vessel in this area.
johnson_indications: Frequent painful urination due to urinary spasms
techniques: Use thinnest gauge possible and needle 0.1 to 0.2 cun . This point can also be bled. | Johnson: Depth: 1-2 fen
comments: Energetic pathways: In the point name, “Wood” indicates a Five Element correspondence to the Liver, so Wood Ear can be chosen to treat liver disease. Urinary spasms: Protracted, frequent, painful urination (due to urinary spasms) often requires long-term treatment to resolve. By far, my treatment of choice for interstitial cystitis or bladder spasm is to bleed the A-Line (Koryo Hand Theraphy) on the palm (see 66.02 Wood Wife, comprehensive commentary).

name: Huo Er, Fire Ear (T 99.03)
location: This point is on the superior crus of antihelix, at the level of the superior border of the inferior crus of antihelix. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Hip Joint Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine. | Johnson: Fire Ear is located on the anterior surface of the ear, in the middle of the outer border of the antihelix, lateral to Shen Men.
johnson_indications: Heart disease: heart failure, palpitation, shortness of breath
Knee pain (due to Heart deficiency or rheumatoid arthritis)
techniques: Use thinnest gauge possible and needle 0.1 to 0.2 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 1-2 fen
comments: Energetic pathways: Fire Ear corresponds with the auricular point “Knee.” In the point name, “Fire” indicates a correspondence to the Heart. Master Tung taught that knee pain comes from the Heart; therefore, points that treat the Heart also treat knee pain. Because Heart governs blood circulation, Fire Ear can be used to treat pain of the extremities.

name: Tu Er, Earth Ear (T 99.04)
location: This point is located in between the cymba concha and cavum concha, at the end of the helix crus where it disappears into the concha. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Splenomegaly Area in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine. | Johnson: Earth Ear is located on the anterior surface of the ear, in the center of the cavity of the concha.
techniques: Use thinnest gauge possible and needle 0.1 to 0.2 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 1-2 fen
comments: Energetic pathways: Earth Ear corresponds with the auricular point “Spleen.” In the point name, “Earth” indicates a Five Element correspondence to the Spleen; therefore, it tonifies the Spleen. For high fever, bleeding 99.08 Ear Apex is more effective than Earth Ear.

name: Jin Er, Gold Ear (T 99.05)
location: On the posterior of the ear, this point is on the upper 1/3 of the superior edge of the dorsal helix. It is approximately at the same location as the top point of the auricular Three Shoulder Points in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine. | Johnson: Gold Ear is located on the posterior surface of the ear, on the upper third of the outer edge of the dorsal aspect of the helix. Look for a blood vessel in the area.
techniques: Use thinnest gauge possible and needle 0.1 to 0.2 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 1-2 fen
comments: Energetic pathways: Gold Ear overlaps the auricular point “Lung.” In the point name, “Gold” corresponds with Metal and therefore Lung. Sciatica (UB): Gold Ear treats Lung-deficient sciatica. Master Tung taught that points indicated to treat the Lung also treat Urinary Bladder channel sciatica, due to the special relationship between the Hand Tai Yin (LU) and Foot Tai Yang (UB).

name: Shui Er, Water Ear (T 99.06)
location: This point is located at the lower end of the antihelix, in the depression between the inferior border of the antihelix and the scapha. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Clavicle Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine. Some sources indicate this point to be more medial, on the antitragus, at the lower end of the antihelix. | Johnson: Water Ear is located on the anterior surface of the ear, at the lower end of the outer border of the antihelix.
primary_indications: Kidney deficiency with soreness and weakness of the back
techniques: Use thinnest gauge possible and needle 0.1 to 0.2 cun . | Johnson: Depth: 1-2 fen
comments: Energetic pathways: Water Ear overlaps the auricular point “Kidney and urinary disorders: nephritis,” and it is indicated for the treatment of Kidney diseases. In the point name, “Water” also indicates a connection to the Kidney.

name: Er Bei, Ear Back (T 99.07)
location: This point is approximately at the midpoint of the posterior ear, 0.3 cun above Muer (T 99.02). | Johnson: 99.07 Ear Back is located in the center of the upper half of the back of the ear; look for a good blood vessel. 99.08 Ear Apex is a three-point unit, but only the top point is commonly used. The principal point overlaps auricular point Er Jian. Fold the ear forward; the point found at the tip of the ear is referred to as the ear apex. The second point is found at the most lateral aspect of the ear. The third point is found at the bottom-most aspect of the ear.
johnson_indications: Skin diseases including acne, shingles, facial pigment changes*
techniques: | Johnson: These points are only bled: 99.07 Ear Back and 99.08 Ear Apex are virtually interchangeable. Look for a good vessel on the back of the ear; if one is found, bleed it. If there is not a good vessel at Ear Back, bleed the tip of the ear instead. •  When bleeding ear points: Look for an obvious vessel, especially at the apex, as you will usually find one and it will bleed sufficiently. Insert a lancet or triangular needle obliquely to avoid damaging the cartilage. Thicker ears bleed easily; thinner ears must be squeezed. Bleeding even just a few drops of blood can be very effective. On occasion, I have had to stop the bleeding intentionally, because the ear can tend to bleed freely, especially with high blood pressure or excess conditions of the head. Before a bleeding treatment, warm the patient’s ears with your hands; if they are cold, they will not bleed as well as when they are warm. •  Ear Back: When bleeding this point, any blood vessel on the upper third of the ear is a good choice.
comments: Energetic pathways: Bleeding Ear Back or Ear Apex tonifies the Heart, which controls the shen, and it tonifies the Kidney, which controls the brain. Bleeding either point clears Liver fire, calms the spirit, disperses wind, vitalizes the blood and relieves stagnation. •  Chronic or acute: Chronic diseases affect the Heart and Kidney; acute diseases are related to the Liver. These points address both chronic and acute conditions. •  Mental and structural issues: The Urinary Bladder channel goes to the ears via 1010.01 Upright Meeting (DU20). Therefore, the ears can be chosen to address head issues, both mental and structural, as well as Urinary Bladder channel problems, including spine and back pain. •  Connection to the Gallbladder (wind) and skin: The Urinary Bladder and Gallbladder channels meet at the back of the ear. Because the Urinary Bladder channel dominates the exterior, these points are good for treating skin diseases. Because the Gallbladder channel is primary in dispersing wind, these ear points can treat all kinds of wind diseases. The combination of these two influences makes these ear points some of Master Tung’s favorites, and they are exceptionally useful in treating both wind in the head (hypertension, headache and facial paralysis) and skin diseases. I always add 88.17-88.19 Four Horses when treating the skin. •  Connecting Heart and Kidney: The Heart meridian opens to the tongue internally and the ear externally. Because the Heart controls the spirit and the ear is the opening to both the Heart and the Kidney, when Heart and Kidney are not communicating there may be palpitations, insomnia, sweating and anxiety. Ear Back and Ear Apex restore proper communication by calming the spirit, dispersing wind and clearing heat. Night sweats: Because the Heart controls sweating, Ear Back or Ear Apex can be bled for night sweats. For menopausal women, include 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points with 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors and LV3 and LI4 Four Gates. •  Case history (diabetic kitty): A former office manager in my clinic relocated to the east coast. She called me in distress because her aging diabetic cat was failing due to blood sugar that could not be controlled. She asked me if there were any treatments she might be able to do herself. Bleeding Ear Back was the only treatment I could imagine being highly effective and relatively easy to do. Because the animal’s ears were almost translucent, it was easy for her to find a vessel to puncture with a lancet. She bled her cat’s ears every other day, and his blood sugar normalized within the week. He obviously felt better, though she was required to bleed him weekly in order for his insulin to work. •  Low back pain (Dr. Young): “To treat low back pain, bleed 99.07 Ear Back or 99.08 Ear Apex. The best time to bleed is between 1pm-5pm in the afternoon, because at that time qi and blood circulate in the Hand Tai Yang (SI) and Foot Tai Yang (UB) meridians” (Dr. Young, 2008).
combinations: Additional auricular treatments: I learned to needle patients’ ears in Dr. Lee’s clinic, using her simple prescriptions for weight loss and smoking cessation. Sometimes she applied electrical stimulation to the ear needles, especially if patients were in active drug withdrawal. She also used electrical stimulation on Four Gates at the same time. She did not use ear seeds because they were not available at the time, although press tacks were. Neither of us liked the non-sterile approach of retaining press tacks. The following are general combinations that include points not found in Tung’s acupuncture: •  Stop smoking: •  Weight loss: Apply needles or ear seeds unilaterally to: Heart/Thyroid, Inner Secretion, Hunger Point, Kidney, Sympathetic and Shen Men (Dr. Lee, 1992). •  Classic TCM textbooks have good ear charts to reference; however, auricular therapy has evolved over time. When needling ears, I still think of Dr. Lee’s prescriptions. I also often use some of the points listed below, from French and German resources. More than five hundred points are found on the ear; the following are some of my favorites and may be located easily in many auricular books,45 or in charts found on the Internet: •  Shen Men •  Sympathetic •  Endocrine Point (Internal Secretion) •  Lung (for smoking, not weight loss) •  Zero Point •  Darwin’s Point •  Omega Point (Master Omega, Omega 1, Omega 2) Anxiety Point •  Valium Point (V Point) •  Hunger Point (for weight loss) •  Amygdala Point •  Tranquilizer Point •  Hippocampus Point •  Nicotine Point •  Fear/Worry Point (Neurasthenia Point) •  Anger Point •  Grief Point •  Liver Point (Liver 1, Liver 2, Liver 3) •  Aggression Point •  Marvelous Point •  Anti-depression Point •  Adrenals Point •  Hypothalamus Point •  Mercury Toxicity Point •  Sleep Point I, II •  Dental Analgesia Point •  Psychosomatic Point
reaction_areas: Ear Back: Throat Ear Apex: Kidney, Lung

name: Ersan, Ear Apex (T 99.08)
location: This is a three-point set on the outer edge of the helix of the ear and earlobe. The top point is at the apex. The middle point is at the outer midpoint of the helix. The bottom point is at the most inferior point of the earlobe. | Johnson: 99.07 Ear Back is located in the center of the upper half of the back of the ear; look for a good blood vessel. 99.08 Ear Apex is a three-point unit, but only the top point is commonly used. The principal point overlaps auricular point Er Jian. Fold the ear forward; the point found at the tip of the ear is referred to as the ear apex. The second point is found at the most lateral aspect of the ear. The third point is found at the bottom-most aspect of the ear.
johnson_indications: Skin diseases including acne, shingles, facial pigment changes*
techniques: Bleed only two of the three points each time per ear. Unilateral or bilateral needling are both appropriate. | Johnson: These points are only bled: 99.07 Ear Back and 99.08 Ear Apex are virtually interchangeable.
