name: Shener * (T 99.09)
location: This is a three-point set on the posterior ear groove. Divide the groove into fourths, and locate these three points at ¼, ½, and ¾ of the groove. The upper point and lower point are approximately at the same locations as the auricular Lumbosacral Posterior Point and C3-C4 Posterior Point, respectively, in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Various emergencies such as heart attack
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun at an angle downwards.

name: Tianer * (T 99.10)
location: This point is on the posterior ear groove. It is 0.2 cun lateral to the upper point of Shener (T 99.09)*.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Eryuan * (T 99.11)
location: This point is on the outer edge of the ear where the helix meets the earlobe.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Muying * (T 99.12)
location: This point is on the cymba conchae, superior to the end of the helix crus. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Hepatomegaly Area in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
techniques: This point can also be bled.

name: Waier * (T 99.13)
location: On the posterior of the ear, this point is 0.3 cun superior and 0.2 cun lateral to Jiner (T 99.05). It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Tennis Elbow Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: blurry vision Emergency point for stroke and unconsciousness
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Pifu * (T 99.14)
location: This point is on the scapha next to Darwin's tubercle. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Allergy Area in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Urticaria and any dermatological condition or allergy
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 cun. This point can also be bled.

name: Jiangyadian * (T 99.15)
location: This is a three-point set at the lower tragus area. It is approximately between the auricular Adrenal Gland and Vision 1 points in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun .

name: Sanchashenjing * (T 99.16)
location: This is a three-point set on the medial border of the ear lobe. The three points are spaced evenly from the intertragic notch to the bottom of the medial ear lobe. They are approximately at the same locations as the auricular Tooth Point, Neurasthenia Point, Anxious Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 cun .

name: Zhongliu * (T 99.17)
location: This point is an area from where the helix ends to the bottom of the ear lobe. It is at the same location as the auricular Tumor Specific Area 1 in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 cun . 4-6 needles can be used.

name: Xiaxin * (T 99.18)
location: This is a two-point set at the center of the cavum conchae. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Heart Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 cun .

name: Jiazhuangxianzhong * (T 99.19)
location: This is a three-point set on the posterior ear lobe. The three points are vertically and evenly spaced along the medial end of the ear lobe. They are approximately at the same locations as the auricular Smart Point, Deep Sleep Point, and Be Happy Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 cun .

name: Feiqizhong * (T 99.20)
location: This point is inferior to the highest point of the antitragus, almost horizontally leveled with the bottom of the intertragic notch. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Forehead Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 cun .

name: Xingfen * (T 99.21)
location: This point is on the antitragus medial to Shuier (T 99.06). It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Stop Asthma Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Fenzhishang, Separate Branch Upper (T DT.01)
location: This point is on the SI channel at the inferior junction of the humerus and scapula. | Johnson: DT.01 Separate Branch Upper and DT.02 Separate Branch Lower are located on the lateral edge of the scapula, though we would refer to the Toxin Area as half on and half off the scapula. Though I never needle these points, I cup them all the time. See the picture above, showing cup marks over areas that have been seven-star hammered on the outside edge of the right scapula; also see Needling Notes and Comments below. Note: On a large person, it is permissible to use three cups to cover the area.
primary_indications: bites by toxic animals such as snakes
suicide attempts by taking poison (mild cases only) Foul breath
sexually transmitted disease with urinary dysfunction
techniques: Needle 1 - 1.5 cun . | Johnson: Dao Ma: DT.01 Separate Branch Upper and DT.02 Separate Branch Lower are used together and are referred to as DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Area, Toxin Points or Poison Points. These points are usually cupped: Though the points are usually cupped until clear margins are noticed, the Toxin Area may extend beyond DT.01-DT.02, to the rib cage beneath the armpit, as well as medially toward the spine. DT.01-DT.02 may be needled, bled or seven-star hammered. Depth: 1.0-1.5 cun (Note: I have never needled these points and I discourage it.)
comments: Cupping the DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas: Also known as the Poison Points, these are in an area on the lateral edge of the shoulder blades, where the liver stashes toxins that it cannot fully eliminate from the body. Cupping the Toxin Areas is very effective in clearing accumulated waste or poisons (environmental, pharmaceutical, etc.). I usually cup the Toxin Areas on every patient until their skin stops coloring; on a healthy person, this would be accomplished in two cupping sessions. The first time a patient is cupped, their cup marks are usually much darker and the treatment is far more uncomfortable than in subsequent cupping sessions. Eighty percent of the toxins that have accumulated are usually removed during the first cupping treatment and also within the first minute, making this time the most painful. The second cupping treatment, done at least ten days later, should remove the residual 20% of toxins, which are usually found in the gaps between the previously applied cups. If this is the case, the third treatment, a few months later, verifies that toxins are not continuing to accumulate. If the area continues to color in the second cupping treatment much as it did in the first session, this is a sign that the toxin buildup is severe. Continue to cup until the color stops appearing. If, by the fifth round of cupping, the cupped areas are still dark after cupping, this indicates that the patient is likely being exposed to toxins via their environment or is consuming too much animal protein. In my experience, when a patient removes all animal protein from their diet for a few weeks, the color becomes lighter and lighter. Once their skin has stopped coloring completely, animal protein may be reintroduced in significantly reduced amounts. In more than thirty years of practice, I have only seen dark cupping color reoccur three times. Patients should not need to have their 505 Back and Chest Points Toxin Areas cupped frequently. All of the patients in my practice are kept clean with quarterly or at least bi-annual cupping. I rarely need to seven-star hammer. Seven-star hammering: A picture tells a thousand words, so before you consider seven-star hammering a patient, I highly recommend that you watch the segments on seven-star hammering and sterile waste disposal in my online bleeding class (Please see Additional Learning Tools). When to seven-star hammer: Seven-star hammering followed by cupping of the Toxin Areas is a beautiful treatment, but it is rarely done. This technique is excruciatingly painful, but afterwards, people report enormous relief from severe itching – for example, from shingles, severe poison oak or poison ivy. These are the only reasons I would consider seven-star hammering the Toxin Areas. Shingles or herpes: It is a horrific experience to have shingles. If a patient suffers a severe case, they will never have shingles again and do not need to be vaccinated against it. I am cautious in recommending any vaccine, as most of them contain aluminum, a known neurotoxin. When seven-star hammering for shingles, never hammer and cup an area with blisters, as this would spread the virus. For shingles outbreaks anywhere on the body, the Toxin Areas may be hammered and cupped, and also the local area may be seven-star hammered. Remember to wait until the scabs fall off to hammer the new, fresh, pink skin beneath, while it is still visible. Though local hammering is even more painful than hammering the Toxin Areas, it allows the toxins that are lodged in the nerve endings a way to escape, thus preventing postherpetic neuralgia, a gruesome aftermath of shingles. The same treatment is also a fantastic way to end repetitive herpes outbreaks. Though the herpes virus is still likely to reside in the spinal cord, it will no longer live in the habituated distal areas. Remember, never hammer a herpes blister; wait for the scab to fall off, as you will then see pink skin indicating the proper location. Whether this treatment is for shingles or herpes, there are places where cups cannot be applied (such as within the hairline or eyebrow). For these, simply seven-star hammer and then swipe with a sterile gauze pad. The patient should feel immediate relief with the first swipe. When hammering and swiping, always wear gloves and do not make skin contact with the “dirty” blood. Blood products must be disposed of properly; flush them down the toilet or place them in a doubled Sharps bag. Never seven-star hammer the genitals. Note: When students are learning about detoxification through cupping and seven-star hammering, they tend to get overexcited before they have personally experienced these treatments. I never use a treatment on another person unless I have experienced it. Be sensitive to your patient, as simply cupping the Toxin Area is highly effective 99.9% of the time. Even when you know toxins exist, seven- star hammering is excessive. Simple cupping is enough to handle toxicity from environmental sources, pharmaceuticals, food poisoning, or allergic responses, as well as conditions as common as eczema, psoriasis, and rashes. When, and only when, there is severe itching, I seven-star hammer and then cup the Toxin Area. Additional Toxin Areas: In the course of cupping thousands of patients and seeing interesting similarities, I have identified additional Toxin Areas that may be cupped. When the Toxin Areas on the outside of the scapula are cupped, this effectively gives the liver a larger storage area in which to deposit that which otherwise overwhelms it. Areas of pain or discomfort often harbor waste or toxins that the body is unable to eliminate on its own. Toxins also accumulate in places that are not particularly painful, but the skin colors darkly when cupped. I define these places as additional toxin areas, and I suspect that they overlap with the lymphatic system. So far, I have discovered three areas, in addition to DT.01-DT.02, that frequently color in this way. These areas are described below. Note: To avoid injury in these sensitive areas, be sure to use a cup no larger than the #4 (1.3 cun). Behind the earlobes: Directly behind the earlobes (as close as a cup can be placed without cupping the actual flesh of the earlobe) is another Toxin Area where almost every person’s skin turns black when it is cupped. This area is often very dark on the front half, which is why the cup needs to be directly behind the lobe to remove as much accumulated toxicity as possible – and therefore to get the skin to color as much as possible. It is very useful to cup here until color no longer appears, when treating any kind of Shao Yang neck pain, TMJ, headaches, ear infections, vertigo or tinnitus. Because the skin is dark after cupping on every person I have ever cupped for the first time, it is also part of my standard practice in long-term care. As an aside, to definitively diagnose an ear infection, the practitioner may palpate directly behind the earlobe. When an infection is brewing, this area is very sore, as is the depression just in front of the opening to the ear. If it is sore upon palpation, cup behind the ear carefully and gently, always using a small cup. Do not cup if it is excruciating, as this indicates that the eardrum is ready to burst. Cupping will not burst the eardrum, but at this advanced stage of an ear infection, the procedure would be far too painful. Where the neck and top of the shoulders come together on the sides: When cupping a patient’s neck, it is necessary to shave or oil the fine hair on the back of the neck. I usually begin cupping on the back of the neck, as close to the occiput as I can get. Then, I proceed downward toward DU14 and continue around the sides of the neck to find another Toxin Area located where the neck and top of the shoulder come together. When #4 cups are placed on these toxin points, they stand at a 45-degree angle away from the body. This indicates that the placement is correct. Because these cups are half on the neck and half on the shoulder, toxins are being pulled from the base of the neck, where cervical and thoracic vertebrae unite, tension is held, and toxins accumulate. Frequently, the skin color from cupping this Shao Yang area is even darker than the color found on the Tai Yang where the neck joins the back. Because of the finer muscles, tendons and nerves in this area, please be sure to honor the recommendation to use a smaller sized cup, even on a larger neck. Where the sacrum and coccyx meet: This Toxin Area would be likely to color on most people, but I do not routinely cup it, not only because it is inconvenient but also because the area is somewhat private. However, if I am cupping other points in the vicinity, I am sure to catch this one too, even if the patient is not complaining of coccyx pain. I always inform the patient before palpating or cupping a personal area such as this one. It is necessary to stretch the cheeks of the buttocks at the top of the crease in order to keep a small cup from popping off. If you see a tiny line of blood underneath this cup, there is yeast in the crease that may be treated topically with a cream, such as Monistat. Strengthen immunity: Due to the Reaction Area of the Endocrine Glands, the Toxin Points assist in regulating the endocrine system. They are very effective in draining 507 Back and Chest Points toxins located anywhere in the body, in part because of their proximity to the Small Intestine channel, which drains damp heat. When the skin continues to color from cupping, I frequently extend the Toxin Area and follow the color under the armpit; however, I usually don’t do this in the first cupping session, as the area tends to be painful when cupped, and the skin tends to color darkly. When people are very ill and their entire system is compromised, toxins also accumulate in the area of the rib cage just under the armpit, perhaps influencing or influenced by other pathways such as the Spleen, Heart, Liver and Gallbladder. When this entire area is cleaned through cupping, toxins are dumped into the bloodstream quickly, so the patient needs to rest and drink lots of water to assist in their removal. Be sure to instruct the patient to rest and eat well after a cupping treatment that yields dark skin color. Hardy patients can endure an all-in-one cupping treatment, while extremely fragile patients may prefer multiple cupping sessions to a very thorough one. Within 48 hours, all patients should expect to feel far better than they did before the cupping. Immediately, however, they may be a little tired while their circulatory system eliminates the toxins that were pulled from structural tissues and deeper organs outward to the surface of the skin. Cupping the Toxin Areas strengthens the immune system, boosts circulation and frees all bodily processes of elimination. The liver loves to have the Toxin Areas cupped. Breast inflammation: Please note that the lower Toxin Point also has the Reaction Area of the Breast, making the cupping of this area a good choice when female patients have premenstrual breast pain. Cancer treatment detoxification: Of course, I cup the Toxin Areas when detoxing a patient from chemotherapy or radiation (waiting until they have a break from those treatments), whether they are being treated for breast cancer or any other type. Case history (poison oak): For the first few weeks of this patient’s treatment, I really did not know what he looked like, because he came to me with the most severe case of poison oak I have ever seen. Someone had burned slash in his mountain neighborhood and inadvertently exposed everyone within distance of the smoke to systemic cases of poison oak, via inhalation. This poor man looked like a monster and could not see from either of his eyes. His sinus, nose and lips were so swollen that he could barely breathe through them. Because he had inhaled poison oak into his lungs, it had spread to his bloodstream and throughout his entire body. When he came to me for treatment, he had already received several cortisone injections and was taking prednisone. Because seven-star hammering and cupping of his Toxin Areas immediately and significantly relieved the itching that had him on the brink of suicide, he became my patient for life. Case history (shingles): A woman in her mid-thirties came to me with a patch of shingles on the back of her neck. To immediately stop the burning and itching, I applied a combination of toxic topical herbs mixed with sesame oil to the lesion, and gave her some of the mixture to reapply at home. Weeks later, when the scabs had fallen off, I lightly seven-star hammered the area to complete the treatment. Interestingly, this episode of shingles was the first indication of a compromised immune system. A healthy thirty-year old is unlikely to contract shingles; usually, shingles only occurs in the elderly, weak or compromised. Twenty years later, I cupped her Toxin Areas and bled the site of the original shingles outbreak (1010.07 All Pivot) for nausea and vomiting from chemotherapy. Her treatment for breast cancer was effective and she returned to her life as a teacher and mother.
combinations: Hepatitis or exhaustion due to liver weakness or toxicity: Cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas, needle 11.20 Wood Inflammation only on the left side, bilaterally needle 88.12- 8.14 Three Yellows. •  Psoriasis: Cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas, bilaterally needle A.04 San Cha Three, 88.17-88.19 Four Horses. If there are larger lesions, seven-star hammer the healthy skin just outside the lesion to bring healing qi to the area. The lesion will shrink 1-2cm within two weeks. Do not seven-star hammer cracked or bleeding lesions. •  Detoxification following chemotherapy and/or radiation: During breaks between rounds of cancer treatment, cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas. If there is nausea and vomiting during the treatment, it is perfectly acceptable to bleed 1010.07 All Pivot to immediately stop vomiting; however, because the patient is enduring toxic allopathic options, it is best not to clear the toxins until they have a break in their treatment. Please also investigate the alternatives to poisonous interventions, as many patients die from the allopathic treatment before the cancer would have killed them. •  Severe itching (poison oak): Seven-star hammer then cup DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas. (See Comments, above).
reaction_areas: Separate Branch Upper/Lower: Liver, Endocrine Glands5 Separate Branch Lower (only): Breast, Lung Brain, Lung

name: Fenzhixia, Separate Branch Lower (T DT.02)
location: This point is on the SI channel, 1.5 cun inferior and 0.5 cun medial to the inferior junction of the humerus and scapula, close to Jianzhen (SI 9) . | Johnson: DT.01 Separate Branch Upper and DT.02 Separate Branch Lower are located on the lateral edge of the scapula, though we would refer to the Toxin Area as half on and half off the scapula. Though I never needle these points, I cup them all the time. See the picture above, showing cup marks over areas that have been seven-star hammered on the outside edge of the right scapula; also see Needling Notes and Comments below. Note: On a large person, it is permissible to use three cups to cover the area.
primary_indications: bites by toxic animals such as snakes
suicide attempts by taking poison (mild cases only) Foul breath
sexually transmitted disease with urinary dysfunction
techniques: Needle 1 - 1.5 cun . | Johnson: Dao Ma: DT.01 Separate Branch Upper and DT.02 Separate Branch Lower are used together and are referred to as DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Area, Toxin Points or Poison Points. These points are usually cupped: Though the points are usually cupped until clear margins are noticed, the Toxin Area may extend beyond DT.01-DT.02, to the rib cage beneath the armpit, as well as medially toward the spine. DT.01-DT.02 may be needled, bled or seven-star hammered. Depth: 1.0-1.5 cun (Note: I have never needled these points and I discourage it.)
comments: Cupping the DT.01-DT.02 Toxin Areas: Also known as the Poison Points, these are in an area on the lateral edge of the shoulder blades, where the liver stashes toxins that it cannot fully eliminate from the body. Cupping the Toxin Areas is very effective in clearing accumulated waste or poisons (environmental, pharmaceutical, etc.). I usually cup the Toxin Areas on every patient until their skin stops coloring; on a healthy person, this would be accomplished in two cupping sessions. The first time a patient is cupped, their cup marks are usually much darker and the treatment is far more uncomfortable than in subsequent cupping sessions. Eighty percent of the toxins that have accumulated are usually removed during the first cupping treatment and also within the first minute, making this time the most painful. The second cupping treatment, done at least ten days later, should remove the residual 20% of toxins, which are usually found in the gaps between the previously applied cups. If this is the case, the third treatment, a few months later, verifies that toxins are not continuing to accumulate. If the area continues to color in the second cupping treatment much as it did in the first session, this is a sign that the toxin buildup is severe. Continue to cup until the color stops appearing. If, by the fifth round of cupping, the cupped areas are still dark after cupping, this indicates that the patient is likely being exposed to toxins via their environment or is consuming too much animal protein. In my experience, when a patient removes all animal protein from their diet for a few weeks, the color becomes lighter and lighter. Once their skin has stopped coloring completely, animal protein may be reintroduced in significantly reduced amounts. In more than thirty years of practice, I have only seen dark cupping color reoccur three times. Patients should not need to have their 505 Back and Chest Points Toxin Areas cupped frequently. All of the patients in my practice are kept clean with quarterly or at least bi-annual cupping. I rarely need to seven-star hammer. Seven-star hammering: A picture tells a thousand words, so before you consider seven-star hammering a patient, I highly recommend that you watch the segments on seven-star hammering and sterile waste disposal in my online bleeding class (Please see Additional Learning Tools). When to seven-star hammer: Seven-star hammering followed by cupping of the Toxin Areas is a beautiful treatment, but it is rarely done. This technique is excruciatingly painful, but afterwards, people report enormous relief from severe itching – for example, from shingles, severe poison oak or poison ivy. These are the only reasons I would consider seven-star hammering the Toxin Areas. Shingles or herpes: It is a horrific experience to have shingles. If a patient suffers a severe case, they will never have shingles again and do not need to be vaccinated against it. I am cautious in recommending any vaccine, as most of them contain aluminum, a known neurotoxin. When seven-star hammering for shingles, never hammer and cup an area with blisters, as this would spread the virus. For shingles outbreaks anywhere on the body, the Toxin Areas may be hammered and cupped, and also the local area may be seven-star hammered. Remember to wait until the scabs fall off to hammer the new, fresh, pink skin beneath, while it is still visible. Though local hammering is even more painful than hammering the Toxin Areas, it allows the toxins that are lodged in the nerve endings a way to escape, thus preventing postherpetic neuralgia, a gruesome aftermath of shingles. The same treatment is also a fantastic way to end repetitive herpes outbreaks. Though the herpes virus is still likely to reside in the spinal cord, it will no longer live in the habituated distal areas. Remember, never hammer a herpes blister; wait for the scab to fall off, as you will then see pink skin indicating the proper location. Whether this treatment is for shingles or herpes, there are places where cups cannot be applied (such as within the hairline or eyebrow). For these, simply seven-star hammer and then swipe with a sterile gauze pad. The patient should feel immediate relief with the first swipe. When hammering and swiping, always wear gloves and do not make skin contact with the “dirty” blood. Blood products must be disposed of properly; flush them down the toilet or place them in a doubled Sharps bag. Never seven-star hammer the genitals. Note: When students are learning about detoxification through cupping and seven-star hammering, they tend to get overexcited before they have personally experienced these treatments. I never use a treatment on another person unless I have experienced it. Be sensitive to your patient, as simply cupping the Toxin Area is highly effective 99.9% of the time. Even when you know toxins exist, seven- star hammering is excessive. Simple cupping is enough to handle toxicity from environmental sources, pharmaceuticals, food poisoning, or allergic responses, as well as conditions as common as eczema, psoriasis, and rashes. When, and only when, there is severe itching, I seven-star hammer and then cup the Toxin Area. Additional Toxin Areas: In the course of cupping thousands of patients and seeing interesting similarities, I have identified additional Toxin Areas that may be cupped. When the Toxin Areas on the outside of the scapula are cupped, this effectively gives the liver a larger storage area in which to deposit that which otherwise overwhelms it. Areas of pain or discomfort often harbor waste or toxins that the body is unable to eliminate on its own. Toxins also accumulate in places that are not particularly painful, but the skin colors darkly when cupped. I define these places as additional toxin areas, and I suspect that they overlap with the lymphatic system. So far, I have discovered three areas, in addition to DT.01-DT.02, that frequently color in this way. These areas are described below. Note: To avoid injury in these sensitive areas, be sure to use a cup no larger than the #4 (1.3 cun). Behind the earlobes: Directly behind the earlobes (as close as a cup can be placed without cupping the actual flesh of the earlobe) is another Toxin Area where almost every person’s skin turns black when it is cupped. This area is often very dark on the front half, which is why the cup needs to be directly behind the lobe to remove as much accumulated toxicity as possible – and therefore to get the skin to color as much as possible. It is very useful to cup here until color no longer appears, when treating any kind of Shao Yang neck pain, TMJ, headaches, ear infections, vertigo or tinnitus. Because the skin is dark after cupping on every person I have ever cupped for the first time, it is also part of my standard practice in long-term care. As an aside, to definitively diagnose an ear infection, the practitioner may palpate directly behind the earlobe. When an infection is brewing, this area is very sore, as is the depression just in front of the opening to the ear. If it is sore upon palpation, cup behind the ear carefully and gently, always using a small cup. Do not cup if it is excruciating, as this indicates that the eardrum is ready to burst. Cupping will not burst the eardrum, but at this advanced stage of an ear infection, the procedure would be far too painful. Where the neck and top of the shoulders come together on the sides: When cupping a patient’s neck, it is necessary to shave or oil the fine hair on the back of the neck. I usually begin cupping on the back of the neck, as close to the occiput as I can get. Then, I proceed downward toward DU14 and continue around the sides of the neck to find another Toxin Area located where the neck and top of the shoulder come together. When #4 cups are placed on these toxin points, they stand at a 45-degree angle away from the body. This indicates that the placement is correct. Because these cups are half on the neck and half on the shoulder, toxins are being pulled from the base of the neck, where cervical and thoracic vertebrae unite, tension is held, and toxins accumulate. Frequently, the skin color from cupping this Shao Yang area is even darker than the color found on the Tai Yang where the neck joins the back. Because of the finer muscles, tendons and nerves in this area, please be sure to honor the recommendation to use a smaller sized cup, even on a larger neck. Where the sacrum and coccyx meet: This Toxin Area would be likely to color on most people, but I do not routinely cup it, not only because it is inconvenient but also because the area is somewhat private. However, if I am cupping other points in the vicinity, I am sure to catch this one too, even if the patient is not complaining of coccyx pain. I always inform the patient before palpating or cupping a personal area such as this one. It is necessary to stretch the cheeks of the buttocks at the top of the crease in order to keep a small cup from popping off. If you see a tiny line of blood underneath this cup, there is yeast in the crease that may be treated topically with a cream, such as Monistat. Strengthen immunity: Due to the Reaction Area of the Endocrine Glands, the Toxin Points assist in regulating the endocrine system. They are very effective in draining 507 Back and Chest Points toxins located anywhere in the body, in part because of their proximity to the Small Intestine channel, which drains damp heat. When the skin continues to color from cupping, I frequently extend the Toxin Area and follow the color under the armpit; however, I usually don’t do this in the first cupping session, as the area tends to be painful when cupped, and the skin tends to color darkly. When people are very ill and their entire system is compromised, toxins also accumulate in the area of the rib cage just under the armpit, perhaps influencing or influenced by other pathways such as the Spleen, Heart, Liver and Gallbladder. When this entire area is cleaned through cupping, toxins are dumped into the bloodstream quickly, so the patient needs to rest and drink lots of water to assist in their removal. Be sure to instruct the patient to rest and eat well after a cupping treatment that yields dark skin color. Hardy patients can endure an all-in-one cupping treatment, while extremely fragile patients may prefer multiple cupping sessions to a very thorough one. Within 48 hours, all patients should expect to feel far better than they did before the cupping. Immediately, however, they may be a little tired while their circulatory system eliminates the toxins that were pulled from structural tissues and deeper organs outward to the surface of the skin. Cupping the Toxin Areas strengthens the immune system, boosts circulation and frees all bodily processes of elimination. The liver loves to have the Toxin Areas cupped. Breast inflammation: Please note that the lower Toxin Point also has the Reaction Area of the Breast, making the cupping of this area a good choice when female patients have premenstrual breast pain. Cancer treatment detoxification: Of course, I cup the Toxin Areas when detoxing a patient from chemotherapy or radiation (waiting until they have a break from those treatments), whether they are being treated for breast cancer or any other type. Case history (poison oak): For the first few weeks of this patient’s treatment, I really did not know what he looked like, because he came to me with the most severe case of poison oak I have ever seen. Someone had burned slash in his mountain neighborhood and inadvertently exposed everyone within distance of the smoke to systemic cases of poison oak, via inhalation. This poor man looked like a monster and could not see from either of his eyes. His sinus, nose and lips were so swollen that he could barely breathe through them. Because he had inhaled poison oak into his lungs, it had spread to his bloodstream and throughout his entire body. When he came to me for treatment, he had already received several cortisone injections and was taking prednisone. Because seven-star hammering and cupping of his Toxin Areas immediately and significantly relieved the itching that had him on the brink of suicide, he became my patient for life. Case history (shingles): A woman in her mid-thirties came to me with a patch of shingles on the back of her neck. To immediately stop the burning and itching, I applied a combination of toxic topical herbs mixed with sesame oil to the lesion, and gave her some of the mixture to reapply at home. Weeks later, when the scabs had fallen off, I lightly seven-star hammered the area to complete the treatment. Interestingly, this episode of shingles was the first indication of a compromised immune system. A healthy thirty-year old is unlikely to contract shingles; usually, shingles only occurs in the elderly, weak or compromised. Twenty years later, I cupped her Toxin Areas and bled the site of the original shingles outbreak (1010.07 All Pivot) for nausea and vomiting from chemotherapy. Her treatment for breast cancer was effective and she returned to her life as a teacher and mother.

name: Qixing, Seven Stars (T DT.03)
location: 7 points total Point 1 is 1 cun superior to the center of the posterior hairline in the depression directly below the occipital protuberance. This point overlaps with Fengfu (GV 16) . Point 2 is at the center of the posterior hairline, 1 cun inferior to Point 1. Point 3 is 2 cun inferior to Point 2. Points 4 and 5 are 0.8 cun lateral and 0.8 cun inferior to Point 2, one on each side. Points 6 and 7 are 1 cun inferior to Points 4 and 5. | Johnson: This is officially a seven-point unit; however, the entire area may be cupped, bled, or scraped with a Gua Sha technique. To simplify the point locations, they can be described as three points approximately one cun apart; the first is 0.8 cun above the posterior hairline. The next two points are found one cun apart, directly below the first. The last four points are located one cun lateral to the second and third points. Meridians: Du Mai and Urinary Bladder Reaction Areas: Brain, Lung Cautions: Superficially bleed these points. Deep puncture may cause deafness and aphasia, especially in children.
primary_indications: summer-stroke Common cold with headache Fever (infantile) and internal wind conditions with spasms and tremors in children
johnson_indications: Nausea and vomiting (disturbance of the five zang organs)*
Other childhood diseases due to wind
techniques: This point can be bled. Pinch the skin first prior to pricking for blood. Be extra cautious in children not to injure the nerve of the brain which may lead to deafness or aphasia. Bleeding the first three points are usually sufficient to see results. | Johnson: Always pinch up the skin when bleeding points on the neck, to avoid damaging underlying muscles, nerves or blood vessels.
comments: Common cold: These points are used to treat a common cold, especially one with a fever. The first two points duplicate the function of 1010.07 All Pivot, which I bleed for nausea and vomiting. See 1010.07 All Pivot for additional information. Energetic pathways: The DT.03 Seven Stars combination mimics the effects of DU14 Da Zhui in relieving cold or wind heat from the body. Especially useful in the treatment of high fever, these points are located on the Du Mai and Urinary Bladder channels. I frequently bleed All Pivot and DU14, but rarely DT.03. The entire area can be oiled and scraped with a Chinese porcelain soupspoon to detoxify the brain stem and neck areas where toxic residues commonly accumulate. This treatment usually resolves most nausea and vomiting, including that caused by drug withdrawal.
reaction_areas: Brain, Lung Cautions: • Superficially bleed these points. Deep puncture may cause deafness and aphasia, especially in children. Heart, Liver, Lung, Spleen

name: Wuling, Five Mountain Range (T DT.04)
location: 40 points total The first 10 points are on the spine, below the spinous process of T2 to T11. 7 of the 10 points overlap with Shenzhu (GV 12) , Shendao (GV 11) , Lingtai (GV 10) , Zhiyang (GV 9) , Jinsuo (GV 8) , Zhongshu (GV 7) , Jizhong (GV 6) . The second set of 16 points is 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 to T9 (8 points on each side). 14 of the 16 points overlap with Fufen (BL 41) , Pohu (BL 42) , Gaohuangshu (BL 43) , Shentang (BL 44) , Yixi (BL 45) , Geguan (BL 46) , Hunmen (BL 47) . The third set of 14 points is 6 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 to T8 (7 points on each side). 4 of the 14 points overlap with Tianzong (SI 11) and Bingfeng (SI 12) . | Johnson: This combination of 40 points is located along five lines on the upper back. Although it is good to understand the five-element application of each point in this pattern, the idea of puncturing 40 points is only loosely followed when actually bleeding Five Mountain Range. One cup may be used to cover multiple punctures, as cupping is required in order to draw the blood. A simplified description follows: Make ten punctures, starting beneath the posterior vertebral process of T2 and ending beneath T12.6 Then make a line of eight punctures, three cun lateral to the first line, ending lateral to the space below T10. Then puncture a third line of seven points, six cun lateral to the first line, ending lateral to the space below T9.
primary_indications: cardiomegaly Any chronic disorder with blood stagnation
secondary_indications: vomiting Hemiplegia Cholera (yin or yang type)
acute stomach pain Back pain from atherosclerosis
johnson_indications: Hemiplegia or numbness (especially after stroke or with high blood pressure)
Peripheral neuropathy due to high blood pressure or stroke
techniques: This point can be bled. Pinch the skin first prior to pricking for blood. It is unnecessary to bleed all 40 points. Choose the points that relate to the correct innervations and bleed accordingly. | Johnson: Bleed: Using a three-edged needle or 14-gauge hypodermic needle tip (a lancet is insufficient), bleed five rows of points on the Du Mai and Urinary Bladder channel. 6 This text abbreviates the names of vertebrae; for example, the first thoracic vertebra is referred to as T1. 511 Back and Chest Points Always wear gloves. When puncturing this many sites, if at all possible, have someone there to hold a tray of glass cups for you to choose from. Have your cups, lighter and cotton balls ready and waiting. Hold two small cotton balls with a hemostat, and soak them in denatured alcohol, thoroughly wringing them out to avoid dripping burning alcohol after they are lit. Palpate the spine to familiarize yourself with the upper back before beginning your bleeding technique. Use your thumbnail to press the points before puncturing them; this will result in less pain and better results. You may squeeze and swipe the beads of blood; however, cupping over as many punctures as possible is the most efficient way to draw the blood. With large cups, often more than one puncture site can be covered by one cup. It is not necessary to bleed all forty points, precisely. Though I may puncture close to 40 times, I do not count the punctures because that would be distracting.
comments: Emergency points for high fever or hypertension: I have used Five Mountain Range on multiple occasions when urgent treatment was required to open the DU Mai. In every case, a trip to the emergency room was avoided and I was afforded the time to treat the underlying condition. I use Five Mountain Range primarily to drop a very high fever that involves severe lung stagnation (such as pneumonia or pneumocystis), or to lower extremely high blood pressure (220/120). Alternative hypertension treatment: When treating extremely high blood pressure, consider also bleeding the fingertips as they will produce more blood and be less painful to bleed than the Jing-Well points. This is equally effective and easier to accomplish, though the ten fingertip punctures may be more painful than Five Mountain Range. Caution (high blood pressure): A patient whose blood pressure is nearing 220/120 should not be allowed to leave the clinic until blood pressure treatments bring it down to around 150/90, after which they should be directed to the nearest emergency room for medication. It is always wiser to wean patients with high blood pressure off their medications slowly than to risk any kind of cerebrovascular event. Be smart!

name: Shuang Feng, Double Phoenix (T DT.05)
location: 14 points total These points are 1.5 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 to T8 (7 points on each side). 12 of the 14 points overlap with Fengmen (BL 12) , Feishu (BL 13) , Jueyinshu (BL 14) , Xinshu (BL 15) , Dushu (BL 16) , Geshu (BL 17) . | Johnson: This is a 14-point pattern comprised of two lines of seven points each, 1.5 cun lateral to the spine, beginning at T2.
primary_indications: foot numbness Arteriosclerosis on the arm or leg
johnson_indications: Whole-body pain due to blood stagnation
Arteriosclerosis causing pain and numbness of the hands and feet
techniques: Johnson: Bleed bilaterally; cup over the puncture sites to draw blood.
comments: Energetic pathways: The name Double Phoenix means “Both Limbs.” All points in this pattern belong to the element of fire, so they are used to vitalize and circulate the blood. Numbness can be caused by several different factors, including arteriosclerosis, bone spurs and high blood pressure. We normally bleed the upper extremity points to treat the lower body, and bleed the lower extremity points to treat the upper body; Double Phoenix can treat them all. Bone spurs: Bone spurs on the neck may create numbness of one or more fingers. Thumb and index finger numbness relates to cervical vertebrae C5-C6. Middle finger numbness relates to C7. If all of the fingers are numb, the cause could be multiple bone spurs on the spine, or the numbness could relate to pharmaceutical side effects, arteriosclerosis, high blood pressure, high cholesterol or diabetes. In order to properly treat numbness, differential diagnosis is essential. See 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One (SI3) for the bone spur protocol.

name: Jiu Hou, Nine Monkeys (T DT.06)
location: 18 points total The first set of 6 points is 1.5 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 to T4 (3 points on each side). They overlap with Fengmen (BL 12) , Feishu (BL 13) , Jueyinshu (BL 14) . The second set of 8 points is 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T1 to T4 (4 points on each side). 6 of the 8 points overlap with Fufen (BL 41) , Pohu (BL 42) , Gaohuangshu (BL 43) . The third set of 4 points is 6 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 to T3 (2 points on each side). 2 of the 4 points overlap with Bingfeng (SI 12) . | Johnson: The first line consists of three points, one cun apart and 1.5 cun lateral to the spine, beginning at the level just below the posterior vertebral process of T2. The second line of four points is three cun lateral to the spine, beginning at the level just below the posterior vertebral process of T1. The third line consists of two points, six cun lateral to the space between the spinous processes of T2 and T3.
primary_indications: Syndrome this point is best at treating is rash with red dot eruptions that are extremely itchy.
techniques: Johnson: Bleed bilaterally.
comments: Energetic pathways: These points relate to fire and metal, and they are very similar to DT.04 Five Mountain Range. All nine points have the function of clearing the Lung and reducing fire. Scarlet fever: The characteristic diagnostic trait of scarlet fever is a whole-body rash with unusual redness of the cheeks and a pale ring around the mouth. Scarlet fever typically occurs after exposure to the streptococcal bacteria, and a throat culture is required to accurately diagnose this strain of bacteria. Painful and enlarged tonsils, fatigue and fever are telltale of both strep throat and scarlet fever, though scarlet fever is followed by a characteristic rash beginning on the first or second day, usually fading by the third or fourth day. Other complications are rare but can be severe; without them, resolution is expected by the tenth day. Because DT.05 disperses heat and clears fire in the Lungs, bleeding these points hastens the disease process and reduces symptoms, though antibiotics are recommended. Red monkey disease: “They are used to treat scarlet fever (a.k.a. red monkey disease), thus the name” (Dr. Young, 2008).

name: San Jin, Three Gold (T DT.07)
location: 6 points total These points are 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T3 to T5 (3 points on each side). They overlap with Pohu (BL 42) , Gaohuangshu (BL 43) , Shentang (BL 44) . | Johnson: These three points are located at UB42 Po Hu, UB43 Gao Huang Shu, and UB44 Shen Tang, 3.0 cun (four fingers) lateral to the spine, level with the spaces between the T3- T6 vertebrae.
johnson_indications: Soft tissue inflammation due to bone spurs
techniques: Johnson: Palpate and choose the most sensitive point. If more than one point is sensitive, two may be punctured. However, if no points are significantly sensitive, the treatment is unlikely to work, so I do not perform it. Bleed bilaterally: I always bleed bilaterally because a degenerative process affects both sides, even if one side is more pronounced. This point does not bleed freely and must be cupped in order to draw at least a tablespoon of blood. If you bleed these points and the pain returns within twenty-four hours, it will not be effective to bleed them again; the knee degeneration is too advanced.
comments: Energetic pathways: I only bleed these points for knee pain, and only if one or more of the points (on the same side as the pain) are extremely sensitive to palpation. All three points are metal, hence the name Three Gold. They relate to the Shu points of the Lung, Pericardium and Heart. In Tung’s acupuncture, all points that strengthen the Heart also treat the knees. Bleeding Three Gold has a remarkable effect on the treatment of pain that is underneath the kneecap, inside the joint. If the patient cannot describe the pain that way, I do not use this treatment. I have not found it to be effective if the knee pain is medial, lateral, proximal or distal to the joint. It is not used for injuries such as ACL tears. However, for chronic pain inside the joint, Three Gold is unsurpassed. This is one of the reasons I have coined the term “Magic” in “Master 515 Back and Chest Points Tung’s Magic Points” – when bleeding DT.07 is successful, patients have been known to laugh and cry with the joy of a gentle deep knee bend. Bone spurs in the knee: If walking downstairs is more painful than walking upstairs, there is likely to be a bone spur in the joint. Knee spurs are more frequently medial than lateral. Three Gold affects only soft tissue inflammation. See 22.08 Wrist Prosperous One (SI3) for further information about bone spurs. Case history: A retired physical education teacher had experienced thirty years of knee pain. She was visiting from out of town when she came to my clinic for treatment. I bled DT.07 Three Gold, and ten minutes later she got off the table and did a deep knee bend, laughing as she rose, free of pain. The treatment lasted for ten years, after which she returned to see me. I bled Three Gold again and the pain was gone once again. Such is the miraculous effect of bleeding these points. Case history: A fifty-year-old patient came for treatment of hot flashes and night sweats. In the course of her intake, I discovered that she had pain inside her knee joints. I bled the most sensitive of her Three Gold points, and the knee pain went away immediately. I then needled 11.06 Return to the Nest and 11.24 Gynecological Points with 77.18-77.21 Three Emperors, and gave her Liu Wei Di Huang to take home. One year later, she returned for treatment of her hot flashes, which were just beginning again. The knee pain had not yet returned. Three years later, when she noticed the knee pain again, I bled her Three Gold once more. I did not hear from this patient again for five years, at which time she called me; she’d had an X-ray, and an orthopedic surgeon had scheduled a knee replacement. I suggested that she come to see me for the tried and true bleeding of DT.07, after which she cancelled the knee replacement and returned to Thailand where she had relocated. It is not always a substitute for surgery, but in her case the treatment lasted for years at a time. This is typical of Three Gold and so I always try it, as long as I can palpate a telltale sensitive point. Case history (knee pain, Dr. Lee): “At a clinic in China I was introduced to an old man suffering from knee pain. He had suffered from knee pain for nine years whenever he stood up especially in the winter. He had been receiving standard TCM acupuncture for this problem for over nine years without much relief. In other words, he had been needled innumerable times at ST35 Xi Yan, ST36 Zu San Li, GB34 Yang Ling Quan, etc. Using Master Tung’s system I bled the area of UB43 Gao Huang Shu. After the treatment, the old man got up and said that this was the first time in nine years he had been able to stand without pain in his knees. The director of the clinic said sourly that they did not do such treatment in their clinic and dismissed the whole affair at that. Whether my treatment was right or wrong, however, should only be judged by the patient’s relief” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Knee pain (degenerative): Bilaterally bleed DT.07 Three Gold, providing it is sensitive. Remember, bleeding is always done on the same side as the indications. To treat the most painful knee, after bleeding Three Gold, needle opposite-side PC6 Nei Guan, with same-side 66.03 Fire Hardness (Tung’s LV2) or 66.04 Fire Master (Tung’s LV3) as a Guiding Point. An alternative option is to add opposite-side ST36, SP9 and GB34 to the above points. Enlarged heart and heart disease: Bleed DT.07 Three Gold (Shu Points close to HT, PC, SI and LU).

name: Jing Zhi, Essence Branch (T DT.08)
location: 4 points total These points are 6 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 and T3 (2 points on each side). 2 of the 4 points overlap with Bingfeng (SI 12) . | Johnson: DT.08 is a two-point pattern found 3.0 cun lateral to the top two points of DT.07 Three Gold (UB42, 43), or 6.0 cun lateral to the space below the posterior spinous processes of T2 and T3. Note: Another way to find these points is to palpate for the most sensitive spots in the area of the back where the arm connects to the torso, close to SI9 and SI10 and extending to the region of the supraspinatus process of the scapula. See Commentary below.
johnson_indications: Lower leg tight, distended or painful
techniques: Johnson: Bleed on the same side, or bilaterally.
comments: These two points relate to metal. Gallbladder channel sciatica: I have found bleeding DT.08 Essence Branch to be exceedingly helpful in the treatment of stubborn gallbladder channel sciatica, especially in the area approximately 6.0 cun above the ankle. Case history: As a young acupuncturist, I used acupuncture and cupping techniques to treat an elderly woman with severe and chronic Gallbladder channel sciatica. After three weeks of treatment, she was eighty percent better, except for the area between GB39 and GB40. I called Dr. Lee to ask her advice and she told me to palpate the area of DT.08 for an extremely sensitive point. After I bled this point, the last four inches of the patient’s sciatica disappeared immediately. I have never forgotten this case and have used Essence Branch many times successfully over the past thirty years. Lower leg disorders: These points also may be used to treat pain, tightness or distension of the lower leg. “Lower leg distension can be difficult to treat. However, bleeding this point can sometimes relieve this condition” (Dr. Lee, 1992).
combinations: Gallbladder channel sciatica (especially just above the ankle): Bilaterally bleed DT.08 Essence Branch, needle opposite-side 22.06-22.07 Zhong Bai/Xia Bai. Optionally, needle same-side GB41 Zhu Lin Qi as a Guiding Point.

name: Jin Lin, Gold Forest (T DT.09)
location: 6 points total These points are 6 cun lateral to the spinous process of T4 to T6 (3 points on each side). 2 of the 4 points overlap with Tianzong (SI 11) . | Johnson: Gold Forest points are located 3.0 cun lateral to UB44, UB45 and UB46, or 6.0 cun lateral to the space below the posterior spinous processes of T4, T5 and T6. The lowest point is approximately level with the base of the scapula. The superior point is related to the metal element, and the two inferior points to wood.
johnson_indications: Sciatica due to arteriosclerosis (Gall Bladder channel)
techniques: Johnson: Palpate DT.08 and DT.09 to find the most sensitive points to bleed and cup. Bleed bilaterally.
comments: Gallbladder channel sciatica: Because Gold Forest treats the thigh, these points are very effective for Gallbladder channel sciatica. Areas of effect: The three points consist of one metal and two wood points. The top two points treat the thigh and lower leg; the bottom point treats the lower leg only.
reaction_areas: Left side – Heart, Liver, Spleen Right side – Heart, Liver, Lung

name: Ding Zhu, Top Pillar (T DT.10)
location: 22 points total The first set of 12 points is 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T4 to T9 (6 points on each side). 10 of the 12 points overlap with Gaohuangshu (BL 43) , Shentang (BL 44) , Yixi (BL 45) , Geguan (BL 46) , Hunmen (BL 47) . The second set of 10 points is 6 cun lateral to the spinous process of T4 to T8 (5 points on each side). 2 of the 10 points overlap with Tianzong (SI 11) . | Johnson: Top Pillar is comprised of 22 points. The first two points in this pattern are related to the metal element and are in the same location as UB43 and UB44. The third point relates to fire and is located at UB45. The next three points are related to wood and are located at UB46, UB47 and UB48. In the second line of points, the first point relates to metal and is found 6.0 cun lateral to the space below T4. The next four points relate to wood and are found 6.0 cun lateral to the spaces between T5 and T8.
primary_indications: sudden onset of back pain due to wrong posture with difficulty breathing
johnson_indications: Low back pain due to arteriosclerosis
Pain of the leg, thigh and lower back
techniques: Johnson: Bleed bilaterally.
comments: I rarely use Top Pillar: Though I would bleed these points to treat back pain due to arteriosclerosis, I do not use them for stray gas or most back pain. For stray gas: Needle PC6 Nei Guan with SP4 Gong Sun, and ask the patient to strike their sternum three times with a flat-fingered fist and then belch. Often this method of dislodging painful pockets of gas is all that is needed. In my thirty years of practice, I’ve found it has always done the trick. If a patient calls you in the middle of the night fearing they are having a heart attack, have them try this technique. If they can talk, it’s likely that the symptoms are caused by gas. If their pain is not immediately relieved by striking the sternum and belching, send them to the emergency room. For twisted back, general back pain or leg pain: I suggest bleeding veins found on the popliteal crease (UB40 area), needling 11.12 Two Corner Bright and/or cupping the lumbar and thoracic areas of the back.
reaction_areas: Left side – Lung, Kidney, Spleen Right side – Lung

name: Houxin, Posterior Heart (T DT.11)
location: 20 points total The first 6 points are on the spine, below the spinous process of T4 to T9. 4 of the 6 points overlap with Shendao (GV 11) , Lingtai (GV 10) , Zhiyang (GV 9) , Jinsuo (GV 8) . The second set of 8 points is 1.5 cun lateral to the spinous process of T4 to T7 (4 points on each side). The third set of 6 points is 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T4 to T6 (3 points on each side). They overlap with Gaohuangshu (BL 43) , Shentang (BL 44) , Yixi (BL 45) . | Johnson: Posterior Heart is comprised of 20 points, all related to fire: The first six points are found between the spinous processes of T4 through T9. The next four points are found 1.5 cun lateral to the spine, directly lateral to the first four points of the first line. The last three points are found 3.0 cun lateral to the spine, directly lateral to the first three points of the first line. Note: These points are very similar to DT.04 Five Mountain Range.
primary_indications: furuncles Cardiac insufficiency Gastrointestinal disorders Acute heart failure Severe common cold
johnson_indications: Heart attack or coronary heart disease
Severe common cold with wind-cold transmitted into the interior
techniques: This point can be bled. Pinch the skin first prior to pricking for blood. | Johnson: Bleed bilaterally.
comments: Energetic pathways: Posterior Heart strengthens the Heart, warms the yang and regulates body temperature. Strengthening fire promotes earth, treating diseases of the stomach. Toxic heat: “These points are for the treatment of severe toxic heat. If one does Gua Sha on the back, at each pimple, one may express a white hair. This is called ‘goat’s hair’. These points also treat ‘ding’ or a kind of severe boils that are potentially lethal. Nowadays, we have antibiotics to treat these kinds of diseases and also one does not see much of this in the West. Whenever there are purple spots on the back (or black spots if even more severe), quickly bleed and pull the hair out. Mostly this is for rural use in the countryside of China” (Dr. Lee, 1992).

name: Ganmaosan, Catch Cold Three (T DT.12)
location: 3 points total Point 1 is on the spine, below the spinous process of T1. It overlaps with Taodao (GV 13) . Points 2 and 3 are 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T3, one on each side, overlapping Pohu (BL 42) . | Johnson: This is a three-point pattern with the same location as DU13 Tao Dao and UB42 Po Hu.
techniques: Needle subcutaneously. This point can also be bled. Both are very effective. | Johnson: For any of the above indications, bleed, cup or moxa these points. These points are rarely needled; however, when they are bilaterally needled, the needles are directed obliquely under the skin. These points are bled because bleeding on the torso is always shallow. Needling DU13 too deeply may cause injury to the spinal cord, characterized by a numbing or electrical sensation of the entire body. Needling UB42 too deeply may cause pneumothorax.
comments: Energetic pathways: These points alleviate pain, clear heat and activate the Du Mai. DU13 is the meeting point of the Governing Vessel and the Urinary Bladder channel. UB42 Po Hu (also known as “House of the Spirit”) tonifies Lung and nourishes Lung yin, stops cough, activates the channel and alleviates pain of the neck, shoulder and back. It may be bled or used with moxa, but needling deeply may cause a pneumothorax. Common cold: Bleed Catch Cold, particularly if the patient is experiencing a fever. When a patient has a wind-chill invasion, I immediately cup their entire upper back, then needle 88.17-88.19 Four Horses and A.04 San Cha Three. Illness may be avoided altogether if, within a few hours of being chilled, the patient takes an extremely hot shower with water beating upon the upper back and neck. This corresponds with the Chinese teaching, “The wind-chill evil enters through the back of the neck.” They need to be careful not to get exposed to another chill after the hot shower (bring warm clothes into the bathroom). A good sweat, followed by a change of clothes, should relieve the chill. Often patients feel a shudder of cold coming out through the surface while they stand under the steaming hot water.

name: Shuizhong, Water Center (T DT.13)
location: 2 points total These two points are 1.5 cun lateral to the spinous process of L1, one on each side, overlapping Sanjiaoshu (BL 22) . | Johnson: These two points are located at UB22 San Jiao Shu.
johnson_indications: Pain of the lumbar vertebrae (due to coldness)
techniques: Needle 0.8 - 1 cun | Johnson: I bleed, cup or use moxa on these points to strengthen the Kidneys. I do not needle them; however TCM practitioners do. Needle insertion may cause a sore and numbing sensation that radiates to the abdomen. If needled, the depth is 0.8-1.0 cun.
comments: Energetic pathways: Due to the Reaction Area of the Kidney and the special relationship between the Foot Shao Yin (KD) and the Hand Shao Yang (SJ), Water Center tonifies Kidney qi. As the Shu point of the San Jiao, Water Center regulates the San Jiao. Water Center: Regulates the San Jiao and dissolves dampness, regulates fluids and promotes urination, benefits original qi and tonifies the lower back and legs. It is frequently used with UB23 Shen Shu (also known as DT.14 Water Bowels), especially with moxa (pots or boxes) to treat Kidney deficiency.

name: Shuifu, Water Bowels (T DT.14)
location: 2 points total These two points are 1.5 cun lateral to the spinous process of L2, one on each side, overlapping Shenshu (BL 23) . | Johnson: These two points are located at UB23 Shen Shu.
secondary_indications: insomnia Headache Diabetes Non-descent of fetus
techniques: Needle 0.8 - 1 cun | Johnson: I might bleed, cup or use moxa on these points to strengthen the Kidneys, but I do not needle them.
comments: Energetic pathways: UB23 tonifies the Kidneys, strengthens the yang and benefits the original qi. It also nourishes Kidney yin, strengthens Kidney qi and regulates the fluid waterways, benefitting urination. It is used to strengthen the lower back and legs as well as the power of vision and hearing. Tonifying with moxa: My preferred treatment in this area is to moxa, especially during “moxa season.” Moxa season is a month-long period during which the Ming Men is said to be opening and closing. The two weeks in the middle of this time are when the gate is open wide, allowing the penetrating heat of moxa to tonify and build the pure qi more powerfully than at any other time. Moxa season occurs during every change of season; however, we focus only on the change from fall to winter (November 1-28), and winter to spring (starting the week prior to Lunar New Year). During the middle of moxa season, when the gate is open wide, a wind-cold invasion is particularly destructive, making it difficult for the patient to recover, perhaps for the entire year. During moxa season, daily application of moxa for 30 minutes over the kidneys, and then another 30 minutes between the navel and pubic bone, ensures good health and longevity.

name: San Jiang, Three Rivers (T DT.15)
location: 19 points total The first 7 points are on the spine at the level of L1 to S2. 3 of the 7 points overlap with Xuanshu (GV 5) , Mingmen (GV 4) , Yaoyan gguan (GV 3) . The second set of 12 points is 3 cun lateral to the spine at the level of L2 to S2 (6 points on each side). 4 of the 12 points overlap with Zhishi (BL 52) and Baohuang (BL 53) . | Johnson: Three Rivers is comprised of 19 points: Seven points are located between the spinous processes beginning below L1. To these seven points, we add DT.16 Two Rivers, which consists of six additional water points on each side of the spine, beginning 3.0 cun lateral to Ming Men (L2).
primary_indications: acute chest or rib pain with difficulty breathing
johnson_indications: Pain in back, shoulder, arms, elbow and hands
Acute or chronic lower back pain
techniques: Johnson: Bleed bilaterally. Note: It is not necessary to bleed every point.
comments: Three Rivers includes Two Rivers: DT.16 Two Rivers is chosen mostly for arm, shoulder, and upper back pain. When the points on the Du Mai are included, the combination becomes DT.15 Three Rivers, and it is used to treat twisted lower back, intestinal disease and reproductive disorders, including infertility. Bleeding the back to treat the front: Because bleeding the abdomen is not recommended, we bleed the back to treat the front for intestinal disease, amenorrhea or ovarian disease and male or female infertility. While visiting Dr. Xiu Zhen Wang (my bleeding teacher) in He Fei, China, I saw her bleed a man in this general area. He was being treated for infertility. A few weeks later, there was a big commotion in the courtyard of the hospital as this man led his parade of family and friends holding a large sign decorated with crackling fireworks, announcing his wife’s pregnancy. See bleeding class photos, Net of Knowledge/Eastern Currents webinar.

name: Shuang He, Two Rivers (T DT.16)
location: 12 points total These points are 3 cun lateral to the spine at the level of L2 to S2 (6 points on each side). 4 of the 12 points overlap with Zhishi (BL 52) and Baohuang (BL 53) . | Johnson: See DT.15 Three Rivers for point location.
johnson_indications: Pain in back, shoulder, arms, elbow and hands
techniques: Johnson: Bleed bilaterally. Note: It is not necessary to bleed every point. When dark blood is seen during bleeding treatments, there will usually be a stronger effect.
comments: See DT.15 Three Rivers for comments.

name: Chongxiao, Up-Shooting Heaven (T DT.17)
location: 3 points total on the spine Point 1 is at the level of S3 of the sacral vertebra. Point 2 is 1 cun inferior from Point 1. Point 3 is 1 cun inferior from Point 2. | Johnson: A three-point pattern located just above the coccyx, evenly spaced on the midline of the sacrum.
johnson_indications: Acute or chronic lower back pain
techniques: This point can be bled. | Johnson: For the best treatment, use your fingers to stretch the skin in the sacral area to expose any visible veins in the area, and then bleed them. Cup over the puncture sites with small glass cups to draw the blood.
comments: Energetic pathways: In Tung’s body of work, the top treats the bottom, and the bottom treats the top. Therefore, bleeding DT.17 is a primary treatment for any excess in the head, including headache, dizziness, vomiting and high blood pressure.
reaction_areas: Reaction Area: Cerebellum (Note: 55.06 Upper Tumor shares this Reaction Area.)

name: Hou E Jiu (T VT.01)
location: 9 points total Point 1, or center point, is on the thyroid cartilage or over the Adam’s apple. Points 2 and 3 are 1.5 cun lateral to Point 1, one on each side. They overlap with Renying (ST 9) . Points 4, 5, 6 are 1 cun superior to Points 1, 2, 3. Points 7, 8, 9 are 1.5 cun inferior to Points 1, 2, 3. Two of the points are close to Shuitu (ST 10) .
techniques: Pinch the skin when bleeding these points to avoid unnecessary injury. | Johnson: Palpate the area of the throat that the patient is complaining about and find the thick or swollen tissue, and superficially bleed that location. •  Pinch up the skin to puncture it, thus avoiding any injury to the sinews or cartilage. •  It is necessary to squeeze and swipe, wearing gloves, as these points do not bleed on their own. I never cup the front of the neck.
comments: Nine Moths: Bleeding the throat is less painful than bleeding LU11 and LI1 because nerve endings are far apart on the neck but are very close together at the Jing-Well points. In the treatment of a severe sore throat, I have found local bleeding to be equally effective. Bleeding the ah-shi points found on the throat is primarily used for acute conditions and immediately relieves the pain.

name: Shi Er Hou, Twelve Monkeys (T VT.02)
location: 12 points total These points are arranged in 2 lines of 3 points inferior to the clavicle (6 points on each side). The first line is 1.3 cun inferior to the clavicle, and the second line is 2.8 cun inferior to the clavicle. The 3 points are 1.5 cun apart. 8 of the points are nearby or on Kufang (ST 14) , Wuyi (ST 15) , Shencang (KI 25) , Yuzhong (KI 26) . | Johnson: Twelve Monkeys consists of two parallel lines of three points each, found inferior to the clavicle (forming a rectangle of six points). The middle point of each line is found on the center line of the clavicle, and the other two points are found 1.5 cun lateral to the middle point. The top line of points is found 1.3 cun inferior to the clavicle. The bottom line of points is found 1.5 cun inferior to the top line. Note: Bilaterally, the two rectangles consist of six points each, adding up to 12 points; hence the name Twelve Monkeys.
primary_indications: Cholera 喉痧 "Monkey Sha" which is scarlet fever or the result of severe common cold or flu
cholera Asthma due to arteriosclerosis Food poisoning with abdominal pain but no vomiting Diarrhea
techniques: Pinch the skin while bleeding the points to avoid unnecessary harm. | Johnson: These points are bled. 531 Chest Points

name: Jin Wu, Gold Five (T VT.03)
location: 5 points total The first point is on the midline of the sternum, level with the 2 nd ICS and overlaps Zigong (CV 19) . Each subsequent point is 1 cun inferior to the previous one, totaling 5 points. | Johnson: Gold Five is a line of five points, 1.0 cun apart, located on the midline of the sternum. The first point is found in the depression between the manubrium and body of the sternum. The next four points are each found one cun inferior, respectively, measured from the point above it.
primary_indications: food poisoning with abdominal pain but no vomiting Hypochondriac pain
johnson_indications: Dry heaves from Liver fire rising
techniques: This point can be bled. | Johnson: These points are bled.

name: Wei Mao Qi, Stomach Hair Seven (T VT.04)
location: 7 points total Point 1 is just inferior to the tip of the xiphoid process and overlaps Zhongting (CV 16) . Point 2 is 1 cun below Point 1. Point 3 is 2 cun below Point 1. Points 4 and 5 are 1.5 cun lateral to Point 2, one on each side. Points 6 and 7 are 1.5 cun lateral to Point 3, one on each side. | Johnson: These seven points are located along three lines – the medial line, and two lines found lateral to the medial line of points. The medial line consists of three points: The first point is found just beneath the xiphoid process. The second point is found one cun inferior to the first point. The third point is found one cun inferior to the second point. The lateral line consists of two points on each side of the midline: The first points are found 1.5 cun lateral to the midline, at the level of the second point on the medial line. The second points are found 1.5 cun lateral to the midline, at the level of the third point on the medial line. Note: Together, the three midline points and the four points found lateral to them add up to seven points, hence the name Stomach Hair Seven.
primary_indications: cholera Palpitation 羊毛痧 "Goat's Hair Sha " with dizziness
back pain. This condition usually occurs in the summer when one is over-exhausted. It is called "goat's hair sha " because during the recovery stage of this condition
the skin produces something that resembles goat's hair. The removal of this "goat's hair" substance is necessary for complete recovery of this condition.
techniques: This point can be bled. | Johnson: These points are bled.

name: Fu Chao Er Shi San, Bowels Nest Twenty-Three (T VT.05)
location: 23 points total The first 7 points are on the CV channel. Points 1 and 2 are 1 cun and 2 cun superior to the umbilicus, overlapping Shuifen (CV 9) and Xiawan (CV 10) . Points 3-7 are all below the umbilicus, starting at 1 cun inferior. Each subsequent point is then 1 cun inferior to the previous one, totaling 5 points. They overlap with Yinjiao (CV 7) , Shimen (CV 5) , Guanyuan (CV 4) , Zhongji (CV 3) , Qugu (CV 2) . The second set of 8 points is 1 cun lateral to the CV channel (4 points on each side). Points 8 and 9 are leveled with the umbilicus. Points 10 and 11 are 1 cun superior to Points 8 and 9. Points 12 and 13 are 1 cun inferior to Points 8 and 9. Points 14 and 15 are 2 cun inferior to Points 8 and 9. The third set of 8 points is 2 cun lateral to the CV channel (4 points on each side). Points 16 and 17 are leveled with the umbilicus, overlapping Tianshu (ST 25) . Points 18 and 19 are 1 cun superior to Points 16 and 17, overlapping Huaroumen (ST 24) . Points 20 and 21 are 1 cun inferior to Points 16 and 17, overlapping Wailing (ST 26) . Points 22 and 23 are 2 cun inferior to Points 16 and 17, overlapping Daju (ST 27) . | Johnson: Bowels Nest Twenty-Three consists of 23 points arranged in a rectangular pattern on the abdomen. There is no point located at the navel, but the navel is used to find the other points. There are two points found directly superior to the navel, on the midline: The first point is found one cun superior to the navel. The second point is found one cun superior to the first point. There are five points found directly inferior to the navel, also on the midline: The first point is found one cun inferior to the navel. The remaining four points are each found (in order, respectively) one cun inferior to the previous point. There are two additional lines of four points, each found lateral to the midline: The first lateral line is found one cun lateral to the navel: The first point on this line is level with the navel. The second point is found one cun superior to the first point. The third and fourth points are found one cun and two cun inferior to the first point. The second lateral line is found two cun lateral to the navel: The first point on this line is level with the navel. The second point is found one cun superior to the first point. The third and fourth points are found one cun and two cun inferior to the first point. Note: Together, the seven midline points and the 16 points found lateral to them add up to 23 points, hence the name Bowels Nest Twenty-Three.
primary_indications: food poisoning with abdominal pain but no vomiting
techniques: This point can be bled. | Johnson: These points are bled.
